Term: 10-K: Definition, What's Included, Instructions, and Where to Find it
Definition: A 10-K is a comprehensive report filed annually by public companies about their financial performance./nThe report is required by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and is far more detailed than the annual report./nInformation in the 10-K includes corporate history, financial statements, earnings per share, and any other relevant data./nThe 10-K is a useful tool for investors to make important decisions about their investments.

Term: 10-K Wrap: What It Is, How It Works, Elements
Definition: A 10-K wrap is part of a larger annual performance document required by the SEC./nThe "wrap" is a short commentary covering the more personal side of the business, and usually includes a letter to the shareholders and a corporate vision statement./nThe 10-K wrap report is shorter than a company's annual report./nWhile a 10-K wrap (typically) has a lower-value production budget with limited graphics, its cover may be extremely polished by comparison./nThe basic sections of a 10-K wrap summarize the company's financial status, plus an overview of the company's financial plans for upcoming quarters./nUsually, a 10-K wrap provides debt and spending level forecasts, as well.

Term: 10-Year US Treasury Note: What It Is and Investment Advantages
Definition: Treasury notes (T-notes) have maturities of up to 10 years. These can be appropriate for long-term saving or investing./nYou don't necessarily have to hold 10-year T-notes for the entire duration. You can sell them at any time in the secondary market./nThe 10-year T-note is the most widely tracked government debt instrument in finance./nT-note prices typically move in the opposite direction from major stock market indexes.

Term: What Does 1%/10 Net 30 Mean in a Bill's Payment Terms?
Definition: A 1%/10 net 30 deal is when a 1% discount is offered for services or products as long as they are paid within 10 days of a 30-day payment agreement./nThe cost of credit is used as a percentage and occurs when the buyer does not take the reduced cost, thus paying the higher cost, reflecting the discount loss./nA vendor may offer incentives to pay early to accelerate the inflow of cash, which is especially important for businesses with no revolving lines of credit.

Term: 0x Protocol: What it Means, How it Works, Goals
Definition: The 0x protocol is an open protocol that enables the peer-to-peer exchange of assets on the Ethereum blockchain./n0x Labs, an organization focused on creating new markets in the 0x ecosystem, built the 0x protocol./nBuilt on the foundation of Ethereum token standards, 0x protocol acts as the critical infrastructure layer for the growing number of financial applications implementing the blockchain technology stack.

Term: SEC Form 10-Q: Definition, Deadlines for Filing, and Components
Definition: SEC Form 10-Q is a comprehensive quarterly report of financial performance submitted by all public companies to the SEC./nForm 10-Q contains financial statements, management discussion and analysis, disclosures, and internal controls for the previous quarter./nCompanies must file their 10-Qs 40 or 45 days after the end of their quarters, depending on the size of their public float./nA snapshot of a company's financial position, Form 10-Q provides investors with information they can compare to previous periods and use to evaluate the outlook for the stock's performance./nForm 10-Q is not an audited statement, unlike the annual Form 10-K that companies are also required to file.

Term: Form 1040-A: U.S. Individual Tax Return: Overview
Definition: Form 1040-A was a simplified version of Form 1040 used for filing individual income tax./nFilers using 1040-A were required to have less than $100,000 in taxable income and not have exercised any incentive stock options during the year./nThe IRS eliminated Form 1040-A for the 2018 tax year in favor of the redesigned Form 1040./nAnother variant of Form 1040 was Form 1040-EZ, which was even simpler than Form 1040-A and was also eliminated starting with the 2018 tax filing.

Term: 100% Equities Strategy: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A 100% equities strategy involves only long positions in stocks./nSuch a strategy is common among mutual funds that allocate all investable cash solely to stocks, forgoing higher-risk instruments such as derivatives or riskier strategies such as short selling./nWith 100% equity strategies, a portfolio's style can be further subdivided into capital appreciation, aggressive growth, growth, value, capitalization, and income, among others.

Term: What Was Form 1040EZ, and Why Is It No Longer Used?
Definition: Form 1040EZ was a shortened version of Form 1040 for taxpayers with basic tax situations./nThe form was discontinued as of the 2018 tax year and replaced with the redesigned Form 1040./nForm 1040EZ could only be used by people below age 65 with no dependents earning less than $100,000 per year./n1040EZ was about one-fifth as long as the full 1040 form, with fewer deductions and tax credits./nAnyone who hasn't filed taxes for 2017 or earlier can still use the 1040EZ form for that year.

Term: Form 1040: U.S. Individual Tax Return Definition, Types, and Use
Definition: Form 1040 is what individual taxpayers use to file their taxes with the IRS./nThe form determines if additional taxes are due or if the filer will receive a tax refund./nTaxpayers must include personal information on Form 1040, such as name, address, Social Security number, and the number of dependents./nA filer also needs to report wages, salary, taxable interest, capital gains, pensions, Social Security benefits, and other types of income./nTaxpayers may need to file supplemental tax 1040 forms depending on their situation.

Term: SEC Release IA-1092: What it is, History
Definition: SEC Release IA-1092 clarifies how state and federal securities laws apply to investment advisers and financial planners./nThis memo, which was issued in 1987, expands on the Investment Advisers Act of 1940./nIA-1092 defines the roles and duties of investment advisers and pension consultants, in particular.

Term: 125% Loan: What It is, History, Pros and Cons
Definition: A 125% loan is a mortgage equal to 1.25 times the value of the property securing the loan./nPopular in the 1990s, 125%, and similar loans became increasingly risky and unmanageable during the 2007–08 housing bubble./nDue to the risk involved for the lender, 125% loans carry significantly higher interest rates than traditional mortgages./nToday, 125% loans are less common but are still available from some lenders.

Term: 12b-1 Fund: What It Means and how It Works
Definition: A 12b-1 fund carries a 12b-1 fee, which covers a fund's sales and distribution costs./nThis fee is a percentage of the fund's market value, as opposed to funds that charge a load or sales fee./n12b-1 fees include the cost of marketing and selling fund shares, paying brokers and other sellers of the funds, as well as advertising costs, such as printing and mailing fund prospectuses to investors./nOnce popular, 12b-1 funds have lost investor interest in recent years, particularly amid the rise of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and low-cost mutual funds.

Term: 130-30 Strategy: What it is, How it Works
Definition: This investing strategy makes use of shorting stocks and putting the cash from shorting those shares to work buying and holding the best-ranked stocks for a designated period./nThese strategies tend to work well for limiting the drawdown that comes in investing./nThey do not appear to keep up with major averages in total returns but do have better risk-adjusted returns.

Term: 18-Hour City: What it Means, How it Works, Examples
Definition: Eighteen-hour cities are vibrant smaller metro areas that are proving attractive to new residents, entrepreneurs and investors./nThey boast lower living costs along with solid infrastructure and appealing amenities./nMany have emerged as alternatives to big cities for starting or relocating a business or investing in real estate.

Term: 183-Day Rule: Definition, How It's Used for Residency, and Example
Definition: The 183-day rule refers to criteria used in many countries to determine tax residency of individuals./nIn general, individuals are considered residents if they are physically present in a country for at least 183 days in a calendar year./nThe U.S. Internal Revenue Service uses a more complicated formula, which considers both presence in a given year, as well as a fraction of presence in the two prior years./nThe U.S. hastax treatieswith other countries which concern what taxes individuals owe and to whom, as well as what exemptions may apply./nU.S. citizens and residents may exclude up to $120,000 of their foreign-earned income in 2023 if they meet the physical presence test for and paid taxes in a foreign country.

Term: 1979 Energy Crisis: Definition, History, Causes, and Impact
Definition: The energy crisis of 1979 was one of two oil price shocks during the 1970s—the other was in 1973./nHigher prices and concerns about supplies led to panic buying in the gasoline market./nCrude oil prices nearly doubled to almost $40 per barrel in twelve months./nThe energy crisis of 1979 led to the development of smaller, more fuel-efficient vehicles./nOPEC's market share fell sharply and utility companies moved toward alternative energy sources.

Term: What is a 2-1 Buydown Loan and How do They Work
Definition: A 2-1 buydown is a type of financing that lowers the interest rate on a mortgage for the first two years before it rises to the regular, permanent rate./nThe rate is typically two percentage points lower during the first year and one percentage point lower in the second year./nSellers, including home builders, may offer a 2-1 buydown to make a property more attractive to buyers./n2-1 buydowns can be a good deal for homebuyers, provided that they will be able to afford the higher monthly payments once those begin.

Term: 2-2-8 Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (2/28 ARM): Meaning, How It Works
Definition: 2/28 adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs) offer an introductory fixed rate for two years, after which the interest rate adjusts semiannually for 28 more years./nWhen ARMs adjust, interest rates change based on their marginal rates and the indexes to which they’re tied./nHomeowners generally have lower mortgage payments during the introductory period, but are subject to interest rate risk afterward.

Term: 2011 U.S. Debt Ceiling Crisis: Meaning and Outcome
Definition: The 2011 U.S. Debt Ceiling Crisis was one of a series of recurrent debates over increasing the total size of the U.S. national debt./nIn 2008, the federal budget deficit stood at $458.6 billion, which widened to $1.4 trillion the following year as the government spent heavily to boost the economy./nCongress passed a law to resolve the crisis that increased the debt ceiling by $2.4 trillion./nAs a result of the crisis, the United States’ credit rating was reduced from AAA to AA+ by Standard & Poor’s./nThe 2011 debt ceiling crisis had implications for future debt ceiling discussions.

Term: 2000 Investor Limit: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: The 2,000 investor limit or rule is a key threshold for private businesses that do not wish to disclose financial information for public consumption./nA business with more than 2,000 distinct shareholders, totaling $10 million or more in capital, must file with the SEC even if it is a privately-held company./nCongress raised the limit from 500 individual investors to 2,000 investors in 2016 as part of the JOBS and FAST Acts.﻿﻿/nThe increased investor limit has opened greater possibility for equity crowdfunding.

Term: 25% Rule: What it Means, How it Works, Rules
Definition: The 25% rule can refer to either public finance or intellectual property law./nIn public finance, the 25% rule prescribes that a public entity’s total debt should not exceed one-quarter of its annual budget./nIn intellectual property, the 25% rule suggests the reasonable royalty that a license should pay an intellectual property holder on profits.

Term: 3-2-1 Buydown Mortgage: Meaning, Pros and Cons, FAQs
Definition: With a 3-2-1 buydown mortgage, the borrower pays a lower than normal interest rate over the first three years of the loan./nThe loan interest rate is reduced by 3% in the first year, 2% in the second year, and 1% in the third year; for example, a 5% mortgage would be just 2% in year one./nAfter the buydown period ends, the lender charges the full interest rate for the remainder of the mortgage term./nBuydowns are often used by sellers, including home builders, to help buyers afford a property.

Term: 3-6-3 Rule: Slang Term for How Banks Used to Operate
Definition: The 3-6-3 rule is a slang term from the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, which involved paying depositors 3% interest on account, lending money at 6% interest, and the ability to be playing golf by 3 p.m./nThe 3-6-3 rule describes the structure behind paying account holders a lower interest rate on deposits and changing a higher rate when loaning out the money/nThe net interest rate spread is the difference between the rates a bank pays customers and what it receives in income-generating activities/nThe government implemented tighter banking regulations after the Great Depression controlling the rate banks could lend money and reducing bank-to-bank competition/nLooser regulation after the 1970s allowed banks to operate in a more competitive and complex fashion and provide additional services to customers

Term: What Is 3C1 and How Is the Exemption Applied?
Definition: 3C1 refers to a portion of the Investment Company Act of 1940 that exempts certain private investment companies from regulations./nA firm that's defined as aninvestment companymust meet specific regulatory and reporting requirements stipulated by the SEC./n3C1 allows private funds with 100 or fewer investors and no plans for an initial public offering to sidestep certain SEC requirements.

Term: 3D Printing: What It Is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: Three-dimensional (3D) printing is an additive manufacturing process in which a physical object is created from a digital design by printing thin layers of material and then fusing them together./nSome industries, such as hearing aids manufacturers, airline manufacturers, and car manufacturers, use 3D printing to create prototypes and mass produce their products using custom scans./nWhile it is currently too slow to be used in mass production, 3D printing technology is still evolving and has the potential to massively disrupt both the manufacturing logistics and inventory management industries.

Term: 3/27 Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (ARM)
Definition: A 3/27 adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) is a 30-year mortgage with a three-year fixed interest rate period./nThe fixed interest rate is generally lower than the current rates on 30-year conventional mortgages./nAfter three years, and for the remaining 27 years of the loan, the interest rate will float based on an index, such as the yield on one-year U.S. Treasury bills./nBecause their monthly payments can rise significantly once the interest rate adjusts, borrowers should plan carefully before taking out a 3/27 ARM to make sure it will still be affordable.

Term: 3(c)(7) Exemption: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: The 3(c)(7) exemption refers to the Investment Company Act of 1940's section permitting qualifying private funds exemption from some SEC regulations./nPrivate funds must not plan to issue an IPO, and their investors must be qualified purchasers to qualify for the 3C7 exemption./n3C7 funds with over 1,999 investors are required to register with the SEC.

Term: 3P Oil Reserves: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: 3P oil reserves are the total amount of estimated reserves inclusive of all proven and unproven reserves that a company has access to./nEach category of reserve used in the calculation has a probability assigned to it in terms of the viability of recovering crude oil./nMost oil and gas companies provide rosy estimates of their 3P oil reserves; hence, investors rely on findings by independent consultants to assess their stock picks.

Term: 30-Year Treasury: Meaning, History, Examples
Definition: 30-year Treasuries are bonds issued by the U.S. government and have a maturity of 30 years./nOther securities issued by the U.S. government include Treasury bills, notes, and Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS)./n30-year Treasuries pay interest semiannually until they mature and at maturity pay the face value of the bond.

Term: 401(a) Plan: What It Is, Contribution Limits, Withdrawal Rules
Definition: A 401(a) plan is employer-sponsored, and both the employer and employee can contribute./n401(a) plans are usually used by government and non-profit organizations./n401(a) plans give the employer a larger share of control over how the plan is invested./nAn employee can withdraw funds from a 401(a) plan through a rollover to a different qualified retirement plan, a lump-sum payment, or an annuity./nInvestments in 401(a) plans are low risk and typically include government bonds and funds focused on value-based stocks.

Term: What Is a 403(b) Tax-Sheltered Annuity Plan?
Definition: The 403(b) Tax-Sheltered Annuity Plan serves employees of public schools and tax-exempt organizations./nContributions to 403(b) plans are made through payroll deductions./nThe IRS limits how much employees can contribute to their 403(b) plans./nInvestment choices may be more limited with a 403(b) and some accounts offer less protection from creditors than 401(k)s.

Term: 341 Meeting: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A 341 meeting is intended to establish the facts of the bankruptcy in question and to facilitate the negotiation of a repayment plan between the debtor and their creditors./nTo be considered legally valid, the meeting must include both the individual filing for bankruptcy and the court-appointed bankruptcy trustee./nGenerally, 341 meetings occur at the offices of the trustee, rather than in a courtroom.

Term: 408(k) Plan: What it is, How it Works, Compared to 401(k)
Definition: A 408(k) is an employer-sponsored retirement plan akin to a 401(k)./nThe plan is also referred to as a simplified employee pension, which is a type of individual retirement account./nThe 408(k) plan is available to companies of any size as well as self-employed individuals who are subject to the same contribution limits as employers./nOnly employer contributions are allowed into the 408(k) plan./nThe IRS limits how much employers can contribute to their employees' 408(k) plans.

Term: What Is a 401(k) and How Does It Work?
Definition: A 401(k) plan is a company-sponsored retirement account in which employees can contribute a percentage of their income. Employers often offer to match at least some of these contributions./nThere are two basic types of 401(k)s—traditional and Roth—which differ primarily in how they're taxed./nEmployer contributions can be made to both traditional and Roth 401(k) plans.

Term: 412(i) Plan: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A 412(i) plan was a defined-benefit pension plan that was designed for small business owners in the U.S./nA 412(i) was a tax-qualified benefit plan, meaning the owner's contributions to the plan became a tax deduction for the company./nGuaranteed annuities or a combination of annuities and life insurance were the only things that could fund the plan./nDue to tax avoidance schemes that were occurring under 412(i), the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) replaced it with 412(e)(3).

Term: 48-Hour Rule: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: The 48-hour rule refers to a part of the mortgage allocation process related to the buying and selling of to-be-announced (TBA) mortgage-backed securities (MBS)./nThe 48-hour rule stipulates that the seller of an MBS notifies the buyer with the details of the underlying mortgages that make up the MBS by 3 p.m. Eastern Time, 48 hours before the settlement date./nThe Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association (SIFMA) enforces the 48-hour rule./nWhen an MBS is traded in the secondary market, the underlying mortgages are not known, which helps facilitate trading and liquidity./nCertain information is agreed upon when an MBS trade is made, such as the price, par, and coupon, but not the underlying mortgages./nThe TBA market is the second most traded secondary market after the U.S. Treasury market.

Term: 500 Shareholder Threshold: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The 500 shareholder threshold was a rule mandated by the SEC that required companies to publicly disclose financial statements and other information if they achieved 500 or more distinct shareholders./nThe rule, in place from 1964-2012, was meant to discourage fraud, opacity, and misinformation alleged in the over-the-counter market./nToday, the shareholder threshold is now 2,000, largely in response to the rapid growth of investment in tech start-ups that caused the 500 limit to be reached too quickly.

Term: 5/1 Hybrid Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (5/1 Hybrid ARM) Examples
Definition: 5/1 hybrid adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs) offer an introductory fixed rate for five years, after which the interest rate adjusts annually./nWhen ARMs adjust, interest rates change based on their marginal rates and the indexes to which they’re tied./nHomeowners generally enjoy lower mortgage payments during the introductory period./nA fixed-rate mortgage may be preferable for homeowners who prefer predictability with their mortgage payments and interest costs.

Term: 5/6 Hybrid Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (ARM) Definition
Definition: A 5/6 hybrid ARM has an interest rate fixed for the first five years, then adjusts every six months./nThe adjustable interest rate on 5/6 hybrid ARMs is usually tied to a common benchmark index./nA risk associated with an adjustable interest rate is that a rising rate may make monthly payments unaffordable.

Term: 457 Plan
Definition: The 457 plan is an IRS-sanctioned, tax-advantaged employee retirement plan./nThe plan is offered only to public service employees and employees at tax-exempt organizations./nParticipants are allowed to contribute up to 100% of their salaries up to a dollar limit for the year./nThe interest and earnings in the account are not taxed until the funds are withdrawn. The exception is the Roth option, if available, in which only post-tax money is deposited.

Term: 501(c)(3) Organization: What It Is, Pros and Cons, Examples
Definition: Section 501(c)(3) is a portion of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code (IRC) and a specific tax category for nonprofit organizations./nOrganizations that meet the requirements of Section 501(c)(3) are exempt from federal income tax./nThe IRS recognizes more than 30 types of nonprofit organizations but only organizations that qualify for 501(c)(3) status can say that donations made to them are tax deductible./n501(c)(3) organizations must pay their employees fair market value wages./nThe nonprofit organization must not deviate from its purpose or mission to receive its favorable tax treatment.

Term: 501(c) Organization: What They Are, Types, and Examples
Definition: Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code designates certain types of organizations as tax-exempt—they pay no federal income tax./nCommon tax-exempt organizations include charities, government entities, advocacy groups, educational and artistic groups, and religious entities./nThe 501(c)(3) organization is probably the most familiar entity./nDonations to certain qualified tax-exempt organizations may be deductible from a taxpayer's income.

Term: 51% Attack: Definition, Who Is At Risk, Example, and Cost
Definition: Blockchains are distributed ledgers that record every transaction made on a cryptocurrency's network./nA 51% attack is an attack on a blockchain by an entity or group that controls more than 50% of the network./nAttackers with majority network control can interrupt the recording of new blocks by preventing other miners from completing blocks./nChanging historical blocks is impossible due to the chain of information stored in Bitcoin's blockchain./nAlthough a successful attack on Bitcoin or Ethereum is unlikely, smaller networks are frequent targets for 51% attacks.

Term: 52-Week Range: Overview, Examples, Strategies
Definition: The 52-week range is designated by the highest and lowest published price of a security over the previous year./nAnalysts use this range to understand volatility./nTechnical analysts use this range data, combined with trend observations, to get an idea of trading opportunities.

Term: 52-Week High/Low: Definition, Role in Trading, and Example
Definition: The 52-week high/low is the highest and lowest price at which a security has traded during the time period that equates to one year and is viewed as a technical indicator./nThe 52-week high/low is based on the daily closing price for the security./nTypically, the 52-week high represents a resistance level, while the 52-week low is a support level that traders can use to trigger trading decisions.

Term: 60-Plus Delinquencies: Meaning, Foreclosure, Example
Definition: The 60-plus delinquency rate is a metric typically used to measure the number of mortgage loans that are more than 60 days past due on their monthly payments./nA 60-plus delinquency rate is often expressed as a percentage of a group of loans that have been underwritten within a specified time period, such as one year./nThe 60-plus delinquency rate is helpful because it shows lenders the consumers who might default on their loans.

Term: 8-K (8K Form): Definition, What It Tells You, Filing Requirements
Definition: The SEC requires companies to file an 8-K to announce significant events relevant to shareholders./nCompanies have four business days to file an 8-K for most specified items./nPublic companies use Form 8-K as needed, unlike some other forms that must be filed annually or quarterly./nForm 8-K is a valuable source of complete and unfiltered information for investors and researchers.

Term: The 80-20 Rule (aka Pareto Principle): What It Is, How It Works
Definition: The 80-20 rule maintains that 80% of outcomes comes from 20% of causes./nThe 80-20 rule prioritizes the 20% of factors that will produce the best results./nA principle of the 80-20 rule is to identify an entity's best assets and use them efficiently to create maximum value./nThis rule is a precept, not a hard-and-fast mathematical law./nPeople sometimes mistakenly conclude that if 20% of factors should get priority, then the other 80% can be ignored.

Term: 80-10-10 Mortgage: Meaning, Benefits and Examples
Definition: An 80-10-10 mortgage is structured with two mortgages: the first being a fixed-rate loan at 80% of the home’s cost; the second being 10% as a home equity loan; and the remaining 10% as a cash down payment./nThis type of mortgage scheme reduces the down payment of a home without having to pay private mortgage insurance (PMI), helping borrowers obtain a home more easily with the up-front costs./nHowever, borrowers will face relatively larger monthly mortgage payments and may see higher payments due on the adjustable loan if interest rates increase.

Term: 83(b) Election: Tax Strategy and When and Why to File
Definition: The 83(b) election is a provision under the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) that gives an employee, or startup founder, the option to pay taxes on the total fair market value of restricted stock at the time of granting./nThe 83(b) election applies to equity that is subject to vesting./nThe 83(b) election alerts the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to tax the elector for the ownership at the time of granting, rather than at the time of stock vesting.

Term: 8(a) Firm: Meaning, Purpose, Qualifications
Definition: 8(a) firms are small businesses that are owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals./nThe (8)a Business Development Program is run and administered by the SBA, or Small Business Administration, with the goal of giving a leg up to specially selected small businesses./nThe 8(a) program helps aspiring entrepreneurs obtain government contracts and also includes mentoring, procurement assistance, training, financial assistance, management assistance, and technical assistance, among other benefits./nApplicants go through a rigorous application process for 8(a) status. 8 (a) status lasts up to nine years from when it is granted.

Term: 90/10 Investing Strategy: Definition, How It Works, Pros & Cons
Definition: The 90/10 strategy calls for allocating 90% of your investment capital to low-cost S&P 500 index funds and the remaining 10% to short-term government bonds./nWarren Buffett described the strategy in a 2013 letter to his company's shareholders./nA 90/10 investing strategy is very aggressive compared to other common asset allocation models and probably not for everyone.

Term: China A-Shares: Definition, History, Vs. B-Shares
Definition: China A-shares are the stock shares of mainland China-based companies that trade on the two Chinese stock exchanges, the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) and the Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE)./nHistorically, China A-shares were only available for purchase by mainland citizens due to China's restrictions on foreign investment./nChina A-shares are different from B-shares; A-shares are only quoted in RMB, while B-shares are quoted in foreign currencies, such as the U.S. dollar, and are more widely available to foreign investors.

Term: A-B Trust: Definition, How It Works, Tax Benefits
Definition: An A-B trust is a joint trust created by a married couple; upon one spouse's death, the trust splits into a survivor portion (the A trust) and a bypass portion (the decedent's trust, or B trust)./nVia the split, the A-B trust effectively minimizes estate taxes and defers them until after the death of the surviving spouse./nThe surviving spouse has limited control over the decedent's trust but the terms of the decedent's trust can be set to allow the surviving spouse to access the assets, and even draw income from them./nA-B trusts are no longer widely used as the estate tax exemption, which is now indexed to inflation, is sufficient for most estates.

Term: AAA: Definition as Credit Rating, Criteria, and Types of Bonds
Definition: The highest possible rating that a bond may achieve is AAA, which is only bestowed upon those bonds that exhibit the highest levels of creditworthiness./nThis AAA rating is used by Fitch Ratings and Standard & Poor’s, while Moody’s uses a similar Aaa lettering./nBonds that receive AAA ratings are viewed as the least likely to default./nIssuers of AAA-rated bonds generally have no trouble finding investors, although the yield offered on these bonds is lower than other tiers because of the high credit rating.

Term: AARP: Overview, Affiliates, Lobbying for Members Age 50+
Definition: AARP is a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization with a mission to empower retired people to choose how they live as they age./nAARP offers membership benefits including discounts, healthcare options, insurance products, travel-related services, education, and learning resources./nAARP has grown to be a powerful organization, with nearly 38 million active members and a strong lobbying presence in Washington and state capitals.

Term: Abenomics: Definition, History, and Shinzo Abe's Three Arrows
Definition: Abenomics is a set of economic policies championed by Japanese prime minister, Shinzo Abe, when he came into power a second time in 2012./nAbenomics was originally described as a three arrow approach of increasing the money supply, undertaking government spending to stimulate the economy, and undertaking economic and regulatory reforms to make Japan more competitive in the global market./nAbenomics has grown as prime minister Abe continues to govern Japan, and now encompasses goals for female employment, sustainable growth, and a concept known as Society 5.0 which is aimed at the further digitalization of Japan.

Term: Ability-to-Pay Taxation: Definition and Examples
Definition: The ability-to-pay principle holds that those who have a greater ability to pay taxes—measured by income and wealth—should pay more./nOne idea behind "ability to pay" is that those who have enjoyed success should be willing to give back a little more to the society that helped make that success possible./nProponents of ability-to-pay taxation argue that a single dollar ultimately means less to a rich person than a wage earner, so the rich should pay more to equalize their sacrifice.

Term: Abnormal Return: Definition, Causes, Example
Definition: An abnormal return is one that deviates from an investment's expected return./nThe presence of abnormal returns, which can be either positive or negative in direction, helps investors determine risk-adjusted performance./nAbnormal returns can be produced by chance, due to some external or unforeseen event, or as the result of bad actors./nA cumulative abnormal return (CAR) is the sum total of all abnormal returns and can be used to measure the effect lawsuits, buyouts, and other events have on stock prices.

Term: Absolute Return: Definition, Example, Vs. Relative Return
Definition: Absolute return is the return that an asset achieves over a certain period./nReturns can be positive or negative and may be considered unrelated to other market activities./nAbsolute return, unlike relative return, does not make any comparison against other possible investments or to a benchmark.

Term: Absolute Advantage: Definition, Benefits, and Example
Definition: Absolute advantage is when a producer can provide a good or service in greater quantity for the same cost, or the same quantity at a lower cost, than its competitors./nA concept developed by Adam Smith, absolute advantage can be the basis for large gains from trade between producers of different goods with different absolute advantages./nBy specialization, division of labor, and trade, producers with different absolute advantages can always gain more than producing and consuming in isolation./nAbsolute advantage can be contrasted with comparative advantage, which is the ability to produce goods and services at a lower opportunity cost.

Term: Absorption Costing Explained, With Pros and Cons and Example
Definition: Absorption costing differs from variable costing because it allocates fixed overhead costs to each unit of a product produced in the period./nAbsorption costing allocates fixed overhead costs to a product whether or not it was sold in the period./nThis type of costing method means that more cost is included in the ending inventory, which is carried over into the next period as an asset on the balance sheet./nBecause more expenses are included in ending inventory, expenses on the income statement are lower when using absorption costing.

Term: Accelerated Depreciation: What Is It, How to Calculate It
Definition: Accelerated depreciation is any depreciation method that allows for the recognition of higher depreciation expenses during the earlier years./nThe key accelerated depreciation methods include double-declining balance and sum of the years’ digits (SYD)./nAccelerated depreciation is unlike the straight-line depreciation method, where the latter spreads the depreciation expenses evenly over the life of the asset./nCompanies may use accelerated depreciation for tax purposes, as these methods result in a deferment of tax liabilities since income is lower in earlier periods.

Term: What Is Absorption Rate in Real Estate?
Definition: The absorption rate is commonly used in the real estate market to determine how many homes are sold at a particular time./nThe equation can determine how long it would take to sell the supply of homes on the market./nRealtors, appraisers, and lending institutions use absorption rates to understand market conditions and adjust terms accordingly.

Term: Accepting Risk: Definition, How It Works, and Alternatives
Definition: Accepting risk, or risk retention, is a conscious strategy of acknowledging the possibility for small or infrequent risks without taking steps to hedge, insure, or avoid those risks./nThe rationale behind risk acceptance is that the costs to mitigate or avoid risks are too great to justify given the small probabilities of a hazard, or the small estimated impact it may have./nSelf-insurance is a form of risk acceptance. Insurance, on the other hand, transfers risk to a third-party.

Term: Acceleration Clause: Explanation and Examples
Definition: An acceleration clause or covenant is a contract provision that allows a lender to require a borrower to repay all of an outstanding loan if specific requirements are not met./nThe acceleration clause clearly outlines the reasons that the lender can demand loan repayment and the repayment required, such as maintaining a certain credit rating./nAn acceleration clause helps to protect lenders who extend financing to businesses in need of capital.

Term: Acceptable Quality Level (AQL): Definition and How It Works
Definition: The acceptable quality level (AQL) is the worst quality level that is tolerable for a product./nThe AQL differs from product to product. Products that might cause more of a health risk will have a lower AQL./nBatches of products that do not meet the AQL, typically based on a percentage measurement, are rejected when tested during pre-shipment inspections.

Term: Accidental Death and Dismemberment (AD&D) Insurance
Definition: Accidental death and dismemberment (AD&D) insurance is usually added as a rider to a life insurance policy./nAD&D insurance pays benefits in the case of a person’s accidental death or dismemberment: the loss—or loss of use—of body parts or functions./nAD&D insurance usually comes with significant coverage limitations, so always read the fine print./nAD&D does not pay if the insured died due to natural causes, such as cancer or heart disease./nKnown as double indemnity, AD&D may pay a benefit equal to or a multiple of (usually 2x) the regular policy's face amount.

Term: What Is an Account Balance?
Definition: An account balance represents the current value of a financial account, such as a checking, savings, or investment account./nFinancial institutions provide account balances on paper statements and online./nFor investments in brokerage accounts, an account balance can change daily as security prices rise and fall in the market.

Term: Accidental Death Benefit: What It Is, Examples of What It Covers
Definition: An accidental death benefit is paid to the beneficiary of an accidental death insurance policy./nAccidental death benefit riders often end at a specific age, which is set by theinsurancecompany./nInsurance companies often have strict perimeters of what constitutes an accidental death./nAccidental death benefits are optionalriders, so they aren’t included in standard life insurance policies./nCertain jobs and workers in dangerous environments should consider an accidental death benefit rider.

Term: What Is a Bank Account Number?
Definition: A bank account number is a unique identifier of the owner of a bank account and permits access to it./nIn online banking, account numbers are vulnerable to fraud./nMulti-factor identification and other security measures work to protect bank account numbers, along with passwords./nYou can find your bank account number on the bottom of a paper check, just after the routing number.

Term: Account in Trust: Definition, Types, Benefits, How To Set One Up
Definition: Trust accounts are managed by a trustee on behalf of a third party./nParents often open trust accounts for minor children./nAn account in trust can include cash, stocks, bonds, and other types of assets./nTotten or Payable on Death (POD) trust accounts allow beneficiaries to claim the account's assets upon the death of the account holder./nAccount in Trust accounts generally avoid probate, making it easier and faster for the account to be settled.

Term: Account Statement: Definition, Uses, and Examples
Definition: An account statement is a periodic statement summarizing account activity over a set period of time./nAccount statements can be thought of as a summary of the account and include statements of services provided, fees charged, and money owed./nAccount statements should be scrutinized for accuracy, and historical statements are critical for budgeting./nAccount statements may often be received electronically, as distributors may charge fees for paper copies./nAccount statements usually contain a unique identifier, starting information, ending information, and transactions.

Term: Accountability: Definition, Types, Benefits, and Example
Definition: Accountability is the acceptance of responsibility for one's own actions and implies a willingness to be transparent./nFinancial accountability in the U.S. includes a requirement that public corporations make accurate financial records available to all stakeholders./nThere are various ways to be accountable in the workplace, including setting deadlines, delegating tasks, defining ownership, and rewarding success./nAccountability may help invoke confidence from external investors, loyalty from employees, and better company returns./nThere is an increased focus on other elements of corporate accountability such as ethical conduct, environmental impact, a commitment to diversity, and fair treatment of employees.

Term: Accountant Responsibility: Overview and Examples
Definition: Accountant responsibility is the ethical responsibility an accountant has to those who rely on their work./nAn accountant's responsibility may vary depending on the industry and type of accounting, auditing, or tax preparation being performed./nAll accountants must perform their duties following all applicable principles, standards, and laws.

Term: What Does an Accountant Do?
Definition: Accountants are employed by accounting firms or in the accounting departments of large companies. Many choose to open their own practices./nTheir roles include monitoring and recording expenses and income, and projecting the costs of proposed new projects./nTax preparation and tax planning are specialized roles for accountants./nMany accountants choose to become certified public accountants because the CPA designation is considered the gold standard in the accounting profession.

Term: Accounting Cycle Definition: Timing and How It Works
Definition: The accounting cycle is a process designed to make the financial accounting of business activities easier for business owners./nThe first step in the eight-step accounting cycle is to record transactions using journal entries./nThe eighth and final step is the closing of the books after preparing financial statements./nThe accounting cycle generally comprises a year or other accounting period./nAccounting software today mostly automates the accounting cycle.

Term: Accounting Conservatism: Definition, Advantages & Disadvantages
Definition: Accounting conservatism is a principle that requires company accounts to be prepared with caution and high degrees of verification./nAll probable losses are recorded when they are discovered, while gains can only be registered when they are fully realized./nIf an accountant has two solutions to choose from when facing an accounting challenge, the one that gives the least optimistic view of the situation should be selected.

Term: What Is the Accounting Equation, and How Do You Calculate It?
Definition: The accounting equation is considered to be the foundation of the double-entry accounting system./nThe accounting equation shows on a company’s balance sheet that a company’s total assets are equal to the sum of the company’s liabilities and shareholders’ equity./nAssets represent the valuable resources controlled by a company. The liabilities represent its obligations./nBoth liabilities and shareholders’ equity represent how the assets of a company are financed./nFinancing through debt shows as a liability, while financing through issuing equity shares appears in shareholders’ equity.

Term: What Are Accounting Policies and How Are They Used? With Examples
Definition: Accounting policies are procedures that a company uses to prepare financial statements./nUnlike accounting principles, which are rules, accounting policies are the standards for following those rules./nAccounting policies may be used to manipulate earnings legally./nA company's choice in accounting policies will indicate whether management is aggressive or conservative in reporting its earnings./nAccounting policies still need to adhere to generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).

Term: What Are Accounting Methods? Definition, Types, and Example
Definition: An accounting method consists of the rules and procedures a company follows in reporting its revenues and expenses./nThe two main accounting methods are cash accounting and accrual accounting./nCash accounting records revenues and expenses when they are received and paid./nAccrual accounting records revenues and expenses when they occur. Generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) requires accrual accounting./nThe Internal Revenue Services (IRS) requires accrual accounting for businesses making an average of $25 million or more in sales for the preceding three years./nOnce a company chooses an accounting method, it has to stick to that method per rules set by the IRS and requires approval if it wants to change its accounting method.

Term: Accounting Principles Explained: How They Work, GAAP, IFRS
Definition: Accounting standards are implemented to improve the quality of financial information reported by companies./nIn the United States, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issues generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP)./nGAAP is required for all publicly traded companies in the U.S.; it is also routinely implemented by non-publicly traded companies as well./nInternationally, the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) issues International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)./nThe FASB and the IASB sometimes work together to issue joint standards on hot-topic issues, but there is no intention for the U.S. to switch to IFRS in the foreseeable future.

Term: Accounting Profit: Definition, Calculation, Example
Definition: Accounting profit shows the amount of money left over after deducting the explicit costs of running the business./nExplicit costs include labor, inventory needed for production, and raw materials, together with transportation, production, and sales and marketing costs./nAccounting profit differs from economic profit as it only represents the monetary expenses a firm pays and the monetary revenue it receives./nAccounting profit also differs from underlying profit, which seeks to eliminate the impact of nonrecurring items.

Term: Accounting Rate of Return (ARR): Definition, How to Calculate, and Example
Definition: The accounting rate of return (ARR) formula is helpful in determining the annual percentage rate of return of a project./nARR is calculated as average annual profit / initial investment./nARR is commonly used when considering multiple projects, as it provides the expected rate of return from each project./nOne of the limitations of ARR is that it does not differentiate between investments that yield different cash flows over the lifetime of the project./nARR is different than the required rate of return (RRR), which is the minimum return an investor would accept for an investment or project that compensates them for a given level of risk.

Term: Accounting Ratio Definition and Different Types
Definition: Accounting ratios, an important sub-set of financial ratios, are a group of metrics used to measure the efficiency and profitability of a company based on its financial reports./nAn accounting ratio compares two line items in a company’s financial statements, namely made up of its income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement./nThese ratios can be used to evaluate a company’s fundamentals and provide information about the performance of the company over the last quarter or fiscal year./nCommon accounting ratios include the debt-to-equity ratio, the quick ratio, the dividend payout ratio, gross margin, and operating margin./nAccounting ratios are used by both the company itself to make improvements or monitor progress as well as by investors to determine the best investment option.

Term: What Is Accounting Theory in Financial Reporting?
Definition: Accounting theory provides a guide for effective accounting and financial reporting./nAccounting theory involves the assumptions and methodologies used in financial reporting, requiring a review of accounting practices and the regulatory framework./nThe Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issues generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) which aim to improve comparability and consistency in accounting information./nAccounting theory is a continuously evolving subject, and it must adapt to new ways of doing business, new technological standards, and gaps that are discovered in reporting mechanisms.

Term: Accounting Standard Definition: How It Works
Definition: An accounting standard is a set of practices and policies used to systematize bookkeeping and other accounting functions across firms and over time./nAccounting standards apply to the full breadth of an entity’s financial picture, including assets, liabilities, revenue, expenses, and shareholders' equity./nBanks, investors, and regulatory agencies count on accounting standards to ensure information about a given entity is relevant and accurate.

Term: Understanding Accounts Payable (AP) With Examples and How to Record AP
Definition: Accounts payable (AP) are amounts due to vendors or suppliers for goods or services received that have not yet been paid for./nThe sum of all outstanding amounts owed to vendors is shown as the accounts payable balance on the company's balance sheet./nThe increase or decrease in total AP from the prior period appears on the cash flow statement./nManagement may choose to pay its outstanding bills as close to their due dates as possible in order to improve cash flow.

Term: Accounts Payable Turnover Ratio Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: The accounts payable turnover ratio is a short-term liquidity measure used to quantify the rate at which a company pays off its suppliers./nAccounts payable turnover shows how many times a company pays off its accounts payable during a period./nIdeally, a company wants to generate enough revenue to pay off its accounts payable quickly, but not so quickly that the company misses out on opportunities because it could use that money to invest in other endeavors.

Term: Accounts Receivable (AR): Definition, Uses, and Examples
Definition: Accounts receivable (AR) is an asset account on the balance sheet that represents money due to a company in the short term./nAccounts receivable is created when a company lets a buyer purchase their goods or services on credit./nAccounts payable is similar to accounts receivable, but instead of money to be received, it is money owed./nThe strength of a company’s AR can be analyzed with the accounts receivable turnover ratio or days sales outstanding./nA turnover ratio analysis can be completed to expect when the AR will be received.

Term: Accounts Receivable Aging: Definition, Calculation, and Benefits
Definition: Accounts receivable aging is the process of distinguishing open accounts receivables based on the length of time an invoice has been outstanding./nAccounts receivable aging is useful in determining the allowance for doubtful accounts./nThe aged receivables report tabulates those invoices owed by length, often in 30-day segments, for quick reference./nAccounts receivable aging is used to estimate the value of receivables that the company does not expect to collect./nThis information is used to adjust the company's financial statements to avoid overstating its income.

Term: What Is Accounts Receivable Financing? Definition and Structuring
Definition: Accounts receivable financing provides financing capital in relation to a portion of a company’s accounts receivable./nAccounts receivable financing deals are usually structured as either asset sales or loans./nMany accounts receivable financing companies link directly with a company’s accounts receivable records to provide fast and easy capital for accounts receivable balances.

Term: Accredited In Business Valuation (ABV): Requirements, Exam
Definition: Accredited in Business Valuation (ABV) is a professional designation awarded to certified public accounts specializing in business valuation./nABV professionals must complete 60 hours of continuing professional education every three years to keep their designation./nCPAs seeking an ABV certification must meet educational and professional metrics before they are eligible for the designation.

Term: Accredited Asset Management Specialist (AAMS): Definition Vs. CFP
Definition: The Accredited Asset Management Specialist (AAMS) professional designation is recognized as an industry benchmark for asset management credentials and is endorsed by the top financial firms./nTo earn the AAMS, financial professionals must complete a rigorous self-study program, pass an exam, and agree to comply with a code of ethics./nTo maintain the designation, AAMS holders must complete 16 hours of continuing education every two years and pay a $95 renewal fee.

Term: Accredited Investor Defined: Understand the Requirements
Definition: Accredited investors are defined by the SEC as qualified to invest in complex or sophisticated types of securities that are not closely regulated./nCertain criteria must be met, such as having an average yearly income over $200,000 ($300,000 with a spouse or domestic partner) or working in the financial industry./nSellers of unregistered securities are allowed to sell only to accredited investors, who are deemed able to bear the risks./nUnregistered securities are inherently riskier because they lack the normal disclosure requirements that come with SEC registration.

Term: Accretion: Definition in Finance and Accounting
Definition: Accretion refers to the gradual and incremental growth of assets./nIn finance, accretion is also the accumulation of additional income an investor expects to receive after purchasing a bond at a discount and holding until maturity./nThe accretion rate is determined by dividing a bond's discount by the number of years in its term to maturity.

Term: Accretion of Discount: Meaning, Calculation
Definition: The accretion of discount is a reference to the increase in the value of a discounted security as its date of maturity closes in./nIt's an accounting process used to adjust the value of a financial instrument that has been bought at a discounted rate./nWhile a bond can be bought at par, at a premium, or at a discount, its value is at par at the time of maturity./nA bond purchased at a discount will slowly increase in value until it reaches par value at maturity; this process is the accretion of discount.

Term: What Are Accruals? How Accrual Accounting Works, With Examples
Definition: Accruals are needed for any revenue earned or expense incurred, for which cash has not yet been exchanged./nAccruals improve the quality of information on financial statements by adding useful information about short-term credit extended to customers and upcoming liabilities owed to lenders./nAccruals and deferrals are the basis of the accrual method of accounting./nThis is the preferred method of accounting according to GAAP./nAccruals are created by adjusting journal entries at the end of each accounting period.

Term: Accrue: Definition, How It Works, and 2 Main Types of Accruals
Definition: Accrue is the accumulation of interest, income, or expenses over time—interest in a savings account is a popular example./nWhen something financial accrues, it essentially builds up to be paid or received in a future period./nAccrue most often refers to the concepts of accrual accounting, where there are accrued revenue sand accrued expenses./nAccrued revenue is when a company has sold a product or service but has yet to be paid for it./nAccrued expenses are expenses that are recognized before being paid, such as certain interest expenses or salaries.

Term: What Is Accrual Accounting, and How Does It Work?
Definition: Accrual accounting is an accounting method where revenue or expenses are recorded when a transaction occurs vs. when payment is received or made./nThe method follows the matching principle, which says that revenues and expenses should be recognized in the same period./nAccrual accounting uses the double-entry accounting method./nAccrual accounting is required for companies with average revenues of $25 million or more over three years./nCash accounting is the other accounting method, which recognizes transactions only when payment is exchanged.

Term: Accrued Expenses: Definition, Examples, and Pros and Cons
Definition: Accrued expenses are recognized on the books when they are incurred, not when they are paid./nAccrual accounting requires more journal entries than simple cash basis accounting./nAccrual accounting provides a more accurate financial picture than cash basis accounting./nLarge, public companies with shares on stock market exchanges are often required to comply with accrual-based accounting as opposed to the cash method of accounting./nAccruals are recognition of events that have already happened but cash has not yet settled, while prepayments are recognition of events that have not yet happened but cash has settled.

Term: Accrued Income: Money Earned But Not Yet Received
Definition: Accrued income is revenue that's been earned, but has yet to be received./nBoth individuals and companies can receive accrued income./nAlthough it is not yet in hand, accrued income is recorded on the books when it is earned, in accordance with the accrual accounting method.

Term: Accrued Liabilities: Overview, Types, and Examples
Definition: An accrued liability occurs when a business has incurred an expense but has not yet paid it out./nAccrued liabilities arise due to events that occur during the normal course of business./nThese liabilities or expenses only exist when using an accrual method of accounting./nAccounting for accrued liabilities requires a debit to an expense account and a credit to the accrued liability account, which is then reversed upon payment with a credit to the cash or expense account and a debit to the accrued liability account./nExamples of accrued liabilities can include payroll and payroll taxes.

Term: Accrued Interest Definition & Example
Definition: Accrued interest is a feature of accrual accounting, and it follows the guidelines of the revenue recognition and matching principles of accounting./nAccrued interest is booked at the end of an accounting period as an adjusting journal entry, which reverses the first day of the following period./nThe amount of accrued interest to be recorded is the accumulated interest that has yet to be paid as of the end date of an accounting period.

Term: Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income: Definition and Types
Definition: Accumulated other comprehensive income (OCI) includes unrealized gains and losses that are reported in the equity section of the balance sheet./nAn unrealized gain or loss occurs when an investment, pension plan, or hedging transaction has appreciated or depreciated in fair value, but a sale transaction has not yet occurred for the gain or loss to be realized./nAccumulated other comprehensive income is displayed on the balance sheet in some instances to alert financial statement users to a potential for a realized gain or loss on the income statement down the road.

Term: Accrued Revenue: Definition, Examples, and How To Record It
Definition: Accrued revenue is used in accrual accounting where revenue is recorded at the time of sale, even if payment is not yet received./nThis follows the revenue recognition principle, which requires that revenue be recorded in the period in which it is earned./nAccrued revenue is recorded with an adjusting journal entry that recognizes items that would otherwise not appear in the financial statements at the end of the period./nIt is commonly used in the service industry, where contracts for services may extend across many accounting periods.

Term: Accumulated Depreciation: Everything You Need to Know
Definition: Accumulated depreciation is the sum of all recorded depreciation on an asset to a specific date./nDepreciation is recorded to tie the cost of using a long-term capital asset with the benefit gained from its use over time./nAccumulated depreciation is presented on the balance sheet below the related capital asset line./nAccumulated depreciation is recorded as a contra asset with a natural credit balance instead of asset accounts with natural debit balances./nThe carrying value of an asset is its historical cost minus accumulated depreciation.

Term: Accumulation Phase: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: Accumulation phase refers to the period in a person's life in which they are saving for retirement./nThe accumulation happens ahead of the distribution phase when they are retired and spending the money./nAccumulation phase also refers to a period when an annuity investor is beginning to build up the cash value of the annuity. (The annuitization phase, when payments are dispersed, follows the accumulation period.)/nThe length of the accumulation phase will vary based on when an individual begins saving and when the person plans to retire.

Term: Accumulation/Distribution Indicator (A/D): What it Tells You
Definition: The accumulation/distribution (A/D) line gauges supply and demand of an asset or security by looking at where the price closed within the period’s range and then multiplying that by volume./nThe A/D indicator is cumulative, meaning one period’s value is added or subtracted from the last./nIn general, a rising A/D line helps confirm a rising price trend, while a falling A/D line helps confirm a price downtrend.

Term: Acquisition Accounting: Definition, How It Works, Requirements
Definition: Acquisition accounting is a set of formal guidelines describing how assets, liabilities, non-controlling interest and goodwill of an acquired company must be reported by the purchaser./nThe fair market value of the acquired company is allocated between the net tangibleand intangible assets portion of the balance sheet of the buyer. Any resulting difference is regarded as goodwill./nAll business combinations must be treated as acquisitions for accounting purposes.

Term: Acid-Test Ratio: Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The acid-test, or quick ratio, compares a company's most short-term assets to its most short-term liabilities to see if it has enough cash to pay its immediate liabilities, such as short-term debt./nThe acid-test ratio disregards current assets that are difficult to liquidate quickly, such as inventory./nThe acid-test ratio may not give a reliable picture of a firm's financial condition if the company has accounts receivable that take longer than usual to collect or current liabilities that are due but have no immediate payment needed.

Term: Acquisition: Meaning, Types, and Examples
Definition: An acquisition is a business combination that occurs when one company buys most or all of another company’s shares./nA firm effectively gains control of that company if it buys more than 50% of a target company’s shares./nAn acquisition is often friendly, but a takeover can be hostile. A merger creates a brand-new entity from two separate companies./nAcquisitions are often carried out with the help of an investment bank because they’re complex arrangements with legal and tax ramifications./nAcquisitions are closely related to mergers and takeovers.

Term: What Is an Acquisition Cost in Business Accounting?
Definition: Acquisition cost refers to an amount paid for fixed assets, for expenses related to the acquisition of a new customer, or for the takeover of a competitor./nIt is useful in identifying the full cost of fixed assets because it includes items such as legal fees and commissions and removes discounts and closing costs./nAcquisition costs are also useful to determine the full expense incurred in enticing new customers, and it can be used to compare to the revenue new customers generate.

Term: Acquisition Premium: Difference Between Real Value and Price Paid
Activist Investor: Definition, Role, Biggest Player
Definition: Activist investors buy minority stakes in public companies to change how they are run./nIf they fail to persuade company managers, they may wage a proxy fight for board seats./nSome hedge funds specialize in activist investing while institutional investors may engage in it from time to time./nInvestor activism may focus on maximizing shareholder value or on the company's social responsibilities./nThe SEC has proposed tougher disclosure rules for activist investors that critics contend may make activism unprofitable.

Term: Active Management Definition, Investment Strategies, Pros & Cons
Definition: Active management involves making buy and sell decisions about the holdings in a portfolio./nPassive management is a strategy that aims to equal the returns of an index./nActive management seeks returns that exceed the performance of the overall markets, to manage risk, increase income, or achieve other investor goals, such as implementing a sustainable investment approach.

Term: What Is Activity-Based Budgeting (ABB)? How It Works and Example
Definition: Activity-based budgeting (ABB) is a method of budgeting where activities that incur costs are recorded, analyzed and researched./nIt is more rigorous than traditional budgeting processes, which tend to merely adjust previous budgets to account for inflation or business development./nUsing activity-based budgeting (ABB) can help companies to reduce costs and, as a result, squeeze more profits from sales./nThis method is particularly useful for newer companies and firms undergoing material changes.

Term: Activity-Based Costing (ABC): Method and Advantages Defined with Example
Definition: Activity-based costing (ABC) is a method of assigning overhead and indirect costs—such as salaries and utilities—to products and services./nThe ABC system of cost accounting is based on activities, which are considered any event, unit of work, or task with a specific goal./nAn activity is acost driver, such as purchase orders or machine setups./nThe cost driver rate, which is the cost pool total divided by cost driver, is used to calculate the amount of overhead and indirect costs related to a particular activity.

Term: Activity-Based Management (ABM) Definition and Examples
Activity Ratios: Definition, Formula, Uses, and Types
Definition: An activity ratio broadly describes any type of financial metric that helps investors and research analysts gauge how efficiently a company uses its assets to generate revenues and cash./nActivity ratios may be utilized to compare two different businesses within the same sector, or they may be used to monitor a single company's fiscal health over time./nActivity ratios can be subdivided into merchandise inventory turnover ratios, total assets turnover ratios, return on equity measurements, and a spectrum of other metrics.

Term: Activity Cost Driver: Definition and Examples
Definition: An activity cost driver is an action that triggers higher or lower variable costs for a business./nActivity cost drivers give a more accurate determination of the true cost of business activity by considering the indirect expenses./nKeeping tabs on these fluctuating costs can help boost efficiency and company profits./nActivity cost drivers are used in activity-based costing (ABC) inmanagerial accounting.

Term: Actuarial Life Table: What it is, How it Works, FAQs
Definition: The statistics in an actuarial life table calculate the probability of surviving a particular year of age, among other things./nInsurance companies use actuarial life tables in their work./nThese tables may be called different names like a mortality table, actuarial or life table./nActuarial science uses primarily two types of life tables.

Term: What Is an Actuarial Gain Or Loss? Definition and How It Works
Definition: Actuarial gains and losses are created when the assumptions underlying a company's projected benefit obligation change./nAccounting rules require companies to disclose both the pension obligations (liabilities) and the assets meant to cover them. This shows investors the overall health of the pension fund.﻿﻿/nAll defined benefits pension plans will see periodic actuarial gains or losses as key demographic assumptions or key economic assumptions making up the model are updated.

Term: What Is Actuarial Science? Definition and Examples of Application
Definition: Actuarial science assesses financial risks in the insurance and finance fields, using mathematical and statistical methods./nActuarial science applies probability analysis and statistics to define, analyze, and solve the financial impact of uncertain future events./nActuarial science helps insurance companies forecast the probability of an event occurring to determine the funds needed to pay claims./nThe Casualty Actuarial Society (CAS) and Society of Actuaries (SOA) promote several professional certifications for actuaries to pursue beyond a bachelor's degree in actuarial science./nThe most recent salary information from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows actuaries earned an average salary of nearly $113,990 as of May 2022.

Term: Ad Valorem Tax: Definition and How It's Determined
Definition: An ad valorem tax is a tax based on the assessed value of an item, such as real estate or personal property./nThe most common ad valorem taxes are property taxes levied on real estate./nThe Latin phrasead valoremmeans "according to value." So all ad valorem taxes are based on the assessed value of the item being taxed./nProperty ad valorem taxes (property taxes) are usually levied by local jurisdictions, such as counties or school districts./nAd valorem taxes are generally levied on both real property (land, buildings and other structures) and major personal property, such as a car or boat.

Term: Add-On Interest Definition, Formula, Cost vs. Simple Interest
Definition: Most loans are simple interest loans, where the interest is based on the amount owed on the remaining principal after each monthly payment is made./nAdd-on interest loans combine principal and interest into one amount owed, to be paid off in equal installments./nThe result is a substantially higher cost to the borrower./nAdd-on interest loans are typically used with short-term installment loans and for loans made to subprime borrowers.

Term: Addition Rule for Probabilities Formula and What It Tells You
Definition: The addition rule for probabilities consists of two rules or formulas, with one that accommodates two mutually-exclusive events and another that accommodates two non-mutually exclusive events./nNon-mutually-exclusive means that some overlap exists between the two events in question and the formula compensates for this by subtracting the probability of the overlap, P(Y and Z), from the sum of the probabilities of Y and Z./nIn theory the first form of the rule is a special case of the second form.

Term: Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC): Definition and Who Qualifies
Definition: The Additional Child Tax Credit is the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit./nIt is claimed by families who owe the IRS less than their qualified Child Tax Credit amount./nFor 2023, the Additional Child Tax Credit will refund eligible taxpayers up to $1,600. For 2024, it's $1,700./nTo determine whether you're eligible for the Additional Child Tax Credit, you can fill out Schedule 8812 along with your Form 1040.

Term: Additional Paid-in Capital: What It Is, Formula, and Examples
Definition: Additional paid-in capital (APIC) is the difference between the par value of a stock and the price that investors actually pay for it./nTo be the "additional" part of paid-in capital, an investor must buy the stock directly from the company during its IPO./nThe APIC is usually booked as shareholders' equity on the balance sheet./nHowever, the cash generated from the sale of stock (both the par value and APIC) is recorded in the asset section of the balance sheet./nAPIC is a great way for companies to generate cash without having to give any collateral in return.

Term: Adhesion Contract: Definition, History, and Enforceability
Definition: Adhesion contracts are "take it or leave it" agreements where you must accept the contract or walk away./nAdhesion contracts are meant to simplify business transactions by standardizing the agreement between the supplier and the buyer./nTo be enforceable, adhesion contracts cannot be unreasonably one-sided./nCourts ultimately decide what is reasonable within an adhesion contract./nThe legal view of such contracts has evolved over time and may differ across jurisdictions.

Term: What Is Adjudication? Definition, How It Works, Types, and Example
Definition: Adjudication is the process by which a court judge resolves issues between two parties./nAdjudication hearings are similar to the arbitration hearing process./nGenerally, adjudication hearings involve money or nonviolent infractions that result in a distribution of rights and obligations for all parties involved.

Term: Adjustable Life Insurance: Definition, Pros & Cons, vs. Universal
Definition: Adjustable life insurance allows you to make changes to the cash value, premiums, and death benefit./nIt gives you the flexibility to adjust your insurance coverage based on shifting life events./nAdjustable life insurance includes a savings component known as cash value./nAs the cash value grows, you may borrow from it or use it to pay your premiums./nThe cash value account often earns interest but the gains are typically modest.

Term: Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (ARM): What It Is and Different Types
Definition: An adjustable-rate mortgage is a home loan with an interest rate that can fluctuate periodically based on the performance of a specific benchmark./nARMS are also called variable rate or floating mortgages./nARMs generally have caps that limit how much the interest rate and/or payments can rise per year or over the lifetime of the loan./nAn ARM can be a smart financial choice for homebuyers who are planning to keep the loan for a limited period of time and can afford any potential increases in their interest rate.

Term: Adjusted Closing Price: How It Works, Types, Pros & Cons
Definition: The adjusted closing price amends a stock's closing price to reflect that stock's value after accounting for any corporate actions./nThe closing price is the raw price, which is just the cash value of the last transacted price before the market closes./nThe adjusted closing price factors in corporate actions, such as stock splits, dividends, and rights offerings./nThe adjusted closing price can obscure the impact of key nominal prices and stock splits on prices in the short term.

Term: Adjusted Funds From Operations (AFFO): Definition and Calculation
Definition: Adjusted funds from operations (AFFO) is a financial measure used to estimate the value of a real estate investment trust (REIT)./nAFFO is based on funds from operations (FFO), but is considered preferable, because it takes costs into consideration, thus more accurately estimating the REIT's present values and ability to pay dividends./nThough no one official measure exists, an AFFO formula is along the lines of AFFO = FFO + rent increases - capital expenditures - routine maintenance amounts.

Term: Adjusted EBITDA: Definition, Formula and How to Calculate
Definition: The adjusted EBITDA measurement removes non-recurring, irregular and one-time items that may distort EBITDA./nAdjusted EBITDA provides valuation analysts with a normalized metric to make comparisons more meaningful across a variety of companies in the same industry./nPublic companies report standard EBITDA in financial statement filings as Adjusted EBITDA is not required in GAAP financial statements.

Term: What Is Adjusted Gross Income (AGI)?
Definition: The IRS uses your adjusted gross income (AGI) to determine how much income tax you owe for the year./nYour AGI is calculated by subtracting certain adjustments to income from your total income for the year (your gross income)./nYour AGI can affect the size of your tax deductions as well as your eligibility for some types of retirement plan contributions, such as a Roth individual retirement account (Roth IRA)./nModified adjusted gross income (MAGI) is your AGI with some otherwise allowable deductions added back in. For many people, AGI and MAGI will be the same./nAmong the items subtracted from your gross income when calculating your AGI are educator expenses and contributions to retirement plans.

Term: Adjusting Journal Entry Definition: Purpose, Types, and Example
Definition: Adjusting journal entries are used to record transactions that have occurred but have not yet been appropriately recorded in accordance with the accrual method of accounting./nAdjusting journal entries are recorded in a company's general ledger at the end of an accounting period to abide by the matching and revenue recognition principles./nThe most common types of adjusting journal entries are accruals, deferrals, and estimates./nIt is used for accrual accounting purposes when one accounting period transitions to the next./nCompanies that use cash accounting do not need to make adjusting journal entries.

Term: What Are Administrative Expenses and What Are Some Examples?
Definition: Administrative expenses are costs incurred to support the functioning of a business but that aren't directly related to the production of a specific product or service./nSome level of administrative expenses will always be incurred as a necessary part of operations./nAdministrative expenses are often among the first identified for budget cuts because they don't directly impact a company's main business functions./nManagement may allocate administrative expenses to its business units based on a percentage of revenue, expenses, or other measures.

Term: Adjusted Present Value (APV): Overview, Formula, and Example
Definition: APV is the NPV of a project or company if financed solely by equity plus the present value of financing benefits./nAPV shows an investor the benefit of tax shields from tax-deductible interest payments./nIt is best used for leverage transactions, such as leveraged buyouts, but is more of an academic calculation.

Term: Advance/Decline (A/D) Line: Definition and What It Tells You
Definition: The advance/decline (A/D) line is abreadth indicatorused to show how many stocks are participating in a stock market rally or decline./nWhenmajor indexesare rallying, a rising A/D line confirms the uptrend showing strong participation./nIf major indexes are rallying and the A/D line is falling, it shows that fewer stocks are participating in the rally which means the index could be nearing the end of its rally./nWhen major indexes are declining, a falling advance/decline line confirms the downtrend./nIf major indexes are declining and the A/D line is rising, fewer stocks are declining over time, which means the index may be near the end of its decline.

Term: Administrative Services Only (ASO): Definition, Pros & Cons
