Definition: A bear trap is a false technical indication of a reversal from a down-trending market to an up-trending one that can trap unsuspecting shorts./nBear traps can occur in all asset markets, including equities, futures, bonds, and currencies./nIt's difficult to tell if the downward correction will continue or become a bear trap./nThey are another reason to proceed with caution about your position sizes if what feels like steady ground is a ruse that traps you in a bad position.

Term: Bearer Share: Definition, Example, Risks, and Benefits
Definition: Bearer shares are unregistered equity securities owned by the possessor of the physical share documents. The issuing company pays out dividends to owners of the physical coupons./nWhile bearer shares were often used internationally in Europe, South America, and other regions, many large corporations no longer use them and have transitioned to using registered shares./nThe use of bearer shares has dwindled worldwide because they incur increased costs and are convenient instruments to secure funding for terrorism and other criminal activities.

Term: Bearer Bond: Definition, How It Works, and Why They're Valuable
Definition: A bearer bond is a physical certificate with coupons attached that are used to redeem the interest payments./nAs their ownership is not registered, the owner of a bearer bond is the person in possession of it./nDue to the lack of registration, bearer bonds are as vulnerable as cash to theft or loss./nThe U.S. started using bearer bonds after the Civil War but discontinued them in 1982./nIndividuals who still hold government bearer bonds can claim them through TreasuryDirect. Those that own corporate bearer bonds, most likely will not be able to redeem their value.

Term: Bearish Engulfing Pattern: Definition and Example of How To Use
Definition: A candle chart is a visual representation of price moves over time, using rectangular “candles” (with wicks out the top and bottom) to show opening, closing, high, and low prices./nThe candle body, which represents the difference between the opening and closing price, is what matters for this pattern, not the changes in the “wicks.” The body of the down candle must engulf the up candle: the high must be higher and the low must be lower than the previous one./nA bearish engulfing pattern can occur anytime, but it is more significant if it occurs after a price advance. This could mark the end of the uptrend or a pullback from an upswing to a more significant downtrend./nIdeally, both candles are of decent size relative to the price bars around them. Two very small bars may create an engulfing pattern, but it is far less significant than if both candles are large, showing more volatility./nThe pattern has less significance in choppy sideways markets when there’s volatility but no clear trends have emerged.

Term: What Is Behavioral Economics? Theories, Goals, and Applications
Definition: Behavioral economics is the study of psychology that analyzes the economic decisions people make./nFactors that affect behavior include bounded rationality, choice architecture, cognitive biases, discrimination, and herd mentality./nBehavior economics is crafted around many principles including framing, heuristics, loss aversion, and the sunk-cost fallacy./nCompanies use information from behavioral economics to price their goods, craft their commercials, and package their products.

Term: Bell Curve Definition: Normal Distribution Meaning Example in Finance
Definition: A bell curve is a graph depicting the normal distribution, which has a shape reminiscent of a bell./nThe top of the curve shows the mean, mode, and median of the data collected./nIts standard deviation depicts the bell curve's relative width around the mean./nBell curves (normal distributions) are used commonly in statistics, including in analyzing economic and financial data.

Term: Below-the-Line Advertising: Definition and Use in Marketing
Definition: Below-the-line advertising is an advertising strategy where products are promoted in media other than mainstream radio or television./nBelow-the-line advertising campaigns include direct mail campaigns, trade shows, catalogs, and targeted search engine marketing./nAbove-the-line methods are ideal for general brand awareness, while below-the-line tactics are preferable for fostering direct relationships with potential customers.

Term: Who Is Ben Bernanke? Why Is He Important?
Definition: Ben Bernanke is a former Federal Reserve chair, serving from 2006 to 2014./nAs Fed chair, Bernanke oversaw the central bank's response to the 2008 financial crisis and the Great Recession./nBernanke succeeded Alan Greenspan and was replaced by Janet Yellen./nBernake introduced several strategies, including quantitative easing, to boost the U.S. economy during the 2008 recession./nCritics argue that Bernake flooded the economy with too much money, contributing to inflation and increased debt.

Term: Benchmarks: Definition, Types, and How to Use Them in Investing
Definition: A benchmark is a standard with which to measure performance./nIn investing, benchmarks are generally indexes of investment instruments against which portfolio performance is evaluated./nDepending on the particular investment strategy or mandate, the benchmark will differ./nThere are benchmarks for every type of investment and strategy.

Term: What Is a Beneficiary? How They Work, Types, and Examples
Definition: A beneficiary is an individual who receives a benefit that's typically a monetary distribution./nDistributions can have tax consequences./nBeneficiaries who inherit a retirement account may have various options for the distribution of its funds./nOptions for distributions frominherited IRAsdepend on whether the beneficiary is an eligible designated beneficiary or a designated beneficiary./nYou can change the beneficiaries of financial accounts at any time, though doing so requires completing and returning the relevant paperwork.

Term: Beneficial Ownership Meaning and Regulation
Definition: A beneficial owner is a person who enjoys the benefits of ownership though the property's title is in another name./nBeneficial ownership is distinguished from legal ownership, though in most cases, the legal and beneficial owners are one and the same./nPublicly traded securities are often registered in the name of a broker for safety and convenience./nWealthy individuals often list their assets under trust while they remain the beneficial owner.

Term: Benefit-Cost Ratio (BCR): Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The benefit-cost ratio (BCR) is an indicator showing the relationship between the relative costs and benefits of a proposed project, expressed in monetary or qualitative terms./nIf a project has a BCR greater than 1.0, the project is expected to deliver a positive net present value to a firm and its investors./nIf a project’s BCR is less than 1.0, the project’s costs outweigh the benefits, and it should not be considered.

Term: BHD (Berhad): Definition, What It Indicates and Example Companies
Definition: Berhad (BHD) is a suffix used in Malaysia to identify a public limited company. The suffix Sendirian Berhad (SDN BHD) identifies a private limited company./nSDN BHD companies are typically small or midsized enterprises. BHD companies are the largest companies in Malaysia./nBHD companies have stricter financial reporting standards than SDN BHD companies because they must disclose their financial statements to the public./nAlthough most BHD companies list their shares andtrade on a stock market, they can choose to stay unlisted.

Term: Who Was Benjamin Graham?
Definition: Benjamin Graham was an English-born investor and researcher whose work provided the framework for stock analysis./nGraham earned approximately $500,000 per year by age 25 but lost nearly all of his earnings and investments from the stock market crash of 1929./nThe market crash of 1929 inspired Benjamin Graham to co-write a research book titledSecurity Analysis./nIn 1949, Graham publishedThe Intelligent Investor: The Definitive Book on Value Investing,which is known as the investor's bible./nAs an instructor at Columbia University, Graham instructed and mentored now-billionaire investor Warren Buffet.

Term: Bermuda Option: What They Are, Examples, Pros and Cons
Definition: A Bermuda option can be exercised early, but only on a set of specific dates before its expiration./nThese exercise dates are often set in one-month increments./nPremiums for Bermuda options are typically lower than those of American options, which can be exercised any time before expiry.

Term: Bespoke CDO: Definition, Uses, Vs. Bespoke Tranche Opportunity
Definition: A bespoke CDO is a collateralized debt obligation that has been customized to the specific needs of a particular group of investors/nShunned due to their outsized role in the 2007-09 financial crisis, bespoke CDOs began reappearing in 2016 under the moniker bespoke tranche opportunities (BTOs)./nBespoke CDOs today are mainly utilized by hedge funds and other sophisticated institutional investors.

Term: Berkshire Hathaway: What It Is, Market Cap, and Who Owns It
Definition: Berkshire Hathaway is a massive holding company that's been run by famed value investor Warren Buffett since the 1960s./nBerkshire Hathaway has a market capitalization of over $700 billion./nIn May 2023, its class A shares(BRK.A)are among the most expensive in the stock market and trading at almost half a million dollars per share./nIt owns a variety of well-known private businesses and has significant minority interests in public companies, such as Apple./nGreg Abel is the heir apparent to Berkshire CEO Warren Buffett who, in his nineties, has yet to announce any plans to step down.

Term: Bernie Madoff: Who He Was, How His Ponzi Scheme Worked
Definition: Bernie Madoff was a money manager responsible for one of the largest financial frauds in modern-day history./nBernie Madoff's Ponzi scheme, which likely ran for decades, defrauded thousands of investors out of tens of billions of dollars./nInvestors put their trust in Madoff because he created a front of respectability, his returns were high but not outlandish, and he claimed to use a legitimate strategy./nIn 2009 Madoff was sentenced to 150 years in prison and forced to forfeit $170 billion as restitution./nAs of September 2021, the Madoff Victims Fund distributed its seventh distribution of more than $568 million.

Term: Best Endeavors: Meaning, Overview, Limits
Definition: Best endeavors is a legal term that represents an obligation on a party in a contract to take all the steps in their power to fulfill the terms of the agreement./nBest efforts are generally preferred to best endeavors in the United States, but the terms are equivalent./nBest endeavors are limited by the right of a party in a contract to avoid actions that are self-damaging.

Term: Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement (BATNA)
Definition: A best alternative to a negotiated agreement (BATNA) exists when negotiations are not agreeable to the parties involved./nA BATNA represents the most attractive option available if negotiations fail./nBATNAs are used to determine the reservation value—the worst possible offer that a negotiator is willing to accept./nNegotiators can improve their position by exploring multiple BATNAs./nGeneral negotiations are often a better and quicker strategy.

Term: Best Practices: Definition in Business, How To Develop, Examples
Definition: Best practices are the working standards or ethical guidelines that provide the best course(s) of action in a given situation./nCompanies, regulators, or governing bodies can all set best practices for businesses./nBest practices serve as a roadmap for a company on how to do business and provide the best way to deal with problems and issues that arise./nSteps to setting best practices include researching the industry and competitors, communicating the standards to all employees, setting metrics, managing change, evaluating and refining the best practices./nTwo common best practices that have been implemented for inventory management include "just in time" and "kaizen."

Term: Better Business Bureau: An Overview and How Its Ratings Work
What Beta Means for Investors
Definition: Beta (β) compares a stock or portfolio's volatility or systematic risk to the market./nBeta provides an investor with an approximation of how much risk a stock will add to a portfolio./nThe S&P 500 has a beta of 1.0.

Term: Bicameral System: What It Is, How It Works, History in U.S.
Definition: A bicameral legislature is a government style with two separate divisions within the legislative branch of government./nThe U.S. bicameral system is divided into the House of Representatives and the Senate./nThe majority of international governments use the unicameral system—with a roughly 60/40 split between unicameral and bicameral./nEach house of the legislative branch has differing powers to ensure there are checks and balances within the system./nThe more populous House of Representatives branch has less stringent requirements for members when it comes to age and citizenship length compared to the Senate.

Term: Bid: What It Means, How It Works, Types, and Examples
Definition: A bid is an offer made by an investor, trader, or dealer in an effort to buy an asset or to compete for a contract./nThe spread between the bid and the ask is a reliable indicator of supply and demand for the financial instrument./nMarket makers are vital to the efficiency and liquidity of the marketplace./nBids can be made live, online, through brokers, or through a closed bidding process./nTypes of bids include auction bids, online bids, and sealed bids.

Term: Bid and Ask Definition, How Prices Are Determined, and Example
Definition: The bid price refers to the highest price a buyer will pay for a security./nThe ask price refers to the lowest price a seller will accept for a security./nThe difference between these two prices is known as the spread; the smaller the spread, the greater the liquidity of the given security.

Term: What Is a Bid-Ask Spread, and How Does It Work in Trading?
Definition: A bid-ask spread is the difference between the highest price that a buyer is willing to pay for an asset and the lowest price that a seller is willing to accept./nThe spread is the transaction cost. Price takers buy at the ask price and sell at the bid price, but the market maker buys at the bid price and sells at the ask price./nThe bid represents demand and the ask represents supply for an asset./nThe bid-ask spread is the de facto measure of market liquidity.

Term: Bid Bond: What It Is, How It Works, Vs. Performance Bond
Definition: A bid bond is a legal agreement that ensures contractors fulfill their stated obligations on a project./nThis form of assurance provides both financial and legal recourse to the owner of the project./nBid bonds are usually submitted in conjunction with the project's contract./nBid bonds are backed by specialized surety companies that guarantee the payments will be made if the contractor fails to uphold their end of the bargain./nThe other main types of construction bonds are performance and payment bonds.

Term: Bid Price: Definition, Example, Vs. Ask Price
Definition: The bid price is the highest price a buyer is willing to pay for a security or asset./nA bid price is generally arrived at through a process of negotiation between the seller and a single buyer or multiple buyers./nThe difference between the bid price and ask price is known as the market's spread, and is a measure of liquidity in that security.

Term: What Is Big Data? Definition, How It Works, and Uses
Definition: Big data is a great quantity of diverse information that arrives in increasing volumes and with ever-higher velocity./nBig data can be structured (often numeric, easily formatted and stored) or unstructured (more free-form, less quantifiable)./nNearly every department in a company can utilize findings from big data analysis, but handling its clutter and noise can pose problems./nBig data can be collected from publicly shared comments on social networks and websites, voluntarily gathered from personal electronics and apps, through questionnaires, product purchases, and electronic check-ins./nBig data is most often stored in computer databases and is analyzed using software specifically designed to handle large, complex data sets.

Term: Bid Size Defined and Explained With Real World Example
Definition: Bid size represents the quantity of a security that investors are willing to purchase at a specified bid price./nBid size is stated in board lots representing 100 shares each. Therefore, a bid size of four represents 400 shares./nBid sizes are important because they reflect the demand and liquidity of a security./nLevel 1 quotations will only show the bid size for the best available bid price./nLevel 2 quotations show depth of market information on many layers of bid prices and bid sizes.

Term: Bilateral Contract: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A bilateral contract is the most common type of binding agreement, which involves concessions or obligations owed by both sides of the contract./nAny sales agreement, lease, or employment contract are common examples of a bilateral contract./nA unilateral agreement, in contrast, requires only one party to commit to an obligation.

Term: Bilateral Trade Definition and Pros & Cons of Agreements
Definition: Bilateral trade agreements are agreements between countries to promote trade and commerce./nThey eliminate trade barriers such as tariffs, import quotas, and export restraints in order to encourage trade and investment./nThe main advantage of bilateral trade agreements is an expansion of the market for a country's goods through concerted negotiation between two countries./nBilateral trade agreements can also result in the closing down of smaller companies unable to compete with large multinational corporations.

Term: What Is a Bill of Materials? (BOM)
Definition: A bill of materials (BOM) is a source of information containing a list of items and instructions to to design or manufacture a product./nA bill of materials lists the finished product at the top, followed by individual components and materials./nBOMs can be presented as an explosion display or an implosion display./nThe two main types of BOMs are manufacturing and engineering.

Term: Bill Auction: Definition, How It Works & How to Participate
Definition: Treasury bills are issued through an electronic bill auction, which the government conducts every week./nThe bill auction is open to the public, both institutional and individual investors; 24 primary dealers—financial institutions and brokerages—are required to participate./nParticipants are divided into competitive and non-competitive bidders. The competitive bids determine the discount rate to be paid on each T-bill issue. Non-competitive bids are guaranteed to get their securities, though they must accept the rate set by the competitive bids./nThe lowest discount rate that meets the supply of debt being sold serves as the “winning” yield.

Term: What Is a Billing Cycle? How It Works, How Long It Is and Example
Definition: A billing cycle refers to the interval of time from the end of one billing statement date to the next billing statement date./nA billing cycle is traditionally set on a monthly basis but may vary depending on the product or service rendered./nBilling cycles guide companies on when to charge customers, and they help businesses estimate how much revenue they will receive./nBilling cycles help customers regulate their expectations regarding the payment timetables so they can budget their money responsibly.

Term: Bill of Exchange Definition: Examples and How It Works
Definition: A bill of exchange is a written order binding one party to pay a fixed sum of money to another party on demand or at some point in the future./nA bill of exchange often includes three parties—the drawee is the party that pays the sum, the payee receives that sum, and the drawer is the one that obliges the drawee to pay the payee./nA bill of exchange is used in international trade to help importers and exporters fulfill transactions./nWhile a bill of exchange is not a contract itself, the involved parties can use it to specify the terms of a transaction, such as the credit terms and the rate of accrued interest.

Term: Bill of Lading: Meaning, Types, Example, and Purpose
Definition: A bill of lading is a legal document issued by a carrier to a shipper that details the type, quantity, and destination of the goods being carried./nA bill of lading is a document of title, a receipt for shipped goods, and a contract between a carrier and a shipper./nThis document must accompany the shipped goods and must be signed by an authorized representative from the carrier, shipper, and receiver./nIf managed and reviewed properly, a bill of lading can help prevent asset theft./nThere are different types of bills of lading, so it’s important to choose the right one.

Term: Binance Coin (BNB) Uses, Support, and Market Cap
Definition: Binance Coin is the cryptocurrency issued by the Binance exchange and trades with the BNB symbol./nEvery quarter, Binance uses one-fifth of its profits to repurchase and permanently destroy (or "burn") BNB held in its treasury./nBinance was created as a utility token for discounted trading fees in 2017, but its uses have expanded to numerous applications, including payments for transaction fees (on the Binance Chain), travel bookings, entertainment, online services, and financial services./nAt the time of writing, Binance Coin (BNB) had a market cap of more than $87 billion, ranking behind only Bitcoin, Ethereum, and USD Tether.

Term: Binary Option: Definition, How They Trade, and Example
Definition: Binary options depend on the outcome of a "yes or no" proposition./nTraders receive a payout if the binary option expires in the money and lose their wager if it expires out of the money./nBinary options set a fixed payout and loss amount./nBinary options don't allow traders to take a position in the underlying security./nMost binary options trading occurs on platforms outside the United States.

Term: Binomial Distribution: Definition, Formula, Analysis, and Example
Definition: Binomial distribution is a statistical probability distribution that summarizes the likelihood that a value will take one of two independent values under a given set of parameters or assumptions./nThe underlying assumptions of binomial distribution are that there is only one outcome for each trial, that each trial has the same probability of success, and that each trial is mutually exclusive or independent of one another./nBinomial distribution is a common discrete distribution used in statistics, as opposed to a continuous distribution, such as normal distribution.

Term: What Is Bioremediation and How Does It Work?
Definition: Bioremediation is a branch of biotechnology that employs the use of living organisms such as microbes and bacteria to decontaminate affected areas./nIt's used in the removal of contaminants, pollutants, and toxins from soil, water, and other environments./nBioremediation is used to clean up oil spills or contaminated groundwater./nBioremediation can be accomplished "in situ," at the site of the contamination or "ex situ," away from the site.

Term: Bird In Hand: Definition as Strategy in Investing and Example
Definition: The bird-in-hand theory says investors prefer stock dividends to potential capital gains due to the uncertainty of capital gains./nThe theory was developed as a counterpoint to the Modigliani-Miller dividend irrelevance theory, which maintains that investors don't care where their returns come from./nCapital gains investing represents the "two in the bush" side of the adage "a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush."

Term: Binomial Option Pricing Model
Definition: The binomial option pricing model values options using an iterative approach utilizing multiple periods to value American options./nWith the model, there are two possible outcomes with each iteration—a move up or a move down that follow a binomial tree./nThe model is intuitive and is used more frequently in practice than the well-known Black-Scholes model.

Term: What Is Bitcoin Cash (BCH), and How Does It Work?
Definition: Bitcoin Cash is the result of aBitcoin hard forkthat happened in August 2017./nBitcoin Cash was created to allow more transactions in a single block, theoretically decreasing the fees and transaction times./nDespite their philosophical differences, Bitcoin Cash and Bitcoin share several technical similarities: They use the same consensus mechanism and have capped their supply at 21 million coins./nBitcoin Cash continues to trade—at a fraction of Bitcoin's price—but has yet to achieve widespread consumer acceptance as a form of payment.

Term: What Is Bitcoin Mining?
Definition: Validating transaction information, maintaining the integrity of the blockchain, and opening new blocks are mining's purposes, while the Bitcoin reward is the incentive to mine./nBitcoin mining is necessary to maintain the ledger of transactions upon which Bitcoin is based./nMiners have become very sophisticated over the past several years, using complex machinery and grouping to speed up mining operations./nBitcoin mining has generated controversy because it is not considered environmentally friendly.

Term: Bitcoin Misery Index (BMI): Meaning, Goals, FAQs
Definition: The Bitcoin Misery Index (BMI) was created in 2018 by Tom Lee, a co-founder of Fundstrat Global Advisors./nThe index incorporates the percentage of winning trades to total trades and volatility; it is calculated on a 100 point scale where zero indicates maximum misery./nThe index is considered "at misery" when the value is below 27. As a contrarian index, the closer the index is to zero, the louder the signal is to "buy."

Term: Cryptocurrency Wallet: What It Is, How It Works, Types, Security
Definition: A cryptocurrency wallet is a device or program that stores your cryptocurrency keys and allows you to access your coins./nWallets contain a public key (the wallet address) and your private keys needed to sign cryptocurrency transactions. Anyone who knows the private key can control the coins associated with that address./nThere are several different types of wallets, each with its own features and levels of security./nMany cryptocurrency wallets can be used to store key for different cryptocurrencies.

Term: What Is Black Money? Meaning, Definition, and Criticism
Definition: Black money includes all funds earned through illegal activity and otherwise legal income that is not recorded for tax purposes./nHigher amounts of black money in the economy often lead to increased corruption./nOn the other hand, black money can reduce the negative impact of oppressive laws./nBlack money can be illegally disguised as legitimate money through money laundering.

Term: Black Friday: What It Means to Economists and to You
Definition: Black Friday refers to the day after Thanksgiving and is symbolically seen as the start of the critical holiday shopping season for retailers./nIn the lead-up to Black Friday stores typically advertise big discounts on electronics, toys, clothing, and other popular gifts./nAlso important to retailers: Cyber Monday, the first day back to work for many consumers after the long holiday weekend, during which online retailers offer major discounts.

Term: What Is a Black Box Model? Definition, Uses, and Examples
Definition: A black box model receives inputs and produces outputs but its workings are unknowable./nBlack box models are increasingly used to drive decision-making in the financial markets./nTechnology advances, particularly in machine learning capabilities, make it impossible for a human mind to analyze or understand precisely how black box models produce their conclusions./nThe opposite of a black box is a white box. Its results are transparent and can be analyzed by the user./nThe term black box model can be easily misused and may merely reflect a need to protect proprietary software or a desire to avoid clear explanations.

Term: What Is the Black Market and What's Sold There? Types and Example
Definition: An illegal market is an economic activity that occurs outside of government-sanctioned channels./nBlack markets trade in illegal goods and services, legal goods and services to avoid taxes, or both./nExamples of black markets include the sale of illegal drugs, weapons, human trafficking, and the illegal wildlife trade./nBlack markets can have a negative impact on the economy because the activity is not reported and taxes are not collected on the transactions./nBlack markets do provide some benefits, such as creating jobs for those who may not be able to find employment in traditional markets and allowing access to medicine and healthcare to those individuals that might not have had access otherwise.

Term: Black Monday: Definition in Stocks, What Caused It, and Losses
Definition: Black Monday refers to the stock market crash that occurred on Oct. 19, 1987, when the DJIA lost almost 22% in a single day, triggering a global stock market decline./nThe SEC has built a number of protective mechanisms, such as trading curbs and circuit breakers, to prevent panic-selling./nInvestors can take pre-emptive steps in order to deal with the possibility of a stock market crash, similar to Black Monday, happening again.

Term: Black-Scholes Model: What It Is, How It Works, and Options Formula
Definition: The Black-Scholes model, aka the Black-Scholes-Merton (BSM) model, is a differential equation widely used to price options contracts./nThe Black-Scholes model requires five input variables: the strike price of an option, the current stock price, the time to expiration, the risk-free rate, and the volatility./nThough usually accurate, the Black-Scholes model makes certain assumptions that can lead to predictions that deviate from real-world results./nThe standard BSM model is only used to price European options, as it does not take into account that American options could be exercised before the expiration date.

Term: What Is Black Tuesday? Definition, History, and Impact
Definition: Black Tuesday refers to a precipitous drop in the value of the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) on Oct 29, 1929./nBlack Tuesday marked the beginning of the Great Depression, which lasted until the beginning of World War II./nCauses of Black Tuesday included too much debt used to buy stocks, global protectionist policies, and slowing economic growth./nBlack Tuesday had far-reaching consequences on America's economic system and trade policy.

Term: Black Swan in the Stock Market: What Is It, With Examples and History
Definition: A black swan is an extremely rare event with severe consequences./nIt cannot be predicted beforehand, though after the fact, many falsely claim it should have been predictable./nBlack swan events can cause catastrophic damage to an economy by negatively impacting markets and investments, but even the use of robust modeling cannot prevent a black swan event./nReliance on standard forecasting tools can both fail to predict and potentially increase vulnerability to black swans by propagating risk and offering false security./nThe term was popularized by the book,The Black Swan,by Nassim Nicholas Taleb.

Term: Defining a Blind Trust, How It Works, Examples
Definition: A blind trust is a trust established by the owner (or trustor) giving another party (the trustee) full control of the trust./nThe trustee has control over the assets and investments while managing the assets and any income generated in the trust./nBlind trusts are often established when individuals want to avoid conflicts of interest between their employment and investments.

Term: Blended Rate: Definition, Examples, Calculation Formula
Block Trade: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A block trade is a large, privately negotiated securities transaction./nBlock trades are generally broken up into smaller orders and executed through different brokers to mask the true size./nBlock trades can be made outside the open market through a private purchase agreement.

Term: Blockchain-as-a-Service (BaaS) Meaning and Major Players
Definition: Blockchain-as-a-service (BaaS) refers to third-party cloud-based infrastructure and management for companies building and operating blockchain apps./nBaaS functions like a sort of web host, running the back-end operation for a block-chain based app or platform./nBaaS may be the catalyst that leads to the widespread adoption of blockchain technology.

Term: Blockchain Wallet: What It Is, How It Works, Security Issues
Definition: Broadly speaking, a blockchain wallet is a digital wallet that allows users to store, manage, and trade their cryptocurrencies./nBlockchain Wallet is also the name of a specific wallet service provided by the company Blockchain. This is an E-wallet that allows individuals to store and transfer cryptocurrencies./nBlockchain Wallet users can manage their balances of Bitcoin, Ether, and other crypto assets./nBlockchain Wallet charges dynamic fees, meaning that the transaction fees can be different based on factors such as transaction size./nBlockchain Wallet has a number of security features to prevent theft, including by company insiders.

Term: Bloomberg: Overview and History of the Financial News Company
Definition: Bloomberg is a media conglomerate and provider of financial news and information, research, and financial data./nBloomberg was founded by Michael Bloomberg in 1981 as a provider of financial analytics and information./nThe Bloomberg Terminal provides snapshots and detailed information about financial markets.

Term: Blockchain Facts: What Is It, How It Works, and How It Can Be Used
Definition: Blockchain is a type of shared database that differs from a typical database in the way it stores information; blockchains store data in blocks linked together via cryptography./nDifferent types of information can be stored on a blockchain, but the most common use for transactions has been as a ledger./nIn Bitcoin’s case, blockchain is decentralized so that no single person or group has control—instead, all users collectively retain control./nDecentralized blockchains are immutable, which means that the data entered is irreversible. For Bitcoin, transactions are permanently recorded and viewable to anyone.

Term: What Is a Blotter? Definition, How It Works, Uses, and Example
Definition: A blotter is a detailed record of one's trading activity and history./nClearing firms and regulatory agencies like the SEC use trade blotters to adjust or correct out trades and to detect instances of illegal trading./nA blotter can also be used by traders to evaluate and analyze trading positions at the end of a day.

Term: What Is a Bloomberg Terminal? Functions, Costs, and Alternatives
Definition: Developed by businessman Michael Bloomberg, a Bloomberg terminal is a popular hardware and software system that allows investors access to real-time market data, investing analytics, and proprietary trading platforms./nBecause of their relatively high cost, Bloomberg terminals are typically used by large institutional investors, portfolio managers, and financial analysts./nBloomberg offers investors independent stock research from more than 1,500 resources, charting tools, and trade analytics for both the buy-side and sell-side./nBloomberg's biggest competitor is Thomson Reuters—which offers Eikon, a set of software products designed to help investors analyze and trade the financial markets./nBoth Bloomberg and Reuters are seeing competition from other companies that offer similar products at a lower price, most notably Capital IQ and FactSet.

Term: Blue Book: What it is, How it Works, Effect
Definition: The Blue Book, also known as the Kelley Blue Book, is a popular and trusted guide for automotive price quotes in North America./nBlue Books show car buyers and sellers what prices others have paid to acquire vehicles of the same make, model, year, and comparable mileage and use./nThe Blue Book analyzes the private party value, trade-in value, suggested retail value, certified pre-owned (CPO) value, and many other prices for used cars./nBlue Books can also help car buyers determine the potential future costs of car ownership, such as the costs of fuel, maintenance, repairs, and insurance.

Term: Blue Chip Meaning and Examples
Definition: A blue chip stock refers to the shares of an established, profitable, and well-recognized corporation./nBlue chips are characterized by a large market capitalization, a listing on a major stock exchange, and a history of reliable growth and dividend payments./nBlue chip stocks are seen as relatively safe investments, with a proven track record of success and stable growth./nAlthough blue chips are reliably stable, they are unlikely to generate the same high returns as potentially riskier investments./nDespite their stability, blue chip stocks can experience volatility and failure, as did some during the 2007-2008 financial crisis.

Term: What Is Blue Ocean? Definition in Markets and Characteristics
Definition: A blue ocean is considered (from a marketing standpoint) a yet unexploited or uncontested market space./nThe term was coined by Chan Kim and Renee Mauborgne in the bookBlue Ocean Strategy: How to Create Uncontested Market Space and Make the Competition Irrelevant./nBlue ocean firms tend to be innovators of their time./nBlue oceans are contrasted with "red oceans," characterized by cutthroat competition and crowded markets./nIn their book, Kim and Mauborgne wrote about 150 blue ocean strategies that have been undertaken by companies over about 100 years.

Term: What Are Blue Chip Stocks and Are They Good Investments?
Definition: Blue chip companies are large, stable companies with excellent reputations, and often include big household names./nBlue chip stocks can be smart additions to a portfolio, thanks to their reliable financial returns./nMany investors turn to blue chips for their longstanding, rising dividends./nMany investors believe that blue chips can survive market challenges of many kinds; while this may be largely true, it is not a guarantee./nFor this reason, it's crucial to diversify a portfolio beyond only blue chip stocks.

Term: Blue Sky Laws: Definition, Purpose, How They're Regulated
Definition: Blue sky laws are state-level, anti-fraud regulations that require issuers of securities to be registered and to disclose details of their offerings./nBlue sky laws create liability for issuers, allowing legal authorities and investors to bring action against them for failing to live up to the laws' provisions./nMost states' blue sky laws follow the model Uniform Securities Act of 1956 and are superseded by federal securities laws in case of duplication.

Term: Board of Directors: What It Is, What Its Role Is
Definition: The board of directors of a public company is elected byshareholders./nThe board makes key decisions on issues such as mergers and dividends, hires senior managers, and sets their pay./nBoard of directors candidates can be nominated by the company's nominations committee or by outsiders seeking change./nPublic companies must have a board of directors./nThe New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq require that the majority of members on the boards of listed companies be outside, or independent, directors.

Term: What Is a Board of Trustees? Who's Included and Responsibilities
Definition: The board of trustees is responsible for managing an organization./nThe trustees ensure stakeholders' best interests./nThe board of trustees is similar to the board of directors, but are commonly in private organizations.

Term: Boil the Ocean: Business Jargon for an Impossible Task
Definition: "Boiling the ocean" means undertaking an impossible task or making a task unnecessarily difficult./nThe phrase is used in a variety of settings as a negative comment on how one conducts business or projects./nThe phrase derives from the literal concept of boiling the ocean, which is an impossible task./nTo avoid boiling the ocean, tasks and projects should have clear guidelines within the resources provided, frequent discussions on progress, and provisions against any unnecessary expansion.

Term: Boilerplate Language, Uses, History, Examples, Pros & Cons
Definition: Boilerplate language is the standardized text that can be found in many documents such as contracts./nThese passages of text are often part of a template that is personalized as needed./nThe term is also used to describe sections of code that can be reused in various software programs or web pages./nBoilerplates are time and money-savers, but can also favor only one party in the case of contracts.

Term: Board of Governors: Overview, Duties, FAQ
Definition: A board of governors oversees an organization's operations, including financial matters./nThe most well-known board of governors in the U.S. is the Federal Reserve, whose responsibilities include analyzing domestic and international economic developments and overseeing operations of the Federal Reserve Banks./nIn a corporation, a board of directors is an appointed group that oversees the business./nMembers of the Federal Reserve's board of governors are nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate./nA competent and well-organized board of governors is seen as a key component of the success of an organization.

Term: Boiler Room Definition, How It Operates, Common Scams
Definition: A boiler room is a scheme in which salespeople apply high-pressure sales tactics to persuade investors to purchase securities, including speculative and fraudulent securities./nMost boiler room salespersons contact potential investors through cold calls./nSome notable boiler room tactics include making claims that cannot be easily verified by the investor, demanding immediate payment, or issuing threats for noncompliance./nThese methods, if not illegal, clearly violate the National Association of Securities Dealers' (NASD) rules of fair practice./nBoiler room sales tactics are also restricted by the Securities and Exchange Commission's Rule 10b5, which forbids dealers from making untrue statements, omitting material facts, or other deceitful behavior.

Term: Bollinger Bands: What They Are, and What They Tell Investors
Definition: Bollinger Bands is a technical analysis tool used to determine where prices are high and low relative to each other./nThese bands are composed of three lines: a simple moving average (the middle band) and an upper and lower band./nThe upper and lower bands are typically two standard deviations above or below a 20-period simple moving average (SMA)./nThe bands widen and narrow as the volatility of the underlying asset changes.

Term: What Is the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE)?
Definition: Established in 1875 as the Native Share and Stock Brokers' Association, the BSE is Asia's first exchange./nThe BSE has been instrumental in developing India's capital markets./nThe BSE enables investors to trade equities, currencies, debt instruments, derivatives, and mutual funds.

Term: Bonds: How They Work and How To Invest
Definition: A bond is referred to as a fixed-income instrument since bonds traditionally pay a fixed interest rate or coupon to debtholders./nBond prices are inversely correlated with interest rates: when rates go up, bond prices fall, and vice-versa./nBonds have maturity dates at which point the principal amount must be paid back in full or risk default.

Term: Bond Discount: Definition, Example, Vs. Premium Bond
Definition: Bond discount is the amount by which the market price of a bond is lower than its principal amount due at maturity./nA bond issued at a discount has its market price below the face value, creating a capital appreciation upon maturity since the higher face value is paid when the bond matures./nDifferent bonds trade at a discount for different reasons—for example, bonds on the secondary market with fixed coupons trade at discounts when interest rates rise, while zero-coupon bonds short-term bonds are often issued at a bond discount when supply exceeds demand.

Term: Bond Covenant: Definition, Example, Affirmitive Vs. Negative
Definition: A bond covenant sets out certain activities that must be undertaken, or what activities are forbidden, by a bond issuer./nCovenants are legally binding clauses, and if breached will trigger compensatory or other legal action./nAffirmative (positive) covenants are legal promises to engage in certain activities or meet certain benchmarks added to a financial contract that an issuer must follow./nRestrictive (negative) covenants instead restrict a company or issuer from engaging in certain actions.

Term: Bond Equivalent Yield (BEY): Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: Fixed income securities come in different forms./nDiscounted (zero-coupon) bonds have shorter durations than traditional fixed income securities, which makes it impossible to calculate their annual yields./nThe bond equivalent yield (BEY) formula can help approximate what a discounted bond would pay annually, letting investors compare their returns with those of traditional bonds.

Term: What Is a Bond Fund? How It Works, Benefits, Taxes, and Types
Definition: A bond fund invests primarily in a portfolio of fixed-income securities such as municipal and corporate bonds./nBond funds provide diversification for investors for a low required minimum investment./nDue to the inverse relationship between interest rates and bond prices, a long-term bond has greater interest rate risk than a short-term bond.

Term: Bond ETF Definition, Types, Examples, and How to Invest
Definition: Bond ETFs are exchange-traded funds that invest in various fixed-income securities such as corporate bonds or Treasuries./nBond ETFs allow ordinary investors to gain passive exposure to benchmark bond indices in an inexpensive way./nBond ETFs are available for a variety of bond categories, including Treasuries, corporates, convertibles, and floating-rate bonds./nBond ETFs are also amenable to laddering./nInvestors should understand the risks to bond ETFs including the effect of interest rate changes.

Term: Bond Futures: What They Are, How They Work, and How to Buy Them
Definition: Bond futures are contracts that entitle the contract holder to purchase a bond on a specified date at a price determined today./nA bond futures contract trades on a futures exchange and is bought and sold through a brokerage firm that offers futures trading./nBond futures are used by speculators to bet on the price of a bond or by hedgers to protect bond holdings./nBond futures are indirectly used to trade or hedge interest rate moves.

Term: Bond Ladder: Overview, Benefits, FAQ and Examples
Definition: A bond ladder is a portfolio of fixed-income securities in which each security has a significantly different maturity date./nIn a bond ladder, the bonds' maturity dates are evenly spaced across several months or several years so that the proceeds are reinvested at regular intervals as the bonds mature./nThe purpose of purchasing several smaller bonds with varying dates of maturity rather than one large bond with a single maturity date is to minimize interest-rate risk, increase liquidity, and diversify credit risk./nIn order to build an ETF bond ladder, an investor simply needs to put an equal amount of money in a number of different ETFs; all with a different defined maturity date./nSince callable bonds can be redeemed by the issuer before maturity, they're not ideal when building a bond ladder.

Term: The Bond Market and Debt Securities: An Overview
Definition: Governments use proceeds from bonds to finance infrastructural improvements and pay debts./nCompanies issue bonds to raise capital to maintain operations, grow product lines, or open new locations./nBonds are either issued on the primary market or traded on the secondary market, in which investors may purchase existing debt via brokers or other third parties.

Term: What Are Bond Ratings? Definition, Effects, and Agencies
Definition: A bond rating is a letter-based credit scoring scheme used to judge the quality and creditworthiness of a bond./nInvestment grade bonds are assigned “AAA” to “BBB-" ratings from Standard & Poor's and Fitch, and "Aaa" to "Baa3" ratings from Moody’s. Junk bonds have lower ratings./nThe higher a bond's rating, the lower the interest rate it will carry, due to the lower risk, all else equal./nThe bond rating agencies rate all types of bonds, from corporate bonds to sovereign bonds.

Term: Bond Quote: Definition, How to Read for Trading, and Example
Definition: A bond quote supplies the price and other details of a bond./nBond quotes are expressed as a percentage of par or face value and converted to a point scale./nThe par value is traditionally set at 100, representing 100% of a bond's $1,000 face value./nBond quotes may also be expressed as fractions.

Term: Bond Rating Agencies: Overview, Benefits, and Criticisms
Definition: Bond rating agencies are companies that assess the creditworthiness of both debt securities and their issuers./nThe three primary bond rating agencies used in the U.S. are Standard & Poor's Global Ratings, Moody's, and Fitch Ratings./nThe bond rating agencies provide useful information to the markets and help investors save on research costs./nRating agencies are regulated by the SEC in addition to various reform acts such as CRARA and Dodd-Frank./nBond rating agencies were heavily criticized early in the 21st century for assigning flawed ratings, particularly for mortgage-backed securities.

Term: Bond Valuation: Calculation, Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: Bond valuation is a way to determine the theoretical fair value (or par value) of a particular bond./nIt involves calculating the present value of a bond's expected future coupon payments, or cash flow, and the bond's value upon maturity, or face value./nAs a bond's par value and interest payments are set, bond valuation helps investors figure out what rate of return would make a bond investment worth the cost.

Term: Bondholder: Definition, Risks and Rewards, Taxes
Definition: A bondholder is an investor who acquires bonds issued by an entity such as a corporation or government body./nBondholders essentially become creditors to the issuer, and so bondholders enjoy certain protections and priority over stock (equity) holders./nThe holders of bonds receive their initial principal back when the bonds mature in addition to periodic interest (coupon) payments for most bonds./nBondholders may additionally profit if the particular bonds that they own increase in value, which can then be sold on the secondary market.

Term: Bond Yield: What It Is, Why It Matters, and How It's Calculated
Definition: Bond yield is the return an investor realizes on an investment in a bond./nA bond can be purchased for more than its face value, at a premium, or less than its face value, at a discount./nThe current yield is the bond's coupon rate divided by its market price./nPrice and yield are inversely related and as the price of a bond goes up, its yield goes down.

Term: Bonus Issue of Shares Explained: How They Work
Definition: A bonus issue of shares is the allocation of additional shares to stockholders./nBonus shares increase a company’sshare capitalbut not its market capitalization./nA bonus issue of shares is funded by a company’s earnings or share reserves./nBonus issues don’t dilute shareholders’ equity because they are issued in a constant ratio that keeps the relative equity of each shareholder the same as before the issue./nCompanies issue bonus shares to make their stock more attractive for retail investors, provide an alternative to a cash dividend, and/or reflect a position of financial health./nA downside of bonus issues is theopportunity costof earnings utilized for other purposes.

Term: Bonus: Definition, Different Types, and Tax Treatment
Definition: A bonus is a financial compensation that is above and beyond the normal payment expectations of its recipient./nBonuses may be awarded by a company as an incentive or to reward good performance./nTypical incentive bonuses a company can give employees include signing, referral, and retention bonuses./nCompanies have various ways they can award employee bonuses, including cash, stock, and stock options.

Term: What Is Bonus Depreciation? Definition and How It Works
Definition: Bonus depreciation allows businesses to deduct a large percentage of the cost of eligible purchases the year they acquire them, rather than depreciating them over a period of years./nIt was created as a way to encourage investment by small businesses and stimulate the economy./nBusinesses shoulduse IRS Form 4562to record bonus depreciation as well as other types of depreciation and amortization./nThe rules and limits for bonus depreciation have changed over the years, and the latest ones are scheduled to expire in 2023./nIn 2022, bonus depreciation allows for 100% upfront deductibility of depreciation; this depreciates 20% in each subsequent year until its final year in 2026.

Term: Book Building
Definition: Book building is the process by which an underwriter attempts to determine the price at which an initial public offering (IPO) will be offered./nThe process of price discovery involves generating and recording investor demand for shares before arriving at an issue price./nBook building is the de facto mechanism by which companies price their IPOs and is highly recommended by all the major stock exchanges as the most efficient way to price securities.

Term: Book Runner: Definition, Duties, Vs. Other Underwriters
Definition: A book runner is the primary underwriter or lead coordinator in the issuance of new equity, debt, or securities instruments./nIn investment banking, the book runner is the lead underwriting firm that runs or is in charge of the books during the issuance of new equity of a client firm./nThe book runner serves as lead underwriter and usually works with other investment banks to establish an underwriter syndicate, thereby creating the initial sales force for shares./nIn leveraged buyouts, a book runner represents one of the participating companies and works with other participating firms.

Term: Book-to-Bill Ratio: Definition, How It's Calculated, and Example
Definition: Book-to-bill ratio is the ratio of orders received to units shipped and billed for the period./nA ratio above one means more orders were received than filled, indicating strong demand./nA ratio below one means more orders were shipped than received during the month, indicating diminishing demand.

Term: Book-to-Market Ratio Definition
Definition: The book-to-market ratio helps investors find a company's value by comparing the firm's book value to its market value./nA high book-to-market ratio might mean that the market is valuing the company's equity cheaply compared to its book value./nMany investors are familiar with the price-to-book ratio, which is simply the inverse of the book-to-market ratio formula.

Term: Book Value: Definition, Meaning, Formula, and Examples
Definition: A company's book value is the sum of all the line items in the shareholders' equity section of a balance sheet./nBook value is often different than a company's market value./nBook value per share (BVPS) and price-to-book (P/B) ratio are utilized in fundamental analysis.

Term: Book Value Per Share (BVPS): Definition, Formula, How to Calculate, and Example
Definition: Book value per share (BVPS) takes the ratio of a firm's common equity divided by its number of shares outstanding./nBook value of equity per share effectively indicates a firm's net asset value (total assets - total liabilities) on a per-share basis./nWhen a stock is undervalued, it will have a higher book value per share in relation to its current stock price in the market./nBVPS is used mainly by stock investors to evaluate a company's stock price.

Term: Boom and Bust Cycle: Definition, How It Works, and History
Definition: The boom and bust cycle describes alternating phases of economic growth and decline typically found in modern capitalist economies./nFirst anticipated by Karl Marx in the 19th century, the boom-bust cycle is driven just as much by investor and consumer psychology as it is by market and economic fundamentals./nThe cycle can last anywhere from several months to several years, with the average length being approximately 5 years going back to the 1850s.

Term: Book Value Per Common Share (BVPS): Definition and Calculation
Definition: Book value per common share (BVPS) calculates the common stock per-share book value of a firm./nSince preferred stockholders have a higher claim on assets and earnings than common shareholders, preferred equity is subtracted from shareholder’s equity to derive the equity available to common shareholders./nIf a company’s BVPS is higher than its market value per share, then its stock may be considered to be undervalued.

Term: Bookie: Definition, Meaning, Duties, How They Make Money, and Fee
Definition: The term “bookie“ is slang for “bookmaker.“/nA bookie places bets for customers, usually on sporting events. They also set odds and pay out winnings on behalf of other people./nThe bookie’s goal is to maintain balance in the books by adjusting the odds as much as possible to maintain an even amount of people betting on a win or loss.

Term: Borrowing Base: Definition, How It's Determined, and Example
Both-To-Blame Collision Clause: Meaning, Overview, Example
Definition: A both-to-blame collision clause is an insurance policy clause that says both vessel owners must share in the responsibility of a collision between ships if the crash was due to negligence./nMarine insurance coverage includes such actions as ship sinking or collisions but does not cover wear and tear or war./nThe Hague-Visby Rules say that if the carrier has exercised due diligence to provide a seaworthy ship they are not liable for claims resulting from a collision partly or wholly caused by negligent navigation./nThe both-to-blame collision clause is designed to preserve the protection a carrier has under the Hague-Visby Rules by giving a contractual indemnity against the cargo interests.

Term: Bootstrapping Definition, Strategies, and Pros/Cons
Definition: Bootstrapping is the process of founding and running a company using only personal finances or operating revenue./nIt is a form of financing that allows the entrepreneur to maintain more control even though it can increase financial strain./nOwners can bootstrap by cutting costs, personally financing operations, cutting back operations, or looking for other creative short-term financing solutions./nThe term also refers to a method of building the yield curve for certain bonds./nAmazon, GoPro, and Facebook are examples of companies with humble beginnings and bootstrapped starts.

Term: Bottleneck: A Point of Congestion in a Production System
Definition: A bottleneck is a point of congestion in a production system that stops or severely slows the system./nShort-term bottlenecks are temporary and usually caused by employees on vacation or sick leave./nLong-term bottlenecks are built into the manufacturing protocol and often related to inefficient equipment or processes./nBottlenecking, the process that creates bottlenecks, can have a significant impact on the flow of manufacturing and can sharply increase the time and expense of production./nBottlenecks have a negative effect on practical production capacity, keeping it further below theoretical (perfect) capacity than normal./nEliminating bottlenecks is key to increasing production efficiency.

Term: Bottom-Up Investing: Definition, Example, Vs. Top-Down
Definition: Bottom-up investing is an investment approach that focuses on analyzing individual stocks and de-emphasizes the significance of macroeconomic and market cycles./nBottom-up investors focus on a specific company and its fundamentals, whereas top-down investors focus on the industry and economy./nThe bottom-up approach assumes individual companies can do well even in an underperforming industry.

Term: What Is a Bottom Line in Accounting, and Why Does It Matter?
Definition: The bottom line refers to a company's net income, which is presented at the bottom of the income statement./nManagement can increase the bottom line by enacting strategies to increase revenues or decrease expenses./nNet income, or the bottom line, can be retained for future use in the business, distributed in the form of dividends, or used to repurchase shares of outstanding stock./nThe top line refers to gross sales or revenues, which are found on the top line of the income statement./nTriple bottom line (TPL) refers to measuring the profitability of a company, along with how socially and environmentally responsible a company is.

Term: Bounced Check: Definition, What Happens Next, Fees & Penalties
Definition: A bounced check occurs when the writer of the check has insufficient funds available to fulfill the payment amount on the check to the payee./nWhen a check bounces, it is not honored by the depositor’s bank and may result in overdraft fees and banking restrictions./nAdditional penalties for bouncing checks may include negative credit score marks, refusal of merchants to accept your checks, and potentially legal trouble./nBanks often offer overdraft protection to prevent inadvertent check bouncing.

Term: Boundary Conditions: What They are, How They Work
Definition: Boundary conditions were used to set minimum and maximum possible values for call and put options prior to the introduction of binomial tree and Black-Scholes pricing models./nBoundary conditions change according to whether the option is American or European, since American options can be exercised prior to expiry./nThe absolute minimum value for an option is zero, since an option cannot be sold for a negative amount of money./nThe maximum value in a boundary condition is set to the current value of the underlying asset.

Term: Box Spread: Definition, Example, Uses & Hidden Risks
Definition: A box spread is an options arbitrage strategy that combines buying a bull call spread with a matching bear put spread./nA box spread's ultimate payoff will always be the difference between the two strike prices./nThe longer the time to expiration, the lower the market price of the box spread today./nThe cost to implement a box spread—specifically, the commissions charged—can be a significant factor in its potential profitability./nTraders use box spreads to synthetically borrow or lend for cash management purposes.

Term: Brain Drain: Definition, Causes, Effects, and Examples
Definition: Brain drain is a slang term referring to substantial emigration./nBrain drain can result from political turmoil or the existence of more favorable professional opportunities elsewhere./nIt causes countries, industries, and organizations to lose a core portion of valuable individuals./nSome of the consequences of brain drain include the loss of tax revenue./nOne of the best ways to reduce brain drain is to boost government investment in the local economy.

Term: Branch Accounting
Definition: Branch accounting is a bookkeeping system in which separate accounts are kept for each branch or operating location of an organization./nTechnically, the branch account is a temporary or nominal ledger account, lasting for a designated accounting period./nBranch accounting provides better accountability and control since profitability and efficiency can be closely tracked for each location./nBranch accounting has a long history, going back to the Venetian banks of the 14th century.

Term: Branch Banking: Definition, Advantages, vs. Unit Banking
Definition: Branch banking refers to the operation of storefront spinoffs that offer the same key services as the institution's flagship home office./nSince the 1980s, branch banking has undergone significant changes in response to a more competitive national market, deregulation of financial services, and the growth of internet banking./nIf you use a branch bank today, it is most likely to be one of the "big four" banks: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Bank of America, Wells Fargo, or Citibank.

Term: Branch Manager: Definition, Job Description, and Salary
Definition: A branch manager is an employee who oversees the operations of a branch of a bank or financial institution./nThe branch manager's responsibilities include managing resources and staff, developing and attaining sales goals, delivering customer service, and growing the location's revenues./nBranch managers oversee the performance of other employees who work in their branches./nEmployers seek managers with experience, proven success, and leadership skills./nBranch managers typically have undergraduate degrees in finance, accounting, or related fields of study.

Term: Brand: Types of Brands and How to Create a Successful Brand Identity
Definition: A successful brand communicates the qualities of a product to the consumer./nA product’s design, logo, packaging, and advertising message are all coordinated to convey the brand’s message to the consumer./nIts brands are among a company’s most important and valuable assets./nCompanies can protect their brands by registering trademarks to protect elements of their brands.

Term: What Is Brand Awareness? Definition, How It Works, and Strategies
Definition: Brand awareness refers to the familiarity of consumers with a particular product or service./nA brand awareness campaign seeks to familiarize the public with a new or revised product and differentiate it from the competition./nSocial media has become an important new tool in brand awareness marketing.

Term: Brand Equity: Definition, Importance, Effect on Profit Margin, and Examples
Definition: Brand equity refers to the value a company gains from its name recognition when compared to a generic equivalent./nBrand equity has three basic components: consumer perception, negative or positive effects, and the resulting value./nBrand equity has a direct impact on sales volume and a company's profitability because consumers gravitate toward products and services with great reputations./nOften, companies in the same industry or sector compete on brand equity.

Term: Brand Loyalty: What It Is, and How to Build It
Definition: Brand loyalty—repeat purchases of a particular brand based on the perception of higher quality and better service than any competitor—is not dependent on price./nCompanies with high scores on brand loyalty grow revenues 2.5 times faster than industry peers./nBrand-loyalty leaders also deliver two to five times the returns to shareholders over 10-year time frames./nThe first and most important condition for brand loyalty is quality. No matter how large the marketing spend, poor quality will kill brand loyalty./nBrand loyalty is measured through customer retention, customer lifetime value, and customer satisfaction surveys.

Term: Brand Identity: What It Is and How To Build One
Definition: Brand identity is the visible elements of a brand, such as color, design, and logo that identify and distinguish the brand in consumers' minds./nConsistent marketing and messaging lead to consistent brand identity and, therefore, consistent sales./nBuilding a positive brand image can bring in consistent sales and make product roll-outs more successful./nBuilding a positive, cohesive brand image requires analyzing the company and its market, and determining the company's goals, customers, and message./nSocial media is a powerful driver of brand awareness.

Term: Brand Extension: Definition, How It Works, Example, and Criticism
Definition: Brand extension is the introduction of a new product that relies on the name and reputation of an established product./nBrand extension works when the original and new products share a common quality or characteristic that the consumer can immediately identify./nBrand extension fails when the new product is unrelated to the original, is seen as a mismatch, or even creates a negative association.

Term: What Is Brand Management? Requirements, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Brand management is a function of marketing that uses techniques to increase the perceived value of a product line or brand over time./nEffective brand management helps a company build a loyal customer base and helps fuel a company's profits./nA brand manager ensures the innovation of a product or brand, creating brand awareness via the use of price, packaging, logo, associated colors, and lettering format./nBrand management is usually centered around fostering the brand recognition, brand equity, and brand loyalty of a product./nBrand equity refers to the value a company gains from its name recognition, enabling it to be the popular choice among consumers even when compared to a generic brand with a lower price point.

Term: What Is Brand Recognition? Why It's Important and Benefits
Definition: Brand recognition is the ability of consumers to recognize an identifying characteristic of one company versus a competitor./nA company is perceived as having successful brand recognition when consumers are able to recognize the firm through visual or auditory cues alone, even without hearing the company's name./nA company's marketing department will come up with the cues that are then marketed to customers./nCues that can lead to brand recognition may come in the form of names, marks, logos, and jingles.

Term: What Is Brand Personality? How It Works and Examples
Definition: Brand personality is a set of characteristics that is attributed to abrandname./nCompanies should accurately define their brand personalities so that they resonate with their target consumers./nA company's brand should aim to elicit a positive emotional response from a targeted consumer segment./nThe personal side of brand personality is especially important in the digital age of artificial intelligence and automation./nDon't confuse brand personality with imagery, which consists of a company's creative assets.

Term: BRICS: Acronym for Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa
Definition: BRICS is an acronym for Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa./nEconomist Jim O'Neill created the term BRIC in 2001 (for Brazil, Russia, India, and China) with the belief that these economies would dominate global growth by 2050./nThe BRICS nations offered a source of foreign expansion for firms and strong returns for institutional investors./nThe organization seeks to deepen economic cooperation between the member countries and stand in contrast to the Western sphere of power./nSaudi Arabia, Iran, Ethiopia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, and Argentina were invited to join BRICS in 2023.

Term: BRICS: Acronym for Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa
Definition: BRICS is an acronym for Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa./nEconomist Jim O'Neill created the term BRIC in 2001 (for Brazil, Russia, India, and China) with the belief that these economies would dominate global growth by 2050./nThe BRICS nations offered a source of foreign expansion for firms and strong returns for institutional investors./nThe organization seeks to deepen economic cooperation between the member countries and stand in contrast to the Western sphere of power./nSaudi Arabia, Iran, Ethiopia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, and Argentina were invited to join BRICS in 2023.

Term: Breadth Indicator: Overview, Examples, Limitations
Definition: Breadth indicators don't typically providetrade signalson their own, but rather provide an overall picture of the health on an index./nTypically, when a breadth indicator is rising, and the stock index is rising, it shows there is strong participation in the price rise. This means the price rise is more likely to sustain itself./nThe same concept applies to a falling breadth indicator and a falling stock index value./nWhen the breadth indicator and a stock index diverge, that may forewarn of a reversal. Fewer stocks are moving in the stock index's direction. This means the stock index could be setting up to change direction.

Term: Break-Even Analysis: Formula and Calculation
Definition: Using the break-even point formula, businesses can determine how many units or dollars of sales cover the fixed and variable production costs./nThe break-even point (BEP) is considered a measure of the margin of safety./nBreak-even analysis is used broadly, from stock and options trading to corporate budgeting for various projects.

Term: Break-Even Price: Definition, Examples, and How To Calculate It
Definition: A break-even price describes a change of value that corresponds to just covering one's initial investment or cost./nFor an options contract, the break-even price is that level in an underlying security when it covers an option's premium./nIn manufacturing, the break-even price is the price at which the cost to manufacture a product is equal to its sale price./nBreak-even pricing is often used as a competitive strategy to gain market share, but a break-even price strategy can lead to the perception that a product is of low quality.

Term: Breakeven Point: Definition, Examples, and How to Calculate
Definition: In accounting, the breakeven point is calculated by dividing the fixed costs of production by the price per unit minus the variable costs of production./nThe breakeven point is the level of production at which the costs of production equal the revenues for a product./nIn investing, the breakeven point is said to be achieved when the market price of an asset is the same as its original cost./nA breakeven analysis can help with finding missing expenses, limiting decisions based on emotions, establishing goals, securing funding, and setting appropriate prices.

Term: Bretton Woods Agreement and the Institutions It Created Explained
Definition: The Bretton Woods Agreement and System created a collective international currency exchange regime that lasted from the mid-1940s to the early 1970s./nThe Bretton Woods System required a currency peg to the U.S. dollar which was in turn pegged to the price of gold./nThe Bretton Woods System collapsed in the 1970s but created a lasting influence on international currency exchange and trade through its development of the IMF and World Bank.

Term: Breakout: Definition, Meaning, Example, and What It Tells You
Definition: A breakout is when the price moves above a resistance level or moves below a support level./nBreakouts can be subjective since not all traders will recognize or use the same support and resistance levels./nBreakouts provide possible trading opportunities. A breakout to the upside signals traders to possible get long or cover short positions. A breakout to the downside signals traders to possibly get short or to sell long positions./nBreakouts with relatively high volume show conviction and interest, and therefore the price is more likely to continue moving in the breakout direction./nBreakouts on low relative volume are more prone to failure, so the price is less likely to trend in the breakout direction.

Term: Brick-and-Mortar Stores: Types, Advantages, and Disadvantages
Definition: Brick-and-mortar refers to a traditional business that has a physical store or stores where customers browse and make purchases in person./nThese kinds of traditional stores have had a harder time in the digital economy, in which web-based retailers such as eBay or Amazon benefit from lower operating costs and more flexibility for customers./nMany traditionally brick-and-mortar companies have created simultaneous, connected web-based businesses to better compete with online-only firms./nSimilarly, the long-standing and important brick-and-mortar model has had an impact on some previously web-only companies that have opened physical locations to realize the advantages of traditional retail.

Term: Bridge Financing Explained: Definition, Overview, and Example
Definition: Bridge financing can take the form of debt or equity and can be used during an IPO./nBridge loans are typically short-term in nature and involve high interest./nEquity bridge financing requires giving up a stake in the company in exchange for financing./nIPO bridge financing is used by companies going public. The financing covers the IPO costs and then is paid off when the company goes public.

Term: What Is a Bridge Loan and How Does It Work, With Example
Definition: A bridge loan is short-term financing used until a person or company secures permanent financing or removes an existing obligation./nBridge loans are often used in real estate, but many types of businesses use them as well./nHomeowners can use bridge loans toward the purchase of a new home while they wait for their current home to sell.

Term: Brexit Meaning and Impact: The Truth About the U.K. Leaving the EU
Definition: Brexit refers to the United Kingdom’s exit from the European Union (EU)./nBrexit took place on Jan. 31, 2020, following the June 2016 referendum in the country./nThe Leave side received 51.9% of the vote, while the Remain side got 48.1%./nNegotiations took place between the U.K. and the EU from 2017 to 2019 on the terms of a divorce deal./nThere was a transition period following Brexit that expired on Dec. 31, 2020.

Term: Broad Money: Definition, About Calculation, Example, and Benefits
Definition: Broad money is the most flexible method for measuring an economy's money supply, accounting for cash and other assets easily converted into currency./nThe formula for calculating money supply varies from country to country, so the term broad money is always defined to avoid misinterpretation./nCentral banks tend to keep tabs on broad money growth to help forecast inflation.

Term: Broker: Definition, Types, Regulation, and Examples
Definition: A broker is an individual or firm that acts as an intermediary between an investor and a securities exchange./nA broker can also refer to the role of a firm when it acts as an agent for a customer and charges the customer a commission for its services./nDiscount brokers execute trades on behalf of a client, but typically don’t provide investment advice./nFull-service brokers provide execution services as well as tailored investment advice and solutions./nBrokers register with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA), while investment advisers register through the SEC as registered investment advisors (RIAs).

Term: What Is a Broker-Dealer (B-D), and How Does It Work?
Definition: A broker-dealer is a financial entity that is engaged with trading securities on behalf of clients, but which may also trade for itself./nA broker-dealer is acting as a broker or agent when it executes orders on behalf of its clients, and as a dealer or principal when it trades for its own account./nThere are thousands of broker-dealers comprising two broad categories: a wirehouse, which sells its own products, or an independent broker-dealer, which sells products from outside sources

Term: What Is a Brokerage Account? Definition, How to Choose, and Types
