Definition: Investors have different financial and investment needs and should choose their brokerage firms accordingly./nInvestors who desire advisory services may benefit from a full-service brokerage firm, which charges higher fees than other brokerages./nFull-service firms charge either a flat fee based on the size of the account or commissions on the trades that they execute./nOnline brokerages charge lower fees and may suit investors who wish to conduct their own research, trades, and other account transactions./nRobo-advisors offer financial planning, investing, and portfolio management using algorithms and minimal human intervention.

Term: What Is a Brokerage Fee? How Fees Work and Types
Definition: A broker or agent charges a brokerage fee to execute transactions or provide specialized services./nBrokerage fees are based on a percentage of the transaction, as a flat fee, or as a hybrid of the two, and vary according to the industry and type of broker./nThe three main types of financial securities industry brokers that charge brokerage fees are full-service, discount, and online./nToday, many online brokerage platforms offer $0 brokerage fees for listed stocks and ETFs.

Term: What Is a Brokerage Firm? How It Makes Money, and Types
Definition: A brokerage company primarily acts as a middleman, connecting buyers and sellers to facilitate a transaction./nFull-service brokerage companies are compensated via a flat annual fee or fees per transaction./nOnline brokers offer a set amount of free stock trading but charge fees for other services./nThe lines are blurring, with full-service brokers launching phone apps and online discount brokers adding fee-based services.

Term: What Is a Brown Bag Meeting? Definition, Types, and Key Benefits
Definition: A brown bag meeting is an informal meeting that takes place in the workplace, generally around lunchtime./nBrown bag meetings are typically informal training and learning sessions offered by employers./nTopics for brown bag meetings can be work-related or geared to help employees with their lives outside of work./nThe seminar, small group meeting, hybrid meeting, and social meeting are the four most common types of brown bag meetings./nBrown bag meetings foster the sharing of information and teamwork and help ensure a consistent message is delivered.

Term: Brownfield Investment: Definition, Advantages, Vs. Greenfield
Definition: When a company or government entity purchases or leases existing production facilities to launch a new production activity, it is called a brownfield investment./nGreenfield investments, unlike brownfields, undertake new construction of property, plant, and equipment./nA brownfield investment is a common form of foreign direct investment (FDI)./nBrownfield investments come with many advantages, such as buildings already having been constructed, reduced time of startup, reduced costs, and buildings that are up to code./nBrownfield land could also be contaminated from prior use from pollution, hazardous material, or other contaminants./nWhen a property owner has no intention of allowing further use of vacant brownfield property, it is referred to as a mothballed brownfield.

Term: What Is an Economic Bubble and How Does It Work, With Examples
Definition: A bubble is an economic cycle that is characterized by the rapid escalation of market value, particularly in the price of assets./nThis fast inflation is followed by a quick decrease in value, or a contraction, that is sometimes referred to as a "crash" or a "bubble burst."/nBubbles are typically attributed to a change in investor behavior, although what causes this change in behavior is debated.

Term: What Is a Budget? Plus 11 Budgeting Myths Holding You Back
Definition: A budget is an estimation of revenue and expenses utilized by governments, businesses, and individuals of any income level./nA budget is a financial plan for a defined period that can greatly enhance the success of any financial undertaking./nCorporate budgets are essential for operating at peak efficiency./nAside from earmarking resources, a budget can also aid in setting goals, measuring outcomes, and planning contingencies./nPersonal budgets are extremely useful in helping individuals and families manage their finances.

Term: Budget Deficit: Causes, Effects, and Prevention Strategies
Definition: A budget deficit occurs when expenses exceed revenue./nCertain unanticipated events and policies may cause budget deficits./nCountries can counter budget deficits by raising taxes or cutting spending.

Term: What Is a Budget Surplus? What's the Impact, and Pros & Cons?
Definition: A budget surplus is when income or revenue exceeds expenditures./nGovernments and companies with surpluses have additional money that can be reinvested or used to pay off debts./nThe opposite of a surplus isa deficit, which occurs when spending exceeds revenues./nThe last time the U.S. ran a budget surplus was in 2001 under President Bill Clinton./nThe U.S. budget had a deficit of more than $421 billion as of January 2023.

Term: Budget Variance: Definition, Primary Causes, and Types
Definition: A budget variance is an accounting term that describes instances where actual costs are either higher or lower than the standard or projected costs./nAn unfavorable, or negative, budget variance is indicative of a budget shortfall, which may occur because revenues miss or costs come in higher than anticipated./nVariances may occur for internal or external reasons and include human error, poor expectations, and changing business or economic conditions.

Term: Build America Bonds (BABs): Types, Restrictions, Vs. Other Bonds
Build-Operate-Transfer Contract: Definition, Risks, and Framework
Definition: A build-operate-transfer (BOT) contract is a model used to finance large projects, typically infrastructure projects developed through public-private partnerships./nBOT projects are normally large-scale, greenfield infrastructure projects that would otherwise be financed, built, and operated solely by the government./nUnder a build-operate-transfer (BOT) contract, an entity—usually a government—grants a concession to a private company to finance, build, and operate a project for a period of 20 to 30 years, hoping to earn a profit./nAfter that period, the project is returned to the public entity that originally granted the concession.

Term: What Is a Bull? Definition in Investing, Traits, and Examples
Definition: A bull believes that the market will increase in value over time./nBears are the opposite of bulls; they believe that the general direction of prices in the market trends toward a decline./nA bullish investor can fall prey to a bull trap, when they believe a sudden increase in the value of a particular security is the beginning of a trend, resulting in the investor going long./nSome of the more common bullish patterns used by traders and investors include the Cup and Handle, Bull Flag, Bull Pennant, and Ascending Triangle.

Term: Bull Put Spread: How (and Why) To Trade This Options Strategy
Definition: A bull put spread is an options strategy that is used when the investor expects a moderate rise in the price of the underlying asset./nAn investor executes a bull put spread by buying a put option on a security and selling another put option for the same date but a higher strike price./nThe maximum loss is equal to the difference between the strike prices and the net credit received./nThe maximum profit is the difference in the premium costs of the two put options. This only occurs if the stock's price closes above the higher strike price at expiry.

Term: What Is a Bull Market, and How Can Investors Benefit From One?
Definition: A bull market is a period of time in financial markets when the price of an asset or security rises continuously./nThe commonly accepted definition of a bull market is when stock prices rise by 20%./nTraders employ a variety of strategies, such as increased buy and hold and retracement, to profit off bull markets./nThe opposite of a bull market is a bear market, when prices trend downward.

Term: What Is Bull Spread? How It Works As Trading Strategy and Example
Definition: A bull spread is an optimistic options strategy used when the investor expects a moderate rise in the price of the underlying asset./nBull spreads come in two types: bull call spreads, which use call options, and bull put spreads, which use put options./nBull spreads involve simultaneously buying and selling options with the same expiration date on the same asset, but at different strike prices./nBull spreads achieve maximum profit if the underlying asset closes at or above the higher strike price.

Term: Bull Call Spread: How this Options Trading Strategy Works
Definition: A bull call spread is an options strategy used when a trader is betting that an asset will have a limited increase in its price./nThe strategy uses two call options to create a range consisting of a lower strike price and an upper strike price./nThe bullish call spread can limit the losses of owning the asset, but it also caps the gains.

Term: Bullet Bond: Definition, Example, Vs. Amortizing Bond
Definition: A bullet bond is a non-callable bond in which the principal is repaid as a lump sum when the bond matures./nBoth governments and corporations issue bullet bonds in a variety of maturities./nThe issuer of a bullet bond accepts the risk that interest rates during the life of the bond will decrease, rendering its rate of return relatively costly.

Term: Bull Trap
Definition: A bull trap denotes a reversal that forces market participants on the wrong side of price action to exit positions with unexpected losses./nBull traps occur when buyers fail to support a rally above a breakout level./nTraders and investors can lower the frequency of bull traps by seeking confirmation following a breakout through technical indicators and/or pattern divergences.

Term: Bullet Repayment: Definition, Examples, Vs. Amortization
Bullish Engulfing Pattern: Definition, Example, and What It Means
Definition: A bullish engulfing pattern is a candlestick pattern that forms when a small black candlestick is followed the next day by a large white candlestick, the body of which completely overlaps or engulfs the body of the previous day’s candlestick./nBullish engulfing patterns are more likely to signal reversals when they are preceded by four or more black candlesticks./nInvestors should look not only to the two candlesticks which form the bullish engulfing pattern but also to the preceding candlesticks.

Term: Bullish Harami: Definition in Trading and Other Patterns
Definition: A bullish harami is a candlestick chart indicator used for spotting reversals in a bear trend./nIt is generally indicated by a small increase in price (signified by a white candle) that can be contained within the given equity's downward price movement (signified by black candles) from the past couple of days.

Term: Bullish Abandoned Baby: Definition and How Pattern Is Used
Definition: The bullish abandoned baby is a three-bar pattern following a downtrend./nIt consists of a strong down candle, a gapped down doji, and then a strong bullish candle that gaps up./nThis pattern signals the potential end of a downtrend and the start of a price move higher./nSome traders allow for slight variation. There may be more than one doji, or gaps may not be present after the first or second candle. But the overall psychology of the pattern should still be present.

Term: Bundle of Rights Definition in Real Estate and What's Included
Bungalow Definition: What Makes a House a Bungalow?
Definition: A bungalow is a style of house or cottage that is typically either a single story or has a second, half, or partial story, that is built into a sloped roof./nBungalows are typically small in terms of size and square footage and often are distinguished by the presence of dormer windows and verandas./nBungalows are cost-efficient, easy to maintain, and due to increased square footage versus multi-story homes, relatively easy to modify./nOn the downside, Bungalows have smaller and fewer rooms than multi-story houses, and are more vulnerable to break-ins, due to how low they sit on the ground.

Term: Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS): What it is, How it Works
Definition: The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) is an American government agency tasked with collecting and disseminating a range of economic and employment data./nThe BLS is responsible for two key inflation indicators: the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and Producer Price Index (PPI)./nIn addition, the BLS produces national and regional figures on employment, labor force participation, productivity, and wages.

Term: Burn Rate: What It Is, 2 Types, Formula, and Examples
Definition: The burn rate is the pace at which a new company not yet generating profits consumes its cash reserves./nThe burn rate is typically calculated in terms of the amount of cash that the company is spending per month./nGross burn is the total amount of operating costs that a company racks up each month, while net burn is the total amount of money that a company loses monthly./nThe burn rate affects a company’s financial “runway,” which is how long the company has before its operating capital is exhausted; a higher rate means a shorter runway.

Term: What Is a Bureaucracy and How It Works, With Examples
Definition: The word bureaucracy implies a complex structure with multiple layers and procedures./nThe systems that are put in place under a bureaucracy make decision-making slow./nBureaucracies can render systems formal and rigid, which is needed when following safety procedures is critical./nThe term bureaucracy is often criticized and deemed negative because of the implication that procedures are more important than efficiency./nThe Glass-Steagall Act is a good example of effective bureaucracy in place in the United States.

Term: Business Assets: Overview and Valuation Method
Definition: A business asset is a piece of property or equipment purchased exclusively or primarily for business use. They can also be intangible items, such as intellectual property./nBusiness assets are itemized and valued on the balance sheet. They are listed at historical cost and in order of liquidity./nMost business assets can be written off and either depreciated or expensed under section 179 in the year of purchase./nBusiness assets are divided into two sections: current assets and non-current assets./n﻿The value of business assets can be determined by an appraiser.

Term: Business Activities: Definition and 3 Main Types
Definition: Business activities are any events that are undertaken by a corporation for the purpose of earning a profit./nOperating activities relate directly to the business providing its goods to the market, including manufacturing, distributing, marketing, and selling; they provide most of the company's cash flow and hugely influence its profitability./nInvesting activities relate to thelong-term use of cash, such as buying or selling a property or piece of equipment, or gains and losses from investments in financial markets and operating subsidiaries./nFinancing activities include sources of cash from investors or banks, and the uses of cash paid to shareholders, such as payment of dividends or stock repurchases, and the repayment of loans.

Term: What Is a Business? Understanding Different Types and Company Sizes
Definition: A business is defined as an organization or enterprising entity engaged in commercial, industrial, or professional activities./nBusinesses can be for-profit entities or non-profit organizations./nBusiness types range from limited liability companies to sole proprietorships, corporations, and partnerships./nSome businesses run as small operations in a single industry while others are large operations that spread across many industries around the world./nApple and Walmart are two examples of well-known, successful businesses.

Term: What Is Business Banking? Definition and Services Offered
Definition: Business banking is a range of services provided by a bank to a business or corporation./nServices offered under business banking include loans, credit, savings accounts, and checking accounts, all of which are tailored specifically to the business./nBanks are able to offer business, retail, and investment banking services under one roof./nThe largest bank in the U.S. in terms of assets is JPMorgan Chase.

Term: What Is a Business Continuity Plan (BCP), and How Does It Work?
Definition: Business continuity plans (BCPs) are prevention and recovery systems for potential threats, such as natural disasters or cyber-attacks./nBCP is designed to protect personnel and assets and make sure they can function quickly when disaster strikes./nBCPs should be tested to ensure there are no weaknesses, which can be identified and corrected.

Term: Business Cycle: What It Is, How to Measure It, the 4 Phases
Definition: Business cycles are composed of concerted cyclical upswings and downswings in the broad measures of economic activity—output, employment, income, and sales./nThe alternating phases of the business cycle are expansions and contractions./nContractions often lead to recessions, but the entire phase isn't always a recession./nRecessions often start at the peak of the business cycle—when an expansion ends—and end at the trough of the business cycle, when the next expansion begins./nThe severity of a recession is measured by the three Ds: depth, diffusion, and duration.

Term: Business Economics: Definitions and Types
Definition: Business economics is a field of applied economics that studies the financial, organizational, market-related, and environmental issues faced by corporations./nBusiness economics encompasses subjects such as the concept of scarcity, production factors, distribution, and consumption./nManagerial economics is one important offshoot of business economics./nThe National Association for Business Economics (NABE) is the professional association for business economists in the U.S.

Term: Business Development Company (BDC): Definition and How to Invest
Definition: A business development company (BDC) is a type of closed-end fund that makes investments in developing and financially distressed firms./nMany BDCs are publicly traded and are open to retail investors./nBDCs offer investors high dividend yields and some capital appreciation potential./nBDCs' heavy use of leverage and small or distressed company targeting makes them relatively high-risk investments.

Term: Understanding Business Expenses and Which Are Tax Deductible
Definition: Business expenses are deductions from taxable income./nThe total of business expenses is subtracted from revenue to arrive at the business' total amount of taxable income./nThe IRS defines allowable business deductions as costs that are "ordinary and necessary" for the industry in which the business operates./nThe main deductible categories are direct expenses, indirect expenses, and interest on debt.

Term: What Is a Business Ecosystem and How Does It Work?
Definition: A business ecosystem is the network of organizations—including suppliers, distributors, customers, competitors, government agencies, and so on—involved in the delivery of a specific product or service through both competition and cooperation./nThe idea is that each entity in the ecosystem affects and is affected by the others, creating a constantly evolving relationship in which each entity must be flexible and adaptable in order to survive, as in a biological ecosystem./nEcosystems create strong barriers to entry for new competition as the ecosystem already consists of the players that allow it to function./nThe theory of business ecosystems was developed by business strategist James Moore in 1993.

Term: What Is Business Ethics? Definition, Principles, and Importance
Definition: Business ethics refers to implementing appropriate business policies and practices with regard to arguably controversial subjects./nSome issues that come up in a discussion of ethics include corporate governance, insider trading, bribery, discrimination, social responsibility, and fiduciary responsibilities./nThe law usually sets the tone for business ethics, providing a basic guideline that businesses can choose to follow to gain public approval.

Term: Business Exit Strategy: Definition, Examples, Best Types
Definition: A business exit strategy is a plan that a founder or owner of a business makes to sell their company, or share in a company, to other investors or other firms./nInitial public offerings (IPOs), strategic acquisitions, and management buyouts are among the more common exit strategies an owner might pursue./nIf the business is making money, an exit strategy lets the owner of the business cut their stake or completely get out of the business while making a profit./nIf the business is struggling, implementing an exit strategy or "exit plan" can allow the entrepreneur to limit losses.

Term: What Is Business Intelligence (BI)? Types, Benefits, and Examples
Definition: Business intelligence represents the technical infrastructure that collects, stores, and analyzes company data./nBusiness intelligence parses data and produces reports and information that help managers to make better decisions./nSoftware companies produce BI solutions for companies that wish to make better use of their data./nBI tools and software come in a wide variety of forms such as spreadsheets, reporting/query software, data visualization software, data mining tools, and online analytical processing (OLAP)./nSelf-service BI is an approach to analytics that allows individuals without a technical background to access and explore data.

Term: What Is Commercial Insurance?
Definition: Commercial insurance refers to insurance coverage intended for businesses instead of individuals./nCommercial insurance is also called business insurance./nBusiness insurance covers losses related to unexpected events like lawsuits, accidents, or natural disasters, among others./nDifferent types of commercial insurance products include general liability insurance, professional liability, property insurance, and home-based business insurance./nProduct liability, vehicle insurance, and business interruption insurance are also types of commercial insurance.

Term: How Companies Make Money
Definition: A business model is a company's core strategy for profitably doing business./nModels generally include information like products or services the business plans to sell, target markets, and any anticipated expenses./nThere are dozens of types of business models including retailers, manufacturers, fee-for-service, or freemium providers./nThe two levers of a business model are pricing and costs./nWhen evaluating a business model as an investor, consider whether the product being offered matches a true need in the market.

Term: Business-to-Business (B2B): What It Is and How It’s Used
Definition: Business-to-business (B2B) is a transaction or business conducted between one business and another, such as a wholesaler and retailer./nB2B transactions tend to happen in the supply chain where one company will purchase raw materials from another to be used in the manufacturing process./nB2B transactions are also commonplace for auto industry companies, as well as property management, housekeeping, and industrial cleanup companies./nMeanwhile, business-to-consumer transactions (B2C) are those made between a company and individual consumers.

Term: What Is Business Process Outsourcing (BPO), and How Does It Work?
Definition: Business process outsourcing (BPO) utilizes third-party vendors or subcontractors to carry out certain parts of their business operations./nBPO began with large manufacturing companies to aid with supply chain management,/nToday BPO has grown to include all sorts of sectors, including services companies./nBPO is considered "offshore outsourcing" if the vendor or subcontractor is located in a different country; for instance, in the case of customer support./nBPO today is an industry unto itself, with companies specializing in facilitating BPO to companies around the world.

Term: What Is Business Risk? Definition, Factors, and Examples
Definition: Business risk is any exposure a company or organization has to factor(s) that may lower its profits or cause it to go bankrupt./nThe sources of business risk are varied but include changes in consumer taste and demand, the state of the overall economy, and government rules and regulations./nRisk can be created by external factors that the business doesn't control, as well as by decisions made within the company's management or executive team./nWhile companies may not be able to completely avoid business risk, they can take steps to mitigate its impact, including the development of a strategic risk plan.

Term: Business Plan: What It Is, What's Included, and How to Write One
Definition: A business plan is a document describing a company's business activities and how it plans to achieve its goals./nStartup companies use business plans to get off the ground and attract outside investors./nFor established companies, a business plan can help keep the executive team focused on and working toward the company's short- and long-term objectives./nThere is no single format that a business plan must follow, but there are certain key elements that most companies will want to include.

Term: B2C: How Business-to-Consumer Sales Works, 5 Types and Examples
Definition: Business-to-consumer refers to the process of businesses selling products and services directly to consumers, with no middle person./nB2C typically refers to online retailers who sell products and services to consumers through the internet./nOnline B2C became a threat to traditional retailers, who profited from adding a markup to the price./nHowever, companies like Amazon, eBay, and Priceline have thrived, ultimately becoming industry disruptors.

Term: Business to Government (B2G): Selling to The Government
Definition: B2G, or business to government, is the provision of goods and services to government agencies at the federal, state, and local levels./nMost contracts are granted in response to a request for proposal (RFP) from an agency./nBusinesses bid for contracts by submitting responses to RFPs.

Term: Buy-Sell Agreement Definition, Types, Key Considerations
Definition: Buy and sell agreements stipulate how a partner's share of a business may be transferred in the event of the partner's death or departure./nBuy and sell agreements may also establish a method for determining the value of a business./nThe most common buy and sell agreements are cross-purchase, and entity-purchase (redemption); some agreements will combine the two./nCross-purchase agreements allow remaining owners to buy the interests of a deceased or selling owner./nRedemption agreements require the business entity to buy the interests of the selling owner.

Term: Butterfly Spread: What It Is, With Types Explained & Example
Definition: A butterfly spread is an options strategy that combines both bull and bear spreads./nThese are neutral strategies that come with a fixed risk and capped profits and losses./nButterfly spreads pay off the most if the underlying asset doesn't move before the option expires./nThese spreads use four options and three different strike prices./nThe upper and lower strike prices are equal distance from the middle, or at-the-money, strike price.

Term: What Is Buy and Hold? How the Investing Strategy Works
Definition: Buy and hold is a long-term passive strategy where investors keep a relatively stable portfolio over time, regardless of short-term fluctuations./nBuy and hold investors tend to outperform active management, on average, over longer time horizons and after fees, and they can typically defer capital gains taxes./nCritics, however, argue that buy-and-hold investors may not sell at optimal times.

Term: Buy-In For Stocks: How Share Repurchases Work
Definition: A buy-in is a reference to the repurchasing of shares by an investor because the original seller failed to deliver the shares as promised./nA buy-in can also be an agreement to purchase shares of something, in some cases to buy a stake in a company that also has other owners./nBeyond the financial markets, a buy-in is an act of agreeing with or accepting the terms that someone is offering, such as in a job or organization./nIn a forced buy-in, shares are repurchased to cover an open short position, as opposed to a traditional buy-in.

Term: Buy-IN Management Buyout (BIMBO): What it is, How it Works
Definition: A buy-in management buyout (BIMBO) occurs when an outside management team joins a company (buying-in) while also buying out the existing management team./nThis form of leveraged buyout (LBO) is used to streamline the transition from one owner to the next with little interruption in business operations./nLike all LBOs, there are still risks of disruption, conflicts, and reduced performance - but these may be minimized as the new managers have bought in as owners as well.

Term: Buy Side Investing: Examples and Benefits
Definition: The buy-side is a segment of financial markets made up of investing institutions that buy securities for money-management purposes./nThe sell-side is the opposite of the buy-side, providing only investment recommendations and services to facilitate the purchasing of securities by the buy-side./nA business involved in buy-side activities will purchase stocks, bonds, and other financial products based on the needs and strategy of their company's or client's portfolio./nCommon buy-side institutions include hedge funds, pension funds, and mutual funds.

Term: What Is a Buy Stop Order and When Would You Use One?
Definition: A buy stop order is an order to purchase a security only once the price of the security reaches the specified stop price./nThe stop price is entered at a level, or strike, set above the current market price./nIt is a strategy to profit from an upward movement in a stock’s price by placing an order in advance./nBuy stop orders can also be used to protect against unlimited losses of an uncovered short position.

Term: What Is Buy to Cover and How Does It Work?
Definition: Buy to cover refers to a buy trade order that closes a trader's short position./nShort positions are borrowed from a broker and a buy to cover allows the short positions to be "covered" and returned to the original lender./nThe trade is made on the belief that a stock's price will decline, so shares are sold at a higher price and then bought back at a lower price./nBuy to cover orders are generally margin trades.

Term: Buy Limit Order: Definition, Pros & Cons, and Example
Definition: A buy limit order is an order to purchase an asset at or below a specified maximum price level./nA buy limit, however, is not guaranteed to be filled if the price does not reach the limit price or moves too quickly through the price./nBuy limits control costs but can result in missed opportunities in fast-moving market conditions./nAll order types are useful and have their own advantages and disadvantages.

Term: Buy The Dips
Definition: Buying the dips refers to going long an asset or security after its price has experienced a short-term decline, in repeated fashion./nBuying the dips can be profitable in long-term uptrends, but unprofitable or tougher during secular downtrends./nDip buying can lower one's average cost of owning a position, but the risk and reward of dip-buying should be constantly evaluated.

Term: Buyback: What It Means and Why Companies Do It
Definition: A buyback is a company's purchase of its own shares in the stock market./nA repurchase reduces the number of shares outstanding, inflating earnings per share and often leading to further increases in the stock's market price./nA share repurchase is viewed by investors as a positive sign that the business has plenty of cash.

Term: Buy to Open: Definition, What It Means in Trading, and Example
Definition: A buy-to-open order is generally used by traders to open positions in a given option or stock./nBuying to open an options position can offset or hedge other risks in a portfolio./nA buy-to-open position in options creates the opportunity for large gains with minimal losses, but it has a high risk of expiring worthless.

Term: Buyer's Market: Definition, Characteristics, and Example
Definition: A buyer's market is created when purchasers have an advantage over sellers in price negotiations./nBuyer's markets typically occur when supply increases, demand decreases, or both happen at once./nThe term buyer's market is commonly used to describe real estate conditions, but it can apply to any type of market where conditions favor buyers./nThe opposite of a buyer's market is a seller's market, a situation in which conditions favor sellers.

Term: Buying on Margin: How It's Done, Risks and Rewards
Definition: Buying on margin means you are investing with borrowed money./nBuying on margin amplifies both gains and losses./nIf your account falls below the maintenance margin, your broker can sell some or all of your portfolio to get your account back in balance.

Term: Buying Power (Excess Equity): Definition in Trading and Example
Definition: Buying power is the money an investor has available to purchase securities./nBuying power equals the total cash held in the brokerage account plus all available margin./nA standard margin account provides two times equity in buying power./nA pattern day trading account provides four times equity in buying power./nAdditional buying power magnifies both profits and losses.

Term: What Is a Buyout, With Types and Examples
Definition: A buyout is the acquisition of a controlling interest in a company and is used synonymously with the term acquisition./nIf the stake is bought by the firm’s management, it is known as a management buyout, while if high levels of debt are used to fund the buyout, it is called a leveraged buyout./nBuyouts often occur when a company is going private.

Term: What Is a C Corp? Definition, Pros & Cons, and Taxes
Definition: A C corporation legally separates owners' or shareholders' assets and income from that of the corporation./nC corporations limit the liability of investors and firm owners since the most that they can lose in the business's failure is the amount they have invested in it./nC corporations are mandated to hold annual meetings and have a board of directors that is voted on by shareholders.

Term: What Is the C-Suite?: Meaning and Positions Defined
Definition: “C-suite” refers to the executive-level managers within a company./nCommon C-suite executives include chief executive officer (CEO), chief financial officer (CFO), chief operating officer (COO), and chief information officer (CIO)./nC-level members work together to ensure a company stays true to its established plans and policies./nHistorically, there are more men in C-suite positions than women./nC-suite execs often work long hours and have high-stress jobs, but usually, these jobs come with extremely lucrative compensation packages.

Term: Call: Definitions in Finance, Call Options & Call Auctions
Definition: A call can refer to either a call auction or a call option./nA call option grants the right, but not the obligation, for a buyer to purchase an underlying instrument at a given strike price within a given timeframe./nCall options are commonly used for speculating on up-moves, hedging, or writing covered calls./nThe call auction is a type of trading where prices are determined by trading during a specified time and period./nA call auction is a trading method used in illiquid markets to determine security prices.

Term: What Is a Call Option and How to Use It With Example
Definition: A call is an option contract giving the owner the right, but not the obligation, to buy an underlying security at a specific price within a specified time./nThe specified price is called the strike price, and the specified time during which the sale can be made is its expiration (expiry) or time to maturity./nYou pay a fee to purchase a call option, called the premium; this per-share charge is the maximum you can lose on a call option./nCall options may be purchased for speculation or sold for income purposes or tax management./nCall options may also be combined for use in spread or combination strategies.

Term: Callable (or Redeemable) Bond Types, Example, Pros & Cons
Definition: A callable bond is a debt security that can be redeemed early by the issuer before its maturity at the issuer's discretion./nA callable bond allows companies to pay off their debt early and benefit from favorable interest rate drops./nA callable bond benefits the issuer, and so investors of these bonds are compensated with a more attractive interest rate than on otherwise similar non-callable bonds.

Term: Canceled Check Definition and How to Get a Copy
Definition: A canceled check is one that has been cleared by cashing or depositing it, rendering the check null and void for further transactions./nA canceled check indicates that the clearing process has been completed, so canceled checks can be used as proof of payment./nA check may also be canceled by its writer before it has been cashed by alerting the issuing bank.

Term: Cap and Trade Basics: What It Is, How It Works, Pros & Cons
Definition: Cap-and-trade energy programs are intended to gradually reduce pollution by giving companies an incentive to invest in clean alternatives./nThe government issues a set amount of permits to companies that comprise a cap on allowed carbon dioxide emissions./nCompanies that surpass the cap are taxed, while companies that cut their emissions may sell or trade unused credits./nThe total limit (or cap) on pollution credits declines over time, giving corporations an incentive to find cheaper alternatives./nCritics say that caps could be set too high and give companies an excuse to avoid investing in cleaner alternatives for too long.

Term: Candlestick Chart Definition and Basics Explained
Definition: Candlestick charts display the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a specific period./nCandlesticks originated from Japanese rice merchants and traders to track market prices and daily momentum hundreds of years before becoming popularized in the United States./nCandlesticks can be used by traders looking for chart patterns.

Term: Capacity Utilization Rate: Definition, Formula, Uses in Business
Definition: Calculating the capacity utilization rate pinpoints the degree to which an organization is achieving its full production potential./nBusiness executives can use the rate to decide how much production can be ramped up without the cost of investing in new equipment./nA nation's economists use it to track how its industries are performing given the current economic environment. Fiscal and monetary policy may be adjusted based on the number./nCapacity utilization is most relevant to industries that produce physical products rather than services./nIn the U.S., the Federal Reserve tracks capacity utilization rates in 89 industries within the mining, manufacturing, and utility sectors.

Term: CAPE Ratio (Shiller PE Ratio): Definition, Formula, Uses, Example
Definition: The CAPE ratio is used to analyze a publicly held company's long-term financial performance while considering the impact of different economic cycles on the company's earnings./nThe CAPE ratio is similar to the price-to-earnings ratio and is used to determine whether a stock is over-or under-valued./nThe ratio considers the impact of economic influences by comparing a stock price to average earnings, adjusted for inflation, over a 10-year period.

Term: Capital: Definition, How It's Used, Structure, and Types in Business
Definition: The capital of a business is the money it has available to pay for its day-to-day operations and to fund its future growth./nThe four major types of capital include working capital, debt, equity, and trading capital. Trading capital is used by brokerages and other financial institutions./nAny debt capital is offset by a debt liability on the balance sheet./nThe capital structure of a company determines what mix of these types of capital it uses to fund its business./nEconomists look at the capital of a family, a business, or an entire economy to evaluate how efficiently it is using its resources.

Term: What the Capital Adequacy Ratio (CAR) Measures, With Formula
Definition: CAR is critical to ensure that banks have a large enough financial cushion to absorb a reasonable amount of losses before they become insolvent./nCAR is used by regulators to determine capital adequacy for banks and to run stress tests./nTier 1 and tier 2 capital are both used to measure CAR./nThe downside of using CAR is that it doesn't account for the risk of a potential run on the bank, or what would happen in a financial crisis.

Term: Capital Account Explained: How It Works and Why It's Important
Definition: The capital account, on a national level, represents the balance of payments for a country./nThe capital account keeps track of the net change in a nation's assets and liabilities during a year./nThe capital account's balance will inform economists whether the country is a net importer or net exporter of capital.

Term: What Is a Capital Asset? How It Works, With Example
Definition: Capital assets are assets that are used in a company's business operations to generate revenue over the course of more than one year./nThey are often recorded as an asset on the balance sheet and expensed over the useful life of the asset through a process called depreciation./nExpensing the asset over the course of its useful life helps to match the cost of the asset with the revenue it generated over the same time period./nCapital assets may be tangible or intangible, though most capital assets are related to buildings, land, or FFE./nCapital assets are different than ordinary assets in that capital assets are more useful in the long-term whereas ordinary assets primary value is in the day-to-day operations of the company.

Term: Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM): Definition, Formula, and Assumptions
Definition: The capital asset pricing model, or CAPM, is a financial model that calculates the expected rate of return for an asset or investment./nCAPM does this by using the expected return on both the market and a risk-free asset, and the asset’s correlation or sensitivity to the market (beta)./nThere are some limitations to the CAPM, such as making unrealistic assumptions and relying on a linear interpretation of risk vs. return./nDespite its issues, the CAPM formula is still widely used because it is simple and allows for easy comparisons of investment alternatives./nFor instance, it is used in conjunction with modern portfolio theory (MPT) to understand portfolio risk and expected return.

Term: Capital Budgeting: Definition, Methods, and Examples
Definition: Capital budgeting is used by companies to evaluate major projects and investments, such as new plants or equipment./nThe process involves analyzing a project's cash inflows and outflows to determine whether the expected return meets a set benchmark./nThe major methods of capital budgeting include discounted cash flow, payback analysis, and throughput analysis.

Term: Capital Employed: Calculation and How to Use It to Determine Return
Definition: Capital employed is derived by subtracting current liabilities from total assets; or alternatively by adding noncurrent liabilities to owners' equity./nCapital employed tells you how much capital has been put to use in an investment./nReturn on capital employed (ROCE) is a common financial analysis metric to determine the return on an investment.

Term: Capital Gains: Definition, Rules, Taxes, and Asset Types
Definition: A capital gain is the increase in a capital asset's value and is realized when the asset is sold./nCapital gains may apply to any type of asset, including investments and those purchased for personal use./nThe gain may be short-term (one year or less) or long-term (more than one year) and must be claimed on income taxes./nUnrealized gains and losses reflect an increase or decrease in an investment's value but are not considered taxable./nA capital loss is incurred when there is a decrease in the capital asset value compared to an asset's purchase price.

Term: Capital Gains Tax: What It Is, How It Works, and Current Rates
Definition: Capital gains taxes are due only after an investment is sold./nCapital gains taxes apply only to capital assets, which include stocks, bonds, digital assets like cryptocurrencies and NFTs, jewelry, coin collections, and real estate./nLong-term gains are levied on profits of investments held for more than a year./nShort-term gains are taxed at an individual's regular income tax rate, which is higher than the tax on long-term gains.

Term: Capital Goods: Types, Examples, vs. Consumer Goods
Definition: Capital goods are physical assets a company uses to produce goods and services for consumers./nCapital goods include fixed assets, such as buildings, machinery, equipment, vehicles, and tools./nCapital goods differ from consumer goods, which are the end product of production and manufacturing.

Term: Capital Expenditure (CapEx) Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: Capital expenditures are payments made for goods or services that are recorded or capitalized on a company's balance sheet instead of expensed on the income statement./nSpending is important for companies to maintain existing property and equipment and to invest in new technology and other assets for growth./nIf an item has a useful life of less than one year, it must be expensed on the income statement rather than capitalized, which means it isn't considered CapEx./nUnlike CapEx, operating expenses (OpEx) are shorter-term expenses used for the day-to-day operations of a business./nExamples of CapEx include the purchase of land, vehicles, buildings, or heavy machinery.

Term: What Is a Capital Improvement, and How Does It Work?
Definition: A capital improvement is a durable upgrade, adaptation, or enhancement of a property that increases its value, often involving a structural change or restoration./nThe IRS grants special tax treatment to qualified capital improvements, distinguishing them from ordinary repairs./nIn addition to enhancing a home, capital improvements can increase the cost basis of a property, which in turn reduces the tax burden when it is sold./nIn some states, capital improvements can allow landlords to increase rent more than what the law would otherwise allow.

Term: Capital Investment: Types, Example, and How It Works
Definition: Capital investment is the expenditure of money to fund a company's long-term growth./nThe term often refers to a company's acquisition of permanent fixed assets such as real estate and equipment./nCapital assets are reported as non-current assets and most are depreciated./nThe funds for capital investment can come from a number of sources, including cash on hand, though big projects are most often financed through obtaining loans or issuing stock./nExamples of capital investments are land, buildings, machinery, equipment, or software.

Term: S&P Capital IQ Definition, Products and Services
Definition: S&P Capital IQ is the research arm of S&P Global, the provider of research, ratings, and market indices./nThe company was first bought by McGraw-Hill Financial in 2004 when it was called Capital IQ. McGraw-Hill has since been rebranded as S&P Global and Capital IQ is now known as S&P Capital IQ./nS&P Capital IQ analyzes more than 135 billion data points from an assortment of sources to provide actionable intelligence to subscribers.

Term: Capital Lease: What It Means in Accounting, 4 Criteria
Definition: A capital lease is a contract entitling a renter to the temporary use of an asset/nA capital lease is considered a purchase of an asset, while an operating lease is handled as a true lease under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP)./nUnder a capital lease, the leased asset is treated for accounting purposes as if it were actually owned by the lessee and is recorded on the balance sheet as such./nAn operating lease does not grant any ownership-like rights to the leased asset, and is treated differently in accounting terms.

Term: Capital Loss Carryover: Definition, Rules, and Example
Definition: Capital lossesthat exceed capital gains in a year may be used to offset capital gains or as a deduction against ordinary income up to $3,000 in any one tax year./nNet capital losses in excess of $3,000 can be carried forward indefinitely until the amount is exhausted./nDue to the wash-sale IRS rule, investors need to be careful not to repurchase any stock sold for a loss within 30 days, or the capital loss does not qualify for the beneficial tax treatment./nCapital loss carryovers give taxpayers flexibility as to when to use them to benefit from losses./nCapital losses are reported on Schedule D.

Term: Understanding Capital Market Line (CML) and How to Calculate It
Definition: The capital market line (CML) represents portfolios that optimally combine risk and return./nCML is a special case of the capital allocation line (CAL) where the risk portfolio is the market portfolio. Thus, the slope of the CML is the Sharpe ratio of the market portfolio./nThe intercept point of CML and efficient frontier would result in the most efficient portfolio called the tangency portfolio./nAs a generalization, buy assets if Sharpe ratio is above CML and sell if Sharpe ratio is below CML.

Term: What Are Capital Markets, and How Do They Work?
Definition: Capital markets refer to the venues where funds are exchanged between suppliers and those who seek capital for their own use./nSuppliers in capital markets are typically banks and investors while those who seek capital are businesses, governments, and individuals./nCapital markets are used to sell different financial instruments, including equities and debt securities./nThese markets are divided into two categories: primary and secondary markets./nThe best-known capital markets include the stock market and the bond markets.

Term: Capital Project: Definition, Examples, and How Funding Works
Definition: A capital project is an often-pricey, long-term project to expand, maintain, or improve upon a significant piece of property./nA capital project is distinct from other company projects as it is large in scale, high-cost, and requires considerable planning relative to other investments./nCapital projects often refer to infrastructure, like roads or railways, or, in the case of a corporation, the development of a manufacturing plant or office.

Term: Capital Structure Definition, Types, Importance, and Examples
Definition: Capital structure is how a company funds its overall operations and growth./nDebt consists of borrowed money that is due back to the lender, commonly with interest expense./nEquity consists of ownership rights in the company, without the need to pay back any investment./nThe debt-to-equity (D/E) ratio is useful in determining the riskiness of a company's borrowing practices.

Term: Capital Stock: Definition, Example, Preferred vs. Common Stock
Definition: Capital stock is the amount of common and preferred shares that a company is authorized to issue—recorded on the balance sheet under shareholders' equity./nThe amount of capital stock is the maximum amount of shares that a company can ever have outstanding./nIssuing capital stock allows a company to raise money without incurring debt./nThe drawbacks of issuing capital stock are that the company relinquishes more control and dilutes the value of outstanding shares.

Term: What Is Capitalism: Varieties, History, Pros & Cons, Socialism
Definition: Capitalism is an economic system characterized by private ownership of the means of production, with labor solely paid wages./nCapitalism depends on the enforcement of private property rights, which provide incentives for investment in and productive use of capital./nCapitalism developed out of feudalism and mercantilism in Europe and dramatically expanded industrialization and the large-scale availability of mass-market consumer goods./nPure capitalism can be contrasted with pure socialism, in which all means of production are collective or state-owned.

Term: Capitalization Rate: Cap Rate Defined With Formula and Examples
Definition: The capitalization rate is calculated by dividing a property's net operating income by the current market value./nThis ratio, expressed as a percentage, is an estimation of an investor's potential return on a real estate investment./nThe cap rate is most useful as a comparison of the relative value of similar real estate investments.

Term: Capitalization: What It Means in Accounting and Finance
Definition: In accounting, capitalization allows for an asset to be depreciated over its useful life—appearing on the balance sheet rather than the income statement./nAssets are capitalized to record the expense over time to match the period when benefit is received to when costs are recognized./nIn finance, capitalization refers to the book value or the total of a company's debt and equity./nCompanies that are undercapitalized mean the company does not have enough capital on hand to finance all obligations./nMarket capitalization is the dollar value of a company's outstanding shares and is calculated as the current market price multiplied by the total number of outstanding shares.

Term: Capitalized Cost: Definition, Example, Pros and Cons
Definition: With capitalized costs, the monetary value isn’t leaving the company with the purchase of an item, as it is retained in the form of a fixed or intangible asset./nCapitalized costs are depreciated or amortized over time instead of being expensed immediately./nThe purpose ofcapitalizing costsis to better line up the cost of using an asset with the length of time in which the asset is generating revenue./nCompanies each have a dollar value threshold for what it considers an expense versus a capitalizable cost./nEmployee salaries and bonuses may be capitalized in certain situations.

Term: Capitalize: What It Is and What It Means When a Cost Is Capitalized
Definition: To capitalize is to record a cost or expense on the balance sheet for the purposes of delaying full recognition of the expense./nCapitalization is used in corporate accounting to match the timing of cash flows./nIn finance, capitalization is a reference to a company's capital structure, or the total of a company's long-term debt, stock, and retained earnings.

Term: Capitalization (Cap) Table: What It Is and How to Create and Maintain One
Definition: A capitalization table, or cap table, is a table showing the equity ownership capitalization for a company./nThe capitalization table is essential for financial decisions involving equity ownership, market capitalization, and market value./nCapitalization tables help private companies maintain the calculation of their market value. In the private market, they are also important for shareholder reporting and new capital issuance marketing.

Term: Capitalized Interest: Definition and Example
Definition: Capitalized interest is the cost of borrowing to obtain a long-term asset./nUnlike typical interest expenses, capitalized interest is not expensed immediately on a company's income statement./nBecause many companies finance long-term assets with debt, companies are allowed to expense the assets over the long term./nBy capitalizing the interest expense, companies are able to generate revenue from the asset in order to pay for it over time./nCapital interest is expensed over time as part of the depreciation process of the asset.

Term: Capitulation: What It Is in Finance and Investing, With Examples
Definition: Capitulation happens when a significant proportion of investors succumbs to fear and sells over a short period of time, causing the price of a security or a market to drop sharply amid high trading volume./nCapitulation marks a short-term low in the price and is followed by at least a relief rally./nUntil the price rebounds significantly, there can be no assurance the apparent "capitulation" won't be followed by additional dramatic drops./nCapitulation causes heavy turnover among investors, enabling a rebound by replacing risk-averse sellers with risk-tolerant buyers, but it can't guarantee those buyers won't eventually sell even lower.

Term: Carbon Credits and How They Can Offset Your Carbon Footprint
Definition: Carbon credits were devised as a mechanism to reduce greenhouse gas emissions./nCompanies receive a set number of credits that decline over time and they can sell any excess credits to another company./nCarbon credits create a monetary incentive for companies to reduce their carbon emissions./nCarbon credits are based on the cap-and-trade model that was used to reduce sulfur pollution in the 1990s./nNegotiators at the Glasgow COP26 climate change summit in November 2021 agreed to create a global carbon credit offset trading market.

Term: Carried Interest Explained: Who It Benefits and How It Works
Definition: Carried interest is a share of profits from a private equity, venture capital, or hedge fund paid as incentive compensation to the fund's general partner./nCarried interest typically is only paid if a fund achieves a specified minimum return./nIn most cases, carried interest is considered a return on investment and taxed as a capital gain rather than ordinary income, usually at a lower rate./nBecause carried interest is typically distributed after a period of years, it defers taxes in the manner of an unrealized capital gain.

Term: What Is Carding? How It Works, Prevention Methods, and Examples
Definition: Carding is a third-party attack on an individual's financial information./nCard forums are online venues for stolen credit and debit card information and criminal techniques./nNewer technologies like CVVs, CAPTCHA, and multifactor authentication protect users against carders.

Term: Carriage and Insurance Paid to (CIP): Definition and Example
Definition: The term “carriage and insurance paid to (CIP)” signifies that the seller will pay freight and insurance in sending goods to someone chosen by the seller at a mutually agreeable location./nThe seller must insure the goods being sent for 110% of their contract value./nCIP is an Incoterm, one of 11 devised by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) and accepted around the world.

Term: Carve-Out: Definition as Business Strategy, Meaning, and Example
Definition: In a carve-out, the parent company sells some of its shares in its subsidiary to the public through an initial public offering (IPO), effectively establishing the subsidiary as a standalone company./nSince shares are sold to the public, a carve-out also establishes a new set of shareholders in the subsidiary./nA carve-out allows a companyto capitalize on a business segmentthat may not be part of its core operations as it still retains an equity stake in the subsidiary./nA carve-out is similar to a spin-off, however, a spin-off is when a parent company transfers shares to existing shareholders as opposed to new ones.

Term: Cash Advance: Definition, Types, and Impact on Credit Score
Definition: A cash advance is a type of short-term loan, often issued by a credit card company, and usually involving high-interest rates and fees./nOther types of cash advances include merchant cash advances, which are alternative loans for businesses, and payday loans, which have exorbitantly high rates and are prohibited in many states./nA credit card cash advance won't directly hurt your credit score, but it will hurt it indirectly by lifting your outstanding balance and your credit utilization ratio, which is a factor in credit scores.

Term: Cash Accounting Definition, Example & Limitations
Definition: Cash accounting is simple and straightforward. Transactions are recorded only when money goes in or out of an account./nCash accounting doesn't work as well for larger companies or companies with a large inventory because it can obscure the true financial position./nThe alternative to cash accounting is accrual accounting, where transactions are recorded as revenues are earned and expenses are incurred, regardless of the exchange of cash.

Term: Cash-and-Carry Arbitrage Definition and Example
Definition: Cash-and-carry arbitrage seeks to exploit pricing inefficiencies between spot and futures markets for an asset by going long in the spot market and opening a short on the futures contract./nThe idea is to "carry" the asset for physical delivery until the expiry date for the futures contract./nCash-and-carry-arbitrage is not entirely without risk because there may be expenses associated with physically "carrying" an asset until expiry.

Term: Cash and Cash Equivalents (CCE) Definition: Types and Examples
Definition: Cash and cash equivalents refers to the line item on the balance sheet that reports the value of a company's assets that are cash or can be converted into cash immediately./nCash equivalents include bank accounts and some types of marketable securities such as commercial paper and short-term government bonds./nCash equivalents should have maturities of 90 days or less./nCash equivalents must also be able to be liquidated to cash; for this reason, cash equivalents need to be highly liquid assets./nA company carries cash and cash equivalents to pay its short-term bills but to also preserve capital for long-term capital deployment.

Term: What Is Cash Back? Hint: It's Not Free Money
Definition: Cash back refers to a credit card benefit that refunds the cardholder’s account a small percentage of the sum spent on purchases./nCash back rewards are actual cash that can be applied to a credit card bill or received as a check or bank account deposit./nCash back apps and websites can offer consumers a way to earn money back on purchases./nSome cash-back rewards programs come with annual fees or a highannual percentage rate(APR), but not all./nCash back can also refer to the practice of charging an amount above the purchase price on a debit card and receiving the extra money in cash at the point of sale.

Term: Cash Balance Pension Plan: Overview, Pros and Cons, and FAQ
Definition: A cash balance pension plan is one in which participants receive a set percentage of their yearly compensation plus interest charges./nThis type of plan is maintained on an individual account basis, much like a defined-contribution plan./nThe benefit of such plans is that contribution limits increase with age./nCash balance pension plans do not have contribution limits because the employer funds them to meet a specific account balance at an employee's planned retirement date.

Term: Cash Budget Definition: Parts and How to Create One
Definition: A cash budget is a company's estimation of cash inflows and outflows over a specific period of time, which can be weekly, monthly, quarterly, or annually./nA company will use a cash budget to determine whether it has sufficient cash to continue operating over the given time frame./nA cash budget will also provide a company with insight into its cash needs and any surpluses, which help it determine if the business is using cash effectively./nCash budgets can be viewed as short-term cash budgets, usually, a time frame of weeks to months, or long-term cash budgets, which are viewed as years./nA company must manage its sales and expenses to reach optimal cash flow.

Term: Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC): What Is It, and How Is It Calculated?
Definition: The cash conversion cycle (CCC) is a metric that expresses the length of time (in days) that it takes for a company to convert its investments in inventory and other resources into cash flows from sales./nThis metric takes into account the time needed for the company to sell its inventory, the time required for the company to collect receivables, and the time that the company is allowed to pay its bills without incurring any penalties./nCCC will differ by industry sector based on the nature of business operations.

Term: Cash Cow: Definition, Investment Type, and Examples
Definition: A cash cow is a business or unit that, once it has been paid for, will produce steady cash flow over its lifespan./nA cash cow is also one of four quadrants in the BCG matrix, which looks at the value of different units within a corporation./nCash cows are part of mature, slow-growing industries, have a large chunk of the market share and require minimal investment to thrive.

Term: Cash Dividend: Definition, Example, Vs. Stock Dividend
Definition: A cash dividend is a payment made by a company to its stockholders in the form of periodic distributions of cash (as opposed to in stock or any other form)/nCash dividends are often paid on a regular basis, such as monthly or quarterly, but are sometimes one-time-only payouts, such as after a settlement./nMost brokers offer a choice to accept or reinvest cash dividends./nDividend-paying companies are typically established, with stable cash flow, and beyond the growth stage./nDividend reinvestment plans (DRIPs) are increasingly common among companies and brokers.

Term: What Are Cash Equivalents? Types, Features, Examples
Definition: Cash and cash equivalents are actual cash on hand and securities that are similar to cash./nThe total for cash and cash equivalents is always shown on the top line of a company balance sheet because these current assets are the mostliquid assets./nStocks, bonds, and cash equivalents make up the three main asset classes in finance./nThese low-risk securities include U.S. government T-bills, bank CDs, bankers' acceptances, corporate commercial paper, and othermoney marketinstruments./nThe amount of cash and cash equivalents on hand speaks to a company's financial health as it reflects the ability to pay short-term obligations.

Term: Cash Flow: What It Is, How It Works, and How to Analyze It
Definition: Cash flow is the movement of money in and out of a company./nCash received signifies inflows, and cash spent is outflows./nThe cash flow statement is a financial statement that reports a company's sources and use of cash over time./nA company's cash flow can be categorized as cash flows from operations, investing, and financing.

Term: Cash Flow from Financing Activities (CFF) Formula & Calculations
Definition: Cash flow from financing activities is a section of a company’s cash flow statement that shows the net flows of cash that are used to fund the company./nFinancing activities include transactions involving debt, equity, and dividends./nDebt and equity financing are reflected in the cash flow from financing section, which varies with the different capital structures, dividend policies, or debt terms that companies may have.

Term: Cash Flow From Operating Activities (CFO) Defined, With Formulas
Definition: Cash flow from operating activities is an important benchmark to determine the financial success of a company's core business activities./nCash flow from operating activities is the first section depicted on a cash flow statement, which also includes cash from investing and financing activities./nThere are two methods for depicting cash from operating activities on a cash flow statement: the indirect method and the direct method./nThe indirect method begins with net income from the income statement then adds back noncash items to arrive at a cash basis figure./nThe direct method tracks all transactions in a period on a cash basis and uses actual cash inflows and outflows on the cash flow statement.

Term: Cash Flow From Investing Activities Explained: Types and Examples
Definition: Cash flow from investing activities is a section of the cash flow statement that shows the cash generated or spent relating to investment activities./nInvesting activities include purchases of physical assets, investments in securities, or the sale of securities or assets./nNegative cash flow from investing activities might not be a bad sign if management is investing in the long-term health of the company.

Term: Cash Flow Statement: How to Read and Understand It
Definition: A cash flow statement provides data regarding all cash inflows that a company receives from its ongoing operations and external investment sources./nThe cash flow statement includes cash made by the business through operations, investment, and financing—the sum of which is called net cash flow./nThe first section of the cash flow statement is cash flow from operations, which includes transactions from all operational business activities./nCash flow from investment is the second section of the cash flow statement, and is the result of investment gains and losses./nCash flow from financing is the final section, which provides an overview of cash used from debt and equity.

Term: Cash on Delivery (COD): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: Cash on delivery (COD) is when a recipient pays for a good or service at the time of delivery./nA COD transaction can take several forms, each affecting a company’s accounting./nCOD shipping offers customers an advantage in that they have time to save and make a full payment./nSellers receive faster payment for sales as long as the buyer accepts the goods.

Term: What Is Cash Management in Accounting and Why Is It Important?
Definition: Cash management is the process of managing cash inflows and outflows./nThere are many cash management considerations and solutions available in the financial marketplace for both individuals and businesses./nIndividuals can use options like banks and financial institutions for their cash management needs./nFor businesses, the cash flow statement is a central component of cash flow management./nThe cash flow statement is a central component of corporate cash flow management.

Term: Cash-on-Cash Return in Real Estate: Definition, Calculation
Definition: Cash-on-cash return measures the amount of cash flow relative to the amount of cash invested in a property investment and is calculated on a pre-tax basis./nThe cash-on-cash return metric measures only the return for the current period, typically one year, rather than for the life of the investment or project./nCash-on-cash return can also be used as a forecasting tool to set a target for projected earnings and expenses.

Term: Cash Ratio: Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The cash ratio is a liquidity measure that shows a company's ability to cover its short-term obligations using only cash and cash equivalents./nThe cash ratio is derived by adding a company's total reserves of cash and near-cash securities and dividing that sum by its total current liabilities./nThe cash ratio is more conservative than other liquidity ratios because it only considers a company's most liquid resources./nA calculation that's greater than one means that a company has more cash on hand than current debts. A calculation of less than one means that a company has more short-term debt than cash./nLenders, creditors, and investors use the cash ratio to evaluate the short-term risk of a company.

Term: What Is Cash Surrender Value? How It Compares to Cash Value
Definition: The cash surrender value is the amount of money that a life insurance company pays out to a policyholder if they decide to cancel the plan./nCash value is the amount of equity in a life insurance policy./nA policyholder builds cash value with premium payments and it grows over time./nLife insurance companies could deduct fees for a policy surrender./nA policyholder could withdraw or borrow their cash value as an alternative to surrendering.

Term: Cash-Out Refinancing Explained: How It Works and When to Do It
Definition: In a cash-out refinance, a new mortgage is taken out for more than your previous mortgage balance, and the difference is paid to you in cash./nYou usually pay a higher interest rate or more points on a cash-out refinance mortgage compared to a rate-and-term refinance, in which a mortgage amount stays the same./nA lender will determine how much cash you can receive with cash-out refinancing, based on standards such as your property’s loan-to-value (LTV) ratio and your credit profile.

Term: What Is Cash Value in Life Insurance? Explanation With Example
Definition: Permanent life insurance policies such as whole life and universal life can accumulate cash value over time./nCash value life insurance is more expensive than term life insurance./nUnlike term life insurance, cash value insurance policies don't expire after a specific number of years./nYou may borrow against a cash value life insurance policy./nYou may also withdraw cash from the policy, but this will reduce the death benefit.

Term: Caveat Emptor (Buyer Beware): What It Is, and What Replaced It
Definition: Caveat emptor is a Latin phrase that means "let the buyer beware."/nThe principle of caveat emptor is sometimes used in legal contracts as a type of disclaimer./nA caveat emptor disclaimer precludes post-purchase disputes despite the seller having more information than the buyer about the quality of a good or service./nCaveat emptor is more often accepted in real estate transactions, and in some states than others in the U.S./nThe U.S. has generally shifted from caveat emptor to caveat venditor, or, "let the seller beware."

Term: Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance (CFDA): What It Was
Definition: The Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance (CFDA) was an directory of federal assistance programs, including grants, loans, and scholarships./nIn 2018, the CFDA website was consolidated with other government systems. It is now available through the Assistance Listings section of SAM.gov./nCFDA detailed the federal grants, loans, scholarships, counseling, and other assistance programs available to the American public./nCFDA recipients included corporate and government agencies, United States territories, and U.S. citizens.

Term: Central Limit Theorem (CLT): Definition and Key Characteristics
Definition: The central limit theorem (CLT) states that the distribution of sample means approximates a normal distribution as the sample size gets larger, regardless of the population's distribution./nSample sizes equal to or greater than 30 are often considered sufficient for the CLT to hold./nA key aspect of CLT is that the average of the sample means and standard deviations will equal the population mean and standard deviation./nA sufficiently large sample size can predict the characteristics of a population more accurately./nCLT is useful in finance when analyzing a large collection of securities to estimate portfolio distributions and traits for returns, risk, and correlation.

Term: What Is a Central Counterparty Clearing House (CCP) in Trading?
Definition: A central counterparty clearing house (CCP) is an organization, usually operated by a major bank, that exists in European countries to help facilitate derivatives and equities trading./nCentral counterparty clearing houses (CCPs) perform two primary functions as the intermediary in a transaction: clearing and settlement./nA CCP acts as a counterparty to both sellers and buyers, collecting money from each, which allows it to guarantee the terms of a trade.

Term: Centrally Planned Economy
Definition: In a centrally planned economy, major economic decisions are made by a central authority such as the government./nCentrally planned economies aredifferentfrom market economies where large numbers of individual consumers and profit-seeking private firms operate most or all of the economy./nCentral planning allows the government to marshal society's resources for goals that might not be achieved by market forces alone./nCentral planning is commonly associated with socialist or communist forms of government./nOther countries might resort to central planning in times of war or national emergency.

Term: What Is a Certificate of Insurance (COI)? When You Need One
Definition: A certificate of insurance (COI) is issued by an insurance company or broker and verifies the existence of an insurance policy./nSmall business owners and contractors typically require a COI that grants protection against liability for workplace accidents or injuries to conduct business./nIf you receive a COI from a business, check the policy coverage dates and the limits of the policy.

Term: What a Certainty Equivalent Is, What It Tells You, How to Use It
Definition: The certainty equivalent represents the amount of guaranteed money an investor would accept now instead of taking a risk of getting more money at a future date./nThe certainty equivalent varies between investors based on their risk tolerance, and a retiree would have a higher certainty equivalent because they're less willing to risk their retirement funds./nThe certainty equivalent is closely related to the concept of risk premium or the amount of additional return an investor requires to choose a risky investment over a safer investment.

Term: Certificate of Origin (CO): Definition, Types, and How to Get One
Definition: A certificate of origin (CO) records the country of origin that an imported good has come from./nThe CO is often mandated by importing countries and included in trade agreements, as it is used to levy the appropriate import tax, if any./nIn the U.S., the American World Trade Chamber of Commerce (AWTCC) provides the electronic COs needed for export./nPreferred COs are truncated versions that verify they qualify under a free-trade agreement.

Term: Certified Financial Planner™ (CFP®): What It Is and How to Become One
Definition: A certified financial planner (CFP®) has received a formal designation from the Certified Financial Planner Board of Standards, Inc./nCFPs help individuals in a variety of areas in managing their finances, such as retirement, investing, education, insurance, and taxes./nBecoming a CFP®is a difficult and stringent process. It requires years of experience, successful completion of standardized exams, a demonstration of ethics, and a formal education./nThe most important aspect quality of a CFP®is that they have a fiduciary duty, meaning they must make decisions with their client's best interests in mind.

Term: Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA): Definition, Exam
Definition: Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA) is the global standard for professionals who have acareer in information systems, in particular, auditing, control, and security./nCISA candidates must pass a comprehensive exam and satisfy industry work experience requirements./nCISA candidates must have a minimum of five years of professional experience and must undertake 20 hours of training per year to keep their designation./nThe CISA exam is broken into five domains, and each domain is weighted differently./nThe four-hour CISA exam must be passed with a score of 450 in order to earn the CISA certification.

Term: Certified Management Accountant (CMA) Definition and Examples
Definition: The certified management accountant (CMA) designation indicates expertise in financial accounting and decision-making./nThis certification prepares professionals for a wide variety of careers./nCMAs are required to adhere to a strict set of professional standards, in addition to passing a rigorous two-part exam.

Term: Certified Public Accountant: What the CPA Credential Means
