Definition: The certified public accountant (CPA) is a professional designation given to qualified accountants./nTo become a CPA, you must pass a rigorous exam, known as the Uniform CPA Exam./nCertified public accountants must meet education, work, and examination requirements—including holding a bachelor’s degree typically, but not required to be, in business administration, finance, or accounting, and completing 150 hours of education./nOther requirements for the CPA designation include having two or more years experience in public accounting./nCPAs generally hold various positions in public and corporate accounting, as well as executive positions, such as the controller or chief financial officer (CFO).

Term: Chair: Definition in Business, Responsibilties, Vs. CEO
Definition: A chair is an executive elected by a company's board of directors who is responsible for presiding over board meetings./nA chair often sets the agenda and has significant sway as to how the board votes./nThe CEO runs the company and is the person that company executives report to, but since the CEO is appointed by the board, the chair can influence who will be chosen as CEO./nIn some companies, the roles of CEO and chair are combined, which can reduce transparency and accountability due to fewer checks and balances.

Term: What Is Channel Stuffing? How It Works, Purpose, and Legality
Definition: Channel stuffing refers to the practice of a company shipping more goods to distributors and retailers along the distribution channel than end-users are likely to buy in a reasonable time period./nBy channel stuffing, distributors temporarily increase sales figures and related profit measures for a particular period./nRegulators frown on the practice and consider it deceptive. In some cases, legal action can be brought to the offending company.

Term: What Does Ceteris Paribus Mean in Economics?
Definition: Ceteris paribus is a Latin phrase that generally means "all other things being equal."/nIn economics, it acts as a shorthand indication of the effect one economic variable has on another, provided all other variables remain the same./nMany economists rely on ceteris paribus to describe relative tendencies in markets and to build and test economic models./nThe difficulty with ceteris paribus is the challenge of holding all other variables constant in an effort to isolate what is driving change./nIn reality, one can never assume "all other things being equal."

Term: Chapter 11 Bankruptcy: What's Involved, Pros & Cons of Filing
Definition: A Chapter 11 bankruptcy allows a company to stay in business and restructure its finances and operations./nIf a company filing for Chapter 11 opts to propose a reorganization plan, it must be in the best interest of the creditors./nIf the debtor does not put forth a plan, the creditors may propose one instead./nMany major corporations, including General Motors and United Airlines, have used Chapter 11 bankruptcies as an opportunity to restructure their debts while continuing to do business.

Term: Chart of Accounts (COA) Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A chart of accounts is a financial organizational tool that provides a complete listing, by category, of every account in the general ledger of a company./nIt is used to organize finances and give interested parties, such as investors and shareholders, a clearer view and understanding of a company’s financial health./nTo ensure the quick location of specific accounts, each COA typically contains an identification code, name, and brief description./nCOAs can be modified by a company to fit its size and type of business./nIt's important to use the same COA format over time for the accuracy of period-to-period comparisons.

Term: Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA): Definition and Exams
Definition: The CFA charter is one of the most respected designations in finance and is widely considered to be the gold standard in the field of investment analysis./nTo become a charter holder, candidates must pass three difficult exams, have a bachelors degree, and have at least 4,000 hours of relevant professional experience over a minimum of three years. Passing the CFA Program exams requires strong discipline and an extensive amount of studying./nThere are more than 200,000 CFA charter holders worldwide in 164 countries./nThe designation is handed out by the CFA Institute, which has 11 offices worldwide and 160 local member societies./nTheCFA Institutewas formerly the Association for Investment Management and Research (AIMR).

Term: What Is a Chartered Retirement Planning Counselor (CRPC)?
Definition: A chartered retirement planning counselor has earned a professional designation awarded by the College for Financial Planning./nThe study program includes training in making a comprehensive assessment of an individual's financial needs before or after retirement, including sources of retirement income, personal savings, income taxes, estate planning, and more./nIndividuals who have earned the CRPC designation report a 9% increase in earnings, according to the college.

Term: What Is a Chartered Accountant (CA) and What Do They Do?
Definition: Chartered accountants are financial professionals who execute accounting procedures./nThe CA designation is granted to accounting professionals in many countries around the world, aside from the United States./nThe equivalent to the CA designation in the U.S. is a chartered public accountant./nCAs typically focus on one of the following areas: audit and assurance, financial accounting and reporting, management accounting, and applied finance or taxation./nSome chartered accountant institutions have reciprocity agreements with the U.S., whereby if they pass certain exams, they can work as CPAs.

Term: Chattel Mortgage: Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: A chattel mortgage is a loan to purchase movable personal property, such as construction equipment./nMobile or manufactured homes, where the homeowner buys the residential unit but not the land it occupies, are financed with chattel mortgages./nChattel mortgages tend to carry higher interest rates and have fewer consumer protections than regular mortgages.

Term: Cheapest to Deliver (CTD): Definition and Calculation Formula
Definition: Cheapest to deliver is the cheapest security that can be delivered in a futures contract to a long position to satisfy the contract specifications./nIt is common in Treasury bond futures contracts./nDetermining the cheapest to deliver security is important for the short position because there is a difference between a security's market price and the conversion factor used to determine its value.

Term: Check: What It Is, How Bank Checks Work, and How to Write One
Definition: A check is a written, dated, and signed draft that directs a bank to pay a specific sum of money to the bearer./nChecks instruct a financial institution to transfer funds from the payor’s account to the payee or that person's account./nCheck features include the date, the payee line, the amount of the check, the payor’s endorsement, and a memo line./nTypes of checks include certified checks, cashier’s checks, and payroll checks, also called paychecks./nIn some countries, such as Canada and England, the spelling used is “cheque.”

Term: Checks and Balances: Definition, Examples, and How They Work
Definition: Checks and balances refer to the separation of power to avoid one entity or body wielding too much power./nChecks and balances can help reduce mistakes and prevent improper behavior in organizations./nChecks and balances are most commonly used in the context of government, for example in the U.S. government through the establishment of the executive branch, the legislative branch, and the judicial branch./nChecks and balances are important in businesses and other organizations where one individual can make decisions that affect operations, such as the CEO or a majority shareholder./nThe idea of checks and balances dates back as far as the ancient Rome.

Term: Chi-Square (χ2) Statistic: What It Is, Examples, How and When to Use the Test
Chief Executive Officer (CEO): What They Do vs. Other Chief Roles
Definition: The chief executive officer (CEO) is the highest-ranking person in a company./nWhile every company differs, CEOs are often responsible for expanding the company, driving profitability, and, in the case of public companies, improving share prices. CEOs manage the overall operations of a company./nAcross many companies, CEOs are elected by the board of directors./nStudies suggest that 45% of company performance is influenced by the CEO, while others show that they affect 15% of the variance in profitability.

Term: What Is a Chief Financial Officer (CFO)? Role and Responsibilities
Definition: A chief financial officer is a top-level executive./nThe CFO is a financial controller who handles everything relating to cash flow, financial planning, and taxation issues./nA CFO is often the highest financial position and the third-highest position in a company, playing a vital role in the company's strategic initiatives./nFinancial reports completed under a CFO must adhere to financial standards./nPeople interested in becoming a CFO must have an academic and professional background in finance, economics, and/or analysis.

Term: Chief Operating Officer (COO): Definition, Types, and Qualifications
Definition: The chief operating officer (COO) is a senior executive tasked with overseeing the day-to-day administrative and operational functions of a business./nThe COO typically reports directly to the chief executive officer (CEO) and is considered to be second in the chain of command./nDepending on the CEO's preference, the COO often handles a company's internal affairs, while the CEO functions as the public face of the company, and thereby handles all outward-facing communication./nSkills required to be a COO include strong analytical, managerial, communication, and leadership skills./nThere are generally seven different types of COOs that are best suited for different situations and different companies.

Term: Chief Technology Officer (CTO): Definition, How to Become One, Average Salary
Definition: A chief technology officer (CTO) is an executive who is responsible for the management of an organization's research and development (R&D) as well as its technological needs./nAs of May 12, 2024, the average base salary of a CTO is $303,528./nDepending on the company, a CTO may play one of several roles, including strategic planner, customer relations liaison, and overseer of infrastructure./nBecoming a CTO often involves at least 15 years of IT experience, along with a graduate degree and certifications in computer sciences and business administration.

Term: Child Tax Credit Definition: How It Works and How to Claim It
Definition: The Child Tax Credit is a $2,000-per-child tax benefit claimed by filing Form 1040 and attaching Schedule 8812 to the return./nTo qualify for the credit, the taxpayer's dependent must generally be under the age of 17 and must have a Social Security number./nThe full benefit is available to people whose income did not exceed $400,000 for joint filers, or $200,000 for single filers. It phases out at higher income levels./nUp to $1,600 of the credit is refundable in the 2023 tax year, rising to $1,700 in 2024.

Term: Churn Rate: What It Means, Examples, and Calculations
Definition: The churn rate measures a company's loss of subscribers for a given period of time./nChurn rates can be applied to subscription-based businesses as well as to the number of employees that leave a firm./nChurn rate is the opposite of growth rate, which measures the acquisition of customers./nFor a company to experience growth it must ensure that its new subscriptions are higher than its lost subscriptions in a given period./nEach industry will have a different average churn rate that companies can compare themselves with to understand their competitiveness.

Term: Chinese Wall: Definition and Examples in Business and Finance
Definition: An ethical wall is a business term used to describe a virtual barrier erected to block the exchange of information between departments in a company./nThe wall is not a physical one, but an virtual one intended to prevent the sharing of information that might lead to ethical or legal violations./nIn the financial industry, the need for such barriers grew with the enactment of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act of 1999 (GLBA), which repealed federal laws banning firms from any combination of banking, investing, and insurance services.

Term: Circular Flow Model Definition and Calculation
Definition: The circular flow model demonstrates how money moves from producers to households and back again in an endless loop./nIn an economy, money moves from producers to workers as wages and then back from workers to producers as workers spend money on products and services./nThe models can be made more complex to include additions to the money supply, like exports, and leakages from the money supply, like imports./nWhen all of these factors are totaled, the result is a nation's gross domestic product (GDP) or the national income./nAnalyzing the circular flow model and its current impact on GDP can help governments and central banks adjust monetary and fiscal policy to improve an economy.

Term: Churning: Definition and Types in Finance
Definition: Churning is excessive trading of assets in a client's brokerage account in order to generate commissions./nChurning is illegal and unethical and is subject to severe fines and sanctions./nBrokerages may charge a commission on trades or a flat percentage fee for managed accounts./nFlat-fee accounts can be subjected to "reverse churning," in which little or no trading is done in return for an annual slice of the assets./nInvestors can avoid churning and reverse churning by maintaining an active role in decision-making regarding their portfolios.

Term: Classical Economics
Definition: Classical economic theory was developed shortly after the birth of western capitalism. It refers to the dominant school of thought for economics in the 18th and 19th centuries./nClassical economic theory helped countries to migrate from monarchic rule to capitalistic democracies with self-regulation./nAdam Smith’s 1776 release of theWealth of Nationshighlights some of the most prominent developments in classical economics./nTheories to explain value, price, supply, demand, and distribution, were the focus of classical economics./nClassical economics was eventually replaced with more updated ideas, such as Keynesian economics, which called for more government intervention.

Term: Clawback: Definition, Meaning, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A clawback is a contractual provision that requires an employee to return money that's already paid by an employer, sometimes with a penalty./nClawbacks act as insurance policies in the event of fraud or misconduct, a drop in company profits, or poor employee performance./nProvisions typically only involve incentive-based pay such as bonuses or other benefits./nClawbacks are used primarily in the financial industry but they can also be found in government contracts, pensions, and Medicaid.

Term: Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914: History, Amendments, Significance
Definition: The Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914 continues to regulate U.S. business practices today./nIntended to strengthen earlier antitrust legislation, the act prohibits anti-competitive mergers, predatory and discriminatory pricing, and other forms of unethical corporate behavior./nThe act also protects individuals by allowing lawsuits against companies and upholding the rights of labor to organize and protest peacefully./nThere have been several amendments to the act, expanding its provisions./nThe law is jointly enforced by the FTC and DOJ.

Term: Clearinghouse: An Essential Intermediary in the Financial Markets
Definition: A clearinghouse or clearing division is an intermediary between a buyer and a seller in a financial market./nIn acting as the middleman, the clearinghouse provides the security and efficiency that is integral for financial market stability./nTo mitigate default risk in futures trading, clearinghouses impose margin requirements.

Term: What Is Clearing? Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Clearing is the correct and timely transfer of funds to the seller and securities to the buyer./nA specialized organization often acts as an intermediary known as a clearinghouse and assumes the role of tacit buyer and seller to reconcile orders between transacting parties./nClearing is necessary to match all buy and sell orders to ensure smoother and more efficient markets./nWhen trades don't clear, the resulting out trades can cause real monetary losses./nThe clearing process protects the parties involved in a transaction by recording the details and validating the availability of funds.

Term: Close Position: Definition, How It Works in Trading, and Example
Definition: Closing a position refers to canceling out an existing position in the market by taking the opposite position./nIn a short sale, this would mean buying back the security, while a long position entails selling the security./nA closing transaction is generally initiated by a trader but, in some instances, it may also be forced closed by brokerage firms if certain conditions are met.

Term: What Is a Closed Economy and Why Are There None Today?
Definition: A closed economy refers to a country that produces all of its own goods and services and doesn't participate in international trade./nClosed economies are virtually nonexistent today, although some countries come closer than others to having one./nEven in countries with relatively open economies, governments may close off a specific sector or industry from international competition through the use of quotas, subsidies, and tariffs—a practice often referred to as protectionism.

Term: How a Closed-End Fund Works and Differs From an Open-End Fund
Definition: The initial capital for a closed-end fund is raised through a one-time offering of a limited number of shares in the fund./nThe shares may then be bought and sold on a public stock exchange, but no new shares can be created./nClosed-end funds are usually actively managed, unlike index mutual funds and many ETFs, and typically concentrate on a single industry, sector, or region.

Term: What Is Cloud Computing?
Definition: Cloud computing is the on-demand delivery of computing services such as servers, storage, databases, networking, software, and analytics./nCloud-based storage makes it possible to save files to a remote source./nCloud data storage platforms include Google Drive, Dropbox, OneDrive, and Box.

Term: CBOE Options Exchange
Definition: The CBOE is an important options exchange based in Chicago, founded in 1973./nThe CBOE Options Exchange was previously the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE)./nIn 2010 the exchange incorporated as a holding company with the exchange as its main asset./nIn 2017 the holding company and exchange rebranded as CBOE Global Markets Inc. and the CBOE Options Exchange, respectively./nCBOE is home to the VIX volatility index and many other volatility instruments.

Term: Chicago Mercantile Exchange: Definition, History, and Regulation
Definition: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, or Merc, is an organized exchange for trading futures and options./nCME was originally called the Chicago Butter and Egg Board and was used for trading agricultural products, such as wheat and corn./nIn the 1970s the CME added financial futures, followed shortly by precious metals, Treasuries, and other assets./nIn 2007, the CME merged with the Chicago Board of Trade to create CME Group, one of the world's largest financial exchange operators. CME Group now owns several other exchanges in different cities./nNowadays, CME is also known for trading unusual commodities like Bitcoin futures and weather derivatives.

Term: Code of Ethics: Understanding Its Types, Uses Through Examples
Definition: A code of ethics sets out an organization's ethical guidelines and best practices to follow for honesty, integrity, and professionalism./nFor members of an organization, violating the code of ethics can result in sanctions including termination./nIn some industries, including banking and finance, specific laws govern business conduct. In others, a code of ethics may be voluntarily adopted./nThe main types of codes of ethics include a compliance-based code of ethics, a value-based code of ethics, and a code of ethics among professionals./nA focus on climate change has become an integral part of companies' codes of ethics, detailing their commitment to sustainability.

Term: Coase Theorem: What It Means in Economics and Law, with Examples
Definition: The Coase Theorem argues that under the right conditions, parties to a dispute over property rights will be able to negotiate an economically optimal solution, regardless of the initial distribution of the property rights./nThe Coase Theorem offers a potentially useful way to think about how to best resolve conflicts between competing businesses or other economic uses of limited resources./nFor the Coase Theorem to apply fully, the conditions of efficient, competitive markets and—most importantly—zero transaction costs must occur./nIn the real world, it is rare that perfect economic conditions exist, making the Coase Theorem better suited to explaining why inefficiencies exist as opposed to a way to resolve disputes.

Term: Coefficient of Variation: Meaning and How to Use It
Definition: The coefficient of variation (CV) is a statistical measure of the relative dispersion of data points in a data series around the mean./nIt represents the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean./nThe CV is useful for comparing the degree of variation from one data series to another, even if the means are drastically different from one another./nIn finance, the coefficient of variation allowsinvestorsto determine how much volatility, or risk, is assumed in comparison to the amount of return expected from investments./nThe lower the ratio of the standard deviation to mean return, the better the risk-return tradeoff.

Term: Coefficient of Determination: How to Calculate It and Interpret the Result
Definition: The coefficient of determination is a complex idea centered on statistical analysis of data and financial modeling./nThe coefficient of determination is used to explain the relationship between an independent and dependent variable./nThe coefficient of determination is commonly called r-squared (or r2) for the statistical value it represents./nThis measure is represented as a value between 0.0 and 1.0, where a value of 1.0 indicates a perfect correlation. Thus, it is a reliable model for future forecasts, while a value of 0.0 suggests that asset prices are not a function of dependency on the index.

Term: The Collar Options Strategy Explained in Simple Terms
Definition: A collar is an options strategy that involves buying a downside put and selling an upside call to protect against large losses, but that also limits large upside gains./nThe protective collar strategy involves two strategies known as a protective put and covered call./nAn investor's best-case scenario is when the underlying stock price is equal to the strike price of the written call option at expiry.

Term: Coinsurance: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Coinsurance is the percentage under an insurance plan that the insured person pays toward a covered expense or service./nCoinsurance kicks in after the policy deductible is satisfied./nOne of the most common coinsurance breakdowns is the 80/20 split: The insurer pays 80%, the insured 20%./nCopays require the insured to pay a set dollar amount at the time of the service./nThe coinsurance clause in a property insurance policy requires that a home is insured for a percentage of its total cash or replacement value.

Term: Collateral Definition, Types, & Examples
Definition: Collateral is an item of value pledged to secure a loan./nCollateral reduces the risk for lenders./nIf a borrower defaults on the loan, the lender can seize the collateral and sell it to recoup its losses./nMortgages and car loans are two types of collateralized loans./nOther personal assets, such as a savings or investment account, can be used to secure a collateralized personal loan.

Term: Collateralized Debt Obligation (CDOs): What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A collateralized debt obligation is a complex structured finance product that is backed by a pool of loans and other assets./nThese underlying assets serve as collateral if the loan goes into default./nThe tranches of CDOs indicate the level of risk in the underlying loans, with senior tranches having the lowest risk./nCDOs backed by risky subprime mortgages were one of the causes of the financial crisis between 2007 and 2009./nThough risky and not for all investors, CDOs are a viable tool for diversifying risk and creating more liquid capital for investment banks.

Term: Collateralized Loan Obligation (CLO) Structure, Benefits, and Risks
Definition: A collateralized loan obligation (CLO) is a single security backed by a pool of debt./nCLOs are often corporate loans with low credit ratings or loans taken out by private equity firms to conduct leveraged buyouts./nWith a CLO, the investor receives scheduled debt payments from the underlying loans, assuming most of the risk if borrowers default.

Term: What Is a Collateralized Mortgage Obligation (CMO)?
Definition: Collateralized mortgage obligations are investment debt securities consisting of packaged mortgages organized according to their risk profiles./nThey are similar to collateralized debt obligations, which are a broader collection of debt obligations across multiple financial instruments./nCMOs played a prominent role during the 2008 financial crisis when they ballooned in size.

Term: Collection Agency: Definition, How It Works, and Regulations
Definition: A collection agency is a company that lenders use to recover funds that are past due or from accounts that are in default./nCollection agencies work closely with lenders to try to retrieve delinquent funds./nCollection agencies are regulated by the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) and bound by rules about what they can and cannot do to collect funds.

Term: Combined Loan-to-Value (CLTV) Ratio Definition and Formula
Definition: CLTV ratio is the ratio of all loans on a property to the property's value./nLenders consider CLTV ratios in determining the risk of a borrower defaulting./nIn general, most lenders are willing to lend to borrowers with strong credit scores and CLTV ratios of 80% and below./nThe real estate bubble of 2008-2009 underscored the relevance of keeping an eye on CLTV ratios.

Term: Combined Ratio: Definition, What It Measures, Formula, Examples
Definition: The combined ratio is a measure of profitability used by an insurance company to gauge how well it is performing in its daily operations./nThe combined ratio is typically expressed as a percentage./nA ratio below 100 percent indicates that the company is making an underwriting profit, while a ratio above 100 percent means that it is paying out more money in claims that it is receiving from premiums./nMany insurance companies believe that the combined ratio is the best way to measure success because it does not include investment income and only includes profit earned through efficient management.

Term: Collusion: Definition, Examples, and Preventative Steps
Definition: Collusion occurs when entities or individuals work together to influence a market or pricing to their advantage./nActs of collusion can include price fixing, synchronized advertising, and sharing insider information./nAntitrust and whistleblower laws help to deter collusion./nCollusion is illegal in the United States.

Term: Commerce: What It Is, How It Differs From Business and Trade
Definition: Commerce began when prehistoric humans started exchanging goods and services for mutual benefit./nToday, commerce commonly refers to the large-scale purchases and sales of goods and services./nCommerce is a subset of business that focuses on the distribution of goods./nSelling a single item is a transaction. All transactions are collectively called commerce./nE-commerce is a variation of commerce that entails selling goods and services electronically via the Internet.

Term: Command Economy: Definition, How It Works, and Characteristics
Definition: In a command economy, the central government dictates the level of production of goods and controls their distribution and prices./nProponents of command economies argue that government control rather than private enterprise can ensure the fair distribution of goods and services./nIn a free-market system, private enterprises set production and price levels based on demand.

Term: Commercial: What It Means in Business and the Financial Markets
Definition: Commercial refers to activities of commerce—business operations to earn profits./nNon-commercial activity can be conducted by non-profit organizations or government agencies./nIn financial markets, the term is used to describe a trading activity that is hedged using derivatives contracts./nCommercial positions in the options and futures markets generally indicate hedging activity, while non-commercial positions denote speculative activity./nA commercial may also refer to an advertisement broadcast over a media channel.

Term: Commercial Loan: What It Is, How It Works, Different Types
Definition: A commercial loan is done between a bank and a business, used to fund operating costs and capital expenditures./nMany commercial loans require collateral, such as property or equipment./nCompanies generally have to provide financial statements to prove their ability to repay./nAlthough most commercial loans are short-term, they can be “rolled,” or renewed to extend the life of the loan.

Term: What Is a Commercial Mortgage-Backed Security (CMBS)?
Definition: CMBS are secured by mortgages on commercial properties rather than residential real estate./nCommercial mortgage-backed securities are in the form of bonds, and the underlying loans typically are contained within trusts./nThe loans in a CMBS act as collateral—with principal and interest passed on to investors—in the event of default.

Term: How Do Commercial Banks Work, and Why Do They Matter?
Definition: Commercial banks offer basic banking services, including deposit accounts and loans, to consumers and businesses./nThese financial institutions make money from a variety of fees and by earning interest income from loans./nCommercial banks have traditionally been located in physical locations, but a growing number now operate exclusively online./nCommercial banks are important to the economy because they create capital, credit, and liquidity in the market.

Term: Commercial Real Estate Definition and Types
Definition: Commercial real estate refers to properties used specifically for business or income-generating purposes./nCommercial real estate differs from residential real estate because it has the potential to generate profit for the property owner through capital gain or rental income./nThe four main classes of commercial real estate are office space, industrial, multifamily rentals, and retail./nCommercial real estate provides rental income as well as the potential for some capital appreciation for investors./nPublicly traded real estate investment trusts (REITs) are a feasible way for individuals to indirectly invest in commercial real estate.

Term: What Is Commercialization, Plus the Product Roll-Out Process
Definition: Commercialization is the process of bringing new products or services to market./nCommercialization requires a carefully-developed three-tiered product roll-out and marketing strategy, that includes the ideation phase, the business process, and the stakeholder stage./nThe broader act of commercialization entails production, distribution, marketing, sales, customer support, and other key functions critical to achieving the commercial success of the new product or service.

Term: Commercial Paper: Definition, Advantages, and Example
Definition: Commercial paper is a form of unsecured, short-term debt./nIt's commonly issued by companies to finance their payrolls, payables, inventories, and other short-term liabilities./nMaturities on commercial paper range from one to 270 days, with an average of around 30 days./nCommercial paper is issued at a discount and matures at its face value./nThe minimum denomination of commercial paper is $100,000 and it pays a fixed rate of interest that fluctuates with the market.

Term: Commission: Definition and Examples, Vs. Fees
Definition: Full-service brokerages derive much of their profit from charging commissions on client transactions./nCommission-based advisors make money from buying and selling products on behalf of their clients./nIn the financial-services sector, commissions and fees are different, where fees are a flat rate for managing a client's money./nWhen considering a brokerage or advisor, look at the full list of commissions for services and be wary of financial advisors who appear interested in selling products just for commissions rather than for your best interest./nToday, most online brokers no longer charge commission for buying and selling stocks.

Term: Commingled Fund: Definition, Purpose, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A commingled fund is one where an investment manager accumulates money from different investors and combines it into one fund./nLike mutual funds, commingled funds are overseen and managed byportfoliomanagers who invest in a range of securities./nUnlike mutual funds, commingled funds are not regulated by the SEC./nCommingled funds do not trade publicly and are not available for individual purchase./nThey feature in institutional accounts such as pension funds, retirement plans, and insurance policies.

Term: Commodity Trading Advisor (CTA) Definition, Requirements
Definition: A commodity trading advisor (CTA) is a person or entity registered to provide advice regarding commodities trading./nAdvisors must meet specific proficiency requirements to be registered as a CTA./nCTA registration requires CTAs to advise on all forms of commodity investments./nWith some exceptions, CTA registration is required by the National Futures Association (NFA)./nThe NFA was created by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to register CTAs and ensure compliance with CFTC regulations and NFA rules.

Term: Commodity Futures Contract: Definition, Example, and Trading
Definition: A commodity futures contract is a standardized contract that obliges the buyer to purchase some underlying commodity (or the seller to sell it) at a predetermined future price and date./nCommodity futures can be used to hedge or protect a position in commodities./nA futures contract also allows one to speculate on the direction of a commodity, taking either a long or short position, using leverage./nThe high degree of leverage used with commodity futures can amplify gains, as well as losses./nThe IRS requires a specific form when reporting gains and losses from commodity futures contracts:Form 6781.

Term: What Are Commodities and Understanding Their Role in the Stock Market
Definition: A commodity is a basic good used in commerce that is interchangeable with other commodities of the same type./nCommodities are most often used as inputs in the production of other goods or services./nInvestors and traders can buy and sell commodities directly in the spot (cash) market or via derivatives such as futures and options./nHard commodities refer to energy and metals products, while soft commodities are often agricultural goods./nMany investors view allocating commodities in a portfolio as a hedge against inflation.

Term: Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) Definition and Calculation
Definition: Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) covers liquid bank holdings such as cash and stock./nThe CET1 ratio compares a bank's capital against its assets./nAdditional Tier 1 (AT1) capital is composed of instruments that are not common equity./nIn the event of a crisis, equity is taken first from Tier 1./nMany bank stress tests use Tier 1 capital as a starting measure to test the bank's liquidity and ability to survive a challenging monetary event.

Term: Common Size Financial Statement: Definition and Example
Definition: A common size financial statement displays entries as a percentage of a common base figure rather than as absolute numerical figures./nCommon size statements let analysts compare companies of different sizes, in different industries, or across time in an apples-to-apples way./nCommon size financial statements commonly include the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement.

Term: Common Law: What It Is, How It's Used, and How It Differs From Civil Law
Definition: Common law, also known as case law, is a body of unwritten laws based on legal precedents established by the courts./nCommon law draws from institutionalized opinions and interpretations from judicial authorities and public juries./nCommon laws sometimes prove the inspiration for new legislation to be enacted.

Term: Common Size Income Statement Definition and Example
Definition: A common size income statement is an income statement whereby each line item is expressed as a percentage of revenue or sales./nThe common size percentages help to show how each line item or component affects the financial position of the company./nCommon size financial statements help to compare a company's performance over several periods as well as against a competitor's.

Term: What Is Communism? Learn Its History, Pros, and Cons
Definition: Communism is an economic ideology that advocates for a classless society in which all property and wealth are communally owned, instead of being owned by individuals./nVisions of a society that may be considered communist appeared as long ago as the 4th Century BCE./nModern communist ideology began to develop during the French Revolution, and its seminal tract, Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels' "Communist Manifesto," was published in 1848./nCommunism was pitted against capitalism, which relies on democracy and production of capital to form a society./nProminent examples of communism were the Soviet Union and China. While the former collapsed in 1991, the latter has drastically revised its economy to include some capitalism.

Term: Common Stock: What It Is, Different Types, vs. Preferred Stock
Definition: Common stock is a security that represents ownership in a corporation./nIn a liquidation, common stockholders receive whatever assets remain after creditors, bondholders, and preferred stockholders are paid./nThere are different kinds of stock traded in the market: value stocks are lower in price in relation to their fundamentals and growth stocks are in companies that tend to increase in value due to increasing earnings./nInvestors should diversify their portfolios by putting money into different securities based on their tolerance for risk.

Term: What Is the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA)?
Definition: The Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) helps ensure that federally insured banks meet the credit needs of the communities in which they are located, consistent with safe and sound banking practices./nThe CRA was one of several laws passed during the late 1960s and 1970s to expand access to credit./nThough regulators look at the lending activity and other data in their evaluation, there are no specific benchmarks banks have to meet./nCRA performance ratings areavailable onlineand upon request at local bank branches./nA 2023 update to CRA regulations introduces a metrics-based approach for evaluating bank performance, adapts to digital banking trends, and focuses on expanding access to credit and banking services in low- and moderate-income communities./nMost of the new regulations will go into effect beginning Jan. 1, 2026, with the remainder, including data reporting requirements, as of Jan. 1, 2027.

Term: Comparable Company Analysis (CCA): How Is It Used in Investing?
Definition: Comparable company analysis is the process of comparing companies based on similar metrics to determine their enterprise value./nA company's valuation ratio determines whether it is overvalued or undervalued. If the ratio is high, then it is overvalued. If it is low, then the company is undervalued./n﻿The most common valuation measures used in comparable company analysis are enterprise value to sales (EV/S), price to earnings (P/E), price to book (P/B), and price to sales (P/S).

Term: What Is Comparative Advantage?
Definition: Comparative advantage is an economy's ability to produce a particular good or service at a lower opportunity cost than its trading partners./nThe theory of comparative advantage introduces opportunity cost as a factor for analysis in choosing between different options for production./nComparative advantage suggests that countries will engage in trade with one another, exporting the goods in which they have a relative advantage./nThere are downsides to focusing only on a country's comparative advantages, which can exploit the country's labor and natural resources./nAbsolute advantage refers to the uncontested superiority of a country to produce a particular good better.

Term: Competitive Intelligence: Definition, Types, and Uses
Definition: Competitive intelligence refers to the ability to gather and use information on factors that affect a company's competitive advantage./nOrganizations analyze collected data and information to develop effective and efficient business practices./nCompetitive intelligence can be classified as myopic-oriented, tactical intelligence, or long-term focused strategic intelligence./nGathering data and information is more complex than conducting a simple Internet search.

Term: Compensatory Damages: Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: Compensatory damages represent the money awarded to a plaintiff in a lawsuit./nThis type of compensation is awarded in civil court cases./nThere are two types of compensatory damages—general and actual./nActual damages are intended to provide funds to only replace what was lost./nGeneral compensatory damages awarded are more complex, as these compensatory damages do not represent a monetary expenditure.

Term: What Is Comparative Market Analysis (CMA) in Real Estate?
Definition: A comparative market analysis (CMA) is an estimate of a home's price used to help sellers set listing prices and help buyers make competitive offers./nThe analysis considers the location, age, size, construction, style, condition, and other factors for the property and comparables./nIf you're a buyer or seller interested in a CMA for a specific property, ask a local real estate agent or broker for help, or do your own research by comparing homes online.

Term: Competitive Advantage Definition With Types and Examples
Definition: Competitive advantage is what makes an entity's products or services more desirable to customers than that of any other rival./nCompetitive advantages can be broken down into comparative advantages and differential advantages./nComparative advantage is a company's ability to produce something more efficiently than a rival, which leads to greater profit margins./nA differential advantage is when a company's products are seen as both unique and of higher quality, relative to those of a competitor.

Term: Compliance Officer: Definition, Job Duties, and How to Become One
Definition: A compliance officer is an individual who ensures that a company complies with its outside regulatory and legal requirements as well as internal policies and bylaws./nCompliance officers have a duty to their employer to work with management and staff to identify and manage regulatory risk./nIn the event of a regulatory breach, it is important for the compliance officer to have appropriate disciplinary measures in place to avoid a future recurrence.

Term: Compounding Interest: Formulas and Examples
Definition: Compounding is the process whereby interest is credited to an existing principal amount as well as to interest already paid./nCompounding thus can be construed as interest on interest—the effect of which is to magnify returns to interest over time, the so-called “miracle of compounding.”/nWhen banks or financial institutions credit compound interest, they will use a compounding period such as annual, monthly, or daily./nCompounding may occur on investments in which savings grow more quickly or on debt where the amount owed may grow even if payments are being made./nCompounding naturally occurs in savings accounts; some investments that yield dividends may also benefit from compounding.

Term: The Power of Compound Interest: Calculations and Examples
Definition: Compounding multiplies savings or debt at an accelerated rate./nCompound interest is interest calculated on both the initial principal and all of the previously accumulated interest./nGenerating "interest on interest" is known as the power of compound interest./nInterest can be compounded on a variety of frequencies, such as daily, monthly, quarterly, or annually./nThe higher the number of compounding periods, the larger the effect of compounding.

Term: Comprehensive Income: Statement, Purpose, and Definition
Definition: Comprehensive income reflects the changes to owners' equity originating from non-owner and traditional income sources./nComprehensive income includes adjustments made to the prices of securities held for sale by the firm and/or derivatives used to hedge such positions, foreign currency exchange rate changes, and adjustments to pension liabilities./nIt excludes owner-caused changes in equity./nDetails on comprehensive income often appear in the footnotes to a company's financial statements./nSome companies produce a separate statement of comprehensive income.

Term: Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) Formula and Calculation
Definition: The compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) is one of the most accurate ways to calculate and determine returns for anything that can rise or fall in value over time./nIt measures a smoothed rate of return./nInvestors can compare the CAGR of two or more alternatives to evaluate how well one stock performed against other stocks in a peer group or a market index./nCAGR is thus a good way to evaluate how different investments have performed over time, or against a benchmark./nThe CAGR does not, however, reflect investment risk.

Term: Comps: Definition, How They're Used in Analysis, and Example
Definition: Not including new stores in comps removes extraneous factors, such as grand opening promotions, that may skew results./nComps are valuable metrics used by retailers to identify the profitability of a current store.

Term: Conditional Value at Risk (CVar): Definition, Uses, Formula
Definition: Conditional value at risk is derived from the value at risk for a portfolio or investment./nThe use of CVaR as opposed to just VaR tends to lead to a more conservative approach in terms of risk exposure./nThe choice between VaR and CVaR is not always clear, but volatile and engineered investments can benefit from CVaR as a check to the assumptions imposed by VaR.

Term: What Is a Confidence Interval and How Do You Calculate It?
Definition: A confidence interval displays the probability that a parameter will fall between a pair of values around the mean./nConfidence intervals measure the degree of uncertainty or certainty in a sampling method./nThey are also used in hypothesis testing and regression analysis./nStatisticians often use p-values in conjunction with confidence intervals to gauge statistical significance./nThey are most often constructed using confidence levels of 95% or 99%.

Term: Conditional Probability: Formula and Real-Life Examples
Definition: Conditional probability refers to the chances that some outcome (A) occurs given that another event (B) has also occurred./nIn probability, this is written as A given B, or as this formula: P(A|B), where the probability of A depends on that of B happening./nConditional probability can be contrasted with unconditional probability./nProbabilities are classified as conditional, marginal (the base probability without any dependence on another event), or joint (the probability of two events occurring together)./nBayes' theorem is a mathematical formula that forms out of and can be used to calculate conditional probabilities.

Term: Conflict of Interest Explained: Types and Examples
Definition: A conflict of interest occurs when a person's or entity's vested interests raise a question of whether their actions, judgment, and/or decision-making can be unbiased./nIn business, a conflict of interest arises when a person chooses personal gain over duties to their employer, or to an organization in which they are a stakeholder, or exploits their position for personal gain in some way./nConflicts of interest often have legal ramifications.

Term: Conflict Theory Definition, Founder, and Examples
Definition: Conflict theory focuses on competition among groups within society over limited resources./nMarxist conflict theory sees society as divided along lines of economic class between the proletarian working class and the bourgeois ruling class./nConflict theory views social and economic institutions as tools in the struggle among groups or classes, used to maintain inequality and the dominance of the ruling class./nLater versions of conflict theory look at other dimensions of conflict among capitalist factions and among various social, religious, and other types of groups.

Term: Conglomerate: Definition, Meaning, Creation, and Examples
Definition: A conglomerate is a corporation made up of several different, independent businesses./nIn a conglomerate, one company owns a controlling stake in smaller companies that each conduct business operations separately./nConglomerates can be created in several ways, including mergers or acquisitions./nThe parent company can cut back the risks from being in a single market by becoming a conglomerate diversified across several industry sectors./nEconomists warn that conglomerates can become too oversized to operate efficiently.

Term: Consignment
Definition: Consignment is an arrangement in which goods are left with a third party to sell./nThe party that sells the goods on consignment receives a portion of the profits, either as a flat rate fee or commission./nSelling via a consignment arrangement can be a low-commission, low-time-investment way of selling items or services./nItems commonly sold by consignment include clothing, athletic equipment, furniture, musical instruments, art, and jewelry./nMost consignment shops and online dealers will offer terms, but some are willing to negotiate./nConsignment is a good workaround if you don't possess a physical store or online marketplace in which to sell your goods.

Term: Consolidate: What It Means in Business and Finance
Definition: To consolidate (consolidation) is to combine assets, liabilities, and other financial items of two or more entities into one./nIn financial accounting, the term “consolidate” often refers to the consolidation of financial statements wherein all subsidiaries report under the umbrella of a parent company./nConsolidation also refers to the union of smaller companies into larger companies through mergers and acquisitions.

Term: Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA)
Definition: The Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) allows many employees to stay on their employers' group health plans for a period of time after losing their jobs./nPrivate-sector employers with more than 20 employees must generally provide the option for COBRA coverage./nEmployees must pay the full cost of the insurance, plus a small administrative premium./nCOBRA benefits generally last for a maximum of 18 months, but employers have the option of extending that period.

Term: Consolidation: Definition, Meaning, Example, and How It Works
Definition: Consolidation is a technical analysis term used to describe a stock's price movement within a given support and resistance range for a period of time./nIt is generally caused due to trader indecisiveness./nA consolidation pattern could be broken for several reasons, such as the release of materially important news or the triggering of a succession of limit orders./nAccounting-wise, consolidated financial statements are used by analysts to evaluate parent and subsidiary companies as a single company.

Term: What Is Consumer Discretionary? Definition in Economic Indicators
Definition: Consumer discretionary is an economic sector classification of non-essential consumer goods and services./nThe sector, its industries, and individual companies are watched by analysts and investors as an indicator of economic growth or slowdown./nConsumers tend to spend more on consumer discretionary products in economic growth phases, when they may have more disposable income./nSpending on consumer discretionary products slows in a weak economy./nConsumer discretionary can be contrasted with consumer staples, which is a sector comprised of industries/companies that produce products essential to daily needs.

Term: Construction Loan: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A construction loan may be sought by a builder or an individual to cover the costs of building or extensively remodeling a house./nSuch loans are usually short-term, about a year, and are then folded into a mortgage loan./nA strong credit history is required as the loan is not collateralized.

Term: Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG): What They Are vs. Durable Goods
Definition: Consumer packaged goods (CPG) are items used daily by average consumers that require routine replacement or replenishment, like food, toilet paper, or cosmetics./nThe CPG industry is one of the largest sectors in the U.S. economy./nThe CPG sector is valued at approximately $2 trillion and is led by well-established companies like Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble, and L'Oréal./nConsumer packaged goods are different from durable goods, which are more expensive and intended to last for several years./nDurable goods are things like computers, cars, and washing machines.

Term: Consumer Goods Meaning, Types, and Examples
Definition: Consumer goods, or final goods, are goods sold to consumers for their use or enjoyment./nConsumer goods can be classified as durable, nondurable, or service goods./nConsumer goods are categorized based on consumer behavior and marketed by type of good, such as a convenience product or specialty item.

Term: Consumer Price Index (CPI): What It Is and How It's Used
Definition: The Consumer Price Index measures the overall change in consumer prices based on a representative basket of goods and services over time./nThe CPI is the most widely used measure of inflation, closely followed by policymakers, financial markets, businesses, and consumers./nThe widely quoted CPI is based on an index covering 93% of the U.S. population, while a related index covering wage earners and clerical workers is used for cost-of-living adjustments to federal benefits./nThe CPI is based on about 80,000 price quotes collected monthly from some 23,000 retail and service establishments as well as 50,000 rental housing units./nHousing rents are used to estimate the change in shelter costs including owner-occupied housing that accounts for about a third of the CPI.

Term: Consumer Staples: Definition, Role in GDP, and Examples
Definition: Consumer staple stocks represent companies that are noncyclical because they produce or sell goods or services that are always in demand./nCharacterized by steady if unspectacular growth, the consumer staple sector is a haven in for investors in recessionary times./nConsumer staples stocks can be a good option for investors seeking consistent growth, solid dividends, and low volatility.

Term: Consumer Surplus Definition, Measurement, and Example
Definition: A consumer surplus happens when the price consumers pay for a product or service is less than the price they're willing to pay./nConsumer surplus is based on the economic theory of marginal utility, which is the additional satisfaction a consumer gains from one more unit of a good or service./nConsumer surplus always increases as the price of a good falls and decreases as the price of a good rises./nIt is depicted visually by economists as the triangular area under the demand curve between the market price and what consumers would be willing to pay./nConsumer surplus plus producer surplus equals the total economic surplus.

Term: Consumerism Explained: Definition, Economic Impact, Pros & Cons
Definition: Consumerism is the theory that individuals who consume goods and services in large quantities will be better off./nSome economists believe that consumer spending stimulates production and economic growth./nEconomists view consumption as about fulfilling biological needs & wants based on maximizing utility./nSociologists instead view consumption as additionally about fulfilling socially-inscribed needs and wants via symbolic transactions./nHyper-consumerism has been widely criticized for its economic, social, environmental, and psychological consequences.

Term: Consumption Function: Formula, Assumptions, and Implications
Definition: The consumption function is an economic formula that measures the relationship between income and total consumption of goods and services in the economy./nThe consumption function was introduced by John Maynard Keynes./nKeynes argued that the consumption function could track and predict total aggregate consumption spending./nEconomists and leaders can use the consumption function to make important economic and investment decisions./nOther economists have come up with variations of the consumption function over time, including those developed by Franco Modigliani and Milton Friedman.

Term: Contango Meaning, Why It Happens, and Backwardation
Definition: Contango is a situation where the futures price of a commodity is higher than the spot price./nIn all futures market scenarios, the futures prices will usually converge toward the spot prices as the contracts approach expiration./nAdvanced traders can use arbitrage and other strategies to profit from contango./nContango tends to cause losses for investors in commodity ETFs that use futures contracts, but these losses can be avoided by purchasing ETFs that hold actual commodities.

Term: What Are Contingencies and Contingency Plans? Definition and Examples
Definition: A contingency is a potentially negative event that may occur in the future, such as an economic recession, natural disaster, or fraudulent activity./nCompanies and investors plan for various contingencies through analysis and implementing protective measures./nA thorough contingency plan minimizes loss and damage caused by an unforeseen negative event./nContingency plans can include the purchase of options or insurance for investment portfolios./nBanks must set aside a percentage of capital for negative contingencies, such as a recession, to protect the bank against losses.

Term: Contingent Asset: Overview and Consideration
Definition: A contingent asset is only valuable if certain events or conditions that are independent of a company's own actions come to pass in the future./nUpon meeting certain conditions, contingent assets are reported in the accompanying notes of financial statements./nA contingent asset can be recorded on a firm's balance sheet only when the realization of cash flows associated with it becomes relatively certain.

Term: Contingent Beneficiary: Definition, Characteristics, and Benefits
Definition: A contingent beneficiary inherits only if the primary beneficiary is deceased, unable to be located, or refuses the inheritance when the proceeds are paid out./nMultiple contingent beneficiaries can be listed, with each contingent beneficiary due a percentage of the total amount./nLike primary beneficiaries, contingent beneficiaries named on accounts need to be reviewed and updated as circumstances demand.

Term: Contingent Convertibles (CoCos): Definition and Use in Europe
Definition: CoCos have a strike price at which the bond can be converted into stock./nThey're are used by the banking industry to absorb losses automatically and to satisfy regulatory capital requirements./nA bank that's struggling financially does not have to repay the bond, make interest payments, or convert the bond to stock./nCoCo investors receive interest payments that are typically much higher than those from traditional bonds.

Term: Contingent Liability: What Is It, and What Are Some Examples?
Definition: A contingent liability is a potential liability that may occur in the future, such as pending lawsuits or honoring product warranties./nIf the liability is likely to occur and the amount can be reasonably estimated, the liability should be recorded in the accounting records of a firm./nContingent liabilities are recorded to ensure that the financial statements are accurate and meet requirements of generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) or International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)./nGAAP recognizes three categories of contingent liabilities: probable, possible, and remote.

Term: Contingent Value Right (CVR) Meaning, Types, Risks, and Example
Definition: CVRs are rights granted to the shareholders of a target company by the acquirer./nThese rights stipulate that a shareholder will receive certain benefits if a specific performance event is met in a specific time frame./nThe benefits typically include a monetary benefit, such as additional stock or a cash payout./nJust like unsecured obligations, CVRs aren't backed by any collateral and don't guarantee a payout./nCVRs can be transferable, which are listed on an exchange, and non-transferable.

Term: Continuous Compounding Definition and Formula
Definition: Most interest is compounded on a semiannually, quarterly, or monthly basis./nContinuously compounded interest assumes interest is compounded and added back into the balance an infinite number of times./nThe formula to compute continuously compounded interest takes into account four variables./nThe concept of continuously compounded interest is important in finance even though it’s not possible in practice.

Term: Contra Account Definition, Types, and Example
Definition: A contra account is an account used in a general ledger to reduce the value of a related account./nThey are useful to preserve the historical value in a main account while presenting a decrease or write-down in a separate contra account that nets to the current book value./nContra accounts are presented on the same financial statement as the associated account, typically appearing directly below it with a third line for the net amount./nNote that accountants use contra accounts rather than reduce the value of the original account directly to keep financial accounting records clean./nKey examples of contra accounts include accumulated depreciation and allowance for doubtful accounts.

Term: What Is Contractionary Policy? Definition, Purpose, and Example
Definition: Contractionary policies are macroeconomic tools designed to combat economic distortions caused by an overheating economy./nContractionary policies aim to reduce the rates of monetary expansion by putting some limits on the flow of money in the economy./nContractionary policies are typically issued during times of extreme inflation or when there has been a period of increased speculation and capital investment fueled by prior expansionary policies.

Term: Contract for Differences (CFD) Definition, Uses, and Examples
Definition: A contract for differences (CFD) is a financial contract that pays the differences in the settlement price between the open and closing trades./nCFDs essentially allow investors to trade the direction of securities over the very short-term and are especially popular in FX and commodities products./nCFDs are cash-settled but usually allow ample margin trading so that investors need only put up a small amount of the contract's notional payoff.

Term: What Is a Contrarian? Strategy in Trading, Risks, and Rewards
Definition: Contrarian investing is an investment strategy that involves bucking against existing market trends to generate profits./nThe idea is that markets are subject to herding behavior augmented by fear and greed, making markets periodically over- and underpriced./nThe contrarian sees buying opportunities in stocks that are currently selling for below their intrinsic value./nBeing a contrarian can be rewarding, but it is often a risky strategy that may take a long period of time to pay off./nAnother drawback associated with being a contrarian investor is the need to spend a good deal of time researching stocks to find undervalued opportunities.

Term: Contributed Capital: Definition, How It's Calculated, Example
Definition: Contributed capital, also known as paid-in capital, is the cash and other assets that shareholders have given a company in exchange for stock./nThis is the price that shareholders paid for their stake in the company./nContributed capital is reported in the shareholder’s equity section of the balance sheet and usually split into two different accounts: common stock and additional paid-in capital account.

Term: Contribution Margin: Definition, Overview, and How To Calculate
Definition: The contribution margin represents the portion of a product's sales revenue that isn't used up by variable costs, and so contributes to covering the company's fixed costs./nThe concept of contribution margin is one of the fundamental keys in break-even analysis./nLow contribution margins are present in labor-intensive companies with few fixed expenses, while capital-intensive, industrial companies have higher fixed costs and thus, higher contribution margins.

Term: Financial Controller Roles, Duties, Skillset, Career Path
Definition: A controller acts as an overseer of a company's financial health by taking ownership of the financial reporting process./nA controller oversees internal control implementation, assists with budget preparation, ensures reporting compliance, and manages the transaction reporting process./nControllers often have at least a decade of relevant work experience and a degree, though many companies now seek candidates with a CPA license./nControllers vary from CFOs and VPs of Finance, as controllers are usually more involved in the daily transactional aspects of overseeing a company's performance./nAccording to Glassdoor, controllers made an average of $156,000 per year at the end of 2021.

Term: Conventional Mortgage or Loan
Definition: A conventional mortgage or conventional loan is a homebuyer’s loan not offered or secured by a government entity./nIt is available through or guaranteed by a private lender or the two government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs): Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac./nPotential borrowers need to complete an official mortgage application and supply the required documents, their credit history, and current credit score./nConventional loan interest rates may be higher than government-backed mortgages, such as Federal Housing Administration (FHA) loans.

Term: Convertible Bond: Definition, Example, and Benefits
Definition: A convertible bond pays fixed-income interest payments, but can be converted into a predetermined number of common stock shares./nThe conversion from the bond to stock happens at specific times during the bond's life and is usually at the discretion of the bondholder./nA convertible bond offers investors a type of hybrid security that has features of a bond, such as interest payments, while also having the option to own the underlying stock.

Term: Convexity in Bonds: Definition, Meaning, and Examples
Definition: Convexity is used to measure a portfolio's exposure to market risk./nConvexity is the curvature in the relationship between bond prices and bond yields./nConvexity demonstrates how the duration of a bond changes as the interest rate changes./nIf a bond's duration increases as yields increase, the bond is said to have negative convexity./nIf a bond's duration rises and yields fall, the bond is said to have positive convexity.

Term: Convertible Preferred Stock: Definition, Common Terms, and Example
Definition: Convertible preferred stock is a type of preferred share that pays a dividend and can be converted into common stock at a fixed conversion ratio after a specified date./nConvertible preferred stock is a type of hybrid security with features of both debt and equity./nIf the common share trades above the conversion price, preferred shareholders may find it worthwhile to convert their stock to common shares./nPreferred shareholders who convert their shares give up their rights as preferred shareholders (no fixed dividend or higher claim on assets) and become common shareholders (with the ability to vote and participate in share priceappreciation).

Term: What It Means to 'Cook the Books' Plus Examples
Definition: Cook the books is a slang term for using accounting tricks to make a company's financial results look better than they really are./nTypically, cooking the books involves manipulating financial data to inflate a company's revenue, deflate expenses, and pump up profit./nCompanies can use credit sales to exaggerate their revenue while others buy back stock to disguise a decline in their earnings per share (EPS).

Term: Copyright: Definition, Types, and How It Works
Definition: Copyright law protects creators of original material from unauthorized duplication or use./nFor an original work to be protected by copyright laws, it has to be in tangible form./nIn the United States, the work of a creator is usually protected by copyright laws until 70 years after their death./nOther forms of protection for property that cannot be copyrighted include trademarks and patents.

Term: Corporate Bonds: Definition and How They're Bought and Sold
Definition: A corporate bond is debt issued by a company in order for it to raise capital./nAn investor who buys a corporate bond is effectively lending money to the company in return for a series of interest payments, but these bonds may also actively trade on the secondary market./nCorporate bonds are typically seen as somewhat riskier than U.S. government bonds, so they usually have higher interest rates to compensate for this additional risk./nThe highest quality (and safest, lower yielding) bonds are commonly referred to as "Triple-A" bonds, while the least creditworthy are termed "junk".

Term: Core Competencies in Business: Finding a Competitive Advantage
Definition: Core competencies are the defining characteristics that make a business or an individual stand out from the competition./nIdentifying and exploiting core competencies is seen as important for a new business making its mark or an established company trying to stay competitive./nA company's people, physical assets, patents, brand equity, and capital can all make a contribution to a company's core competencies./nThe idea of core competencies was first proposed in the 1990s as a new way to judge business managers compared to how they were judged in the 1980s./nExamples of companies that have core competencies that have allowed them to remain successful for decades include McDonald's, Apple, and Walmart.

Term: Corporate Charter: Definition, Purpose, and Legal Requirements
Definition: A corporate charter is a document filed with the Secretary of State or registrar to establish a company as a corporation./nThe corporate charter must detail the governance, structure, objectives, operations, as well as other major details of the company.

Term: Corporate Citizenship: What It Means, 5 Stages, and Examples
Definition: Corporate citizenship refers to a company’s responsibilities toward society./nCorporate citizenship is growing increasingly important as both individual and institutional investors begin to seek out companies that have socially responsible orientations such as their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices./nCompanies go through increasing stages during the process of developing corporate citizenship.

Term: Corporate Culture Definition, Characteristics, and Importance
Definition: Corporate culture refers to the beliefs and behaviors that determine how a company's employees and management should interact and perform./nIt can affect employee hiring and retention, performance and productivity, business results, and company longevity./nCorporate culture is influenced by national cultures and traditions, economic trends, international trade, company size, and products./nCorporate culture represents the core values of a company’s ideology and practice./nThe four types of corporate culture are clan culture, adhocracy culture, market culture, and hierarchy culture.

Term: Corporate Finance Definition and Activities
Definition: Corporate finance is concerned with how businesses fund their operations to maximize profits and minimize costs./nIt deals with the day-to-day demands on business cash flows and long-term financing goals (e.g., issuing bonds)./nCorporate finance also involves monitoring cash flows, accounting, preparing financial statements, and taxation./nDetermining whether or not to issue a dividend is another corporate finance activity./nCorporate finance jobs can pay attractive salaries.

Term: Corporate Governance: Definition, Principles, Models, and Examples
Definition: Corporate governance is the structure of rules, practices, and processes used to direct and manage a company./nA company's board of directors is the primary force influencing corporate governance./nBad corporate governance can destroy a company's operations and ultimate profitability./nThe basic principles of corporate governance are accountability, transparency, fairness, responsibility, and risk management.

Term: Corporate Hierarchy: Definition, How It Works, and Configuration
Definition: Corporate hierarchy refers to the organization of people within a corporation according to power, status, and job function./nSmall businesses generally have a simple organizational structure, while the structure of larger corporations tends to be more complex./nCorporate hierarchies typically resemble a pyramid—the more powerful people sit at the top, while employees with the least amount of power are at the bottom.

Term: What Is CSR? Corporate Social Responsibility Explained
Definition: Corporate social responsibility is a business model by which companies make a concerted effort to operate in ways that enhance rather than degrade society and the environment./nCSR can help improve society and promote a positive brand image for companies./nCSR includes four categories: environmental impacts, ethical responsibility, philanthropic endeavors, and financial responsibilities.

Term: Corporate Tax: Definition, Deductions, How It Works
Definition: Corporate taxes are collected by the government as a source of income./nTaxes are based on taxable income after expenses have been deducted./nThe corporate tax rate in the United States is currently at a flat rate of 21%. Before the Trump tax reforms of 2017, the corporate tax rate was 35%./nA company can register as an S corporation to avoid double taxation. An S corporation does not pay corporate tax as the income passes through to business owners who are taxed through their individual tax returns.

Term: Corporation: What It Is and How To Form One
Definition: Corporations possess many of the same legal rights and responsibilities as individuals./nThelimited liabilityaspect of a corporation means that itsshareholdersare not personally responsible for the company's debts./nA corporation may be created by an individual or a group of people.

Term: Correction
Definition: A correction is a decline of 10% or greater in the price of a security, asset, or a financial market./nCorrections can last anywhere from days to months, or even longer./nWhile damaging in the short term, a correction can be positive, adjusting overvalued asset prices and providing buying opportunities.

Term: Correlation: What It Means in Finance and the Formula for Calculating It
Definition: Correlation is a statistic that measures the degree to which two variables move in relation to each other./nIn finance, the correlation can measure the movement of a stock with that of a benchmark index, such as the S&P 500./nCorrelation is closely tied to diversification, the concept that certain types of risk can be mitigated by investing in assets that are not correlated./nCorrelation measures association, but doesn't show if x causes y or vice versa—or if the association is caused by a third factor./nCorrelation may be easiest to identify using a scatterplot, especially if the variables have a non-linear yet still strong correlation.

Term: The Correlation Coefficient: What It Is and What It Tells Investors
Definition: Correlation coefficients are used to assess the strength of associations between data variables./nThe most common, called a Pearson correlation coefficient, measures the strength and the direction of a linear relationship between two variables./nValues always range from -1 for a perfectly inverse, or negative, relationship to 1 for a perfectly positive correlation. Values at, or close to, zero indicate no linear relationship or a very weak correlation./nThe coefficient values required to signal a meaningful association depend on the application. The statistical significance of a correlation can be calculated from the correlation coefficient and the number of data points in the sample, assuming a normal population distribution.

Term: Correspondent Bank: Definition and How It Works
Definition: A correspondent bank is an authorized financial institution that provides services on behalf of another financial institution./nCorrespondent bank's services may include funds transfer, settlement, check clearing, and wire transfers./nThe accounts held between correspondent banks and the banks to which they are providing services are referred to as nostro and vostro accounts./nDomestic banks can serve their international clients and gain access to foreign financial markets by using correspondent banks, rather than setting up branches overseas.

Term: What Is Cost and Freight (CFR) in Foreign Trade Contracts?
Definition: Cost and freight is a legal term specifying that sellers are required to transport goods by sea to a port of destination and provide the buyer with the documents necessary to pick up the goods at the destination./nIf a buyer and a seller agree to include cost and freight in their transaction, this provision means that the seller is not responsible for securing insurance for the cargo for loss or damage during transportation./nCost and freight is a commonly used International Commercial Term (Incoterm), a set of globally recognized terms that help to create a standard for foreign trade contracts and are published and regularly updated by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC).

Term: Cost Basis: What It Is, How to Calculate, and Examples
