Definition: Decoupling is when the returns of an asset class that have been correlated with other assets in the past no longer move in-step according to expectations./nDecoupling may also refer to a disconnect between a country's investment market performance and the state of its underlying economy./nInvestors can view a decoupling as an opportunity if they believe that the previous pattern of correlation will return, but there is no guarantee that it will./nMany sustainable development economists also advocate for decoupling economic growth from environmental pressures—i.e., finding ways to achieve growth without increasing environmental consequences./nRelative decoupling refers to a decreasing correlation between two assets, while absolute decoupling means a zero or negative correlation.

Term: Decreasing Term Insurance: Definition, Example, Pros & Cons
Definition: Decreasing term insurance features a death benefit that gets smaller each year, according to a predetermined schedule that also sees premiums decrease over time./nDecreasing term insurance is often purchased to provide personal asset protection./nIt may also be required by a lender to guarantee the remaining balance of a loan until its maturity in case the borrower dies./nA decreasing term life policy is very similar and may mirror the amortization schedule of a mortgage./nDecreasing term life insurance is less expensive than traditional term or permanent life policies.

Term: What Does Tax Deductible Mean, and What Are Common Deductions?
Definition: A deductible for taxes is an expense that a taxpayer or business can subtract from adjusted gross income, which reduces their taxable income, thereby reducing the amount of taxes owed./nMost wage-earners use the standard deduction but those with very high deductible expenses can choose to itemize if that results in a smaller tax bill./nThe Internal Revenue Service (IRS) provides lists, requirements, and amounts of all available deductibles./nCommon deductions for individuals include student loan interest, self-employment expenses, charitable donations, and mortgage interest./nBusiness deductibles include payroll, utilities, rent, leases, and other operational costs.

Term: Deed: Legal Definition, Types, Requirements, vs. Title
Definition: A deed is a signed legal document that grants its holder ownership to an asset but may set a number of conditions on the transfer of the title./nThe deed is not a title. It is the vehicle for transferring a title./nIf the deed is not written, notarized, and entered into the public record, it could be open to legal challenges and delays./nThere are three main deed types: the grant deed, the warranty deed, and the quitclaim deed.

Term: Deduction Definition and Standard Deductions for 2023 and 2024
Definition: A deduction is an expense that can be subtracted from taxable income to reduce the amount owed./nMost taxpayers who take the standard deduction only need to file Form 1040./nTaxpayers who itemize deductions must use Schedule A Form 1040 to list all of their allowable deductions./nThe standard tax deductions have increased steadily since the passage of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act in 2017.

Term: Deed of Reconveyance: How it Works, Examples and FAQ
Definition: A deed of reconveyance is issued when a mortgage has been paid in full./nThe deed of reconveyance confirms that the title has been transferred from the lender to the borrower./nIf a deed of reconveyance is not recorded in the local county or recorder's office, the homeowner will have difficulty selling the home.

Term: What Is a Deed of Release? Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A deed of release literally releases the parties to a deal from previous obligations, such as payments under the term of a mortgage because the loan has been paid off./nThe lender holds the title to real property until the mortgage’s terms have been satisfied when a deed of release is commonly entered into./nA deed of release can also free an employer and an employee of any obligations that they had under their employment agreement, such as in the case of a severance package./nDeed of release forms can also be used to relieve personal guarantee obligations for business loans.

Term: Default: What It Means, What Happens When You Default, Examples
Definition: A default occurs when a borrower stops making required payments on a debt./nDefaults can occur on secured debt, such as a mortgage loan secured by a house, or on unsecured debt, such as credit cards or a student loan./nDefaults expose borrowers to legal claims and may limit their future access to credit opportunities.

Term: Deep in the Money: Definition and How They're Used in Trade
Definition: Deep in the money options have strike prices that are significantly above or below the underlying's market price, and thus contain a mostly intrinsic value./nThese options have nearly a 100% delta, meaning that their price changes in step with every change in the underlying asset's price./nTraders will often exercise deep in the money options early (if they are American style).

Term: What Is the Default Rate? Definition, How It Works, and Criteria
Definition: The default rate is the percentage of all outstanding loans that a lender has written off after a prolonged period of missed payments./nA loan is typically declared in default if payment is 270 days late./nDefault rates are an important statistical measure used by economists to assess the overall health of the economy.﻿

Term: Default Risk: Definition, Types, and Ways to Measure
Definition: Default risk refers to the likelihood that a borrower won't be able to make their required debt payments to a lender./nThe default risk posed by consumers can be gauged through their credit reports and credit scores./nThe default risk posed by companies and governments, as well as the bonds they issue, are rated by rating agencies./nBorrowers who are a high default risk will typically pay higher interest rates.

Term: Defensive Interval Ratio (DIR): Formula, Advantages
Definition: The defensive interval ratio (DIR) seeks to calculate how many days a company can operate while relying only on liquid assets./nCurrent assets are compared to daily expenditures to determine the defensive interval ratio./nThe defensive interval ratio can be viewed over time to determine if a company's liquidity buffer to meet its expenses is increasing or decreasing./nMany analysts view the defensive interval ratio (DIR) as more useful than the quick ratio or current ratio as it compares assets to actual expenses rather than liabilities./nThough a higher DIR number is preferred, there is no specific number that indicates what is right or better to aim for.

Term: Understanding Defensive Stocks, Pros & Cons, and Examples
Definition: A defensive stock is a stock that provides consistent dividends and stable earnings regardless of the state of the overall stock market./nWell-established companies such as Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson, Philip Morris International, and Coca-Cola are considered to be defensive stocks./nDefensive stocks offer the substantial benefit of similar long-term gains with lower risk than other stocks./nThe low volatility of defensive stocks often leads to smaller gains during bull markets and a cycle of mistiming the market.

Term: What Are Deferred Acquisition Costs (DAC)? Definition
Definition: Deferred acquisition costs (DAC) is an accounting method that is applicable in the insurance industry./nUsing the DAC method allows a company to defer the sales costs that are associated with acquiring a new customer over the term of the insurance contract./nUsing this accounting method tends to reduce the first-year strain of policy and produces a smoother pattern of earnings./nCompanies may only defer costs associated with the successful placement of new business and cannot amortize all back-office expenses.

Term: Deferment Period: Meaning, Overview, Applications
Definition: A deferment period is an agreed-upon time during which a borrower does not have to pay the lender interest or principal on a loan./nDepending on the loan, interest may accrue during a deferment period, which means the interest is added to the amount due at the end of the deferment period./nCallable securities can also have a deferment period, which is the time during which the issuer can buy them back from the investor at a predetermined price before the maturity date.

Term: Deferred Annuity Definition, Types, How They Work
Definition: A deferred annuity is an insurance contract that promises to pay the buyer a regular income or a lump sum of money at some date in the future. Immediate annuities, by contrast, start paying right away./nDeferred annuities come in several different types—fixed, indexed, and variable—which determine how their rates of return are computed./nWithdrawals from a deferred annuity may be subject to surrender charges as well as a 10% tax penalty if the owner is under age 59½.

Term: What Is Deferred Compensation?
Definition: Employers use deferred compensation plans to incentivize prospective and current employees./nDeferred compensation can be structured as either qualified or non-qualified under federal regulations./nSome deferred compensation is made available only to top employees, such as executives./nA risk of deferred compensation in a non-qualified plan is that the employee can lose the money if the company goes bankrupt.

Term: Deferred Income Tax: Definition, Purpose, and Examples
Definition: Deferred income tax is a result of the difference in income recognition between tax laws (i.e., the IRS) and accounting methods (i.e., GAAP)./nDeferred income tax shows up as a liability on the balance sheet./nThe difference in depreciation methods used by the IRS and GAAP is a common cause of deferred income tax./nDeferred income tax can be classified as either a current or long-term liability.

Term: Deferred Interest: Definition, How It Works, Examples
Definition: A deferred interest loan postpones interest payments till after a certain period of time./nIf the loan is not paid off by the specified time, interest starts accruing./nThe interest paid can sometimes be backdated to the entire loan balance and include high-interest rates./nDeferred interest loans are typically found on credit cards or offered by retailers./nMortgages can also include deferred interest options, in which the unpaid interest is added to the principal balance of the loan, also known as negative amortization./nGenerally, deferred interest loans are not considered a financially prudent means of financing.

Term: Deferred Profit Sharing Plan (DPSP): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: A deferred profit sharing plan (DPSP) is an employer-sponsored profit sharing plan in Canada that is meant to help employees save for retirement./nEmployers that offer a DPSP may elect to share their profits with all or just a select group of employees./nDPSPs are often used in conjunction with other types of employer-based retirement plans./nDPSPs can be funded only with employer contributions. Employees themselves cannot contribute./nEmployer contributions are tax deductible, while employees enjoy tax-deferred growth until they withdraw the money.

Term: Deferred Tax Asset: Calculation, Uses, and Examples
Definition: A deferred tax asset is an item on the balance sheet that results from an overpayment or advance payment of taxes./nIt is the opposite of a deferred tax liability, which represents income taxes owed./nA deferred tax asset usually is found when there are differences between tax rules and accounting rules./nThey also occur with a carryover of tax losses./nBeginning in 2018, most companies could carry over a deferred tax asset indefinitely.

Term: What Deferred Revenue Is in Accounting, and Why It's a Liability
Definition: Deferred revenue is a liability on a company's balance sheet that represents a prepayment by its customers for goods or services that have yet to be delivered./nDeferred revenue is recognized as earned revenue on the income statement when the good or service is delivered to the customer./nThe use of the deferred revenue account follows GAAP guidelines for accounting conservatism./nThe company may owe the money back to its customer if the good or service isn't delivered as planned.

Term: Deferred Tax Liability Definition: How It Works With Examples
Definition: A deferred tax liability represents an obligation to pay taxes in the future./nThe obligation originates when a company or individual delays an event that would cause it to also recognize tax expenses in the current period./nFor instance, earning returns in a qualified retirement plan, like a 401(k), represents a deferred tax liability since the retirement saver will eventually have to pay taxes on the saved income and gains upon withdrawal.

Term: What Are Deficits? Definition, Types, Risks, and Benefits
Definition: A deficit occurs when expenses exceed revenues, imports exceed exports, or liabilities exceed assets in a particular year./nGovernments and businesses sometimes run deficits deliberately, to stimulate an economy during a recession or to foster future growth./nThe two major types of deficits incurred by nations are budget deficits and trade deficits.

Term: Deficit Spending: Definition, Theory, Arguments Pro & Con
Definition: Deficit spending occurs when government spending exceeds its revenue./nDeficit spending often refers to intentional excess spending meant to stimulate the economy./nBritish economist John Maynard Keynes is the most well-known proponent of deficit spending as a form of economic stimulus.

Term: Deficit Spending Unit: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A deficit spending unit describes how an economy or economic unit within an economy has spent more than it has earned over a given measurement period./nThe opposite of a deficit spending unit is a surplus spending unit, which leaves money for the company to redistribute./nThe term deficit spending unit applies not only to corporations but also to households.

Term: What Are Defined Contribution Plans, and How Do They Work?
Definition: Defined contribution (DC) retirement plans allow employees to invest pre-tax dollars in the capital markets, where they can grow tax-deferred until retirement./n401(k) and 403(b) are popular DC plans companies and organizations commonly use to encourage their employees to save for retirement./nDC plans can be contrasted with defined benefit (DB) pensions, in which an employer guarantees retirement income./nThere are no guarantees with a DC plan, and participation is voluntary and self-directed.

Term: What Is a Defined-Benefit Plan? Examples and How Payments Work
Definition: A defined-benefit plan is an employer-based program that pays benefits based on factors such as length of employment and salary history./nPensions are defined-benefit plans./nIn contrast to defined-contribution plans, the employer, not the employee, is responsible for all of the planning and investment risk of a defined-benefit plan./nBenefits can be distributed as fixed-monthly payments like an annuity or in one lump-sum payment./nThe surviving spouse is often entitled to the benefits if the employee passes away.

Term: Degree of Combined Leverage (DCL): Definition and FormulaÂ
Definition: The DCL formula summarizes the effects that the combined degree of operating leverage and degree of financial leverage have on a company's earnings per share, based on a given change in shares./nThe ratio helps a company discern its best possible levels of operational and financial leverage./nThe formula helps companies understand how the combined leverage affects the company's total earnings.

Term: Deflation: Definition, Causes, Changing Views on Its Impact
Definition: Deflation is the general decline of the price level of goods and services./nDeflation is usually associated with a contraction in the supply of money and credit, but prices can also fall due to increased productivity and technological improvements./nWhether the economy, price level, and money supply are deflating or inflating changes the appeal of different investment options.

Term: Degree of Financial Leverage (DFL): Definition and Formula
Definition: The degree of financial leverage (DFL) is a leverage ratio that measures the sensitivity of a company’s earnings per share to fluctuations in its operating income, as a result of changes in its capital structure./nThis ratio indicates that the higher the degree of financial leverage, the more volatile earnings will be./nThe use of financial leverage varies greatly by industry and by the business sector.

Term: Degree of Operating Leverage (DOL)
Definition: The degree of operating leverage measures how much a company's operating income changes in response to a change in sales./nThe DOL ratio assists analysts in determining the impact of any change in sales on company earnings./nA company with high operating leverage has a large proportion of fixed costs, meaning a big increase in sales can lead to outsized changes in profits.

Term: Degrees of Freedom in Statistics Explained: Formula and Example
Definition: Degrees of freedom refer to the maximum number of logically independent values, which may vary in a data sample./nDegrees of freedom are calculated by subtracting one from the number of items within the data sample./nThe earliest concept of degrees of freedom was noted in the early 1800s with the works of mathematician and astronomer Carl Friedrich Gauss./nDegrees of freedom are commonly discussed in various forms of hypothesis testing in statistics, such as a chi-square./nDegrees of freedom can describe business situations where management must make a decision that dictates the outcome of another variable.

Term: Delaware Corporation: Definition, Role of Usury Laws and Benefits
Definition: Delaware corporations are companies that are legally registered in the state of Delaware but can conduct business anywhere./nRoughly half of the companies listed on the S&P 500 are incorporated in Delaware because it is perceived as being business-friendly./nDelaware especially appeals to financial firms due to usury laws which give banks and credit card companies the freedom to charge high-interest rates on loans.

Term: What Is a Delayed Draw Term Loan (DDTL) and How Does It Work?
Definition: A delayed draw term loan is a provision in a term loan that specifies when and how much the borrower receives./nThe DDTL typically has specific time periods, such as three, six, or time months, for the periodic payments, or the timing of the payments can be based on company milestones./nThe provisions allow a lender to better manage cash requirements./nThe delayed draw gives the borrower the flexibility of knowing when they will see guaranteed, periodic cash flows.

Term: Deleverage: Overview, Examples and Formulas
Definition: To deleverage is to reduce outstanding debt without incurring any new debt./nThe goal of deleveraging is to reduce the relative percentage of a business's balance sheet funded by liabilities./nToo much systemic deleveraging can lead to financial recession and a credit crunch.

Term: Delinquent Account Credit Card: Definition, Example, Impact
Definition: In the context of credit cards, delinquent accounts are those that have not made at least a minimum payment for 30 days or more./nCredit card companies manage their risk of loss from delinquent accounts by seeking to contact and negotiate with the borrower and using internal or third-party credit collection services./nDelinquencies can remain on a borrower's credit report for up to seven years, resulting in a lower credit score, making it difficult to utilize other forms of debt.

Term: Delinquent: Definition, Example, and Statistics on Delinquencies
Definition: Being delinquent refers to the state of being past due on a debt./nDelinquency occurs as soon as a borrower misses a payment on a loan, which can affect their credit score./nDelinquency rates are used to show how many accounts in a financial institution's portfolio are delinquent./nConsistently delinquent borrowers end up in default./nFinancial professionals who fail to live up to their duties and responsibilities are considered delinquent.

Term: Delisting: What It Means and How It Works for Stock Shares
Definition: Delisting occurs when a stock is removed from a stock exchange./nIt can be either mandatory or voluntary./nSome companies opt to go private or get taken over by companies that want them out of the public eye./nStocks that fail to meet the exchange’s requirements risk being kicked out and delisted./nThe consequences of delisting are significant, and some companies strenuously avoid being delisted.

Term: Deliverables: Meaning in Business, Types, and Examples
Definition: The word "deliverables" is a project management term describing the quantifiable goods or services that must be provided upon the completion of a project./nDeliverables can be tangible in nature, such as the acquisition of a dozen new computers, or they can be intangible, like the implementation of a computer program aimed at improving a company's accounts receivable computational efficiency./nA deliverable may refer to in-person or online training programs, as well as design samples for products in the process of being developed./nIn many cases, deliverables are accompanied by instruction manuals./nIn film production, deliverables refer to the range of audio, visual, and paperwork files that producers must furnish to distributors.

Term: Delivered at Frontier (DAF): What it is, How it Works, Incoterms
Delivered-at-Place (DAP) Definition, How It Works, and Obligations
Definition: Delivered-at-place is an international trade term that was introduced in the International Chamber of Commerce's eighth publication of its Incoterms./nUnder DAP, a seller agrees to pay all costs and suffer any potential losses of moving goods sold to a specific location./nIn simpler terms, the seller takes on all the risks and costs of delivering goods to an agreed-upon location under DAP rules./nThe buyer assumes all the risk and responsibility once the shipment arrives at the destination./nIncoterms help clear up any confusion with respect to the rights and responsibilities of buyers and sellers of trade contracts.

Term: Delivered Duty Paid: What DDP Means for Importers, Exporters
Definition: Delivered duty paid (DDP) is a delivery agreement whereby the seller assumes all responsibility for transporting the goods until they reach an agreed-upon destination./nIt is an incoterm, or a standardized contract for international shipments./nUnder DDP, the seller must arrange for all transportation and associated costs including export clearance and customs documentation required to reach the destination port./nThe risks to the seller are broad and include VAT charges, bribery, and storage costs if unexpected delays occur./nA DDP benefits a buyer as the seller assumes most of the liability and costs for shipping.

Term: Delivered Duty Unpaid (DDU): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: Delivered Duty Unpaid (DDU) is an international trade term meaning the seller is responsible for ensuring goods arrive safely to a destination; the buyer is responsible for import duties./nBy contrast, Delivered Duty Paid (DDP) indicates that the seller must cover duties, import clearance, and any taxes./nDDU is still commonly used in transportation contracts, even though the International Chamber of Commerce has officially replaced it with the term Delivered-at-Place (DAP)./nThe primary benefit of delivered duty unpaid (DDU) shipping is that it gives the buyer more control over the shipping procedures./nFrom the seller's perspective, DDU shipping provides the ability to take more of a "hands-off" approach when it comes to the destination country's shipping rules./nThe biggest problem for buyers in DDU shipping is the possibility of surprise duties and/or tax charges when their shipment finally arrives.

Term: Delivery Versus Payment (DVP): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: Delivery versus payment is a securities settlement process that requires that payment is made either before or at the same time as the delivery of the securities./nThe process is meant to reduce the risk that securities could be delivered without payment or that payments could be made without the delivery of securities./nThe delivery versus payment system became a widespread industry practice in the aftermath of the October 1987 market crash.

Term: What Is Delivered Ex Ship (DES), and How Is It Different From DAT and DAP?
Definition: Delivered ex-ship (DES) was an Incoterm (an international commercial term) that applied to both inland and sea shipping and often in charter shipping./nDES stipulated that a seller had to deliver goods to a buyer at a certain port of arrival, as specified in an international shipping contract. After delivery, all obligations shifted to the buyer./nDiscontinued in 2011, DES was replaced by two new Incoterms, delivered at terminal (DAT) and delivered at place (DAP).

Term: Delphi Method Forecasting: Definition and How It's Used
Definition: The Delphi method is a process used to arrive at a group opinion or decision by surveying a panel of experts./nExperts respond to several rounds of questionnaires, and the responses are aggregated and shared with the group after each round./nThe experts can adjust their answers each round, based on how they interpret the “group response” provided to them./nThe ultimate result is meant to be a true consensus of what the group thinks.

Term: What Is Delta in Derivatives Trading, and How Does It Work?
Definition: Delta expresses the amount of price change a derivative will see based on the price of the underlying security (e.g., stock)./nDelta can be positive or negative, being between 0 and 1 for a call option and negative 1 to 0 for a put option./nDelta spread is an options trading strategy in which the trader initially establishes a delta neutral position by simultaneously buying and selling options in proportion to the neutral ratio./nThe most common tool for implementing a delta spread strategy is a calendar spread, which involves constructing a delta neutral position using options with different expiration dates.

Term: Delta Hedging: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Delta hedging is an options strategy that seeks to be directionally neutral by establishing offsetting long and short positions in the same underlying./nBy reducing directional risk, delta hedging can isolate volatility changes for an options trader./nAn options position could also be delta-hedged using shares of the underlying stock./nDelta hedging benefits traders when they anticipate a strong move in the underlying stock but does require traders to constantly watch and adjust the positions involved./nOptions position could be hedged with options that have a delta that is opposite to that of the current options holding to maintain a delta-neutral position.

Term: Delta Neutral: Definition, Use With a Portfolio, and Example
Definition: Delta neutral is a portfolio strategy that uses multiple positions to balance positive and negative deltas so the overall delta of the assets totals zero./nA delta-neutral portfolio evens out the response to market movements for a certain range to bring the net change of the position to zero./nOptions traders use delta-neutral strategies to profit from either implied volatility or time decay of the options./nDelta-neutral strategies are also used for hedging purposes.

Term: Demand: How It Works Plus Economic Determinants and the Demand Curve
Definition: The law of demand concerns consumers' changing desire to purchase goods and services at given prices./nDemand can refer to either market demand for a specific good or aggregate demand for the total of all goods in an economy./nDemand and supply determine the actual prices of goods and the volume that changes hands in a market./nBusinesses study demand to price products to meet demand and generate profits./nThe demand curve demonstrates visually how the decreasing price for a product increases the quantity purchased.

Term: Demand Deposit Definition, Account Types, and Requirements
Definition: Demand deposit accounts (DDAs) allow funds to be withdrawn at any time from the financial institution./nDemand deposits provide funds for daily expenses and purchases./nDemand deposit accounts pay little or no interest—the trade-off for the funds being so readily available./nDemand deposit accounts can have joint owners.

Term: Demand Curves: What Are They, Types, and Example
Definition: A demand curve is a graph that shows the relationship between the price of a good or service and the quantity demanded within a specified time frame./nDemand curves can be used to understand the price-quantity relationship for consumers in a particular market, such as corn or soybeans./nThe demand curve generally slopes down from left to right, due to the law of demand while the quantity demanded drops as the price rises for the majority of goods./nChanges in factors besides price and quantity can shift a demand curve to the right or left./nThere are some exceptions to the relationship between price and demand, including Giffen goods and Veblen goods.

Term: Demand Draft: What It Is and How It Works Versus Checks
Definition: A demand draft is a way to initiate a bank transfer that does not require a signature, as is the case with a check./nA demand draft is a prepaid instrument; therefore, you cannot stop payment on it in the case of fraud or mis-intended recipient./nBecause demand drafts can be used to defraud people, there are regulations now in place that allow victims to recover funds from the holding bank./nDemand drafts are less flexible compared to other payment methods but may offer greater security compared to electronic payments or online payment systems./nContact your bank if your demand draft is lost or stolen.

Term: Price Elasticity of Demand: Meaning, Types, and Factors That Impact It
Definition: Price elasticity of demand is a measurement of the change in consumption of a product in relation to a change in its price./nA good is perfectly elastic if the price elasticity is infinite (if demand changes substantially even with minimal price change)./nIf price elasticity is greater than 1, the good is elastic; if less than 1, it is inelastic./nIf a good’s price elasticity is 0 (no amount of price change produces a change in demand), it is perfectly inelastic./nIf price elasticity is exactly 1 (price change leads to an equal percentage change in demand), it is known as unitary elasticity./nThe availability of a substitute for a product affects its elasticity. If there are no good substitutes and the product is necessary, demand won’t change when the price goes up, making it inelastic.

Term: What Is Demand-Pull Inflation?
Definition: Demand-pull inflation happens when demand for goods and services outweighs supply, which remains stable or drops./nDemand-pull inflation results in higher prices./nA low unemployment rate is unquestionably good in general, but it can cause inflation because more people have more disposable income./nAlthough increased government spending is good for the economy, it may lead to a scarcity of certain goods followed by inflation./nDemand-pull inflation can be compared with cost-push inflation, whereby production costs increase and higher prices are passed on to consumers.

Term: Demand Shock: Definition, Causes, Impact, and Examples
Definition: A demand shock is a sharp, sudden change in the demand for a product or service./nA positive demand shock will cause a shortage and drive the price higher, while a negative shock will lead to oversupply and a lower price./nDemand shocks are usually short-lived, but can have longer-term consequences.

Term: Demand Schedule: Definition, Examples, and How to Graph One
Definition: Analysts can estimate the demand for a good at any point along the demand schedule./nDemand schedules, used in conjunction with supply schedules, provide a visual depiction of the supply and demand dynamics of a market./nDemand schedules are used to forecast the raw materials and labor needed during manufacturing should management decide to sell goods at one price over another./nDemand schedules inform management of the elasticity of a product, the response in demand of a good based on changing prices./nDemand schedules do have limitations, as they must be continually revised to match true market expectations as well as they do not incorporate non-financial impacts to demand.

Term: Dematerialization (DEMAT): Definition, How It Works, Benefits
Definition: Dematerialization (DEMAT) is the move from physical certificates to electronic bookkeeping./nDEMAT accounts are required by some trading institutions due to the fact they are the most accurate form of record keeping./nDematerialization was designed to offer more security, as well as increased speed, to financial trades. It has become the norm in bookkeeping for financial institutions.

Term: Demand Theory: Definition in Economics and Examples
Definition: Demand theory describes the way that changes in the quantity of a good or service demanded by consumers affects its price in the market,/nThe theory states that the higher the price of a product is, all else equal, the less of it will be demanded, inferring a downward sloping demand curve./nLikewise, the more demand that occurs, the greater the price will be for a given supply./nDemand theory places primacy on the demand side of the supply-demand relationship.

Term: What Is the Demographic Dividend, and How Does It Work?
Demonetization: Meaning, Example, and How It Works
Definition: Demonetization is a drastic intervention into the economy that involves removing the legal tender status of a currency./nDemonetization can cause chaos or a serious downturn in an economy if it goes wrong./nDemonetization has been used as a tool to stabilize the currency and fight inflation, facilitate trade and access to markets, and push informal economic activity into more transparency and away from black and gray markets./nA famous example of demonetization occurred in 2016 when India demonetized 86% of its nation's currency./nDemonetized may also refer to social media or digital content that formerly qualified for revenue distribution but has since been denied income proceeds.

Term: Demographics: How to Collect, Analyze, and Use Demographic Data
Definition: Demographic analysis is the collection and analysis of broad characteristics about groups of people and populations./nDemographic data is very useful for businesses to understand how to market to consumers and plan strategically for future trends in consumer demand./nThe combination of the internet, big data, and artificial intelligence is greatly amplifying the usefulness and application of demographics as a tool for marketing and business strategy./nMarket segments are often grouped by age or generation./nDemographic information can be used in many ways to learn more about the generalities of a particular population.

Term: Demutualization: Definition and How the Process Works
Definition: Demutualization occurs when a company structured as a mutual company transitions to a stockholder corporation./nThe most common place that demutualization happens is among companies in the life insurance sector./nSeveral methods exist for demutualization, but in all cases, policyholder customers are replaced as owners by shareholder investors.

Term: Understanding Denomination With Real World Example
Definition: A denomination defines the monetary unit with which assets, securities, and transactions are priced in./nOften, the denomination will refer to the face value of the instrument, for instance based on the bond's par value denominated in U.S. dollars./nCollectible currencies will at times, have a market value that is higher than the face value denomination, such as an old penny today worth several hundred dollars.

Term: What Is the Dependency Ratio, and How Do You Calculate It?
Definition: The dependency ratio is a demographic measure of the ratio of the number of dependents to the total working-age population in a country or region./nThis indicator paints a picture of the make-up of a population compared to its workforce and can shed light on the tax implications of dependency./nAs the overall age of the population rises, the ratio can be shifted to reflect the increased needs associated with an aging population.

Term: Dependents: Definition, Types, and Tax Credits
Definition: A dependent is a person who relies on someone else for financial support and can include children or other relatives./nIf you claim one or more dependents on your tax return, you may be eligible for certain tax credits./nThe amount of the Child Tax Credit is $2,000 per qualifying child, and it is partially refundable./nUsually, any person who filed a joint return (as a married person) cannot be claimed as a dependent on anyone else's tax return./nTo be claimed as a dependent, a person must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. resident alien, U.S. national, or a resident of Canada or Mexico.

Term: Dependent Care Benefits: Meaning, How it Works
Definition: Dependent care benefits include tax credits and employee benefits, such as daycare allowances, for the care of their dependents./nThe IRS provides a child and dependent care tax credit to eligible taxpayers who paid child or dependent care expenses for the tax year./nEligible employees can allocate a portion of their pay to be put into a special flexible spending account to later be reimbursed for qualifying out-of-pocket dependent care expenses./nPaid leave is another benefit available to certain employees who take time away from work to care for a dependent.

Term: Depletion: Definition, 4 Affecting Factors, and Depletion Methods
Definition: Depletion is an accrual accounting method used to allocate the cost of extracting natural resources such as timber, minerals, and oil from the earth./nWhen the costs associated with natural resource extraction have been capitalized, the expenses are systematically allocated across different time periods based upon the resources extracted./nThere are two basic forms of depletion allowance: percentage depletion and cost depletion.

Term: What Is DWAC (Deposit/Withdrawal at Custodian)?
Definition: DWAC is a method of requesting the transfer ofshare certificatesbetween broker/dealers and theDepository Trust Company (DTC)./nIt uses the Fast Automated Securities Transfer Program (FAST)./nDWAC offers the benefits of efficient and quick processing and no risk of loss or damage to shares because they are electronic book-entry deposits and withdrawals, not actual paper certificates that must be physically moved./nBrokers and custodial banks, known as DTC participants, can make the request to move shares.

Term: What Is a Deposit? Definition, Meaning, Types, and Example
Definition: A deposit generally refers to money held in a bank account./nA deposit can also be the funds used as security or collateral for the delivery of goods or services./nA demand deposit account is essentially a checking account in which you can withdraw funds at any time./nA time deposit account usually requires that you hold your funds in the account for a certain amount of time or face a fee for withdrawal.

Term: Deposit Multiplier: Definition, How It Works, and Calculation
Definition: The deposit multiplier is the maximum amount of money a bank can create in the form of checkable deposits for each unit of money of reserves./nThis figure is key to maintaining an economy's basic money supply./nIt's a component of the fractional reserve banking system./nAlthough reserve minimums are set by the Federal Reserve, banks may set higher ones for themselves./nThe deposit multiplier is different from the money multiplier, which reflects the change in a nation's money supply created by the actual use of a loan.

Term: Deposit Slip: What It Is, How It Works, Benefits
Definition: A deposit slip is a small paper form that a bank customer includes when depositing funds into a bank account./nA deposit slip contains the date, the name of the depositor, the depositor's account number, and the amounts being deposited as well as a breakdown of whether the deposit consists of checks, cash, or if the depositor wants a specific amount of cash back from a check deposit./nThe deposit slip serves as proof that the bank acknowledged receiving the funds from the customer.

Term: Deposition: What It Means, How It Works, Questions
Definition: A deposition is testimony made under oath and taken down in writing by an authorized officer of the court, typically in an out-of-court setting and before trial./nDepositions are usually taken from key witnesses, but can also involve the plaintiff or defendant, to give the involved parties a fair preview of all the evidence./nThe individual making the deposition is known as the deponent and false statements can carry civil and criminal penalties.

Term: Depository: Definition, Meaning, Types, and Examples
Definition: A depository can be a facility or institution, such as a building, office, or warehouse, where something is deposited for storage or safeguarding./nDepositories also may be organizations, banks, or institutions that hold currency or securities and assist in the trading of securities./nThey provide security, liquidity, and a means of transferring funds.

Term: Depository Transfer Check: Definition, How It Works, and Benefits
Definition: Companies use depository transfer checks in order to have a better cash management system./nDepository transfer checks (DTC) may look similar to a deposit check but they do not have signatures on them./nAutomatic clearing house systems are replacing depository transfer check systems but some companies continue to use DTCs for deposits./nDepository transfer checks are not the same thing as overnight deposits.

Term: What Is a Depositary Receipt (DR)? Definition, Types and Examples
Definition: A depositary receipt (DR) is a negotiable certificate representing shares in a foreign company traded on a local stock exchange./nDepositary receipts allow investors to hold equity shares of foreign companies without the need to trade directly on a foreign market./nDepositary receipts allow investors to diversify their portfolios by purchasing shares of companies in different markets and economies./nDepositary receipts are more convenient and less expensive than purchasing stocks directly in foreign markets.

Term: Depreciated Cost: Definition, Calculation Formula, Example
Definition: Depreciated cost is the value of a fixed asset minus all of the accumulated depreciation that has been recorded against it./nThe value of an asset after its useful life is complete is measured by the depreciated cost./nThe depreciated cost helps companies assess their capital spending habits as well as their accounting methodology./nThe depreciated cost is also known as the "salvage value," "net book value," or "adjusted cost basis."

Term: What Is the Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation (DTCC)?
Definition: The Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation (DTCC) is a financial services company that provides clearing and settlement services for the financial markets./nThe DTCC settles most securities transactions in the U.S./nSettlement is integral to securities transactions. It boosts investor confidence and reduces market risk.

Term: What Is the Depository Trust Company (DTC) in Banking?
Definition: Founded in 1973, the Depository Trust Company is one of the world's largest securities depositories./nThe DTC's automated system lowers costs and improves accuracy./nThe DTC provides direct registration, underwriting, reorganization, and proxy and dividend services./nIn 2021, the DTC held more than 1.3 million current securities issues valued at $87 trillion and issued in the U.S. and 131 countries and territories.

Term: Depreciation, Depletion, and Amortization (DD&A): Examples
Definition: Depreciation, depletion, and amortization (DD&A) are accounting techniques that enable companies to gradually expense resources of economic value./nDepreciation relates to the cost of a tangible asset, depletion to the cost of extracting natural resources, and amortization to the deduction of an intangible asset./nThe use of all three expensing strategies is typically associated with the acquisition, exploration, and development of new oil and natural gas reserves./nDD&A charges can be found on a company's net income statement.

Term: Depreciation Recapture: Definition, Calculation, and Examples
Definition: Depreciation recapture is a tax provision that allows the IRS to collect taxes on any profitable sale of an asset that the taxpayer had used to previously offset taxable income./nDepreciation recapture on non-real estate property is taxed at the taxpayer's ordinary income tax rate, rather than the more favorable capital gains tax rate./nDepreciation recaptures on gains specific to real estate property are capped at a maximum of 25%./nTo calculate the amount of depreciation recapture, the adjusted cost basis of the asset must be compared to the sale price of the asset.

Term: Depreciation: Definition and Types, With Calculation Examples
Definition: Depreciation allows businesses to spread the cost of physical assets (such as a piece of machinery or a fleet of cars) over a period of years for accounting and tax purposes./nThere are several different depreciation methods, including straight-line and various forms of accelerated depreciation./nSome methods of accounting for depreciation require that the business estimate the "salvage value" of the asset at the end of its useful life.

Term: Depth of Market Meaning and How to Use DOM Data
Definition: Depth of market (DOM) is an indicator of the current interest in a stock or other asset./nIt can be read as a signal of the likely direction of a stock's price./nIt is used to judge the optimal time to buy or sell an asset.

Term: Deregulation: Definition, History, Effects, and Purpose
Definition: Deregulation is the reduction or elimination of government power in an industry./nRemoving regulations allows businesses to operate more freely and can stimulate the economy./nCritics suggest that deregulation can lead to monopolies and hurt consumers./nThe financial industry has undergone a great degree of deregulation.

Term: Descending Triangle: What It Is, What It Indicates, Examples
Definition: A descending triangle signals traders to take a short position to accelerate abreakdown./nA descending triangle is detectable by trend lines drawn for the highs and lows on a chart./nA descending triangle is the counterpart of anascending triangle, another trend line-based chart pattern used by technical analysts.

Term: Derivatives: Types, Considerations, and Pros and Cons
Definition: Derivatives are financial contracts, set between two or more parties, that derive their value from an underlying asset, group of assets, or benchmark./nA derivative can trade on an exchange or over-the-counter./nPrices for derivatives derive from fluctuations in the underlying asset./nDerivatives are usually leveraged instruments, which increases their potential risks and rewards./nCommon derivatives include futures contracts, forwards, options, and swaps.

Term: Derived Demand: Definition, How It's Calculated, and Uses
Definition: Derived demand is an economic term that refers to the demand for a good or service that results from the demand for a different, or related, good or service./nDerived demand is related solely to the demand placed on a product or service for its ability to acquire or produce another good or service./nThe demand that is derived from the demand for another product can be an excellent investing strategy when used to anticipate the potential market for goods outside of the original product desired./nThe pick-and-shovel investment strategy guides investors to invest in the technology needed to produce a good or service that is realizing an increase in demand./nCertain raw or processed materials, widely used to produce various products, may not see a shift in demand when the demand for a final product changes.

Term: Descriptive Statistics: Definition, Overview, Types, and Example
Definition: Descriptive statistics summarizes or describes the characteristics of a data set./nDescriptive statistics consists of three basic categories of measures: measures of central tendency, measures of variability (or spread), and frequency distribution./nMeasures of central tendency describe the center of the data set (mean, median, mode)./nMeasures of variability describe the dispersion of the data set (variance, standard deviation)./nMeasures of frequency distribution describe the occurrence of data within the data set (count).

Term: Devaluation: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: Devaluation is the deliberate downward adjustment of a country's currency value./nThe government issuing the currency can decide to devalue its currency./nDevaluing a currency reduces the cost of a country's exports and can help shrink trade deficits.

Term: What Is a Developed Economy? Definition, How It Works, HDI Index
Definition: Countries with relatively high levels of economic growth and security are considered to have developed economies./nCommon criteria for evaluation include income per capita or per capita gross domestic product./nIf per capita gross domestic product is high but a country has poor infrastructure and income inequality, it would not be considered a developed economy./nNoneconomic factors, such as the human development index, may also be used as criteria./nDeveloping economies are often helped by globalization to reach improved levels of income and increased standards of living.

Term: Diamonds ETF: Meaning, Popularity, Statistics
Definition: The SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average ETF is colloquially called the Diamond ETF, also known as the Dow Jones Diamond Index./nSince its launch in 1998, the Diamond ETF has become popular among investors as a way of achieving approximately the same returns as owning the individual stocks in the underlying Dow Jones Industrial Average./nOwning shares of Diamonds allows investors to attain the diversity of the DJIA with relatively low transaction fees.

Term: Development Economics Definition and Types Explained
Definition: Development economics is a branch of economics whose goal is to better the fiscal, economic, and social conditions of developing countries./nAreas that development economics focuses on include health, education, working conditions, and market conditions./nDevelopment economics seeks to understand and shape macro and microeconomic policies in order to lift poor countries out of poverty./nThe application of development economics is complex and varied as the cultural, social, and economic frameworks of every nation is different./nFour common theories of development economics include mercantilism, nationalism, the linear stages of growth model, and structural-change theory.

Term: Digital Currency Types, Characteristics, Pros & Cons, Future Uses
Definition: Digital currencies are currencies that are only accessible with computers or mobile phones because they only exist in electronic form./nTypical digital currencies do not require intermediaries and are often the cheapest method for trading currencies./nAll cryptocurrencies are digital currencies, but not all digital currencies are cryptocurrencies./nSome of the advantages of digital currencies are that they enable seamless transfer of value and can make transaction costs cheaper./nSome of the disadvantages of digital currencies are that they can volatile to trade and are susceptible to hacks.

Term: Digital Money: What It Is, How It Works, Types, and Examples
Definition: Digital money is money in purely digital form. It is not a tangible asset like cash or commodities./nDigital money streamlines financial infrastructure, making it cheaper and faster to conduct monetary transactions. It can also make it easier for central banks to implement monetary policy./nExamples of types of digital money are central bank digital currencies, cryptocurrency, and stablecoins./nBecause software and networking are essential components of digital money, it is susceptible to hacks.

Term: What Is Digital Marketing? Types and Examples
Definition: Digital marketing promotes products and services through channels such as websites, mobile devices, and social media platforms./nDigital marketers have a number of tools to measure the effectiveness of their campaigns./nOne of the biggest challenges digital marketers face is how to set themselves apart in a world that is oversaturated with digital ads and other distractions.

Term: What Is Diluted EPS? Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: Diluted earnings per share (EPS) is a measurement of a company’s earnings per share if all convertible securities were converted./nDilutive securities are securities that can be converted to common stock./nDilution devalues a shareholder's existing equity stake and reduces a firm's earnings per share./nDiluted EPS is considered a conservative metric because it indicates a worst-case scenario in terms of EPS.

Term: Binary Option: Definition, How They Trade, and Example
Definition: Binary options depend on the outcome of a "yes or no" proposition./nTraders receive a payout if the binary option expires in the money and lose their wager if it expires out of the money./nBinary options set a fixed payout and loss amount./nBinary options don't allow traders to take a position in the underlying security./nMost binary options trading occurs on platforms outside the United States.

Term: What Is a Digital Wallet?
Definition: Digital wallets are financial applications that allow you to store funds, make transactions, and track payment histories on devices like phones and tablets./nYou can store all of your financial information in a digital wallet; some even let you store identification cards and driver's licenses./nDigital wallets may be included in a bank's mobile app or payment apps like PayPal or Alipay./nDigital wallets allow people in financially underserved parts of the world to access financial services they may not have been able to before.

Term: What Is Dilution in Trading? Definition and Examples
Definition: Dilution is the reduction in shareholders' equity positions due to the issuance or creation of new shares./nDilution also reduces a company's earnings per share (EPS), which can have a negative impact on share prices./nDilution can occur when a firm raises additional equity capital, though existing shareholders are usually disadvantaged.

Term: Dim Sum Bond: What it is, How it Works, Panda Bonds
Definition: A dim sum bond refers to an RMB-denominated bond issued in Hong Kong, which is a relatively autonomous region of China./nDim sum bonds are marketed to foreigners who wish to circumvent Chinese capital controls, but still have direct exposure to renminbi-denominated assets./nMultinational corporations may choose to issue these bonds to access regional financing from foreign creditors without restrictions or strict oversight from Chinese authorities.

Term: What Are Direct Costs? Definition, Examples, and Types
Direct Investment Definition, With Types and Examples
Definition: Direct investment, or foreign direct investment, is designed to acquire a controlling interest in an enterprise./nDirect investment provides capital funding in exchange for an equity interest without the purchase of regular shares of a company's stock./nDirect investment may involve a company in one country opening its own business operations in another country./nDirect investment can also involve acquiring control of a business's assets already operating in the foreign country./nThere are three general types of direct investment: vertical, horizontal, or conglomerate investment.

Term: Direct Deposit: What It Is, How It Works, Benefits & Risks
Definition: Direct deposit is the deposit of funds electronically into a bank account rather than through a physical, paper check./nIt requires the use of an electronic network that allows deposits to take place between banks called the automated clearing house./nPayees must provide the payer with their banking information or a void check in order to receive direct deposit payments./nSalaries, tax refunds, investment redemptions, and government benefits are commonly paid through direct deposit.

Term: Direct Market Access (DMA): Definition, Uses, and Benefits
Definition: Direct market access describes the direct access to the electronic facilities and order books of the financial market exchanges in order to execute trades./nIndividual investors typically do not have direct market access but usually rely on an intermediary brokerage firm for trade execution./nInvestment banks and other sell-side firms use sophisticated electronic trading technology that allows them direct market access to the exchanges./nSell-side firms may offer direct market access on a sponsored basis to buy-side entities, such as hedge funds, pension funds, and mutual funds.

Term: Direct Participation Program (DPP): Definition and Requirements
Definition: A direct participation program, or DPP, offers investors access to a business's cash flow and tax benefits./nA DPP requires a buy-in from the members in order to access the program's benefits./nMost DPPs are real-estate investment trusts (REITs) and limited partnerships.

Term: Direct Marketing: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: Direct marketing consists of any marketing that relies on direct communication or distribution to individual consumers, rather than through a third party such as mass media./nThe call to action is a common factor in much of direct marketing./nThe effectiveness of direct marketing is easier to measure than media advertising.

Term: Direct Method: Complexities of Cash Flow Method of Accounting
Definition: Cash flow from operations for a time period can be determined using either the direct or indirect method./nThe cash flow direct method determines changes in cash receipts and payments, which are reported in the cash flow from the operations section./nThe indirect method takes the net income generated in a period and adds or subtracts changes in the asset and liability accounts to determine the implied cash flow./nThe direct method for the statement of cash flows provides more detail about the operating cash flow accounts, although it's time-consuming.

Term: What Is a Direct Quote? Definition in Currency and Formula
Definition: A direct quote is a currency pair quote where the foreign currency is expressed in per-unit terms of the domestic currency./nA direct quote gives you the quantity of local currency needed to purchase one unit of foreign currency./nBecause the U.S. dollar is the most traded currency in the world, the USD generally serves as the base currency in most direct quotes. Some major exceptions to this rule include the British pound and the euro.

Term: Direct Stock Purchase Plan (DSPP): Definition and How DSPPs Work
Definition: A direct stock purchase plan (DSPP) allows investors to purchase shares directly from the company./nDSPPs require very little money to get started./nSome DSPPs have no fees, but most have small fees./nThese programs present long-term investors with a simple and automatic way to acquire shares over time.

Term: Direct Public Offering (DPO): Definition, How It Works, Examples
Definition: With a direct public offering (DPO), or direct placement, a company raises capital by offering its securities directly to the public./nA DPO enables a company to eliminate the intermediaries that are normally part of such an offering and ultimately cut costs./nRaising money independently allows a firm to avoid the restrictions of bank and venture capital funding; the terms of the offering are solely established by the issuing company./nPre-DPO, the company must present compliance documents to regulators of each state where it plans on offering securities; but unlike with an IPO, the firm doesn't usually need to register with the SEC.

Term: What Is Dirty Price? Definition, Vs. Clean Price, and Example
Definition: A dirty price includes accrued interest along with a bond's coupon payment./nIf a bond quotes between coupon payment dates, the price cited includes accrued interest up to the day of the quote./nIn short, a dirty bond price includes accrued interest while a clean bond price does not./nClean quotes are typical in the United States, and dirty quotes are standard in Europe.

Term: Direct Tax Definition, History, and Examples
Definition: A direct tax is paid by an individual or organization to the entity that levied the tax./nDirect taxes include income taxes, property taxes, and taxes on assets./nThere are also indirect taxes, such as sales taxes, wherein a tax is levied on the seller but paid by the buyer.

Term: Directional Movement Index (DMI) Formula, Calculations, Uses
Definition: The directional movement index (DMI) measures both the strength and direction of a price movement and is used to reduce false signals./nThe DMI employs two standard indicators, one negative (-DI) and one positive (+DI), with a third, the average directional index (ADX), which is nondirectional but shows momentum./nThe larger the spread between the two primary lines, the stronger the price trend. If +DI is way above -DI, the price trend is strongly up. If -DI is way above +DI, then the price trend is strongly down./nADX measures the strength of the trend, either up or down. If it's above 25, that indicates a strong trend.

Term: What Is Disability Insurance? Definition and How It Protects You
Definition: Disability insurance is a type of insurance protecting against loss of income due to disability./nDisability insurance is available through both public and private programs./nSome of the variables affecting the cost of disability insurance include the strictness of requirements for qualifying under the plans; the amount of income to be replaced; the length of time in which benefits are paid; the medical history; and the length of time policyholders must wait before beginning to collect those benefits.

Term: What Is a Disbursement?
Definition: A disbursement is the delivery of money from a fund./nIn business accounting, a disbursement is a payment recorded in the general ledger./nA record of disbursements shows how a business spends its cash./nPayments of dividends to shareholders are often termed disbursements./nStudent loan money paid into a school's account on behalf of a student is a disbursement.

Term: What Is Disclosure? How It Works and Laws on Transparency
Definition: Federal regulations require the disclosure of all relevant financial information by publicly-listed companies./nIn addition to financial data, companies are required to reveal their analysis of their strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats./nSubstantive changes to their financial outlooks must be released in a timely fashion.

Term: Discontinued Operations: What They Are and How to Report Them
Definition: Discontinued operations is an accounting term for parts of a firm's operations that have been divested or shut down./nThey are reported on the income statement as a separate entry from continuing operations./nWhen companies merge, understanding which assets are being divested can give a clearer picture of how a company will make money in the future.

Term: Discounts: Definition and Different Types
Definition: In fixed-income trading, a discount occurs when a bond's price is trading below its par or face value,/nBonds may trade at a discount for several reasons, including rising interest rates, or financial distress with the issuer./nDiscount bonds may thus indicate the belief that the underlying company may default on its debt obligations.

Term: Discount Bond: Definition, Using Yield to Maturity, and Risks
Definition: A discount bond is a bond that is issued, or trades in the market for less than its par or face value./nA distressed bond trading at a significant discount to par can effectively raise its yield to attractive levels./nDiscount bonds may indicate the belief that the underlying company may default on their debt obligations.

Term: Discount Broker: Definition, What They Do, Downsides, and Cost
Definition: A discount broker is a stockbroker who carries out buy and sell orders and charges little or no commissions for the service./nDiscount brokers don't provide the investment advice or guidance that's provided by full-service brokers./nDiscount online brokers compose a large segment of the fintech industry./nWhether an investor opts for a discount broker or a full-service broker depends on their investing knowledge, market experience, financial goals, and financial status.

Term: Discount Margin (DM): Definition, When It Applies, and Calculation
Definition: Discount margin is a type of yield-spread calculation designed to estimate the average expected return of a variable-rate security, usually a bond./nA discount margin is the spread (a security's yield relative to the yield of its benchmark) that equates the security's future cash flow to its current market price.

Term: Discount Rate Defined: How It's Used by the Fed and in Cash-Flow Analysis
Definition: In banking, the discount rate is the interest rate the Federal Reserve charges banks for short-term loans./nDiscount lending is a key monetary policy tool and part of the Fed's function as the lender-of-last-resort./nIn discounted cash flow analysis, the discount rate is the rate used to discount future cash flows./nThe discount rate expresses the time value of money in DCF and can make the difference between whether an investment project is financially viable or not./nYou can calculate the discount rate in DCF as long as you know the future and present values and the total number of years.

Term: Discount Yield Formula, Meaning and Examples
Definition: Discount yield computes the expected return of a bond purchased at a discount and held until maturity./nDiscount yield is computed using a standardized 30-day month and 360-day year./nThis calculation is commonly used for evaluating Treasury bills and zero-coupon bonds.

Term: Discounted Payback Period: What It Is, and How To Calculate It
Definition: The discounted payback period is used as part of capital budgeting to determine which projects to take on./nMore accurate than the standard payback period calculation, the discounted payback period factors in the time value of money./nThe discounted payback period formula shows how long it will take to recoup an investment based on observing the present value of the project's projected cash flows./nThe shorter a discounted payback period is, means the sooner a project or investment will generate cash flows to cover the initial cost.

Term: Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Explained With Formula and Examples
Definition: Discounted cash flow analysishelps to determine the value of an investment based on its future cash flows./nThe present value of expected future cash flows is arrived at by using a projected discount rate./nIf the DCF is higher than the current cost of the investment, the opportunity could result in positive returns and may be worthwhile./nCompanies typically use the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) for the discount rate because it accounts for the rate of return expected by shareholders./nA disadvantage of DCF is its reliance on estimations of future cash flows, which could prove inaccurate.

Term: Discounting: What It Means in Finance, With Example
Definition: Discounting is the process of determining the present value of a future payment or stream of payments./nA dollar is always worth more today than it would be worth tomorrow according to the concept of the time value of money./nA higher discount indicates a greater level of risk associated with an investment and its future cash flows./nAn asset has no real value unless it can produce future cash flows.

Term: Discretionary Account: Definition, Examples, Pros & Cons
Definition: A discretionary account is one in which clients hand over control of their trading account to brokers or advisors, who select and execute trades for them./n﻿Clients can customize such accounts by specifying restrictions or preferences for investing style or themes. In recent times, robo-advisers have also become popular instruments for discretionary accounts./nAdvantages of discretionary accounts include quick execution of trades and expert services. Disadvantages of discretionary accounts include higher fees and the possibility of negative performance.

Term: Discouraged Worker: Definition, Causes, Vs. Unemployed
Definition: Discouraged workers are workers who have stopped looking for work because they found no suitable employment options or failed to be shortlisted when applying for a job./nThe causes for worker discouragement are complex and varied./nDiscouraged workers are not included in the headline unemployment number. Instead, they are included in the U-4, U-5, and U-6 unemployment measures./nThe U-4 rate is calculated by dividing the sum of unemployed and discouraged workers by the total labor force, including discouraged workers./nPolicymakers use underutilization of labor rates, such as U-4, to create plans that help discouraged workers get back to work and incentivize companies for hiring them.

Term: Discretionary Income
Definition: Discretionary income is money left over after a person pays their taxes and essential goods and services like housing and food./nNonessential items like vacations and luxury goods are usually paid for with funds from discretionary income./nDisposable income and discretionary income are two different things./nDisposable income is the net income of a person's take-home pay and is used to pay for all expenses (both essential and nonessentials)./nDiscretionary income is used by economists to measure economic health.

Term: Discretionary Expense Definition, Examples, Budgeting
Definition: A discretionary expense is a cost that is not essential for the operation of a home or a business./nIn a corporate environment, discretionary expenses are usually costs linked with improving a company’s reputation among its customers and employees./nTracking discretionary expenses enables businesses and households to identify where they can save money in times of financial difficulties./nDiscretionary expenses vary depending on the business or person.

Term: Discrete Probability Distribution: Overview and Examples
Definition: A discrete probability distribution counts occurrences that have countable or finite outcomes./nDiscrete distributions contrast with continuous distributions, where outcomes can fall anywhere on a continuum./nCommon examples of discrete distribution include the binomial, Poisson, and Bernoulli distributions./nThese distributions often involve statistical analyses of "counts" or "how many times" an event occurs./nIn finance, discrete distributions are used in options pricing and forecasting market shocks or recessions.

Term: Diseconomies of Scale Definition: Causes and Types Explained
Definition: Diseconomies of scale occur when the expansion of output comes with increasing average unit costs./nDiseconomies of scale can involve factors internal to an operation or external conditions beyond a firm's control./nDiseconomies of scale may result from technical issues in a production process, organizational management issues, or resource constraints on productive inputs.

Term: Disinflation: Definition, How It Works, Triggers, and Example
Definition: Disinflation is a temporary slowing of the pace of price inflation. The term is used to describe occasions when the inflation rate has reduced marginally over the short term./nUnlike inflation and deflation, which refer to the direction of prices, disinflation refers to the rate of change in the rate of inflation./nA healthy amount of disinflation is necessary since it prevents the economy from overheating./nThe danger that disinflation presents is when the rate of inflation falls near to zero, as it did in 2015, raising the specter of deflation./nDisinflation has reemerged in 2023 after inflation reached its highest levels in four decades last year.

Term: Disguised Unemployment: Definition and Different Types
Definition: Disguised unemployment is unemployment that does not affect aggregate economic output./nIt occurs when productivity is low and too many workers are filling too few jobs./nIt can refer to any part of the population that is not employed at full capacity.

Term: Disequilibrium: Definition in the Market, Reasons, and Example
Definition: Disequilibrium is when external forces cause a disruption in a market's supply and demand equilibrium. In response, the market enters a state during which supply and demand are mismatched./nDisequilibrium is caused due to several reasons, from government intervention to labor market inefficiencies and unilateral action by a supplier or distributor./nDisequilibrium is generally resolved by the market entering into a new state of equilibrium./nFor instance, people are incentivized to start producing more overpriced goods, increasing the supply to meet demand and lowering the price back to its equilibrium./nExamples can include short-term scenarios like flash crashes to long-term events like recessions and depressions.

Term: Disintermediation: Definition and Examples in Business & Finance
Definition: Disintermediation is the process of cutting out one or more middlemen from a transaction, supply chain, or decision-making process./nThe usual reasons for disintermediation are to reduce costs or increase delivery speed./nIn financial terms, disintermediation involves the removal of banks, brokers, or other third parties, allowing individuals to transact or invest directly./nCryptocurrencies are disintermediating the financial sector and government from monetary transactions./nThe process doesn't always work because it requires additional staffing and other resources to replace the services supplied by an intermediary.

Term: Disinvestment: Definition, Meaning, Types, and Examples
Definition: Disinvestment is when governments or organizations sell or liquidate assets or subsidiaries./nDisinvestments can take the form of divestment or a reduction of capital expenditures (CapEx)./nDisinvestment is carried out for a variety of reasons, such as strategic, political, or environmental.

Term: Disposition: Definition, How It Works in Investing, and Example
Definition: A disposition refers generally to the selling securities or assets on the open market./nDispositions can also take the form of transfers or donations to charities, endowments, or trusts./nFor business dispositions, the SEC requires certain reporting to be completed depending on the nature of the disposition./nDispositions that are donations, assignments, or transfers, can often be used to take advantage of beneficial tax treatment.

Term: What Is Disposable Income, and Why Is It Important?
Definition: Disposable income is the amount of income left after taxes and other mandatory charges are deducted./nDiscretionary income is the amount of net income an individual has to spend after all necessary expenses are paid./nEconomists monitor both numbers to help determine how consumers as a whole are saving, spending, and borrowing money.

Term: Dispersion in Statistics: Understanding How It's Used
Definition: Dispersion refers to the range of potential outcomes of investments based on historical volatility or returns./nDispersion can be measured using alpha and beta, which calculate risk-adjusted returns and returns relative to a benchmark index, respectively./nGenerally speaking, the higher the dispersion, the riskier an investment is, and vice versa.

Term: Disruptive Innovation: Meaning and Examples
Definition: Disruptive innovation refers to innovations and technologies that make expensive or sophisticated products and services accessible and more affordable to a broader market./nDisruptive innovation refers to the use of technology that upsets a structure, as opposed to "disruptive technology", which refers to the technology itself./nAmazon, launched as an online bookstore in the mid-1990s, is an example of disruptive innovation./nDisruptive innovation requires enabling technology, an innovative business model, and a coherent value network./nSustaining innovation is the process of innovating to improve products and services for existing customers.

Term: Disruptive Technology: Definition, Example, and How to Invest
Definition: A disruptive technology supersedes an older process, product, or habit./nIt usually has superior attributes that are immediately obvious, at least to early adopters./nUpstarts rather than established companies are the usual source of disruptive technologies.

Term: Dissenters' Rights: What They are, How They Work, In Practice
Definition: Dissenters' rights ensure a shareholder that they can sell their shares at fair value in the event that a company takes a decision that they do not agree with./nDissenters' rights are guaranteed under state corporate law./nWhen a dissenting shareholder disagrees with a firm's actions, they can exercise appraisal rights; appraising their shares, and being paid the fair market value for them./nDissenters' rights provide an easy way out of a company for a shareholder./nThere are many risks associated with dissenters' rights, such as the cost of litigation or shares being undervalued in the appraisal process.

Term: Distressed Securities: Meaning, Overview and Examples
Definition: Distressed securities are securities issued by a company that is near to—or in the midst of—bankruptcy./nThe company may also have breached covenants (conditions of the security issuance), which is frequently a precursor to the bankruptcy itself./nCertain high-risk investors, sometimes known as ‘hawks’, are willing to invest in distressed securities in the hope of making a quick buck.

Term: Basics of a Distress Sale, Why It Often Leads to Financial Loss
Definition: Distress sales occur when the seller needs to sell an asset urgently, often to pay debts or medical expenses or for other emergencies./nA short sale is a form of distressed sale in which the homeowner attempts to sell their property even though the current market value is below the amount owed to their lender./nDistress sales often result in a financial loss for the seller because buyers realize that the seller is in a hurry to obtain funds and will offer a lower price./nBuying a property through foreclosure or a distressed sale may mean that the property is in a poor state of repair.

Term: Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT): Definition and How It Works
Definition: Distributed ledgers are maintained by a network of nodes, each of which has a copy of the ledger, validates the information, and helps reach a consensus about its accuracy./nDistributed ledgers have been around for decades but have become more well-known, researched, used, and developed since Bitcoin was introduced./nDistributed ledgers can be used in nearly every industry where data is collected and used./nAll blockchains are distributed ledgers, but not all distributed ledgers are blockchains./nThough DLT enhances accountability, security, and accessibility, it is still complex, difficult to scale, and not subject to strong regulation.

Term: Distributed Ledgers: Definition, How They're Used, and Potential
