Definition: Economic stimulus refers to targeted fiscal and monetary policy intended to elicit an economic response from the private sector./nEconomic stimulus relies on encouraging private sector spending to make up for loss of aggregate demand./nFiscal stimulus measures include deficit spending and lowering taxes. Monetary stimulus measures are produced by central banks and may include lowering interest rates./nEconomists still argue over the usefulness of coordinated economic stimulus, with some claiming that it can do more long-term harm than short-term good.

Term: Economic Value: Definition, Examples, Ways To Estimate
Definition: Economic value is the value that a person places on a good or service, based on the benefit they get from it./nEconomic value is subjective and difficult or impossible to measure, though there are approaches to estimating it./nProducers use estimates of economic value to set prices for their products taking into consideration tangible and intangible factors such as brand name.

Term: Economic Value Added (EVA) Definition: Pros and Cons, With Formula
Definition: Economic value added (EVA), also known as economic profit, aims to calculate the true economic profit of a company./nEVA is used to measure the value a company generates from funds invested in it./nHowever, EVA relies heavily on invested capital and is best used for asset-rich companies, where companies with intangible assets, such as technology businesses, may not be good candidates.

Term: Economic Value of Equity (EVE) Definition, Limitations
Economies of Scope: Definition, Example, and Importance
Definition: Economies of scope describe situations where producing two or more goods together results in a lower marginal cost than producing them separately./nEconomies of scope differ from economies of scale, in that the former means producing a variety of different products together to reduce costs while the latter means producing more of the same good in order to reduce costs by increasing efficiency./nEconomies of scope can result from goods that are co-products or complements in production, goods that have complementary production processes, or goods that share inputs to production.

Term: Economies of Scale: What Are They and How Are They Used?
Definition: Economies of scale are cost advantages companies experience when production becomes efficient, as costs can be spread over a larger amount of goods./nA business's size is related to whether it can achieve an economy of scale—larger companies will have more cost savings and higher production levels./nEconomies of scale can be both internal and external. Internal economies are caused by factors within a single company while external factors affect the entire industry.

Term: What Is an Economist? Definition, Role, Duties, and Influence
Definition: An economist is an expert who studies the relationship between a society's resources and its production or output, using a number of different indicators, in order to predict future trends./nAccording to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median pay for an economist in 2021 was $105,630 per year or $50.79 per hour./nA career as an economist has two main requirements: an advanced degree, such as a Ph.D. or a master's degree, and an area of specialization to focus research efforts./nThe theories of economists can provide a way for businesses and the government to react to the future direction of the economy.

Term: Economy: What It Is, Types of Economies, Economic Indicators
Definition: An economy is a system of interrelated production and consumption activities that ultimately determine the allocation of resources within a group./nThe production and consumption of goods and services fulfills the needs of those living and operating within an economy./nMarket-based economies, also called free market economies, are self-regulated, allowing goods to be produced and distributed in response to demand from consumers./nCommand-based economies are regulated by a government body that determines the goods that are produced, their quantities, and their prices./nIn the modern world, few economies are purely market-based or command-based.

Term: What Is EdTech? Definition, Example, Pros & Cons
Definition: EdTech, short for education technology, refers to new technological implementations in the classroom./nIn-classroom tablets, interactive projection screens and whiteboards, online content delivery, and MOOCs are all examples of EdTech./nThe goal of EdTech is to improve student outcomes, enhance individualized education, and reduce the teaching burden on instructors./nWhile many praise technology in the classroom, others fear that it is impersonal and can lead to data collection and tracking of both students and instructors.

Term: Education Loan: Definition, Types, Debt Strategies
Definition: An education loan is a sum of money borrowed to finance post-secondary education or higher education-related expenses./nEducation loans are intended to cover the cost of tuition, books and supplies, and living expenses while the borrower is in the process of pursuing a degree./nPayments are often deferred while students are in college and, depending on the lender, sometimes they are deferred for an additional six-month period after earning a degree./nAlthough there are a variety of education loans, they can be broken down generally into two basic types: federal loans (sponsored by the federal government) and private loans.

Term: Education IRA: Definition, Rules and Limits, Vs. 529 Plan
Definition: An education IRA is a tax-advantaged savings account used to pay for children's' educational expenses./nThey are formally known as Coverdell Education Savings Accounts./nEducational IRAs are similar to 529 savings plans but with some key differences.

Term: Effective Annual Interest Rate: Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The effective annual interest rate is the true interest rate on an investment or loan because it considers the effects of compounding./nThe more frequent the compounding periods, the higher the rate./nA savings account or a loan may be advertised with both a nominal interest rate and an effective annual interest rate./nThe effective annual interest rate is the rate that should be compared between loans and investment rates of return./nThe effective annual interest rate does not communicate risk, incorporate fees, or factor in tax implications.

Term: Effective Date
Effective Gross Income (EGI): Definition and Calculation Formula
Definition: Effective gross income is calculated by adding the potential gross rental income with other income and subtracting vacancy and credit costs of a rental property./nEGI is key in determining the value of a rental property and the true positive cash flow it can produce./nGross potential rental income is the hypothetical amount an investor would receive not considering the negative situations associated with rental properties./nSome of the most common examples of other income generated from rental properties include storage units, pet fees, monthly parking permits, and on-premise vending machines.

Term: Effective Duration: Definition, Formula, Example
Definition: Effective duration is a duration calculation for bonds that have embedded options./nCash flows are uncertain in bonds with embedded options, making it difficult to know the rate of return./nThe impact on cash flows as interest rates change is measured by effective duration./nEffective duration calculates the expected price decline of a bond when interest rates rise by 1%.

Term: What Is the Effective Interest Method of Amortization?
Definition: The effective interest method is used to discount, or write off, a bond./nThe amount of the bond discount is amortized to interest expense over the bond's life. As a bond's book value increases, the amount of interest expense increases./nThe effective interest method considers the impact of the bond purchase price rather than accounting only for its par value or face value./nFor lenders or investors, the effective interest rate reflects the actual return far better than the nominal rate./nFor borrowers, the effective interest rate shows costs more effectively./nUnlike the real interest rate, the effective interest rate does not account for inflation.

Term: Effective Tax Rate: How It's Calculated and How It Works
Definition: The effective tax rate represents the percentage of their taxable income that individuals pay in taxes./nFor corporations, the effective corporate tax rate is the rate they pay on their pre-tax profits./nEffective tax rate typically refers only to federal income tax./nThe effective tax rate can be computed to reflect an individual's or a company's total tax burden./nIndividuals are taxed at differing rates that rise as income hits certain thresholds under marginal tax rates.

Term: What Is Effective Yield? Definition, Calculation, and Example
Definition: The effective yield is calculated as the bond’s coupon payments divided by the bond’s current market value/nEffective yield assumes coupon payments are reinvested. Reinvested coupons mean the effective yield of a bond is higher than the nominal (stated coupon) yield./nTo compare a bond's effective yield and its yield-to-maturity, the effective yield must be converted to an effective annual yield./nBonds trading with an effective yield higher than the yield-to-maturity sell at a premium. If the effective yield is lower than the yield-to-maturity, the bond trades at a discount.

Term: Efficiency: What It Means in Economics, the Formula To Measure It
Definition: Efficiency occurs when you reduce waste to produce a given number of goods or services./nYou can measure efficiency by dividing total output by total input./nThere are a number of different types of efficiency, including economic efficiency, market efficiency, and operational efficiency./nEfficiency is an important attribute because all inputs are scarce./nYou can measure the efficiency of your investments using the return on investment figure.

Term: Efficient Frontier: What It Is and How Investors Use It
Definition: The efficient frontier comprises investment portfolios that offer the highest expected return for a specific level of risk./nThe standard deviation of returns in a portfolio measures investment risk and consistency in investment earnings./nLower covariance between portfolio securities results in lower portfolio standard deviation./nSuccessful optimization of the return versus risk paradigm should place a portfolio along the efficient frontier line./nOptimal portfolios that comprise the efficient frontier usually exhibit a higher degree of diversification.

Term: Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH): Definition and Critique
Definition: The efficient market hypothesis (EMH) or theory states that share prices reflect all information./nThe EMH hypothesizes that stocks trade at their fair market value on exchanges./nProponents of EMH posit that investors benefit from investing in a low-cost, passive portfolio./nOpponents of EMH believe that it is possible to beat the market and that stocks can deviate from their fair market values.

Term: Elasticity: What It Means in Economics, Formula, and Examples
Definition: Companies that operate in highly competitive industries offer products and services that are elastic, as the companies tend to be price-takers./nWhen the price of a good or service has reached the point of elasticity, sellers and buyers quickly adjust their demand for that good or service./nElasticity is an important economic measure, particularly for sellers of goods or services, because the reflects how much of a good or service buyers will consume when the price increases or decreases./nProducts or services that are elastic are either unnecessary or can be easily replaced with a substitute.

Term: Egalitarianism: Definition, Ideas, and Types
Definition: Egalitarianism is a philosophy based on equality, namely that all people are equal and deserve equal treatment in all things./nAs an idea, it can be looked at in terms of its implications for individuals in both an economic and legal capacity./nEconomic egalitarianism, which argues that all should have access to wealth, is the basis for both Marxism and socialism./nLegal egalitarianism says that everyone must follow the same laws, with no special legal protections for one over another./nMany countries in the world have aspects of egalitarianism woven into the fabric of their societies.

Term: What Is Elasticity in Finance; How Does it Work (with Example)?
Definition: Elasticity is an economic measure of how sensitive one economic factor is to changes in another./nFor example, changes in supply or demand to the change in price, or changes in demand to changes in income./nIf demand for a good or service is relatively static even when the price changes, demand is said to be inelastic, and its coefficient of elasticity is less than 1.0./nExamples of elastic goods include clothing or electronics, while inelastic goods are items like food and prescription drugs./nCross elasticity measures the change in demand for one good given price changes in a different, related good.

Term: Elective-Deferral Contribution: What It Is, How It Works, Limits
Definition: An elective-deferral contribution is a portion of an employee's salary that's withheld and transferred into a retirement plan such as a 401(k)./nElective deferrals can be made on a pre-tax or after-tax basis if an employer allows./nThe IRS limits how much you can contribute to a qualified retirement plan./nIndividuals under the age of 50 can contribute up to $22,500 in 2023 and $23,000 in 2024./nPeople 50 and above can make catch-up contributions of an additional $7,500 in 2023 and 2024 for a total of $30,000 and $30,500, respectively.

Term: Electronic Bill Payment & Presentment (EBPP): Definition, Types
Definition: EBPPs are systems used to collect payments electronically./nA biller-direct EBPP lets users pay bills directly via the company's website./nIn the bank-aggregator model, a banking customer can pay several different bills from their bank accounts./nSome newer services allow customers to pay all of their bills from one website and these are called consumer-consolidation EBPPs.

Term: Electronic Check (E-Check): Definition and How It Works
Definition: An electronic check is a form of payment made via the internet that is designed to perform the same function as a conventional paper check./nOne of the more frequently used versions of the electronic check is the direct deposit system offered by many employers./nGenerally, the costs associated with issuing an electronic check are notably lower than those associated with paper checks./nAn electronic check has more security features than standard paper checks.

Term: E-commerce Defined: Types, History, and Examples
Definition: E-commerce is the buying and selling of goods and services over the internet./nIt is conducted over computers, tablets, smartphones, and other smart devices./nAlmost anything can be purchased through e-commerce today, which makes e-commerce highly competitive./nIt can be a substitute for brick-and-mortar stores, though some businesses choose to maintain both./nE-commerce operates in several market segments including business-to-business, business-to-consumer, consumer-to-consumer, and consumer-to-business.

Term: Electronic Communication Network (ECN): Definition and Examples
Definition: An electronic communication network (ECN) is a digital system that matches buyers and sellers looking to trade securities in the financial markets./nECNs allow brokerages and investors in different geographic areas to trade without a third party involved, offering privacy for investors./nECNs enables trading to happen outside of traditional trading hours, therefore enabling investors to react to or anticipate after-hours news./nOne of the downsides of using ECNs is that they have access fees and commission charges that can jack up the overall price of use./nWithout ECNs, it would take considerably longer for buyers and sellers to be matched with one another, making it more difficult to enter or exit positions and adding to the costs and risks of trading.

Term: Electronic Data Gathering Analysis and Retrieval: Overview, FAQ
Definition: Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis, and Retrieval (EDGAR) is an online database of public filings maintained by the Securities and Exchange Commission./nUnder the Securities Act of 1933, public companies are required to disclose certain information to the public./nIn addition to equity information, EDGAR can also be used to search the public filings of mutual funds, variable insurance products, or other types of securities./nEDGAR was launched in 1992, but electronic filings did not become mandatory until 1995./nToday, EDGAR can be used to find annual or quarterly reports for public companies as far back as 1995 or even 1994.

Term: Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS) Overview
Definition: The Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS) is a 24-7 service provided by the U.S. Department of the Treasury that allows taxpayers to make tax payments either by telephone or online./nThe system allows taxpayers to file directly with the IRS using a filer's social security number and personalized PIN number./nIn the past, fraudulent emails were sent that targeted EFTPS users, indicating that identification numbers were rejected or prompting users to follow an embedded link to change personal information.

Term: Electronic Filing (E-File) Definition, Options, and Advantages
Definition: Electronic filing is the process of submitting tax returns via the Internet./nIt's available from professional tax preparers, through guided preparation software that has been preapproved by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), or free fillable forms on the IRS website./nIt allows taxpayers to file taxes online at their convenience and speeds up refunds while reducing errors.

Term: Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA): Definition and Requirements
Definition: The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) protects consumers when transferring funds electronically./nThe EFTA was enacted in 1978 as a result of the increased use of ATMs./nProtection under the EFTA includes transfers made via ATMs, debit cards, direct deposits, point-of-sale, and phone.

Term: What Is Electronic Money or eMoney?
Definition: Electronic money is currency stored in banking computer systems./nElectronic money is backed by fiat currency and the central banking system./nVarious companies allow for transactions with electronic money, such as Square or PayPal.

Term: Electronic Retailing (e-Tailing): Definition, Types, Examples
Definition: Electronic retailing is the sale of goods and services through the internet./nE-tailing can include business-to-business (B2B) and business-to-consumer (B2C) sales of products and services./nAmazon.com (AMZN) is by far the largest online retailer providing consumer products and subscriptions through its website./nMany traditional brick-and-mortar stores are investing in e-tailing through their websites.

Term: Electronic Payments Network (EPN): What it is, How it Works
Definition: The Electronic Payments Network is a financial clearinghouse that handles electronic funds transfers for the private sector./nThe network facilitates bulk credit and debit transactions, such as payroll deposits and loan payments./nIt is used to process recurring payments as well as one-time debit transfers.

Term: What Is an Elevator Pitch? Definition and How They're Used
Definition: An elevator pitch is a slang term that refers to a brief speech that outlines the idea for a product, service, or project./nAn elevator pitch gets its name from the notion that the speech should be short—no longer than the time period of an elevator ride—or about 30 to 60 seconds long./nThe objective of an elevator pitch is to pique the listener's curiosity enough for them to take any action, such as asking for more information or scheduling a follow-up meeting./nProject managers, salespeople, and job seekers use elevator pitches as a way of marketing themselves, their products, or their ideas./nEntrepreneurs use elevator pitches to help obtain startup capital from venture capitalists and angel investors.

Term: Email Money Transfer (EMT): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: An email money transfer allows users to transfer funds between personal accounts, using email and their online banking service./nEMT is provided by Interac and is not available to U.S. citizens./nNearly all online banks in Canada offer EMTs.

Term: Elliott Wave Theory: What It Is and How to Use It
Definition: The Elliott Wave theory is a technical analysis of price patterns related to changes in investor sentiment and psychology./nThe theory identifies impulse waves that establish a pattern and corrective waves that oppose the larger trend./nEach set of waves is within another set of waves that adhere to the same impulse or corrective pattern, described as a fractal approach to investing.

Term: What Is Embezzlement, and How Does It Happen?
Definition: Embezzlement takes place when a person intentionally uses funds for a different purpose than they were intended to be used./nThe embezzler has permission to handle an asset in a certain way, but not to take it./nEmbezzlers might create bills and receipts for activities that did not occur and then use the money paid for personal expenses./nPonzi schemes are an example of embezzlement. Others include destroying employee records or pocketing company cash./nBusinesses lost approximately $400 billion each year to theft./nEmbezzlers can be held civilly and criminally responsible for their crimes.

Term: Embargo: Definition, Examples, and Effects
Definition: Embargoes are international trade restrictions adopted in response to objectionable policies./nEmbargoes have been more effective in punishing targeted countries than in getting them to alter their behavior./nU.S. embargoes bar trade with Cuba, North Korea, Iran, and Syria, and trade restrictions on Russia and Russian-occupied Ukraine have had a similar effect./nThe U.S. faced an Arab oil embargo in 1973-1974 over its support for Israel.

Term: Emergency Banking Act of 1933: Definition, Purpose, Importance
Definition: The Emergency Banking Act of 1933 was a legislative response to the bank failures of the Great Depression, and the public's lack of faith in the U.S. financial system./nThe Act, which temporarily closed banks for four days for inspection, served immediately to shore up confidence in the banks and to provide a boost to the stock market./nMany of its key provisions have endured to this day, notably the insuring of bank accounts by the FDIC and the executive powers it granted the president to respond to financial crises.

Term: Emerging Industries: Meaning, Overview, Examples
Definition: An emerging industry refers to companies that are formed around a new product or idea that is in the early stages of development./nCompanies that are in emerging industries must overcome many barriers to entry if they are to become profitable./nThese barriers may include the lack of sufficient funding, the inability to take advantage of economies of scale, government restrictions, and competition from established companies./nExamples of current emerging industries include artificial intelligence (AI), robotics, virtual reality, self-driving cars, and biotechnology./nSeveral exchange traded funds (ETFs) have been created to enable investment in emerging industries while reducing some of the risks associated with investing in these new sectors.

Term: Emergency Fund
Definition: An emergency fund is a financial safety net for future mishaps and/or unexpected expenses./nEmergency funds should typically have three to six months’ worth of expenses, although the 2020 economic crisis and lockdown has led some experts to suggest up to one year’s worth./nIndividuals should keep their emergency funds in accounts that are easily accessible and easily liquidated./nSavers can use tax refunds and other windfalls to build up their funds./nSome employers have established programs to encourage emergency fund saving.

Term: Emerging Market Economy Definition, How It Works, and Examples
Definition: An emerging market economy is an economy that's transitioning into a developed economy./nEmerging market economies typically feature a unified currency, stock market, and banking system; they're in the process of industrializing./nEmerging market economies can offer greater returns to investors due to their rapid growth./nThey also offer greater exposure to some inherent risks due to their status./nOver time, emerging markets typically adopt reforms seen in developed markets.

Term: Understanding Emerging Markets Bond Index (EMBI) & How It's Used
Definition: The emerging markets bond index (EMBI) tracks the performance of emerging market bonds and was first published by investment bank JP Morgan./nEmerging market bonds are debt instruments issued by developing countries, which tend to carry higher yields than government or corporate bonds of developed countries./nMost of the benchmark EMBI index tracks emerging sovereign debt, with the rest in regional corporate bonds.

Term: MSCI Emerging Markets Index: Overview, How to Invest
Definition: The MSCI Emerging Markets Index is used to measure the financial performance of companies in fast-growing economies around the world./nThe index tracks mid-cap and large-cap stocks in 25 countries./nIts top holdings currently concentrate on Asian and Indian companies in the infotech, financial, and consumer discretionary sectors./nInvestors can invest in the index through an ETF that mirrors it or a fund that uses it as a benchmark./nAll emerging market funds are considered long-term, high-risk investments, with outsized potential for gains and losses.

Term: What Is Emigration? Definition, Reasons, and Economic Impact
Definition: Emigration is the relocation or process of people leaving one country to reside in another./nPeople emigrate for many reasons, including increasing one's chance of employment or improving quality of life./nEmigration has an economic impact on the countries involved, including the workforce and consumer spending./nThe sending country may lose knowledgeable resources, though departing labor may actually alleviate unemployment pressures.

Term: Eminent Domain: Meaning and Types
Definition: Eminent domain is the right of governments like the United States to seize private property for public use, following fair compensation./nEverything from airspace, land, and contract rights to intellectual property is subject to eminent domain if a case can be made for its public use./nUnfair invoking of eminent domain, such as when property owners are not fairly compensated, is called inverse condemnation./nBoth an entire property and a partial property can be seized, as well as the potential for a temporary seizure./nThere have been some instances where a private party has used eminent domain seizures under the guise of public improvements.

Term: What Is Empire Building? How It Works, Strategies, and Examples
Definition: Empire building is the pursuit to enlarge the size, scope, and influence of an individual or organization's power./nIncreasing market share, buying power, or deal-making influence are all elements to empire building./nEmpire building can be considered as a negative for a corporation because management can become fixated on controlling resources and influence than with optimally allocating resources and maximizing profits./nEmpire building can be done through a variety of strategies including mergers and acquisitions, vertical integration, and strategic alliances./nAdvantages of empire-building include possible economies of scale for the company, job security for the empire builders, and increased prestige (for both the company and empire builders)

Term: Empirical Rule: Definition, Formula, Example, How It's Used
Definition: The Empirical Rule states that 99.7% of data observed following a normal distribution lies within 3 standard deviations of the mean./nUnder this rule, 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation, 95% percent within two standard deviations, and 99.7% within three standard deviations from the mean./nThree-sigma limits that follow the empirical rule are used to set the upper and lower control limits in statistical quality control charts and in risk analysis.

Term: Employee Buyout (EBO): Voluntary Severance Overview
Definition: An employee buyout (EBO) is when an employer offers select employees a voluntary severance package./nA buyout package usually includes benefits and pay for a specified period of time./nEmployee buyouts are used to reduce employee headcount and therefore, salary costs, the cost of benefits, and any contributions by the company to retirement plans./nAn employee buyout can also refer to when employees take over the company they work for by buying a majority stake.

Term: Employee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOP): What It Is, How It Works, Advantages
Definition: An employee stock ownership plan (ESOP) is an employee benefit plan that gives workers ownership interest in the company in the form of shares of stock./nESOPs encourage employees to give their all as the company’s success translates into financial rewards./nThey also help staff to feel more appreciated and better compensated for the work they do./nCompanies typically tie distributions from the plan to vesting, which gives employees rights to employer-provided assets over time./nIt’s important to read the terms of your ESOP, as each one may vary and have different rules./nOther versions of employee ownership include direct-purchase programs, stock options, restricted stock, phantom stock, and stock appreciation rights.

Term: Employee Stock Options (ESOs): A Complete Guide
Definition: Employee stock options are offered by companies to their employees as equity compensation plans./nThese grants come in the form of regular call options and give an employee the right to buy the company’s stock at a specified price for a finite period of time./nESOs can have vesting schedules that limit the ability to exercise./nESOs are taxed at exercise, and stockholders will be taxed if they sell their shares in the open market./nThey can have significant time value even if they have zero or little intrinsic value.

Term: Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) History, Purpose
Definition: ERISA is a federal law that implements standards for certain employer-sponsored retirement and health plans./nThe law has gone through a series of changes since it was first enacted in 1974./nERISA prohibits fiduciaries from misusing funds and sets standards for participation, benefit accrual, vesting, and funding of retirement plans.

Term: Employers' Liability Insurance: Definition, Coverage, Limits
Definition: Employers' liability insurance covers companies against costs and claims by employees that are not covered by workers' compensation./nMany organizations choose to carry employers' liability insurance to help cover legal costs and lawsuits./nMost workers’ compensation insurance policies automatically include employers' liability insurance./nEmployers' liability insurance places limits on the amounts paid out per employee, per incident, or per policy.

Term: Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: An ESPP is a program in which employees can purchase company stock at a discounted price./nEmployees contribute through payroll deductions, which build until the purchase date./nThe discount can be as much as 15% in some cases./nIncome or loss from the sale of shares you purchased through an ESPP is generally taxed as a capital gain or loss, though there are holding period requirements.

Term: Employer Identification Number (EIN): Who Needs It and How to Get It
Definition: An employer identification number is a unique nine-digit number that is assigned to a business entity./nEINs allow the IRS to easily identify businesses for tax reporting purposes./nAll businesses that meet certain criteria must have an EIN before they can begin operating./nApplying for one is free and applications are available on the IRS website./nAlong with tax reporting, EINs allow businesses to open bank accounts and apply for credit.

Term: Employment Agency Fees: Meaning, Overview, Types
Definition: Employment agency fees are paid by a company to an employment agency when it successfully places a suitable employee with that employer./nWith employer-paid fees, the employer pays the fee to the agency, so the employee pays nothing./nApplicant-paid fees are less common and are normally claimed as a portion of a worker's hourly pay during the term of a contract.

Term: Employment Insurance (EI): What it Means, How it Works
Employment-to-Population Ratio: Definition and What It Measures
Definition: The employment-to-population ratio is a measure of the number of people employed against the total working-age population./nSeasonal variations and short-term labor fluctuations do not affect the employment-to-population ratio./nUnlike the unemployment rate, the employment-to-population ratio includes unemployed people not looking for jobs.

Term: Encumbrance: Definition, Examples, and Types
Definition: An encumbrance is a claim made against a property by someone other than the current titleholder./nSome claims, such as those in commercial cases, do not affect the value of the property./nCommon types of claims include leases,property tax liens,easements, and mortgages./nBuyers of real estate should find out if any encumbrance is attached to the property they wish to purchase before they buy.

Term: What Is End-To-End? A Full Process, From Start to Finish
Definition: End-to-end refers to delivering complex systems or services in functional form after developing it from beginning to end./nEnd-to-end is most common in the IT sector and is used during the planning, implementation, and evaluation stages./nEnd-to-end processing can help optimize a business's performance and efficiency by eliminating the middle man./nWhen dealing with complex services or systems, end-to-end arrangements are often cost-effective./nLogistics, when service providers take care of inventory management, storage, and distribution, is an example of end-to-end in industries outside of IT.

Term: Encroachment: What It Means in Real Estate and How It Happens
Definition: Encroachment occurs when a property owner trespasses onto their neighbor’s property by building or extending structures beyond their property line./nProperty owners may encroach on their neighbors intentionally or unintentionally./nStructural encroachment occurs when a property owner builds or extends a structure onto public spaces./nBoundaries and property lines can be cleared up by getting a land survey./nAlthough similar, easements are consensual and provide fair compensation to the legal property owner.

Term: Endogenous Growth Theory: Definition, History, and Criticism
Definition: Endogenous growth theory maintains that economic growth is primarily the result of internal forces, rather than external ones./nIt argues that improvements in productivity can be tied directly to faster innovation and more investments in human capital from governments and private sector institutions./nThis view contrasts with neoclassical economics.

Term: Endogenous Variable: Definition, Meaning, and Examples
Definition: Endogenous variables are variables in a statistical model that are changed or determined by their relationship with other variables./nEndogenous variables are dependent variables, meaning they correlate with other factors—although it can be a positive or negative correlation./nEndogenous variables are important in economic modeling because they show whether a variable causes a particular effect.

Term: Endorsements: Signatures, Insurance Riders, and Public Approvals
Definition: An endorsement has different meanings, but most have to do with the concept of approval or authorization./nAn endorsement refers to a signature or an equivalent stamp that authorizes payment or a transfer of funds, as when an individual signs a check./nEndorsements can refer to amendments to contracts or documents, such as life insurance policies or driver's licenses./nA public declaration of support for a person, product, or service is also called an endorsement.

Term: Endowment Effect: Definition, What Causes It, and Example
Definition: The endowment effect describes a circumstance in which an individual places a higher value on an object that they already own than the value they would place on that same object if they did not own it./nEndowment effect can be clearly seen with items that have an emotional or symbolic significance to the individual./nResearch has identified "ownership" and "loss aversion" as the two main psychological reasons causing the endowment effect./nThe endowment effect is closely tied to marketing in which companies often try to take advantage of this cognitive bias./nInvestors can overcome the endowment effect by having a clear investment strategy with a plan on when to sell specific investments.

Term: Understanding Endowments: Types and Policies That Govern Them
Definition: Endowments are usually awarded by a trust, private foundation, or public charity./nThey benefit nonprofit educational institutions, cultural institutions, and service-oriented organizations./nMost endowments come with restrictions that limit their use to the investment income of the fund, not the principal.

Term: Energy Return on Investment (EROI): Overview, Calculations
Definition: Energy Return on Investment (EROI) is the amount of energy expended to produce a certain amount of net energy./nEROI is an important determinant in energy commodity and electricity pricing./nEROI decreases when energy becomes scarcer and more difficult to extract or produce.

Term: Energy Sector: Understanding Which Types of Companies Comprise It
Definition: The energy sector includes corporations that primarily are in the business of producing or supplying energy such as fossil fuels or renewables./nThe energy sector has been an important driver of industrial growth over the past century, providing fuel to power the rest of the economy./nCompanies in the energy industry are classified based on how the energy is sourced such as non-renewables or fossil fuels and renewables such as solar.

Term: Engagement Letter: What It Is, How It Works, and Why It's Important
Definition: An engagement letter defines a business relationship between two parties./nA letter of engagement limits the responsibilities of the company, directly or by inference./nA wide range of businesses including attorneys, auditors, accountants, and consultants use engagement letters routinely./nEngagement letters can be used by individuals or large corporations.

Term: Energy Risk Professional (ERP): What It is, How to Become one
Definition: Energy Risk Professional (ERP) is a professional designation provided by the Global Association of Risk Professionals (GARP)./nThe ERP designation is completed by individuals working in the oil, coal, natural gas, and alternative energy industries./nThe ERP designation equates to advanced degrees in different nations, such as a master's degree in the United States./nThe purpose of the ERP exam is to gauge the ability of an applicant to manage the physical and financial risks inherent in the world of energy./nGARP announced in 2020 that the designation will no longer be offered and that 2021 will be the last year exams are conducted; only for those who have completed Part I of the two-part exam.

Term: Engel's Law, Curve, and Coefficient Explained
Definition: Engel's Law is a 19th-century observation that as household income increases, the percentage of income that a household spends on food will decline./nIn part, this is because the amount and quality of food that a family can consume is fairly limited./nAs food spending declines on a relative basis, households spend a greater portion of their income on other things, such as education and recreation.

Term: Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR): What it Means, Examples
Definition: Enhanced oil recovery (EOR) is the practice of extracting oil from a well that has already gone through the primary and secondary stages of oil recovery./nDepending on the price of oil, EOR techniques may not beeconomically viable./nEOR techniques can affect the environment negatively, though new innovations in the sector may help reduce this impact in the future.

Term: Enrolled Agent (EA): Overview, History, FAQ
Definition: Enrolled agents are federally authorized to represent taxpayers before the IRS./nProspective enrolled agents must either pass the Special Enrollment Examination (SEE) or meet minimum IRS experience requirements./nFraudulent claims submitted for Civil War losses prompted the creation of the enrolled agent./nEnrolled agents also provide tax planning and preparation./nAlthough enrolled agents may represent individuals and businesses before the IRS, they are not IRS employees.

Term: What Was Enron? What Happened and Who Was Responsible
Definition: Enron was an energy company that began to trade extensively in energy derivatives markets./nThe company hid massive trading losses, ultimately leading to one of the largest accounting scandals and bankruptcy in recent history./nEnron executives used fraudulent accounting practices to inflate the company's revenues and hide debt in its subsidiaries./nThe SEC, credit rating agencies, and investment banks were also accused of negligence—and, in some cases, outright deception—that enabled the fraud./nAs a result of Enron, Congress passed the Sarbanes-Oxley Act to hold corporate executives more accountable for their company's financial statements.

Term: Enterprise Risk Management (ERM): What Is It and How It Works
Definition: Enterprise risk management (ERM) is a firm-wide strategy to identify and prepare for hazards with a company's finances, operations, and objectives./nERM allows managers to shape the firm's overall risk position by mandating certain business segments engage with or disengage from particular activities./nTraditional risk management, which leaves decision-making in the hands of division heads, can lead to siloed evaluations that do not account for other divisions./nThe COSO framework for enterprise risk management identifies eight core components of developing ERM practices./nSuccessful ERM strategies can mitigate operational, financial, security, compliance, legal, and many other types of risks.

Term: Enterprise Multiple (EV/EBITDA): Definition, Formula, Examples
Definition: Enterprise multiple, also known as the EV-to-EBITDA multiple, is a ratio used to determine the value of a company./nIt is computed by dividing enterprise value by EBITDA./nThe enterprise multiple takes into account a company's debt and cash levels in addition to its stock price and relates that value to the firm's cash profitability./nEnterprise multiples can vary depending on the industry./nHigher enterprise multiples are expected in high-growth industries and lower multiples in industries with slow growth.

Term: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP): Meaning, Components, and Examples
Definition: ERP software can integrate all of the processes needed to run a company./nERP solutions have evolved over the years, and many are now typically web-based applications that users can access remotely./nSome benefits of ERP include the free flow of communication between business areas, a single source of information, and accurate, real-time data reporting./nThere are hundreds of ERP applications a company can choose from, and most can be customized./nAn ERP system can be ineffective if a company doesn't implement it carefully.

Term: Enterprise-Value-to-Revenue Multiple (EV/R): Definition
Definition: A measure of the value of a stock that compares a company's enterprise value to its revenue./nOften used to determine a company's valuation in the case of a potential acquisition./nCan be used for companies that do not generate income or profits.

Term: Enterprise Value (EV) Formula and What It Means
Definition: Enterprise value (EV) measures a company’s total value, often used as a more comprehensive alternative to equity market capitalization./nEnterprise value includes in its calculation not only the market capitalization of a company but also short-term and long-term debt and any cash on the company’s balance sheet./nEnterprise value is used as the basis for many financial ratios that measure a company’s performance.

Term: What Is Enterprise Value-to-Sales (EV/Sales)? How to Calculate
Definition: Enterprise value-to-sales (EV/sales) is a financial ratio that measures how much it would cost to purchase a company's value in terms of its sales./nA lower EV/sales multiple indicates that a company is a more attractive investment as it may be relatively undervalued./nThis measurement is considered more accurate than the related price-to-sales because EV/sales takes into account a company's debt load.

Term: Entity Theory: What it is, How it Works, Criticisms
Definition: The entity theory is the legal and accounting doctrine that treats business firms as separate entities from their owners and other stakeholders./nThe entity theory allows the calculation of profits and losses among a set of related transactions and the formation of corporations and limited liability companies./nThe entity theory may be criticized for its inherent detachment from reality and its possible contribution to agency problems.

Term: Envelope: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: An envelope, in technical analysis, refers to trend lines plotted both above and below the current price./nAn envelope's upper and lower bands are typically generated by a simple moving average and a pre-determined distance above and below the moving average—but can be created using any number of other techniques./nMany traders react to a sell signal when the price reaches or crosses the upper band and a buy signal when the price reaches or crosses the lower band of an envelope channel.

Term: Entrepreneur: What It Means to Be One and How to Get Started
Definition: A person who undertakes the risk of starting a new business venture is called an entrepreneur./nAn entrepreneur creates a firm to realize their idea, known as entrepreneurship, which aggregates capital and labor in order to produce goods or services for profit./nEntrepreneurship is highly risky but also can be highly rewarding, as it serves to generate economic wealth, growth, and innovation./nEnsuring funding is key for entrepreneurs: Financing resources include Small Business Administration loans and crowdfunding./nThe way entrepreneurs file and pay taxes will depend on how the business is set up in terms of structure.

Term: Environmental Economics: Definition, Importance, and Example
Definition: Environmental economics studies the impact of environmental policies and devises solutions to problems resulting from them./nEnvironmental economics can either be prescriptive-based or incentive-based./nA major subject of environmental economics is externalities, the additional costs of doing business that are not paid by the business or its consumers./nAnother major subject of environmental economics is placing a value on public goods, such as clean air, and calculating the costs of losing those goods./nSince some environmental goods are not limited to a single country, environmental economics often requires a transnational approach.

Term: EOS Tokens Defined: The Basics and Examples
Definition: EOS is a blockchain-based platform that enables the development of business applications, or DApps./nEOS supports secure access and authentication, permissioning, data hosting, usage management, and communication between the DApps and the Internet./nEOS.IO is the system architecture./nThe EOS token is the network's cryptocurrency./nIts main competitor is the better-established Ethereum platform.

Term: What Is the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)? What It Does
Definition: The Environmental Protection Agency is a United States federal government agency whose mission is to protect human and environmental health./nThe EPA regulates the manufacturing, processing, distribution, and use of chemicals and other pollutants./nThe agency enforces its findings through fines, sanctions, and other procedures./nIt oversees programs to promote energy efficiency, environmental stewardship, sustainable growth, air and water quality, and pollution prevention./nSome of the areas that aren’t covered by the EPA include wildlife, wetlands, food safety, and nuclear waste.

Term: What Is ESG Investing?
Definition: Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing is used to screen investments based on corporate policies and to encourage companies to act responsibly./nMany brokerage firms offer investment products that employ ESG principles./nESG investing can help portfolios avoid holding companies engaged in risky or unethical practices.

Term: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC): Definition & Role
Definition: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) investigates charges brought against employers regarding discrimination against employees and job applicants./nIt was created by Congress in 1964 to enforce Title VII of the Civil Rights Act./nCompanies are subject to the law if they have 15 or more employees (20 or more employees for age discrimination cases)./nThe laws apply to all aspects of work, including hiring, firing, promotions, harassment, training, wages, and benefits.

Term: What Is the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA)?
Definition: The Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) was signed into law in 1974 and prohibits lending discrimination in all aspects of a credit transaction./nECOA makes it illegal for lenders to discriminate based on race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, the receipt of public assistance, and the applicant's exercise of specific consumer protection laws./nThe Department of Justice can file lawsuits under ECOA (and theFair Housing Act, if the discrimination involves mortgages) where there is a pattern or practice of discrimination./nVarious federal agencies enforce ECOA, including theConsumer Finance Protection Bureau (CFPB), the FDIC and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency./nThe CFPB enforces ECOA for banks, savings associations, and credit unions holding more than $10 billion in assets.

Term: Equal Weight Investing: Performance and Examples
Definition: Equal weight is a proportional measure that gives the same importance to each stock in a portfolio or index fund, regardless of a company's size./nEqual weight contrasts with weighting by market capitalization, which is more commonly used by indexes and funds./nThe concept of equally-weighted portfolios has gained interest due to the historical performance of small-cap stocks and the emergence of several exchange-traded funds (ETFs)./nEqual-weighted index funds tend to have higher stock turnover than market-cap weighted index funds, and as a result, they usually have higher trading costs.

Term: Equated Monthly Installment (EMI): How It Works, Formula, Examples
Definition: An equated monthly installment (EMI) is a fixed payment made by a borrower to a lender on a specified date of each month./nEMIs are applied to both interest andprincipaleach month so that over a specified time period, the loan is paid off in full./nEMIs can be calculated in two ways: the flat-rate method or the reducing-balance method./nThe EMI reducing-balance method generally is more favorable for borrowers, as it results in lower interest payments overall./nEMIs allow borrowers the peace of mind of knowing exactly how much money they will need to pay each month toward their loan.

Term: Equation of Exchange: Definition and Different Formulas
Definition: The equation of exchange is a mathematical expression of the quantity theory of money./nIn its basic form, the equation says that the total amount of money that changes hands in an economy equals the total money value of goods that change hands, or that nominal spending equals nominal income./nThe equation of exchange has been used to argue that inflation will be proportional to changes in the money supply and that total demand for money can be broken down into demand for use in transactions and demand to hold money for its liquidity.

Term: Equilibrium Price: Definition, Types, Example, and How to Calculate
Definition: A market is said to have reached equilibrium price when the supply of goods matches demand./nA market in equilibrium demonstrates three characteristics: the behavior of agents is consistent, there are no incentives for agents to change behavior, and a dynamic process governs equilibrium outcomes./nThere are several types of equilibrium used in economics./nDisequilibrium is the opposite of equilibrium and it is characterized by changes in conditions that affect market equilibrium./nIn reality, markets are never in perfect equilibrium, although prices do tend toward it.

Term: Equilibrium Quantity: Definition and Relationship to Price
Definition: Equilibrium quantity is when supply equals demand for a product./nThe supply and demand curves have opposite trajectories and eventually intersect, creating economic equilibrium and equilibrium quantity./nHypothetically, this is the most efficient state the market can reach and the state to which it naturally gravitates.

Term: Equitable Relief: How it Works in Practice
Definition: Equitable relief is granted by a court requiring one party to either act or refrain from taking an action./nEquitable relief is usually a remedy for a breach of contract or in cases of intellectual property theft./nA common form of equitable relief is the canceling of a contract, which ends all terms and obligations, allowing both parties to return to their pre-contract status.

Term: Equity Accounting (Method): What It Is, Plus Investor Influence
Definition: Equity accounting is an accounting method for recording investments in associated companies or entities./nThe equity method is applied when a company's ownership interest in another company is valued at 20–50% of the stock in the investee./nThe equity method requires the investing company to record the investee's profits or losses in proportion to the percentage of ownership./nThe equity method also makes periodic adjustments to the value of the asset on the investor's balance sheet.

Term: Equity Co-Investment: Definition, How It Works, Benefits
Definition: Equity co-investments are relatively smaller investments made in a company concurrent with larger investments by a private equity or VC fund./nCo-investors are typically charged a reduced fee, or no fee, for the investment and receive ownership privileges equal to the percentage of their investment./nThey offer benefits to the larger funds in the form of increased capital and reduced risk while investors benefit by diversifying their portfolio and establishing relationships with senior private equity professionals.

Term: Equity Capital Market (ECM) Definition, How It Works, Types
Definition: Equity Capital Markets (ECM) refers to a broad network of financial institutions, channels, and markets that together assist companies to raise capital./nEquity capital is raised by issuing shares in the company, publicly or privately, and is used to fund the expansion of the business./nPrimary equity markets refer to raising money from private placement and mainly involves OTC markets./nSecondary equity markets involve stock exchanges and are the primary venue for public investment in corporate equity./nECM activities include bringing shares to IPO and secondary offerings.

Term: Equity Meaning: How It Works and How to Calculate It
Definition: Equity represents the value that would be returned to a company’s shareholders if all of the assets were liquidated and all of the company's debts were paid off./nWe can also think of equity as a degree of residual ownership in a firm or asset after subtracting all debts associated with that asset./nEquity represents the shareholders’ stake in the company, identified on a company's balance sheet./nThe calculation of equity is a company's total assets minus its total liabilities, and it's used in several key financial ratios such as ROE./nHome equity is the value of a homeowner's property (net of debt) and is another way the term equity is used.

Term: Equity Derivative: Definition, How They're Used, and Example
Definition: Equity derivatives are financial instruments whose value is derived from price movements of the underlying asset, where that asset is a stock or stock index./nTraders use equity derivatives to speculate and manage risk for their stock portfolios./nEquity derivatives can take on two major forms: equity options and equity index futures. Equity swaps, warrants, and single-stock futures are also equity derivatives.

Term: Equity Compensation: Definition, How It Works, Types of Equity
Definition: Equity compensation is non-cash pay that is offered to employees./nEquity compensation may include options, restricted stock, and performance shares; all of these investment vehicles represent ownership in the firm for a company's employees./nAt times, equity compensation may accompany a below-market salary./nEquity compensation is a benefit provided by many public companies and some private companies, especially startup companies.

Term: Equity-Efficiency Tradeoff: Definition, Causes, and Examples
Definition: The equity-efficiency tradeoff is when there is some conflict between maximizing pure economic efficiency and achieving other social goals./nMost economic theory uses a utilitarian approach as its ethical framework, but this may conflict with other moral values that people hold, leading to an equity-efficiency tradeoff./nInequality and the redistribution of income is a common example of an equity-efficiency tradeoff.

Term: Equity Financing: What It Is, How It Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: Equity financing is used when companies need cash./nIt is typical for businesses to use equity financing several times as they become mature companies./nThere are two methods of equity financing: the private placement of stock with investors and public stock offerings./nEquity financing differs from debt financing: the first involves selling a portion of equity in a company, while the latter involvesborrowing money./nNational and local governments closely monitor equity financing to ensure it's done according to regulations.

Term: Equity-Linked Security (ELKS): Meaning, Types, Examples
Definition: An equity-linked security is a debt instrument with variable payments linked to an equity market benchmark./nThey are offered to investors so the issuer can raise capital./nThese securities are an alternative type of fixed-income investment—structured products most often created as bonds./nELKS normally mature within a one-year period and normally pay higher yields than that of the underlying security./nSome kinds of ELKS include corporate, bank-offered, and market-linked.

Term: Investing in Equity Funds: A Beginner’s Guide
Definition: Equity funds are pooled investments that put money primarily into stocks listed on major exchanges./nEquity funds provide investors with several benefits, including diversification, professional management, and the potential for superior returns./nThese funds also come with risks associated with stock market volatility and losses./nEquity funds can be categorized in several ways, including investment style, portfolio focus, and level of diversification.

Term: Equity Market: What It Is, How It Works, Types, and Examples
Definition: Equity markets are meeting points for issuers and buyers of stocks in a market economy./nEquity markets are a method for companies to raise capital and investors to own a piece of a company./nStocks can be issued in public markets or private markets. Depending on the type of issue, the venue for trading changes./nMost equity markets are stock exchanges that can be found around the world, such as the New York Stock Exchange and the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

Term: Equity Method of Accounting Definition and Example
Definition: The equity method is used to value a company's investment in another company when it holds significant influence over the company it is investing in./nThe threshold for "significant influence" is commonly a 20% ownership./nThe investment is initially recorded at historical cost, and adjustments are made to the value based on the investor's percentage ownership in net income, loss, and dividend payouts./nNet income of the investee company increases the investor's asset value on their balance sheet, while the investee's loss or dividend payout decreases it./nThe investor also records the percentage of the investee's net income or loss on their income statement.

Term: What Is the Equity Multiplier? Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: An equity multiplier is a measure of the portion of the company’s assets that is financed by stock rather than debt./nA high equity multiplier generally means that a company has a higher level of debt./nA lower equity multiplier may indicate that a company is using shareholders' equity to finance its assets or that it cannot attract lenders for a loan./nInvestors judge a company's equity multiplier in the context of its industry and its peers./nThe equity multiplier is also known as the financial leverage ratio.

Term: Equity Swap: Definition, How It Works, Example
Definition: An equity swap is similar to an interest rate swap, but rather than one leg being the "fixed" side, it is based on the return of an equity index./nThese swaps are highly customizable and are traded over-the-counter. Most equity swaps are conducted between large financing firms such as auto financiers, investment banks, and lending institutions./nThe interest rate leg is often referenced to LIBOR while the equity leg is often referenced to a major stock index such as the S&P 500.

Term: Equity Premium Puzzle (EPP): Definition, History, Explanations
Definition: The equity premium puzzle (EPP) refers to the excessively high historical outperformance of stocks over Treasury bills, which is difficult to explain./nTheoretically, the premium should actually be much lower than the historical average of between 5% and 8%./nThe prospect theory by Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, the role of personal debt, the importance of liquidity, the impact of government regulation, and tax considerations have been applied to the puzzle./nPrevious lack of knowledge, the decline of the U.S. dollar relative to gold, the benefits of diversification, and population growth are all possible solutions to the equity premium puzzle.

Term: What Is Equity Risk Premium, and How Do You Calculate It?
Definition: An equity risk premium is an excess return earned by an investor when they invest in the stock market over a risk-free rate./nThis return compensates investors for taking on the higher risk of equity investing./nDetermining an equity risk premium is theoretical because there's no way to tell how well equities or the equity market will perform in the future./nCalculating an equity risk premium requires using historical rates of return.

Term: Equivalent Annual Annuity Approach (EAA) Overview and Formulas
Definition: The equivalent annual annuity approach is one of two methods used in capital budgeting to compare mutually exclusive projects with unequal lives./nWhen used to compare projects with unequal lives, an investor should choose the one with the higher equivalent annual annuity./nOften, an analyst will use a financial calculator, using the typical present value and future value functions to find the EAA.

Term: Equivalent Annual Cost (EAC): What It Is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: Equivalent annual cost (EAC) is the annual cost of owning, operating, and maintaining an asset over its entire life./nEAC is often used by firms for capital budgeting decisions, as it allows a company to compare the cost-effectiveness of various assets that have unequal lifespans./nEAC allows managers to compare the net present values of different projects over different periods, to accurately determine the best option.

Term: Erosion: What it is, How it Works, Types
Definition: Erosion generally applies to longer-term downward trends in a company’s business; short-term losses are usually not considered erosion./nProfit erosion can happen when profits are redirected elsewhere in a business or costs rise./nUnexpected asset erosion, for example, due to technical innovation, can lower the perceived value—or book value—of a business./nSales erosion happens when there are long-term declines in sales, perhaps due to new competition or price undercutting.

Term: Error Term: Definition, Example, and How to Calculate With Formula
Definition: An error term appears in a statistical model, like a regression model, to indicate the uncertainty in the model./nThe error term is a residual variable that accounts for a lack of perfect goodness of fit./nHeteroskedastic refers to a condition in which the variance of the residual term, or error term, in a regression model varies widely.

Term: What Is Errors and Omissions Insurance?
Definition: Errors and omissions insurance protects your company against claims by clients for negligence, mistakes, faulty advice, or failure to provide the promised results./nAny business that offers a professional service or advice likely needs E&O insurance. Examples are insurance agents, doctors, lawyers, wedding planners, and financial advisors./nE&O insurance doesn’t cover claims for property damage, bodily injury, workplace injuries, data breaches, intellectual property violations, or criminal acts such as fraud./nThe cost of E&O insurance varies depending on the size and nature of your business, but the average premium for a small business is around $735 a year.

Term: Escheat Definition
Definition: Escheat refers to the right of a government to take ownership of estate assets or unclaimed property./nEscheatment can occur when property remains unclaimed for a certain number of years./nEscheat rights are often determined through probate or other types of court proceedings./nEach state in the U.S. has rules and regulations for granting escheat rights./nMost states have standard procedures for automatically transferring dormant account assets after a specified period.

Term: How Escrow Protects Parties in Financial Transactions
Definition: Escrow refers to a neutral third party holding assets or funds before they are transferred from one party in a transaction to another./nThe third party holds the funds until both buyer and seller have fulfilled their contractual requirements./nEscrow is associated with real estate transactions but it can apply to any situation where funds will pass from one party to another./nEscrow can be used when purchasing a home and for the life of a mortgage./nOnline escrow has been on the rise as a way to offer secure online transactions for expensive items, such as art or jewelry.

Term: Escrow Agent: Explanation in Real Estate
Definition: An escrow agent is a third party, a person or entity, which holds an asset or funds before they are transferred from one party to another./nThe escrow agent holds the funds or the asset until both parties have fulfilled their contractual requirements./nEscrow agents are often associated with real estate transactions, but they can be used in any situation where funds will pass from one party to another.

Term: What Is an Escrow Agreement? How It Works, Uses, and Types
Definition: An escrow agreement is a legal document outlining terms and conditions between parties as well as the responsibility of each./nAgreements usually involve an independent third party called an escrow agent, who holds an asset until the contract's conditions are met./nEscrow agreements are commonly used in real estate transactions./nThe escrow agreement generally includes, but is not limited to, information about the escrow agent's identity, the funds in escrow, and the acceptable use of funds by the agent﻿.

Term: Esoteric Debt: What it Means, How it Works, Financial Crisis
Definition: Esoteric debt refers to debts or other financial instruments that have complex structure that is properly understood by only a few people with specialized knowledge./nBecause of their inscrutability, the true nature of their fair value and their risk/return profile can be unknown or misleading to market participants./nMispricings and inadequate risk management of these positions has therefore led to financial crises and large losses when esoteric investments fail to perform as advertised./nEsoteric debt often arises through the process of securitization or in the form of derivatives contracts.

Term: Escrowed Shares Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: Escrowed shares are stocks that are held in an escrow account./nEscrow means that the shares are held by a third party until certain conditions have been met to reduce counterparty risk in a transaction./nCompanies will also issue stock in escrow, imposing limitations on when the shares can be sold, as part of an employee's compensation plan./nMergers and acquisitions often require shares of the target company to be held in escrow until the deal is finalized./nUnder a compensation plan, companies often hold their stock in escrow to retain executive employees.

Term: What Is an Estate, Estate Planning, and Drawing Up a Will
Definition: An estate is the economic valuation of all the investments, assets, and interests of an individual./nThe estate includes a person's belongings, physical and intangible assets, land and real estate, investments, collectibles, and furnishings./nEstate planning refers to the management of how assets will be transferred to beneficiaries when an individual passes away./nEstate taxes may be levied on the value of one's estate at death.

Term: Estimated Ultimate Recovery (EUR): What it is, How it Works
Definition: Estimated ultimate recovery (EUR) refers to potential production expected from an oil well or deposit./nEUR is made up of three levels of confidence is the amount of oil yet to be recovered: proven reserves; probable reserves; and possible reserves./nEUR is used by oil companies, as well as analysts and investors, to compute the NPV for oil exploration and drilling projects and the expected corporate profits associated with that.

Term: Estate Tax: Rates, Exclusions, and Impact on Gift and Inheritance Taxes
Definition: The estate tax is a financial levy on an estate based on the current value of its assets./nFederal estate taxes are levied on assets of more than $12.92 million for 2023, and more than $13.61 million for 2024./nAssets transferred to spouses are exempt from estate tax./nRecipients of an estate's assets may be subject to inheritance tax.

Term: Ethereum Classic (ETC) Definition, History, and Future
Definition: Ethereum Classic is an open-source, decentralized, blockchain-based distributed cryptocurrency platform that runs smart contracts./nEthereum Classic is the original Ethereum blockchain./nIt was conceived by Vitalik Buterin and the Ethereum Foundation and launched in 2015./nEthereum Classic was created after The DAO hack in 2016./nA dispute caused a split in the Ethereum community, with the majority choosing to reverse the hack while Ethereum Classic did not accept the reversal.

Term: Estoppel
Definition: Estoppel is a legal principle that is found in common law systems in the U.S., U.K., Canada, and other countries./nIt protects one party by holding another to their word or requiring them to adhere to established legal facts./nForms of the doctrine of estoppel vary by country./nTypes of estoppel include collateral estoppel, equitable estoppel, and promissory estoppel./nEstoppel certificates are commonly used in real estate and must be signed by tenants when the landlord is trying to conduct a transaction with the property.

Term: What Is Ether (ETH)? Definition, How It Works, vs. Bitcoin
Definition: Ether is the native token that facilitates operations on the Ethereum network./nWhile ether is the cryptocurrency of the Ethereum network, metaphorically speaking, it is more accurate to refer to it as the "fuel" of the network./nEther is the world's second-largest virtual currency by market capitalization; it is second only to Bitcoin (BTC) according to market cap.

Term: Ethical Investing: Overview and How To Do It
Definition: Ethical investing is the practice of selecting investments based on ethical or moral principles./nSelecting investments based on ethics offers no guarantee of performance./nEthical investors typically avoid investments from sin stocks, which are companies involved with stigmatized activities, such as gambling, alcohol, smoking, or firearms./nAnalyzing investments according to ethics should also include reviewing whether the company’s actions align with its commitment to ethics and its historical, current, and projected performance.

Term: What Are Euro Notes and What Are Their Denominations?
Definition: The euro is the official currency of the European Union (EU), adopted by 19 of the EU's 27 member nations./nIt is the world's second most widely held and traded currency after the U.S. dollar./nThe euro remains overwhelmingly popular in the countries using it for its role in easing European trade and travel and promoting political integration of the EU./nAdoption of a common currency without the stabilizing features of a fiscal union was a major cause of the European sovereign debt crisis, forcing the EU to deepen its economic and political integration.

Term: Euro Interbank Offer Rate (Euribor) Definition, Uses, Vs. Eonia
Definition: Euribor is an overnight interbank rate comprised of the average interest rates from a panel of large European banks that are used for lending to one another in euros./nEuribor has various maturities in which each maturity has its own interest rate./nEuribor is calculated by a benchmark administrator called Global Rate Set Systems Ltd. and offered by the European Money Markets Institute (EMMI).

Term: What Is a Euro Medium Term Note (EMTN)? Definition and Example
Definition: A euro medium-term note (EMTN) is a medium-term, flexible debt security that is issued and traded outside of the United States and Canada./nEMTNs have become a significant funding source for U.S. and foreign companies, multinational institutions, federal agencies, and sovereign nations./nEMTNs offer diversity as companies can issue them in a wide range of currencies and with various maturities.

Term: Euro Overnight Index Average (EONIA): Definition, Switch to ESTER
Definition: The Euro Overnight Index Average (EONIA) is the average overnight reference rate for which European banks lend to one another in euros./nThe EONIA is the interest rate for one-day loans between European banks./nThe Euro Overnight Index Average is calculated by the European Central Bank (ECB) based on the loans made by 28 panel banks./nDue to European regulatory reforms, EONIA was replaced in 2022 with a more comprehensive benchmark called ESTER.

Term: Euroclear: Definition, How It Works, Vs. Clearstream
Definition: Euroclear is a major clearinghouse that settles and clears securities trades executed on European exchanges./nEuroclear also functions as a central securities depository, where it is a custodian for major financial institutions involved in European markets./nIn addition to stock trades, Euroclear also handles orders in fixed income securities and derivatives.

Term: Eurocurrency: Meaning, Overview, Examples
Definition: The term eurocurrency refers to currency deposits held at banks outside of their country of origin./nThe most famous example of eurocurrency is the eurodollar, which involves U.S. dollar (USD) deposits held outside the United States./nEurocurrency has become an extremely important facet of the global financial system, due to factors such as globalization and financial regulations.

Term: Eurobond: Definition, Issuers, Advantages and Disadvantages
Definition: A Eurobond is a debt instrument that's denominated in a currency other than the home currency of the country or market in which it is issued./nEurobonds are important because they help organizations raise capital while having the flexibility to issue them in another currency./nEurobond refers only to the fact the bond is issued outside of the borders of the currency's home country; it doesn't mean the bond was issued in Europe.

Term: Eurocurrency Market: Definition, History, and Types of Markets
Definition: The eurocurrency market is the money market for currency outside of the country where it is legal tender./nThe term eurocurrency is a generalization of eurodollar and should not be confused with the EU currency, the euro./nThere is also a eurobond market for countries, companies, and financial institutions to borrow in currencies outside of their domestic market./nEurocurrency markets can offer better rates for both borrowers and lenders, but they also have higher risks.

Term: Eurodollar: Definition, Why It's Important, and Example
Definition: Eurodollars refer to dollar-denominated accounts at foreign banks or overseas branches of American banks./nThe eurodollar market is one of the world's biggest capital markets and consists of sophisticated financial instruments.

Term: Euromarket: Meaning, Overview and History
Definition: The euromarket may refer to the single market and free-trade among European Union (EU) countries./nThe euromarket extends beyond the Eurozone countries that use the euro currency to all countries signed on to that free trade agreement./nThe euromarket may also refer to the eurocurrencies market, where an institution uses money from another country, but not in the originating country's home market.

Term: What Is EMEA? Included Countries and Importance in Business
Definition: Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA) refer to a geographical grouping and acronym which includes the continents and regional areas./nEMEA is used by global corporations to distinguish business activity from other regions like the Americas and Asia./nEMEA includes subregions like SEMEA, Southern Europe Middle East and Africa, or EMENA, Europe, Middle East, and North Africa.

Term: European Banking Authority (EBA): What it is, How it Works
Definition: The European Banking Authority (EBA) aims to maintain financial stability in the European Union’s banking industry by conducting regular solvency checks./nThe EBA ensures market transparency, exerts quality control over new bank instruments, and protects investors./nEBA transparency exercises involve cultivating data on a bank’s capital, profits and losses, credit risk, and other metrics.

Term: European Central Bank (ECB): Definition, Structure, and Functions
