Definition: The European Central Bank (ECB) is the central bank of the European Union and the Eurozone currency union./nThe ECB coordinates Eurozone monetary policy, including setting target interest rates and controlling the supply of the euro common currency./nThe ECB's primary mandate is price stability; it targets 2% inflation over the medium term as a buffer against the risk of destabilizingdeflation./nECB decisions on monetary policy and banking supervision are made by the ECB Governing Council comprising six executive board members and a monthly rotation of national central bank governors.

Term: European Currency Unit (ECU): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The European Currency Unit (ECU) was the monetary unit used by the European Monetary System (EMS) before being replaced by the euro./nThe ECU was introduced in 1979 and replaced by the euro in 1999./nIt was a composite of 12 European Union member countries./nThe exchange rate mechanism (ERM) was introduced alongside the ECU, designed to reduce exchange rate variability and achieve monetary stability in Europe.

Term: What Was the European Community (EC)? Definition and History
Definition: The European Community (EC) was created in 1957 as a way to foster trade cooperation and reduce tensions in the aftermath of World War II./nThe European Community consisted of three economic associations: the European Economic Community (EEC), the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), and the European Atomic Energy Community./nThe six founding member countries of the European Community were Belgium, Germany, France, Italy, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands./nIn 1993, the European Community was replaced by the European Union when the Maastricht Treaty went into effect.

Term: What Was the European Monetary System (EMS)?
Definition: The European Monetary System (EMS) was an adjustable exchange rate arrangement set up in 1979 to foster closer monetary policy cooperation between members of the European Community (EC)./nThe European Monetary System (EMS) was established to stabilize inflation and stop large exchange rate fluctuations between these neighboring nations, with the intended goal of making it easy for them to trade goods with each other./nThe European Monetary System (EMS) was succeeded by the European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU), which established a common currency, the euro.

Term: European Economic and Monetary Union: Overview, History, FAQ
Definition: The European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) involves the coordination of economic and fiscal policies, a common monetary policy, and a common currency, the euro among 19 Eurozone nations./nThe decision to form the EMU was adopted by Treaty of the European Council in the Dutch city of Maastricht in 1992 ./n2002 saw the introduction of the common euro currency finally replacing the national currencies of most EU member states.

Term: Eurozone Definition, History, Member Countries
Definition: The eurozone refers to an economic and geographic region consisting of all the European Union (EU) countries that incorporate the euro as their national currency./nIn 1992, the Maastricht Treaty created the EU and paved the way for the formation of a common economic and monetary union consisting of a central banking system, a common currency, and a common economic region, the eurozone./nThe eurozone consists of the following 19 countries in the EU: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Spain./nNot all European Union nations participate in the eurozone; some opt to use their own currency and maintain their financial independence./nEuropean Union nations that decide to participate in the eurozone must meet requirements regarding price stability, sound public finances, the durability of convergence, and exchange rate stability.

Term: European Option: Definition, Types, Versus American Options
Definition: A European option is a version of an options contract that limits rights exercise to only the day of expiration./nAlthough American options can be exercised early, it comes at a price since their premiums are often higher than European options./nInvestors can sell a European option contract back to the market before expiry and receive the net difference between the premiums earned and paid initially./nInvestors usually don't have a choice of buying either the American or the European option and most indexes use European options./nThe Black-Scholes option model is often used to value European options.

Term: European Sovereign Debt Crisis: Eurozone Crisis Causes, Impacts
Definition: The European sovereign debt crisis began in 2008 with the collapse of Iceland's banking system./nSome of the contributing causes included the financial crisis of 2007 to 2008, and the Great Recession of 2008 through 2012./nThe crisis peaked between 2010 and 2012.

Term: European Union (EU): What It Is, Countries, History, Purpose
Definition: The EU is a political and economic grouping of 27 countries committed to shared democratic values./nThe euro is the shared official currency of 19 EU members known collectively as the eurozone./nIn recent years, the EU has expanded to include many of the countries that had been socialist states before the collapse of the Soviet Union./nIn the 2016 referendum known as Brexit, the U.K. voted to leave the EU; it officially left in 2020.

Term: Evening Star Pattern: What It Is, What It Means, and Example Chart
Definition: An evening star is a candlestick pattern that's used by technical analysts to predict future price reversals to the downside./nThe evening star pattern is rare but it's considered by traders to be a reliable technical indicator./nThe evening star is the opposite of the morning star pattern./nThe candlestick pattern is bearish and the morning star pattern is bullish.

Term: EV/2P Ratio: Meaning, Calculation, Example
Definition: Enterprise value compared to proven and probable reserves is a metric that helps analysts understand how well a company's resources will support its operations and growth./nThe EV/2P ratio is a ratio used to value oil and gas companies. It consists of theenterprise value(EV) divided by the proven and probable (2P) reserves./nIt's important to compare a company's EV/2P ratio with those of similar companies and with the historical values of the ratio.

Term: Event Study: Definition, Methods, Uses in Investing and Economics
Definition: An event study, or event-history analysis, examines the impact of an event on the financial performance of a security, such as company stock./nAn event study employs statistical methods, using time as the dependent variable and then looking for variables that explain the duration of an event—or the time until an event occurs./nIf the same type of statistical analysis is used to analyze multiple events of the same type, a model can predict how stock prices typically respond to a specific event.

Term: What Is an Evergreen Contract? Uses, Cancellation, and Examples
Definition: An evergreen contract is one that automatically renews after its initial term expires./nThe parties agree that the contract rolls over automatically and indefinitely until one gives the other notice to terminate it./nEvergreen contracts are found in rental leases, service agreements, and purchasing contracts.

Term: Evergreen Funding: What You Need to Know
Definition: Evergreen funding is a term used to describe the incremental addition of money into a business by investors; the company receives capital on an established schedule or as the need for funds arises./nThe idea is that, like the evergreen tree, such a firm always has the “green” it needs to survive; however, by spacing out the investments, the company will ideally avoid the tendency of some startups to grow too fast and then fall apart./nEvergreen funding plans allow a business to renew its debt at different times, pushing back the maturity date so that the amount of time until the debt is due holds steady while the arrangement is active.

Term: Evergreen Loans: Definition, Examples and Best Practices
Definition: An evergreen loan is a type of interest-only loan in which principal payment is deferred./nTypically, the repayment of principal is only expected at the end of the loan term, although interest rates may be higher or contain penalties for delayed payment./nThey are called evergreen since interest can be paid but the repayment of principal can, in effect, be delayed indefinitely such that it works like revolving credit.

Term: Ex-Ante: What It Means and How It Works
Definition: Ex-ante is a form of financial analysis that uses forecasting or predictions for future events./nEx-ante, which is Latin for before the event, takes historical performance into account./nEx-ante is the opposite of ex-post, which is a form of analysis that takes place after the event and uses concrete results.

Term: Ex-Dividend Date: Definition, Key Dates, and Example
Definition: The ex-dividend date, or ex-date, marks the cutoff point for shareholders to be credited a pending stock dividend./nTo receive the upcoming dividend, shareholders must have bought the stock before the ex-dividend date./nThere are four dates to know when it comes to companies' dividends: the declaration date, the ex-dividend date, the record date, and the payable date./nOn the ex-dividend date, stock prices typically decline by the amount of the dividend.

Term: Ex Gratia Payment
Definition: An ex gratia payment is made to an individual by an organization, government, or insurer for damages or claims, but it does not require the admittance of liability by the party making the payment./nAn ex gratia payment is considered voluntary because the party making the payment is not obligated to compensate the individual./nEx gratia payments in the U.S. are typically subject to federal and state income taxes.

Term: Ex-Dividend: Meaning and Date
Definition: Ex-dividend means a company's dividend allocations have been specified./nThe ex-dividend date is when the stock begins trading without the subsequent dividend value./nInvestors who purchase stock before the ex-dividend date are entitled to the next dividend payment while those who purchase stock on or after the ex-dividend date are not.

Term: Ex-Post: Definition, Calculation, Vs. Ex-Ante
Definition: Ex-post is a word for actual returns and translates from Latin as "after the fact."/nEx-post analysis looks at financial results after they have occurred and utilizes them to predict the likelihood of future returns./nThe ex-post value is obtained by taking into consideration the beginning and ending value of an asset, the growth and decline of the asset, and any earned income./nEx-post stands in contrast to ex-ante, which uses estimates to gauge future performance. Ex-post is standard practice as it relies on proven results.

Term: Ex Works (EXW) Defined, Pros and Cons, Plus More Incoterms
Definition: Ex Works (EXW) is a shipping arrangement in which a seller makes a product available at a specific location, but the buyer has to pay the transport costs./nOnce buyers have their goods, they are responsible for other risks, such as loading them onto trucks, transferring them to a ship or plane, and meeting customs regulations./nEx Works is an Incoterms (International Commercial Terms), one of 11 standardized international trade terms published by the International Chamber of Commerce.

Term: Excess Capacity Definition, Causes, Impact, Example
Definition: Excess capacity exists when the market demand for a product is less than the volume of product that a company could potentially supply./nThe term excess capacity pertains mainly to manufacturing, but it's also used in the services sector./nExcess capacity can indicate healthy growth, but too much excess capacity can hurt an economy.

Term: Excess of Loss Reinsurance Definition and How It Works
Definition: Excess of loss reinsurance is a type of reinsurance in which the reinsurer indemnifies–or compensates–the ceding company for losses that exceed a specified limit./nExcess of loss reinsurance takes a different approach than a treaty or facultative reinsurance policy; the reinsurance company is held responsible for the total amount of losses above a certain limit./nExcess of loss reinsurance can also work in a slightly different way; rather than require the reinsurer to be responsible for all losses over a certain amount, the contract may instead indicate that the reinsurer is responsible for a percentage of losses over that threshold.

Term: Excess Reserves: Bank Deposits Beyond What Is Required
Definition: Excess reserves are funds a bank deposits and keeps at its nation's central bank beyond regulatory requirements./nThe Federal Reserve discontinued reserve requirements in 2020, thus eliminating excess reserves./nBanks can voluntarily hold reserves at the Fed, which pays them interest in a program called Interest on Reserve Balances (IORB).

Term: Excess Cash Flow: Definition, Calculation Formulas, Example
Definition: Excess cash flow is cash received or generated by a company that triggers a repayment to a lender, as stipulated in their bond debenture or credit agreement./nLenders impose restrictions on how excess cash can be spent in an effort to maintain control of the company's debt repayments./nHowever, the lender does not want to create so many restrictions that it hurts the financial viability of the company./nIf excess cash flow is generated, a lender might require a repayment that is all or some portion of the excess cash flow amount.

Term: Exchange Controls: Meaning & How Companies Get Around Them
Excess Returns Meaning, Risk, and Formulas
Definition: Excess returns are returns achieved above and beyond the return of a proxy./nExcess returns will depend on a designated investment return comparison for analysis./nThe riskless rate and benchmarks with similar levels of risk to the investment being analyzed are commonly used in calculating excess return./nAlpha is a type of excess return metric that focuses on performance return in excess of a closely comparable benchmark./nExcess return is an important consideration when using modern portfolio theory which seeks to invest with an optimized portfolio.

Term: Exchanges: Explanation, Types and Examples
Definition: Exchanges are marketplaces for the trade of securities, commodities, derivatives, and other financial instruments./nCompanies may use an exchange to raise capital./nA company must have at least $4 million in shareholder's equity to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange./nMore than 80% of trading on the New York Stock Exchange is done electronically./nThe New York Stock Exchange has been around since 1792.

Term: Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM): Definition, Objective, Examples
Definition: An exchange rate mechanism (ERM) is a way that governments can influence the relative price of their national currency in forex markets./nThe ERM allows the central bank to tweak a currency peg in order to normalize trade and/or the influence of inflation./nMore broadly, ERM is used to keep exchange rates stable and minimize currency rate volatility in the market.

Term: Exchange Rates: What They Are, How They Work, Why They Fluctuate
Definition: An exchange rate is the rate at which one currency can be exchanged for another currency./nMost exchange rates are defined asfloating. They'll rise or fall based on supply and demand in the market./nSome exchange rates arepeggedor fixed to the value of a specific country's currency./nExchange rate changes affect businesses by changing the cost of supplies that are purchased from a different country and by changing the demand for their products from overseas customers.

Term: Exchange of Futures for Physical (EFP): Definition and Example
Definition: Exchange of futures for physical (EFP) allows for one party to swap a futures contract for the actual underlying asset./nEFPs are traded over-the-counter (OTC) and are often used by commodities producers to hedge positions or regulate production./nEFPs are especially useful when a large transaction takes place so the market price is not artificially altered by a non-speculative trade.

Term: Understanding and Calculating the Exchange Ratio
Definition: The exchange ratio calculates how many shares an acquiring company needs to issue for each share an investor owns in a target company to provide the same relative value to the investor./nThe target company purchase price often includes a price premium paid by the acquirer due to buying 100% control of the target company./nThe intrinsic value of the shares and the underlying value of the company are considered when coming up with an exchange ratio./nThere are two types of exchange ratios: a fixed exchange ratio and a floating exchange ratio.

Term: Exchange-Traded Derivative: Definition, Examples, Vs. OTC
Definition: An exchange-traded derivative is a security with a standardized financial contract that trades on a regulated exchange./nExchange-traded derivatives settle through a clearinghouse and are guaranteed./nClearinghouses include theOptions Clearing Corporation(OCC) and theCommodity Futures Trading Commission(CFTC)./nClearing trades through regulated clearinghouses reduces investment risk./nExchange-traded derivatives are listed on exchanges such as theCBOE Global Marketsand theNew York Mercantile Exchange(NYMEX), and are overseen by theSecurities and Exchange Commission(SEC).

Term: Exchange-Traded Product (ETP): Definition, Types, and Example
Definition: Exchange-traded products (ETP) are instruments that track underlying security, index, or financial products./nETPs trade on exchanges similar to stocks./nThe price of ETPs fluctuates from day to day and intraday./nThe share price of ETPs comes from the underlying investments that they track.

Term: Excise Tax: What It Is and How It Works, With Examples
Definition: Excise taxes are taxes levied on specific goods or services like fuel, tobacco, and alcohol./nThey are primarily taxes that must be paid by businesses, usually increasing prices for consumers indirectly./nExcise taxes can be ad valorem (paid by percentage) or specific (cost charged by unit)./nSin taxes are a form of excise tax on goods that have a high social cost, such as alcohol and tobacco./nSome excise taxes can be required directly from the consumer like property taxes and excise tax penalties on certain retirement account activities.

Term: What Are Exchange-Traded Notes (ETNs), and How Do They Work?
Definition: An exchange-traded note (ETN) is an unsecured debt security that tracks an underlying index of securities./nETNs are similar to bonds but do not pay periodic interest payments./nInvestors can buy and sell ETNs on major exchanges, like stocks, and profit from the difference, subtracting any fees.

Term: Execution: Definition, Types of Orders, Examples
Definition: Execution refers to filling a buy or sell order in the market, subject to conditions placed on the order by the end client./nThere are several ways to execute a trade and they encompass manual as well as automated methods./nBrokers are required by law to find the best possible means to execute a client's trade.

Term: Exculpatory Clause: What it is, How it Works, Limitations
Definition: An exculpatory clause is language found in a contract that relieves on party from liability resulting from the normal execution of that contract./nDisclaimers are one common example of exculpatory language found in a range of contexts./nAn exculpatory clause runs the risk of being rendered invalid if there is an intent to deceive or commit fraud under the terms and conditions of the policy.

Term: What Is an Executive MBA (EMBA)? Comparison to MBA and Costs
Definition: Executive master of business administration (EMBA) is designed for working corporate executives and senior managers./nTypically, an individual working towards an EMBA continues to work full-time at work./nConsiderable work experience and business knowledge are helpful to succeed in a top-tier EMBA program./nEarning an EMBA means usually taking a mix of evening, online, and weekend classes, tutorials, and workshops./nWhile a full-time MBA program may take a year, an EMBA program takes up to two years./nEMBA programs are time-consuming and expensive. It makes sense to weigh the pros and cons of a program before entering one.

Term: What Is an Executor? Duties and Role in Estate Planning
Definition: An executor administers a person's estate upon their death./nAn executor may be named by the testator or by a court./nThe primary duty of an executor is to carry out the wishes of the deceased person based on instructions spelled out in their will or trust documents.

Term: What Is an Exempt Employee in the Workplace? Pros & Cons
Definition: An exempt employee is an employee who does not receive overtime pay or qualify for minimum wage./nExempt employees are paid a salary rather than by the hour, and they work in professional, administrative, executive, outside sales, and computer-related fields./nExempt employees stand in contrast to nonexempt employees, who must be paid at least the minimum wage, and overtime when they work more than the standard 40-hour workweek./nThe details and rules governing exempt and nonexempt employees are covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)./nWorkers are generally considered exempt if they fall in the above categories, are salaried, and earn a minimum of $684 per week or $35,568 annually.

Term: Exempt Income: Definition, Examples, and Tax Rules
Definition: Exempt income is not subject to taxation./nSome income may be exempt at the state level but taxed at the federal level./nIncome from some types of investments, like municipal bonds, qualifies as exempt income./nDistributions from Roth 401(k)s and Roth IRAs are tax-exempt./nIncome from benefits, such as employer-sponsored supplemental disability insurance and most benefits from employer-sponsored health insurance plans, are exempt from taxes.

Term: Exempt-Interest Dividend Examples and FAQ
Definition: An exempt-interest dividend is a distribution from a mutual fund that is not subject to federal income tax./nHigh-net-worth investors often invest in municipal bonds to take advantage of the tax breaks./nThough exempt from federal income tax, interest dividends from municipal bonds may or may not be exempt from state taxes./nInterest-dividend may also be subject to the alternative minimum tax (AMT) even if it is exempt from federal or state income taxes./nTax-exempt interest dividends are reported on Form 1099-DIV in box 12.

Term: Exemption : How They Work, Types, and FAQs
Definition: An exemption reduces the amount of income that would otherwise be taxed./nUntil the end of 2025, personal exemptions have been repealed and replaced by higher standard deductions./nThere are a variety of other exemptions and they can come in many forms./nCertain income, such as income made from municipal bonds, counts as exempted income.

Term: Exempt Transaction: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Exempt transactions do not require registrations to be filed./nExempt securities are tax-exempt in most cases./nThere are some regulations for exempt transactions such as anti-fraud provisions.

Term: Exercise: Definition and How It Works With Options
Definition: In options trading, "to exercise" means to put into effect the right to buy or sell the underlying security that is specified in the options contract./nTo exercise an option, you simply advise your broker that you wish to exercise the option in your contract./nIf the holder of aputoptionexercisesthe contract, they willsellthe underlying security at a stated price within a specific timeframe./nIf the holder of acalloptionexercisesthe contract, they willbuythe underlying security at a stated price within a specific timeframe./nBefore exercising an option, it is important to consider what type of option you have and whether you can exercise it.

Term: Exit Strategy Definition for an Investment or Business
Definition: An exit strategy is a conscious plan to dispose of an investment in a business venture or financial asset./nAn exit strategy helps to minimize losses and maximize profits on investments./nStartup exit strategies include initial public offerings (IPOs), acquisitions, or buyouts but may also include liquidation or bankruptcy to exit a failing company./nEstablished business exit plans include mergers and acquisitions as well as liquidation and bankruptcy for insolvent companies./nExit strategies for investors include the 1% rule, a percentage-based exit, a time-based exit, or selling a stake in a business.

Term: Excersise Price: Overview, Put and Calls, In and Out of The Money
Definition: An option's exercise price is the price the underlying security can be either bought or sold for./nBoth call and put options have an exercise price./nInvestors also refer to the exercise price as the strike price./nThe difference between the exercise price and the underlying security’s price determines if an option is “in the money” or “out of the money."

Term: Exogenous Growth: Definition, Economic Theory, Vs. Endogenous
Definition: Exogenous growth, a key tenet of neoclassical economic theory, states that economic growth is fueled by technological progress independent of economic forces./nThe exogenous growth model factors in production, diminishing returns of capital, savings rates, and technological variables to determine economic growth./nBoth the exogenous and endogenous growth models stress the role of technological progress in achieving sustained economic growth./nThe endogenous growth model differs from the exogenous growth model in that it suggests that forces within the economic system result in creating the atmosphere for technological progress.

Term: Expanded Accounting Equation: Definition, Formula, How It Works
Definition: The expanded accounting equation is the same as the common accounting equation but decomposes equity into component parts./nThe components of equity include contributed capital, retained earnings, and revenue minus dividends./nIt also accounts for total assets and total liabilities./nSome terminology may vary among different companies, depending on how they organize their balance sheets.

Term: Exotic Option: Definition and Comparison to Traditional Options
Definition: Exotic options are options contracts that differ from traditional options in their payment structures, expiration dates, and strike prices./nExotic options can be customized to meet the risk tolerance and desired profit of the investor./nAlthough exotic options provide flexibility, they do not guarantee profits.

Term: Expansion: Definition in Economics, Length, and Indicators
Definition: Expansion is the phase of the business cycle when the economy moves from a trough to a peak./nExpansions last on average about four to five years but have been known to go on anywhere from 10 months to more than a decade./nFocusing on interest rates and capital expenditure can help investors to determine where we are in the business cycle.

Term: Expatriate (Expat): Definition, With Pros/Cons of Living Abroad
Definition: An expatriate is somebody who has left their country of origin in order to reside in another country./nExpats may leave home for work reasons and seek more lucrative employment in a different country./nExpatriates may live for a while overseas or completely renounce their citizenship of one country in favor of another./nRetiring abroad has become an increasingly popular option./nThe IRS may impose an expatriation tax on individuals who renounce their citizenship, usually based on the value of a taxpayer's property or income in the United States.

Term: Expansionary Fiscal Policy: Risks and Examples
Definition: Expansionary policy seeks to stimulate an economy by boosting demand through monetary and fiscal stimulus./nExpansionary fiscal policy can include issuing stimulus checks or creating tax breaks, while expansionary policy can include lowering the federal funds rate./nExpansionary policy is intended to prevent or moderate economic downturns and recessions./nThough popular, expansionary policy can involve significant costs and risks including macroeconomic, microeconomic, and political economy issues./nExpansionary policy is directly related to inflation; though it may fight unemployment, it may also unintentionally cause higher prices.

Term: Expected Loss Ratio – ELR Method: Overview, Calculation, Formulas
Definition: Used to determine the projected amount of claims, relative to earned premiums./nInsurers set aside a portion of premiums from policies to pay for future claims—the expected loss ratio determines how much they set aside./nELR is used for businesses or business lines that lack past data, while the chain ladder method is used for stable businesses.

Term: What Is Expectations Theory? Predicting Short-Term Interest Rates
Definition: Expectations theory predicts future short-term interest rates based on current long-term interest rates/nThe theory suggests that an investor earns the same amount of interest by investing in two consecutive one-year bond investments versus investing in one two-year bond today/nIn theory, long-term rates can be used to indicate where rates of short-term bonds will trade in the future

Term: Expected Value Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: Expected value describes the long-term average level of a random variable based on its probability distribution./nIn investing, the EV of a stock or other investment is an important consideration and is used in scenario analyses./nModern portfolio theory uses EV in conjunction with an investment's risk (standard deviation) to come up with optimized portfolios./nEV can help investors size up whether an investment's risk is worth the potential reward.

Term: Expedited Funds Availability Act (EFAA): What it is, How it Works
Definition: The Expedited Funds Availability Act (EFAA) regulates the hold periods that commercial banks can make on deposits./nThe four main types of deposit hold types are statutory, large deposit, new account, and exception holds./nIn addition, the EFAA specifies that checks from insurance drawn on in-state banks must be made available five business days after deposit.

Term: Expected Utility: Definition, Calculation, and Examples
Definition: Expected utility refers to the utility of an entity or aggregate economy over a future period of time, given unknowable circumstances./nExpected utility theory is used as a tool for analyzing situations in which individuals must make a decision without knowing the outcomes that may result from that decision/nThe expected utility theory was first posited by Daniel Bernoulli who used it to solve the St. Petersburg Paradox./nExpected utility is also used to evaluate situations without immediate payback, such as purchasing insurance.

Term: Expected Return: Formula, How It Works, Limitations, Example
Definition: The expected return is the amount of profit or loss an investor can anticipate receiving on an investment./nAn expected return is calculated by multiplying potential outcomes by the odds of them occurring and then totaling these results./nExpected returns cannot be guaranteed./nThe expected return for a portfolio containing multiple investments is the weighted average of the expected return of each of the investments.

Term: Expense: Definition, Types, and How Expenses Are Recorded
Definition: An expense is the cost of operations that a company incurs to generate revenue./nBusinesses can write off tax-deductible expenses on their income tax returns, provided that they meet the IRS’ guidelines./nAccountants record expenses through one of two accounting methods: cash basis or accrual basis./nThere are two main categories of business expenses in accounting: operating expenses and non-operating expenses./nThe IRS treats capital expenses differently than most other business expenses.

Term: Expenditure Method: What It Is, How It Works, Formula
Definition: The expenditure method is the most common way of calculating a country's GDP./nThis method adds up consumer spending, investment, government expenditure, and net exports./nAggregate demand is equivalent to the expenditure equation for GDP in the long-run./nThe alternative method to calculate GDP is the income approach.

Term: Expense Ratio: Definition, Formula, Components, and Example
Definition: The expense ratio is a measure of mutual fund operating costs relative to assets./nInvestors pay attention to the expense ratio to determine if a fund is an appropriate investment for them after fees are considered./nExpense ratios may also be expressed as gross, net, and after-reimbursement expense ratios./nPassive index funds will have lower expense ratios than actively managed funds or those in less liquid asset classes./nIn general, expense ratios have declined as competition for investor dollars has increased.

Term: What Are Experience Ratings in Insurance
Definition: Insurance experience ratings are losses an insured party has relative to similar insured parties./nExperience ratings help determine the likelihood an insured will file a claim./nInsurers charge higher premiums to risky policyholders, which also incentivizes the policyholder to improve risk management practices./nExperience modifiers are adjustments of annual premiums based on previous loss experience.

Term: What Does Expiration Date Mean for Food and Prescriptions Drugs?
Definition: Expiration dates on food are not required by federal law except on infant formula./nDates on food indicate how long they will retain their freshness and best quality./nMost perishable foods are good well beyond the "sell by" or "use by" date./nPrescription and non-description drugs must carry expiration dates by federal law./nPrescription drug expiration dates indicate how long the manufacturer can guarantee the product's safety and effectiveness based on its own internal testing.

Term: Expiration Time Explained: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: The expiration time is the precise date and time at which derivatives contracts cease to trade and any obligations or rights come due or expire./nTypically, the last day to trade an option is the third Friday of the expiration month./nDerivative contracts will specify the exact expiration date and time.

Term: Explicit Cost: Definition, Examples, and How It Works
Definition: Inaccounting, explicit costs are normal business expenses that are tangible and easy to track; they appear in the general ledger./nExplicit costs are the only costs used to calculate a profit, as they demonstrably affect a company’s bottom line./nThough the depreciation of an asset cannot be tangibly traced, it is nevertheless an explicit cost, as it is linked to the cost of the underlying company asset.

Term: Exponential Growth: Definition, Examples, and Formula
Definition: Exponential growth is a pattern of data that shows sharper increases over time./nIn finance, compounding creates exponential returns, where investors benefit from larger growth over longer periods./nSavings accounts with a compounding interest rate can show exponential growth.

Term: Exploration & Production (E&P): Role in Oil and Gas Industry
Definition: Exploration and production (E&P) is the early stage of energy production, which includes searching for and extracting oil and natural gas./nAfter identifying potentially viable fields, a well is drilled to test the findings by collecting samples./nIf there are both the quality and quantity needed to produce and sell commercially, the production of oil wells begins./nThe oil and gas deposits are extracted from the wells, stored temporarily, and eventually shipped via a pipeline to a refinery.

Term: Expiration Date Basics for Options (Derivatives)
Definition: Options with longer expiration dates are generally more expensive due to the increased time value, while those nearing expiration may lose value quickly due to time decay./nOptions contracts have different expiration timelines, including daily, weekly, monthly, and even longer-term options known as LEAPS./nOption holders can exercise the option and realize profits or losses or let it expire as worthless./nUnderstanding how volatility interacts with the time to expiration helps investors make more informed decisions and manage risk effectively.

Term: Export Trading Company Defined, Reasons for Using One
Definition: An export trading company (ETC) handles the exportation process for clients, navigating all legal requirements and regulations that a company must follow before a country will allow its goods to be exported./nAlso called export management companies, ETCs can be either local or based in a foreign country, such as the country that imports the goods that the company is trying to properly export./nAn ETC can provide a firm with local knowledge about the laws and regulations in a foreign country, reduce training and recruitment costs, and help strategize ways to minimize exchange rate risk.

Term: What is EMA? How to Use Exponential Moving Average With Formula
Definition: The EMA is a moving average that places a greater weight and significance on the most recent data points./nLike all moving averages, this technical indicator is used to produce buy and sell signals based on crossovers and divergences from the historical average./nTraders often use several different EMA lengths, such as 10-day, 50-day, and 200-day moving averages.

Term: What Is an Export Credit Agency (ECA)?
Definition: Export credit agencies offer loans, loan guarantees, and insurance to help domestic companies limit the risk of selling goods and services in overseas markets./nECAs can be government agencies, private lenders, or semi-government bodies./nThe OECD maintains a list of official global ECAs.

Term: Express Warranty: Meaning, Overview and Examples
Definition: An express warranty is an agreement by a seller to provide repairs or a replacement for a faulty product, component, or service within a specified time period./nUnder the Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act, a company that provides a written express warranty must adhere to federal guidelines./nDetails about a product or service that are outlined in an advertisement can set the precedent for an express warranty./nIn the absence of communicated guarantees, an implied warranty may come into force.

Term: What Is Exposure at Default (EAD)? Meaning and How To Calculate
Definition: Exposure at default (EAD) is the predicted amount of loss a bank may be exposed to when a debtor defaults on a loan./nEAD is dynamic; as a borrower's risk and debt profile change, lenders often reassess exposure risk./nExposure at default, loss given default, and the probability of default is used to calculate the total credit risk capital of financial institutions./nEAD is important in assessing financial risk, preserving financial stability, and avoiding cascading defaults due to overexposed lending positions./nAs a result of the 2008 Global Financial Crisis, legislation and government policies attempt to monitor and oversee the banking industry's ability to manage stress.

Term: What Are Exports? Definition, Benefits, and Examples
Definition: An export refers to a product or service produced in one country and sold to a buyer abroad./nExports are one of the oldest forms of economic transfer and occur on a large scale between nations./nExports can increase a firm's sales and profits, and they may even present an opportunity to capture significant global market share./nCompanies that export heavily are typically exposed to a higher degree of financial risk./nIn 2022, the world exported nearly $31.34 trillion of goods and services, led by China ($3.7 trillion of exports).

Term: External Debt: Definition, Types, vs. Internal Debt
Definition: External debt is the portion of a country’s debt that is borrowed from foreign lenders, including commercial banks, governments, or international financial institutions./nIf a country cannot repay its external debt, it is said to be in sovereign debt and faces a debt crisis./nExternal debt can take the form of a tied loan, whereby the borrower must apply any spending of the funds to the country that is providing the loan.

Term: Expropriation: Definition, Purposes, Compensation Concerns
Definition: Expropriation is the act of a government claiming privately owned property to be used for the benefit of the overall public./nProperties may be expropriated in order to build highways, railroads, airports, or other infrastructure projects./nProperty owners must be compensated fairly for property that is expropriated, as instructed by the Fifth Amendment.

Term: Extended Trading: How It Works, Risks, and Hours
Definition: Extended trading occurs on electronic marketplaces outside of the official trading hours of the exchange./nU.S. exchanges open at 9:30 a.m. and close at 4:00 p.m. EST. Extended trading occurs outside those hours./nMost brokers require traders to enter limit orders during extended trading sessions.

Term: External Economies of Scale: Definition and Examples
Definition: External economies of scale are business-enhancing factors that occur outside a company but within the same industry./nIn addition to lower production and operating costs, external economies of scale may also reduce a company's variable costs per unit because of operational efficiencies and synergies./nOn the downside, external economies of scale could dull the competitive edge of a company, as it cannot exclude its competitors from benefiting.

Term: Externality: What It Means in Economics, With Positive and Negative Examples
Definition: An externality is an event that occurs as a byproduct of another event occurring./nAn externality can be good or bad, often noted as a positive externality or negative externality./nAn externality can also be generated when something is made (i.e. a production externality) or used (i.e. a consumption externality)./nPollution caused by commuting to work or a chemical spill caused by improperly stored waste are examples of externalities./nGovernments and companies can rectify externalities by financial and social measures.

Term: Production Externality: Definition, Measuring, and Examples
Definition: Production externality refers to a side effect from an industrial operation, such as a chemical company leaking improperly stored chemicals into the water table./nProduction externalities can be measured in terms of the difference between the actual cost of production of the good and the real cost to society at large./nThe impact of production externalities can be positive or negative or a combination./nA positive production externality is the positive effect an activity imposes on an unrelated third party; a negative externality is the negative effect an activity imposes on the same.

Term: Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM): Definition, Examples, AGM
Definition: When a company has a shareholder meeting that isn't its scheduled annual meeting, it's called an extraordinary general meeting (EGM)./nThe extraordinary general meeting is utilized to deal with urgent matters that come up between annual shareholders' meetings./nEGMs are often considered for emergency measures such as resolving an immediate legal matter or the removal of a key manager.

Term: Extraordinary Item: Definition, How They Work, and Requirements
Definition: Extraordinary items were gains or losses from infrequent and unusual events that were separately classified on companies' financial statements./nIn January 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) eliminated the concept of extraordinary items.﻿﻿/nFASB discontinued the accounting treatment for extraordinary items to reduce the cost and complexity of preparing financial statements.

Term: Extrinsic Value: Definition, How to Calculate, and Example
Definition: Extrinsic value is the difference between the market price of an option, also knowns as its premium, and its intrinsic price, which is the difference between an option's strike price and the underlying asset's price./nExtrinsic value rises with increase in volatility in the market.

Term: 1913 Federal Reserve Act: Definition and Why It's Important
Definition: The 1913 Federal Reserve Act created the Federal Reserve System, known simply as "The Fed."/nIt was implemented to establish economic stability in the U.S. by introducing a central bank to oversee monetary policy.﻿﻿/nThe Federal Reserve Act is one of the most influential laws shaping the U.S. financial system.

Term: Face Value: Definition in Finance, Comparison With Market Value
Definition: Face value describes the nominal value or dollar value of a security; the face value is stated by the issuing party./nA stock's face value is the initial cost of the stock, as indicated on the certificate of the stock in question; a bond's face value is the dollar figure due to be paid to the investor, once the bond reaches maturity./nThe actual market value of a stock or a bond is not reliably indicated by its face value, because there are many other influencing forces at play, such as supply and demand.

Term: FAANG Stocks: Definition and Companies Involved
Definition: FAANG is an acronym referring to the stocks of the five most popular and best-performing American technology companies./nThese are: Meta (formerly known as Facebook); Amazon; Apple; Netflix; and Alphabet (formerly known as Google)./nIn addition to being widely known among consumers, the five FAANG stocks are among the largest companies in the world./nSome have raised concerns that the FAANG stocks may be in the midst of a bubble, whereas others argue that their growth is justified by the stellar financial and operational performance they have shown in recent years./nThe term was coined byThe Street'sBob Lang and popularized by Jim Cramer on his CNBC TV showMad Money.

Term: Facility: Definition, Loan Types, and Examples
Definition: Facilities are financial assistance programs offered by banks and lending institutions to help companies./nThe main types of facilities are overdraft services, business lines of credit, term loans, and letters of credit./nA facility is essentially another name for a loan taken out by a company.

Term: What Factor Investing Is and How the Strategy Works
Definition: Factor investing utilizes multiple factors, including macroeconomic as well as fundamental and statistical, to analyze and explain asset prices and build an investment strategy./nFactors that have been identified by investors include: growth vs. value; market capitalization; credit rating; and stock price volatility - among several others./nSmart beta is a common application of a factor investing strategy.

Term: Factor Definition: Requirements, Benefits, and Example
Definition: A factor is a funding source; it agrees to pay a company the value of an invoice—less a discount for commission and fees./nThe terms and conditions set by a factor may vary depending on its internal practices./nThe factor is more concerned with the creditworthiness of the invoiced party than the company from which it has purchased the receivable.

Term: Factor Market: Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: In the view of economists, there are only two markets: the factor market (or input market) and the goods and services, or output, market./nThe three main factor markets are the labor market, the capital market, and the land market, which refers to all natural resources./nThe input market supplies the resources needed to make finished products./nThe output market buys and uses the finished products./nThe factor market is driven by demand in the goods and services market.

Term: FactSet: What it is, How it Works, Company Structure
Definition: FactSet Research System is a financial data and software company that provides research for Wall Street professionals and individual investors./nFactSet combines data from a variety of financial information resources into one source, available to users online./nFactSet's system provides market analytics, financial content, stock screening, customized data, and other features.

Term: 4 Factors of Production Explained With Examples
Definition: Factors of production is an economic term that describes the inputs used in the production of goods or services to make an economic profit./nThese include any resource needed for the creation of a good or service./nThe factors of production are land, labor, capital, and entrepreneurship./nThe state of technological progress can influence the total factors of production and account for any efficiencies not related to the four typical factors./nLand as a factor of production can mean agriculture and farming as well as the use of natural resources, and even land to construct buildings on.

Term: What Is Failure to Deliver, and What Happens With FTDs?
Definition: Failure to deliver (FTD) refers to not being able to meet one's trading obligations./nIn the case of buyers, it means not having the cash; in the case of sellers, it means not having the goods./nThe reckoning of these obligations occurs at trade settlement./nFailure to deliver can occur in derivatives contracts or when selling short naked.

Term: Facultative Reinsurance: Definition, Vs. Treaty Reinsurance
Definition: Facultative reinsurance is coverage purchased by a primary insurer to cover a single risk or a block of risks held in the primary insurer's book of business./nFacultative reinsurance allows the reinsurance company to review individual risks and determine whether to accept or reject them and so are more focused in nature than treaty reinsurance./nBy covering itself against a single or block of risks, reinsurance gives the insurer more security for its equity and solvency and more stability when unusual or major events occur.

Term: Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA): How It Protects Consumers
Definition: The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) provides consumers with protection against unfair billing practices./nThe FCBA applies only to open-end credit, such as credit cards and lines of credit. It does not apply to loans like auto loans or mortgages./nBilling errors covered by the law include unauthorized charges, charges with an incorrect date or amount, and calculation errors./nConsumers have 60 days from the time they receive their bill to dispute a charge with the card issuer or other lender./nWhile the FCBA protects consumers from unfair billing practices, the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) addresses practices involving the use of a consumer's personal information./nA chargeback is the return of money to a customer following the successful dispute of a particular transaction.

Term: Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Overview and History
Definition: The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) protects workers against unfair employment practices./nFLSA rules specify when workers are considered on the clock, when they should be paid overtime, and a minimum wage./nEmployees are deemed either exempt or nonexempt with regard to the FLSA./nThe FLSA applies to employers whose annual sales total $500,000 or more or are engaged in interstate commerce./nOriginally, the FLSA prohibited child labor; it has since been expanded to prohibit wage discrimination because of gender and age.

Term: How the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) Protects Consumer Rights
Definition: The Fair Credit Reporting Act governs how credit bureaus can collect and share information about individual consumers./nBusinesses check credit reports for many purposes, such as deciding whether to make a loan or sell insurance to a consumer. Employers may check them, too./nThe FCRA also gives consumers certain rights, including free access to their own credit reports at least once a year./nViolations of the FCRA can carry fines, including damages if any are incurred./nEnforcement of the FCRA falls to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB).

Term: Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA): Definition and Rules
Definition: The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) covers when, how, and how often a third-party debt collector can contact a debtor./nThe FDCPA sets limits on who the debt collector is allowed to contact in addition to the debtor./nIf a debt collector violates the FDCPA, the debtor can sue them in state or federal court for damages and legal fees within one year of the violation.

Term: Fallen Angel: What it is, How it Works, Risks
Definition: A fallen angel is a bond that has been reduced to junk status because its issuer has fallen into financial trouble./nIts bonds pay higher returns than investment-quality bonds but are riskier./nSome bond funds and ETFs focus on fallen angels.

Term: Fair Market Value (FMV): Definition and How to Calculate It
Definition: The fair market value is the price an asset would sell for on the open market when certain conditions are met./nThe conditions are: the parties involved are aware of all the facts, are acting in their own interest, are free of any pressure to buy or sell, and have ample time to make the decision./nFair market value is different than market value and appraised value./nTax settings and the real estate market are two areas that commonly use fair market value./nInsurance companies use fair market value in determining certain claim payouts.

Term: Fair Value: Its Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: Fair value is the estimated price at which an asset is bought or sold when both the buyer and seller freely agree on a price./nIndividuals and businesses may compare current market value, growth potential, and replacement cost to determine the fair value of an asset./nFair value is a measure of an asset's worth and market value is the price of an asset in the marketplace./nFair value accounting is the practice of measuring a business's liabilities and assets at their current market value.

Term: What Is a Falling Knife and How Do Investors and Traders Use It?
Definition: The term falling knife refers to a sharp drop./nThere's no specific magnitude or duration to the drop before it's considered to be a falling knife./nA falling knife is generally used as a caution not to jump into a stock or other asset during a drop./nTraders will trade on a sharp drop but they generally want to be in a short position and will use technical indicators to time their trades.

Term: Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA): What You Need to Know
Definition: The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) is a 1993 labor law that protects the jobs of employees who need to take a leave of absence for personal or family reasons./nThe law guarantees that a qualified employee may take up to 12 weeks for reasons such as childbirth, adoption, and personal or family illness./nThe Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 guarantees that when an employee returns to work, they can return to the job they held before the leave. If that job is no longer available, they must be offered a job that is essentially equal in pay and status./nTo qualify for the FMLA, an employee must work for a firm that employs at least 50 people working within a 75-mile radius of the work site, and they must have been employed for at least 1,250 hours within the past 12 months.

Term: Fama and French Three Factor Model Definition: Formula and Interpretation
Definition: The Fama French 3-factor model is an asset pricing model that expands on the capital asset pricing model by adding size risk and value risk factors to the market risk factors./nThe model was developed by Nobel laureates Eugene Fama and his colleague Kenneth French in the 1990s./nThe model is essentially the result of an econometric regression of historical stock prices.

Term: FANG Stocks: Definition, Companies, Performance, and How to Invest
Definition: The acronym "FANG" refers to the stocks of four popular American technology companies: Facebook (Meta), Amazon, Netflix, and Google (Alphabet)./nSince 2017, Apple has also been included, making the acronym FAANG./nEach FANG company has shown extraordinary growth, reflected in their revenues and net profits./nHowever, these stocks can also be quite volatile when tech stocks take a beating./nAlthough their business models vary, they each share the use of advanced technologies to acquire and retain users.

Term: What Is a Family Office and Do You Need One?
Definition: Family offices provide a broad spectrum of private wealth management services to one or a small number of ultra-high-net-worth families./nBesides financial services, family offices can provide various kinds of planning, charitable giving advice, concierge services, and other comprehensive services./nAn important responsibility a family office has is to educate next generations in the handling and management of their wealth./nSingle-family offices serve one individual and their family, while multi-family offices serve more than one family, and are less expensive due to economies of scale./nThe need for a family office can be determined by the extent of a family's wealth and the complexity of its life due to that wealth.

Term: Family Limited Partnership (FLP): Definition, Pros & Cons
Definition: A family limited partnership (FLP) is a business or holding company owned by two or more family members./nWithin a family limited partnership (FLP), each family member can buy shares in the venture for a potential profit./nThere are two types of partners in an FLP: general partners and limited partners. General partners are responsible for management of the business./nFLPs are often established to preserve a family's generational wealth, allowing for tax-free transfers of assets, real estate, and other wealth./nIf the business fails, members risk losing their investment or even incurring debt.

Term: Fast Fashion: How It Impacts Retail Manufacturing
Definition: Fast fashion describes low-priced but stylish clothing that moves quickly from design to retail stores to meet trends, with new collections being introduced continuously./nInnovations in supply chain management among retailers make fast fashion possible./nZara and H&M are two giants in the fast fashion field./nFast fashion offers affordable prices and instant gratification for consumers.

Term: Farmers Home Administration (FmHA): Meaning, History, Examples
Definition: The Farmers Home Administration (FmHA) was a government agency created to help dispense loans to farmers and rural communities following the Great Depression./nIt is known today as USDA Rural Development./nAccording to a U.S. Government Accountability Office report, the FmHA faltered by the 1990s due to weak lending practices./nThe FmHA was abolished in October 1994 and its functions transferred to another agency at the USDA.

Term: Fast-Moving Consumer Goods (FMCG) Industry: Definition, Types, and Profitability
Definition: Fast-moving consumer goods are nondurable products that sell quickly at relatively low costs./nFMCGs have low profit margins and high-volume sales./nExamples of FMCGs include milk, gum, fruit and vegetables, toilet paper, soda, beer, and over-the-counter drugs like aspirin.

Term: FDIC Insured Account Definition, Requirements, Pros/Cons
Definition: An FDIC insured account is a bank account at an institution where deposits are federally protected against bank failure or theft./nThe FDIC is a federally backed deposit insurance agency where member banks pay regular premiums to fund claims./nThe maximum insurable amount is currently $250,000 per depositor, per bank.

Term: The Fear & Greed Index: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: The Fear & Greed Index was developed by CNN Business to measure whether stocks are fairly priced./nThe index attempts to determine how emotions influence how much investors are willing to pay for stocks./nThe index assumes that fear drives stocks lower, while greed boosts stock values./nThe index is calculated based on seven indicators, which each measure a distinct aspect of stock market behavior.

Term: What Is a Federal Agency? Definition, Purposes, Bond Issues
Definition: Federal agencies are special government organizations set up for a specific purpose such as the management of resources or national security issues./nFederal agencies are created to regulate industries or practices that require close oversight or specialized expertise./nA number of these organizations issue or guarantee securities such as stocks and bonds./nSince agency bonds are less liquid than Treasury bonds, they offer a slightly higher interest rate.

Term: Fed Balance Sheet: The Federal Reserve's Assets and Liabilities
Definition: The Fed balance sheet is a listing of the Federal Reserve's assets and liabilities./nThe Fed's assets and liabilities are disclosed in a weekly report by the Fed./nThe Fed's balance sheet has grown dramatically since 2008 to support the economy after the global financial crisis and again following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Term: Federal Communications Commission (FCC): Mission and FQS
Definition: The FCC is an independent U.S. government agency that answers to the United States Congress./nThe FCC oversees all interstate and international communications./nIt also maintains standards and consistency among media types and communication methods while protecting the interests of consumers and businesses./nThe agency is accountable to U.S. Congress and its actions are monitored closely by investors./nThe FCC is headed by a chair, who is one of five commissioners appointed by the President.

Term: Federal Direct Loan Program: Meaning, Types, Pros and Cons
Definition: The Federal Direct Loan Program offers direct loans that are subsidized and unsubsidized, as well as PLUS loans and consolidation loans./nSubsidized federal student loans offer the lowest interest rates./nParent PLUS loans often have the highest interest rates of all the federal student loans offered by the government./nAll loans have maximum amounts that are set annually, with each successive year allowing for a specified increase./nFederal direct loans often have more favorable interest rates than private loans.

Term: Federal Discount Rate: Definition, vs. Federal Funds Rate
Definition: The federal discount rate is the interest rate the Federal Reserve (Fed) charges banks to borrow funds from a Federal Reserve bank from the discount window./nThe Fed's discount rate is set by the Fed's board of governors, and can be adjusted up or down as a tool of monetary policy./nLending at the discount rate is part of the Fed's function as a lender of last resort, and is one of the Fed's primary monetary policy tools./nThe federal funds rate target is set by the fed, but the actual rate is determined by the supply and demand for overnight loans in the interbank money market.

Term: Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. (FDIC): Definition & Limits
Definition: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. (FDIC) is an independent federal agency insuring deposits in U.S. banks and thrifts in the event of bank failures./nThe FDIC insures deposits up to $250,000 per depositor, as long as the institution is a member firm./nThe FDIC covers checking and savings accounts, certificates of deposit (CDs), money market accounts, IRAs, revocable and irrevocable trust accounts, and employee benefit plans./nMutual funds, annuities, life insurance policies, stocks, and bonds aren't covered by the FDIC.

Term: Federal Home Loan Bank (FHLB) System: Definition and History
Definition: The FHLB is a network of 11 regional banks that provide cash to other banks in order to keep money flowing to consumers and businesses./nThe FHLB was created by the federal government during The Great Depression./nThe FHLB receives no taxpayer funding: Its banks are private cooperatives./nFHLB banks raise funds primarily from issuing bonds called consolidated obligations./nFHLB banks focus on mortgage financing and related community investments, providing low-cost loans that member banks can pass on to customers.

Term: Federal Funds Rate: What It Is, How It's Determined, and Why It's Important
Definition: The federal funds rate is the target interest rate range set by the FOMC./nThis is the rate at which commercial banks borrow and lend their excess reserves to each other overnight./nThe FOMC sets a target federal funds rate eight times a year, based on prevailing economic conditions./nThe federal funds rate can influence short-term rates on consumer loans and credit cards./nInvestors keep an eye out on the federal funds rate as well because it has an impact on the stock market.

Term: What Are Federal Funds? Definition and How Loans and Rates Work
Definition: Federal funds refer to excess reserves held by financial institutions, over and above the mandated reserve requirements of the central bank./nBanks will borrow or lend their excess funds to each other on an overnight basis, as some banks find themselves with too much reserves and others with too little./nThe federal funds rate is a target set by the central bank, but the actual market rate for federal fund reserves is determined by this overnight inter-bank lending market.

Term: Federal Housing Administration (FHA): Overview, History, FAQ
Definition: The Federal Housing Administration (FHA) offers mortgage insurance to approved lenders./nThe agency was established in 1934 and became part of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) in 1965./nThe FHA home loan program is designed for borrowers who can’t make large down payments, have lower credit scores, and don’t qualify for conventional mortgages./nBorrowers with FHA loans must purchase FHA mortgage insurance./nMortgage insurance premiums (MIPs) collected from FHA-insured loans help pay for the program.

Term: Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC): What It Is and Does
Definition: The Federal Open Market Committee is a branch of the Federal Reserve System./nThe FOMC determines the direction of monetary policy by directing open market operations./nThe committee is composed of the seven members of the Board of Governors and five Federal Reserve Bank presidents./nIt has eight regularly scheduled meetings each year that are the subject of speculation on Wall Street.

Term: Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC): What It Is and Does
Definition: The Federal Open Market Committee is a branch of the Federal Reserve System./nThe FOMC determines the direction of monetary policy by directing open market operations./nThe committee is composed of the seven members of the Board of Governors and five Federal Reserve Bank presidents./nIt has eight regularly scheduled meetings each year that are the subject of speculation on Wall Street.

Term: Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA): What It Is, Who Pays
Definition: Individuals' FICA contributions pay current benefits and build future ones that will be owed to them./nFICA contributions are withheld from a wage earner's gross pay; the amount withheld depends on gross wages./nEmployers match the FICA taxes paid by their employees./nWage earners cannot opt out of paying FICA taxes./nSince the 1930s, FICA has funded Social Security programs that provide benefits to retirees, children and surviving spouses, and the disabled.

Term: Federal Poverty Level (FPL) Definition
Definition: The federal poverty level is the annualized income earned by a household below which they would be eligible to receive certain welfare benefits./nThe FPL is the minimum income that a family requires for food, clothing, transportation, shelter, and other necessities./nThe FPL is published by the Department of Health and Human Services and is adjusted for inflation annually./nThe FPL is used to determine eligibility for certain federal and state assistance programs, such as housing vouchers, Medicaid, and CHIP./nThe FPL is different from the poverty threshold, which defines poverty and provides statistics on the number of people living under such conditions in the U.S.

Term: Federal Reserve System (FRS): Functions and History
Definition: The Federal Reserve System is the central bank of the United States./nIts key functions include handling the country's monetary policy and regulating banks, among other things./nThe Federal Reserve payments system, known as the Fedwire, moves trillions of dollars daily between banks./nThe Federal Open Market Committee is the Fed's monetary policy-making body and manages the country's money supply./nThe FOMC adjusts the target for the overnight federal funds rate, which controls short-term interest rates, based on its view of the economy.

Term: Federal Reserve Board (FRB): How It Works, Structure, and Duties
Definition: The Federal Reserve Board (FRB) is the governing body of the Federal Reserve System, America's central bank./nThe FRB is an independent governmental agency in charge of conducting monetary policy through open market operations or setting interest rates./nThe FRB is composed of seven members including a chair, appointed by Congress from among the regional federal reserve banks.

Term: Federal Trade Commission (FTC): What It Is and What It Does
Definition: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is a bipartisan federal agency that enforces antitrust laws and protects consumers./nIt was signed into law by President Woodrow Wilson in 1914 as part of the administration's trust-busting efforts./nFTC activities include investigating fraud or false advertising, congressional inquiries, and pre-merger notification./nThe FTC also handles scams and unfair or predatory business practices./nThe FTC discourages anticompetitive behavior through the Bureau of Competition, which reviews proposed mergers with the Department of Justice.

Term: What Is FUTA? Definition and How to Calculate FUTA Liability
Definition: The Federal Unemployment Tax Act is legislation that imposes a payroll tax on any business with employees; the revenue raised is used to fund unemployment benefits./nThe FUTA tax rate is 6% of the first $7,000 paid to each employee annually./nFUTA taxes are only imposed on employers even though they are based on employees' wages./nFUTA and SUTA are similar taxes just imposed on different levels of government, while FUTA and FICA fund entirely different programs by charging different individuals./nEmployers who also pay their state unemployment insurance can receive a federal tax credit of up to 5.4%, resulting in an effective FUTA tax rate of 0.6%.

Term: Feasibility Study
Definition: A company may conduct a feasibility study when it’s considering launching a new business, adding a new product line, or acquiring a rival./nA feasibility study assesses the potential for success of the proposed plan or project by defining its expected costs and projected benefits in detail./nIt’s a good idea to have a contingency plan on hand in case the original project is found to be infeasible.

Term: Feed-In Tariff (FIT): Explanation, History, and Uses
Definition: A feed-in tariff (FIT) is a policy designed to support the development of renewable energy sources by providing a guaranteed, above-market price for producers./nFITs usually involve long-term contracts, from 15 to 20 years./nFITs are common in the U.S. and around the world, used most notably in Germany and Japan.

Term: What Is a Fee? Definition, How They Work, Types, and Examples
Definition: Most often, fees are the payment one makes for service, both basic—mowing a lawn, for example, and complex—like drafting a will or preparing your taxes./nSometimes there is more than one fee charged for a service (i.e., buying a plane ticket for X amount of money, but getting hit with luggage fees and travel fees)./nThere are government (local and federal) fees connected with obtaining licenses, such as a driver’s license or a passport./nFees can add up fast; for example, some lenders charge hefty fees for late charges./nSome services use hidden fees to pad their bills with unexpected costs. Asking about hidden fees (or simply fees that are not obvious) may save you from a higher bill than expected.

Term: Bank Fees: Everything to Know About How Banks Make Money
Definition: A feeder fund is one of many smaller investment funds that pool investor money, which is then aggregated under a single centralized master fund./nConsolidation of feeder funds into a master fund allows for reductions of operation and trading costs, and a larger portfolio has the added benefit of economies of scale./nHedge funds commonly use master-feeder structures, where fees generated are pro-rated and distributed to the feeder funds.

Term: FHA 203(k) Loan: Definition, Use, Types, Pros, and Cons
Definition: An FHA 203(k) loan is a government-backed mortgage that is essentially a construction loan that finances both the purchase and repairs of a home./nThese loans are intended to support homeownership among lower-income households, allowing them to improve and update older properties as their primary residence./nThe FHA offers different varieties of the 203(k) loan depending on the extent of repairs needed.

Term: Fibonacci Sequence: Definition, How it Works, and How to Use It
Definition: The Fibonacci sequence is a set of steadily increasing numbers where each number is equal to the sum of the preceding two numbers./nThe golden ratio of 1.618 is derived from the Fibonacci sequence./nMany things in nature have dimensional properties that adhere to the golden ratio of 1.618./nThe Fibonacci sequence can be applied to finance by using four techniques including retracements, arcs, fans, and time zones.

Term: All About Fibonacci Extensions: What They Are, How To Use Them
Definition: Because Fibonacci ratios are common in everyday life, some traders believe these common ratios may also have significance in the financial markets./nFibonacci extensions don't have a formula. Rather, they are drawn at three points on a chart, marking price levels of possible importance./nThe Fibonacci extensions show how far the next pricewavecould move following a pullback./nBased on Fibonacci ratios, common Fibonacci extension levels are 61.8%, 100%, 161.8%, 200%, and 261.8%./nExtension levels signal possible areas of importance, but should not be relied on exclusively.

Term: What Are Fibonacci Retracement Levels, and What Do They Tell You?
Definition: Fibonacci retracement levels connect any two points that the trader views as relevant, typically a high point and a low point./nThe percentage levels provided are areas where the price could stall or reverse./nThe most commonly used ratios include 23.6%, 38.2%, 50%, 61.8%, and 78.6%./nThese levels should not be relied on exclusively, so it is dangerous to assume that the price will reverse after hitting a specific Fibonacci level./nFibonacci numbers and sequencing were first used by Indian mathematicians centuries before Leonardo Fibonacci.

Term: Fiat Money: What It Is, How It Works, Example, Pros & Cons
Definition: Fiat money is a government-issued currency that is not backed by a commodity such as gold./nFiat money gives central banks greater control over the economy because they can control how much money is printed./nMost modern paper currencies, such as the U.S. dollar, are fiat currencies./nOne danger of fiat money is that governments can print too much of it, resulting in hyperinflation.

Term: Fidelity Bond: Definition, Types, and Uses
Definition: Fidelity bonds are insurance policies that protect policyholder companies from wrongful acts committed by employees./nFidelity bonds are not tradable securities./nThis form of insurance is considered a component of a company’s risk management strategy.

Term: FICO Score
Definition: FICO credit scores are a method of quantifying and evaluating an individual’s creditworthiness./nFICO scores are used in 90% of mortgage application decisions in the United States./nScores range from 300 to 850, with scores in the 670 to 739 range considered to be “good” credit scores./nYou can improve your FICO score by paying bills on time, using less than 30% of your available credit, and having a mix of different types of credit.

Term: Fiduciary Definition: Examples and Why They Are Important
Definition: Fiduciaries are legally bound to put their client’s best interests ahead of their own./nFiduciary duties appear in various business relationships, including between a trustee and a beneficiary, corporate board members and shareholders, and executors and legatees./nAn investment fiduciary is anyone with legal responsibility for managing somebody else’s money, such as a member of the investment committee of a charity./nRegistered investment advisors and insurance agents have a fiduciary duty to their clients./nBroker-dealers may be subject to the less stringent standard set by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Regulation Best Interest, implemented in 2019.

Term: Fill or Kill (FOK) Order: Definition and Example
Definition: A Fill or Kill (FOK) order is an order that is directed to be executed immediately at the market or a specified price or canceled if not filled./nA FOK order combines an all-or-none (AON) specification indicating it must be filled entirely with an immediate-or-cancel (IOC) timeframe./nTypical FOK orders last a couple of seconds to minimize disruption to the stock's price and partial fills are not allowed.

Term: Financial Account Definition, With Components and Assets
Definition: A financial account is a component of a country’s balance of payments that covers claims on or liabilities to nonresidents concerning financial assets./nFinancial account components include direct investment, portfolio investment, and reserve assets broken down by sector./nThe financial account involves financial assets such as gold, currency, derivatives,special drawing rights, equities, and bonds.

Term: What Does Finance Mean? Its History, Types, and Importance Explained
Definition: Finance is a term broadly describing the study and system of money, investments, and other financial instruments./nFinance can be divided broadly into three distinct categories: public finance, corporate finance, and personal finance./nMore recent subcategories of finance include social finance and behavioral finance./nThe history of finance and financial activities dates back to the dawn of civilization./nWhile it has roots in scientific fields, such as statistics, economics, and mathematics, finance also includes nonscientific elements that liken it to an art.

Term: Financial Accounting Meaning, Principles, and Why It Matters
Definition: Financial accounting is the framework that dictates the rules, processes, and standards for financial recordkeeping./nNonprofits, corporations, and small businesses use financial accountants to prepare their books and records and generate their financial reports./nFinancial reporting occurs through the use of financial statements, such as the balance sheet, income statement, statement of cash flow, and statement of changes in shareholder equity./nFinancial accounting differs from managerial accounting, as financial reporting is for reporting to external parties, while managerial accounting is for internal strategic planning./nFinancial accounting may be performed under the accrual method (recording expenses for items that have not yet been paid) or the cash method (only cash transactions are recorded).

Term: Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB): Definition and How It Works
