Definition: The Heckscher-Ohlin model evaluates the equilibrium of trade between two countries that have varying specialties and natural resources./nThe model explains how a nation should operate and trade when resources are imbalanced throughout the world./nThe model isn't limited to commodities, but also incorporates other production factors such as labor.

Term: Hedge Definition: What It Is and How It Works in Investing
Definition: A hedge is a strategy that seeks to limit risk exposures in financial assets./nPopular hedging techniques involve taking offsetting positions in derivatives that correspond to an existing position./nOther types of hedges can be constructed via other means likediversification. An example could be investing in both cyclical and countercyclical stocks./nBesides protecting an investor from various types of risk, it is believed that hedging makes the market run more efficiently.

Term: Hedge Clause: What It is, How it Works, Structure
Definition: A hedge clause refers to text added to industry research or analysts' reports that serve as a disclaimer./nThe hedge clause absolves the author(s) of the report from any responsibility due to errors or omissions./nHedge clauses must be carefully worded so that they do not transgress regulatory rules around securities fraud and making false claims.

Term: Hedge Fund: Definition, Examples, Types, and Strategies
Definition: Hedge funds are actively managed funds focused on alternative investments that commonly use risky investment strategies./nA hedge fund investment typically requires accredited investors and a high minimum investment ornet worth./nHedge funds charge higher fees than conventional investment funds./nThe strategies used by hedge funds depend on the fund manager and relate to equity, fixed-income, and event-driven investment goals./nA hedge fund investor's investment usually is locked up for a year before they may sell shares and withdraw funds.

Term: Hedge Ratio: Definition, Calculation, and Types of Ratios
Hedge Fund Manager: Definition, Strategies, and Compensation
Definition: A hedge fund manager is an individual or financial company that employs professional portfolio managers and analysts to establish and maintain hedge funds./nHedge fund managers typically earn above-average compensation, often from a two-and-twenty fee structure./nHedge fund managers typically specialize in a particular investment strategy that they then use to power their fund portfolio's mandate for profits./nIn 2022, the 25 highest-paid hedge fund managers made a total of $21.5 billion./nThe top amount was $4.1 billion for the year.

Term: Hedged Tender
Definition: A hedged tender is a way to counteract the risk that the offering company refuses some or all of an investor's shares that are submitted as part of a tender offer./nA tender offer is a proposal from one investor or company to purchase a set number of shares of another company's stock at a price that is higher than the current market price.

Term: Hedging Transaction: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A hedging transaction is a tactical action that an investor takes with the intent of reducing the risk of losing money (or experiencing a shortfall) while executing their investment strategy./nHedging transactions usually involve derivatives, such as options, futures or forward contracts, to reduce the risk of investments./nMore sophisticated hedging can take place using inversely correlated securities.

Term: Hedonic Pricing: Definition, How the Model Is Used, and Example
Definition: Hedonic pricing identifies the internal and external factors and characteristics that affect an item’s price in the market./nHedonic pricing is most often seen in the housing market, since real estate prices are determined by the characteristics of the property itself as well as the neighborhood or environment within which it exists./nHedonic pricing captures a consumer’s willingness to pay for what they perceive are environmental differences that add or detract from the intrinsic value of an asset or property.

Term: Hedonic Regression
Definition: Hedonic regression is the application of regression analysis to estimate the impact that various factors have on the price or demand for a good./nIn a hedonic regression model, a price is usually the dependent variable and the attributes that are believed to provide utility to the buyer or consumer are the independent variables./nHedonic regression is commonly used in real estate pricing and quality adjustment for price indexes.

Term: Heikin-Ashi Technique Definition and Formula
Definition: Heikin-Ashi is a candlestick pattern technique that aims to reduce some of the market noise, creating a chart that highlights trend direction better than typical candlestick charts./nThe downside to Heikin-Ashi is that some price data is lost with averaging, which could affect risk./nLong down candles with little upper shadow represent strong selling pressure, while long up candles with small or no lower shadows signal strong buying pressure.

Term: Held-By-Production Clause: What It is, How It Works
Definition: Held-by-production clauses allow miners for oil, gas and minerals extend their land leases after they expire as long as the mines are still productive./nheld-by-production clauses are also called “habendum” clauses/nMining companies seek held-by-production clauses to lock in a lease price in potentially “hot” areas of production.

Term: What Is Held-For-Trading Security? Role of Fair Value Adjustment
Definition: A held-for-trading security is a debt or equity investment purchased with the intention of short-term gain./nAny gains or losses for a held-for-trading security during its period of holding must be reported on the balance sheet of the trading firm./nOn the balance sheet, held-for-trading securities are considered current assets./nHeld-for-trading securities are reported at fair value, and unrealized/gains or losses are reflected in earnings./nAccounting standards require debt or equity securities to be classified when they are purchased. In addition to held-for-trading, classifications include held-to-maturity and available for sale.

Term: What Is an Heir? Definition, Types, Dying Intestate, and Examples
Definition: An heir is a person who is legally entitled to collect an inheritance when a deceased person did not formalize a last will and testament./nGenerally speaking, heirs who inherit the property are children, descendants, or other close relatives of the decedent./nLegally speaking, heirs differ from beneficiaries, who are designated by a will or other written documents, as the intended recipient of a decedent's assets./nThe portion of a deceased person's estate that's bequeathed to an heir is known as an inheritance./nWhen an individual dies without a will, it is known as intestate, and a probate court determines how the assets are distributed.

Term: Held Order: What it Means, How it Works, Uses
Definition: A held order is given to a broker for prompt execution and an immediate fill, such as with a market order./nThe benefit of a held order is that the customer will be sure to have executed the entire size of their order, whether a buy or a sale, without delay./nA not-held order, on the other hand, gives some discretion to the broker to work the order to try to find a better price.

Term: Held-to-Maturity (HTM) Securities: How They Work and Examples
Definition: Held-to-maturity (HTM) securities are purchased to be owned until maturity./nBonds and other debt vehicles—such as certificates of deposit (CDs)—are the most common form of held-to-maturity (HTM) investments./nHeld-to-maturity (HTM) securities provide investors with a consistent income stream; however, they are not ideal if an investor anticipates needing cash in the short term.

Term: Helicopter Drop (Helicopter Money): Economics Examples and Types
Definition: Helicopter drop, an idea of economist Milton Friedman, is a type of monetary stimulus that injects cash into an economy as if it was thrown out of a helicopter./nHelicopter money refers to increasing a nation's money supply through more spending, tax cuts, or boosting money supply./nSome of the stimulus measures taken in response to the Covid-19 crisis resemble the concept of helicopter drop money.

Term: University of Iowa Tippie College of Business
Definition: The University of Iowa Tippie College of Business is a business school located at the University of Iowa in Iowa City, Iowa./nThe University of Iowa Tippie College of Business is a large and multifaceted institution, home to over 4,000 students in a variety of programs./nThe campus in Iowa City is home to a wide range of research institutions in areas such as marketing, business development, and investment banking.

Term: Hell or High Water Contract: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A hell or high water contract is one where the obligee agrees to fulfill their end of the contract regardless of the difficulty./nIn lease or financing contracts, this means that the lessor or borrower is obligated to continue making payments even if the lease or financed asset is damaged or destroyed./nA hell or high water contract shifts almost all of the risk of nonperformance or default on to the obligee, and thus can induce lessors or lenders to agree to transactions that would otherwise be too risky for them.

Term: Who Was Herbert A. Simon? Bounded Rationality and AI Theorist
Definition: Herbert A. Simon is widely associated with the theory of bounded rationality./nHis theories challenged classical economic thinking on rational behavior./nHe won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics for his contributions to modern business economics and administrative research.

Term: Herd Instinct: Definition, Stock Market Examples, & How to Avoid
Definition: A herd instinct is a behavior wherein people join groups and follow the actions of others./nHerding occurs in finance when investors follow the crowd instead of their own analysis./nIt has a history of starting large, unfounded market rallies and sell-offs that are often based on a lack of fundamental support to justify either./nThe dotcom bubble of the late 1990s and early 2000s is a prime example of the effects of herd instinct./nPeople can avoid herding by doing their own research, making their own decisions, and taking risks.

Term: Heritage and Stabilization Fund (HSF): Meaning, History, FAQs
Definition: The Heritage and Stabilization Fund is Trinidad and Tobago's sovereign fund, used to maintain the countries' heritage and provide a buffer during economic downturns./nThe fund was created with The Heritage and Stabilization Act, No. 6 of 2007./nThe HSF had a Net Asset Value in June 2022 of $4.7 billion (according to the latest available quarterly report).

Term: Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) is used to determine market competitiveness./nA market with an HHI of less than 1,500 is considered a competitive marketplace, an HHI of 1,500 to 2,500 is moderately concentrated, and an HHI of 2,500 or greater is highly concentrated./nThe primary disadvantage of the HHI stems from the fact that it is such a simple measure that it fails to take into account the complexities of various markets.

Term: Heroes Earned Retirement Opportunities (HERO) Act
Definition: The Heroes Earned Retirement Opportunities (HERO) Act allows military personnel to use combat pay for individual retirement accounts (IRAs)./nCombat pay is tax-free income for military personnel, but general IRA rules require the account holder have taxable income before contributing./nThe HERO Act allows such personnel to get around the requirement that IRA contributions be with earned taxable income.

Term: Herrick Payoff Index: What It is, How It Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: The Herrick Payoff is a tool used to confirm price trends or reversals in derivatives markets using price and volume information to track money flows./nOne advantage of the Herrick Payoff Index is that it can produce signals even in the midst of a trending market./nHowever, because it is forward-looking, the Index can also produce false positives, and so should be used in combination with other technical indicators.

Term: Heston Model: Meaning, Overview, Methodology
Definition: The Heston Model is an options pricing model that utilizes stochastic volatility./nThis means that the model assumes that volatility is arbitrary, in contrast to the Black-Scholes model that holds volatility constant./nThe Heston Model is a type of volatility smile model, which is a graphical representation of several options with identical expiration dates that show increasing volatility as the options become more ITM or OTM.

Term: Situational Leadership (Hersey-Blanchard) Model: How It Works
Definition: The Situational Leadership (Hersey-Blanchard) Model suggests that no leadership style is better than another./nThe model suggests that managers adapt their leadership style to tasks and relationships in the workplace./nThe model’s leadership styles are related directly to employees’ different maturity categories.

Term: Heterodox Economics: Definition, Examples, Vs. Orthodox
Definition: Heterodox economics refers to all the various theories and schools of thought that are outside the mainstream Keynesian and neoclassical approaches./nA wide variety of competing and conflicting economic schools of thought can at any given time be classified as heterodox economics, though their ideas may eventually enter the mainstream./nHeterodox economists advocate theories, assumptions, or methods that may be radically different from or contradict those used in mainstream economics./nHeterodox economics plays an important role in developing new ideas and challenging established schools of economic thought./nHeterodox theories such as the Austrian business cycle theory (ABCT) and Minsky's financial instability hypothesis rose to public prominence during the Great Recession because they provided powerful explanations that mainstream theories didn't.

Term: Heteroscedasticity Definition: Simple Meaning and Types Explained
Definition: In statistics, heteroskedasticity (or heteroscedasticity) happens when the standard errors of a variable, monitored over a specific amount of time, are non-constant./nWith heteroskedasticity, the tell-tale sign upon visual inspection of the residual errors is that they will tend to fan out over time, as depicted in the image above./nHeteroskedasticity is a violation of the assumptions for linear regression modeling, and so it can impact the validity ofeconometric analysisor financial models like CAPM.

Term: Heuristics: Definition, Pros & Cons, and Examples
Definition: Heuristics are mental shortcuts for solving problems in a quick way that delivers a result that is sufficient enough to be useful given time constraints./nInvestors and financial professionals use a heuristic approach to speed up analysis and investment decisions./nHeuristics can lead to poor decision-making based on a limited data set, but the speed of decisions can sometimes make up for the disadvantages./nBehavioral economics has focused on heuristics as one limitation of human beings behaving like rational actors./nAvailability, anchoring, confirmation bias, and the hot hand fallacy are some examples of heuristics people use in their economic lives.

Term: Hidden Value: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: Hidden values are balance sheet items whose true market value may not be reflected in a company's current share price./nAssets like land or equipment depreciated to book value are examples of potential hidden values./nValue investors are keen to identify companies with a cache of hidden values, hoping that its full value will be realized in due course as reflected in its stock price.

Term: Hierarchical Deterministic (HD) Wallet: Meaning in Cryptocurrency
Definition: A hierarchical deterministic wallet is a digital wallet commonly used to store the keys for holders of cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin and Ethereum./nTo prevent hacking these keys must be randomly generated and backed up in the wallet./nHD wallets enable a series of key pairs to be created from one random seed, providing convenience and manageability as well as high-level security.

Term: Hierarchy of GAAP: Meaning, Organization, Requirements
Definition: The GAAP hierarchy is a four-tiered framework for selecting the principles that accountants should use in preparing financial statements of nongovernmental entities./nBecause multiple organizations regulate separate parts of the accounting world, there was a need to identify the most relevant standards for various accounting topics./nThe hierarchy of GAAP identifies which standards and best practices are the most authoritative for a particular instance or problem./nIf no information on the topic is given at the higher levels, the accountant should look to the next level down for relevant pronouncements.

Term: High Close: What It Means, Example, Misuse
Definition: A high close is a stock manipulation tactic in which small trades are made at high prices during the final minutes of trading./nThe use of a high close is especially popular in stocks with low liquidity and a high degree of information asymmetry./nIndicators like candlestick charts can help investors determine if there were any trading manipulations.

Term: High Earners, Not Rich Yet (HENRYs) Definition
Definition: High earners, not rich yet (HENRYs) are people who have high incomes ($250,000 and $500,000) and the potential to be wealthy in the future./nMost of a HENRY's income is allocated to expenses rather than investments and savings./nLuxury brands, such as Louis Vuitton and Tag Heuer, have found HENRYs to be a lucrative market segment and are now incorporating them in their marketing strategies./nHENRYs are labeled the "working rich" as their rich status is largely attributed to their working income, not their accumulated wealth./nHENRYs can move to wealth by reducing debt and increasing savings and investments.

Term: High-Deductible Health Plan (HDHP): Definition, Coverage, and Costs
Definition: A high-deductible health plan is a health insurance plan with a sizable deductible and lower monthly premiums./nOnly HDHPs qualify for tax-advantaged health savings accounts./nAn HDHP is best for younger, healthier people who don’t expect to need health care coverage except in the face of a serious health emergency./nWealthy individuals and families who can afford to pay the high deductible out of pocket and want the benefits of an HSA may benefit from HDHPs./nHDHPs are believed to lower overall health care costs by making people more aware of the cost of medical expenses.

Term: High-Frequency Trading (HFT): What It Is, How It Works, and Example
Definition: HFT is complex algorithmic trading in which large numbers of orders are executed within seconds./nHFT adds liquidity to the markets and eliminates small bid-ask spreads./nHFT is criticized for allowing large companies to gain an upper hand in trading./nAnother complaint is thatthe liquidity produced by this type of trading is momentary—it disappears within seconds, making it impossible for traders to take advantage of it.

Term: High-Low Method Definition
Definition: The high-low method is a simple way to segregate costs with minimal information./nThe simplicity of the approach assumes the variable and fixed costs as constant, which doesn't replicate reality./nOther cost-estimating methods, such as least-squares regression, might provide better results, although this method requires more complex calculations.

Term: High Minus Low (HML): Definition and Uses in Finance
Definition: High Minus Low (HML), also referred to as the value premium, is one of three factors used in the Fama-French three-factor model./nThe Fama-French three-factor model is a system for evaluating stock returns that the economists Eugene Fama and Kenneth French developed./nThis system argues that companies with high book-to-market ratios, also known as value stocks, outperform those with lower book-to-market values, known as growth stocks./nAlong with another factor, called Small Minus Big (SMB), High Minus Low (HML) is used to estimate portfolio managers’ excess returns./nMuch of portfolio performance can be explained by the observed tendency of small stocks and value stocks to outperform large or growth-oriented ones on average.

Term: High-Net-Worth Individual (HNWI): Criteria and Example
Definition: A high-net-worth individual is a person with at least $1 million in liquid financial assets./nNorth America had a record number of high-net-worth individuals at 7.4 million people as of 2022./nAn ultra-high-net-worth individual has a net worth of more than $30 million./nIn 2022, the wealth of ultra-high-net-worth individuals worldwide decreased by about -3.7%.

Term: High Ratio Loan: Meaning, Calculation, Example
Definition: A high-ratio loan is one where the loan's value is large relative to the property value being used as collateral./nA high-ratio loan usually means the loan-to-value (LTV) exceeds 80% of the property's value and may approach 100% or higher./nMortgage loans that have high loan ratios can be quite risky, and carry above-average interest rates.

Term: High-Speed Data Feed: What It is, How It Works
Definition: High-speed data feeds are ultra low-latency data connections that provide real-time information and executions for algorithmic and high-frequency traders./nHigh-frequency traders invest heavily to obtain the fastest networks and data feeds to gain a competitive edge in trading./nThe biggest determinant of latency is the distance that the signal has to travel or the length of the physical cable (usually fiber-optic) that carries data from one point to another./nSince light in a vacuum travels at 186,000 miles per second, an HFT firm with its servers co-located within an exchange would have a lower latency—and hence a trading edge—than a rival firm located even a few miles away.

Term: High Street Bank: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A high street bank is a large retail bank with many branch locations./nThe term high street, which originated and is used in the United Kingdom, describes the main thoroughfare where major business is conducted in cities and towns./nHigh street is the British equivalent of North America's Main Street./nBarclays, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds, and HSBC are popular high street banks.

Term: High-Water Mark: What It Means in Finance, With Examples
Definition: A high-water mark is the highest level in value an investment account or fund has reached./nA high-water mark is often used as a demarcation point in determining performance fees that an investor must pay./nThe purpose is to protect investors from paying a fee for poor performance, and from paying a fee repeatedly every time the fund earns a profit./nWith a high-water mark, the investor pays a fee that only covers the amount the fund earned between the point of entry and its highest level.

Term: What Is a High-Yield Bond Spread? Definition and Use in Investing
Definition: A high-yield bond spread, also known as a credit spread, is the difference in the yield on high-yield bonds and a benchmark bond measure, such as investment-grade or Treasury bonds./nHigh-yield bonds offer higher yields due to default risk. The higher the default risk the higher the interest paid on these bonds./nHigh-yield bond spreads are used to evaluate credit markets, where rising spreads can signal weakening macroeconomic conditions.

Term: High-Yield Bond: Definition, Types, and How to Invest
Definition: High-yield bonds, or junk bonds, are corporate debt securities that pay higher interest rates than investment-grade bonds./nHigh-yield bonds tend to have lower credit ratings of below BBB- from Standard & Poor’s and Fitch, or below Baa3 from Moody’s./nJunk bonds are more likely to default and have higher price volatility.

Term: High-Yield Investment Program (HYIP): Definition and Fraudulence
Definition: A high-yield investment program (HYIP) is a fraudulent investment scheme that promises high returns, often in excess of 100%./nMost HYIPs are Ponzi schemes where the organizers take money from new investors to pay returns to established investors./nHYIPs, often known as "prime bank scams," typically involve the alleged trading or issuance of “prime” bank financial securities./nThey may include references to prime European or prime World Bank instruments./nWarning signs of a HYIP include excessive guaranteed returns, fictitious financial instruments, extreme secrecy, claims of an exclusive opportunity, and inordinate investment complexity.

Term: The Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA): Definition and Provisions
Definition: The Higher Education Act of 1965, or HEA, has failed to gain Congressional reauthorization since 2013 but continues to operate on temporary extensions./nThe HEA provides financial assistance to college students, including subsidized grants and loans to qualified post-secondary school students./nPell Grants and Stafford Loans are among the programs created through the HEA./nThe HEA also directly funds college continuing education programs, school libraries, and teaching resources.

Term: Highly Leveraged Transaction (HLT): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Highly leveraged transactions are financing arrangements extended to companies that are already deeply in debt./nHighly leveraged transactions are undertaken for the purpose of recapitalizing, buying out a company, or even acquiring another company./nHighly leveraged transactions pay the financiers much higher rates of interest to compensate them for the additional risks posed by the large debt load.

Term: Highly Compensated Employee (HCE) Definition and Compensation Threshold
Definition: The 401(k) plan contributions of an employee designated as highly compensated are limited by IRS regulation./nThe IRS wants to ensure that the benefit of pre-tax contributions applies equally to all employees./nIt requires that all 401(k) plans perform an annual nondiscrimination test to determine whether or not all employees are treated equally as far as tax advantages go./nHow much an HCE can contribute to their retirement plan depends on the level of non-HCE participation in the plan.

Term: Highest In, First Out (HIFO) Definition vs LIFO, FIFO
Definition: Highest in, first out (HIFO) is a method of accounting for a firm's inventories wherein the highest cost items are the first to be taken out of stock./nHIFO inventory helps a company decrease their taxable income since it will realize the highest cost of goods sold./nHIFO usage is quite rare and is not recognized by general accounting practices and guidelines such as GAAP or IFRS.

Term: Hindenburg Omen: Definition, 4 Main Criteria, and Example
Definition: The Hindenburg Omen is a technical indicator that was designed to signal the increased probability of a stock market crash./nIt compares the percentage of new 52-week highs and lows to a predetermined reference percentage./nIn practice, the Hindenburg Omen is not always correct, but it may be used with other forms of technical analysis to decide when it's time to sell.

Term: Hindsight Bias: Causes, Examples and FAQ
Definition: Hindsight bias is a psychological phenomenon in which one becomes convinced they accurately predicted an event before it occurred./nIt causes overconfidence in one's ability to predict other future events and may lead to unnecessary risks./nHindsight bias can negatively affect decision-making./nIn investing, hindsight bias may manifest as a sense of frustration or regret at not having acted in advance of an event that moves the market./nOne key to managing hindsight bias involves documenting the decision-making process via a journal (e.g., an investment diary).

Term: Hikkake Pattern: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: The hikkake pattern is a price pattern used by technical analysts and traders hoping to identify a short-term move in the market's direction./nThis pattern has two different setups, one implying a short-term downward movement in price action, and a second setup implying a short-term upward trend in price./nThe hikkake pattern appears to work based on traders' expectations of price moving one way, and then collectively bailing out as price reverses.

Term: Hire Purchase Agreements: Definition, How They Work, Pros and Cons
Definition: Hire purchase is an agreement where the buyer makes a downpayment and pays the balance plus interest in installments./nThese types of agreements are generally used for very expensive goods./nHire purchase agreements are not seen as an extension of credit./nOwnership is not transferred to the purchaser in a hire purchase agreement until all payments are made./nHire purchase agreements usually prove to be more expensive in the long run than purchasing an item outright.

Term: Hiring Freeze: How it Works and its Impact
Definition: A hiring freeze means a business has stopped adding employees for a period of time./nHiring freezes are a cost containment tactic for companies large and small that are suffering financial stress or coping with an economic downturn./nHiring freezes leave vacancies created by layoffs or voluntary departures unfilled./nA hiring freeze often increases workloads of employees, who must take on the job responsibilities that would otherwise have been handled by newly hired workers./nSome hiring freezes allow managers to assign work to freelancers or to add part-time or temporary help, while barring the hiring of permanent, full-time employees.

Term: Historic Structure: What It is, How It Works, Criteria
Definition: A historic structure is a sub-category of a historic property as designated by the National Register of Historic Places./nThere are currently more than 2,600 national historic landmarks in the United States./nHistoric structures can include bridges, mines, canals, ships, and highways but the official designation distinguishes a structure as being distinct from a human shelter./nHistoric structures can be listed as historic property with the National Park Service but must meet at least one of four key National Register criteria./nThe intent of these criteria is to ensure that structures that have some kind of cultural and historical relevance are preserved.

Term: How a Histogram Works to Display Data
Definition: A histogram is a bar graph-like representation of data that buckets a range of classes into columns along the horizontal x-axis./nThe vertical y-axis represents the number count or percentage of occurrences in the data for each column/nColumns can be used to visualize patterns of data distributions./nIn trading, the MACD histogram is used by technical analysts to indicate changes in momentum./nThe MACD histogram columns can give earlier buy and sell signals than the accompanying MACD and signal lines.

Term: Historic Pricing: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: Historic pricing is a method for calculating an investment's net asset value (NAV) based on changes from its previous valuation./nInvestors using historic pricing can accurately compute the total number of shares or units that a certain dollar amount will buy, but runs the risk the last valuation will be stale./nForward pricing of NAV is used more frequently than historic pricing.

Term: Historical Cost: Definition, Principle, and How It Works
Definition: Most long-term assets are recorded at their historical cost on a company's balance sheet./nHistorical cost is one of the basic accounting principles laid out under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP)./nHistorical cost is in line with conservative accounting because it prevents overstating the value of an asset./nHighly liquid assets can be recorded at fair market value and impaired assets may be written down to fair market value.

Term: Historical Returns: Definition, Uses, and How It's Calculated
Definition: Historical returns are often associated with the past performance of a security or index, such as the S&P 500./nInvestors study historical return datawhen trying to forecast future returns or to estimate how a security might react in a situation./nCalculating the historical return is done by subtracting the most recent price from the oldest price and divide the result by the oldest price.

Term: Hit the Bid: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: "Hit the bid" means that a trader sells at the prevailing bid price in a market./nThe bid is the highest price that a buyer is willing to pay for a security./nOne will hit the bid if they are willing to sell at the best bid price using a market order.

Term: HM Revenue & Customs: Tax Authority of the United Kingdom
Definition: HMRC is the national taxing authority of the U.K./nHMRC administers certain benefits and tax credit payments to U.K. residents./nIn 2005, HMRC was formed with the merger of Inland Revenue and the Board of Customs and Excise.

Term: Hoarding: Definition, How It Works with Commodities, and Examples
Definition: Hoarding is the purchase of large quantities of a commodity by a speculator with the intent of benefiting from future price increases./nIt is possible for hoarding to create a cycle of speculation, self-fulfilling prophecies, and inflation./nLaws are often passed against certain types of hoarding to prevent tragedies and reduce economic instability./nIn the long run, investing in stocks has outperformed hoarding commodities.

Term: Hobby Loss: What it is, How it Works, Avoiding it
Definition: A hobby loss refers to any loss incurred while a taxpayer conducts business that the IRS considers a hobby./nThe IRS defines a hobby as any activity undertaken for pleasure rather than for profit./nIncome derived from all sources, including hobbies, must be reported to the IRS./nPrior to 2018, taxpayers were able to deduct some losses stemming from the activity if they didn't exceed the gross income for the activity./nThe Tax Cuts and Jobs Act eliminated all itemized miscellaneous deductions between the 2018 and 2025 tax years.

Term: Hockey Stick Chart: Overview and Examples in Investing
Definition: A hockey stick chart is a chart characterized by a sharp increase after a relatively flat and quiet period./nIt is generally observed in scientific research measuring medical results or environmental studies. In cases of business sales, a hockey stick chart is represented by a sudden and dramatic increase in sales./nIt is important to analyze whether the sudden increase is a permanent state of affairs or an aberration.

Term: HODL: The Cryptocurrency Strategy of "Hold on for Dear Life" Explained
Definition: HODL is a crypto slang term meaning to buy-and-hold indefinitely./nIt implies not selling when markets go down or become volatile./nSometimes, it is said to mean "hold on for dear life."/nHODL originated from a typo of "holding" as "hodling" in a 2013 online post./nToday, it is a core tenet of many Bitcoin and crypto believers.

Term: What Is a Hold Recommendation on a Stock?
Definition: A hold recommendation means that the analyst making it doesn't see the stock in question outperforming or underperforming comparable stocks in the near term./nA hold is sometimes considered damning with faint praise, but stocks that are hold can still perform long-term./nA stock can have conflicting recommendations, so investors need to dig into the details before making a decision one way or another.

Term: Hodrick-Prescott (HP) Filter: Why You Should Not Use It
Definition: The Hodrick-Prescott filter refers to a data-smoothing technique used primarily in macroeconomics./nIt is commonly applied during analysis to remove short-term fluctuations associated with the business cycle./nIn practice, it is used to smooth and detrend the Conference Board's Help Wanted Index so it can be benchmarked against the Bureau of Labor Statistic's JOLTS, which measures job vacancies in the U.S.

Term: Holacracy Meaning, Origins, How It Works
Definition: Holacracy is a system a system of self-management where leadership roles are not subject to a traditional hierarchy of command./nInstead of having a static job description, individuals in a holacracy assume multiple roles, each associated with a purpose, domain, and accountabilities./nIndividuals in a holacracy are given broad authority to make decisions within their role, so long as they do not break any prior rule in doing so./nAny problems that arise within the organization can be raised in periodic governance meetings.

Term: Hold Harmless Clause: Definition, How It's Used, and Examples
Definition: A hold harmless clause is used to protect the service provider in a contract from being held liable for damages or losses sustained by the party using those services./nBy signing the agreement, the second party accepts responsibility for certain risks involved in contracting for a service from the first party./nThese agreements are commonly found in business sectors where there is a significant risk of loss or injury, such as sports or real estate./nA unilateral hold harmless clause protects one party to a contract. A reciprocal hold harmless clause protects both parties./nSuch agreements can be disregarded if they are nebulous in language, overly broad in scope, or believed to be fraudulent.

Term: Holdco, or Holding Company, Examples and Overview
Definition: Holdco is an abbreviation for "holding company," which is a firm that exercises control over other investments, such as stocks, bonds, other firms, and anything that has value./nA holdco earns money by collecting the dividends from the shares of firms in which it owns a controlling interest./nA holdco can be both less expensive and more legally complicated than a merger or consolidation.

Term: Holding Company: What It Is, Advantages and Disadvantages
Definition: A holding company is a type of financial organization that owns a controlling interest in other companies, which are called subsidiaries./nThe parent corporation can control the subsidiary’s policies and oversee management decisions but doesn’t run day-to-day operations./nHolding companies are protected from losses accrued by subsidiaries—so if a subsidiary goes bankrupt, its creditors can’t go after the holding company.

Term: Holder of Record: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A holder of record is the person who is the registered owner of a security and who has the rights, benefits, and responsibilities of ownership./nFor a stock, the holder of record typically has shareholder voting rights and receives dividend payouts, if there are any./nFor a bond, the holder of record owns the bond and receives the principal and interest payments./nHolders of record may be recorded in a register of shareholders or similar type of ledger.

Term: Holding Company Depository Receipt (HOLDR): Overview
Definition: A holding company depository receipt (HOLDR) was a diversified investment product offered by Merrill Lynch that gave investors access to several stocks in a certain industry or sector via a single holding./nUnlike an ETF, each HOLDR represented individual ownership in the stocks underlying the HOLDR, with the value of the HOLDR fluctuating along with the changes in the value of the underlying stocks./nHOLDRs no longer trade and the last of them were either liquidated or effectively converted into ETFs in 2011.

Term: What Are Holding Costs? Definition, How They Work, and Example
Definition: Holding costs are costs associated with storing unsold inventory./nA firm’s holding costs include storage space, labor, and insurance, as well as the price of damaged or spoiled goods./nMinimizing inventory costs is an important supply-chain management strategy./nStrategies to avoid holding costs include quick payment collection and calculating accurate reorder points.

Term: What Is a Holding Period (Investments), and How Is It Calculated?
Definition: A holding period is the amount of time the investment is held by an investor, or the period between the purchase and sale of a security./nHolding period is calculated starting on the day after the security's acquisition and continuing until the day of its disposal or sale, the holding period determines tax implications./nHolding period return is the total return received from holding an asset or portfolio of assets over a specified period of time, generally expressed as a percentage./nHolding period differences can result in differential tax treatment on an investment.

Term: Holding Period Return/Yield: Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: Holding period return (or yield) is the total return earned on an investment during the time that it has been held./nA holding period is the amount of time the investment is held by an investor, or the period between the purchase and sale of a security./nHolding period return is useful for making like comparisons between returns on investments purchased at different periods in time.

Term: Holding the Market: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: "Holding the market" refers to an illegal trading practice that attempts to prop up the price of a security after negative news has been released that would otherwise cause a drop in its price./nIn certain instances, where regulation calls for market makers or specialists to add liquidity to markets with little depth, this practice may be allowed./nHolding the market is hard to pull off these days because any one person would have to have very deep pockets to make a significant impact on a security's price./nThe practice of owning and holding a broad market index is also referred to as holding the market.

Term: Holdover Tenant: Definition and Legal Rights
Definition: A holdover tenant is a tenant who continues to pay rent, even after the lease has expired. The landlord must also agree, or else eviction proceedings may occur./nHoldover tenancy exists in a gray area between a full rental contract and trespassing. Even a simple one-sentence agreement offers more protection to all parties and should be considered./nThis issue is often negated by the month-to-month rental clause that's in most tenancy agreements.

Term: Holdings: Definition in Investing and Their Role in Diversity
Definition: Holdings are the contents of an investment portfolio held by an individual or an organization./nPortfolio holdings encompass a wide range of investment products, including stocks, bonds, mutual funds, options, futures, and ETFs./nThe number and types of holdings within a portfolio contribute to the degree of its diversification./nDiversification is a risk management strategy that mixes a wide variety of investments within a portfolio.

Term: Holdovers: What They are, How They Work, FAQs
Definition: Holdovers are transactions that have not yet been processed by banks./nThe most common example is that of a check that does not get deposited until the next business day after it was received too late in the day./nHoldovers can cause a phenomenon known as holdover float, during which money temporarily exists in two accounts simultaneously./nHowever, this duplication is typically quickly corrected by the banks once the associated checks have been processed./nHoldovers can lead to illegal or fraudulent use of bad checks, such as floating checks and kiting.

Term: Hollowing Out: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: Hollowing out refers to the disappearance of middle-class manufacturing jobs and spending power as socioeconomic stratification intensifies./nThis leads to an increase in working-class and lower-class households along with a growing concentration of wealth among the very wealthy./nEconomists have blamed this phenomenon on several concurrent factors, including outsourcing jobs, labor-saving technologies, and demographic changes.

Term: Hollywood Stock Exchange (HSX): Meaning, Pros And Cons, Example
Definition: The Hollywood Stock Exchange (HSX) is an entertainment "stock market" where people can buy and sell virtual shares of celebrities and movies with a currency called the Hollywood Dollar®./nShare values rise or fall based on the success of the underlying film or celebrity in the entertainment market. Prices can soar with a blockbuster opening at the box office and plummet with a bomb no one went to see./nFounded in 1996, the New York City-based brokerage firm Cantor Fitzgerald purchased the HSX in 2010./nIt is now headquartered in Los Angeles, California.

Term: Holographic Will: Definition and State Requirements
Definition: Holographic wills can be alternatives to wills that lawyers create./nHolographic wills do not require notarization or witnesses./nThis type of will can lead to problems in probate court.

Term: Home: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: Legally, a home is a person's permanent primary residence—even if they aren't currently living there./nA physical location is still legally considered a home if there is an intention to return and the resident has not claimed someplace else as their legal place of permanent or principal residence./nA home can determine everything from the taxes one pays to one's citizenship status to the laws one follows.

Term: Home Affordable Modification Program: Meaning, Overview, FAQ
Definition: The Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) was a federal program introduced in 2009 to help struggling homeowners avoid foreclosure./nThe HAMP allowed homeowners to reduce their mortgage principal and/or interest rates, temporarily postpone payments, or get loan extensions./nThe program expired at the end of 2016 and has not been renewed.

Term: Home Affordable Refinance Program (HARP) Overview
Definition: The Home Affordable Refinance Program (HARP) was a program offered by the Federal Housing Finance Agency to homeowners who own homes that are worth less than the outstanding balance on the loan./nThe program has since ended, but it was intended to provide relief after the financial crisis of 2008./nWhile HARP ended in December 2018, there are still options for borrowers who are underwater on their mortgages.

Term: Home Banking Defnition, Different Types, Pros and Cons
Definition: Home banking is the practice of conducting banking transactions from home rather than at branch locations/nHome banking includes mobile banking, web banking, banking over the telephone, and banking by mail./nSaving time and reducing physical risks are the main benefits of home banking./nHowever, home banking can also expose users to cybersecurity risks.

Term: Home Bias: What it is, How it Works, Special Considerations
Definition: Home bias is an investor's preference to invest primarily in domestic equities rather than diversifying with foreign investments./nTransaction costs, inaccessibility, and unfamiliarity with foreign equities were reasons for investors to have a home bias./nSome generations may be more likely to exhibit home bias over others./nHome bias affects individual investors as well as experienced and professional investors, such as mutual fund managers./nInvesting in foreign equities is now easier because of the availability of information as well as investment vehicles like ETFs.

Term: Home Buyers' Plan (HBP): What It is, How It Works
Definition: The Home Buyers' Plan (HBP) is a Canadian government incentive program to aid first-time homebuyers using retirement plan savings./nTo qualify, funds must not exceed the limit and must be withdrawn within 30 days after residing in the home./nFunds borrowed from the retirement plan must be repaid over a seventeen-year period (with no mandatory repayments for the first two years of the loan).

Term: Home Country Bias: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: Home country bias is the tendency for an investor to prefer companies from their own country or region./nSuch investors may overweight their exposure to domestic stocks./nInvesting excessively in domestic stock can create an unbalanced portfolio that has greater risk./nHome country bias can also cause an investor to miss out on international investment opportunities.

Term: Home Equity: What It Is, How It Works, and How You Can Use It
Definition: Home equity is the current market value of your home, minus any liens such as a mortgage./nYou can leverage your home equity by using it to back a home equity loan or a home equity line of credit./nWhen you put a down payment on a house of 20% or more, you'll have immediate equity./nThe amount of your home equity can increase or decrease depending on the home's market value.

Term: Home Equity Conversion Mortgage (HECM): Definition, Eligibility
Definition: Home equity conversion mortgages (HECMs) are reverse mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration (FHA)./nHECMs make up the majority of the reverse mortgage market./nHECM terms are often better than those of proprietary reverse mortgages, but the maximum loan amount is limited, andmortgage insurance premiumsare required.

Term: How a Home Equity Loan Works, Rates, Requirements & Calculator
Definition: A home equity loan, also known as a home equity installment loan or a second mortgage, is a type of consumer debt./nHome equity loans allow homeowners to borrow against the equity in their residence./nHome equity loan amounts are based on the difference between a home’s current market value and the homeowner’s mortgage balance due./nHome equity loans come in two varieties: fixed-rate loans and home equity lines of credit (HELOCs)./nFixed-rate home equity loans provide one lump sum, whereas HELOCs offer borrowers revolving lines of credit.

Term: Home Market Effect: What It Means, How It Works, Implications
Definition: The home market effect says that goods, which have large economies of scale and high transport costs, will tend to be produced in and exported by countries with a large domestic demand./nThe home market effect is part of New Trade Theory and was developed as an explanation for evidence from global trade patterns that seemed to contradict comparative advantage./nStudies have confirmed the occurrence of home market effects and the kind of economic factors that influence them./nBusinesses and investors should consider possible advantages from home market effects on choosing where to locate.

Term: Home Appraisal: What it is, How it Works, FAQ
Definition: A home inspection examines a property's safety and current condition./nA buyer typically arranges and pays for a home inspection and—depending on its findings—may choose to move on to closing, renegotiate the sale price, request repairs, or back out of the deal./nA home inspection is not the same as a home appraisal, which is required and scheduled by a lender to determine the value of a property for which a buyer is seeking a mortgage./nBefore buying a home, you should have it inspected. Waiving an inspection may be a risky decision and one that could prove costly later on.

Term: Home Modification: What It is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: A home modification is any alteration made to a home to meet the needs of people who have different physical abilities./nExamples of home modifications include removing throw rugs to prevent slips and falls or installing grab bars in the bathroom for stability./nWhile in some cases, home modifications might also be considered a home improvement or renovation, home modifications specifically refer to alterations made to a home in order to make it more accessible for people with different physical abilities, including elderly people.

Term: What Is a Home Mortgage? Definition, Qualification, and Types
Definition: A home mortgage is a loan given by a bank, mortgage company, or other financial institution for the purchase of a residence./nA home mortgage will have either a fixed or floating interest rate, and a life span of anywhere from three to 30 years./nThe lender who extends the home mortgage retains the title to the property, which it gives to the borrower when the mortgage is paid off.

Term: Home Office Expense: Meaning, Calculation, Examples
Definition: Expenses you incur in the operation of a business you conduct in your home are deductible on your federal taxes within certain limits./nTo calculate your expenses and deductions, you can either tally up all your costs and calculate the percent of your home dedicated to your business or use simplified method to do the same calculation./nThe rules for deductions changed with the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, so make sure to get information on deductions published in 2018 or later.

Term: Mortgage Interest Deduction: Overview, Examples, FAQ
Definition: The mortgage interest deduction helps homeowners lower the amount of tax owed./nThese deductions are reported on Form 1098 and Schedule A or Schedule E, depending on the type of deduction./nThe Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) of 2017 reduced the maximum mortgage principal eligible for the interest deduction to $750,000 (from $1 million)./nSome homeowners, under legacy clauses, are not subject to the new limits./nMany taxpayers forgo claiming the mortgage interest deduction in favor of the larger standard deduction.

Term: Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA): Protection for Borrowers
Definition: The Home Mortgage Disclosure Act is a law passed in 1975 that mandates mortgage lenders maintain certain records./nThe goal is to create greater transparency and protect borrowers in the residential mortgage market./nData collected under the HMDA allows regulators and others to monitor mortgage borrowing trends and lending for compliance with fair housing and other laws and to direct housing investment and government funding to areas where it is needed.

Term: Home Office: What it is, How it Works, FAQ
Definition: Home offices provide a space to work from home for those that are self-employed or work for an employer./nAn employee working from a home often can manage their work schedule and employers are often open to time flexibility./nTo claim the home office deduction, taxpayers must exclusively and regularly use part of their home or a separate structure on their property as their primary place of business./nEmployees of a company are not eligible to claim the home office deduction.

Term: Home Warranty: Meaning, Qualifications, Costs
Definition: A home warranty is a service contract that, for a set period of time, covers the cost of maintaining household systems or appliances./nHome warranties are most often advised when purchasing an older home for which information is not readily available on the items./nThese warranties are different from homeowners' insurance./nHomeowners' insurance covers the loss of the home and its contents due to fire or certain other natural disasters./nHome warranty coveragecan cost between $432 to $816 a year, and there's a $36 to $68 fee for each item serviced.

Term: Homemade Dividends: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Homemade dividends signify a category of investment income that results from the partial sale of an investor's portfolio./nHomemade dividends are unlike the traditional dividends that a company’s board of directors issues to shareholders./nThe ability of investors to mine homemade dividends has triggered a debate as to whether traditional dividends offer substantial value.

Term: Homeowners Association (HOA) Fee: Meaning, Overview and FAQs
Definition: Homeowners association fees are monthly dues collected by homeowners associations (HOAs) from property owners./nHOA fees are standard for most purchased condominiums, apartments, and planned communities./nSome neighborhoods that consist of single-family homes also have HOA fees./nHOA fees are used to pay for amenities, property maintenance, and repairs./nFees depend on the type of property and services provided, and they generally range from $200 to $300.

Term: What Is Homemade Leverage and How Does It Work?
Definition: Individuals can use homemade leverage to recreate the effects of corporate leverage./nThe tax rate difference between corporations and individuals make replicating corporate leverage difficult, however./nThe Modigliani-Miller theorem states that a company’s capital structure should not affect its stock price because investors can use homemade leverage.

Term: What Is a Homeowners Association (HOA), and How Does It Work?
Definition: A homeowners association (HOA) is an organization that makes and enforces rules and guidelines for a subdivision, planned community, or condominium building./nHOA members are the residents of the subdivision, community, or building./nSome communities require mandatory membership for individuals who purchase property in the zone./nHomeowners associations are run by a board of directors and typically collect monthly or annual fees to pay for common area maintenance and the upkeep of facilities./nHomeowners associations may impose fines on noncompliant homeowners.

Term: Homeowners Protection Act: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The Homeowners Protection Act of 1998, also sometimes referred to as the Private Mortgage Insurance (PMI) Cancellation Act, is a law designed to reduce the unnecessary payment of private mortgage insurance by homeowners who may no longer be required to pay it./nPrivate mortgage insurance can be removed once a borrower pays down enough of the mortgage's principal (usually when their equity reaches 20%) or when their loan-to-value (LTV) ratio reaches 80%./nHowever, before the Homeowners Protection Act, many homeowners had problems canceling their private mortgage insurance./nAccording to the Homeowners Protection Act, private mortgage insurance must be automatically terminated for homeowners who accumulate the required amount of equity in their homes; the act also mandates certain disclosures about private mortgage insurance and simplifies the cancellation process, among other provisions.

Term: Homestead Exemption: Definition and How It Works, With State List
Definition: A homestead exemption reduces homeowners' state property tax obligations./nThe exemption can help protect a home from creditors in the event of a spouse dying or a homeowner declaring bankruptcy./nThe provision provides surviving qualifying spouses with ongoing property tax relief in certain states./nThe exemption only applies to one's primary residence./nMost states have homestead exemptions but the rules and protection limits vary.

Term: What Is Homo Economicus? Definition, Meaning, and Origins
Definition: Homo economicus is a theoretical abstraction that some economists use to describe a rational human being./nIn certain neoclassical economic theories, people are portrayed this way: as ideal decision-makers with complete rationality, perfect access to information, and consistent, self-interested goals./nModern behavioral economists and those who study neuroeconomics, however, have demonstrated that human beings are, in fact, not rational in their decision-making./nThe origins of the homo economicus lie in an essay about the political economy by the English civil servant, philosopher, and political economist John Stuart Mill in 1836./nRationality should dictate that the rational business person should use profits from their business to live a fairly frugal existence but that is not always the case.

Term: Homogenous Expectations: Meaning, Advantages, Criticism
Definition: Homogeneous expectations, in the frame of the modern portfolio theory, assume that all investors expect the same and make identical choices in a given situation./nIt posits that investors are rational actors and are not influenced by anything but the facts of the matter at hand./nCritics have questioned that premise, arguing that people and investors are not always rational and have different perceptions and goals that impact their thought processes.

Term: Homoskedastic: What It Means in Regression Modeling, With Example
Definition: Homoskedasticity occurs when the variance of the error term in a regression model is constant./nIf the variance of the error term is homoskedastic, the model was well-defined. If there is too much variance, the model may not be defined well./nAdding additional predictor variables can help explain the performance of the dependent variable./nOppositely, heteroskedasticity occurs when the variance of the error term is not constant.

Term: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX): Overview
Definition: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited is a publicly traded holding company./nHKEX operates the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, the Hong Kong Futures Exchange, the London Metal Exchange, and four clearing houses./nIt is well-capitalized and one of the world's largest market operators./nIts primary services include listing, trading, clearing, market data, reference prices, and connectivity./nHKEX also serves as a regulating body, overseeing the trading activities of companies listed in Hong Kong and those who participate in trading activities within its venue.

Term: What Is Hong Kong SAR, China? Importance in Finance
Definition: Hong Kong is an Asian financial hub once colonized by the British and is now a semi-autonomous part of China./nSpecial Administrative Regions (SARs) exist as relatively autonomous portions of a country that maintain some degree of political and economic independence./nBecause of their history of independence and colonization, SARs such as Hong Kong may find themselves in conflict with the political authority of China.

Term: Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKG): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange is a stock exchange based in Hong Kong./nThe exchange is owned and operated by Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, a publicly traded holding company./nThe exchange lists equities, debt securities, and other securities./nCompanies based in Hong Kong and mainland China trade on the exchange.

Term: Honorarium: Definition and Tax Treatment
Hook Reversal: What It is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: Hook reversals are short-term candlestick patterns that predict reversals trends' directions./nWhen a candlestick has a higher low and a lower high than the previous session's candlestick, this is a hook reversal./nA hook reversal differs from an engulfing pattern, in that the size difference between the first and second bar's body can be relatively small./nAmong active traders, hook reversal patterns are popular since they occur fairly frequently and are relatively easy to spot.

Term: What Was the Hope Credit? How It Worked and Replacement
Definition: The Hope Credit allowed eligible students to qualify for a maximum $1,800 income tax credit for the first two years of college./nThis credit was a nonrefundable tax credit that can only reduce a taxpayer’s liability to zero; any amount that remains from the credit is automatically forfeited by the taxpayer./nTo qualify, taxpayers were subject to eligibility requirements such as the income thresholds of the household and the enrollment status of the student./nIn 2009, the American Opportunity Tax Credit replaced the Hope credit.

Term: Hope Now Alliance
Definition: Hope Now Alliance was formed in 2007 to help homeowners avert foreclosure./nThe alliance was comprised of homeowner resources that navigate mortgage counseling, unemployment, and money management./nIt also advocated for higher lending standards and more ethical conduct in the mortgage industry./nHope Now Alliance was run out of the Housing Policy Council, a trade organization made up of lenders, services, insurers, and other market participants./nThe organization closed down in 2020 because of the global COVID-19 pandemic.

Term: Horizon Analysis: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Horizon analysis compares the projected discounted returns of a security or investment portfolio’s total returns over several time frames, often referred to as the investment horizon./nTypically, horizon analysis is used to gauge the expected performance of portfolios comprised of fixed income securities (bonds)./nHorizon analysis enables the portfolio manager to evaluate which bonds would perform the best over the planned investment horizon.

Term: Horizontal Analysis: What It Is vs. Vertical Analysis
Definition: Horizontal analysis is used in the review of a company's financial statements over multiple periods./nIt is usually depicted as percentage growth over the same line item in the base year./nHorizontal analysis allows financial statement users to easily spot trends and growth patterns./nHorizontal analysis shows a company's growth and financial position versus competitors./nHorizontal analysis can be manipulated to make the current period look better if specific historical periods of poor performance are chosen as a comparison.

Term: Horizontal Acquisition: What It Is, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A horizontal acquisition occurs when one company takes over or acquires a similar company in the same industry./nThe basic business operations expand rather than change after a horizontal acquisition./nThe two companies in a horizontal acquisition often produce similar products and have similar production schedules./nUnlike a horizontal acquisition, a vertical acquisition involves companies in the same industry with completely different production cycles.

Term: Horizontal Channel: What It Means, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Horizontal channels are trend lines that connect variable pivot highs and lows./nIn a horizontal channel, buying and selling pressure is equal, and the prevailing price direction is sideways./nA horizontal channel provides traders with precise points for entering and exiting trades.

Term: Horizontal Equity: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: Horizontal equity is a principle of income tax collection that argues that everybody earning the same income should be subject to the same rate of taxation./nAs such, horizontal equity discounts deductions, tax credits, incentives, and loopholes that can lower ones effective tax rate even if they have the same annual income as somebody else./nHorizontal equity is favored by some economists because it is considered to be a neutral system of taxation, and thus more fair.

Term: Horizontal Line: Definition, Uses, Example in Technical Analysis
Definition: A horizontal line is commonly used in technical analysis to mark areas of support or resistance./nA horizontal line runs parallel to the x-axis./nIn technical analysis, the horizontal line is typically drawn along a swing high, or a series of them, where each high in the series stopped at a similar level. The same concept applies to swing lows.

Term: What Is Horizontal Integration? Definition and Examples
Definition: Horizontal integration is a business strategy in which one company grows its operations at the same level in an industry./nHorizontal integrations help companies grow in size and revenue, expand into new markets, diversify product offerings, and reduce competition./nDisadvantages of horizontal integration include regulatory scrutiny, the reduction of choices for consumers, less internal flexibility, and the potential to destroy value rather than create it./nA company can horizontally integrate by merging with another company, acquiring another company, or internally expanding its operations./nA contrasting approach to horizontal integration is vertical integration, in which a company acquires a firm operating in the same industry, but at a different stage of the production process.

Term: Horizontal Market: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Horizontal markets are those that engage in broad, diversified, and multi-sector production and consumption./nConglomerates, who operate in several market segments and attract a broad customer base are examples of operating in a horizontal market./nThis can be contrasted with vertical markets, which specialize in a particular product or focus on a particular niche demographic.

Term: Horizontal Merger: Definition, Examples, How It Differs from a Vertical Merger
Definition: Horizontal mergers occur when companies of the same industry combine into one entity./nHorizontal mergers can help companies significantly boost market share, increase their reach, and save lots of money./nThey shouldn’t be confused with vertical mergers, which describe two companies at different stages of the production process combining./nMergers aren’t always good for consumers or investors and often underwhelm.

Term: Horizontal Spread: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: Horizontal spread is a simultaneous long and short derivative position on the same underlying asset and strike price but with a different expiration./nHorizontal (calendar) spreads allow traders to construct a trade that minimizes the effects of time./nFutures spreads using this strategy can focus on expected short-term price fluctuations./nBoth options and futures underlying contracts create a de-facto leveraged position.

Term: Hospital Insurance Trust Fund: What It is, How it Works
Definition: The Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is Part A of Medicare and covers hospital stays, hospices, and skilled nursing facilities./nThe Fund is something that every worker pays into, then benefits from at retirement./nGiven changing demographics and regulations, the trust fund is expected to be depleted by 2031.

Term: Horizontal Well: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A horizontal well is a type of directional drilling technique./nOperators use it to retrieve oil and natural gas in situations in which the shape of the reservoir is abnormal or difficult to access./nIt permits access to subsurface reservoirs that may not be accessible from directly above.

Term: Hospital Revenue Bond: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A hospital revenue bond is a type of municipal bond that finances the construction of new facilities or upgrades for existing hospitals and is secured by the revenue that hospitals receive in the course of their normal operations./nHospital revenue bonds typically command higher yields due to their default risk being higher given their inability to raise revenue through taxes like other municipal bonds./nIncome received from a hospital revenue bond may be exempt from state, local, and federal taxation.

Term: Hostile Bid: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: Hostile bids are takeover offers taken directly to shareholders because management has rejected the offer./nA hostile bid can spark a proxy battle in some cases, where the acquiring company looks to replace the management of the target company./nA friendly bid is the opposite of a hostile bid, where management accepts a takeover offer.

Term: Hostile Takeover Explained: What It Is, How It Works, and Examples
Definition: A hostile takeover occurs when an acquiring company attempts to take over a target company against the wishes of the target company's management./nAn acquiring company can achieve a hostile takeover by going directly to the target company's shareholders or fighting to replace its management./nHostile takeovers may take place if a company believes a target is undervalued or when activist shareholders want changes in a company./nA tender offer and a proxy fight are two methods for achieving a hostile takeover./nTarget companies can use certain defenses, such as the poison pill or a golden parachute, to ward off hostile takeovers.

Term: Hot Hand: What it is, How it Works, Evidence
Definition: The "hot hand" is the notion where people believe that after a string of successes, an individual or entity is more likely to have continued success./nPsychologists believe that the hot hand is a fallacy that stems from the representative heuristic, as identified by behavioral economics./nStill, some research shows that for certain sporting events, the hot hand may be real.

Term: Hostile Takeover Bid: What It Is, Tactics, Comeback
Definition: A tender offer is a direct approach to shareholders to sell their shares to the would-be acquirer at a premium over the current market price./nA proxy fight is a campaign to get shareholder support for the replacement of board members with advocates of the takeover./nA would-be acquirer also can buy shares on the open market.

Term: Hot Issue: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A hot issue is an upcoming IPO that is heavily oversubscribed by the investing public./nIt is commonly associated with companies in glamorous or high-tech industries./nHot issues often attract speculators who anticipate buying and flipping the oversubscribed shares for a short-term gain, often on the very next day following the company’s listing.

Term: Hot IPO: What It Means, How It Works, Examples
Definition: A hot IPO is an initial public offering that garners great interest from the media and demand from investors./nHigher demand leads to sharp price increases in the secondary market, which are generally not sustainable./nCompanies bring in at least one bank to underwrite and handle the pricing, marketing, and decisions about the number of shares and share price range./nThe demand for shares in a hot IPO surpasses the initial supply, which means the price needs to be revised upward./nUnderpriced hot IPOs will likely see their stock price rise after the shares begin trading while the stock price drops for overpriced ones,

Term: What Is 'Hot Money'? Definition and Economic Impact
Definition: Hot money is capital that investors regularly move between economies and financial markets to profit from highest short-term interest rates./nBanks bring hot money into an economy by providing short-term certificates of deposit with higher-than-average rates./nThe Chinese economy is an example of a hot money market that turned cold following investor flight.

Term: Hot Waitress Economic Index: What It Means and How It Works
Definition: The hot waitress economic index is an offensive and dubious economic indicator of a financial recession./nIt states that the higher the number of good-looking servers, the weaker the state of the economy./nThe index was first coined by journalist Hugo Lindgren inNew York Magazine./nThe attractive server index hasn't been vetted by economists.

Term: Hot Wallet: Definition, Types, Examples, and Safety Tips
Definition: A hot wallet is a wallet that is always connected to the internet; they allow you to store, send, and receive tokens./nHot wallets store your private keys that allow you, and only you, to access your cryptocurrency./nBecause hot wallets are connected to the internet, they tend to be somewhat more vulnerable to hacks and theft than cold storage methods.

Term: Hotelling's Theory: Definition, How It Works, and History
Definition: Hotelling's Theory defines the price or yield at which the owner of a nonrenewable resource will extract it and sell it, rather than leave it and wait./nIt bases the relative price on U.S. Treasury bonds or some similar interest-bearing security./nThe rule was devised by American statistician Harold Hotelling.

Term: House Maintenance Requirements: What it is, How it Works
Definition: House maintenance requirements are the standards for minimum margin account equity levels chosen by brokerage firms./nThey must be greater or equal than the 25% level stipulated in Regulation T. Often, they are in the 30% to 50% range./nBrokerage firms will sometimes grant lower house maintenance requirements for their larger or more sophisticated clients, although these figures will always be at or above the 25% minimum./nHouse maintenance requirements can also vary depending on the type of investment, with volatile, less liquid ones likely to require more equity for protection.

Term: House Call: What it Means, How it Works, FAQs
Definition: A house call is a brokerage house demand that an investor restore the minimum required deposit in order to offset losses in the value of assets bought on margin./nBuyers on margin borrow from "the house," or the brokerage, to multiply their gains./nIf the investment tanks, the buyer owes the house.

Term: House Money Effect: Meaning, Examples and FAQs
Definition: The house money effect is a behavioral finance concept whereby people risk more with winnings than they would otherwise./nThe effect can be attributed to the perception that the investor has new money that wasn't theirs./nThere are many examples of this effect, but all show a common lack of rigor./nHouse money effect is not to be confused with a predetermined, mathematically calculated strategy of increasing position size when greater than anticipated gains occur.

Term: House Poor: What It Means, Steps to Avoid It
Definition: A house poor person is anyone whose housing expenses account for an exorbitant percentage of their monthly budget./nIndividuals in this situation are short of cash for discretionary items and tend to have trouble meeting other financial obligations, such as vehicle payments./nHouse poor individuals can consider limiting discretionary expenses, taking on another job, dipping into savings, selling assets, or downsizing in order to ease their financial difficulties.

Term: Understanding the House Price Index (HPI) and How It Is Used
Definition: The House Price Index is a broad measure of the movement of single-family house prices in the United States./nIt is published by the Federal Housing Finance Agency using monthly and quarterly data supplied by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac./nThe HPI is one of many economic indicators that investors use to keep a pulse on broader economic trends and potential shifts in the stock market.

Term: Household Employee: Definition, Examples, and Taxes
Household Expenses: Types, Examples, and How to Compute
Definition: Household expenses represent a per-person breakdown of general living expenses./n“Head of household" status for tax purposes gives you a larger standard deduction and lower tax rates./nHousehold expenses can be largely categorized as home-related, child-related, transportation, and entertainment.

Term: Household Income: What It Is and How to Calculate It
Definition: Household income is the combined gross cash income of all members of a household./nThe Census Bureau defines a household as a group of people living under the same roof whether they're related or not./nHousehold income is used to evaluate the economic health of an area or to compare living conditions between geographic regions./nThe definition of household income may vary based on studies and government agencies/programs./nHousehold income is one of three types of measures of wealth — the other two are family income and per capita income.

Term: Housing Authority Bonds Definition
Definition: Housing authority bonds, or housing bonds, are issued by a state or local government agency to help finance the construction or rehabilitation of affordable rental housing./nState and local governments issue housing bonds to finance the construction or rehabilitation of affordable rental housing. In addition to repaying the bond principal, the state or locality must pay interest on the money it borrows./nLike most municipal bonds, housing authority bonds have historically been viewed as very safe investments.

Term: Housing and Economic Recovery Act (HERA): Overview, History, FAQ
