Definition: The Housing and Economic Recovery Act (HERA) of 2008 was a piece of financial reform legislation passed by Congress in response to the subprime mortgage crisis./nHERA allowed the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) to guarantee up to $300 billion in new 30-year fixed-rate mortgages for subprime borrowers./nHERA is composed of several sub-statutes, including the Housing Assistance Tax Act, the FHA Modernization Act, and the Secure and Fair Enforcement for Mortgage Licensing Act./nHERA established minimum down payment standards for FHA loans.

Term: Housing Bonds
Definition: Housing bonds are debt securities, a variation of municipal revenue bonds, issued by state or local governments to raise money for affordable housing development projects./nHousing bonds provide the government with cheap financing and the lender, especially those in the upper tax brackets, with tax advantages./nMortgages provided through housing bonds are restricted to first-time homebuyers who earn no more than the area median income and the price of a home purchased is limited to 90% of the average area purchase price.

Term: Housing Expense Ratio: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The housing expense ratio is the percentage of your gross income that goes toward housing expenses./nHousing expenses can include the mortgage payment as well as insurance, property taxes, and other costs./nLenders use the housing expense ratio to evaluate your credit profile for a mortgage loan./nGenerally, lenders like your housing expense ratio to be below 28%.

Term: What Is a Housing Bubble?
Definition: A housing bubble is a sustained but temporary condition of over-valued prices and rampant speculation in housing markets./nThe U.S. experienced a major housing bubble in the 2000s caused by money inflows to housing markets and loose lending conditions./nHomeowners may force foreclosure once the value of the home plummets and the mortgage exceeds the equity.

Term: NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market index: Meaning, How it Works
Definition: The NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index is a widely watched gauge of sentiment among U.S. builders of single-family homes./nParticipating builders rate current single-family sales, sales prospects over the next six months, and the traffic of prospective buyers./nHMI readings above 50 reflect a generally favorable market view and outlook in the industry./nThe three component indices of HMI are seasonally adjusted and weighted to achieve the highest correlation with housing starts over the next six months, based on historical data.

Term: Housing Starts: An Important Metric for Real Estate Investors
Definition: Housing starts are a measure of new residential construction, and are considered a key economic indicator./nA housing start is counted as soon as groundbreaking begins, and each unit in a multi-family housing project is treated as a separate housing start./nSeasonally adjusted data for the latest month is compared to figures from previous months./nMonthly changes can be volatile, but the longer-term trend tracks a crucial sector for consumer spending and the broader economy.

Term: What Is a Housing Unit? Definition, Recordation, and Statistics
Definition: A housing unit is one unit within a larger structure, such as a house, apartment, mobile home, or group of rooms, where a person or family eat, live, and sleep./nHousing units are separate living quarters where the occupants live separately from other residents of the structure./nResidential construction is the largest component of change in housing units.

Term: Howey Test Definition: What It Means and Implications for Cryptocurrency
Definition: The Howey Test determines what qualifies as an "investment contract," subjecting the asset to U.S. securities laws./nAn investment contract exists if there is an "investment of money in a common enterprise with a reasonable expectation of profits to be derived from the efforts of others."/nThe Howey Test is important for blockchain and digital currency projects conducting fundraising efforts with investors and project backers./nCertain cryptocurrencies and initial coin offerings (ICOs) may be found to meet the definition of an "investment contract" under the Howey Test.

Term: Hub and Spoke Structure: What it Means in Portfolio Management
Definition: A hub and spoke structure, in investments, utilizes multiple portfolio managers or sub-funds, known as "spokes" or "feeders," that invest in a "hub," or "master fund."/nThis structure is often used by investment companies to reduce costs and maintain efficiency./nEach spoke is individually managed by particular fund managers, while the hub is managed by one portfolio manager utilizing an overarching investment strategy.

Term: Hsa Custodian: What It Is, Cost, Example
Definition: An HSA custodian refers to any bank, credit union, insurance company, brokerage, or other approved organizations that offer HSAs./nThey may also be called HSA administrators./nHSAs were established by the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003.

Term: Hubbert Curve: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: The Hubbert curve is a method for predicting the production rate of any finite resource./nIt was first developed in 1956 to explain production rates of fossil fuels.﻿﻿/nToday, the Hubbert curve is used across various resource sectors and has informed debate around the rate of change in global oil production rates.

Term: Hubbert's Peak Theory: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: Hubbert's peak theory predicts the rise, peak, and decline of fossil fuel production./nWith revolutions in new technology, it will be longer than originally predicted before oil reserves run out./nIn the long run, fossil fuel resources are finite, so Hubbert's peak theory applies, but it does not appear to be a threat in the near term.

Term: Hubris in Investing: Examples and FAQs, Bottom Line
Definition: Hubris is an excess of confidence or arrogance in oneself that often leads to a lack of self-awareness and harmful or self-defeating behaviors./nHubris is often found in very successful individuals, due to the nature of their positions./nWhen hubris becomes all-consuming, it frequently leads to an individual's downfall./nOvercoming hubris is possible with practical techniques and increased self-awareness./nHumility is an important tool to combat hubris and should be evaluated/implemented frequently.

Term: What Is a HUD-1 Form and How Is It Used?
Definition: The HUD-1 form, listing all closing costs, is given to all parties involved in reverse mortgage and mortgage refinance transactions./nSince late 2015, a different form, the Closing Disclosure, is prepared for the parties involved in all other real estate transactions./nBoth must be reviewed by the borrower before the closing in order to prevent errors or surprises.

Term: Hungarian Forint (HUF): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The Hungarian forint is the national currency of Hungary./nIntroduced in 1946, the forint is issued and maintained by Magyar Nemzeti Bank the country's central bank./nIt is represented by the symbol Ft and the currency code HUF./nBanknotes range in value from Ft500 and Ft20,000 while coins are minted between values of Ft5 to Ft200./nWhile it is an EU member, Hungary hasn't adopted the euro.

Term: Hulbert Rating
Definition: A Hulbert rating is an investment newsletter score created by financial advisor Mark Hulbert to track the performance of investment newsletters over time./nThe Hulbert rating tracks the buy and sell advice of investment newsletters and evaluates performance using various metrics to arrive at a risk-adjusted performance score./nFor nearly 36 years, Hulbert published newsletter rating scores in theHulbert Financial Digest, which was acquired by MarketWatch/Dow Jones in April 2002./nIn 2016, MarketWatch/Dow Jones ceased publishing theHulbert Financial Digest, at which time Mark Hulbert began publishing newsletter ratings through the company Hulbert Ratings, LLC./nHulbert publishes a newsletter honor roll that lists and grades investment newsletters that have outperformed in both up and down markets.

Term: Hull-White Model: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The Hull-White model is an interest rate derivatives pricing model./nThis model makes the assumption that very short-term rates are normally distributed and revert to the mean./nThe Hull-White model calculates the price of a derivative security as a function of the entire yield curve rather than a single rate.

Term: Human Capital Definition: Types, Examples, and Relationship to the Economy
Definition: Human capital is an intangible asset not listed on a company's balance sheet./nHuman capital is said to include qualities like an employee's experience and skills./nSince all labor is not considered equal, employers can improve human capital by investing in the training, education, and benefits of their employees./nHuman capital is perceived to have a relationship with economic growth, productivity, and profitability./nLike any other asset, human capital has the ability to depreciate through long periods of unemployment, and the inability to keep up with technology and innovation.

Term: Human-Life Approach: Definition, Value Calculation, Example
Definition: The human-life approach is a method of calculating how much life insurance is needed for a family that is based upon their financial loss when the insured person in the family passes away./nThere are a number of factors taken into consideration when calculating the human-life approach, such as the age of the insured, gender, planned retirement age, annual wages, benefits, and so on./nThe human-life approach is primarily applicable to families with working individuals and stands in contrast to the needs approach./nIt is important to replace all of the income lost when an employed family member dies when using the human-life approach./nWhen calculating a life insurance policy for the human-life approach, there are many factors to consider to ensure that a family will not be left in financial distress, such as expected future earnings and length of time the money is needed.

Term: What Is the Human Development Index (HDI)?
Definition: The Human Development Index (HDI) is a measurement system used by the United Nations to evaluate the level of individual human development in each country./nIt was introduced by the U.N. in 1990./nThe HDI was created to emphasize that people and their capabilities should be the ultimate criteria for assessing the development of a country, not economic growth alone./nThe HDI uses components such as average annual income and educational expectations to rank and compare countries./nThe HDI has been criticized by social advocates for not representing a broad-enough measure of quality of life and by economists for providing little additional useful information beyond simpler measures of the economic standard of living.

Term: Human Resources (HR): Meaning and Responsibilities
Definition: Human resources (HR) is the division of a business responsible for finding, recruiting, screening, and training job applicants./nHR departments also handle employee compensation, benefits, and terminations./nHuman resource management (HRM) strategies focus on actively advancing and improving an organization's workforce with the long-term goal of improving the organization itself./nHR departments must keep up to date with laws that can affect the company and its employees./nMany companies have moved traditional HR administrative duties such as payroll and benefits to outside vendors.

Term: Human Resource Planning (HRP) Meaning, Process, and Examples
Definition: Human resource planning (HRP) is a strategy used by a company to maintain a steady stream of skilled employees while avoiding employee shortages or surpluses./nHaving a good HRP strategy in place can mean productivity and profitability for a company./nThere are four general steps in the HRP process: identifying the current supply of employees, determining the future of the workforce, balancing between labor supply and demand, and developing plans that support the company's goals.

Term: Humped Yield Curve: What it Means, How it Works, Types
Definition: A humped yield curve occurs when medium-term interest rates are higher than both short- and long-term rates./nA humped curve is uncommon, but may form as the result of a negative butterfly, or a non-parallel shift in the yield curve where long and short-term yields fall more than intermediate one./nMost often yield curves feature the lowest rates in the short-term, steadily rising over time; while an inverted yield curve describes the opposite. A humped curve is instead bell-shaped.

Term: What Is CWT (Hundredweight) and How Do You Calculate It?
Definition: A hundredweight (abbreviated as CWT) is a standard unit of weight or mass used in certain commodities markets. It also may be used to price smaller shipments of goods./nIn North America, a hundredweight is equal to 100 pounds; in the United Kingdom, a hundredweight is 112 pounds. These may be referred to as a "short" or a "long" hundredweight./nThe hundredweight was originally introduced as a standard unit of measurement to simplify the trading of certain goods between countries./nThe use of the hundredweight as a measurement has declined in recent years in favor of the metric system./nSteel, cattle, oil, seeds, and grains are examples of products measured using the hundredweight.

Term: Hurdle Rate: What It Is and How Businesses and Investors Use It
Definition: A hurdle rate is the minimum rate of return required on a project or investment./nHurdle rates give companies clarity about whether they should pursue a specific project./nGenerally, the higher the risk, the higher the hurdle rate./nInvestors use a hurdle rate in a discounted cash flow analysis to determine an investment's value and assess its worth./nCompanies sometimes use their weighted average cost of capital (WACC) as the hurdle rate./nPrivate equity and hedge funds also use a hurdle rate, which measures when general partners (GPs) are entitled to performance fees.

Term: Hung Convertibles
Definition: Convertible securities are securities that can be repaid in money or the stock of the issuing company, with certain conditions./nHung convertibles are convertible securities where the share price of the underlying security is well below the conversion price, making it unlikely that the securities will be converted into common stock./nDue to their limited prospects for conversion, hung convertibles, also known as busted convertibles, trade more like debt instruments./nMost companies prefer not to have hung convertibles, since these obligations must be repaid in money./nTo solve the issue of a hung convertible, a company would need to improve its fundamentals to spur the common stock high enough to reach the conversion price.

Term: Hybrid Annuity: What It Is, How It Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: A hybrid annuity is a retirement income investment that allows investors to divide their savings between fixed- and variable-rate products./nThey are meant to offer both growth and income, creating a portfolio of both conservative and riskier assets, however, most annuities already offer those perks./nLike other annuities, the goal is to create a steady stream of income during retirement and can begin paying out immediately or be deferred with fixed or flexible premiums./nA hybrid annuity consists of a variable component that allows for investment capital to be allocated to a mutual fund sub-account for growth and a fixed component that guarantees a set amount of payments after retirement./nCritics of hybrid annuities argue that they are over-complicated, expensive, and over-designed and that most annuities provide some sort of growth and income components.

Term: What Is Hurricane Insurance? Definition, Coverage, and Costs
Definition: There is no such thing as hurricane insurance, strictly speaking./nCoverage for the damage-inducing waters or winds that hurricanes cause is provided by flood insurance or windstorm insurance./nMany homeowners insurance policies in coastal states impose a hurricane deductible, an extra out-of-pocket amount the policyholder incurs before coverage kicks in.

Term: Hybrid ARM: What it Means and how it Works
Definition: Hybrid adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs) offer an initial fixed rate for a set number of years, after which the interest rate adjusts annually./nWhen hybrid ARMs become variable, they adjust on a regular basis, typically each year./nHomeowners may benefit from lower mortgage payments during the initial period but may lose out if rates reset higher after the fixed period ends./nA popular hybrid ARM is the 5/1, which has a fixed initial five-year term followed by annual adjustments with a variable rate.

Term: Hybrid Fund: Meaning and Examples of Mixed Asset Class Funds
Definition: A hybrid fund is a classification of a mutual fund or ETF that invests in different types of assets or asset classes to produce a diversified portfolio./nBalanced funds, which hold typically 60% stocks and 40% bonds are a common example of a hybrid fund./nBlended funds, which mix growth and value stocks, are another hybrid fund example.

Term: Hydraulic Fracturing: Meaning, History, Controversy
Definition: Hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, is a way to extract oil and gas reserves trapped deep underground in sedimentary rock formations./nFracking utilizes highly pressurized liquids that are forced into the rock formations, causing cracks and fissures to appear./nThe oil released from these cracks and fissures is then brought to the surface for refining./nFracking remains a controversial method of oil extraction due to environmental concerns and the potential for water table contamination or induced earthquakes.

Term: Hydrocarbons: Definition, Companies, Types, and Uses
Definition: Hydrocarbons are chemical compounds that are utilized as the basis of the vast majority of global energy production./nA variety of complex technologies and techniques have been developed for extracting hydrocarbons from deep within the earth./nSome of the world's largest companies are hydrocarbon companies, primarily oil and gas companies./nThe use of hydrocarbons as an energy source has negatively impacted the world's climate in a significant way, resulting in climate change./nBecause of the serious environmental cost of using hydrocarbons as a primary source of energy, attempts to move away from them towards alternative energy sources, such as solar, nuclear, wind, and geothermal power have increased significantly.

Term: Hyperledger: Open-Source Blockchain Framework and Standards
Definition: Hyperledger is an open-source community focused on developing a suite of stable frameworks, tools, and libraries for permissioned, enterprise-grade blockchain deployments./nIt is a global collaboration, hosted by The Linux Foundation, and includes member organizations that are leaders in finance, banking, Internet of Things, supply chains, manufacturing, and technology./nSeveral sub-projects exist, including Hyperledger Fabric, Sawtooth, Composer, and Cello./nHyperledger varies from Bitcoin as it is not a cryptocurrency but instead used to develop frameworks and tools./nHyperledger uses a consensus layer, smart contract layer, communication layer, and API.

Term: Hyperdeflation: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: Hyperdeflation refers to extremely large decreases in the general prices of goods in an economy—or, correspondingly large increases in a money's purchasing power./nHyperdeflation is very rare, with perhaps the only example being Bitcoin's quick and meteoric rise in price in a short span of time./nHyperinflation is the opposite theoretical concept and is rare, but there have been several cases where the prices of goods have increased rapidly as the value of the currency plummets.

Term: What Is Hyperinflation? Causes, Effects, Examples, and How to Prepare
Definition: Hyperinflation refers to rapid and unrestrained price increases in an economy, typically at rates exceeding 50% each month over time./nHyperinflation can occur in circumstances affecting the underlying production economy, in conjunction with a central bank printing excessive money./nHyperinflation can cause a surge in prices for essential goods—such as food and fuel—as demand outpaces supply./nWhile hyperinflation scenarios are typically rare, they can spiral out of control once they begin.

Term: Hyperledger Burrow: What It Was and How It Worked
Definition: Hyperledger Burrow was a framework that could be used to execute smart contracts inpermissioned blockchains./nHyperledger Burrow was built around a Byzantine Fault Tolerant consensus algorithm. It attempted to allow blockchains to scale up for commercial applications./nHyperledger Burrow was conceived as ErisDB by Monax in 2014. It was part of the Hyperledger family of blockchain projects but was sunsetted in May 2022.

Term: Hyperledger Composer: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: Hyperledger composer is a business-oriented set of tools for creating enterprise blockchain applications, under the umbrella of the Hyperledger project./nComposer was meant to facilitate creation of open-source blockchain application that fostered collaboration between within organizations and business networks.﻿﻿/nWork on composer was halted in summer 2019, and is now part of the more comprehensive Hyperledger Fabric platform.﻿﻿

Term: Hyperledger Explorer: What It is, How It Works
Definition: Hyperledger Explorer is a user-friendly Web application tool used to view or invoke transactions, digital wallets, and other information stored in a Hyperledger blockchain deployment./nThe explorer is a useful tool in finding and understanding otherwise machine-readable data stored as encrypted ledger entries./nIn addition to basic blockchain explorer functionality, the tool provides enterprise-level visualizations that can help decision makers through intuitive graphs, charts, and tables.

Term: Hyperledger Fabric: Definition, Example, Risks and 2.0 Version
Definition: Hyperledger is an enterprise-grade, open-source distributed ledger framework launched by the Linux Foundation in December 2016./nFabric is a highly-modular, decentralized ledger technology (DLT) platform that was designed by IBM for industrial enterprise use./nBecause Hyperledger Fabric is private and requires permission to access, businesses can segregate information (like prices), plus transactions can be sped up because the number of nodes on the network is reduced./nFabric 2.0 was released in January 2020. The main features of this version are faster transactions, updated smart contract technology, and streamlined data sharing.

Term: Hyperledger Iroha: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: Hyperledger Iroha is a business blockchain framework designed for infrastructure projects that need distributed ledger technology./nIroha's platform can be used to build an identity management system such as national IDs./nSoftware apps can also be developed for the unbanked, allowing access to financial services, money transfers, and to buy goods from merchants./nHyperledger Iroha can integrate with Linux, macOS, and Windows platforms.

Term: Hyperledger Sawtooth: What It is, How It Works
Definition: Hyperledger Sawtooth is an open source enterprise blockchain-as-a-service platform that can run customized smart contracts without needing to know the underlying design of the core system./nHyperledger is an umbrella blockchain development group sponsored by organizations such as the Linux Project, IBM, Intel, and SAP./nHyperledger Sawtooth supports a variety of consensus algorithms, including Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) and Proof of Elapsed Time (PoET)

Term: What Is a Hypermarket? Definition, Advantages, and Example
Definition: A hypermarket is a retail store that combines a department store and a grocery supermarket./nThe idea behind hypermarkets is to provide consumers with all the goods they require under one roof./nBig box retailers sell high volumes of merchandise, which in most cases affords them greater buying power compared with retailers who sell goods in smaller quantities./nThe presence of a hypermarket can mean discount prices with profit margins that local competitors might not be able to sustain.

Term: HyperText Markup Language (HTML): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is the basic scripting language used by web browsers to render pages on the World Wide Web./nHyperText allows a user to click a link and be redirected to a new page referenced by that link./nEarly versions of HTML were static (Web 1.0), while newer iterations feature a great deal of dynamic flexibility (Web 2.0, 3.0)./nMarkup is the text that appears between two pointed brackets (i.e., between “<” and “>”), and content is everything else.

Term: Hypothecation: Definition and How It Works, With Examples
Definition: Hypothecation occurs when an asset is pledged as collateral to secure a loan. The owner of the asset does not give up title, possession, or ownership rights, such as income generated by the asset./nHypothecation occurs most commonly in mortgage lending, where the home serves as collateral but the bank does not have any claim on cash flows or income generated from it unless the borrower defaults./nMargin lending in brokerage accounts is another common form of hypothecation found in securities trading and investing.

Term: Hypothesis Testing: 4 Steps and Example
Definition: Hypothesis testing is used to assess the plausibility of a hypothesis by using sample data./nThe test provides evidence concerning the plausibility of the hypothesis, given the data./nStatistical analysts test a hypothesis by measuring and examining a random sample of the population being analyzed./nThe four steps of hypothesis testing include stating the hypotheses, formulating an analysis plan, analyzing the sample data, and analyzing the result.

Term: What Is an Iceberg Order and How Do You Identify It?
Definition: Iceberg orders are large orders that are split up into lots or small sized limit orders. They are split up into visible and hidden parts, with the latter transitioning to visibility after the former type of order is executed./nThey are typically placed by large institutional investors to avoid disrupting trading markets with a single, large order./nTraders can profit off iceberg orders by buying shares just above the price levels supported by initial batches of an iceberg orders.

Term: Hysteresis: Definition in Economics, Types, and Example
Definition: Hysteresis in economics refers to an event in the economy that persists into the future, even after the factors that led to that event have been removed./nHysteresis can include the delayed effects of unemployment, whereby the unemployment rate continues to rise even after the economy has recovered./nHysteresis can indicate a permanent change in the workforce from the loss of job skills making workers less employable even after a recession has ended.

Term: What Is the Ichimoku Cloud Technical Analysis Indicator?
Definition: The Ichimoku Cloud is composed of five lines or calculations, two of which comprise a cloud where the difference between the two lines is shaded in./nThe lines include a nine-period average, a 26-period average, an average of those two averages, a 52-period average, and a laggingclosing priceline./nThe cloud is a key part of the indicator. When the price is below the cloud, the trend is down. When the price is above the cloud, the trend is up./nThe above trend signals are strengthened if the cloud is moving in the same direction as the price. For example, during anuptrend, the top of the cloud is moving up, or during a downtrend, the bottom of the cloud is moving down.

Term: What Is an Ideation? Definition, How It Works, and Process
Definition: Ideation is the process of forming ideas from conception to implementation, most often in a business setting./nIdeation is expressed via graphical, written, or verbal methods, and arises from past or present knowledge, influences, opinions, experiences, and personal convictions./nIdeation is usually derived from brainstorming sessions, online forums, seminars, surveys, social media platforms, and team-building exercises./nAnyone from an organization, from the CEO to an intern, can partake in the ideation process and contribute innovatively to a company./nMost of the ideation process originates from trying to fix a problem; ideation is commonly reverse engineered./nStyles of ideation include problem solutions, derivative ideas, and symbiotic ideas.

Term: ICON: What it is, How it Works, Criticisms
Definition: ICON is a blockchain technology and network framework designed to allow independent blockchains to interact with each other./nCommunities are connected to the ICON Network through a decentralized exchange./nPotential opposition from traditional centralized cryptocurrency exchanges is a major challenge facing ICON.

Term: Idiosyncratic Risk: Definition, Types, Examples, Ways To Minimize
Definition: Idiosyncratic risk refers to the inherent factors that can negatively impact individual securities or a very specific group of assets./nIt is also known as specific, or unsystematic risk./nCertain securities will naturally have more idiosyncratic risk than others./nIdiosyncratic risk can generally be mitigated in an investment portfolio through the use of diversification./nThe opposite of Idiosyncratic risk is a systematic risk, which refers to broader trends that impact the overall financial system or a very broad market.

Term: Identifiable Asset: Meaning, Uses, Example
Definition: Identifiable assets can be given a fair value or expected selling price, such as such as liquid investments, machinery, vehicles, buildings, or other equipment./nIdentifiable assets may be either tangible and intangible but may be contrasted with goodwill./nThese are recorded on a company's balance sheet and come into play when valuing a takeover bid.

Term: What Is Identity Theft? Types and Examples
Definition: Identity theft occurs when someone steals your personal information and credentials to commit fraud./nThere are various forms of identity theft, but the most common is financial./nIdentity theft protection keeps track of people's credit reports, financial activity, and Social Security number use./nRecovering from the damage caused by identity theft can take substantial time and effort./nIf you are the victim of identity theft, contact the Federal Trade Commission at IdentityTheft.gov or 1-877-438-4338.

Term: What Is Idle Time, and What Does It Mean for Businesses?
Definition: Idle time is paid time that an employee, or machine, is unproductive due to factors that can either be controlled or uncontrolled by management./nIdle time can be classified either as normal or abnormal./nMinimizing idle time is key if a business wants to maximize efficiency over long periods of time.

Term: Illiquid Assets: Overview, Risk and Examples
Definition: Illiquidity occurs when a security or other asset that cannot easily and quickly be sold or exchanged for cash without a substantial loss in value./nIlliquid assets may be hard to sell quickly because of a lack of ready and willing investors or speculators to purchase the asset, whereas actively traded securities will tend to be more liquid./nIlliquid assets tend to have wider bid-ask spreads, greater volatility and, as a result, higher risk for investors.

Term: Immediate Family Definition, Criteria, and Legal Aspects
Definition: The immediate family usually consists of one's parents, siblings, spouse, and children./nWho is considered immediate family matters in situations such as a company's family leave policy./nThe Family and Medical Leave Act, for example, defines immediate family as your spouse, parents, and dependent children./nFor U.S. immigration purposes, immediate family is limited to one's spouse, parents, or unmarried children below age 21./nIn estate law, the right of inheritance passes to one's spouses and surviving children before moving on to other relatives.

Term: What Is an Immediate or Cancel Order (IOC)?
Definition: Immediate-or-cancel (IOC) orders attempt to execute immediately and cancel any unfilled portion./nIOC orders only require a partial fill and may be designated as limit or market orders./nIOC is a duration order type like fill or kill (FOK), all or none (AON), and good ‘till canceled (GTC).

Term: Immunization: Definition, Investing Strategies, and Examples
Definition: Immunization is a risk-mitigation strategy that matches asset and liability duration so portfolio values are protected against interest rate changes./nImmunization can be accomplished by cash flow matching, duration matching, convexity matching, and trading forwards, futures, and options on bonds./nThe downside to immunization of a portfolio is foregoing the opportunity cost if the assets were to increase in value while the liabilities did not also rise in the same manner.

Term: Immediate Payment Annuity: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Immediate payment annuities are sold by insurance companies and can provide income to the owner almost immediately after purchase./nBuyers can choose monthly, quarterly, or annual income./nPayments are generally fixed for the term of the contract, but variable and inflation-adjusted annuities are also available.

Term: Impaired Credit: What it is, How it Works, How to Assess it
Definition: Impaired credit refers to a deterioration in the creditworthiness of an individual, a business, or another entity./nImpaired credit will be reflected in a lower credit score for individuals or a lower credit rating for companies, governments, and other entities./nBorrowers with impaired credit struggle to obtain loans and other forms of credit more difficult and more costly./nImpaired credit can sometimes be fixed by addressing the factors that caused it in the first place.

Term: Impact Investing: Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: Impact investing is an investment strategy that seeks to generate financial returns while also creating a positive social or environmental impact./nInvestors who follow impact investing consider a company's commitment to corporate social responsibility or the duty to positively serve society as a whole./nSocially responsible (SRI) and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing are two approaches to impact investing./nMore than 88% of impact investors reported that their investments met or exceeded their expectations./nA 2021 study showed that the median impact fund realized a 6.4% return, compared to 7.4% from non-impact funds.

Term: Impaired Asset: Meaning, Causes, How To Test, and How To Record
Definition: Assets should be tested for impairment on a regular basis to prevent overstatement on the balance sheet./nAssets that are most likely to become impaired include accounts receivable, as well as long-term assets such as intangibles and fixed assets./nWhen an impaired asset's value is written down on the balance sheet, there is also a loss recorded on the income statement./nGAAP and IFRS have differing standards for impairment.

Term: Impeachment: Meaning, Overview, Examples
Definition: Impeachment, as defined in Article II, Section 4 of the U.S. Constitution, is the formal process by which Congress brings charges against high-ranking civil officers, such as the president, in a bid to remove them from office./nOnly the U.S. House of Representatives has the power to impeach a federal official, and only the Senate can convict and remove the impeached official./nOnly three U.S. presidents have been impeached by the House—Andrew Johnson, Bill Clinton, and Donald Trump—and all were acquitted by the Senate.

Term: What Does Impairment Mean in Accounting? With Examples
Definition: Impairment can occur as the result of an unusual or one-time event, such as a change in legal or economic conditions, a change in consumer demand, or damage that impacts an asset./nAssets should be tested for impairment regularly to prevent overstatement on the balance sheet./nImpairment exists when an asset's fair value is less than its carrying value on the balance sheet./nIf impairment is confirmed as a result of testing, an impairment loss should be recorded./nAn impairment loss records an expense in the current period that appears on the income statement and simultaneously reduces the value of the impaired asset on the balance sheet.

Term: What Does Imperfect Competition Mean in Economics?
Definition: Imperfect competition refers to any economic market that does not meet the rigorous assumptions of a hypothetical perfectly competitive market./nIn this environment, companies sell different products and services, set their own individual prices, fight for market share, and are often protected by barriers to entry and exit./nImperfect competition is common and can be found in the following types of market structures: monopolies, oligopolies, monopolistic competition, monopsonies, and oligopsonies./nEconomists generally agree that real-world markets rarely meet the assumptions of perfect competition, but disagree as to how much of a substantial difference this makes for market outcomes.

Term: What Are Imperfect Markets? Definition, Types, and Consequences
Definition: Imperfect markets do not meet the rigorous standards of a hypothetical perfectly or purely competitive market./nImperfect markets are characterized by having competition for market share, high barriers to entry and exit, different products and services, and a small number of buyers and sellers./nPerfect markets are theoretical and cannot exist in the real world; all real-world markets are imperfect markets./nMarket structures that are categorized as imperfect include monopolies, oligopolies, monopolistic competition, monopsonies, and oligopsonies.

Term: Implicit Cost Explained: How It Works, With Examples
Definition: An implicit cost is a cost that exists without the exchange of cash and is not recorded for accounting purposes./nImplicit costs represent the loss of income but do not represent a loss of profit./nThese costs are in contrast to explicit costs, which represent money exchanged or the use of tangible resources by a company./nExamples of implicit costs include a small business owner who may forgo a salary in the early stages of operations to increase revenue.

Term: What Is Implied Authority? Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: There are three types of authority used frequently in business deals, like real estate: express, implied, and apparent./nIn a situation of apparent authority, it means that a person’s conduct gives the impression that they are allowed to act in the principal’s interest./nWhen a real estate agent signs a binder with a client, that agent is given implied authority to act on behalf of the seller./nExpress authority occurs when an agent is working on behalf of his or her company to act on behalf of a principal. For example, a life insurance agent may have express authority under their company.

Term: Implied Contract: Definition, Example, Types, and Rules
Definition: An implied contract is created by the actions, behavior, or circumstances of the people involved./nAn implied contract has the same legal force as a written or verbal contract./nThe implied contract, such as an implied warranty, is assumed to exist, and no confirmation is necessary./nBecause of the lack of documentation, it is more difficult to enforce an implied contract in some circumstances.

Term: Implied Rate: Definition, Calculation With Formula, and Example
Definition: The implied rate is an interest rate equal to the difference between the spot rate and the forward or futures rate./nThe implied rate gives investors a way to compare returns across investments./nAn implied rate can be calculated for any type of security that also has an option or futures contract.

Term: How Implied Volatility (IV) Works With Options and Examples
Definition: Implied volatility is the market's forecast of a likely movement in a security's price./nIV is often used to price options contracts where high implied volatility results in options with higher premiums and vice versa./nSupply and demand and time value are major determining factors for calculating implied volatility./nImplied volatility usually increases in bearish markets and decreases when the market is bullish./nAlthough IV helps quantify market sentiment and uncertainty, it is based solely on prices rather than fundamentals.

Term: Import: Definition, Examples, and Pros and Cons
Definition: An import is a product or service produced abroad and purchased in your home country./nImported goods or services are attractive when domestic industries cannot produce similar goods and services cheaply or efficiently./nFree trade agreements and tariff schedules often dictate which goods and materials are less expensive to import./nEconomists and policy analysts disagree on the positive and negative impacts of imports.

Term: Import Substitution Industrialization (ISI) Defined, With Example
Definition: Import substitution industrialization is an economic theory adhered to by developing countries that wish to decrease their dependence on developed countries./nISI targets the protection and incubation of newly formed domestic industries to fully develop sectors so the goods produced are competitive with imported goods./nDeveloping countries began to reject ISI policy in the 1980s and 1990s.

Term: Import (Customs) Duty: Definition, How It Works, and Who Pays It
Definition: Import duty is also known as customs duty, tariff, import tax or import tariff./nImport duty is levied when imported goods first enter the country./nAround the world, several organizations and treaties have a direct impact on import duties.

Term: What Is an Impression in Online Advertising, How to Count Them
Definition: Impressions are used to quantify the number of digital views or engagements of a piece of content, usually an advertisement, digital post, or a web page./nCounting impressions can often fall in a gray area, such as whether this includes duplicate views, interactions from bots, or if impressions are even an effective way to measure the success of a digital marketing campaign./nTechnically speaking, ad servers provide a barely visible image (or "pixel") that can be found on each publisher page. When a page with that pixel image loads, that is when an impression is made.

Term: Imprest: Definition, Uses, and How It Works
Definition: Imprest refers to a type of cash account maintained by a company used to pay for small incidental or routine expenses./nA fixed account balance is established in the imprest account and refunded as needed when money is withdrawn for items like payroll, travel, or petty cash./nBecause of its small and fixed nature that is easily monitored, imprest discourages unauthorized or lavish expenses.

Term: Imputed Interest: What is is, How to Calculate, FAQs
Definition: Imputed interest is a type of interest that is assumed to have been paid or earned, even though no actual interest payment has been made./nSome loans are exempt from imputed interest, such as gift loans between members of the same family for less than $10,000./nImputed interest is calculated according to the accretive method./nImputed interest can also apply to loans from family and friends, depending on the terms and value of the loan./nThis is done to prevent individuals from avoiding taxes by not charging or paying interest on loans.

Term: Impulse Wave Pattern: Definition, Theory, and Rules
Definition: Impulse waves are trend-confirming patterns identified by Elliott Wave theory./nImpulse waves consist of five sub-waves that make a net movement in the same direction as the trend of the next-largest degree./nElliott Wave Theory is a method of technical analysis that looks for recurrent long-term price patterns that are related to persistent changes in investor sentiment and psychology.

Term: In-App Purchasing: Definition, Conveniences, and Securities Risks
Definition: In-app purchasing refers to the buying of goods and services from inside an application on a mobile device, such as a smartphone or tablet./nIn-app purchases allow developers to provide their applications for free./nBecause in-app purchases are conducted through a mobile device, unauthorized purchases can result in security issues.

Term: Imputed Value: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: Imputed value is a calculated estimate of value produced when a direct or explicit value is unavailable or impossible to obtain./nImputed values may be given to intangible assets held by a firm, such as the value of a patent or other piece of intellectual property./nBecause imputed values are only estimates or forecasts, they may be subject to error. One should heed imputed values with caution when evaluating a company's financial statements.

Term: What Does Escrow (in Escrow) Mean, and How Does It Work?
Definition: Funds or assets held in escrow are temporarily transferred to and held by a third party, usually on behalf of a buyer and seller to facilitate a transaction./n"In escrow" is often used in real estate transactions whereby property, cash, and the title are held in escrow until predetermined conditions are met./nEscrow is often associated with real estate transactions, but it can apply to any situation where funds will pass from one party to another./nValuables held in escrow can include valuables, real property, money, stocks, and other securities.

Term: In-House: Definition, Meaning in Business, Risks, and Advantages
Definition: In-house refers to an activity or operation conducted within a company, instead of relying on outside providers./nMany larger companies use in-house legal teams, developers, marketers, or other specialized services./nWhile it is common for some companies to outsource those divisions, a firm may maintain greater flexibility in those operations by keeping them in-house./nIn-house financing is common among carmakers and financial firms./nThere are tradeoffs to keeping some professionals in-house, since they must be kept full time even if they are not always busy.

Term: In-Service Withdrawal: Definition, Rules, Taxes & Penalties
Definition: In-service withdrawals refer to taking special distributions from aqualified, employer-sponsored retirement plan./nThese distributions occur while the employee is still employed./nThe distributions are normally available for hardship cases./nSpecial rules allow some plan participants to take distributions even without hardship.

Term: In Specie Definition and Meaning in Asset Distributions
Definition: The term in specie is Latin for in the same form or in kind./nIt is the delivery of a financial asset in its current form rather than in an equivalent amount of cash./nIn specie transactions may involve either physical assets or financial assets./nTax implications may influence the decision to transfer assets in specie rather than in cash.

Term: Basics of In-House Financing: Types, Requirements, Example
Definition: In-house financing is when a retailer extends a customer a loan for the purchase of its goods or services./nThe need for banks or other third-party lending institutions is eliminated through in-house financing./nApproval for a loan is typically easier and the process simpler when financing is obtained through the retailer./nThe automobile industry is one of the largest industries utilizing in-house financing./nWith the emergence of technology firms and mobile apps, point-of-sale financing allows for immediate financing for consumers.

Term: In the Money: Definition, Call & Put Options, and Example
Definition: A call option is in the money (ITM) if the market price is above the strike price./nA put option is in the money if the market price is below the strike price./nAn option can also be out of the money (OTM) or at the money (ATM)./nIn-the-money options contracts have higher premiums than other options that are not ITM./nInvestors should account for the costs of buying options when figuring potential profit from an in the money option.

Term: Incidence Rate: Definition, Calculation, and Examples
Definition: The incidence rate measures how often an event, such as disease or foreclosure, is likely to occur over a particular period of time./nThis rate provides the capacity to anticipate future incidents and plan accordingly./nIncidence is different from prevalence, which measures the total accumulation of cases./nPharmaceutical and biotech companies rely on incidence rates when they seek approval from the FDA to get their drugs to market./nCompanies that report positive incidence rates are good picks for investors while those with negative findings often see losses in their stocks.

Term: Incentive Stock Options (ISO): Definition and Meaning
Definition: Incentive stock options (ISOs) are a popular means of employee compensation for corporate management, granting rights to company stock at a discounted price at a future date./nThis type of employee stock purchase plan is intended to retain key employees or managers./nISOs require a vesting period of at least two years and a holding period of more than one year before they can be sold./nISOs often have more favorable tax treatment on profits than other types of employee stock purchase plans.

Term: Incidental Expenses (IE): Definition, Types, Examples, and Taxes
Definition: Incidental expenses are minor costs, such as gratuities, that are incurred in addition to business expenses./nIncidentals ancillary to the costs of transportation, meals, and lodging are most common when an employee travels for work./nReimbursement of incidental expenses, if any, is a matter of company policy./n"Miscellaneous" expenses are no longer deductible by most individual taxpayers./nIncidentals may be tax deductible by an employer if they are reimbursed by the company and proper records are kept.

Term: Income Annuity: What it is, How it Works
Definition: An income annuity is a financial product designed to swap a lump sum amount for guaranteed periodic cash flow (e.g., monthly or annual payments)./nAn income, or immediate annuity, generally starts payment one month after the premium is paid and may continue for as long as the buyer is alive./nSuch annuities are especially suitable for retirees who are concerned about outliving their retirement savings.

Term: Income Approach: What It Is, How It's Calculated, Example
Income Definition: Types, Examples, and Taxes
Definition: Income generally refers to the amount of money, property, and other transfers of value received over a set period of time in exchange for services or products./nTaxable income is gross income minus exclusions, exemptions, and deductions allowed under the tax law./nFinancial regulators, businesses, and investors focus on businesses’ annual financial statements, which are prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).

Term: What Is the Income Effect? Its Meaning and Example
Definition: The income effect describes how an increase in income can change the quantity of goods that consumers will demand./nFor so-called normal goods, as income rises so does the demand for them (and vice-versa)./nThis is reflected in microeconomics via an upward shift in the downward-sloping demand curve./nThis effect, however, can vary depending on the availability of substitutes and the good's elasticity of demand./nFor inferior goods, the income effect dominates the substitution effect and leads consumers to purchase more of a good, and less of substitute goods, when the price rises.

Term: Income Elasticity of Demand: Definition, Formula, and Types
Definition: Income elasticity of demand is an economic measure of how responsive the quantity demanded for a good or service is to a change in income./nThe formula for calculating income elasticity of demand is the percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in income./nBusinesses use the measure to help predict the impact of a business cycle on sales.

Term: Income Fund Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: Income funds are mutual funds or ETFs that prioritize current income, often in the form of interest or dividend-paying investments./nIncome funds may invest in bonds or other fixed-income securities as well as preferred shares and dividend stocks./nIncome funds are often considered lower risk than funds that prioritize capital gains.

Term: Income in Respect of a Decedent (IRD): Definition and Taxes
Definition: Income in respect of a decedent refers to untaxed income that a decedent had earned or had a right to receive during their lifetime./nIRD is taxed as if the decedent is still living./nBeneficiaries are responsible for paying taxes on IRD income under most circumstances.

Term: Income Inequality Definition: Examples and How It's Measured
Definition: Income inequality can result in a lack of opportunities for better standards of living and stable financial futures, and political and social upheavals./nIncome inequality studies help to show the disparity of income among different population segments./nWhen analyzing income inequality, researchers study distributions based on gender, ethnicity, geographic location, and occupation./nCase studies and analyses of income inequality, income disparity, and income distributions are provided regularly by a variety of top sources./nThe Gini Index is a popular way to compare income inequalities universally across the globe.

Term: What Is Income Per Capita? Uses, Limitations, and Examples
Definition: Per capita income is a measure of the amount of money earned per person in a nation or geographic region./nPer capita income includes all individuals, not just adults of working age./nPer capita income as a metric has limitations that include its inability to account for inflation, income disparity, poverty, wealth, or savings.

Term: Income Smoothing: Definition, Legality, Process, and Example
Definition: Income smoothing is the act of using accounting methods to level out fluctuations in net income from different reporting periods./nThe process of income smoothing involves moving revenues and expenses from one accounting period to another./nThough legal if performed within the guidelines of GAAP, income smoothing can be done fraudulently./nReasons for income smoothing include reducing taxes, attracting investors, and as part of a business strategy.

Term: Income Property: What it is, How it Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: An income property is purchased or developed to earn income by renting or leasing it out to others or through price appreciation./nIncome properties may be both commercial and residential./nOwners should have a financial cushion to pay for repairs, maintenance, and other costs such as property taxes in case of emergency./nAlthough they may generate income, owners should consider the risks including interest rates, housing market conditions, and disruptive tenants.

Term: Income Stock: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: Income stocks are stocks that offer regular and steady income, usually in the form of dividends, over a period of time with low exposure to risk./nIncome stocks usually offer a high yield that may generate the majority of the security's overall returns./nThe ideal income stock would have very low volatility, a dividend yield higher than the prevailing 10-year Treasury note rate, and a modest level of annual profit growth./nIncome stocks are different from growth stocks, which have higher volatility and risks associated with their performance.

Term: Income Statement: How to Read and Use It
Definition: An income statement is one of the three major financial statements, along with the balance sheet and the cash flow statement, that report a company’s financial performance over a specific accounting period./nThe income statement focuses on the revenue, expenses, gains, and losses of a company during a particular period./nAn income statement provides valuable insights into a company’s operations, the efficiency of its management, underperforming sectors, and its performance relative to industry peers.

Term: Defining an Incontestability Clause
Definition: Most life insurance policies include an incontestability clause./nAn incontestability clause prevents providers from voiding coverage if the insured misstates information after a contestability period, such as two or three years./nThe clock starts to run on the contestability period the moment the life insurance policy is purchased.

Term: What Is Income Tax and How Are Different Types Calculated?
Definition: Income tax is a type of tax governments impose on income generated by businesses and individuals within their jurisdiction./nIncome tax is used to fund public services, pay government obligations, and provide goods for citizens./nThe federal government and many states, as well as local jurisdictions, levy their own income taxes./nPersonal income tax is a type of income tax levied on an individual’s wages, salaries, and other types of income./nBusiness income taxes apply to corporations, partnerships, small businesses, and the self-employed.

Term: What Does Income Tax Payable Mean in Financial Accounting?
Definition: Income tax payable is the financial accounting term for a current tax liability reported on a company's balance sheet./nThe rules for calculating how much tax is owed and the rules for reporting taxes on financial statements can differ./nIncome tax payable on a balance sheet equals the total tax due to be paid to government tax agencies within 12 months./nIncome taxes to be paid in a future year are reported as deferred income tax liabilities./nTaxes reflected on financial statements can include federal, state, local, and foreign taxes.

Term: Incorporation: Definition, How It Works, and Advantages
Definition: Incorporation is the way that a business entity known as a corporation is formally organized and officially brought into existence./nThe process of incorporation involves writing up a document known as the articles of incorporation and enumerating the firm's shareholders./nIn a corporation, the assets and cash flows of the business entity are kept separate from those of the owners and investors, which is called limited liability./nThough incorporation, a company's tax liability is also treated differently than that of a sole proprietorship or partnership./nIncorporating makes it easier for a business to sells shares, raise capital, and divest ownership from a portion of the business.

Term: Incremental Analysis: Definition, Types, Importance, and Example
Definition: Incremental analysis helps to determine the cost implications of various business opportunities./nIt is also known as marginal analysis, the relevant cost approach, and differential analysis./nNon-relevant sunk costs, or past costs, are not included in the analysis./nIncremental analysis also assists with allocating limited resources to product lines to ensure a scarce asset is used to maximum benefit.

Term: Incoterms: Definition, Examples, Rules, Pros & Cons
Definition: International commercial terms—Incoterms for short—clarify the rules and terms that buyers and sellers use in international and domestic trade contracts./nThe International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) developed Incoterms in 1936 and updates them periodically to conform to changing trade practices./nExamples of Incoterms for modes of transportation include Delivered at Terminal (DAT), Delivered Duty Paid (DDP), and Ex Works (EXW)./nIncoterms were updated for 2020, and although only one term changed, there are notable differences in security costs./nThe terms are standardized, but certain buyers and sellers prefer individual terms over others. As such, which terms will be used is a matter of negotiation.

Term: Incremental Capital Output Ratio (ICOR): Definition and Formula
Definition: The incremental capital output ratio (ICOR) explains the relationship between the level of investment made in the economy and the consequent increase in GDP./nICOR is a metric that assesses the marginal amount of investment capital necessary for a country or other entity to generate the next unit of production./nA lower ICOR is preferred as it indicates a country's production is more efficient./nSome critics of ICOR have suggested that the use of ICOR is limited as it favors developing countries that can increase infrastructure and technology use as opposed to developed countries, which are operating at the highest level possible.

Term: Incremental Cost of Capital: What It is, How It Works
Definition: The incremental cost of capital estimates how adding more debt or equity will affect a company's balance sheet./nKnowing the incremental costs of capital allows a company to assess whether a project is a good idea given the effect it will have on overall borrowing costs./nInvestors watch for changes in the incremental cost of capital, as a rise can be a sign that a company is leveraging itself too much.

Term: Incremental Cash Flow: Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: Incremental cash flow is the potential increase or decrease in a company's cash flow related to the acceptance of a new project or investment in a newasset./nPositive incremental cash flow is a good sign that the investment is more profitable to the company than the expenses it will incur./nIncremental cash flow can be a good tool to assess whether to invest in a new project or asset, but it should not be the only resource for assessing the new venture.

Term: Incremental Cost: Definition, How to Calculate, and Examples
Definition: Incremental cost is the amount of money it would cost a company to make an additional unit of product./nCompanies can use incremental cost analysis to help determine the profitability of their business segments./nA company can lose money if incremental cost exceeds incremental revenue.

Term: Incumbency Certificate: What It Is, with Sample
Definition: An incumbency certificate records the identities of a firm’s current directors, officers, and, sometimes, key shareholders./nAn incumbency certificate will often be required by a financial institution when opening an account to guarantee that the people who claim to be the authorized signatory of a company are actually authorized./nContracts for transactions involving companies usually require an incumbency certificate to determine who can legally bind the company in the contracts.

Term: Incumbent: Definition, Meanings in Contexts, and Examples
Definition: The term incumbent has many different meanings, though normally refers to an individual who currently holds responsibilities within a corporation or a branch of the government./nIn business, an incumbent may also refer to a leader, specifically the leader of a company or a company that holds a large portion of the industry's market share./nIncumbents also refer to business relationships, and in politics, the incumbent is an individual who currently holds office./nCompanies list their leaders on an incumbency certificate. These leaders include current directors, officers, and may also include main shareholders./nIn political elections, incumbents most often win re-election rather than the challenger winning the position.

Term: Incurred But Not Reported (IBNR): Definition and Calculation
Definition: Incurred but not reported (IBNR) is a reserve account used by insurance companies to compensate for claims that have not yet been reported./nIncurred but not reported (IBNR) is most often associated with delayed reporting due to bureaucratic red tape and processing lag./nBecause incurred but not reported (IBNR) claims represent latent liabilities, companies must calculate a proper estimate of funds to hold in reserve.

Term: Indenture: Definition and Types in Finance
Definition: An indenture is a legal and binding contract usually associated with bond agreements, real estate, or bankruptcy./nAn indenture provides detailed information on terms, clauses, and covenants./nThere can be a few different types of indentures and many different types of indenture clauses.

Term: What Is Indemnity Insurance? How It Works and Examples
Definition: Indemnity insurance is a type of insurance policy where the insurance company guarantees compensation for losses or damages sustained by a policyholder./nIndemnity insurance is designed to protect professionals and business owners when found to be at fault for a specific event such as misjudgment./nCertain professionals must carry indemnity insurance including those involved in financial and legal services, such as financial advisors, insurance agents, accountants, mortgage brokers, and attorneys./nMedical malpractice, professional liability, and errors and omissions insurance are examples of indemnity insurance.

Term: Indentured Servitude: Definition, History, and Controversy
Definition: Indentured servitude is a form of labor where an individual is under contract to work without a salary to repay an indenture or loan./nIndentured servitude was popular in the United States in the 1600s as many individuals worked in exchange for the price of passage to America./nIndentured servants could be sold, loaned, or inherited, at least during the duration of their contract terms./nToday, indentured servitude is illegal in the United States and most other countries./nAn illegal form of indentured servitude still exists as "debt bondage," a form of human trafficking.

Term: What Is an Index? Examples, How It's Used, and How to Invest
Definition: An index measures the price performance of a basket of securities using a standardized metric and methodology./nIndexes in financial markets are often used as benchmarks to evaluate an investment's performance against./nSome of the most important indexes in the U.S. markets are the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average./nPassive index investing has become a popular low-cost way to replicate the returns of popular indices such as the S&P 500 Index or Dow Jones Industrial Average./nBenchmarking your investment strategy against the appropriate index is key to understanding a portfolio's performance.

Term: Independent Contractor: Definition, How Taxes Work, and Example
Definition: Independent contractors are not employees, nor are they eligible for employee benefits./nThey do not have taxes withheld from their paychecks but instead must pay estimated income taxes in advance through quarterly payments./nFreelancers can reduce their gross income through the use of allowed business deductions, thus lowering their tax bills./nIndependent contractors must arrange for their own insurance and retirement./nThe category for independent contractors is very broad.

Term: Index-Linked Bond: Definition, How They Work, and Example
Definition: Index-linked bonds—also called Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities in the U.S.—pay interest that is linked to an underlying index, such as the Consumer Price Index (CPI)./nIndex-linked bonds are issued by governments to help mitigate the impact of inflation, paying a real yield plus accrued inflation./nThese bonds are beneficial to investors because they are less volatile than normal bonds and the risk involved with uncertainty is reduced.

Term: What Are Index Futures? Definition, Types, and How to Profit
Definition: Index futures are contracts to buy or sell a financial index at a set price today and are settled in the future./nThese contracts were initially meant only for institutional investors but have been open for decades to anyone./nPortfolio managers use index futures to hedge their equity positions against a loss in stocks./nSpeculators can also use index futures to bet on the market's direction./nThe most popular index futures are based on equities, including the E-mini S&P 500, E-mini Nasdaq-100, and E-mini Dow. International markets also have index futures.

Term: Investing in an index: overview, examples, and FAQ
Definition: Index investing is a passive investment strategy that seeks to replicate the returns of a benchmark index./nIndexing offers greater diversification, as well as lower expenses and fees, than actively managed strategies./nIndexing seeks to match the risk and return of the overall market, on the theory that over the long-term the market will outperform any stock picker./nComplete index investing involves purchasing all of an index's components at their given portfolio weights, while less-intensive strategies involve only owning the largest index weights or a sampling of important components.

Term: Index Option: Option Contracts Based on a Benchmark Index
Definition: Index options are options contracts that utilize a benchmark index, or a futures contract based on that index, as its underlying instrument./nIndex options are typically European style and settle in cash for the value of the index at expiration./nLike all options, index options will give the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to either go long (for a call) or short (for a put) the value of the index at a pre-specified strike price.

Term: Indexation: Meaning and Examples
Definition: Indexation means adjusting a price, wage, or other value based on changes in another price or composite indicator of prices./nIndexation can be done to adjust for the effects of inflation, cost of living, or input prices over time./nIt can adjust for different prices and costs in different geographic areas./nIndexation is often used to escalate wages in inflationary environments where failure to negotiate regular wage increases would lead to ongoing real wage cuts for workers.

Term: Indexing: Definition and Uses in Economics and Investing
Definition: Indexing is the practice of compiling economic data into a single metric or comparing data to such a metric./nThere are many indexes in finance that reflect on economic activity or summarize market activity./nIn economics, indexes can directly impact people's livelihoods, for example in the form of cost-of-living adjustments that are indexed to inflation./nIn investing, indexes become performance benchmarks against which portfolios and fund managers are measured./nIndexing is also used to refer to passively investing in market indexes to replicate broad market returns rather than actively selecting individual stocks.

Term: Indexed Annuity: Definition, How It Works, Yields, and Caps
Definition: An indexed annuity pays a rate of interest based on a particular market index, such as the S&P 500./nIndexed annuities give buyers an opportunity to benefit when the financial markets perform well, unlike fixed annuities, which pay a set interest rate regardless./nHowever, certain provisions in these contracts can limit the potential upside to only a portion of the market's rise.

Term: Indicative Net Asset Value (iNAV): What it is, How it Works
Definition: Indicative net asset value (iNAV) is a measure of the intraday net asset value (NAV) of an investment./nIndicative net asset value (iNAV) is reported approximately every 15 seconds by a calculation agent, typically the exchange that the investment is trading on./nIndicative net asset value (iNAV) can be reported for both closed-end mutual funds and exchange-traded funds (ETFs)./nTo come up with the indicative net asset value (iNAV), the calculation agent will use the established price of all securities in the portfolio to generate the total asset value; then the fund’s liabilities are subtracted from total assets and the remainder is divided by the number of shares.

Term: Rupee: Definition, Value, and Examples of Indian Currency
Definition: The Indian rupee is the currency of India; INR is its currency code, and the currency symbol is ₹./nSince India is a cash-based economy, fake currency has been circulated by those engaged in illegal behavior./nTo prevent fraud, the Reserve Bank of India has changed and updated the rupee notes with new security features over the years./nVarious factors can impact the exchange rate of the Indian rupee, including trade flows, investment flows, and oil prices.

Term: What Is an Indication of Interest (IOI)? How It Works and Example
Definition: Indications of interest are nonbinding agreements to acquire a company or buy a security once available./nThese securities are expressed during IPO registration./nStockbrokers put the IOI in place for investments./nEven though these are nonbinding, IOIs constitute serious inquiries only./nExpressing interest in an IOI does not provide any guarantee once the security reaches the IPO stage.

Term: What Is an Indicator? How It's Used, Types, and Examples
Definition: Indicators are statistics used to measure current conditions as well as to forecast financial or economic trends./nEconomic indicators are statistical metrics used to measure the growth or contraction of the economy as a whole or sectors within the economy./nIn the context of technical analysis, an indicator is a mathematical calculation based on a security's price or volume, with the results used to predict future prices./nA key performance indicator refers to a quantifiable measurement used to measure a company's success against a specific target or objective./nCommonly used indicators of a company's profitability include gross margin, operating margin, net margin, and return on equity (ROE).

Term: Indifference Curves in Economics: What Do They Explain?
Definition: An indifference curve shows a combination of two goods in various quantities that provides equal satisfaction or utility to an individual./nA consumer has an equal preference for the various combinations of goods shown along the curve./nIndifference curves are typically shown convex to the origin and no two indifference curves ever intersect./nEconomists have adopted the principles of indifference curves in the study of welfare economics.

Term: Indirect Loan: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: With an indirect loan, the lender does not have a direct relationship with the borrower, who has borrowed from a third party, arranged by an intermediary./nIndirect loans are often used in the auto industry, with dealers helping buyers facilitate funding through their network of financial institutions and other lenders./nIndirect loans are typically more expensive than direct loans, as they are often used by borrowers who might not otherwise qualify for a loan.

Term: What Is an Indirect Quote? Definition and Vs. Direct Quote
Definition: An indirect quote in the foreign exchange markets expresses the amount of foreign currency required to buy or sell one unit of the domestic currency./nAn indirect quote is also known as a “quantity quotation,” since it expresses the quantity of foreign currency required to buy a unit of the domestic currency./nThe opposite of an indirect quote is a direct quote which expresses the price of one unit of a foreign currency in terms of variable number of units of the domestic currency.

Term: How To Use the Indirect Method To Prepare a Cash Flow Statement
Definition: Under the indirect method, the cash flow statement begins with net income on an accrual basis and subsequently adds and subtracts non-cash items to reconcile to actual cash flows from operations./nThe indirect method is often easier to use than the direct method since most larger businesses already use accrual accounting./nThe complexity and time required to list every cash disbursement—as required by the direct method—makes the indirect method preferred and more commonly used.

Term: Indirect Tax: Definition, Meaning, and Common Examples
Individual Retirement Account (IRA): What It Is, 4 Types
Definition: Individual retirement accounts (IRAs) are retirement savings accounts with tax advantages./nTypes of IRAs include traditional IRAs, Roth IRAs, Simplified Employee Pension (SEP) IRAs, and Savings Incentive Match Plan for Employees (SIMPLE) IRAs./nMoney held in an IRA usually can’t be withdrawn before age 59½ without incurring a hefty tax penalty of 10% of the amount withdrawn./nAnnual income limitations apply to both the deductibility of contributions made to traditional IRAs and contributions made to Roth IRAs./nRMDs from a traditional IRA must begin at age 73.

Term: Industrial Banks or Loan Companies: Overview and Criticism
Definition: An industrial bank–also referred to as an industrial loan company (ILC)–is a state-chartered, financial institution, usually owned by a commercial firm, that is not regulated by a federal banking agency./nIndustrial banks are only chartered by a few states; the state of Utah provides the majority of charters for industrial banks in the U.S./nIndustrial banks have become controversial because they allow nonfinancial companies to offer banking services without oversight by the Federal Reserve.

Term: What Is Industrial Production Index (IPI)? How It Measures Output
Definition: The industrial production index (IPI) measures levels of production and capacity in the manufacturing, mining, electric, and gas industries, relative to a base year./nThe Federal Reserve Board (FRB) publishes the IPI in the middle of every month, and revisions to previous estimates at the end of every March./nThe composite index is an important macroeconomic indicator for economists and investors./nIndustry-level data, meanwhile, is useful for managers and investors within specific lines of business.

Term: Industrial Organization: Definition, Areas of Study, Example
Definition: Industrial organization is an analysis of factors, operational or otherwise, that contribute to a firm's overall strategy and product placement./nIt involves a study of different areas, from market power to product differentiation to industrial policy, that affect a firm's operations.

Term: Industrial Goods Sector: How It Works and How to Track It
Definition: The industrial goods sector is the sector of the economy that is responsible for the manufacturing and production of capital goods./nCompanies in the industrial goods industry sell machinery, equipment, or supplies used in manufacturing and construction./nThe industrial goods sector normally declines during economic recessions and rises during expansions, though its various subsectors can perform differently from one another./nSome of the largest companies in the world can be found in this sector, and the Dow Jones Industrial Index has historically been weighted heavily to industrial stocks.

Term: Industrial Revenue Bonds—IRBs
Definition: Industrial revenue bonds (IRBs) are a type of municipal bond, issued by a state or local government on behalf of a private company for a specific project./nAn IRB is a variety of revenue bond, specifically a private activity bond./nIRBs raise capital to fund the development of a manufacturing facility or equipment that will benefit the community at large; bondholders are repaid by the revenue the project generates./nAs with other munis, IRBs generate tax-free interest income.

Term: Industrial Revolution Definition: History, Pros, and Cons
