Definition: The first Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain in the 1700s and 1800s and was a time of significant innovation./nThe American Industrial Revolution followed in the late 19th century and was an engine of economic growth in the U.S./nThe Industrial Revolution led to inventions that included the assembly line, telegraph, steam engine, sewing machine, and internal combustion engine./nWorking for businesses during the Industrial Revolution paid better wages than agricultural work./nThe increase in the number of factories and migration to the cities led to pollution, deplorable working and living conditions, and child labor.

Term: Industry: Definition in Business and Investing
Definition: Similar companies are grouped into classifications called industries, such as department stores and automakers./nIndustry grouping is based on the primary product that a company makes or sells. Industries are further grouped into sectors./nThe North American Industry Classification System is the standard classification system used by government agencies to organize companies into sectors or industries./nThe Global Industry Classification Standard also assigns every company an economic sector and industry group./nCompanies within an industry often perform similarly due to macroeconomic conditions that help or hurt all companies with similar customer bases or products.

Term: Understanding the Industry Life Cycle: Phases and Examples
Definition: The industry life cycle refers to the evolution of an industry or business based on its stages of growth and decline./nThe four phases of the industry life cycle are the introduction, growth, maturity, and decline phases./nThe industry life cycle ends with the culmination of the decline phase, a period when the industry or business is unable to sustain growth./nMature industries include food and agriculture, mining, and financial services./nInvestors can make better-informed investment decisions once they understand industry life cycles.

Term: Industrialization: What It Is, Examples, and Impacts on Society
Definition: Industrialization is a transformation away from an agricultural- or resource-based economy, toward an economy based on mechanized manufacturing./nIndustrialization is usually associated with a greater average income and improved living standards./nEarly industrialization occurred in Europe and North America during the 18th and 19th centuries, and later in other parts of the world./nNumerous strategies for industrialization have been pursued over time, with varying levels of success.

Term: Industry Life Cycle Analysis: Definition, 4 Stages, and Example
Definition: Industry life cycle refers to the stages of growth, consolidation, and eventual extinction of an industry./nIt mirrors an economic cycle and consists of four main stages: expansion, peak, contraction, and trough./nIt is used to analyze a company's stock, depending on the stage that it is in during a life cycle.

Term: What Is an Inefficient Market? Definition, Effects, and Example
Definition: An inefficient market is one that does not succeed in incorporating all available information into a true reflection of an asset's fair price./nMarket inefficiencies exist due to information asymmetries, transaction costs, market psychology, and human emotion, among other reasons./nAs a result, some assets may be over- or under-valued in the market, creating opportunities for excess profits./nThe presence of inefficient markets in the world somewhat undermines economic theory, and in particular the efficient market hypothesis (EMH).

Term: Infant-Industry Theory: Definition, Main Arguments, and History
Definition: The infant-industry theory states that new industries in developing countries need protection against competitive pressures until they mature./nThis theory, first developed in the early 19th century by Alexander Hamilton and Friedrich List, is often a justification for protectionist trade policies./nDeveloping nation's governments may enact measures such as import duties, tariffs, quotas, and exchange rate controls to give the infant-industry time to develop and stabilize.

Term: Inferior Good: Definition, Examples, and Role of Consumer Behavior
Definition: An inferior good is one whose demand drops when people's incomes rise./nWhen incomes are low or the economy contracts, inferior goods become a more affordable substitute for a more expensive good./nInferior goods may refer to the brand of products purchased, items purchased, or instance of how something occurs (i.e. taking a bus vs. driving a new car)./nInferior goods are the opposite of normal goods, whose demand increases even when incomes increase./nInferior goods also oppose luxury goods, items of higher quality often sold at a premium that are not needed.

Term: Inflation: What It Is, How It Can Be Controlled, and Extreme Examples
Definition: Inflation measures how quickly the prices of goods and services are rising./nInflation is sometimes classified into three types: demand-pull inflation, cost-push inflation, and built-in inflation./nThe most commonly used inflation indexes are the Consumer Price Index and the Wholesale Price Index./nInflation can be viewed positively or negatively depending on the individual viewpoint and rate of change./nThose with tangible assets, like property or stocked commodities, may like to see some inflation as that raises the value of their assets.

Term: Inflation Accounting: Definition, Methods, Pros & Cons
Definition: Inflation accounting is the practice of adjusting financial statements according to price indexes./nNumbers are restated to reflect current values in hyperinflationary business environments./nInternational Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) defines hyperinflation as prices, interest, and wages linked to a price index rising 100% or more cumulatively over three years./nIFRS and U.S. GAAP have different requirements for inflation accounting.

Term: Inflation-Adjusted Return: Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The inflation-adjusted return accounts for the effect of inflation on an investment's performance over time./nAlso known as the real return, the inflation-adjusted return provides a more realistic comparison of an investment's performance./nInflation will lower the size of a positive return and increase the magnitude of a loss.

Term: Inflation Hedge
Definition: Inflation hedging can be used to offset the anticipated drop in a currency's price./nLimiting downside risk is a major commonality between institutional investors and currency hedging is a common practice.

Term: Inflation Swap: Definition, How It Works, Benefits, Example
Definition: An inflation swap is a transaction where one party transfers inflation risk to a counterparty in exchange for a fixed payment./nAn inflation swap can provide a pretty accurate estimation of what would be considered the "break-even" inflation rate./nInflation swaps are used by financial professionals to mitigate (or hedge) the risk of inflation and to use the price fluctuations to their advantage.

Term: What Is an Inflationary Gap?
Definition: An inflationary gap measures the difference between the current real GDP and the GDP of an economy operating at full employment./nThe current real GDP must be higher than the potential GDP for the gap to be considered inflationary./nPolicies that reduce an inflationary gap include reductions in government spending, tax increases, bond and securities issues, interest rate increases, and transfer payment reductions./nA government may use fiscal policy to help reduce an inflationary gap by decreasing the number of funds circulating within the economy./nA tight monetary policy should lower the money available to most consumers, triggering less demand.

Term: Inflection Point in Business: Overview and Examples
Definition: An inflection point refers to a key event that changes the trajectory of some process or situation related to the economy or society./nInflection points are more significant than the small day-to-day progress typically made in a company, and the effects of the change are often well known and widespread./nWhen an inflection point is identified, it is often a sign that the affected industry must make certain fundamental changes in order to continue to operate./nInflection points can be intentional (actions taken by a company or competitor) or unintentional (those that occur by accident or from unforeseen events)./nIf companies are not able to adapt to an inflection point, they will fail to keep up with competitors and cease operations. For those that can adapt, inflection points can be an advantage.

Term: Information Coefficient (IC): Definition, Example, and Formula
Definition: The information coefficient (IC) is a measure used to evaluate the skill an investment analyst or active portfolio manager./nAn IC of +1.0 indicates a perfect prediction of actual returns, while an IC of 0.0 indicates no linear relationship. An IC of -1.0 indicates that the analyst always fails at making a correct prediction./nThe IC is not to be confused with the Information Ratio (IR). The IR is a measure of an investment manager's skill, comparing a manager's excess returns to the amount of risk taken.

Term: Infrastructure: Definition, Meaning, and Examples
Definition: Infrastructure is the basic facilities and system serving a country, region, or community./nExamples of infrastructure include mass transit and telecommunications networks./nLarge-scale infrastructure is usually produced by the public sector and funded bytax revenue./nInfrastructure can often be produced on a smaller scale by private firms or through local authorities./nInfrastructure can be classified as soft or hard and both are essential to the economy and quality of life of a society.

Term: Information Ratio (IR): Definition, Formula, vs. Sharpe Ratio
Definition: The information ratio (IR) is a measurement of portfolio returns above the returns of a benchmark, usually an index such as the S&P 500, to the volatility of those returns./nThe information ratio is used to evaluate the skill of a portfolio manager at generating returns in excess of a given benchmark./nA higher IR result implies a better portfolio manager who's achieving a higher return in excess of the benchmark, given the risk taken.

Term: Inherent Risk: Definition, Examples, and 3 Types of Audit Risks
Definition: Inherent risk is the risk posed by an error or omission in a financial statement due to a factor other than a failure of internal control./nIn a financial audit, inherent risk is most likely to occur when transactions are complex, or in situations that require a high degree of judgment in regard to financial estimates./nInherent risk is one of the risks auditors and analysts must look for when reviewing financial statements, along with control risk anddetection risk./nInherent risk is common in the financial services sector due to complex regulations and the use of difficult-to-assess financial instruments.

Term: Inheritance: Definition, How It Works, and Taxes
Definition: An inheritance is a financial term describing the assets passed down to individuals after someone dies./nMost inheritances consist of cash that’s parked in a bank account but may contain stocks, bonds, cars, jewelry, automobiles, art, antiques, real estate, and other tangible assets./nThose who receive an inheritance may be subject to inheritance taxes, where the more distantly related a beneficiary is to the decedent, the larger the inheritance tax is likely to be./nSix U.S. states currently impose inheritance taxes: Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Nebraska, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania./nA decedent’s assets are divided according to their will through the probate process. If there is no will, the court will appoint an administrator to divide assets according to state laws.

Term: Inheritance Tax: What It Is, How It's Calculated, and Who Pays It
Definition: Inheritance tax is a levy on assets inherited from a deceased person./nAn inheritance tax is levied on the value of the inheritance received by the beneficiary, and it is paid by the beneficiary./nThere is no federal inheritance tax./nInherited assets may be taxed for residents of Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Nebraska, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania./nWhether you may pay inheritance tax depends on the amount of the inheritance, your relationship to thedecedent, and the state in which the decedent lived.

Term: Inherited IRA: Definition and Tax Rules for Spouses and Non-Spouses
Definition: An inherited IRA, also known as a beneficiary IRA, is an account that you open when you inherit an IRA after the original owner dies./nYou can't make additional contributions to an inherited IRA./nWithdrawals rules vary for spousal and non-spousal beneficiaries./nThe SECURE Act mandated that non-spousal beneficiaries must withdraw all the funds from an inherited IRAs within 10 years./nTraditional IRA owners must take required minimum distributions starting at age 73.

Term: Initial Coin Offering (ICO): Coin Launch Defined, with Examples
Initial Margin: Definition, Minimum Requirements, Example
Definition: Initial margin is the percent of a purchase price that must be paid with cash when using a margin account./nFed regulations currently require that the initial margin is set at a minimum of 50% of a security's purchase price. But brokerages and exchanges can set initial margin requirements higher than the Fed minimum./nInitial margin requirements are different from maintenance margin requirements, which is the percent of equity that must be retained on an ongoing basis in the account.

Term: Inorganic Growth: Definition, How It Arises, Methods, and Example
Definition: Inorganic growth is growth from buying other businesses or opening new locations./nMeanwhile, organic growth is internal growth the company sees from its operations, often measured by same-store or comparable sales./nAcquisitions can help immediately boost a company’s earnings and increase market share./nThe downside of inorganic growth via acquisitions is that implementation of technology or integration of the new employees can take time./nInorganic growth involving the opening of new stores can capitalize on high-traffic areas, but it can also cannibalize existing stores.

Term: Input-Output Analysis: Definition, Main Features, and Types
Definition: Input-output analysis is a macroeconomic analysis based on the interdependencies between different economic sectors or industries./nInput-output analysis is used to estimate the impacts of positive or negative economic shocks and analyzes the ripple effects throughout the economy./nThe use of input-output analysis is not common in the Western world or neoclassical economics but often used in Marxist economics when central planning of an economy is required./nInput-output tables are the foundation of input-output analysis, depicting rows and columns of data that quantify the supply chain for all of the sectors of an economy./nThree types of impacts are modeled in input-output analysis. They are direct impact, indirect impact, and induced impact./nThese impacts on the economy are determined when certain input levels are changed.

Term: INSEAD: What It Means, History, Programs
Definition: INSEAD is one of the world's leading and largest graduate business schools with five campuses and centers around the globe./nThe school offers a variety of graduate programs, including MBAs, a doctorate in management, and a certificate program./nThe school has 165 faculty members and more than 1,500 students enrolled in its graduate degree-granting programs each year.

Term: Indemnity: What It Means in Insurance and the Law
Definition: Indemnity is a comprehensive form of insurance compensation for damage or loss./nIn an indemnity arrangement, one party agrees to pay for potential losses or damage caused by another party./nA typical example is an insurance contract, in which the insurer or the indemnitor agrees to compensate the other (the insured or the indemnitee) for any damage or losses in return for premiums paid by the insured to the insurer.

Term: Understanding an Inside Day Pattern With Example
Definition: An inside day is a common technical chart pattern where the high and low of one day occur inside the high and low of the prior day./nInside days are thought to signal a continuation pattern./nIf trading a breakout from the pattern, the highest probability trades are ones where the overall market direction aligns with the direction into and out of the two-day pattern.

Term: What Is Inside Sales? Definition, How It Works, and Advantages
Definition: An inside sale is the sale of products or services made by personnel who reach customers by phone or online./nOutside sales would instead rely on in-person meetings and physical interaction./nInside and outside sales may be paired for greater efficiency, where they assist each other in tasks, such as lead generation, to increase sales./nPurchasing goods and services online or by phone is increasingly popular among consumers.

Term: Insider Information: Definition, Example, Illegality
Definition: Insider information refers to non-public facts about a publicly-traded company which could provide an advantage to investors./nThe manipulation of insider information to benefit an investor in buying or selling stock is known as insider trading and is illegal./nThe Securities and Exchange Commission regulates legal insider trading.

Term: Insolvencies: Definition, How It Works, and Contributing Factors
Definition: Insolvency is a state of financial distress in which a person or business is unable to pay their debts./nInsolvency is when liabilities are greater than the value of the company, or when a debtor cannot pay the debts they owe./nA company can become insolvent due to a number of situations that lead to poor cash flow./nWhen faced with insolvency, a business or individual can contact creditors directly and restructure debts to pay them off.

Term: Institute For Supply Management (ISM): What It Is, How It Works
Definition: The Institute for Supply Management is a nonprofit supply management association./nThe organization was established in 1915 as the National Association of Purchasing Agents before changing its name in 2002./nIt provides certification, development, education, and research for the supply management and purchasing industries./nISM members can earn the Certified Professional in Supply Management or the Certified Professional in Supplier Diversity./nThe ISM publishes three Purchase Managers' Indexes as part of its ISM Manufacturing Report on Business, which is considered a leading economic indicator.

Term: Installment Debt: Meaning, Types, Pros and Cons
Definition: An installment debt is a loan that is repaid in regular installments, such as most mortgages and car loans./nInstallment loans are good for borrowers as it's a way to finance big-ticket items, while they provide lenders with regular payments./nInstallments loans are generally less risky than other alternative loans that do not have installment payments, such as balloon-payment loans or interest-only loans./nAn installment debt may be a type of personal loan./nYour amortization schedule determines how much you pay in monthly installment debt payments.

Term: What Is Insider Trading and When Is It Legal?
Definition: Insider trading is buying or selling a publicly traded company's stock by someone with non-public, material information about that company./nNon-public, material information is any information that could substantially impact an investor's decision to buy or sell a security that has not been made available to the public./nThis form of insider trading is illegal and has stern penalties, including potential fines and jail time./nInsider transactions are legal as long as you conform to the rules set forth by the SEC.

Term: Institute of Management Accountants (IMA): Meaning, How it Works
Definition: The Institute of Management Accountants (IMA) is a global association for financial professionals and offers the prestigious Certified Management Accountant (CMA) designation./nThe IMA's mission is to promote education and development in management accounting and finance, the highest ethics and best business practices./nAs of Sept. 21, 2022, the IMA had approximately 140,000 members in 150 countries.

Term: I/B/E/S - The Institutional Brokers' Estimate System Explained
Definition: The Institutional Brokers' Estimate System, or IBES, is a database of analyst estimates and company guidance for more than 23,400 public companies./nThe database aggregates all of the available financial data on companies and company sectors to aid in decision-making./nIt features a host of data from equity analyst consensus to forward guidance./nHistorical data is available from 1976 when IBES was introduced, with international data going back to 1987./nIBES is owned today by Thomson Reuters.

Term: Instrument: Definition in Finance, Economics, and Law
Definition: An instrument is an implement with which to store or transfer value or financial obligations./nA financial instrument is a tradable or negotiable asset, security, or contract./nLegal instruments may contain binding terms, rights, and/or obligations.

Term: Institutional Investor: Who They Are and How They Invest
Definition: An institutional investor is a company or organization that invests money on behalf of clients or members./nHedge funds, mutual funds, and endowments are examples of institutional investors./nInstitutional investors are considered savvier than the average investor and are often subject to less regulatory oversight./nThe buying and selling of large positions by institutional investors can create supply and demand imbalances that result in sudden price moves in stocks, bonds, or other assets./nInstitutional investors are the big fish on Wall Street.

Term: Insurable Interest
Definition: Insurable interest is the basis of all insurance policies linking the insured and owner of the policy./nInsurable interest can be an object which, if damaged or destroyed, would result in financial hardship for the policyholder./nTo exercise insurable interest, the policyholder would buy insurance on the item or entity in question./nThe policy must not create a moral hazard, in which a policyholder would have a financial incentive to allow or even cause a loss.

Term: Non-Sufficient Funds (NSF): What It Means & How to Avoid Fees
Definition: A checking account is said to have “non-sufficient funds” (NSF), or "insufficient funds” when it lacks the money needed to cover transactions./nThe acronym NSF also references the fee a customer is charged for presenting a check or payment that cannot be covered by the balance in the account./nConsumers can avoid NSF fees by opting for overdraft protection through their banks.

Term: Insurance Claim
Definition: An insurance claim is a formal request by a policyholder to an insurance company for coverage or compensation for a covered loss or policy event./nThe insurance company validates the claim and, once approved, issues payment to the insured or an approved interested party on behalf of the insured./nFor property-casualty insurance, such as for your car or home, filing a claim can cause rate hikes to your future premiums.

Term: Insurance: Definition, How It Works, and Main Types of Policies
Definition: Insurance is a contract (policy) in which an insurer indemnifies another against losses from specific contingencies or perils./nThere are many types of insurance policies. Life, health, homeowners, and auto are among the most common forms of insurance./nThe core components that make up most insurance policies are the premium, deductible, and policy limits.

Term: Insurance Underwriter: Definition, What Underwriters Do
Definition: Insurance underwriters evaluate the risks involved in insuring people and assets and establish pricing for a risk./nUnderwriters in investment banking guarantee a minimum share price for a company planning an IPO (initial public offering)./nCommercial banking underwriters assess the risk of lending to individuals or lenders and charge interest to cover the cost of assuming that risk./nInsurance underwriters assume the risk of a future event and charge premiums in return for a promise to reimburse the client an amount in the event damage or occurs.

Term: Insurance Premium Defined, How It's Calculated, and Types
Definition: An insurance premium is the amount of money an individual or business must pay for an insurance policy./nInsurance premiums are paid for policies that cover healthcare, auto, home, and life insurance./nFailure to pay the premium on the part of the individual or the business may result in the cancellation of the policy and a loss of coverage./nSome premiums are paid quarterly, monthly, or semi-annually depending on the policy./nShopping around for insurance may help you find affordable premiums.

Term: Insurance Coverage: Major Types and How They Work
Definition: Insurance coverage refers to the amount of risk or liability that is covered for an individual or entity by way of insurance services./nThe most common types of insurance coverage include auto insurance, life insurance and homeowners insurance./nInsurance coverage helps consumers recover financially from unexpected events, such as car accidents or the loss of an income-producing adult supporting a family./nIn exchange for insurance coverage, the insured person is responsible for paying premiums to the insurance company.

Term: Overview of Insurtech & Its Impact on the Insurance Industry
Definition: Insurtech is the use of technology innovations designed to make the current insurance model more efficient./nBy using technology such as data analysis, IoT, and AI, insurtech allows products to be priced more competitively./nInsurtech is used to more effectively process claims, evaluate risk, process contracts, or underwrite policies./nInsurtech is similar to fintech, as both leverage modern solutions that are revolutionizing each respective traditional industry./nThere are headwinds for insurtechs, notably regulation issues and a reluctance of established insurers to work with them.

Term: Intangible Personal Property: Definition, Types, and Example
Definition: Intangible personal property has no physical shape but represents something else of value./nIntellectual property is one of the most common forms of intangible personal property./nSome examples of intangible personal property include image, social, and reputational capital, as well as personal social media pages and other personal digital assets./nCompanies also have intangible property, such as patents, copyrights, life insurance contracts, securities investments, and partnership interests./nIt is the opposite of tangible personal property, such as machinery, jewelry, electronics, and other items can be physically touched and have some level of value assigned to them.

Term: Intellectual Capital: Definition, Types, Measurement, Importance
Definition: Intellectual capital refers to the intangible assets that contribute to a company's bottom line. These assets include the expertise of employees, organizational processes, and the sum of knowledge contained within the organization./nThere is no standard method to measure intellectual capital, and standards for measurement vary across organizations./nIntellectual capital includes human capital, information capital, brand awareness, and instructional capital./nBusinesses can increase intellectual capital by hiring better employees, conducting training programs for employees, and developing new patents.

Term: What Are Intangible Assets? Examples and How to Value
Definition: An intangible asset is an asset that is not physical in nature, such as a patent, brand, trademark, or copyright./nBusinesses can create or acquire intangible assets./nAn intangible asset can be considered indefinite (a brand name, for example) or definite, like a legal agreement or contract./nIntangible assets created by a company do not appear on the balance sheet and have no recorded book value.

Term: Intentionally Defective Grantor Trusts (IDGT) in Estate Planning
Definition: An intentionally defective grantor trust (IDGT) allows a person to isolate certain trust assets to segregate income tax from estate tax treatment./nIt is effectively a grantor trust with a purposeful flaw that ensures the individual continues to pay income taxes./nIDGTs are most often utilized when the trust beneficiaries are children or grandchildren where the grantor has paid income tax on the growth of assets they will inherit.

Term: Inter-American Development Bank (IDB): What it is, How it Works
Definition: Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) is a cooperative bank to help support the economic and social development of Latin America and Caribbean countries./nThe IBD includes 48 countries, including the U.S., and financed $13.6 billion for 94 projects in 2021./nThe funds that the Inter-American Development Bank lends to its member countries are raised in the bond market./nThe U.S. is the IDB’s largest shareholder with a 30% stake.

Term: Interactive Media: Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: Interactive media refers to the ways in which people process and share information./nIt's meant to engage the user and interact with them in a way that non-interactive media does not./nSocial media, virtual reality, and apps are all forms of interactive media. Television and radio are the most common examples of non-interactive media./nInteractive media arose through the Internet revolution of the 1990s and improved technology, such as smartphones./nThe uses of interactive media are far and wide, ranging from education and networking to video games.

Term: Interbank Network for Electronic Transfer (INET) Overview
Definition: Interbank Network for Electronic Transfer (INET) processed MasterCard’s debit and credit card transactions./nINET orchestrated the transfer of funds, while MasterCard’s Interbank National Authorization System (INAS) processed card authorizations./nThe two systems were later combined into Banknet, a single entity tying together all MasterCard data processing centers and issuing members into one financial network.

Term: Interbank Deposit: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: An interbank deposit is an arrangement between two banks in which one holds funds in an account for another institution./nThe arrangement requires that the holding bank open a due to account for the other./nMost interbank trading conducted on the market is proprietary—banks do so usually between and for each other only.

Term: The Interbank Market: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: The interbank market is a global network used by financial institutions to trade currencies and other currency derivatives directly between themselves./nBanks use the interbank market to manage their own exchange rate and interest rate risk./nThey can also use the market to take speculative positions based on research./nMost transactions within the interbank network are for a short duration, anywhere from overnight to six months.

Term: What Is the Interbank Rate? Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: The interbank rate, also known as the federal funds rate, is the interest charged on short-term loans made between financial institutions./nThe term "interbank rate" may also refer to the foreign exchange rates paid by banks when they trade currencies with other banks./nIn either case, these are the lowest rates that can be found at any particular time and are reserved for the big banking institutions.

Term: Intercontinental Exchange (ICE): What It Is and What It Does
Definition: The Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) is an American company that owns and operates financial and commodity marketplaces and exchanges./nICE was founded in 2000 and became a publicly traded company on November 16, 2005; it was added to the Russell 1000 Index on June 30, 2006./nWhen it was founded, the company's primary focus was on energy products; however, through various acquisitions, the company's activities have broadened to include other commodities, foreign cash exchanges, and equity index futures.

Term: Interest: Definition and Types of Fees For Borrowing Money
Definition: Interest is the monetary charge for borrowing money—generally expressed as a percentage, such as an annual percentage rate (APR)./nInterest may be earned by lenders for the use of their funds or paid by borrowers for the use of those funds./nInterest is often considered simple interest (based on the principal amount) or compound interest (based on principal and previously-earned interest)./nInterest is often associated with credit cards, mortgages, car loans, private loans, savings accounts, or penalty assessments./nInterest is highly dependent on macroeconomic policy dictated by the Federal Reserve's Federal funds rate.

Term: Interest Expenses: How They Work, Coverage Ratio Explained
Definition: An interest expense is an accounting item that is incurred due to servicing debt./nInterest expenses are often given favorable tax treatment./nFor companies, the greater the interest expense the greater the potential impact on profitability. Coverage ratios can be used to dig deeper.

Term: Interest-Only Mortgage: Definition, How They Work, Pros and Cons
Definition: An interest-only mortgage is one where you solely make interest payments for the first several years of the loan, as opposed to your payments including both principal and interest./nInterest-only payments may be made for a specified time period, may be given as an option, or may last throughout the duration of the loan (mandating you pay it all back at the end)./nUsually, interest-only loans are structured as a particular type of adjustable-rate mortgage./nWhile interest-only mortgages mean lower payments for a while, they also mean you aren't building up equity, and mean a big jump in payments when the interest-only period ends.

Term: Interest Coverage Ratio: Formula, How It Works, and Example
Definition: The interest coverage ratio is used to measure how well a firm can pay the interest due on outstanding debt./nThe interest coverage ratio is calculated by dividing a company's earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) by its interest expense during a given period./nSome variations of the formula use EBITDA or EBIAT instead of EBIT to calculate the ratio./nGenerally, a higher coverage ratio is better, although the ideal ratio may vary by industry.

Term: Interest Rate Collar: Definition, How It Works, Example
Definition: An interest rate collar uses options contracts to hedge interest rate risk to protect variable rate borrowers against rising rates or lenders against falling rates in the case of a reverse collar./nA collar involves selling a covered call and simultaneously buying a protective put with the same expiration, establishing a floor and a cap on interest rates./nWhile the collar effectively hedges interest rate risk, it also limits any potential upside that would have been conferred by a favorable movement in rates.

Term: Interest Rate Call Option: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: An interest rate call option is a derivative that gives the holder the right, but not the obligation, to pay a fixed rate and to receive a variable rate for a specific period./nInterest rate call options can be put in contrast with interest rate puts./nInterest rate calls are used by lending institutions to lock interest rates offered to borrowers, among other uses./nInvestors who want to hedge a position on a loan in which floating interest rates are paid can use interest rate call options.

Term: Interest Rates: Different Types and What They Mean to Borrowers
Definition: The interest rate is the amount charged on top of the principal by a lender to a borrower for the use of assets./nAn interest rate also applies to the amount earned at a bank or credit union from a deposit account./nMost mortgages use simple interest. However, some loans use compound interest, which is applied to the principal but also to the accumulated interest of previous periods./nA borrower that is considered low-risk by the lender will have a lower interest rate. A loan that is considered high-risk will have a higher interest rate./nThe APY is the interest rate that is earned at a bank or credit union from a savings account or CD. Savings accounts and CDs use compounded interest.

Term: What Is an Interest-Rate Derivative? Definition and Examples
Definition: An interest rate derivative is a financial contract whose value is based on some underlying interest rate or interest-bearing asset./nThese may include interest rate futures, options, swaps, swaptions, and FRA's./nEntities with interest rate risk can use these derivatives to hedge or minimize potential losses that may accompany a change in interest rates.

Term: Interest Rate Differential (IRD) Definition and Examples
Definition: Interest rate differentials (IRDs) simply measure the difference between interest rates of two different instruments./nIRD is most often used in fixed income, forex, and lending markets./nIRD also plays a key role in calculating a currency carry trade.

Term: Interest Rate Options: Definition, How They Work, and Example
Definition: Interest rate options are financialderivativesthat allow investors to hedge or speculate on the directional moves in interest rates. A call option allows investors to profit when rates rise and put options allow investors to profit when rates fall./nInterest rate options are cash-settled, which is the difference between the exercisestrike priceof the option and the exercise settlement value determined by the prevailingspot yield./nInterest rate options have European-style exercise provisions, which means the holder can onlyexercisetheir options at expiration.

Term: Interest Rate Parity (IRP) Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: Interest rate parity is the fundamental equation that governs the relationship between interest rates and currency exchange rates./nThe basic premise of interest rate parity is that hedged returns from investing in different currencies should be the same, regardless of their interest rates./nParity is used by forex traders to find arbitrage opportunities.

Term: What Is an Interest Rate Floor and How Is It Used With a Loan?
Definition: Contracts and loan agreements often include interest rate floors./nInterest rate floors are in contrast to interest rate ceilings or caps./nThere are three common interest rate derivative contracts, with interest rate floors being just one./nIf a variable rate falls below the interest rate floor, the floor is triggered and will be the prevailing rate for the period./nA variable-rate floor is meant to protect a lender by ensuring a minimum interest assessment can be collected each month even if adjustable rates reach 0%.

Term: What Is an Interest Rate Future? Definition and How to Calculate
Definition: Interest rate futures are a financialderivativethat allows exposure to changes in interest rates./nInterest rate futures prices move inversely to interest rates./nInvestors can speculate on the direction of interest rates with interest rate futures or use the contracts to hedge against rate changes./nMost interest rate futures that trade on American exchanges have U.S. Treasury securities as their underlying asset.

Term: Interest Rate Sensitivity: Definition, What It Measures, and Types
Definition: Interest rate sensitivity is how much a fixed-income asset price moves with changes in interest rates./nInterest rates and fixed-income asset prices are inversely correlated./nMore interest rate sensitivity means an asset's price fluctuates more with a change in interest rates./nThe longer the maturity of the asset, the more sensitive the asset to changes in interest rates.

Term: Interest Rate Risk Definition and Impact on Bond Prices
Definition: Interest rate risk is the potential that a change in overall interest rates will reduce the value of a bond or other fixed-rate investment:/nAs interest rates rise bond prices fall, and vice versa. This means that the market price of existing bonds drops to offset the more attractive rates of new bond issues./nInterest rate risk is measured by a fixed income security's duration, with longer-term bonds having a greater price sensitivity to rate changes./nInterest rate risk can be reduced through diversification of bond maturities or hedged using interest rate derivatives.

Term: Intermediate Good: Definition and Examples
Definition: Intermediate goods are products that are used in the production process to make other goods, which are ultimately sold to consumers./nIntermediate goods are sold industry-to-industry for resale or to produce other products./nIntermediate goods are typically used directly by a producer, sold to another company to make another intermediary good, or sold to another company to make a finished product./nWhen calculating gross domestic product (GDP), economists use the value-added approach with intermediate goods to guarantee that they are not counted twice—once when purchased, and once when the final good is sold.

Term: Interest Rate Swap: Definition, Types, and Real-World Example
Definition: Interest rate swaps are forward contracts in which one stream of future interest payments is exchanged for another based on a specified principal amount./nInterest rate swaps can exchange fixed or floating rates to reduce or increase exposure to fluctuations in interest rates./nInterest rate swaps are sometimes called plain vanilla swaps, since they were the original and often the simplest such swap instruments.

Term: What Is an Interim Statement? Definition, Purpose, Example
Definition: Interim statements are financial reports produced by firms covering a period of less than one year./nThe goal is to keep shareholders and analysts more up-to-date and in regular communication with corporate management, and to alert the public to material changes to the company in a timely fashion./nQuarterly reports are commonly used by companies, and may sometimes be mandated by the SEC.

Term: What Is an Interim Dividend? How It's Paid and Who Is Eligible
Definition: An interim dividend is typically one of two dividends given out by a company that is providing shareholders with income on a semi-annual basis./nThe interim dividend is usually paid out ahead of a firm's annual general meeting and the release of the final version of its financial statements./nFinal dividends are paid out after the release of the final version of a company's financial statements./nAs a result, final dividends are paid from current earnings, and interim dividends are paid from retained earnings./nThe company's Board of Directors is responsible for declaring an interim dividend, but whether it's approved or not is up to shareholders.

Term: Internal Auditor (IA): Definition, Process, and Example
Definition: An internal auditor (IA) is a trained professional tasked with providing independent and objective evaluations of company financial and operational business activities./nThey are employed to ensure that companies follow proper procedures and function efficiently./nFinal reports are presented to senior management and can include recommendations.

Term: Internal Audit: What It Is, Different Types, and the 5 Cs
Definition: An internal audit offers risk management and evaluates the effectiveness of many different aspects of the company./nTypes of internal audits include financial, operational, compliance, environmental, IT, or for a very specific purpose./nInternal audits provide management and the board of directors with a value-added service where flaws in a process may be caught and corrected prior to external audits./nSimilar to external audits, internal audits are conducted through planning, auditing, reporting, and monitoring steps./nInternal audits may enhance the efficiency of operations, motivate employees to adhere to company policy, and allow management to explore specific areas of its operations.

Term: Internal Controls: Definition, Types, and Importance
Definition: Internal controls are the mechanisms, rules, and procedures implemented by a company to ensure the integrity of financial and accounting information, promote accountability and prevent fraud./nInternal controls aid companies in complying with laws and regulations, and preventing employees from stealing assets or committing fraud./nThey also can help improve operational efficiency by improving the accuracy and timeliness of financial reporting./nInternal audits play a critical role in a company’s internal controls and corporate governance./nThe Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 made managers legally responsible for the accuracy of their companies' financial statements.

Term: Internal Growth Rate (IGR): Definition, Uses, Formula and Example
Definition: An internal growth rate (IGR) is the highest level of growth achievable for a business without obtaining outside financing./nA firm's maximum internal growth rate is the level of business operations that can continue to fund and grow the company without issuing new equity or debt./nInternal growth can be generated by adding new product lines or expanding existing ones.

Term: Internal Rate of Return (IRR): Formula and Examples
Definition: The internal rate of return (IRR) is the annual rate of growth that an investment is expected to generate./nIRR is calculated using the same concept as net present value (NPV), except it sets the NPV equal to zero./nThe ultimate goal of IRR is to identify the rate of discount, which makes the present value of the sum of annual nominal cash inflows equal to the initial net cash outlay for the investment./nIRR is ideal for analyzing capital budgeting projects to understand and compare potential rates of annual return over time./nIn addition to being used by companies to determine which capital projects to use, IRR can help investors determine the investment return of various assets.

Term: What Is the Internal Revenue Service (IRS)?
Definition: The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is the U.S. government agency responsible for collecting federal taxes and enforcing tax laws./nMost of the work of the IRS involves individual and corporate income taxes./nThe IRS audits taxpayers randomly or after detecting irregularities in tax returns.

Term: Internalization: Definition in Business and Investing With Examples
Definition: The term "internalization" refers to handling transactions or projects internally instead of paying an outside entity to do so./nInternalization occurs at a brokerage when an order to buy securities such as stocks is filled using inventory held by the brokerage./nCompany internalization occurs when some project or transaction is completed in-house, not by an outside vendor./nMultinational internalization can occur when the corporation transfers assets to one of its subsidiaries in need of them./nA benefit of internalization is cost savings.

Term: Understanding International Accounting Standards (IAS)
Definition: International Accounting Standards were replaced in 2001 by the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)/nCurrently, the United States, Japan, and China are the only major capital markets without an IFRS mandate/nThe U.S. accounting standards body has been collaborating with the Financial Accounting Standards Board since 2002 to improve and converge American accounting principles (GAAP) and IFRS.

Term: What Is an International Bank Account Number (IBAN) and How Does It Work
Definition: An international bank account number (IBAN) is a standard international numbering system for individual bank accounts around the world./nBanks in Europe originally developed the system to simplify transactions involving bank accounts from other countries./nAn IBAN is used to identify an individual account involved in an international transaction./nThe IBAN also acts as a method of verifying that transaction details are correct./nSociety for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT)codes are another form of international identification systems, but they differ because SWIFT codes are used to identify a specific bank during an international transaction.

Term: International Bank of Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
Definition: The International Bank of Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) is one of two major institutions that make up the World Bank./nThe IBRD advises countries that are interested in limiting poverty and enabling sustainable development./nIts main focus is on providing financing and economic policy advice to help the leaders of middle-income countries navigate the path toward greater prosperity.

Term: International Banking Facility (IBF): Meaning, Regulations
Definition: International banking facilities (IBFs) allow depository institutions in the U.S. to offer services to foreign residents and institutions free of some Federal Reserve requirements and some state and local income taxes./nIBFs enable U.S. institutions to compete more effectively for foreign-source deposits and loan business./nBanks may conduct their IBF activities in their existing U.S.-based offices, but they must maintain separate IBF accounting books.

Term: International Bond Investing: Definition, Examples, and Risks
Definition: An international bond is generally a debt obligation that is issued by a non-domestic entity in its native currency./nMost international bonds are corporate bonds but some government bonds are investable assets./nInternational bonds offer portfolio diversification but are subject to currency risk.

Term: International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) Definition, Activities
Definition: The International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) is the largest business organization in the world, with 45 million member companies from more than 100 countries./nThe International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) aims to foster international trade and commerce to promote and protect open markets for goods and services and the free flow of capital./nThe ICC performs a number of functions for businesses, including the establishment of rules, dispute resolution, policy advocacy, and training./nThe ICC's vast networks of committees and experts belong to a full range of business sectors and keep members informed of all issues that affect their industries./nThe ICC maintains contact with the United Nations, the World Trade Organization, and other intergovernmental agencies.

Term: What Is International Finance, and Why Is It So Important?
Definition: International finance is the study of monetary interactions that transpire between two or more countries./nInternational finance focuses on areas such as foreign direct investment and currency exchange rates./nIncreased globalization has magnified the importance of international finance./nAn initiative known as the Bretton Woods system emerged from a 1944 conference attended by 40 nations and aims to standardize international monetary exchanges and policies in a broader effort to nurture post World War II economic stability.

Term: International Depository Receipt (IDR): Definition and Uses
Definition: An IDR or ADR is a certificate of ownership of a number of shares in a company that trades on a foreign exchange./nInvesting in IDRs is an alternative to purchasing stock on a foreign exchange./nFor the companies, it enables greater access to foreign investors.

Term: International Finance Corporation (IFC): Definition and Example
Definition: A member of the World Bank Group, the International Finance Corporation (IFC) provides financing for private enterprise investments in developing countries./nThe IFC says its focus is eliminating poverty through economic development, but critics claim it is more focused on profits than people./nIn fiscal year 2021, the IFC invested $31.5 billion in financing initiatives.

Term: What Are International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)?
Definition: International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) were created to bring consistency and integrity to accounting standards and practices, regardless of the company or the country./nThey were issued by the London-based Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and address record keeping, account reporting, and other aspects of financial reporting./nThe IFRS system replaced the International Accounting Standards (IAS) in 2001./nIFRS fosters greater corporate transparency./nIFRS is not used by all countries; for example, the U.S. uses generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).

Term: International Fisher Effect (IFE): Definition, Example, Formula
Definition: The International Fisher Effect (IFE) states that differences in nominal interest rates between countries can be used to predict changes in exchange rates./nAccording to the IFE, countries with higher nominal interest rates experience higher rates of inflation, which will result in currency depreciation against other currencies./nIn practice, evidence for the IFE is mixed and in recent years direct estimation of currency exchange movements from expected inflation is more common.

Term: International Maritime Organization (IMO): Definition and Purpose
Definition: The International Maritime Organization is an agency tasked with improving the security and safety of international shipping./nOne of its key duties is to devise strategies and measures to keep the waterways clean by preventing marine pollution from ships./nThe IMO’s governing body, the Assembly, meets every two years, with the first meeting in 1959./nThe IMO is not responsible for enforcing its policies. When a government accepts an IMO policy, that policy becomes a national law that is the government's responsibility to enforce./nFunding for the IMO comes from contributions by member states, as well as voluntary donations and commercial activities.

Term: International Labor Organization (ILO): Definition and Standards
Definition: The International Labour Organization (ILO) is a United Nations (U.N.) agency./nThe goal of the International Labour Organization (ILO) is to advance social and economic justice by setting international labor standards./nThe conventions and protocols of the International Labour Organization (ILO) are a major contributor to international labor law.

Term: International Bond: Meaning and Examples
Definition: International investing means holding securities issued by companies or governments outside an investor's home country./nThrough global investment, portfolios are more diversified and may enhance returns and reduce portfolio risk./nOwning foreign assets exposes investors to unique risks such as changes in exchange rates, foreign interest rates, and geopolitical events.

Term: What Is the International Monetary Fund (IMF)?
Definition: The IMF's mission is to promote global economic growth and financial stability, encourage international trade, and reduce poverty around the world./nThe IMF was originally created in 1945 as part of the Bretton Woods agreement, which attempted to encourage international financial cooperation by introducing a system of convertible currencies at fixed exchange rates./nThe IMF collects massive amounts of data on national economies, international trade, and the global economy in aggregate and provides economic forecasts./nOne of the IMF's most important functions is to make loans to countries that are experiencing economic distress to prevent or mitigate financial crises.

Term: ISIN: What It Is, How and Why It Is Used
Definition: An ISIN is a 12-digit alphanumeric code that uniquely identifies a specific security./nThe numbers are allocated by a country's respective national numbering agency (NNA)./nAn ISIN is not the same as the ticker symbol, which identifies the stock at the exchange level. The ISIN is a unique number assigned to a security that is universally recognizable./nISINs are used for numerous reasons including clearing and settlement. The numbers ensure a consistent format so that holdings of institutional investors can be tracked consistently across markets worldwide.

Term: What Is the International Organization for Standardization (ISO)?
Definition: The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is an international nongovernmental organization made up of national standards bodies that develops and publishes a wide range of proprietary, industrial, and commercial standards./nThe International Organization for Standardization (ISO) was founded in 1947 and is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland./nIn addition to producing standards, ISO also publishes technical reports, technical specifications, publicly available specifications, technical corrigenda, and guides./nThe ISO plays an important role in facilitating world trade by providing common standards among different countries./nISO standards cover all fields, from healthcare to technology to manufacturing to security to the environment.

Term: Internationalization: Definition, Examples, and Benefits
Definition: Internationalization describes designing a product in a way that it may be readily consumed across multiple countries./nThis process is used by companies looking to expand their global footprint beyond their own domestic market understanding consumers abroad may have different tastes or habits./nInternationalization often requires modifying products to conform to the technical or cultural needs of a given country, such as creating plugs suitable for different types of electrical outlets.

Term: What Is the International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA)?
Definition: The International Swaps and Derivatives Association is a professional association that has been operating since 1985 to promote and improve the trading of swaps and derivatives./nThe ISDA developed a standardized agreement to serve as a template for swaps traders./nThe ISDA sees its mission as reducing counterparty risk, increasing transparency, and improving infrastructure.

Term: What Is the Internet of Things (IoT)? How It Works and Benefits
Interpolated Yield Curve (I Curve): Definition and Uses
Definition: An interpolated yield curve or "I curve" refers to a yield curve that has been plotted using data on the yield and maturities of on-the-run Treasuries./nOn-the-run Treasuries are the most recently issued U.S. Treasury bonds or notes of a specific maturity./nInterpolation refers to the methods used to create new estimated data points between known data points on a graph./nTwo of the most common methods to interpolate a yield curve are bootstrapping and regression analysis./nInvestors and financial analysts often interpolate yield curves in order to gain a better understanding of where the bond markets and the economy might be going in the future.

Term: How to Use Interpersonal Skills to Get and Keep a Job
Definition: Interpersonal skills are behaviors we use to interact with others effectively on the job and in the larger world./nSome people are born with good interpersonal skills but everyone can learn, develop and improve them./nExpressing appreciation, resolving disputes, and listening well are all interpersonal skills worth practicing./nExcellent interpersonal skills in the workplace can enhance camaraderie, improve working results, and supportcareer development./nA lack of solid interpersonal skills can put an employee at a disadvantage where group involvement, desired assignments, positive reviews, and job advancement are concerned.

Term: What Is Interpolation, and How Do Investors and Analysts Use It?
Definition: Interpolation is a simple mathematical method investors use to estimate an unknown price or potential yield of a security or asset by using related known values./nBy using a consistent trend across a set of data points, investors can estimate unknown values and plot these values on charts representing a stock's price movement over time./nOne of the criticisms of using interpolation in investment analysis is that it lacks precision and does not always accurately reflect the volatility of publicly traded stocks.

Term: What Is Intertemporal Choice for Business and Individuals?
Definition: Intertemporal choice refers to decisions, such as spending habits, made in the near-term that can affect future financial opportunities./nTheoretically, by not consuming today, consumption levels could increase significantly in the future, and vice versa./nA preference for focusing on current consumption leads many individuals to make intertemporal choices that accommodate near-term needs and wants.

Term: What Is an Inter-Vivos Trust? Definition, How It Works, and Benefits
Definition: An inter-vivos trust is a living trust created that holds assets of a trustor./nA benefit of an inter-vivos trust is that it helps avoid probate or the legal process of distributing the owner's assets after his or her death./nThe trustor can also be the trustee in an inter-vivos trust during their lifetime or until a backup named in the trust is allowed to take over.

Term: Intestate: Definition and State Rules
Definition: When a person dies intestate, it means they left no legal will./nIf there is no will to go by, a state probate court will determine how the person’s estate will be distributed./nCourts generally establish a hierarchy, with spouses and other close relatives being first in line to receive the assets.

Term: Intraday Momentum Index: Overview, Formula, Examples
Definition: The Intraday Momentum Index (IMI) generates trading signals using relative strength (RSI) in conjunction with candlestick charting./nThe IMI looks at the relationship between a security’s open and close price over the course of the day, rather than how the open/close price varies between days./nTechnical analysts can use the IMI to anticipate when a security is overbought or oversold.

Term: Intrapreneurship: Definition, Duties, and Responsibilities
Definition: Intrapreneurship is a system which allows an employee to act like an entrepreneur within an organization./nIntrapreneurs are self-motivated, proactive, and action-oriented people who have leadership skills and think outside the box./nIntrapreneurship is one step toward entrepreneurship—intrepreneurs can use what they've learned as part of a team to develop their own businesses.

Term: What Are Intrapreneurs? History, Role, and Benefits for a Company
Definition: An intrapreneur works inside a company to develop an innovative idea or project that will enhance the company's future./nThe term "intrapreneur" is a portmanteau of the two words "internal" and "entrepreneur." It was first coined by Gifford Pinchot III and Elizabeth S. Pinchot in a 1978 white paper./nThe intrapreneur is generally given autonomy to work on a project that may have a considerable impact on the company./nOver time, an intrapreneur may turn into an entrepreneur and start their own venture outside of the established organization./nIntrapreneurs are typically highly motivated individuals who have specific skill sets—as well as leadership abilities and an innovative vision that others in the corporation can get behind.

Term: Introducing Broker (IB): Definition, Role, Registration, and Examples
Definition: An introducing broker (IB) serves as a middleman, advising clients on futures investing and, as needed, referring them to brokers who work on the trading floor./nThe role of the IB is similar to that of stockbrokers in the equities market./nThe IB maintains the relationship with the investor while the commission merchant, or trader, handles the transactions and back-office operations.

Term: Intrinsic Value Defined and How It's Determined in Investing and Business
Definition: There are various ways to calculate intrinsic, or true, value./nDiscounted cash flow analysis is used for many intrinsic value calculations./nIntrinsic value is a core concept that value investors use to uncover hidden investment opportunities./nIn options trading, intrinsic value is the difference between the current price of an asset and the strike price of the option./nWhen an asset's market price is below its intrinsic value, it may be a smart investment.

Term: Intraday: Definition, Intraday Trading, and Intraday Strategies
Definition: Intraday is shorthand for securities that trade on the markets during regular business hours and their price movements over a single day./nDay traders pay close attention to intraday price movements and time their trades in an attempt to benefit from short-term price fluctuations./nScalping, range trading, and news-based trading are types of intraday strategies used by traders.

Term: What Is Inventory? Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: Inventory is the raw materials used to produce goods as well as the goods that are available for sale./nIt is classified as a current asset on a company's balance sheet./nThe three types of inventory include raw materials, work-in-progress, and finished goods./nInventory is valued in one of three ways, including the first-in, first-out method; the last-in, first-out method; and the weighted average method./nInventory management allows businesses to minimize inventory costs as they create or receive goods on an as-needed basis.

Term: Inventory Financing: Definition, How It Works, Pros, and Cons
Definition: Inventory financing is credit obtained by businesses to pay for products that aren't intended for immediate sale./nFinancing is collateralized by the inventory it is used to purchase./nInventory financing is often used by smaller privately-owned businesses that don't have access to other options./nBusinesses rely on it to keep cash flow steady, update product lines, increase inventory supplies, and respond to high demand./nAlthough businesses don't have to rely on personal or business credit history and assets to qualify, they may be stressed by additional debt if they're new or struggling.

Term: Inventory Accounting: Definition, How It Works, Advantages
Definition: Inventory accounting determines the specific value of assets at certain stages in their development and production./nThis accounting method ensures an accurate representation of the value of all assets, company-wide./nCareful examination by a company of these values could lead to increased profit margins at each stage of the product.

Term: Inventory Write-Off: Definition as Journal Entry and Example
Definition: An inventory write-off is the formal recognition of a portion of a company's inventory that no longer has value./nWrite-offs typically happen when inventory becomes obsolete, spoils, becomes damaged, or is stolen or lost./nThe two methods of writing off inventory include the direct write off method and the allowance method./nIf inventory only decreases in value, instead of losing it completely, it will be written down instead of written off.

Term: Inventory Management Defined, Plus Methods and Techniques
Definition: Inventory management is the entire process of managing inventories from raw materials to finished products./nInventory management tries to efficiently streamline inventories to avoid both gluts and shortages./nFour major inventory management methods include just-in-time management (JIT), materials requirement planning (MRP), economic order quantity (EOQ) , and days sales of inventory (DSI)./nThere are pros and cons to each of the methods, reviewed below.

Term: Inventory Turnover Ratio: What It Is, How It Works, and Formula
Definition: Inventory turnover measures how efficiently a company uses its inventory by dividing the cost of goods sold by the average inventory value during the period./nInventory turnover ratios are only useful for comparing similar companies, and are particularly important for retailers./nA relatively low inventory turnover ratio may be a sign of weak sales or excess inventory, while a higher ratio signals strong sales but may also indicate inadequate inventory stocking./nAccounting policies, rapid changes in costs, and seasonal factors may distort inventory turnover comparisons.

Term: Inverse Head and Shoulders: What the Pattern Means in Trading
Definition: An inverse head and shoulders is similar to the standard head and shoulders pattern, but inverted./nIt may be used to predict reversals in downtrends./nAn inverse head and shoulders pattern, upon completion, signals a bull market./nInvestors typically enter into a long position when the price rises above the resistance of the neckline.

Term: Inverse ETF: Definition, Comparison to Short Selling, and Example
Definition: An inverse ETF is a fund constructed by using various derivatives to profit from a decline in the value of an underlying benchmark./nInverse ETFs allow investors to make money when the market or the underlying index declines, but without having to sell anything short./nInverse ETFs tend to have higher management fees compared to traditional ETFs./nInverse ETFs are only intended for short holding periods.

Term: What Is Inverse Correlation? How It Works and Example Calculation
Definition: Inverse (or negative) correlation is when two variables in a data set are related such that when one is high the other is low./nEven though two variables may have a strong negative correlation, this does not necessarily imply that the behavior of one has any causal influence on the other./nThe relationship between two variables can change over time and may have periods of positive correlation as well.

Term: New Indications
Definition: New indications refers to news signifying that an existing drug may have a broader range of medical applications./nRepurposing existing drugs in this manner can prove less costly than developing new drugs from scratch./nInvestors often view new indications as a bullish indicator, anticipating that the company in question will have access to new revenue streams at a relatively low cost.

Term: Invested Capital: Definition and How to Calculate Returns (ROIC)
Definition: Invested capital refers to the combined value of equity and debt capital raised by a firm, inclusive of capital leases./nReturn on invested capital (ROIC) measures how well a firm uses its capital to generate profits./nA company's weighted average cost of capital calculates how much invested capital costs the firm to maintain.

Term: Inverted Yield Curve: Definition, What It Can Tell Investors, and Examples
Definition: The yield curve graphically represents yields on similar bonds across a variety of maturities./nAn inverted yield curve occurs when short-term debt instruments have higher yields than long-term instruments of the samecredit riskprofile./nAn inverted yield curve is unusual; it reflects bond investors’ expectations for a decline in longer-term interest rates, typically associated with recessions./nMarket participants and economists use a variety of yield spreads as a proxy for the yield curve.

Term: Investment: How and Where to Invest
Definition: An investment involves using capital in the present to increase an asset's value over time./nInvestment may include bonds, stocks, real estate, or alternative investments./nInvestments can be diversified to reduce risk, though this may reduce the amount of earning potential.

Term: Investing Explained: Types of Investments and How to Get Started
Definition: Investing involves deploying capital (money) toward projects or activities expected to generate a positive return over time./nThe type of returns generated depends on the type of project or asset; real estate can produce both rents and capital gains; many stocks pay quarterly dividends; bonds tend to pay regular interest./nIn investing, risk and return are two sides of the same coin; low risk generally means low expected returns, while higher returns are usually accompanied by higher risk./nInvestors can take the do-it-yourself approach or employ the services of a professional money manager./nWhether buying a security qualifies as investing or speculation depends on four factors—the amount of risk taken, the holding period, the frequency of the investment activity, and the source of returns.

Term: Investment Advisers Act of 1940 Definition, Overview
Definition: Financial advisers must adhere to the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, which calls on them to perform fiduciary duty and act primarily on behalf of their clients./nThe Act imposes upon the adviser the “affirmative duty of ‘utmost good faith’ and full and fair disclosure of material facts” as part of their duty to exercise client loyalty and care./nInvestment advisers are required to pass a qualifying exam and register with a regulatory body as part of the Act.

Term: Investment Advisory Representative (IAR): Definition and Duties
Definition: IARs are individuals employed by or associated with an investment advisor who make recommendations or otherwise give financial or investment advice./nIARs receive compensation by charging fees either on a commission basis, at a flat or hourly rate, or as a percentage of assets under management (AUM)./nIARs must be properly registered, and, at a minimum, complete credentialing exams certified by FINRA and other required regulatory agencies./nIARs are often required to pass the Series 63 and Series 65 exams, though requirements vary by state./nIARs responsibilities include making financial recommendations, managing client accounts, providing advisory services to external parties, or overseeing other IARs.

Term: What Is an Investment Adviser, How Do They Work?
Definition: Investment advisers are financial professionals that make investment recommendations or conduct security analysis in exchange for a fee./nIn the U.S., investment advisers are required to register at the state level, and they also need to register with the SEC if they manage $100 million or more in client assets./nInvestment advisers often have discretionary authority over their clients’ assets and are required to uphold standards of fiduciary responsibility.

Term: Investment Analysis: Definition, Types, and Importance
Definition: Investment analysis involves researching and evaluating a security or an industry to predict its future performance and determine its suitability to a specific investor./nInvestment analysis may also involve evaluating or creating an overall financial strategy./nTypes of investment analysis include bottom-up, top-down, fundamental, and technical.

Term: Investment Bank: What It Is, How It Works, Major Examples
Definition: Investment banks specialize in managing complex financial transactions such as IPOs and mergers for corporate clients./nModern investment banking is typically a division of a bigger bank institution such as Citibank and JPMorgan Chase./nAn ethical wall' is supposed to separate investment banking activities from the company's trading division to prevent conflicts of interest.

Term: Investment Banker: What They Do, Required Skills, and Examples
Definition: An investment banker works for a financial institution and is primarily concerned with raising capital for corporations, governments, or other entities./nThe investment banking field is popular because it is typically well-paid./nInvestment bankers must have excellent number-crunching abilities, strong verbal and written communication skills, and the capacity to work long hours when necessary.

Term: What Is an Investment Center? Definition, Purpose, and Example
Definition: An investment center is a business unit that a firm utilizes with its own capital to generate returns that benefit the firm./nThe financing arm of an automobile maker or department store is a common example of an investment center./nInvestment centers are increasingly important for firms as financialization leads companies to seek profits from investment and lending activities in addition to core production.

Term: Investment Company: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: An investment company is a specialized business that is engaged in the business of investing pooled capital into financial securities./nInvestment companies can be privately or publicly owned, and they engage in the management, sale, and marketing of investment products to the public./nInvestment companies make profits by buying and selling shares, property, bonds, cash, other funds and other assets.

Term: Investment Banking: What It Is, What Investment Bankers Do
Definition: Investment banking deals primarily with raising money for companies, governments, and other entities./nInvestment banking activities include underwriting new debt and equity securities for all types of corporations./nInvestment banks will also facilitate mergers and acquisitions, reorganizations, and broker trades for institutions and private investors./nInvestment bankers work with corporations, governments, and other groups. They plan and manage the financial aspects of large projects./nInvestment banks were legally separated from other types of commercial banks in the United States from 1933 to 1999, when the Glass-Steagall Act that segregated them was repealed.

Term: Investment Club: Definition, Advantages, How To Start One
Definition: An investment club refers to a group of individuals who each contribute money to a pool that is then invested for the shared benefit of the group members./nYou can think of an investment club as a small-scale mutual fund where decisions are made by a committee of non-professional club members./nClubs can be informal or established as a legal entity such as a partnership. Either way, the club may be subject to regulatory oversight and must account for taxes properly.

Term: Investment Company Act of 1940 Definition
Definition: The Investment Company Act of 1940 is an act of Congress that regulates the formation of investment companies and their activities./nThe legislation in the Investment Company Act of 1940 is enforced and regulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)./nCompanies seeking to avoid the product obligations and requirements of the Act may be eligible for an exemption./nThe Act was signed into law by FDR who wanted to protect investors after the Stock Market Crash of 1929 and the Great Depression that followed./nThe Act has gone through many changes over the decades as financial markets have evolved and become more complex.

Term: Investment Consultant Overview: Types, Job Prospects, Pay
Definition: An investment consultant helps clients formulate and put into place investment strategies as well as construct and maintain their portfolios./nAs with other financial advisors, investment consultants actively monitor their client's investments and work with them as their financial objectives change over time to adjust their holdings./nThe job market for personal financial consultants is poised to grow in the next decade (2020-2030)./nBecoming an investment consultant typically requires a college degree and some work experience./nProfessional investment consultants must also be properly licensed to advise clients.

Term: Investment Horizon: Considerations For Your Portfolio
Definition: An investment horizon refers to the length of time that an investor is willing to hold the portfolio./nIt is generally commensurate with the amount of risk that an investor is willing to undertake.

Term: Investment Grade Credit Rating Details: What Does It Mean?
Definition: An investment grade rating signals that a corporate or municipal bond has a relatively low risk of default./nDifferent bond rating agencies have different rating symbols to signify investment-grade bonds./nInvestors and analysts commonly look at grades from rating agencies like Standard & Poor's, Moody's, and Fitch.

Term: Investment Income: Definition, Example, and Tax Treatment
