Definition: A "just say no" defense is a strategy used by boards of directors to discourage hostile takeovers by rejecting outright the takeover bid./nNamed after Nancy Reagan's "Just Say No" anti-drug campaign, this strategy gives the board power to decide whether to accept an acquisition proposal or not./nSuch a stance may be taken to render a takeover impossible or to encourage better offers either from the same bidder or, better yet, from a friendly white knight./nThe legality of a "just say no" defense may depend on whether the target company has a long-term strategy or if the takeover bid undervalues the company./nA "just say no" defense is one of many strategies to prevent hostile takeovers. Others include a poison pill strategy and a white knight strategy.

Term: Just-in-Time (JIT): Definition, Example, and Pros & Cons
Definition: The just-in-time (JIT) inventory system is a management strategy that minimizes inventory and increases efficiency./nJust-in-time manufacturing is also known as the Toyota Production System (TPS) because the car manufacturer Toyota adopted the system in the 1970s./nKanban is a scheduling system often used in conjunction with JIT to avoid overcapacity of work in process./nThe success of the JIT production process relies on steady production, high-quality workmanship, no machine breakdowns, and reliable suppliers./nThe terms short-cycle manufacturing, used by Motorola, and continuous-flow manufacturing, used by IBM, are synonymous with the JIT system.

Term: Justified Wage: What It Means, How It Works, and Examples
Definition: A justified wage is a fair level of compensation paid to an employee that takes into account both market and non-market factors./nThe wage is often higher than the minimum wage in order to allow employers to actively recruit and hire workers./nThe type of work, the skills and experience required, the job duties, and the general state of the economy all come into play when establishing a justified wage for a given position.

Term: K: What It Means, How it Works, Real World Example
Definition: K is added to Nasdaq ticker symbols that don't have voting rights./nK is one of many extensions used by Nasdaq to provide additional information about a security./nK shares, with no voting rights, tend to slightly underperform comparable shares with voting rights.

Term: K-Percent Rule: What It is, How It Works
Definition: The K-Percent Rule was a proposal by economist Milton Friedman that the central bank should increase the money supply by a constant percentage every year./nThe K-Percent Rule proposes to set the money supply growth at a rate equal to the growth of gross domestic product (GDP) each year./nIn the United States, this would typically be in the range of 2-4%, based on historical averages.

Term: K-Ratio: Meaning, Formula and Calculation, Example
Definition: K-ratios measure an equity’s consistency of returns over time, calculated using the value-added monthly index (VAMI)./nThe calculation involves running a linear regression on the logarithmic cumulative return of a Value-Added Monthly Index (VAMI) curve./nThe K-ratio takes into account the returns themselves, but also the order of those returns in measuring risk./nThe ratio measures the return of the security over time and is a good tool to measure the performance of equities because it takes the return trend into account.

Term: Kagi Chart: What It Is, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Kagi charts change direction when there is a price reversal of a specified amount, or more./nThe chart continues to move in that direction until there is price reversal of the specified amount in the other direction./nWhen the price moves above the prior Kagi high the line turns thick (or green) and when the price drops below the prior Kagi low the line turns thin (or red). The line stays thick or thin until the opposite signal occurs./nThe changes in direction, changes in line thickness, as well as other patterns can generate buy and sell signals.

Term: Kairi Relative Index (KRI): Meaning, Example
Definition: The Kairi Relative Index measures the distance between closing prices and a Simple Moving Average (SMA)./nExtreme reading in the KRI are considered buy and sell signals./nExtreme readings will vary by asset, with more volatile assets reaching much higher and lower extremes that more sedate assets./nThe KRI is not an accurate timing signal, and therefore, should be combined with other forms of analysis to generate trade signals.

Term: Kamikaze Defense: What It is, How It Works, Types
Definition: A Kamikaze defense is a defensive strategy sometimes resorted to by a company's management to prevent a takeover by another company./nA Kamikaze defense deliberately inflicts damage on the company to prevent a takeover./nKamikaze defenses include selling the crown jewels, scorched earth policies, and the fat man strategy.

Term: What Is the Kanban System?
Definition: Kanban is an inventory control system used in just-in-time (JIT) manufacturing to track production and to order new shipments of parts and materials./nKanban uses visual cues to prompt the action needed to keep a process flowing./nOne of the main goals of kanban is to limit the buildup of excess inventory at any point on the production line./nKanban also strives to limit bottlenecks by promoting communication and information sharing between individuals and departments./nSuccessful implementation of kanban may lead to reduced expenses, greater customer satisfaction, more efficient processes, and minimized risk due to unforeseen problems.

Term: Kaizen: Understanding the Japanese Business Philosophy
Definition: Kaizen is a Japanese business philosophy that focuses on gradually improving productivity and making a work environment more efficient./nKaizen supports change from any employee at any time./nKaizen translates to change for the better or continuous improvement./nKaizen's small changes can involve quality control, just-in-time delivery, standardized work, the use of efficient equipment, and the elimination of waste./nThe Kaizen methodology underscores that small changes now can have big future impacts.

Term: Kangaroo Bond
Definition: Kangaroo bonds are issued in Australian markets by foreign firms and are denominated in Australian dollars./nCompanies might issue bonds in other currencies to benefit from exposure to that country’s market or interest rates, or to raise cash in the foreign currency./nForeign companies often seek to broaden their investor base by raising funds in other jurisdictions./nThe benefit of kangaroo bonds to Australian investors is that they are not subject to currency risks that they would be if purchasing the same bonds in a foreign currency.

Term: Kappa: What It Means, How It Works, Measurement
Definition: Kappa is the measurement of an option contract's price sensitivity to changes in the volatility of the underlying asset./nKappa, also called vega, is one of the four primary Greek risk measures, so-named after the Greek letters that denote them./nKappa measures risk by calculating the amount that an option contract's price changes in reaction to a 1% change in the implied volatility of the underlying asset./nThis set of risk measures—kappa, theta, gamma, delta—indicates how sensitive an option is to time-value decay, changes in implied volatility, and movements in the price of its underlying security.

Term: Kangaroos: What They are, How They Work, Bond Market
Definition: Kangaroos refer colloquially to the stocks included in the Australian All-Ordinaries Index./nThe All-Ordinaries Index reflects is a benchmark of the aggregate market value of the 500 largest traded companies, by market capitalization./nKangaroos can also refer to Australians dollar-denominated securities, such as bonds issued in Australia by foreign companies.

Term: Karl Marx: His Books, Theories, and Impact
Definition: Karl Marx was a prominent thinker who wrote on topics related to economics, political economy, and society./nBorn in Germany, Marx spent much of his time in London, where he wrote many famous works, including "The Communist Manifesto: and "Das Kapital."/nMarx often collaborated with long-time friend and social theorist Friedrich Engels./nMarx is known for his revolutionary writings favoring socialism and a communist revolution./nWhile Marxism and Marxian economics have been largely rejected by the mainstream today, many of Marx's critiques of capitalism remain relevant today.

Term: Kazakhstan National Fund: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: The Kazakhstan National Fund is a sovereign wealth fund for Kazakhstan that is operated by the National Bank of the Republic of Kazakhstan./nThe Kazakhstan National Fund was established in 2000, primarily to act as a stabilization fund to lessen the impact that volatility in oil, gas, and mineral prices have on the Republic of Kazakhstan./nThe Kazakhstan National Fund is financed from surplus revenues gained from taxes on the development of oil, gas, and mineral reserves.

Term: What Was the Katie Couric Clause?
Definition: The Katie Couric Clause was a slang term used to describe a proposed Securities and Exchange Commission rule regarding the disclosure of executive compensation and the compensation of other select employees./nProposed in 2006, the rule would have required companies to publicly acknowledge the pay of up to three of the highest-paid employees at a company beyond the executive suite./nThe rule would have meant that CBS would have had to disclose the salary for Couric, at the time CBS's highest-paid newscaster./nThe rule received blowback from major media companies and Wall Street firms and was ultimately not adopted./nThe rule was proposed as an extension of already-existent executive compensation laws, which require disclosure of the compensation for CEOs and other key executives./nOther regulations introduced in subsequent years, including Dodd-Frank in 2010, addressed the issue of executive compensation, necessitating greater transparency in terms of corporate spending.

Term: KBW Bank Index: Meaning, Overview, History
Definition: KBW Bank Index tracks the stock prices of prominent banking companies in an attempt to be a bellwether for banking industry watchers./nKBW Bank Index has been around since 1991./nKBW Bank Index includes 24 stocks selected from the largest regional and nationwide banking companies.

Term: Keepwell Agreement: What it is, How it Works, Example
Keep and Pay: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: Keep and pay is a strategy allowing a borrower to retain a nonexempt asset, even after having declared bankruptcy./nKeep and pay requires that the debtor agree to repay their creditor an amount equal to the value of the retained asset./nRules regarding keep and pay vary by state.

Term: Kellogg School of Management Overview
Definition: The Kellogg School of Management is a business school at Northwestern University in Illinois./nIt is considered one of the most prestigious business schools in the United States./nGraduates from the Kellogg School of Management generally pursue careers in the management consulting, technology, and financial services sectors.

Term: Kelley School of Business at Indiana University: Overview
Definition: The Kelley School of Business at Indiana University is a high-ranking business school with campuses in Bloomington and Indianapolis./nThe school offers undergraduate, graduate, MBA, and doctorate degrees along with executive education and certificate programs in person and online./nKelley has more than 130,000 living alumni worldwide.

Term: What Is Keiretsu? Definition, How It Works in Business, and Types
Definition: Keiretsu is a Japanese term referring to a business network made up of different companies, including manufacturers, supply chain partners, distributors, and occasionally financiers./nKeiretsus work together, have close relationships, and sometimes take small equity stakes in each other, all the while remaining operationally independent./nKeiretsus rose to prominence after World War II and the destruction of the Japanese zaibatsu./nA horizontal keiretsu is an alliance of different companies, led by a bank that provides them with finance./nA vertical keiretsu refers to manufacturers, suppliers, and distributors partnering up to cut costs and become more efficient.

Term: Kelly Criterion: Definition, How Formula Works, History, and Goals
Definition: Although used for investing and other applications, the Kelly Criterion formula was originally presented as a system for gambling./nThe Kelly Criterion was formally derived by John Kelly Jr., a scientist at AT&T's Bell Laboratories./nThe formula is used to determine the optimal amount of money to put into a single trade or bet./nSeveral famous investors, including Warren Buffett and Bill Gross, are said to have used the formula for their own investment strategies./nSome argue that an individual investor's constraints can affect the formula's usefulness.

Term: Kenneth Arrow: Who he was, Theorem, Legacy
Definition: Kenneth Arrow was a neoclassical economist noted for his wide-ranging contributions to microeconomic and macroeconomic theory./nArrow was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1972 for his work in general equilibrium and welfare economics./nArrow's major contributions to economic theory include the advances in social choice theory, most notably Arrow's impossibility theorem.

Term: Keltner Channel: Definition, How It Works, and How to Use
Definition: Keltner Channels are volatility-based bands that are placed on either side of an asset's price and can aid in determining the direction of a trend./nThe exponential moving average (EMA) of a Keltner Channel is typically 20 periods, although this can be adjusted if desired./nThe upper and lower bands are typically set two times the average true range (ATR) above and below the EMA, although the multiplier can also be adjusted based on personal preference./nPrice reaching the upper Keltner Channel band is bullish while reaching the lower band is bearish./nThe angle of the Keltner Channel also aids in identifying the trend direction. The price may also oscillate between the upper and lower Keltner Channel bands, which can be interpreted as resistance and support levels.

Term: Kenney Rule
Definition: The Kenney Rule sets a target of unearned premiums to an insurer's policyholders’ surplus of a 2-to-1 ratio./nThe Kenny Rule states that the ratio of policyholders’ surplus to its unearned premium reserve indicates the strength of one insurance company relative to another./nA higher policyholders’ surplus relative to unearned premium means an insurer is financially strong.

Term: Kenneth I. Chenault: Early Life, Education, Accomplishments
Definition: Kenneth I. Chenault is a business executive known for his role as chair and CEO of American Express./nChenault worked with American Express between 1981 and 2018./nMr. Chenault was only one of three African-Americans to serve as a CEO of a Fortune 500 company at the time that he left the company./nChenault joined venture capital firm General Catalyst in 2018 after stepping down from American Express./nHe sits on the board of a number of companies, including Airbnb and Berkshire Hathaway.

Term: Keogh Plan: Definition, Types, Advantages & Disadvantages
Definition: "Keogh plan" is a term used to describe tax-deferred pension plans—either defined-benefit or defined-contribution—used by self-employed individuals./nKeogh plans have more administrative burdens and higher upkeep costs than Simplified Employee Pension (SEP) or 401(k) plans, but the contribution limits are higher, making Keogh plans a popular option for many high-income business owners./nBecause current tax retirement laws do not set apart incorporated and self-employed plan sponsors, the term "Keogh plan" is rarely ever used.

Term: Kenyan Shilling (KES): Overview, History
Definition: The Kenyan shilling (KES) is the national currency of the African nations of Kenya, Sudan, and Somalia./nKES remains one of the most stable currencies in east Africa./nKES circulates in nearby countries as a more stable option to store wealth than the local currencies.

Term: Key Employee: The IRS Term for Highly Compensated Employees
Definition: Key employees are often considered crucial to a company's operations./nKey employees may enjoy monetary bonuses and other benefits./nEmployers may address compensation for key employees in a different manner than other staff members.

Term: Key Currency: What it Means, How it Works, Examples
Definition: Key currencies are stable, globally used currencies in international trade and commerce./nOther countries may peg their own currency to a key currency, or a basket of such monies, and they are often kept as reserves by international central banks./nThe seven key currencies today are the U.S. dollar, the Euro, the British pound, the Japanese yen, the Canadian dollar, the Swiss franc, and the Mexican peso—although other contenders, such as the Chinese yuan, also exist.

Term: Key Person Insurance: Definition, Cost, Types, and How It Works
Definition: Key person insurance is a life insurance policy a company buys on the life of a top executive or another critical individual./nSuch insurance is needed if that person's death would be devastating to the future of the company./nFor small businesses, the key person might be the owner or founder./nThe company pays the insurance premiums and is the policy's beneficiary, should the person die.

Term: Key Money: What it is, How it Works, In Practice
Definition: Key money is sometimes a synonym for a security deposit. Other times it's a bribe./nKey money can be an under-the-table payment in return for an apartment lease in a tough market./nPayment of key money is legal and acceptable in certain commercial lease transactions.

Term: KPIs: What Are Key Performance Indicators? Types and Examples
Definition: Key performance indicators (KPIs) measure a company’s success vs. a set of targets, objectives, or industry peers./nKPIs can be financial, including net profit (or the bottom line, net income), revenues minus certain expenses, or the current ratio (liquidity and cash availability)./nCustomer-focused KPIs generally center on per-customer efficiency, customer satisfaction, and customer retention./nProcess-focused KPIs aim to measure and monitor operational performance across the organization./nBusinesses generally measure and track KPIs through analytics software and reporting tools.

Term: Key Rate: Definition, Types, and Importance
Definition: The key rate determines the lending rates for banks as well as the cost of credit for borrowers./nThe two types of key rates are the discount rate and the federal funds rate./nThe key rate will determine the rate at which banks can borrow in order to maintain their reserve levels./nThe Federal Reserve can influence the rate at which banks can borrow money in order to expand or contract the national economy.

Term: Key Rate Duration: Definition, What It Calculates, and Formula
Definition: The key rate duration calculates the change in a bond's price in relation to a 100-basis-point (1%) change in the yield for a given maturity./nWhen a yield curve has a parallel shift, you can use effective duration, but key rate duration must be used when the yield curve moves in a non-parallel manner, to estimate portfolio value changes./nDuration measures tell you the price risk involved in holding fixed income securities given a change in interest rates.

Term: Key Ratio: Meaning, Example, Pros and Cons
Definition: Key ratios are the primary financial ratios used to illustrate and summarize the current financial condition of a company./nThey are produced by comparing different line items from the subject's financial statements./nAnalysts and investors use key ratios to see how companies stack up against their peers./nThere are plenty of financial ratios at our disposal and determining which are key varies according to opinion and the type of company being analyzed.

Term: Keynesian Put
Definition: A Keynesian put is a bet that anticipates a government policy change that will boost the economy in general, and certain investments specifically./nThe term was coined by Bank of America Merrill Lynch analysts in 2016./nA Keynesian put represents the expectation that the government or monetary authorities will spend to maintain growth and inflation in the economy.

Term: Keynesian Economics: Theory and How It's Used
Definition: Keynesian economics advocates using active government policy to manage aggregate demand to address or prevent economic recessions./nThe thrust of Keynesian economics is that government intervention can support and strengthen the economy./nJohn Maynard Keynesdeveloped his theories in response to the Great Depression./nHe was highly critical of previous economic theories, which he referred to as classical economics./nActivist fiscal and monetary policies are the primary tools recommended by Keynesian economists to manage the economy and fight unemployment.

Term: Keystone XL Pipeline: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The Keystone Pipeline was proposed by TC Energy (formerly TransCanadian Corp.) in 2005 to transport new finds of hard-to-extract heavy oil from oil sands in Canada to U.S. refiners./nThe pipeline system is 2,687 miles (4,324 km) long./nKeystone has been controversial for many years due to concerns about its local and global environmental impacts./nOn Jan. 20, 2021, President Joe Biden rescinded the construction permit for the Keystone XL pipeline.

Term: Kickback Definition, How It Works, and Examples
Definition: A kickback is an illegal payment intended as compensation for preferential treatment or any other type of improper services received./nKickbacks are often referred to as a type of bribery./nKickbacks can take many forms but they all feature some sort of collusion between two parties./nPaying or receiving kickbacks is a corrupt practice that interferes with an employee's or a public official’s ability to make unbiased decisions.

Term: Kicker Pattern: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A kicker pattern is a type of candlestick pattern that predicts a change in the direction of an asset's price trend./nThis pattern is characterized by a sharp reversal in price over the span of two candlesticks./nTraders use kicker patterns to determine which group of market participants is in control of the direction./nThe pattern points to a strong change in investors' attitudes towards a security that typically follows the release of valuable information about a company, industry, or economy./nKicker patterns are either bullish or bearish.

Term: Kicker: What it is, How it Works, and Types
Definition: A kicker, also known as a sweetener or a wrinkle, is a feature added to a debt instrument that makes it more desirable to prospective lenders or investors./nKickers provide investors with an extra incentive to purchase debt securities (such as a preferred share or bond) because they add to the investors' expected return on investment (ROI)./nTwo popular types of equity kickers are convertible bonds and warrants to purchase stocks./nFor investment real estate loans, a common type of kicker is for the borrower to offer the lender a share of the total income or gross rental receipts generated from the investment property.

Term: Kicking The Tires: Meaning, Examples, Pros and Cons
Definition: Kicking the tires involves conducting a minimal amount of research before making an investment decision./nTaken from the context of car shopping, it is the opposite of conducting serious, in-depth research or due diligence./nKicking the tires can nonetheless be a valid strategy as it cuts down on time and effort in conducting research by performing some cursory analysis, but can also lead investors astray with incomplete or wrong conclusions.

Term: Kids in Parents' Pockets Eroding Retirement Savings (KIPPERS)
Definition: Kids in Parents' Pockets Eroding Retirement Savings (KIPPERS) is a slang term for adult children who are still living at home with their parents even after finishing school and reaching working age./nParents may enjoy having their KIPPERS at home, but it can cause a financial strain due to the added costs of housing one or more children./nIt may also force them to delay their own big decisions, such as downsizing, moving to a better climate, and retiring./nParents should help their KIPPERS prepare for independent life by establishing rules, charging rent, and helping them manage costs and debt.

Term: Kiddie Tax: What It Is, How It Works, and When It Applies
Definition: The kiddie tax prevents parents from avoiding taxes by transferring large gifts of stock./nAll unearned income over the threshold is taxed at the parent’s marginal income tax rate rather than the lower child’s tax rate./nIt applies to all children who are 18 years of age or under—or dependent full-time students between the ages of 19 and 24./nThe kiddie tax applies to most unearned income that a child receives and does not apply to any salary or wages./nIn 2023, unearned income under $1,250 qualifies for the standard deduction under kiddie tax law.

Term: Kijun-Sen (Base Line): Overview, Formulas, Calculations
Definition: Kijun-sen also means "base line" and is the mid-point of the 26-period high and low./nKijun-sen is typically used in conjunction with Tenkan-sen (conversion line)—the 9-period midpoint price—to generate trade signals when they cross./nKijun-sen is typically used in conjunction with the other Ichimoku indicators./nWhen the price is above Kijun-sen then short- to medium-term price momentum is up. If the price is below Kijun-sen then price momentum is down.

Term: Kijun Line (Base Line): Definition, Formula, Trading Strategies
Definition: When the price is above the Kijun Line it indicates the recent pricemomentumis to the upside. When the price is below the Kijun Line, recent price momentum is to the downside./nThe Kijun Line and Tenkan Line are used together to generate trade signals./nThe Base Line is the midpoint price of the last 26 periods./nThe Kijun Line is one of five components of the Ichimoku indicator.

Term: Killer Bees
Definition: Killer bees are companies or individuals that help target firms avoid being taken over./nTheir job is to devise anti-takeoverdefense strategies that make the target more difficult or costly to acquire./nKiller bees rose to prominence during the 1980s when corporate America came under attack from opportunistic investors known as raiders./nThe strategies killer bees employ are often controversial, frequently questioned by shareholders, and risk being overturned by the courts.

Term: Killer Application: What It Means, How It Works, Value
Definition: A killer application is a feature or piece of software so good that it drives sales and growth of the overall platform or company, similar to flagship products and brands in traditional industries./nKiller applications can be a major source of competitive advantage, brand loyalty, and profitability for a company./nIn the modern economy, killer applications are sought by all kinds of businesses across many industries beyond technology and computing.

Term: Kin: What It Was, How It Worked, and Future
Definition: Kin was the cryptocurrency offered by the messaging service Kik, launched via an ICO in 2017./nThe Kin ICO raised roughly $100 million./nKik had a key advantage over certain cryptocurrency competitors as it already had millions of active users through its messaging platform./nThe Kin Foundation shut its doors in 2023 to fully decentralize the cryptocurrency and blockchain.

Term: Kimchi Premium: A Crypto Investor's Overview
Definition: The kimchi premium is the gap in cryptocurrency prices in South Korean exchanges compared to foreign exchanges./nThe price difference may be caused by a lack of high-return investment options for investors in South Korea./nInvestors in South Korea can only profit from the kimchi premium by purchasing bitcoin outside of and reselling it in South Korea./nCapital controls and financial regulations make profiting from the kimchi premium difficult for South Korean investors.

Term: What Is a Kiosk? Definition in Retail, History, Types, and Risks
Definition: A kiosk refers to a small, temporary, stand-alone booth used in high-traffic areas for marketing purposes./nKiosks may be manned by one or two individuals or may be electronic./nThese booths are considered to be low-cost marketing strategies that are great alternatives for new, emerging entrepreneurs./nThe different types of kiosks include employment kiosks, foodservice kiosks, healthcare kiosks, Bitcoin kiosks, and photo kiosks./nKiosks can help raise brand awareness and provide an interactive way for consumers to engage with a company. They can also be frustrating if they are not maintained properly thereby hurting a brand's image.

Term: Kiting Definition, How It Works With Checks and Securities
Definition: Kiting involves the illegal use of financial instruments to fraudulently obtain additional credit./nSecurities firms "kite" if they fail to follow SEC rules around obtaining securities in a timely way./nCheck kiting targets banks or retailers through a series of bad checks, sometimes drawn on multiple accounts.

Term: NZD (New Zealand Dollar): What it is, How it Works, FAQs
Definition: The New Zealand currency is known as the New Zealand dollar (NZD)./nNew Zealand used to use the British monetary format, which was pounds, shilling, and pence, until 1967, when it switched to dollar-based money./nThe New Zealand dollar went through a series of changes in a fixed exchange rate with the U.S. dollar until March of 1985 when the currency was allowed to float freely./nSince 1999, the New Zealand government has produced polymer or plastic versions of the New Zealand dollar, which has made the note more secure against counterfeiting.

Term: Kiwi Bond
Definition: A kiwi bond is a type of security offered directly to the public and available only to New Zealand residents./nKiwi bonds are denominated in New Zealand dollars with a fixed interest rate that is paid quarterly in arrears./nMaturity dates for bonds are six-months, one-year, two-years, and four-years./nInvestors can purchase bonds for as little as NZ$1,000, with a maximum investment of NZ$500,000 on any single issue.

Term: Comorian Franc (KMF): What It is, History
Definition: The Comorian franc is the official currency of the African island nation of Comoros./nThe Comoros franc is pegged to the euro at an effective rate of about 492 KMF to 1 EUR./nOne franc is divided into 100 centimes, although no centimes have ever been issued./nComoros is one of the poorest countries in the world,with high unemployment and low levels of education.

Term: What Is a Knock-Out Option? How It Works, 2 Types, Pros & Cons
Definition: Knock-out options are a type of barrier option, which expires worthless if the underlying asset's price exceeds or falls below a specified price./nThe two types of knock-out options are up-and-out barrier options and down-and-out options./nKnock-out options limit losses, but also potential profits.

Term: Know Sure Thing (KST) Definition, Calculation, Example
Definition: The Know Sure Thing (KST) is a momentum oscillator intended to interpret rate-of-change price data./nTrading signals are generated when the KST crosses over the signal line, but traders also look for overbought or oversold conditions./nTraders also combine the KST with other technical analysis to maximize their odds of a successful trade.

Term: Knock-In Option Explained, With Different Types, Examples
Definition: A knock-in option is a type of barrier option which is triggered only after the underlying asset's price reaches a certain specified barrier./nThere are two types of knock-in options: down-and-in and up-and-in. In the former, the option is triggered only if the underlying asset's price falls below a certain level. The latter type of option is triggered only after an underlying asset's price rises to a certain level.

Term: Know Your Client (KYC): What It Means, Compliance Requirements
Definition: Know Your Client (KYC) is a standard used in the investment and financial services industry to verify customers and know their risk and financial profiles./nThree components of KYC include the customer identification program (CIP), customer due diligence (CDD), and enhanced due diligence (EDD)./nThe SEC requires that each new customer provide detailed financial information before opening an investment or banking account.

Term: Knowledge Capital: Meaning, Components, Uses
Definition: Knowledge capital is the value of an organization made up of its knowledge, relationships, learned techniques, procedures, and innovations./nKnowledge capita is intangible, provides great value for a company, and gives it a competitive edge over rivals./nHuman capital, relational capital, and structural capital are three components of knowledge capital./nKnowledge capital requires a great investment of time and money because it depreciates./nCompanies can invest in knowledge capital through training, education, and innovation.

Term: What Is the Knowledge Economy? Definition, Criteria, and Example
Definition: The knowledge economy describes the contemporary commercialization of science and academic scholarship./nIn the knowledge economy, innovation based on research is commodified via patents and other forms of intellectual property./nThe knowledge economy lies at the intersection of private entrepreneurship, academia, and government-sponsored research./nKnowledge-related industries represent a large share of the activity in most highly developed countries./nA knowledge economy depends on skilled labor and education, strong communications networks, and institutional structures that incentivize innovation.

Term: What Is Knowledge Process Outsourcing (KPO) and How Does It Work?
Definition: Knowledge process outsourcing (KPO) contracts out knowledge-based work to qualified subject matter experts./nCompanies utilize KPO when they are looking for specialized knowledge and expertise and when they have a shortage of skilled professionals on staff./nIdeally, companies look to KPO to simultaneously obtain a highly skilled workforce at a lower cost.

Term: Knowledge Engineering: What it Means, Examples
Definition: Knowledge engineering is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that develops rules that are applied to data in order to imitate the thought process of a human that is an expert on a specific topic./nIn its initial form, knowledge engineering focused on the transfer process; transferring the expertise of a problem-solving human into a program that could take the same data and make the same conclusions./nIt was determined that transfer processing had its limitations, as it did not accurately reflect how humans make decisions. It did not consider intuition and gut feeling, known as analogous reasoning and nonlinear thinking, that often may not be logical./nToday, knowledge engineering uses a modeling process that creates a system that touches upon the same results as the expert without following the same path or using the same information sources./nThe goal of knowledge engineering is for it to be implemented into software that will make decisions that human experts would, such as financial advisors./nKnowledge engineering is already being used in decision support software and it is expected that at some point it will be used to make better decisions than human experts.

Term: Kontradieff Waves: Definition, Past Cycles, How They Work
Definition: Kondratieff Wave - also known as super-cycles, K-waves, surges, and long waves - refers to cycles, lasting about 40 to 60 years, experienced by capitalist economies./nA Kondratieff Wave is a long-term economic cycle, indicated by periods of evolution and self-correction, brought about by technological innovation that results in a long period of prosperity./nKondratieff Waves, a theory rejected in Kondratieff's home country, are relegated to a branch of economics called "heterodox economics," meaning that it does not conform to the widely accepted, orthodox theories espoused by economists.

Term: Kondratiev Wave: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Kondratiev Waves are apparent long-term (~50 year) wave-like patterns in certain statistically-transformed economic time series data./nKondratiev Waves were originally described by agricultural economist Nicolai Kondratiev and have since been studied by other economists and financial commentators./nKondratiev’s theory is not generally accepted by economists and can easily be explained as a statistical illusion created by his transformations of the raw data.

Term: KOF Economic Barometer: Meaning, History
Definition: The KOF Economic Barometer is a composite leading indicator of Swiss GDP growth./nThe current version of the Barometer is constructed of an aggregate of over 200 economic variables related to the Swiss economy./nInvestors and financial traders use the KO Economic Barometer to inform decisions regarding Swiss investments.

Term: Korea Investment Corporation (KIC): What It is, How It Works
Definition: The Korea Investment Fund (KIC) is the sovereign wealth fund for the nation of South Korea./nThe fund was established in 2005 and has grown to be among the top 15 largest sovereign wealth funds in the world./nThe KIC has the initiative to increase its allocation to sustainable investments by 2035.

Term: Korea Stock Exchange (KRX): Meaning, History, Examples
Definition: Previously a standalone stock market, today, the Korea Stock Exchange is a division of the much larger Korea Exchange (KRX)./nKRX's electronic trading platform is KOSDAQ, which is similar to the Nasdaq in the U.S.; the KOSPI, like the S&P 500, tracks the health of the exchange./nSouth Korea's economy is attractive to some because of its stability and rapid growth rates./nHowever, there are many risks that investors should consider before committing capital to the region./nThe easiest way to invest in Korea is via exchange traded funds.

Term: Krugerrands: Gold Coins Minted by South Africa
Definition: Krugerrands are South African gold coins that were minted in 1967./nKrugerrands accounted for 90% of the world’s gold-coin market in 1980, at the peak of the gold market./nKrugerrands remain popular among gold investors today, despite South Africa's slumping gold production.

Term: KSOP: What It Means, How It Works, Other Options
Definition: A KSOP is a qualified retirement plan that combines an employee stock ownership plan (ESOP) with a 401(k)./nCompanies that offer these plans match employee contributions with stock rather than cash./nKSOPs are defined-benefit plans as companies can reduce the administrative expenses of operating separate ESOPs and 401(k)s./nThere are lower upfront costs associated with KSOPs./nKSOPs bring additional risk to plan holders above and beyond those associated with 401(k)s.

Term: Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE): What it is, How it Works
Definition: The Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange is a Malaysian stock exchange now known as Bursa Malaysia./nIt is one of the largest exchanges in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and is fully automated./nEquities, exchange traded funds, offshore Islamic assets, and other securities are listed on the exchange./nThe exchange's main index is the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI, which is composed of the top 30 companies on the Bursa Malaysia Exchange.

Term: Kuwait Investment Authority: What It is, How it Works
Definition: The Kuwait Investment Authority is a government-owned corporation that manages the sovereign wealth fund of Kuwait./nThe KIA was established to manage government revenue, which primarily consists of the profits from Kuwait's oil reserves./nThe fund invests in private and public equity, real estate, fixed income, and alternative investment markets./nIt is divided into two segments: the General Reserve Fund and the Future Generations Fund.

Term: Kurtosis: Definition, Types, and Importance
Definition: Kurtosis describes the “fatness” of the tails found in probability distributions./nThere are three kurtosis categories: mesokurtic (normal), platykurtic (less than normal), and leptokurtic (more than normal)./nKurtosis risk is a measurement of how often an investment’s price moves dramatically./nA curve’s kurtosis characteristic tells you how much kurtosis risk there is for the investment you’re evaluating.

Term: What Is Kuwaiti Currency? KWD (Kuwaiti Dinar) Defined and History
Definition: The Kuwaiti dinar (KWD) is the currency of the State of Kuwait, and as of 2023 is one of the most valuable currency on Earth./nThe currency fluctuates in a relatively small range and is pegged to an undisclosed basket of currencies./nThe economy of Kuwait is heavily reliant on oil, making it one of the wealthiest nations in the world./nSince its official release in 1961, the KWD has gone through six different versions./nAs of December 2023, one Kuwaiti dinar is equal to approximately $3.25 U.S. dollars.

Term: Cayman Islands Dollar (KYD): Meaning, History, Example
Definition: KYD is the currency abbreviation or currency symbol for the Cayman Islands dollar (KYD), the currency for the Cayman Islands./nThe currency relies on a fixed exchange rate pegged to the U.S. dollar at KYD $1 = USD $1.20/nKYD has two recognized symbols that are used locally: $ and CI$.

Term: What Is The Kyoto Protocol? Definition, History, Timeline, and Status
Definition: The Kyoto Protocol was an international agreement that called for industrialized nations to reduce their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions significantly./nOther accords, like the Doha Amendment, also aimed to compel countries to mobilize against the climate crisis./nThe Paris Climate Agreement of 2015 replaced the Kyoto Protocol and included commitments from all major GHG-emitting countries to reduce their climate-altering pollution./nIn 2020, the U.S. withdrew from the Paris Agreement on the grounds that the mandate was unfair and would hurt the U.S. economy; it rejoined the accord in 2021.

Term: L Share Annuity Class: Meaning, How it Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: L share annuities are a class of variable annuity that allows for shorter surrender periods, typically 3-4 years./nOther variable annuity classes typically have surrender periods of up to 10 or more years./nHowever, the benefit of earlier access to withdraw funds from the annuity without penalty comes with higher administrative charges.

Term: Labor Intensive: Definition and Examples
Definition: Labor intensive refers to a process or industry that requires a large amount of labor to produce its goods or services./nLabor costs encompass all of the costs necessary to secure the human capital necessary to complete work./nIn labor-intensive industries, the costs associated with securing the necessary personnel outweigh the capital costs with regard to importance and volume.

Term: What Is Labor Market Flexibility, What Factors Impact It?
Definition: Labor market flexibility allows companies to make decisions about their labor force in response to market changes and to help boost production./nFlexible labor markets allow companies to make changes such as employee hiring and firing, compensation and benefits, and working hours and conditions./nLaws and regulations prevent employers from making changes at will./nOther factors that impact labor market flexibility include labor unions, skills and training, minimum wage restrictions, and job information.

Term: Labor Market Explained: Theories and Who Is Included
Definition: The labor market refers to the supply of and demand for labor, for which employees provide the supply and employers provide the demand./nThe labor market should be viewed at macroeconomic and microeconomic levels because each offers valuable insight into employment and the economy as a whole./nUnemployment rates and labor productivity rates are two important macroeconomic gauges./nIndividual wages and the number of hours worked are two important microeconomic gauges./nIn the United States, the Bureau of Labor Statistics compiles detailed reports on national and local labor markets.

Term: Labor Productivity: What It Is, How to Calculate & Improve It
Definition: Labor productivity measures output per labor hour./nLabor productivity is largely driven by investment in capital, technological progress, and human capital development./nBusiness and government can increase labor productivity of workers by direct investing in or creating incentives for increases in technology and human or physical capital.

Term: Labor Theory of Value
Definition: The labor theory of value (LTV) states that the value of economic goods derives from the amount of labor necessary to produce them./nIn the labor theory of value, relative prices between goods are explained by and expected to tend toward a "natural price," which reflects the relative amount of labor that goes into producing them./nIn economics, the labor theory of value became dominant over the subjective theory of value during the 18th to 19th centuries but was then replaced by it during the Subjectivist Revolution.

Term: Labor Union: Definition, History, and Examples
Definition: A labor union represents the collective interests of workers, bargaining with employers over wages and working conditions./nModern labor unions have local chapters which operate under charters from a national organization./nU.S. law requires an employer to actively bargain with a union in good faith. The employer is not required to agree to any specific terms.

Term: Laddering: Meaning, Overview, Examples, FAQ
Definition: Laddering is a financial term commonly used in retirement planning, where it refers to a method for reducing interest rate and reinvestment risk./nLaddering is also used in the securities underwriting market to describe an illegal practice that benefits insiders at the expense of regular investors./nA bond ladder is a series of bonds with particular maturities that are each held to maturity and whose proceeds are reinvested in a new, longer-term bonds to maintain the ladder's length./nBond ladders are used to generate fixed income cash flow and manage certain risks.

Term: Laffer Curve: History and Critique
Definition: American economist Arthur Laffer developed a bell-curve analysis in 1974 known as the Laffer curve./nThe Laffer curve shows the relationship between tax rates and total tax revenue./nThe Laffer curve states that total tax revenue is most likely not maximized when tax rates are at 100% because this disincentivizes workers from earning wages./nThe Laffer curve was used as a basis for tax cuts in the 1980s during the Reagan Administration./nCritics argue that the Laffer curve is too simplistic and that it uses a single tax rate.

Term: Laggard: What it Means, How it Works, Risks
Definition: A laggard underperforms its benchmark, in terms of an investment's returns./nIf an investor holds laggards in their portfolio, these are generally the first candidates for selling./nInvestors may mistake a laggard for a bargain, but these will carry excess risk.

Term: Lagging Indicator: Economic, Business, and Technical
Definition: A lagging indicator changes after a change in the economic, financial, or business variable with which it is correlated./nSome examples of lagging economic indicators include the unemployment rate, corporate profits, and labor cost per unit of output./nLagging technical indicators trail the price action of an underlying asset and are used to generate signals or confirm the strength of a trend./nIn business, lagging indicators reflect the impact of past management decisions or changes in business strategy./nLagging indicators differ from leading indicators, such as retail sales and the stock market, which are used to forecast and make predictions.

Term: Lambda: What it is, How it Works, Application
Definition: Lambda values identify the amount of leverage employed by an option./nIt is considered one of the "Minor Greeks" in financial literature. This measure is usually found by working with delta./nThe measure is sensitive to changes in volatility but it is not calculated the same as vega.

Term: What Is a Laissez-Faire Economy, and How Does It Work?
Definition: Laissez-faire is an economic philosophy of free-market capitalism that opposes government intervention./nThe theory of laissez-faire was developed by the French Physiocrats during the 18th century./nLaissez-faire advocates that economic success is inhibited when governments are involved in business and markets./nLater free-market economists built on the ideas of laissez-faire as a path to economic prosperity, though detractors have criticized it for promoting inequality./nCritics argue that markets do need a certain degree of government regulation and involvement.

Term: What Is Land? Definition in Business, Valuation, and Main Uses
Definition: Land can refer to real estate or property that is designated by fixed spatial boundaries./nIn economics, land is a primary factor of production, along with capital and labor./nLand itself is a valuable resource but if it contains natural resources such as oil and gas, its value can increase./nInvesting in land for development can be costly and may come with certain risks but it can also be a source of profits and value appreciation./nLand is used for residential, commercial, industrial, recreational, agricultural, and tranportational purposes.

Term: Lancaster University Management School (LUMS) Definition
Definition: Lancaster University's Management School is a U.K.-based business school offering higher education programs./nLUMS is often ranked among the best business schools in the U.K./nLUMS is accredited by four bodies, including the AACSB, EQUIS, AMBA, and the Small Business Charter.

Term: Land Trust: What It Is, How It Works, Types, and Examples
Definition: Land trusts are organizations that take legal ownership, stewardship, or partial control over property at the request of the landowner./nTitle-holding land trusts, also known as Illinois land trusts, protect landowner anonymity and keep property out of probate./nHowever, liability and privacy protections aren't always guaranteed, and there's a risk of losing redemption rights and being disqualified from secondary market loans./nLand trusts are commonly used by real estate investors and estate planning property owners./nAnother form of land trust is a conservation land trust, used for managing undeveloped land to maintain natural resources, historical sites, and public recreational areas.

Term: Land Value Tax: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A land value tax (LVT) is a method of assessing property taxes that only considers the value of the land itself and related improvements, and not the structures built on the land./nAn LVT is considered to be a more fair method of land taxation for agricultural regions where the land is productive./nLand value taxes are examples of ad valorem taxation and are favored by some economists since land value tends to be more stable than that of houses or other buildings.

Term: Land Value Definition, How It is Determined
Definition: Land value is the value of the land, as well as any improvements that have been made to it./nAlways use an appraiser when assessing land value, as they are professionals at determining potential advantages or disadvantages for each individual property./nLand value is not the same as the site value./nTypically, land value is determined by a third-party appraiser.

Term: Lapping Scheme: How to Detect and Prevent
Definition: A lapping scheme is a form of accounting fraud whereby stolen or misappropriated cash is obscured by an employee who altes the accounts receivable./nA forensic accounting audit of cash receipts can be undertaken to reveal a lapping scheme, which may show increased age of accounts receivables./nA company can take several simple steps to prevent the opportunity of this type of fraud in the workplace.

Term: Landlord: Duties, Responsibilities, and Rights
Definition: A landlord is a person or entity which owns real property and then leases it out to tenants in return for rent payment./nA landlord can rent to either residential or commercial tenants depending on zoning restrictions and type of property./nLandlords and tenants are bound by a lease agreement, which is a legal contract specifying the rights and responsibilities of each party./nBeing a landlord can generate passive rental income, but can also come with unforeseen costs and unique legal and financial risks./nLandlords are not allowed to discriminate (based on things like race or sexual orientation), enter the property without proper notice, evict a tenant improperly, and raise rents without notice.

Term: Landlocked: Definition in Real Estate and Easement Solution
Definition: Landlocked in the context of real estate refers to a piece of property that is inaccessible via public thoroughfare, except through an adjacent lot./nLandlocked property is locked up, meaning it's surrounded by other property, and only accessible through the property that surrounds it./nLandlocked parcels are typically the result of subdivisions or the division of a larger parcel of land into smaller parcels, which are sold off individually./nOwners of a landlocked property can obtain an easement, which grants the right to cross over neighboring land to access the public road.

Term: Lapse: Definition, How It Works With Insurance, and Consequences
Definition: A lapse occurs when the benefits and rights stated in a contract no longer remain active due to the contract holder failing to honor requirements and conditions set forth by a contract or agreement./nA lapse can occur, for instance, due to inaction, the passage of time, or failure to pay what is due./nA stock option lapses when not executed according to the terms of the option contract./nInsurance rates are generally higher for policyholders with lapsed coverage./nMost policies can be reinstated within the policy's grace period.

Term: What Is a Large Cap (Big Cap) Stock? Definition and How to Invest
Definition: Large-cap (sometimes called "big cap") refers to a company with a market capitalization value of more than $10 billion./nLarge-cap is a shortened version of the term "large market capitalization."/nMarket capitalization is calculated by multiplying the number of a company's shares outstanding by its stock price per share./nLarge-cap stocks represent a significant portion of the U.S. equity market and are often used as core portfolio holdings.

Term: Large Trader: What it is, How it Works, Special Considerations
Definition: A large trader is an investor or organization whose trades equal or exceed volume and market value thresholds established by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)./nLarge traders are generally professional market participants and institutional investors that have the ability to buy and sell large blocks of securities./nMutual funds, pension funds, hedge funds, banks, and insurance companies often fall into the category of large traders./nThe SEC identifies large traders as any trader whose transactions in National Market Securities (NMS) equals or exceeds two million shares or $20 million during any calendar day, or 20 million shares or $200 million during any calendar month./nThe SEC monitors the activity of large traders in order to analyze the impact of their activity on the markets, to identify activity that breaks securities laws, and to protect investors from manipulative market practices.

Term: Last In, First Out (LIFO): The Inventory Cost Method Explained
Definition: Last in, first out (LIFO) is a method used to account for inventory./nUnder LIFO, the costs of the most recent products purchased (or produced) are the first to be expensed./nLIFO is used only in the United States and is permitted under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP)./nLIFO accounting can minimize taxable income during years in which inflation is driving up the costs of doing business.

Term: Who Is Larry Ellison?
Definition: Larry Ellison founded Oracle, the software company that created the first commercially viable relational database./nUnder his leadership, Oracle became the largest supplier of database software and the second-largest supplier of business applications globally./nDespite notable setbacks, the company grew steadily until 1992, when its Oracle 7 release swept the market and made Ellison a billionaire./nEllison relinquished the CEO post at Oracle in 2014; he currently serves as board chair and chief technology officer./nAccording to Bloomberg, Ellison was the 5th richest person in the world, with a net worth of $124 billion, as of June 10, 2023.

Term: Last Mile: What It Means in Reaching Customers
Definition: The last mile refers to the short geographical distance that must be spanned to provide services to end-user customers./nLast mile logistics tend to be complex and costly to providers of goods and services who deliver to these areas./nIn communications, the last mile is the relatively expensive and complex delivery of cables or wiring from the provider's trunk to one's home./nLast mile logistics have become a big business and a central focus for both providers of services and consumers./nLast mile logistics for product delivery have become a central focus for retailers in the e-commerce era.

Term: Last Trading Day: Overview and Examples in Option Trading
Definition: The last trading day is the last day that a derivative contract trades.Typically the last trading day is the day before its actual expiration date./nExpiration dates are provided in the contract specifications for a given derivative contract. Contract specifications are found on the exchange's website./nFutures contracts not closed out on the last trading day will be subject to delivery and or cash settlement./nOptions contracts not closed out on the last trading day will be required to provide or take delivery of the underlying asset.Worthless contracts need not be closed.

Term: Last Will and Testament: Definition, Types, and How to Write One
Definition: Having a last will and testament gives you some control over what happens to your assets after your death./nIf you die intestate, or without a will, your estate, including the distribution of all assets, is settled by the courts./nIf parents with children die without a will, the courts will appoint a guardian for those who are minors./nTrusts and financial accounts. including life insurance policies, with named beneficiaries do not pass through probate court./nToday, wills can be drafted affordably using an online will maker.

Term: Late Fee: Definition, How They Work, and How to Avoid Them
Definition: A late fee is a charge you face if you fail to make a payment by the due date./nAll late fees must be explicitly outlined to borrowers./nLate fees generally range from $25 to $50, though some may be lower./nLate fees can increase account balances and can hurt your credit history.

Term: What Is the Law of Demand in Economics, and How Does It Work?
Definition: The law of demand is a fundamental principle of economics that states that at a higher price, consumers will demand a lower quantity of a good./nDemand is derived from the law of diminishing marginal utility, the fact that consumers use economic goods to satisfy their most urgent needs first./nA market demand curve expresses the sum of quantity demanded at each price across all consumers in the market./nChanges in price can be reflected in movement along a demand curve, but by themselves, they don't increase or decrease demand./nThe shape and magnitude of demand shifts in response to changes in consumer preferences, incomes, or related economic goods, not usually to changes in price.

Term: Law of Diminishing Marginal Productivity Defined & Explained
Definition: Diminishing marginal productivity typically occurs when advantageous changes are made to input variables affecting total productivity./nThe law of diminishing marginal productivity states that when an advantage is gained in a factor of production, the productivity gained from each subsequent unit produced will only increase marginally from one unit to the next./nProduction managers consider the law of diminishing marginal productivity when improving variable inputs for increased production and profitability.

Term: Law of Diminishing Marginal Returns: Definition, Example, Use in Economics
Definition: The law of diminishing marginal returns states that adding an additional factor of production results in smaller increases in output./nAfter some optimal level of capacity utilization, the addition of any larger amounts of a factor of production will inevitably yield decreased per-unit incremental returns./nFor example, if a factory employs workers to manufacture its products, at some point, the company will operate at an optimal level; with all other production factors constant, adding additional workers beyond this optimal level will result in less efficient operations.

Term: The Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility: How It Works, With Examples
Definition: Thelaw of diminishing marginal utilitysays that the marginal utility from each additional unit declines as consumption increases./nThe marginal utility may decrease into negative utility, as it may become entirely unfavorable to consume another unit of any product./nDiminishing marginal utility doesn't apply to money because its utility doesn't decrease as someone gets more of it./nDue to diminishing marginal utility, businesses will lower the price of a product to match a consumer's diminishing willingness to buy it.

Term: Law of Large Numbers: What It Is, How It's Used, Examples
Definition: The law of large numbers states that an observed sample average from a large sample will be close to the true population average and that it will get closer the larger the sample./nThe law of large numbers does not guarantee that a given sample, especially a small sample, will reflect the true population characteristics or that a sample that does not reflect the true population will be balanced by a subsequent sample./nThe law of large numbers indicates a bigger sample will represent a population mean, while the central tendency theorem states a bigger sample will represent a population's distribution./nIn business, the term "law of large numbers" is sometimes used in a different sense to express the relationship between scale and growth rates./nAs a company becomes bigger, it will experience difficulties maintaining percentage targets because the underlying dollars may become too large and unfeasible.

Term: Law of One Price: Definition, Example, and Assumptions
Definition: The law of one price states that in the absence of friction between global markets, the price for any asset will be the same in every market./nThe law of one price is achieved by eliminating price differences through arbitrage opportunities between markets./nMarket equilibrium forces would eventually converge the price of the asset.

Term: What Is a Layaway Plan? History, and Which Companies Offer Them
Definition: The term “layaway” refers to the retail purchasing method by which consumers place a deposit on items of merchandise—to “lay them away” for later pickup at a time when they have the funds to pay the balance in full./nLayaway programs are generally geared toward shoppers with limited income who may struggle to pay for purchases in one lump sum./nCreated during the Great Depression of the 1930s, layaway programs declined during the 1980s as the ubiquity of credit cards decreased their utility.

Term: Law of Supply Explained, With the Curve, Types, and Examples
Definition: The law of supply says that a higher price will lead producers to supply a higher quantity to the market./nBecause businesses seek to increase revenue, when they expect to receive a higher price for something, they will produce more of it./nMeanwhile, if prices fall, suppliers are disincentivized from producing as much./nSupply in a market can be depicted as an upward-sloping supply curve that shows how the quantity supplied will respond to various prices over a period of time./nTogether with demand, the law of supply forms half of the law of supply and demand.

Term: Law of Supply and Demand in Economics: How It Works
Definition: The law of demand holds that the demand level for a product or a resource will decline as its price rises and rise as the price drops./nThe law of supply says that higher prices boost the supply of an economic good and lower ones tend to diminish it./nA market-clearing price balances supply and demand and can be graphically represented as the intersection of the supply and demand curves./nThe degree to which changes in price translate into changes in demand and supply is known as the product's price elasticity./nDemand for basic necessities is relatively inelastic. It's less responsive to changes in their price.

Term: Lawful Money: Meaning, Overview, History
Definition: Lawful money is currency issued by the United States Treasury, such as gold and silver coins, Treasury notes, and Treasury bonds./nFiat money, which consists of paper money and checks, is not lawful money but is considered legal tender./nThe difference arises from the U.S. Constitution, which specifies gold and silver as the legal form of tender for debts, hence the varied interpretation since new forms of payments came into circulation./nThe Federal Reserve Act of 1913 gave the Federal Reserve the right to issue Federal Reserve Notes, which are backed by the U.S. government and are redeemed in lawful money, but did not specify what lawful money meant./nIn 1933 Congress amended the Federal Reserve Act to include all U.S. coins and currency as legal tender, to avoid any confusion about what type of money is legally permissible.

Term: What a Layoff Means, Plus Statistics and an Example
Definition: A layoff is an involuntary job termination, usually initiated by the employer as a cost-cutting measure./nWorkers who are laid off qualify for government-sponsored unemployment benefits, unlike those who are fired for cause./nSome employers voluntarily pay severance to laid-off workers, usually based on their length of employment./nMass layoffs can damage the economies of the surrounding communities, especially those dependent on a single employer or industry.

Term: Lead Bank: What it is, How it Works, Applications
Definition: A lead bank coordinates and oversees a syndicate for underwriting loans (bonds) or shares to be sold to investors./nThe lead bank typically receives a more generous amount of fees than syndicate banks due to its coordinating role and responsibilities./nLead banks are key for coordinating and marketing IPOs as well as large corporate debt offerings.

Term: Lead Time: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Lead time measures how long it takes to complete a process from beginning to end./nIn manufacturing, lead time often represents the time it takes to create a product and deliver it to a consumer./nLead time is calculated by adding any combination of the number of days to procure materials, manufacture goods, and deliver finished products./nFactors that can impact lead time include lack of raw materials, breakdown of transportation, labor shortages, natural disasters, and human errors./nIn some cases, companies can improve lead times by implementing automated stock replenishment and just-in-time (JIT) strategies.

Term: What Is the Definition of Leadership? Components and Example
Definition: Leadership is setting and achieving goals, tackling the competition, and solving problems decisively and quickly./nLeadership also refers to the tone a company's management sets in terms of the corporate culture./nSome people with strong leadership skills in the business world rise to become the CEO, COO, CFO, president, or chair of their companies.

Term: Leadership Grid: Definition of the Model and Five Behavior Types
Definition: The Leadership Grid is a model of behavioral leadership developed in the 1960s to measure concern for production against concern for people./nThe grid identifies five types of leaders: Impoverished, Produce or Perish, Middle of the Road, Country Club, and Team./nThe Team approach is considered the most effective form of leadership, according to the creators of the Leadership Grid.

Term: Leakage: Definition in Economics and Examples
Definition: In economics, leakage refers to capital or income that diverges from some kind of iterative system./nLeakage is usually used in relation to a particular depiction of the flow of income within a system, referred to as the circular flow of income and expenditure, in the Keynesian model of economics./nImported goods are sometimes referred to as a source of "leakage" because they can have the effect of transferring income that was earned in one country to another country.

Term: Leads and Lags: Definition, Example, Risks
Definition: Leads and lags refer to the timing of payments (delaying or advancing) on international business agreements to take advantage of a more favorable or anticipated exchange rate changes./nBusinesses can use currency forward contracts and points to adjust a future exchange rate up or down./nNot all currency-rate events can be forecast, but those that can are often tied to political or financial events.

Term: Leading Indicators: Definition and How They’re Used by Investors
Definition: A leading indicator is economic data that may correspond with a future movement or change in the economy./nLeading economic indicators can help to predict an occurrence or forecast the timing of events and trends in business, markets, and the economy./nDifferent leading indicators vary in their accuracy and leading relationships, so it is wise to consult a range of leading indicators when planning for the future./nLeading indicator examples include the Consumer Confidence Index, Purchasing Managers’ Index, initial jobless claims, and average hours worked./nLagging indicators are metrics that can confirm change rather than predict it.

Term: Lean Six Sigma: Definition, Principles, and Benefits
Definition: Lean Six Sigma seeks to improve employee and company performance by eliminating the waste of resources and process/product defects./nIt combines the process improvement methods of Six Sigma and lean enterprise./nLean Six Sigma helps to establish a clear path to achieving improvement objectives./nThe Lean strategy was established by Toyota in the 1940s and attempts to streamline operational processes, from manufacturing to transactions./nSix Sigma originated in the 1980s and seeks to improve output quality by reducing defects.

Term: Lean Startup: Defined, How It Differs From a Traditional Business
Lease Extension: What it Means, How it Works, Examples
Definition: A lease extension refers to a legal agreement that extends the term of an existing lease or rental agreement./nThe lease extension should name the parties involved, the dates on which the extension begins and ends, and should reference the earlier agreement being extended./nLease extensions are common in landlord-tenant relationships, or for the use of vehicles, equipment, machinery, and/or plants.

Term: What Is a Learning Curve? Formula, Calculation, and Example
Definition: The learning curve is a visual representation of how long it takes to acquire new skills or knowledge./nIn business, the slope of the learning curve represents the rate in which learning new skills translates into cost savings for a company./nA learning curve is usually described with a percentage that identifies the rate of improvement./nThe steeper the slope of the learning curve, the higher the cost savings per unit of output.

Term: What Is a Lease Option? Requirements, Benefits, and Example
Definition: A lease option is an agreement that gives a renter a choice to purchase the rented property during or at the end of the rental period./nA lease option also precludes the owner from offering the property for sale to anyone else./nA renter usually pays some percentage above the standard monthly rental amount, which goes to the downpayment for buying the home./nLeasing options may last for any period of time, but they commonly expire after two to three years./nDepending on the contract, the buyer-tenant may be responsible for maintenance and repairs which are normally the landlord's responsibility.

Term: Lease Payments: Definition, Contract Terms, Types of Leases
Definition: Lease payments are regular, often monthly, fees paid for the right to use a property, asset, or piece of equipment./nIndividuals may enter into lease agreements for land, cars, computer equipment, software, or other fixed assets./nThe terms and payment schedule for a leased item or property are often set out in a legal contract./nTime tables for lease agreements may be short. as in month-to-month arrangements, or long, as is frequently the case within land-lease scenarios, which may have contracts lasting a century or more.

Term: Lease Rate: What it is, How it Works, Types
Definition: A lease rate is an amount paid by the lessee to the lessor for use of an asset for a set period of time./nLease rates are generally expressed as dollars per month, but they can also be stated as dollars per square foot of space per year—as is the case with commercial real estate./nThe terms of the lease will spell out the time period that the lease rate applies for and may also spell out incremental increases in the lease rate over multi-year leases.

Term: Leasehold Assets: Types, Examples and FAQ
Definition: A leasehold is an accounting term that refers to an asset or property that a lessee (tenant) contracts to rent from a lessor (property owner) for an agreed-upon time in exchange for scheduled payments./nOwners of retail stores often use leasehold arrangements for their businesses rather than constructing their own buildings./nThe leasehold contract for commercial properties can be complex agreements that stipulate such things as the payment structure, breach of contract clauses, and leasehold improvement clauses./nThe contract will stipulate which party is responsible for making leasehold improvements, which might include such things as building walls and partitions, adding lighting fixtures, or constructing shelves./nThe IRS does not allow leasehold improvements to be deducted. However, the improvements are subject to depreciation.

Term: Leaseback (or Sale-Leaseback): Definition, Benefits, and Examples
Least Squares Criterion: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The least squares criterion method is used throughout finance, economics, and investing./nIt is used to estimate the accuracy of a line in depicting the data that was used to create it./nLeast squares results can be used to summarize data and make predictions about related but unobserved values from the same group or system.

Term: Leasehold Improvement: Definition, Accounting, and Examples
Definition: A leasehold improvement is a change made to a rental property to customize it for the particular needs of a tenant./nLandlords may agree with these improvements for existing or new tenants./nLeasehold improvements may be done by the landlord or tenant./nPainting, installing partitions or customized light fixtures, and changing flooring are all leasehold improvements./nEnlargements to buildings, elevators and escalators, roofs, fire protection, alarm and security systems, and HVAC systems do not qualify as leasehold improvements.

Term: Least Squares Method: What It Means, How to Use It, With Examples
Definition: The least squares method is a statistical procedure to find the best fit for a set of data points./nThe method works by minimizing the sum of the offsets or residuals of points from the plotted curve./nLeast squares regression is used to predict the behavior of dependent variables./nThe least squares method provides the overall rationale for the placement of the line of best fit among the data points being studied./nTraders and analysts can use the least squares method to identify trading opportunities and economic or financial trends.

Term: Ledger Wallet: Examples of How Crypto Wallets Work
Definition: Ledger wallets are hardware cryptocurrency wallets made by Ledger./nThe company's hardware wallets are multicurrency wallets that store private keys for cryptocurrencies offline./nLedger offers three hardware wallets: the Ledger Nano S Plus, the Ledger Nano X, and the Ledger Stax.

Term: What Does Ledger Balance Mean and How Does It Work?
Definition: A ledger balance is calculated at the end of each business day by a bank and includes all debits and credits./nIt is the opening balance in the bank account the next morning and remains the same all day./nThe ledger balance differs from the customer's available balance, which is the aggregate funds accessible for withdrawal at any one point.

Term: Least-Preferred Coworker Scale: Definition and How Scale Works
Definition: The Least-Preferred Coworker Scale (LPC) is a management heuristic that assigns an individual's leadership style as either task-oriented or relationship-oriented./nThe scale utilizes a subjective evaluation of an individual's attitudes toward their least favorable co-worker./nBy seeing how one responds to evaluating the one person they'd least prefer to work with, overall management style can be inferred./nThe leadership-member relationship is a barometer of how much influence and trust exists between the team and its leader./nThe model presented by the scale presents the notion that no single leadership style is perfect or ideal, as the needs change depending on circumstances and context.

Term: What Was FTX US Derivatives?
Definition: FTX U.S. Derivatives wasa regulated platform for trading bitcoin and ether derivatives such as futures, options, and swaps./nFTX U.S. Derivatives acted as a clearinghouse for institutional investors who negotiated cryptocurrency block trades directly with one another./nIn November 2022, FTX filed for bankruptcy—FTX U.S. Derivatives was one of the few FTX-related properties that were not a part of its bankruptcy proceedings./nFTX U.S. derivatives is now LedgerX, LLC, owned by Miami International Holdings.

Term: Leg: Definition in Trading, How It Works, and Strategy Types
Definition: A leg refers to one part of a multi-step or multi-part trade, such as in a spread strategy./nA trader will "leg-into" a strategy to hedge a position, benefit from arbitrage, or profit from a spread./nTraders use multi-leg orders for complex trades where there is less confidence in the trend direction.

Term: What Is a Bank's Legal Lending Limit, How Does It Work?
Definition: A legal lending limit is the most a bank or thrift can lend to a single borrower./nThe legal limit for national banks is 15% of the bank’s capital./nIf the loan is secured by readily marketable securities, the limit is raised by 10%, bringing the total to 25%./nSome loans are not subject to loan limits, such as loans secured by U.S. obligations, bankers' acceptances, or certain types of commercial paper, among others./nState-chartered banks may have their own lending limits, but they are often similar to the OCC standard.

Term: Legal Monopoly: What it is, How it Works
Legal Rate of Interest: What it Means, Special Considerations
