Definition: Loan servicing is a function carried out by the bank or financial institution that issued the loan, a third-party vendor, or a company that specializes in loan servicing./nLoan servicing functions include collecting monthly payments, paying taxes, and other aspects of the loan that occur from the time the proceeds are dispersed until the loan is paid off./nSecuritization of loans made loan servicing less profitable for banks./nLoan servicing is now an industry in and of itself and companies are compensated by receiving a small percentage of loan payments.

Term: What Is Loan Stock? How It Works and Potential Risks to Lenders
Definition: A loan stock is an equity security used as collateral to secure a loan./nThis practice potentially creates the risk for the lender that the value of the collateral will fall if the stock price drops./nThe company that issued the stock can also be impacted in the event of a default, which can make the lender a significant stockholder overnight./nThe Federal Reserve’s Primary Dealer Credit Facility accepts stocks as collateral for overnight loans to major financial institutions, raising the same risks and concerns for the Fed.

Term: Loan-to-Cost Ratio: Definition, What It Tells You, Calculation
Definition: Loan-to-cost (LTC) compares the financing amount of a commercial real estate project to its cost./nLTC is calculated as the loan amount divided by the construction cost./nMeanwhile, loan-to-value (LTV) compares the loan amount to the expected market value of the completed project./nA higher LTC means the project is riskier for lenders, where most lenders will only finance a project with an LTC of up to 80%.

Term: Loan Syndication Definition, How It Works, Types, Example
Definition: Loan syndication occurs when two or more lenders come together to fund one loan for a single borrower./nSyndicates are created when a loan is too large for one bank or falls outside the risk tolerance of a bank./nThe banks in a loan syndicate share the risk and are only exposed to their portion of the loan./nA loan syndicate always has a syndicate agent, which is the lead bank that organizes the loan, its terms, and other relevant information./nThe Loan Syndications and Trading Association provides resources on loan syndications within the corporate loan market.

Term: Loan-to-Deposit Ratio (LDR) Definition
Definition: The loan-to-deposit ratio is used to assess a bank's liquidity by comparing a bank's total loans to its total deposits for the same period./nTo calculate the loan-to-deposit ratio, divide a bank's total amount of loans by the total amount of deposits for the same period./nTypically, the ideal loan-to-deposit ratio is 80% to 90%. A loan-to-deposit ratio of 100% means a bank loaned one dollar to customers for every dollar received in deposits it received.

Term: Lobby: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: A lobby is a group of people who band together and try to influence people in public office and politicians./nThe term may also allude to the action of exerting influence on public officials./nLobbies are formed to influence officials to act in a way that is beneficial to the lobby's best interests, either through favorable legislation or by blocking unfavorable measures./nLobbyists are commonly held in a negative light because they are seemingly able to circumvent the democratic process./nDirect lobbying tries to influence government officials while the aim of grassroots lobbying is to influence public opinion by asking individuals to contact their elected officials about certain issues and legislation.

Term: Local Tax: What It Is and Types
Definition: Most states impose an income tax, which is withheld from employee paychecks./nMost states and some cities and towns impose sales taxes on goods and services./nFor most homeowners, the property tax bill is the biggest single local tax they pay.

Term: Loan-to-Value (LTV) Ratio: What It Is, How to Calculate, Example
Definition: Loan-to-value (LTV) is an often used ratio in mortgage lending to determine the amount necessary to put in a down payment and whether a lender will extend credit to a borrower./nLower LTVs are better in the eyes of lenders, but require borrowers to come up with larger down payments./nMost lenders offer mortgage and home-equity applicants the lowest possible interest rate when the loan-to-value ratio is at or below 80%./nMortgages become more expensive for borrowers with higher LTVs./nFannie Mae's HomeReady and Freddie Mac's Home Possible mortgage programs for low-income borrowers allow an LTV ratio of 97% (3% down payment) but require mortgage insurance (PMI) until the ratio falls to 80%.

Term: Lock-Up Agreement: Definition, Purpose, and Example
Definition: A lock-up agreement temporarily prevents company insiders from selling shares following an IPO./nIt is used to protect investors against excessive selling pressure by insiders./nShare prices often decline following the expiration of a lock-up agreement. Depending on the fundamentals of the company, this can present an opportunity for new investors to buy in at lower prices.

Term: Lock In Profits: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: Locking in profits refers to the realization of previously unrealized gains accrued in a security by closing all or a portion of the holdings./nWhen an investor holds an open position, they may accrue unrealized or paper gains or losses that aren't realized until the position is closed./nInvestors may lock in profits for many reasons, but they often do so to reduce risk./nLocking in profits is also commonly known as realization or taking money off the table.

Term: What Is a Lock-Up Period? How They Work, Main Uses, and Example
Definition: Lock-up periods are when investors cannot sell particular shares or securities./nLock-up periods are used to preserve liquidity and maintain market stability./nHedge fund managers use them to maintain portfolio stability and liquidity./nStart-ups/IPO’s use them to retain cash and show market resilience.

Term: Lockbox Banking: Definition, How It Works, Risks, and Cost
Definition: Lockbox banking is a service provided by banks to companies for the receipt of payment from customers./nThere are pros can cons when it comes to lockbox banking; while it is convenient, it can also be risky and lead to potential fraud, like counterfeiting./nUtilizing advanced lockbox technology, banks have established multiple communication hubs for businesses to use to receive payments and deposits./nBusinesses can use lockbox banking to lower their internal processing costs, convert receivables into cash quickly, and speed up collections.

Term: Locked In: What it Means, How it Works, Reasons
Definition: An investor is "locked in" when they are unwilling or unable to trade a security because of regulations, taxes, or penalties that prevent it from being profitable or make it illegal to do so./nStocks, options and warrants offered under employee incentive programs, which usually come with a mandatory vesting period, can all become locked in./nShares issued in initial public offerings are often locked in by rules that aim to prevent company insiders from gaining an unfair trading advantage.

Term: Locked-in Retirement Account (LIRA): Definition and How It Works
Definition: A Locked-in Retirement Account (LIRA) is a Canadian pension savings account funded by money transferred over from an employer-sponsored pension plan by the account’s beneficiary./nThe funds are tax-sheltered and cannot be withdrawn until retirement./nAt retirement, the money in an LIRA can be transferred to another retirement fund or used to purchase a life annuity./nLocked-in Retirement Accounts are governed by provincial pension laws./nFederal pension laws govern a similar type of account known as a locked-in Registered Retirement Savings Plan (RRSP).

Term: Logarithmic Price Scale: Definition Vs. Linear Price Scale
Definition: Logarithmic price scales are a type of scale used on a chart, plotted such that two equivalent price changes are represented by the same vertical changes on the scale./nThey are generally used for the long-term perspective analysis of price changes./nThey differ from linear price scales because they display percentage points and not dollar price increases for a stock.

Term: Logistics: What It Means and How Businesses Use It
Definition: Logistics is the overall process of managing how resources are acquired, stored, and transported to their final destination./nPoor logistics in a business can impact its bottom line./nLogistics is now used widely in the business sector, particularly by companies in the manufacturing sectors, to refer to how resources are handled and moved along the supply chain.

Term: London Interbank Bid Rate (Libid): What It Is, How It Works
Definition: LIBID was the London Interbank Bid Rate, the "bid" rate at which banks were willing to borrow eurocurrency deposits./nThe "offer" rate at which banks were willing to lend to each other was the more popular LIBOR./nThe most common currency deposited as eurocurrency was the U.S. dollar./nBoth LIBOR and LIBID were phased out beginning in 2021 due to rate-fixing scandals.

Term: LIBOR: What the London Interbank Offered Rate Is and How It's Used
Definition: LIBOR was the benchmark interest rate at which major global banks lend to one another./nLIBOR was administered by the Intercontinental Exchange, which asks major global banks how much they would charge other banks for short-term loans./nThe rate was calculated using the Waterfall Methodology, a standardized, transaction-based, data-driven, layered method./nLIBOR has been subject to manipulation, scandal, and methodological critique, making it less credible today as a benchmark rate./nLIBOR has been replaced by the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) on June 30, 2023.

Term: What Is the London Metal Exchange (LME)? Definition and History
Definition: The London Metal Exchange (LME) is one of the largest commodities exchanges in the world./nFutures and options contracts on metals such as gold, silver, zinc, and copper are listed for trading on the LME./nHedgers and speculators are active on the metals exchange, with hedgers turning to futures and options to mitigate risk and speculators seeking to make short-term profits by taking on risk./nThe LME is the only remaining physical commodities trading market in Europe, as the trend has been moving steadily to electronic trading and away from open outcry.

Term: London Stock Exchange (LSE): Definition, History, and Major Events
Definition: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) is one of the oldest stock exchanges in the world, the largest in Europe, and the primary stock exchange of the United Kingdom./nThe London Stock Exchange (LSE) rivals the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in terms of market capitalization, trade volume, access to capital, and trade liquidity./nThe "Big Bang" refers to the government's deregulation of the London stock market on Oct. 27, 1986, an event that led to a modernized electronic trading system and opened up the LSE to capital markets worldwide.

Term: Long Jelly Roll
Definition: A long jelly roll is an option spread-trading strategy that exploits price differences in horizontal spreads./nLong jelly rolls include buying a long calendar call spread and selling a short calendar put spread./nThe two spreads in a long jelly roll are usually priced so close together that there is not enough profit to be made to justify implementing it.

Term: Long Position: Definition, Types, Example, Pros and Cons
Definition: A long—or a long position—refers to the purchase of an asset with the expectation it will increase in value—a bullish attitude./nA long position in options contracts indicates the holder owns the underlying asset./nA long position is the opposite of a short position./nIn options, being long can refer either to outright ownership of an asset or being the holder of an option on the asset./nBeing long on a stock or bond investment is a measurement of time.

Term: Long Put: Definition, Example, Vs. Shorting Stock
Definition: A long put is a position when somebody buys a put option. It is in and of itself, however, a bearish position in the market./nInvestors go long put options if they think a security's price will fall./nInvestors may go long put options to speculate on price drops or to hedge a portfolio against downside losses./nDownside risk is thus limited using a long put options strategy.

Term: Long Run: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: The long run refers to a period of time where all factors of production and costs are variable./nOver the long run, a firm will search for the production technology that allows it to produce the desired level of output at the lowest cost./nThe long run is associated with the LRAC curve along which a firm would minimize its cost per unit for each respective long run quantity of output./nWhen the LRAC curve is declining, internal economies of scale are being exploited—and vice versa.

Term: Long Straddle: What It Is and How It's Used
Definition: A long straddle is an options strategy where a trader buys a long call and a long put on the same underlying asset with the same expiration date and strike price./nThe goal of a long straddle is to profit from a strong move in the market, usually triggered by a newsworthy event./nThe risk of using a long straddle is that the market may fail to react strongly enough to garnish a profit.

Term: Synthetic Put: What it is and How it Works
Definition: A synthetic put is an options strategy that combines a short stock position with a long call option on that same stock to mimic a long put option./nSynthetic puts are utilized when investors have a bearish bet on a stock and are concerned about potential near-term strength in that stock./nA synthetic put's goal is to profit from the anticipated decline in the underlying stock's price, which is why it is often called a synthetic long put.

Term: Long Tail: Definition as a Business Strategy and How It Works
Definition: The long tail is a business strategy that allows companies to realize significant profits by selling low volumes of hard-to-find items to many customers, instead of only selling large volumes of a reduced number of popular items./nThe term was first coined in 2004 by researcher Chris Anderson./nAnderson argues that these goods could actually increase in profitability because consumers are navigating away from mainstream markets./nThe strategy theorizes that consumers are shifting from mass-market buying to more niche or artisan buying.

Term: Long Term: Definition in Investing for Companies and Individuals
Definition: "Long term" refers to the extended period of time that an asset is held./nThe length of time that designates a long-term asset is usually a security being held for at least a year./n"Long term" is a subjective term that depends on the investor; however, selling an asset that is held for less than a year will have different tax consequences than selling it after holding it for a year or more./nLong-term investments are recorded on the asset side of a company's balance sheet as investments./nShort-term investments are marked-to-market, and any declines in their value are recognized as a loss, where increases are not recognized until sold.

Term: Long-Legged Doji: Definition, Significance, and How to Trade
Definition: The long-legged doji is a candlestick that consists of long upper and lower shadows and has approximately the same opening and closing price./nThe pattern shows indecision and is most significant when it occurs after a strong advance or decline./nWhile some traders may act on the one-candle pattern, others want to see what the price does after the long-legged doji./nThe pattern is not always significant, and won't always mark the end of a trend—it could mark the start of a consolidation period, or it may just end up being an insignificant blip in the current trend.

Term: Long-Run Average Total Cost (LRATC): Definition and Example
Definition: LRATC measures the average cost per unit of output over the long run./nIn long-term time frames, companies have more flexibility to change their operations.

Term: Long-Short Equity: What It Is, How It Works in Investing Strategy
Definition: Long-short equity is an investment strategy that seeks to take a long position in underpriced stocks while selling short overpriced shares./nLong-short seeks to augment traditional long-only investing by taking advantage of profit opportunities from securities identified as both under-valued and over-valued./nLong-short equity is commonly used by hedge funds, which often take a relative long bias—for instance, a 130/30 strategy where long exposure is 130% of AUM and 30% is short exposure.

Term: Long/Short Fund: Meaning, Overview, Examples
Definition: Long/short funds use an investment strategy to take a long position in underpriced stocks while selling short overpriced shares./nLong/short trading goes beyond traditional long-only investing by taking advantage of profit opportunities from securities identified as both undervalued and overvalued./nLong/short equity is commonly used by hedge funds, which frequently have something like a 130/30, where 130% of assets are long exposure and 30% are shorts./nBecause these funds require a lot of active management, analysis, and trading, their expense ratios tend to be higher.

Term: Long-Tail Liability: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: A long-tail liability is a type of liability that carries a long settlement period./nLiability insurance claims often involve large sums of money and can result in a settlement as well as a lengthy court case./nExamples of long-tail liabilities include medical malpractice, employment discrimination, and cases of child abuse.

Term: Long-Term Capital Gains and Losses: Definition and Tax Treatment
Definition: Long-term capital gains or losses apply to the sale of an investment made after owning it for 12 months or longer./nLong-term capital gains are often taxed at a more favorable tax rate than short-term gains./nLong-term losses can be used to offset future long-term gains./nFor 2023 and 2024, the long-term capital gains tax stands at 0%–20% depending on one's tax bracket.

Term: What Was Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM) and What Happened?
Definition: Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM) was a large hedge fund led by Nobel Prize-winning economists and renowned Wall Street traders./nLTCM was profitable in its heyday and by the spring of 1998, drew in about $3.5 billion of investor capital by promising that its arbitrage strategy would yield huge returns for investors./nLTCM’s highly leveraged trading strategies failed to pan out and, with losses mounting due to Russia's debt default, the U.S. government had to step in and arrange a bailout to stave off global financial contagion./nUltimately, a loan fund, comprised of a consortium of Wall Street banks, was created to bail out LTCM in September 1998, enabling it to liquidate in an orderly manner.

Term: Long-Term Assets: Definition, Depreciation, Examples
Definition: Long-term assets are investments in a company that will benefit the company for many years./nLong-term assets can include fixed assets such as a company's property, plant, and equipment, but can also include intangible assets, which can't be physically touched such as long-term investments or a company's trademark./nChanges in long-term assets can be a sign of capital investment or liquidation.

Term: Long-Term Debt to Capitalization Ratio: Meaning and Calculations
Definition: Long-term debt to capitalization ratio is a solvency measure that shows the degree of financial leverage a firm takes on./nIt calculates the proportion of long-term debt a company uses to finance its assets, relative to the amount of equity used for the same purpose./nA higher ratio result means that a company is more highly leveraged, which carries a higher risk of insolvency.

Term: What Is Long-Term Debt? Definition and Financial Accounting
Definition: Long-term debt is debt that matures in more than one year and is often treated differently from short-term debt./nFor an issuer, long-term debt is a liability that must be repaid while owners of debt (e.g., bonds) account for them as assets./nLong-term debt liabilities are a key component of business solvency ratios, which are analyzed by stakeholders and rating agencies when assessing solvency risk.

Term: Long-Term Care (LTC) Insurance: Definition, Costs, Alternatives
Definition: Long-term care insurance usually covers all or part of assisted living facilities and in-home care for people 65 or older or with a chronic condition that needs constant care./nIt is private insurance available to anyone who can afford to pay for it./nLong-term care insurance offers more flexibility and options than Medicaid.

Term: Long-Term Debt-to-Total-Assets Ratio: Definition and Formula
Definition: The long-term debt-to-total-assets ratio is a coverage or solvency ratio used to calculate the amount of a company's leverage./nThe ratio result shows the percentage of a company's assets it would have to liquidate to repay its long-term debt./nRecalculating the ratio over several time periods can reveal trends in a company's choice to finance assets with debt instead of equity and its ability to repay its debt over time.

Term: LEAPS: How Long-Term Equity Anticipation Securities Options Work
Definition: Long-term equity anticipation securities are listed options contracts that expire in more than a year./nThese contracts are ideal for options traders looking to trade a prolonged trend./nLEAPS can be listed on a particular stock or an index as a whole./nThey are often used in hedging strategies and can be particularly effective for protecting retirement portfolios./nThe premiums for LEAPS are higher than those for standard options in the same stock, but lower than the cost of shares of the underlying stock.

Term: Long-Term Growth (LTG): What it is, How it Works, Value Investing
Definition: Long-term growth (LTG) is an investment strategy that aims to increase the value of a portfolio over a multi-year time frame./nAlthough long-term is relative to an investors’ time horizons and individual style, generally long-term growth is meant to create above-market returns over a period of ten years or more./nLTG portfolios can be more aggressive and might have a ratio of 80% stocks to 20% bonds.

Term: Long-Term Investments on a Company's Balance Sheet
Definition: A long-term investment is an account a company plans to keep for at least a year such as stocks, bonds, real estate, and cash./nThe account appears on the asset side of a company's balance sheet./nLong-term investors are generally willing to take on more risk for higher rewards./nThese are different from short-term investments, which are meant to be sold within a year.

Term: Longitudinal Data: Definition and Uses in Finance and Economics
Definition: Longitudinal data is data that is collected sequentially from the same respondents over time./nThis type of data can be very important in tracking trends and changes over time by asking the same respondents questions in several waves carried out of time./nLongitudinal data is used in finance to track company profitability, risk, and to understand the effect of economic shocks.

Term: Long-Term Liabilities: Definition, Examples, and Uses
Definition: Long-term liabilities are due more than one year in the future./nThey are separately identified on the balance sheet./nWhile short-term liabilities must be paid with current assets, long-term liabilities can be repaid through a variety of current and future business activities.

Term: Lookback Option: Definition, Pricing Examples, Fixed Vs. Floating
Definition: Lookback options are exotic options that allow a buyer to minimize regret./nLookback options are only available "over-the-counter" (OTC) and not on any of the major exchanges./nLookback options are expensive to establish and the potential profits are often nullified by the costs./nFixed strike lookback option solves the market exit problem—the best time to get out, while the floating strike lookback option solves the market entry problem—the best time to get in.

Term: Look-Alike Contracts: Meaning, Limitations, Criticism
Definition: A look-alike contract is anOTCderivatives contract that is cash-settled that has otherwise similar specifications to a physically settled futures contract./nBecause physical settlement is not an issue, traders do not have to worry about closing out open positions to avoid making or taking delivery./nCritics argue that look-alike contracts fuel speculation and generate market inefficiencies since they are removed from the underlying asset that they track.

Term: Loophole
Definition: A loophole is basically a technicality that allows one to escape violating the law through some activity./nCommon loopholes are found in taxes and avoiding taxes, as well as with political issues such as political donations./nMost loopholes are closed over time, but some remain open because powerful actors lobby to maintain them.

Term: Loss Carryforward: Definition, Example, and Tax Rules
Definition: Loss carryforwards are used to spread a current net operating loss (NOL) over subsequent years' net operating income (NOI) in order to reduce future tax liability./nThe Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) removed the two-year carryback provision, extended the 20-year carryforward provision out indefinitely, and limited carryforwards to 80% of net income in any future year./nNet operating losses originating in tax years beginning prior to Jan. 1, 2018, are still subject to the former carryover rules.

Term: Loss Adjustment Expense (LAE): Definition, How It Works, and Types
Definition: A loss adjustment expense is a cost that insurance companies shoulder to investigate and settle insurance claims./nAlthough loss adjustment expenses cut into an insurance company’s bottom line, they're incurred to avoid fraudulent claims./nThere are two types of loss adjustment expenses—allocated and unallocated./nAllocated costs accumulate during active claim investigations; unallocated costs are part of the investigation overhead./nSome loss adjustment expenses are recouped by insurance companies by requiring the policyholder to pay them.

Term: Lorenz Curve
Definition: A Lorenz curve is a graphical representation of the distribution of income or wealth within a population./nLorenz curves graph percentiles of the population against cumulative income or wealth of people at or below that percentile./nLorenz curves, along with their derivative statistics, are widely used to measure inequality across a population./nThe Lorenz curve is a central piece in calculating the Gini coefficient, a mathematical representation of inequality levels./nBecause Lorenz curves are mathematical estimates based on fitting a continuous curve to incomplete and discontinuous data, they may be imperfect measures of true inequality.

Term: What Is a Loss Carryback? Definition, History, and Example
Definition: A net operating loss (NOL) carryback allows a firm to apply a net operating loss to a previous year's tax return, for an immediate refund of prior taxes paid./nA tax loss carryforward, on the other hand, applies a tax loss toward future years' returns./nA carryback—and the resulting immediate refund of prior taxes paid—is typically more beneficial than a carryforward due to the time value of money./nNOL carryback provisions in the tax code have been increased, decreased, omitted entirely, and reinstated various times over the years./nIt is important to be aware of the current state of carryback tax provisions.

Term: Loss Development: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Loss development is the difference between what an insurer initially records for liabilities versus the final level of claims./nA loss development factor allows insurers to adjust claims to their projected final levels./nOne of the most important factors for insurers when determining potential losses is the amount of time that it will take to process a claim.

Term: Loss Leader Strategy: Definition and How It Works in Retail
Definition: A loss leader strategy prices a product lower than its production cost in order to attract customers or sell other, more expensive products./nLoss leading is a controversial strategy that is considered predatory./nSome companies use a loss leading strategy when aiming to penetrate new markets to gain market share./nLarge companies can afford to price a product with no margin because they have other products they can sell profitably to make up for the loss./nLoss leading strategies can hurt small businesses as well as suppliers, who might be forced to keep their own prices low so that a business can continue with its loss leading strategy.

Term: Loss Ratio: What It Is, How It's Calculated, Types
Definition: Loss ratio is the losses an insurer incurs due to paid claims as a percentage of premiums earned./nA high loss ratio can be an indicator of financial distress, especially for a property or casualty insurance company./nInsurers will calculate their combined ratios, which include the loss ratio and their expense ratio, to measure total cash outflows associated with their operating activities./nIf loss ratios associated with your policy become excessive, an insurance provider may raise premiums or choose not to renew a policy./nIf health insurers fail to divert 80% of premiums to claims or healthcare improving activities, they will have to issue a rebate to their policyholders.

Term: Loss Payee: Definition, How It Works in Insurance, and Benefits
Definition: When you use collateral to secure your loan, a loss payee will be put onto your insurance policy./nThe loss payee acts as a guard for the lender to protect it against unpaid loans./nWhen there is a total loss, the lender is paid before anyone else.

Term: Loss Given Default (LGD): Two Ways to Calculate, Plus an Example
Definition: The loss given default (LGD) is an important calculation for financial institutions projecting out their expected losses due to borrowers defaulting on loans./nThe expected loss of a given loan is calculated as the LGD multiplied by both the probability of default and the exposure at default./nExposure at default is the total value of the loan at the time a borrower defaults./nAn important figure for any financial institution is the cumulative amount of expected losses on all outstanding loans./nLGD is an essential component of the Basel Model (Basel II), a set of international banking regulations.

Term: Loss Reserves: What They Are and Examples
Definition: A loss reserve is an accounting entry that estimates the amount an insurance company would have to pay out on future insurance claims on policies that it has underwritten./nCalculating loss reserves is a difficult process as it is an attempt to guess when and how many claims come due that the insurance company will be liable for./nRegulations require loss reserves to be reported at nominal value whereas insurance companies would prefer them to be reported as a discounted present value loss./nEstimating the correct loss reserve is important for an insurance company as it directly impacts profitability and solvency./nLoss reserves, when applied to the banking industry, are known as loan loss provisions.

Term: Lost Decade in Japan: History and Causes
Definition: The Lost Decade originally referred to an extended period of slow to negative economic growth, lasting almost ten years, in Japan's economy during the 1990s./nStagnant growth in subsequent years has led the period since 1991 to sometimes be referred to as Japan's Lost Decades./nMisguided government policies in response to a real estate bubble are considered to be the main culprits for the Lost Decade./nWithin the US economy, the first decade of the 21st century, which was bookended by two stock market crashes, is often compared to Japan's Lost Decade.

Term: Lost Policy Release (LPR): What it is, How it Works
Definition: A lost policy release (LPR) is a statement that releases an insurance company from its liabilities./nIn the modern day, canceling an insurance policy no longer requires mailing back original policy documents, so lost policy releases are no longer necessary in most insurance cases./nAn auto insurer may get a policyholder to sign a lost policy release, if they are switching to a different auto insurance provider, though that transaction is likely to happen online.

Term: Low Exercise Price Option (LEPO): Meaning, Pros And Cons
Definition: A low exercise price option (LEPO) is a European-style call option with an exercise price of one cent that mimics a futures contract./nLEPOs function as deep-in-the-money options similar to the stock itself./nBoth buyer and seller of a LEPO operate on margin./nLEPO options are not available on any U.S. exchanges.

Term: Love Money: What it Means, Angel Investors, Importance
Definition: Love money is a slang term for funding that an entrepreneur raises directly from friends and family./nStartups that require love money funding are generally assumed to not fit the requirements of traditional financing sources like banks and venture capitalists./nIt is critical that the entrepreneur and the investors understand the risks involved with love money prior to any capital changing hands./nLove money investments should only be made with capital the investors are prepared to lose entirely.

Term: Lot: What It Means in Stock and Bond Trading, Types, and Examples
Definition: A lot is the number of units of a financial instrument that's traded on an exchange./nA round lot is 100 share units for stocks but any number of shares can be traded and also referred to as lots./nA bond lot can vary. They're sometimes $100,000 or $1 million but face values that individual investors can purchase may be as low as $1,000./nA trader can buy or sell as many futures as they like but the underlying amount that a contract controls is fixed based on the contract size.

Term: Low-Income Housing Tax Credit (LITHC): How It Works
Definition: The LIHTC is intended toencouragethe development of affordable housing by offering a ten-year tax credit for these projects./nThe LIHTC program provides the credits to reduce developers' costs in return for developers agreeing to reserve a certain percentage of rent-restricted units for lower-income families./nMost kinds of properties (single-family, multi-family, apartment complexes, and townhouses) can qualify for the LIHTC credit./nAn LIHTC housing project must rent to tenants whose average income is below the area's median income, and this commitment must be maintained for a period of 15 years./nThe tax credit costs the U.S. government an estimated $13.5 billion every year.

Term: Low Interest Rate Environment Definition, Example, Effects
Definition: Low interest rate environments occur when the risk-free rate is set lower than the historical average./nMuch of the world entered a low interest rate environment following the 2008-09 financial crisis./nLow interest rate environments tend to benefit borrowers at the expense of lenders and savers.

Term: Low Volume Pullback: Definition as Indicator and How It Works
Definition: Low volume pullbacks occur when the price moves towards support levels on lower than average volume./nLow volume pullbacks are often a sign of weak longs taking profit, but suggest that the long-term uptrend remains intact./nHigh volume pullbacks suggest that there could be a near-term reversal.

Term: Lower of Cost or Market (LCM) Method: Why It’s Used and Application
Definition: The lower of cost or market (LCM) method relies on the fact that wheninvestorsvalue a company’s inventory, those assets shall be recorded on the balance sheet at either the market value or the historical cost./nHistorical cost refers to the cost of inventory at the time it was originally purchased./nThe LCM method takes into account that the value of a good can fluctuate. Under this scenario, if the price at which the inventory may be sold dips below the net realizable value (NRV) of the item, which consequently results in a loss, then the LCM method can be employed to record the loss./nThe LCM method is a tenet of generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).

Term: Loyalty Program: Definition, Purpose, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Loyalty programs are offered by retailers and other corporations as a way to attract and retain customers./nLoyalty programs offer rewards, discounts, or other special incentives and are designed as a reward for a customer's repeat business./nLoyalty programs benefit companies not only by developing customer loyalty but also by providing crucial information on how customers are spending and what products or types of offers are most appealing./nWhile companies like Starbucks make great use of loyalty programs, some retailers such as Costco and Amazon rely instead on annual memberships.

Term: What Does Ltd. (Limited) Mean After a Business Name?
Definition: Ltd. is a standard abbreviation for "limited," a form of corporate structure available in countries including the U.K., Ireland, and Canada, and appears as a suffix after the company name./nLimited companies limit the liability of a corporate loss to the business and do not impact the private assets of owners or investors./nLimited companies may be set up as either private or public (PLC).

Term: Lucrative: Meaning, Measurement, Example
Definition: An idea, a venture, or a product that creates substantial returns is lucrative./nIn business, a product can be deemed lucrative only if it produces substantial money in net returns, not gross receipts./nA product can be termed lucrative only in the past tense. In the present tense, it indicates potential, not reality./nInvestors can analyze a company's financial statements and certain financial metrics to determine whether a company is lucrative or not./nOne of the most lucrative companies in the world is Apple Inc.

Term: Luhn Algorithm: Uses in Identity Verification for Credit Cards
Definition: The Luhn Algorithm is a mathematical formula developed in the late 1950s./nIt is widely used to validate the authenticity of identification numbers./nIn finance, it has helped increase electronic payments processing by rapidly identifying mis-entered credit card numbers.

Term: What Is a Lump-Sum Payment, and How Does It Work?
Definition: A lump-sum payment is an amount paid all at once, as opposed to an amount that is paid in installments./nA lump-sum payment is not the best choice for everyone; for some, it may make more sense for the funds to be annuitized as periodic payments./nBased on interest rates, tax situation, and penalties, an annuity may end up having a higher net present value (NPV) than the lump-sum.

Term: What Is a Luxury Item (aka Luxury Good)? Definition and Examples
Definition: A luxury item is not necessary to live, but it is deemed highly desirable within a culture or society./nLuxury items tend to be sensitive to a person's income or wealth, meaning that as wealth rises, so do purchases of luxury items./nLuxury items can include high-end automobiles and yachts but also services, such as full-time or live-in chefs and housekeepers.

Term: What Is a Luxury Tax? Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A luxury tax is a sales or transfer tax imposed only on specific goods./nThe products taxed are considered non-essential or are affordable only to the wealthiest consumers./nThe mansion tax and sin taxes both fall into the category of luxury taxes.

Term: M1 Money Supply: How It Works and How to Calculate It
Definition: M1 is a narrow measure of the money supply that includes currency, demand deposits, and other liquid deposits, including savings deposits./nM1 does not include financial assets, such as bonds./nThe M1 is no longer used as a guide for monetary policy in the U.S. due to the lack of correlation between it and other economic variables./nThe M1 money supply was a much more constrictive measurement of the money supply compared to the M2 or M3 calculation./nThe M1 money supply is reported on a monthly basis by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.

Term: M2 Definition and Meaning in the Money Supply
Definition: M2 is a measure of the money supply that includes cash, checking deposits, and other deposits readily convertible to cash, such as CDs./nM1 is an estimate of cash, checking, and savings account deposits only./nThe weekly M2 and M1 numbers are closely monitored as indicators of the overall money supply. Too-fast growth in the numbers can be a warning sign of inflation./nAnother money supply number, M3, includes all of the above plus large institutional cash deposits. The M3 is published quarterly./nGold is not counted in M1, M2, or M3. In the modern world, gold is no longer used as a common currency.

Term: What Is M3? Definition, Liquidity, Disuse, and M Classifications
Definition: M3 is a collection of the money supply that includes M2 money as well as large time deposits, institutional money market funds, short-term repurchase agreements, and larger liquid funds./nM3 is closely associated with larger financial institutions and corporations than with small businesses and individuals./nM3 was traditionally used by economists to estimate the entire money supply within an economy and by governments to direct policy and control inflation over medium and long-term periods./nSince 2006, the Fed has stopped publishing the M3 money aggregate, but other sources continue to publish the figures.

Term: What Is M-Pesa? Definition, How the Service Works, and Example
Maastricht Treaty: Definition, Purpose, History, and Significance
Definition: The Maastricht Treaty laid down the foundation for the European Union./nThe treaty was signed by 12 countries in the Dutch city of Maastricht in 1992 and went into effect in 1993./nThe agreement established greater cooperation between member states through economic, social, and legal channels./nThe Maastricht Treaty established the European Union's single currency system for the euro./nThe treaty was amended a number of times between 1997 and 2009.

Term: Macro Manager: Definition, How Management Works, and Benefits
Definition: A macro manager is a hands-off boss who trusts his or her employees to do their jobs as they see best./nMacro managers are more concerned with overall plans and results than individual styles or day-to-day habits./nAdopting a macro-management leadership style can include delegating authority and responsibilities, while the manager focuses their attention on developing and executing the overall strategy for the team./nMacro managers can be accused of being aloof and out of touch with daily issues./nA macro manager is the opposite of a micromanager, a supervisor who constantly looks over employees' shoulders and is often perceived as controlling and overly critical.

Term: Macro Environment: What It Means in Economics, and Key Factors
Definition: The macro-environment refers to the broader condition of an economy as opposed to specific markets./nThe macro-environment can be affected by GDP, fiscal policy, monetary policy, inflation, employment rates, and consumer spending./nThe state of the macro environment affects business decisions on things such as spending, borrowing, and investing.

Term: Macroeconomic Factor: Definition, Types, Examples, and Impact
Definition: A macroeconomic factor is an influential fiscal, natural, or geopolitical event that broadly affects a regional or national economy./nThe relationships between various macroeconomic factors are extensively studied in the field of macroeconomics./nExamples of macroeconomic factors include economic outputs, unemployment rates, and inflation./nMacroeconomic factors can be positive, negative, or neutral.

Term: Macroeconomics Definition, History, and Schools of Thought
Definition: Macroeconomics is the branch of economics that deals with the structure, performance, behavior, and decision-making of the whole, or aggregate, economy./nThe two main areas of macroeconomic research are long-term economic growth and shorter-term business cycles./nMacroeconomics in its modern form is often defined as starting with John Maynard Keynes and his theories about market behavior and governmental policies in the 1930s; several schools of thought have developed since./nIn contrast to macroeconomics, microeconomics is more focused on the influences on and choices made by individual actors—such as people, companies, and industries—in the economy.

Term: Magic Formula Investing: Definition and What It Tells You
Definition: Magic formula investing is a successfully back-tested strategy that can increase your chances of outperforming the market./nThe strategy focuses on screening for companies that fit specific criteria and uses a methodical, unemotional process to manage the portfolio over time./nThe strategy, which is value-based, was developed by investor and hedge fund manager Joel Greenblatt and published inThe Little Book That Beat the Marketin 2005. It was updated in 2010 asThe Little Book That Still Beats the Market./nIn the original publication, Greenblatt claimed annualized returns of over 30%./nThe magic formula excludes certain types of companies, such as those with a small market capitalization, foreign companies, finance companies, and utilities.

Term: MICR: What Is a Magnetic Ink Character Recognition Line?
Definition: Magnetic ink character recognition is the string of characters at the bottom left of a personal check that includes the account, routing, and check numbers./nMICR numbers are designed to be readable by both individuals and sorting equipment./nThey can't be faked or copied, due to the use of magnetic ink and unique fonts./nThe benefits of the technology include enhanced security against fraud and mechanization of check processing./nMICR was developed in the late 1950s and is now in use globally.

Term: Magna Cum Laude: Meaning, Requirements, and Value
Definition: Magna cum laude is an academic honorific awarded to students who have achieved academic excellence./nThere is no set standard to qualify for this honor, with each school free to set its own criteria./nThe practice of awarding honors degrees began at Harvard University in the mid-19th century and has spread to colleges and universities around the world./nSome colleges, including Stanford University, do not offer Latin honors and instead use the word “distinction” to honor students who achieve academic excellence.

Term: Maintenance Expenses (Costs of Maintenance): Definition
Definition: Maintenance expenses are necessary costs for upkeep—whether it's a car, home, rental apartment, or condominium./nNeglecting regular maintenance—and not paying expenses for upkeep—may result in higher maintenance costs and, even worse, replacement costs for the asset itself./nIndividuals pay for maintenance on things like homes, automobiles, and appliances, while companies pay for upkeep on fixed assets and technology.

Term: Main Street: Meaning, Types, Government Programs
Definition: The term Main Street is used in many contexts, but it always means local./nLocal businesses, consumers, and financial services firms may be referred to as Main Street./nThe polar opposite of Main Street is Wall Street and the big financial firms and global corporations it represents./nIn London, Main Street is called High Street./nThere are numerous grants and loan opportunities for Main Street businesses.

Term: What Is a Majority Shareholder? Definition, Rights and Privileges
Definition: A majority shareholder is a person or entity who holds more than 50% of shares of a company./nIf the majority shareholder holds voting shares, they dictate the direction of the company through their voting power./nThe exception to a majority shareholder's voting power is if a super-majority is required for a particular voting issue, or certain company bylaws restrict the power of the majority shareholder.

Term: Maintenance Margin: Definition and Comparison to Margin Accounts
Definition: Maintenance margin is the minimum amount of equity that an investor must maintain in the margin account after the purchase has been made./nMaintenance margin is currently set at 25% of the total value of the securities in a margin account as per FINRA requirements.﻿﻿/nThe investor may be hit with a margin call if the account equity falls below the maintenance margin threshold which may necessitate that the investor liquidate positions until the requirement is satisfied.

Term: Make-or-Buy Decision Explained: How to Make Outsourcing Decisions
Definition: A make-or-buy decision is an act of choosing between manufacturing a product in-house or purchasing it from an external supplier./nMake-or-buy decisions, like outsourcing decisions, speak to a comparison of the costs and advantages of producing in-house versus buying it elsewhere./nThere are many factors at play that may tilt a company from making an item in-house or outsourcing it, such as labor costs, lack of expertise, storage costs, supplier contracts, and lack of sufficient volume./nCompanies use quantitative analysis to determine whether making or buying is the most cost-efficient method.

Term: Make to Order (MTO) or Made to Order: Definition and Example
Definition: Make to order (MTO), or made to order, is a business production strategy that typically allows consumers to purchase products that are customized to their specifications./nThe manufacturing process of an MTO item begins only after a confirmed customer order is received./nAdvantages to MTO include customization for customers, reduction in stock obsolescence and finished goods inventory, and overall waste./nDisadvantages to MTO include increased costs and increased wait times for a finished product./nMTO can be contrasted with make to stock (MTS) manufacturing, whereby inventories are produced in advance of consumers buying them off the shelf.

Term: Make To Stock (MTS): Definition, Example, and How It Works
Definition: Make to stock (MTS) is a traditional production strategy that is used to match inventory with anticipated consumer demand./nThe MTS method requires an accurate forecast of this demand to determine how much stock it produces./nTo implement an MTS approach a business needs to redesign operations at specific times, instead of keeping a steady level of production year-round./nThe main drawback of the MTS method is that if a forecast is inaccurate a company can be left with too little or too much inventory, which can impact the bottom line.

Term: Managed Account: Definition and How It Works Vs. Mutual Funds
Definition: A managed account is a portfolio that is owned by one investor but is supervised by a professional money manager who has been hired by that investor./nMoney managers can demand six-figure minimum investments to manage accounts and are compensated by a fee, calculated as a set percentage of assets under management (AUM)./nRobo-advisors offer algorithmically-managed accounts at a lower cost for everyday investors with low starting balances./nA mutual fund is a type of managed account, but it is open to anyone with the means to buy its shares, rather than personalized for a particular investor.

Term: Make-Whole Call Provision: What It Is, How It Works, Advantages
Definition: A make-whole call provision is a type of call provision on a bond allowing the issuer to pay off remaining debt early./nThe payment is derived from a formula based on the net present value (NPV) of previously scheduled coupon payments and the principal that the investor would have received./nIssuers typically don't expect to have to use this type of call provision, and make-whole calls are rarely exercised./nMake-whole calls are better for investors than standard call provisions.

Term: Malpractice Insurance: Definition, Types, Importance
Definition: Malpractice insurance is a type of professional liability insurance intended to cover healthcare professionals./nPatients can file lawsuits against healthcare professionals seeking damages for medical negligence that resulted in further health problems or death./nStudies show that medical negligence is the third leading cause of death in the United States, so more likely than not, a healthcare professional will need malpractice insurance./nMalpractice insurance can be obtained through a private insurer, through an employer, or through organizations, such as medical risk retention groups (RRGs)./nThe two basic types of professional liability insurance are claims-made policies or occurrence policies./nLegal costs, punitive damages, and medical damages are all covered under malpractice insurance.

Term: Managed Futures: Meaning, Overview, How They Trade
Definition: Managed futures are alternative investments consisting of a portfolio of futures contracts that are actively managed by professionals./nLarge funds and institutional investors frequently use managed futures as an alternative to traditional hedge funds to achieve both portfolio and market diversification./nTwo common approaches for trading managed futures are the market-neutral strategy and the trend-following strategy./nMarket-neutral strategies look to profit from spreads and arbitrage created by mispricing, whereas trend-following strategies look to profit by going long or short according to fundamentals or technical market signals.

Term: Management by Objectives (MBO): Learn Its 5 Steps, Pros and Cons
Definition: Management by objectives (MBO) is a process in which a manager and an employee agree on specific performance goals and then develop a plan to reach them./nIt is designed to align objectives throughout an organization and boost employee participation and commitment./nThere are five steps: Define objectives, share them with employees, encourage employees to participate, monitor progress, and finally, evaluate performance and reward achievements./nCritics of MBO argue that it leads to employees trying to achieve the set goals by any means necessary, often at the cost of the company.

Term: What Is Management Buyout (MBO)? Definition, Reasons, and Example
Definition: A management buyout is a transaction where a company’s management team purchases the assets and operations of the business they manage./nMBOs generally occur to take companies private in an effort to streamline operations and improve profitability./nA management team pools resources to acquire all or part of a business they manage./nMBOs are financed with a mix of personal resources, private equity financiers, and seller-financing./nA management buyout is the opposite of a management buy-in, where an external management team acquires a company and replaces the existing management.

Term: Managerial Accounting Meaning, Pillars, and Types
Definition: Managerial accounting involves the presentation of financial information for internal purposes to be used by management in making key business decisions./nTechniques used by managerial accountants are not dictated by accounting standards, unlike financial accounting./nThe presentation of managerial accounting data can be modified to meet the specific needs of its end-user./nManagerial accounting encompasses many facets of accounting, including product costing, budgeting, forecasting, and various financial analysis./nThis differs from financial accounting, which produces and disseminates official financial statements for public consumption that conform to prevailing accounting standards.

Term: Management Discussion and Analysis (MD&A): Definition and Example
Definition: Management discussion and analysis (MD&A) is a section within a company’s annual report or quarterly filing where executives analyze the company’s performance./nThe section can also include a discussion of compliance, risks, and future plans, such as goals and new projects./nThe MD&A section is not audited and represents the thoughts and opinions of management./nCompanies often use the MD&A section to invoke confidence in investors by explain how and why future plans of the company will be successful./nHowever, the MD&A section is less helpful as management does not want to reveal too much of its forward-looking plans in a publicly-availably, required filing.

Term: What Is a Management Fee? Definition, Average Cost, and Example
Definition: Management fees are the cost of having an investment fund professionally managed by an investment manager./nThe management fees may or may not cover not only the cost of paying the managers but also the costs of investor relations and any administrative costs./nFee structures are usually based on a percentage of assets under management (AUM)./nFees tend to range from 0.10% to more than 2% of AUM.

Term: Manufacturer's Suggested Retail Price (MSRP): Definition and How Is Determined
Definition: The manufacturer’s suggested retail price (MSRP) is the sticker price recommended by a product's producer to retailers./nThey are frequently used in the sale of automobiles, although most retail products come with an MSRP./nMSRP is different from the invoice price, the price a dealer or retailer pays a manufacturer./nMany retailers will sell products below the MSRP to reduce inventory, attract more consumers, or during a sluggish economy./nConversely, some retailers will set prices higher than the MSRP for products in high demand.

Term: Manufacturing Resource Planning (MRP II): Definition and Example
Definition: Manufacturing Resource Planning (MRP II) is an integrated information system used by businesses./nMRP II is an extension of materials requirement planning (MRP)./nBoth MRP and MRP II are seen as predecessors to Enterprise resource planning (ERP).

Term: Manufacturing: Definition, Types, Examples, and Use as Indicator
Definition: Manufacturing is the process of turning raw materials or parts into finished goods through the use of tools, human labor, machinery, and chemical processing./nMost products were handmade using human labor and basic tools before the Industrial Revolution./nThe Industrial Revolution led to mass production, assembly line manufacturing, and the use of mechanization to manufacture larger quantities of goods at a lower cost./nFinancial analysts study the ISM Manufacturing Report each month as a potential early indicator of the economy's health and where the stock market might be headed./nManufacturing can be defined and classified under different types, processes, or techniques.

Term: Maquliadora Definition, History, Benefits, Worker Explotation
Definition: A maquiladora is a low-cost factory in Mexico that is owned by a foreign corporation./nFacilities are usually located near the U.S.-Mexico border./nThese plants assemble products and export them back to the United States and other countries./nCompanies can capitalize on a cheaper labor force in Mexico and certain tax advantages under the North American Free Trade Agreement, the USMCA, and the IMMEX Program./nDespite the benefits, maquiladoras have come under fire because of the way they exploit their labor force.

Term: Margin Account: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A margin account allows a trader to borrow funds from a broker, and not need to put up the entire value of a trade./nA margin account typically allows a trader to trade other financial products, such as futures and options (if approved and available with that broker), as well as stocks./nMargin increases the profit and loss potential of the trader's capital./nWhen trading stocks, a margin fee or interest is charged on borrowed funds.

Term: Margin and Margin Trading Explained Plus Advantages and Disadvantages
Definition: Margin is the money borrowed from a broker to purchase an investment and is the difference between the total value of an investment and the loan amount./nMargin trading refers to the practice of using borrowed funds from a broker to trade a financial asset, which forms the collateral for the loan from the broker./nA margin account is a standard brokerage account in which an investor is allowed to use the current cash or securities in their account as collateral for a loan./nLeverage conferred by margin will tend to amplify both gains and losses. In the event of a loss, a margin call may require your broker to liquidate securities without prior consent.

Term: Margin Loan Availability: What it Means, How it Works
Margin Call: What It Is and How to Meet One With Examples
Definition: A margin call occurs when a margin account runs low on funds, usually because of a losing trade./nMargin calls are demands for additional capital or securities to bring a margin account up to the maintenance requirement./nBrokers may force a trader to sell assets, regardless of the market price, to meet the margin call if the trader doesn’t deposit funds./nMargin calls can also occur when a stock goes up in price and losses start mounting in accounts that have sold the stock short./nInvestors can avoid margin calls by monitoring their equity and keeping enough funds in their accounts to maintain the value above the required maintenance level.

Term: Margin Debt: Definition, How It Works, and the Pros and Cons of Using It
Definition: Margin debt is the amount of money that an investor borrows from their broker via a margin account./nMargin debt can be used to buy securities./nRegulation T sets the initial margin at a minimum of 50%, which means an investor can only take on margin debt of 50% of the account balance./nMeanwhile, the typical margin requirement at brokerages is 25%, meaning that customers’ equity must stay above that ratio to prevent a margin call./nUsing margin debt as a form of leverage can magnify gains but also exacerbate losses.

Term: Margin of Safety: Examples, Meaning and FAQ
Definition: A margin of safety is a built-in cushion allowing for some losses to be incurred without major negative effect./nIn investing, the margin of safety incorporates quantitative and qualitative considerations to determine a price target and a safety margin that discounts that target./nBy purchasing stocks at prices well below their target, this discounted price builds in a margin of safety in case estimates were incorrect or biased./nIn accounting the safety margin is built into break-even forecasts to allow for some leeway in those estimates.

Term: Marginal Analysis in Business and Microeconomics, With Examples
Definition: Marginal analysis is an examination of the additional benefits of an activity compared to the additional costs incurred by that same activity./nMarginal refers to the focus on the cost or benefit of the next unit or individual, for example, the cost to produce one more widget or the profit earned by adding one more worker./nCompanies use marginal analysis as a decision-making tool to help them maximize their potential profits./nWhen a manufacturer wishes to expand its operations, either by adding new product lines or increasing the volume of goods produced from the current product line, a marginal analysis of the costs and benefits is necessary./nThe primary takeaway of marginal analysis is to operate until marginal benefit equals marginal cost; this is often the most efficient use of resources.

Term: What Is a Marginal Benefit in Economics, and How Does It Work?
Definition: Marginal benefits represent the maximum cost a consumer will pay for an additional good or service./nA marginal benefit also represents the incremental satisfaction that a consumer receives when an additional good or service is purchased./nThe marginal benefit generally decreases as consumption increases./nThe marginal benefit of some products that are necessities, such as medication, does not decrease over time./nCompanies can use the research they conduct into marginal benefits for the best possible price point for any deal.

Term: Marginal Profit: Definition and Calculation Formula
Definition: Marginal profit is the increase in profits resulting from the production of one additional unit./nMarginal profit is calculated by taking the difference between marginal revenue and marginal cost./nMarginal profit analysis is helpful because it can help determine whether to increase or decrease the level of output.

Term: Marginal Cost: Meaning, Formula, and Examples
Definition: Marginal cost is an important concept in managerial accounting, as it can help an organization optimize its production through economies of scale./nA company can maximize its profits by producing to where marginal cost (MC) equals marginal revenue (MR)./nFixed costs are constant regardless of production levels, so higher production leads to a lower fixed cost per unit as the total is allocated over more units./nVariable costs change based on production levels, so producing more units will add more variable costs./nCompanies must be mindful of when increasing production necessitates results in step costs due to changes in relevant ranges (i.e., additional machinery or storage space needed).

Term: Marginal Propensity To Consume (MPC) in Economics, With Formula
Definition: Marginal propensity to consume is the proportion of an increase in income that gets spent on consumption./nMPC varies by income level. MPC is typically lower at higher incomes./nMPC is the key determinant of the Keynesian multiplier, which describes the effect of increased investment or government spending as an economic stimulus.

Term: Marginal Propensity to Save (MPS): Definition and Calculation
Definition: Marginal propensity to save (MPS) is the proportion of an increase in income that gets saved instead of spent on consumption./nMPS varies by income level and is typically higher at higher incomes./nMPS helps determine the Keynesian multiplier, which describes the effect of increased investment or government spending as an economic stimulus.

Term: Marginal Propensity To Import (MPM): Definition and Calculation
Definition: The marginal propensity to import (MPM) is the change in imports induced by a change in disposable income./nThe idea is that rising income for businesses and households spurs greater demand for goods from abroad and vice versa./nNations that consume more imports as their population's income increases have a significant impact on global trade./nDeveloped economies with sufficient natural resources within their borders typically have a lower MPM than developing countries without these resources.

Term: MRS in Economics: What It Is and the Formula for Calculating It
Definition: The marginal rate of substitution (MRS) measures the willingness of a consumer to replace one good for another good, as long as the same satisfaction—or utility—is maintained./nThe MRS is the slope of the indifference curve at any given point along the curve and displays a frontier of utility for each combination of "good X" and "good Y."/nWhen the law of diminishing MRS is in effect, the MRS forms a downward, negative sloping, convex curve showing more consumption of one good in place of another./nMRS may not inform analysts of true utility as it assumes both products can be exchanged for the same utility./nMRS is also limited in that it only considered two items; it does not consider how additional units may factor into different consumption preferences.

Term: Marginal Rate of Technical Substitution (MRTS) Economic Formula
Definition: The marginal rate of technical substitution shows the rate at which you can substitute one input, such as labor, for another input, such as capital, without changing the level of resulting output./nThe isoquant, or curve on a graph, shows all of the various combinations of the two inputs that result in the same amount of output.

Term: Marginal Rate of Transformation (MRT): Definition and Calculation
Definition: MRT is the number of units that must be forgone to create or attain a unit of another good, considered the opportunity cost to produce one extra unit of something./nMRT is also considered the absolute value of the slope of the production possibilities frontier./nThe marginal rate of substitution focuses on demand, while MRT focuses on supply.

Term: Marginal Revenue Explained, With Formula and Example
Definition: Marginal revenue refers to the incremental change in earnings resulting from the sale of one additional unit./nAnalyzing marginal revenue helps a company identify the revenue generated from each additional unit sold./nMarginal revenue is often shown graphically as a downward-sloping line representing how a company usually has to decrease its prices to drive additional sales./nA company looking to maximize its profits will produce up to the point where marginal cost equals marginal revenue./nWhen marginal revenue falls below marginal cost, firms typically do a cost-benefit analysis and halt production as it may cost more to sell a unit than the company will receive as revenue.

Term: Marginal Revenue Product (MRP): Definition and How It's Predicted
Definition: Marginal revenue product (MRP) is the marginal revenue created by using one additional unit of resource./nMRP is used to make critical decisions on business production and determine the optimal level of a resource./nThe MRP assumes that the expenditures on other factors remain unchanged.

Term: Marginal Tax Rate: What It Is and How To Determine It, With Examples
Definition: The marginaltax rateis the tax rate paid on the highest dollar of income./nUnder theprogressive income taxmethod used for federal income tax in the U.S., the marginal tax rate increases as income increases./nMarginal tax rates are separated into seven tax brackets by income levels./nIndividuals aren't taxed solely at the rate of the tax bracket they fall into (unless they fall into the lowest tax bracket)./nTaxes are calculated at various rates as taxable income rises through the tax brackets.

Term: Marginal Utilities: Definition, Types, Examples, and History
Definition: Marginal utility is the added satisfaction a consumer gets from having one more unit of a good or service./nThe concept of marginal utility is used by economists to determine how much of an item consumers are willing to purchase./nThe law of diminishing marginal utility is often used to justify progressive taxes./nMarginal utility can be positive, zero, or negative.

Term: What Is Maritime (aka Admiralty) Law, and Why Is It Important?
Definition: Maritime law governs private maritime questions, disputes, or offenses and other nautical matters./nIn most developed countries, the maritime law follows a separate code and is an independent jurisdiction from national laws./nThe International Maritime Organization, or IMO, ensures that existing international maritime conventions are kept up to date and develops new agreements when the need arises.

Term: What Is Marital Property (Common Law vs. Community States)?
Definition: Marital property refers to property that a couple acquires during their marriage./nWhere a couple lives determines the laws that govern the distribution of marital property in the event of divorce./nIncommon lawproperty states, property that is acquired by one spouse is considered their sole property unless the title or deed carries both spouses' names./nNine states are community property states, where marital property acquired during the marriage is owned by both spouses equally.

Term: Mark Zuckerberg: Founder and CEO of Meta (formerly Facebook)
Definition: Mark Zuckerberg is a self-taught computer programmer and the co-founder, chair, and CEO of Meta (formerly Facebook)./nAccording toBloomberg, Zuckerberg's net worth as of June 10, 2022, was about $68.2 billion./nFacebook has 2.93 billion monthly active users as of the first quarter of 2022, making it the biggest social network in the world./nIn 2015, Zuckerberg and his wife, Priscilla Chan, founded the Chan Zuckerberg foundation with the goal of delivering "...personalized learning, curing disease, connecting people, and building strong communities."/nIn April 2018, Zuckerberg testified on Capitol Hill about Facebook's use of users' information, including the sharing of 87 million users' information to Cambridge Analytica.

Term: Market: What It Means in Economics, Types, and Common Features
Definition: A market is where buyers and sellers can meet to facilitate the exchange or transaction of goods and services./nMarkets can be physical, like a retail outlet, or virtual, like an e-retailer./nOther examples include illegal markets, auction markets, and financial markets./nThe prices of goods and services are set in markets, determined by supply and demand./nFeatures of a market include the availability of an arena, buyers and sellers, and commodities.

Term: Market Basket: Definition, How It's Used in Investing and Example
Definition: A market basket is a selected mix of goods and services that tracks the performance of a specific market or segment./nA popular market basket is the Consumer Price Index (CPI), which provides an estimate for inflation based on the average change of price paid for a specific basket of goods and services over time./nThe CPI uses over 200 categories, including education, housing, transportation, and recreation, as an economic measure./nA market basket analysis is used by retail stores to predict and increase impulse purchases based on groups of items a customer buys.

Term: Market Approach: Definition and How It Works to Value an Asset
What Is Market Cannibalization? Types and How to Prevent It
Definition: Market cannibalization is a sales loss caused by a company's introduction of a new product that displaces one of its own older products./nMarket cannibalization can occur when a new product is similar to an existing product and both share the same customer base./nMarket cannibalization is sometimes a deliberate strategy to blow out the competition while other times, it's a failure to reach a new target market./nMarket cannibalization is measured by the cannibalization rate, the number of lost sales for old products as a percentage of new sales./nProducts with similar branding are most at risk of cannibalization. It is important to conduct thorough market research and testing to prevent cannibalization.

Term: Market Breadth: Definition, Indicators, and How Investors Use It
Definition: Market breadth looks at the relative change of advancing to declining securities in a market./nIt is a technical analysis technique that gauges the strength or weakness of moves in a major index./nWhen more stocks are advancing than declining, it suggests bullish market sentiment and confirms a broad market uptrend./nConversely, a large number of declining securities confirms bearish momentum and a downside move in the stock index./nCertain breadth indicators also incorporate volume.

Term: Market Capitalization: What It Means for Investors
Definition: Market capitalization shows how much a company is worth as determined by the total market value of all outstanding shares./nTo calculate a company's market cap, multiply the number of outstanding shares by the current market value of one share./nMarket cap is used to determine a company's size, and then compare the company's financial performance to other companies of various sizes.

Term: Market Cycles: Definition, How They Work, and Types
Definition: A cycle refers to trends or patterns that emerge during different business environments./nA cycle time frame often differs for each individual person depending on what trends they are looking for./nA market cycle often has four distinct phases./nIt can be almost impossible to identify what phase of the cycle we are currently in./nAt different stages of a full market cycle, different securities will respond to market forces differently.

Term: Stock Market Capitalization-to-GDP Ratio: Definition and Formula
Definition: The stock market capitalization-to-GDP ratio is a ratio used to determine whether an overall market is undervalued or overvalued compared to a historical average./nIf the valuation ratio falls between 50% and 75%, the market can be said to be modestly undervalued. Also, the market may be fair valued if the ratio falls between 75% and 90%, and modestly overvalued if it falls within the range of 90 and 115%./nThe stock market capitalization-to-GDP ratio is also known as the Buffett Indicator—after investor Warren Buffett, who popularized its use.

Term: What Is Market Depth? Definition, How It's Used, and Example
Definition: Market depth refers to the market liquidity for a security based on the number of standing orders to buy (bids) and sell (offers) at various price levels./nIn addition to price levels, market depth considers the order size, or volume, at each price level./nThe greater the market depth, the less likely that large trades will greatly impact a security's price./nMarket depth can be ascertained by looking at level 2 price quotes that can be found in a security's order book.

Term: Market Dynamics: Definition and Examples
Definition: Market dynamics are the forces that impact prices and the behaviors of producers and consumers in an economy./nThese forces create pricing signals that result from a change in supply and demand./nThe basis of supply-side economics is on the theory that the supply of goods and services is most important in determining economic growth./nDemand-side economics holds that the creation of economic growth is from the high demand for goods and services./nEconomic models cannot capture some dynamics which affect markets and increase market volatility, such as human emotion.

Term: What Is a Market Economy and How Does It Work?
Definition: In a market economy, the law of supply and demand is allowed to determine levels of production and the prices of goods and services./nA market economy gives entrepreneurs the freedom to pursue profits by creating new products, and the freedom to fail if they misread the market./nEconomists broadly agree that market-oriented economies produce better economic outcomes, but they differ on the precise balance between a free market and central planning.

Term: Market Efficiency Explained: Differing Opinions and Examples
Definition: Market efficiency refers to how well current prices reflect all available, relevant information about the actual value of the underlying assets./nA truly efficient market eliminates the possibility of beating the market, because any information available to any trader is already incorporated into the market price./nAs the quality and amount of information increases, the market becomes more efficient reducing opportunities for arbitrage and above market returns.

Term: Market Exposure: Definition, Measurement, Types, Risk Strategies
Definition: Market exposure is the proportion of one's assets that are tied up in a class of securities, a particular industry, or a geographic market./nMarket exposure can be subdivided in various ways to gain insight into the risks posed to investors across different types of markets./nMeasuring and balancing market exposure across all assets in a diversified portfolio is a key aspect of managing total risk.

Term: Market Failure: What It Is in Economics, Common Types, and Causes
Definition: Market failure refers to the inefficient allocation of resources that occurs when individuals acting in rational self-interest produce a sub-optimal outcome./nMarket failure can occur in explicit markets where goods and services are bought and sold outright, or in implicit markets such as elections or the legislative process./nIt may be possible to correct market failures using private market solutions, government-imposed solutions, or voluntary collective actions.
