Term: Negative Feedback: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Negative feedback refers to a case where outputs from a system are subsequently fed back into it, minimizing or reducing the effect of subsequent iterations./nIn markets, negative feedback loops can thus reduce volatility, for example via contrarian investing or value investing./nInvestors using a negative feedback strategy buy stocks when prices decline and sell when prices rise./nWhile technically incorrect, many people refer to a negative feedback loop as a self-perpetuating downward spiral where some initial bad event is compounded and made increasingly worse by the behaviors that result from the initial event. This is, however, an example of a positive feedback loop enhancing a negative outcome.

Term: Negative Gap: What it is, How it Works in Banking
Definition: A negative gap is when an entity's interest-sensitive liabilities exceed its interest-sensitive assets./nIf interest rates decline, the liabilities are priced at lower rates, increasing income. If interest rates increase, the opposite is true./nThe size of a financial institution's gap is an indicator of the impact interest rate changes will have on its net interest income./nA negative gap is a component of asset-liability management; managing cash inflows to pay for liabilities./nA zero duration gap is when there is no positive gap or negative gap and a firm is protected against interest rate movements.

Term: Negative Goodwill (NGW): Definition, Examples, and Accounting
Definition: Negative goodwill (NGW) refers to a bargain purchase amount of money paid when a company acquires another company or its assets./nNegative goodwill indicates that the selling party is in a distressed state and must unload its assets for a fraction of their worth./nNegative goodwill nearly always favors the buyer./nBuying parties must declare negative goodwill on their income statements./nNegative goodwill is the opposite of goodwill, where one company pays a premium for another company's assets./nGoodwill/negative goodwill reporting falls under generally accepted accounting standards (GAAP).

Term: What Is Negative Gearing? Definition, How It Works, and Profiting
Definition: Negative gearing is a form of financial leverage typically seen in the context of property investing./nA negatively geared asset is one that does not produce enough income to cover its cost at the moment./nAn investor who is negative gearing expects to gain from tax benefits in the short term and to eventually sell the asset at a higher price to make up for the initial losses./nNegative gearing only becomes a profitable venture when the property is eventually sold.

Term: Negative Growth: Definition and Economic Impact
Definition: Negative growth is a decline in a company's sales or earnings, or a decrease in an economy's GDP during any quarter./nDeclining wage growth and a contraction of the money supply are characteristics of negative growth, and economists view negative growth as a sign of a possible recession or depression./nThe 2020 COVID-19 pandemic and the Great Recession of 2008 were the last times the U.S. economy experienced significant negative growth.

Term: Negative Interest Rate Environment Definition
Definition: A negative interest rate environment exists when overnight lending rates fall below zero percent./nIn 2009 and 2010, Sweden and, in 2012, Denmark used negative interest rates to stem hot money flows into their economies./nIn 2014, the European Central Bank (ECB) instituted a negative interest rate that only applied to bank deposits intended to prevent the Eurozone from falling into a deflationary spiral./nIn a negative interest rate environment, financial institutions must pay interest to deposit funds and can actually receive interest on borrowed money.

Term: What Is a Negative Interest Rate, and Why Would We Have Them?
Definition: Negative interest rates are a form of monetary policy that sees interest rates fall below 0%./nCentral banks and regulators use this unusual policy tool when there are strong signs of deflation./nBorrowers are credited interest instead of paying interest to lenders in a negative interest rate environment./nCentral banks charge commercial banks on reserves in an effort to incentivize them to spend rather than hoard cash positions./nAlthough commercial banks are charged interest to keep cash with a nation's central bank, they are generally reluctant to pass negative rates onto their customers.

Term: Negative Interest Rate Policy (NIRP): Definition, Uses, Examples
Definition: A negative interest rate policy (NIRP) occurs when a central bank sets its target nominal interest rate at less than zero percent./nThis extraordinary monetary policy tool is used to strongly encourage borrowing, spending, and investment rather than hoarding cash, which will lose value to negative deposit rates./nOfficially set negative rates have been seen in practice following the 2008 financial crisis in several jurisdictions such as in parts of Europe and in Japan.

Term: Negative Pledge Clause: Definition, How It Works, Pros & Cons
Definition: A negative pledge clause is a part of a loan contract that prevents the borrower from pledging their assets to another lender./nNegative pledge clauses are also referred to as "covenants of equal coverage."/nNegative pledge clauses may stipulate that if the bond issuer grants liens against any assets in the future, an equal lien must also be granted to the issuer’s investors./nA negative pledge clause ensures that the original lender will maintain priority if the borrower defaults and their assets are seized./nNegative pledge clauses are sometimes included in mortgages to prevent the borrower from using their home as collateral for other lenders.

Term: Negative Return: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A negative return refers to a loss, either on an investment, a business's performance, or on invested projects./nWhen an investor purchases securities with the goal of those securities appreciating but rather they decrease in value, the investor has a negative return./nIf a business does not generate enough revenues to cover all of its expenses, it will experience a negative return for the period./nProjects that companies invest in utilizing debt financing need to return more than the interest rate on the loan./nNegative returns can greatly impact businesses; in terms of leading to bankruptcy as well as witnessing a decreasing share price and inability to obtain financing.

Term: Negotiable: Definition for Goods, Contracts, Securities
Definition: The word negotiable indicates that the price of a product for sale is not firm./nA negotiable instrument is a document with a face value that can be swapped for cash or goods. A dollar bill is a negotiable instrument, as is a certificate of deposit./nA negotiable instrument is a liquid asset. It can be easily transferred to a series of owners./nNon-negotiable instruments are illiquid. A check issued to one person has no value to another person unless it is properly endorsed by the original payee.

Term: Negative Volume Index (NVI): Meaning, Overview, Calculations
Definition: The negative volume index integrates volume and price to graphically show how price movements are affected by down volume days./nThe negative volume index trendlines can potentially be the best trendlines for following mainstream, smart money movements typically characterized by institutional investors./nNVI can be used in conjunction with the positive volume index (PVI) to see how price is being influenced by volume.

Term: Negotiable Bill of Lading: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Lading is a term that refers to loading cargo onto ships./nA bill of lading is a document outlining the agreement between shipper and carrier as well as the type, quantity, and destination of goods being carried./nAlso known as an order bill of lading, the negotiable bill of lading transfers control (title) of the goods to the order of the entity named on the document./nA clean bill of lading acknowledges that goods have been received in the appropriate condition, without defects./nA straight bill of lading spells out how a carrier can limit their liability.

Term: Negotiable Certificate of Deposit (NCD): Definition and Risk
Definition: Negotiable certificates of deposit are CDs with a minimum face value of $100,000./nThey are guaranteed by banks, cannot be redeemed before their maturation date, and can usually be sold in highly liquid secondary markets./nAlong with U.S. Treasury bills, they are considered a low-risk, low-interest security.

Term: Negotiable Instruments: Definition, Types, and Examples
Definition: A negotiable instrument is a signed document that promises a payment to a specified person or assignee./nNegotiable instruments are transferable, which allows the recipient to take the funds as cash, then use them as preferred./nExamples of negotiable instruments include checks, money orders, and promissory notes.

Term: Negotiable Order of Withdrawal Account: Overview, History
Definition: A NOW Account was a popular interest-earning demand deposit account prior to the Dodd-Frank Act./nNOW Accounts served as an interest-bearing option for liquid funds./nThe Dodd-Frank Act repealed Regulation Q, which prohibited interest on demand deposit accounts.

Term: Negotiated Dealing System (NDS): Definition, History, Membership
Definition: The Negotiated Dealing System (NDS) facilitates trading and dealing in Indian government securities./nThe NDS order matching system (NDS-OM) features two levels of market participation./nEach member type has access to specific modules within the NDS-OM system.

Term: Who Is Nelson Peltz?
Neoclassical Economics: What It Is and Why It's Important
Definition: Classical economists assume that the most important factor in a product's price is its cost of production./nNeoclassical economists argue that the consumer's perception of a product's value is the driving factor in its price./nThe difference between actual production costs and retail price is the economic surplus./nNeoclassical economic theory can impact how businesses operate gov and financial institutions operate, as well as how governments regulate markets./nCritics argue the theory doesn't account for other factors that impact consumer decisions, such as limited information, resource inequality, or emotional thinking.

Term: Negotiation: Definition, Stages, Skills, and Strategies
Definition: Negotiation is a strategic discussion between two parties to resolve an issue in a way that both find acceptable./nNegotiations can take place between buyers and sellers, employers and prospective employees, or the governments of two or more countries, among others./nSuccessful negotiation usually involves compromises on the part of one or all parties.

Term: Nepalese Rupee (NPR): Definition, History, Currency Symbol
Definition: The Nepalese rupee (NPR) is the national currency of Nepal, which was introduced in 1932, replacing the Nepalese mohar./nThe NPR exchange rate is pegged to the Indian rupee (INR) at a rate of 1.6 NPR to INR./nNepal has experienced increased economic growth in recent years, along with declining rates of inflation and a growing gross domestic product (GDP)./nThe currency is available in coins and bills of various denominations. Coins come in rupees and paisas./nTransacting in the NPR can be difficult for foreigners because there are three primary exchange rates operating in Nepal: an official central bank rate, a legal private bank rate, and an illegal black market rate.

Term: What Is the Neoclassical Growth Theory, and What Does It Predict?
Definition: Robert Solow and Trevor Swan first introduced the neoclassical growth theory in 1956./nThe theory states that economic growth is the result of three factors—labor, capital, and technology./nWhile an economy has limited resources in terms of capital and labor, the contribution from technology to growth is boundless.

Term: Neoliberalism: What It Is, With Examples and Pros and Cons
Definition: The policies of neoliberalism typically support fiscal austerity, deregulation, free trade, privatization, and a reduction in government spending./nNeoliberalism is often associated with the economic policies of Margaret Thatcher in the United Kingdom and Ronald Reagan in the United States./nThere are many criticisms of neoliberalism, including its potential danger to democracy, harm it causes to workers' rights, and that it structures society and the economy around markets that are far less rational than assumed./nIt's also been accused of giving corporations too much power and worsening economic inequality.

Term: Nest Egg: Definition, Importance, How To Invest
Definition: A nest egg is a substantial sum of money or other assets that have been saved or invested for a specific purpose./nSuch assets are generally earmarked for longer-term objectives, the most common being retirement, buying a home, and education./nA nest egg should typically be invested in relatively conservative instruments such as certificates of deposit, bonds, and dividend-paying blue chips.

Term: Net Asset Value (NAV): Definition, Formula, Example, and Uses
Definition: Net Asset Value is the net value of an investment fund's assets less its liabilities, divided by the number of shares outstanding./nNAV is commonly used as a per-share value calculated for a mutual fund or ETF./nNAV is calculated at the end of each trading day based on the closing market prices of the portfolio's securities.

Term: Net Asset Value Per Share (NAVPS): Definition, Formula, Uses
Definition: NAVPS represents the value per share of a mutual fund, ETF, or closed-end fund./nIt is often used in relation to open-end mutual funds since shares are redeemed at their NAV./nMarket price and NAVPS, however, may vary for closed-end funds and ETFs.

Term: Net Change: What it is, How it Works, Charts
Definition: Net change is the difference between closing prices from one day to the next./nNet change is the most commonly reported data from securities quotes./nNet change forms the basis of most line charts in technical analysis.

Term: Net Charge-Off: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A net charge-off (NCO) is the amount representing the difference between gross charge-offs and recoveries of delinquent debt./nNet charge-offs are the debt owed to a company unlikely to be recovered by that company./nThe Federal Reserve Bank tracks aggregate net charge-off ratios for banks in the U.S.—the ratio is defined as net charge-offs divided by average total loans during a period.

Term: Net Cash: What It Is and How It's Calculated
Definition: Net cash, a figure that is reported on a company's financial statements, is calculated by subtracting a company's total liabilities from its total cash./nThe net cash figure is commonly used when evaluating a company's cash flows./nNet cash may also refer to the amount of cash remaining after a transaction has been completed and all associated charges and deductions have been subtracted.

Term: Net Current Asset Value Per Share (NCAVPS): Definition & Formula
Definition: Benjamin Graham created net current asset value per share (NCAVPS), a measure that helps investors evaluate a stock as a potential investment./nNCAVPS is a key metric for value investors and is arrived at by subtracting a company's total liabilities (including preferred stock) from its current assets and dividing the total by the shares outstanding./nBy comparing the NCAVPS with the share price, Graham believed investors could find undervalued stocks at a bargain price.

Term: Net Debt Per Capita: What It Means, How It Works, and Significance
Definition: Net debt per capita is calculated by dividing a jurisdiction's total debt by the number of people living within it./nNet debt per capita is one way to assess the level of government debt./nThis statistic is often used to make a political statement about current fiscal policy rather than as a true economic indicator.

Term: How Net Debt Is Calculated and Why It Matters to a Company
Definition: Net debt is a liquidity metric used to determine how well a company can pay all of its debts if they were due immediately./nNet debt shows how much cash would remain if all debts were paid off and if a company has enough liquidity to meet its debt obligations./nNet debt is calculated by subtracting a company's total cash and cash equivalents from its total short-term and long-term debt.

Term: Net Debt-to-EBITDA Ratio: Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The net debt-to-EBITDA ratio is a debt ratio that shows how many years it would take for a company to pay back its debt if net debt and EBITDA are held constant./nWhen analysts look at the net debt-to-EBITDA ratio, they want to know how well a company can cover its debts./nIt is similar to the debt/EBITDA ratio, but net debt subtracts cash and cash equivalents while the standard ratio does not./nIf a company has more cash than debt, the ratio can be negative.

Term: What Is the Net Domestic Product (NDP)? Formula for Calculation
Definition: Net domestic product (NDP) is an annual measure of the economic output of a nation that is adjusted to account for depreciation./nIt is calculated by subtracting depreciation from the gross domestic product (GDP)./nNDP, along with GDP, gross national income (GNI), disposable income, and personal income, is one of the key gauges of economic growth that is reported on a quarterly basis by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA)./nAn increase in NDP would indicate growing economic health, while a decrease would indicate economic stagnation.

Term: Net Exports: Definition, Examples, Formula, and Calculation
Definition: A nation's net exports number is a straightforward calculation: The value of its total exports minus the value of its total imports equals its net exports./nA positive net export number indicates a trade surplus, while a negative number means a trade deficit./nA weak currency exchange rate makes a nation's exports more competitive in price in other countries./nCountries with comparative advantages such as natural resources or a skilled workforce tend to be net exporters./nExamples of net exporters are Australia and Saudi Arabia.

Term: Net Foreign Assets (NFA) Meaning & Creditor/Debtor Status
Definition: Net foreign assets (NFA) determine whether a country is a creditor or debtor nation by measuring the difference in its external assets and liabilities./nA nation's NFA position is also defined as the cumulative change in its current account, which is the sum of the balance of trade, net income over time, and net current transfers over time./nThe NFA metric can be impacted by valuation and exchange rate changes.

Term: Net Foreign Factor Income (NFFI) Definition, Equation, Importance
Definition: Net foreign factor income (NFFI) is the difference between a nation’s gross national product (GNP) and gross domestic product (GDP)./nNFFI is generally not substantial in most nations since payments earned by citizens and those paid to foreigners more or less offset each other./nNFFI may assume increasing importance in a globalized economy, as people and companies move across international borders more easily than they did in the past.

Term: Net Exposure: Overview, Examples, Risks and FAQ
Definition: Net exposure is the difference between a hedge fund's short positions and long positions, expressed as a percentage./nA lower level of net exposure decreases the risk of the fund’s portfolio being affected by market fluctuations./nNet exposure should ideally be considered along with a fund's gross exposure.

Term: Net Importer: Meaning, Example, Pros and Cons
Definition: A net importer is a country, which in aggregate, purchases more goods from foreign countries through trade than it sells abroad./nA net importer, by definition, runs a current account deficit in the aggregate./nThe United States, a consumer colossus, has been a net importer for decades with an import deficit of $678.7 billion in 2020.

Term: Net Income (NI): Definition, Uses, and Formula
Definition: Net income (NI) is calculated as revenue minus expenses, interest, and taxes./nEarnings per share (EPS) are calculated using NI./nInvestors should review the numbers used to calculate NI because expenses can be hidden in accounting methods, or revenues can be inflated./nNI also represents an individual’s total earnings or pretax earnings after factoring deductions and taxes in gross income.

Term: Net Income After Taxes (NIAT): Definition, Calculation, Example
Definition: Net income after taxes (NIAT) is a financial term used to describe a company's profit after all taxes have been paid./nNet income after taxes represents the profit or earnings after all expense have been deducted from revenue./nCompanies that increase net income have more cash to invest in the company's future, pay dividends, and buyback stock.

Term: Net Interest Income: What It Is, How It's Calculated, Examples
Definition: Net interest income reflects the difference between the revenue generated from a bank's interest-bearing assets and the expenses associated with paying its interest-bearing liabilities./nThe type of assets earning interest for the bank can range from mortgages to auto, personal, and commercial real estate loans./nThe amount of net interest income a bank generates will depend on many factors including the quality of the loan portfolio, the collective interest rates each type of loan carries, as well as whether the loans carry a fixed or variable rate./nBanks calculate their net interest income by subtracting the interest they must pay out to their clients from the interest income they generate./nYou can find a bank's net interest income in its quarterly and annual reports.

Term: Net Interest Rate Differential (NIRD): What It is, How it Works
Definition: The net interest rate differential (NIRD) measures the total difference in interest rates of two currencies in the forex market./nThe net interest rate differential is the difference in any interest earned and any interest paid while holding the currency pair position after accounting for fees, taxes, and other charges./nThe NIRD plays an important role in evaluating the merits of a currency carry trade.

Term: What Is Net Interest Margin? Overview, Formula, Example
Definition: Net interest margin is a measure of the profitability of a bank or other financial firm./nNet interest margin is calculated by taking the interest a company earns from loans, and subtracting the interest it pays to its creditors./nA high net interest margin suggests that a company is lending its capital effectively./nNet interest margins tend to increase sharply during a recession, and fall slowly during a recovery.

Term: Net Internal Rate of Return: Definition, Uses, and Example
Definition: Net internal rate of return (Net IRR) is a way of gauging the performance of a project or investment based on its discounted future cash flows./nNet IRR takes traditional IRR and then accounts for the effects of fees, costs, carried interest, and other deductions that IRR would typically overlook./nBecause it factors in costs and fees, net IRR gives investors or managers a more accurate picture of an investment's actualized potential.

Term: Net International Investment Position (NIIP): Definition, Example
Definition: A net international investment position (NIIP) measures the gap between a nation’s stock of foreign assets and a foreigner's stock of that nation's assets./nIt can be viewed as a nation’s balance sheet with the rest of the world at a specific point in time./nNIIP is an important barometer of a nation’s financial condition and creditworthiness./nA nation with a positive NIIP is a creditor nation, while a nation with a negative NIIP is a debtor nation.

Term: Net Interest Rate Spread: Definition and Use in Profit Analysis
Definition: The net interest rate spread is the difference between the interest rate a bank pays and the interest rate it receives in its income-generating activities./nThe net interest rate spread is instrumental to a bank's profitability./nIt can be helpful to think of the net interest rate as how much a bank profits in a given period.

Term: Net Investment: Definition, Uses, How to Calculate, and Example
Definition: Net investment indicates how much a company is spending to maintain and improve its operations./nIf net investment is positive, the company is expanding its capacity./nIf net investment is negative, its capacity is shrinking.

Term: Net Lease Definition and Types—Single, Double, Triple
Definition: In a net lease, the tenant pays a portion or all of the taxes, insurance fees, and maintenance costs for a property in addition to rent./nNet leases are commonly used in the commercial real estate sector./nLandlords use net leases when they don't want to deal with the hassles associated with ongoing maintenance and other costs./nTypes of net leases include single net, double net, and triple net leases.

Term: What Is Net Investment Income (NII)? Overview of How It's Taxed
Definition: Net investment income is income received from assets (before taxes) including bonds, stocks, mutual funds, loans, and other investments (less related expenses)./nNII is subject to a 3.8% tax for individuals with an NII and MAGI above certain thresholds./nEstates and trusts are subject to the NII tax if they have undistributed NII and their annual adjusted gross income exceeds the dollar amount at which the highest tax bracket begins./nFor investment companies, this is the amount of income left after operating expenses are subtracted from total investment income./nThe net investment income tax went into effect in 2013 as a means of raising revenue to fund the Affordable Care Act.

Term: Net Liquid Assets: Meaning, Advantages, Example
Definition: Net liquid assets are a measure of the near-term liquidity position of a firm, calculated as liquid assets less current liabilities./nLiquid assets include cash, marketable securities, and accounts receivables. They are any assets that can be quickly converted into cash./nHaving a net liquid asset position signifies a company is in good health and is able to pay its short-term obligations, such as paying suppliers and paying down short-term debt./nA net liquid asset position also demonstrates that a company can make new investments without having to take on financing./nHaving too many liquid assets, however, demonstrates an idle use of cash, whereby the money could be put to better use, such as other investments or paying out dividends.

Term: Net Loss: Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: A net loss occurs when the sum total of expenses exceeds the total income or revenue generated by a business, project, transaction, or investment./nBusinesses would report a net loss on the income statement, effectively as a negative net profit./nMany factors can contribute to a net loss including low revenues, strong competition, unsuccessful marketing campaigns, and increased cost of goods sold (COGS).

Term: Net-Net: Definition, How It Works, Formula To Calculate
Definition: The net-net value investing strategy was developed by Benjamin Graham using net current asset value per share (NCAVPS) as the primary measure to evaluate the merits of a stock./nAccording to the net-net strategy, the ability to generate revenue from current assets is the true value proposition of a business./nCurrent assets, which are used in the net-net approach, are defined as assets that are cash, and assets that are converted into cash within 12 months, including accounts receivable and inventory./nThe net-net investing strategy does not consider long-term assets or liabilities, making it unreliable for long-term investments according to its critics.

Term: Net National Product (NNP)
Definition: Net national product (NNP) is gross national product (GNP), the total value of finished goods and services produced by a country's citizens overseas and domestically, minus depreciation./nNNP is often examined on an annual basis as a way to measure a nation's success in continuing minimum production standards./nGross Domestic Product (GDP) is the most popular method to measure national income and economic prosperity, although NNP is prominently used in environmental economics.

Term: Net of Tax: Definition, Benefits of Analysis, and How to Calculate
Definition: Net of tax is the amount left after adjusting for the effects of taxes./nNet of tax analysis can be important to consider in all situations where taxes may be involved./nSome scenarios where the net of tax can be especially important include large asset purchases with sales tax, before and after-tax contributions, and income taxes for individuals or businesses.

Term: What Is Net Neutrality? Policies and Controversy
Definition: Network neutrality ensures that all data on the internet is treated equally by ISPs and governments, regardless of content, user, platform, application, or device./nNet neutrality policy discussions target issues such as blocking or filtering online content, and preferential internet speeds based on business agreements./nU.S. net neutrality laws were enacted by the Obama administration in 2015 and repealed by the Trump administration in 2018./nThe Net Neutrality and Broadband Justice Act was introduced in July 2022 and would give the FCC tools to protect the free and open internet and create a just broadband future for everyone in the United States.

Term: Net Operating Loss (NOL): Definition and Carryforward Rules
Definition: A net operating loss exists if a company’s deductions exceed taxable income./nAn NOL can benefit a company by reducing taxable income in future tax years./nThe Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) made significant changes to NOL rules./nNOLs may now be carried forward indefinitely until the loss is fully recovered, but they are limited to 80% of the taxable income in any one tax period./nThe Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act removed the restrictions on tax loss carryback for tax years 2018, 2019, and 2020./nNet operating losses in 2021 or later may not be carried back and must be carried forward indefinitely.

Term: Calculating Net Operating Income (NOI) for Real Estate
Definition: Net operating income measures an income-producing property's profitability./nTo calculate NOI, subtract all operating expenses incurred on a property from all revenue generated./nNOI helps a property owner determine if renting a property is worth the expense of owning and maintaining it.

Term: Net Premium Definition, Calculation, vs. Gross Premium
Definition: Net premium is an insurance industry accounting term./nThe formula to arrive at the net premium is the expected present value (PV) of an insurance policy’s benefits minus the expected PV of future premiums./nNet premium and gross premium are useful in calculating the amount of state taxes an insurance company needs to pay./nSome states' tax laws allow insurance companies to reduce the amount of their taxable gross premium by adding back expenses.

Term: What Is Net Operating Profit Less Adjusted Taxes (NOPLAT)?
Definition: The net operating profit less adjusted taxes (NOPLAT) is EBIT after adjusting for deferred taxes./nThe tax is adjusted to reflect the un-leveraged profits of the firm without taking into account the effects of tax debt./nThis metric is a profit measurement that includes the costs and tax benefits of debt financing./nNOPLAT is used to heavily in M&A, DCF, and LBO models as it enables the calculation of free cash flow.

Term: Net Operating Profit After Tax (NOPAT) Definition and Formula
Definition: Net operating profit after tax (NOPAT) measures the efficiency of a leveraged company's operations./nNOPAT excludes tax savings from existing debt and one-time losses or charges./nMergers and acquisitions analysts use NOPAT to calculate the free cash flow to firm (FCFF) and economic free cash flow to firm.

Term: Net Premiums Written: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Net premiums written is the sum of premiums written, minus the premiums ceded to reinsurance companies, plus any reinsurance assumed./nThe amount of net premiums written sheds light on how much business an insurance company is doing in a specified period./nWhen calculating net premiums, an insurance company must account for the difference between earned and unearned premiums./nThe net premium calculation must take into consideration an estimate for future expenses and include that in the premiums charged to customers.

Term: Net Present Value (NPV): What It Means and Steps to Calculate It
What Are Net Proceeds? Definition, How to Calculate, and Example
Definition: Net proceeds are the amount the seller takes home after selling an asset, minus all costs and expenses that have been deducted from the gross proceeds./nThe amount that constitutes the net proceeds could be marginal or substantial, depending on the asset that has been sold./nCapital gains taxes must be paid on the net proceeds of a sale, not the gross proceeds.

Term: What Is Net Profit Margin? Formula for Calculation and Examples
Definition: Net profit margin measures how much profit a company makes as a percentage of its revenue./nNet profit margin helps investors assess if a company’s management is generating enough profit from its sales and whether operating costs and overhead costs are under control./nNet profit margin is one of the most important indicators of a company’s overall financial health.

Term: NRV: What Net Realizable Value Is and a Formula To Calculate It
Definition: Net realizable value (NRV) accounts for the value of an asset in terms of the amount it would receive upon sale, minus selling costs./nNRV is a conservative method used by accountants to ensure the value of an asset isn't overstated./nIt is a common method used to evaluate accounts receivable and inventory, and is also used in cost accounting./nDownsides to NRV include the fact that assumptions by management may never come to fruition as well as it being a more complicated way of considering asset values./nNRV is used in both generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as well as international financial reporting standards (IFRS).

Term: What Is Net Receivables? Definition, Calculation, and Example
Definition: A company's net receivables are the total amount of money its customers owe minus what the company estimates will likely never be paid./nCompanies use net receivables to measure the effectiveness of their collections process and to make projections of anticipated cash flows./nThe allowance for doubtful accounts is a company's estimate of the amount of the accounts receivable it expects it will have to write-off as uncollectible./nCompanies can improve their net receivables by restricting the credit they issue to customers and by implementing efficient collection procedures.

Term: Net Sales: What They Are and How to Calculate Them
Definition: Net sales is the result of gross sales minus returns, allowances, and discounts./nIf net sales are externally reported they will be notated in the direct costs portion of the income statement./nChanges in net sales will effect a company’s gross profit and gross profit margin but net sales do not include costs of goods sold.

Term: Net Settlement: What it is, How it Works
Definition: During the business day, a bank accumulates credits and debits with other banks./nAt the end of the day, every bank calculates how much it owes other banks, and how much it is owed./nEach bank then files its numbers with the central bank, which manages the transfers of money among all banks.

Term: Net Tangible Assets: Definition, Calculation, Examples
Definition: Net tangible assets are all the physical assets a company owns less any intangible assets and liabilities./nThey are listed on a company's balance sheet and indicate its book value./nTo calculate a company's net tangible assets, subtract its liabilities, par value of preferred shares,and any intangible assets, such as goodwill, patents, and trademarks from its total assets./nNet tangible assets allow analysts to focus on a firm's physical assets in isolation./nCompanies can access financing and determine how much risk they carry based on the value of their net tangible assets.

Term: Net Unrealized Appreciation (NUA): Definition and Tax Treatment
Definition: Net unrealized appreciation (NUA) is the difference between the original cost basis and current market value of shares of employer stock./nThe IRS offers a provision that allows for a more favorable capital gains tax rate on the NUA of employer stock upon distribution, after certain qualifying events./nThe downside is that ordinary income tax must be paid immediately on the cost basis of the shares of employer stock.

Term: Netting: Definition, How It Works, Types, Benefits, and Example
Definition: Netting offsets the value of multiple positions or payments due to be exchanged between two or more parties./nNetting is used in a number of settings and instances—securities or currency trading, bankruptcy, and inter-company transactions, among others./nNetting can involve more than two parties, called multilateral netting, and generally involves a central exchange or clearinghouse.

Term: Netback: Definition, Calculation Formula, Analysis, Example
Definition: Only oil producers use the term netback./nNetback is a summary of all costs associated with bringing one unit of product to the marketplace./nThe netback price can be used to compare one oil producer to another./nA producer can examine cost-effectiveness by reviewing the netback over time.

Term: Net Worth: What It Is and How to Calculate It
Definition: Net worth is a quantitative concept that measures the value of an entity and can apply to individuals, corporations, sectors, and even countries./nNet worth provides a snapshot of an entity's current financial position./nIn business, net worth is also known as book value or shareholders' equity./nPeople with substantial net worth are called high-net-worth individuals (HNWI)./nElon Musk currently has the highest net worth of any individual on the planet.

Term: Network Marketing Meaning and How It Works
Definition: Network marketing appeals to people with high energy and strong sales skills, who can build a profitable business with a modest investment./nA network marketing business can be a single-tier program, whereby you sell the products, or multi-tier, where you also recruit additional salespeople./nBeware of network marketing companies that create many tiers of salespeople or require you to purchase expensive products or training material up-front, Make sure to thoroughly research the company before you join.

Term: Network Effect: What It Is, How It Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: The network effect is a phenomenon whereby increased numbers of people improve the value of a good or service./nE-commerce sites, such as Etsy and eBay, grew in popularity by accessing online networks and attracting consumers to their products./nSome companies cannot achieve critical mass—the number of users needed for the network effect to take hold—even with access to online and offline networks./nCongestion is a negative network effect whereby too many users can slow a network down, reducing its utility and frustrating network members./nThe more popular a business or product grows, the more the users effectively act as salesmen, spreading word of the business themselves.

Term: What Is a Neural Network?
Definition: Neural networks are a series of algorithms that mimic the operations of an animal brain to recognize relationships between vast amounts of data./nAs such, they tend to resemble the connections of neurons and synapses found in the brain./nThey are used in a variety of applications in financial services, from forecasting and marketing research to fraud detection and risk assessment./nNeural networks with several process layers are known as "deep" networks and are used for deep learning algorithms/nThe success of neural networks for stock market price prediction varies.

Term: Networking: What It Is and How to Do It Successfully
Definition: Networking is used by professionals to widen their circles of acquaintances, find out about job opportunities, and increase their awareness of news and trends in their fields./nBusiness owners network to develop relationships with people and companies they may do business with in the future./nProfessional networking platforms provide an online location for people to engage with other professionals, join groups, post blogs, and share information./nThe coronavirus pandemic drove many to network solely online rather than in person./nMany colleges and universities provide opportunities for alumni to network with one another.

Term: Neutral: Meaning, Strategies, Pros and Cons
Definition: Neutral is an agnostic position in terms of price movements and so is neither bullish nor bearish./nSideways markets or other neutral trends can be taken advantage of through neutral trading strategies./nThe use of derivatives such as delta-neutral options positions can achieve a neutral portfolio.

Term: Neutrality of Money Theory: Definition, History, and Critique
Definition: The neutrality of money theory claims that changes in the money supply affect the prices of goods, services, and wages but not overall economic productivity./nThe theory states that changes in the supply of money do not alter the underlying conditions of the economy and, therefore, aggregate supply should remain constant./nSome economists only agree that the theory of neutrality works over the long term. The assumption of long-run money neutrality underlies almost all macroeconomic theory./nCritics of the neutrality of money believe that it increases prices and therefore impacts consumption and production./nThe phrase “neutrality of money” was introduced by Austrian economist Friedrich A. Hayek in 1931.

Term: The New Deal: Meaning, Overview, History
Definition: The New Deal was a series of domestic programs introduced by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in an attempt to end the economic ravages of the Great Depression./nThe New Deal also attempted to curb the excesses of untrammeled capitalism through such policies as setting minimum wages, regulating working conditions, promoting labor unions, and bolstering retirement security./nThe New Deal made the government’s role in steering the economy more important.

Term: New Indications
Definition: New indications refers to news signifying that an existing drug may have a broader range of medical applications./nRepurposing existing drugs in this manner can prove less costly than developing new drugs from scratch./nInvestors often view new indications as a bullish indicator, anticipating that the company in question will have access to new revenue streams at a relatively low cost.

Term: What Is New Growth Theory? Definition, How It's Used, and Example
Definition: The new growth theory presumes the desire and wants of the populace will drive ongoing productivity and economic growth./nA central tenet of new growth theory is that competition squeezes profit, forcing people to constantly seek better ways to do things or invent new products in order to maximize profitability./nThe theory emphasizes the importance of entrepreneurship, knowledge, innovation, and technology, rejecting the popular view that economic growth is determined by external, uncontrollable forces./nKnowledge is treated as an asset for growth that is not subject to finite restrictions ordiminishing returns like other assets such as capital or real estate.

Term: New Fund Offer (NFO): Definition, Types, Launches, and Benefits
Definition: A new fund offer (NFO) refers to the initial sale of fund shares issued by an investment company to investors./nSimilar to an IPO in the stock market, NFOs are intended to raise capital for the fund and attract investors./nEven though NFOs are marketed, they are done less aggressively than IPOs, and target certain select groups of investors. As a result, new fund issues may be less noticeable to individual investors than IPOs./nInvestors should check an NFO's expense ratio and the performance of previous funds offered by the investment company before deciding to invest in an NFO./nInvestors looking to research new fund launches can monitor the press releases of various investment companies as well as news outlets dedicated to aggregating the latest fund news.

Term: New Indications
Definition: New indications refers to news signifying that an existing drug may have a broader range of medical applications./nRepurposing existing drugs in this manner can prove less costly than developing new drugs from scratch./nInvestors often view new indications as a bullish indicator, anticipating that the company in question will have access to new revenue streams at a relatively low cost.

Term: New Home Sales: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: New Home Sales, also known as "new residential sales," is an economic indicator that measures sales of newly built homes./nNew Home Sales is viewed as a lagging indicator of demand, but is still closely watched by investors for clues about the broader movements in the economy./nNew Home Sales data is based on a representative sample of home sales and is driven by factors such as household income, unemployment, and interest rates.

Term: New Economy: Definition, History, Examples of Companies
Definition: New economy is a buzzword that was used to add to the hype of what tech companies in the 1990s were promising in terms of new ways of doing business and earning a living./nAs originally coined, the new economy is here, with more people using technology in their daily lives./nThe companies at the forefront of the new economy have become larger than many of the traditional manufacturing companies they were predicted to replace in terms of importance./nMore recently, the term new economy has also been used to refer to a redesign of the capitalist system around environmental and social goals.

Term: New Keynesian Economics: Definition and Vs. Keynesian
Definition: New Keynesian economics is a modern twist on the macroeconomic doctrine that evolved from classical Keynesian economics principles./nEconomists argued that prices and wages are “sticky," causing involuntary unemployment and monetary policy to have a big impact on the economy./nThis way of thinking became the dominant force in academic macroeconomics from the 1990s through to the financial crisis of 2008.

Term: New Issue: Definition, How It Works in Offerings, and Example
Definition: New issues, whether stocks or bonds, are a means of raising capital for a company./nNew equity shares are often issued via an initial public offering (IPO), allowing investors to buy the stock of a previously private company for the first time./nBonds, preferreds, and convertible securities may also be disseminated as new issues to raise debt capital for a firm./nBonds as new issues are considered a form of debt financing, while stocks and IPOs as new issues are considered a form of equity financing./nInvestors should be aware of the "hype" surrounding a new issue like an IPO, as it could go one way or the other./nCompanies that are already public can make a new issue through a secondary offering.

Term: New Paradigm: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: A new paradigm is a new way of thinking or doing things that replaces the old way./nNew paradigms in the stock world can mean great profit potential as investors pile into revolutionary new ideas./nInvestors in new paradigm ideas should tread cautiously as prices can become too inflated based on hype.

Term: New York Board of Trade (NYBOT): Meaning, How it Works, Example
Definition: The New York Board of Trade (NYBOT) is a commodity futures exchange that today forms part of the ICE since 2006./nNYBOT previously specialized in physical commodities such as sugar and coffee, but has become all-electronic since incorporation into the ICE./nThe NYBOT is one of the oldest asset exchanges in the U.S., dating back to 1870.

Term: New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX): Meaning, Overview, FAQ
Definition: NYMEX is a commodities trading exchange that started in 1872 and was acquired by CME Group in 2008./nThe exchange lists futures and options on various metals, energy, and agricultural commodities./nNYMEX was once an open-outcry market with trading pits, but like most exchanges today, it has become increasingly electronic./nNYMEX trading is a large percentage of the total trading done by CME./nNYMEX's contribution to the CME group from the acquisition was a substantial selection of energy products, metal contracts, and agricultural contracts.

Term: New York Stock Exchange (NYSE): Definition, How It Works, History
Definition: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), which dates back to 1792, is the largest stock exchange in the world based on the total market capitalization of its listed securities./nIt was the first formalized stock exchange established in the United States./nMany of the oldest publicly traded U.S. companies are listed on the "Big Board," the nickname for the NYSE./nThe Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) now owns the NYSE, having purchased the exchange in 2013.

Term: Newly Industrialized Country (NIC): Definition and Examples
Definition: A newly industrialized country (NIC) is one whose economic development is between developing and highly developed classifications./nThe most significant sign that a country is evolving into a NIC is substantial growth in gross domestic product, even if that growth falls short of developed nations./nWhich countries should be included on a list of existing NICs is open to some debate among experts and economists./nHighly developed countries might find opportunities, such as outsourcing, in newly industrialized countries.

Term: NEX: What It Is, How It Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: The NEX is a subsidiary of the TSX Venture Exchange for listed companies that no longer meet the TSX Venture's ongoing listing standards./nThe NEX is designed for companies with low levels of business activity or that have ceased to carry on active business./nThe NEX benefits these companies by providing liquidity and visibility that may attract potential acquirers or investors./nCompanies that do not meet the TSX Venture Exchange's listing requirements are typically moved to the NEX board after 90 days./nNEX has lower listing fees and simplified rules compared to the TSX Venture Exchange.

Term: What Is a News Trader? 'Buy the Rumor, Sell the News' Explained
Definition: News traders use scheduled announcements to take up positions that profit from short-term volatility./nNews traders can also trade significant, unplanned events that impact the domestic or global economy./nNews traders tend to hold positions for a very short period of time as the impact of news usually fades quickly after being made public.

Term: Next In, First Out (NIFO): What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: Next In, First Out (NIFO) is a method of valuation where the cost of an item is based upon its replacement cost rather than its original cost./nTo reflect actual business conditions, companies may use NIFO internally when inflation is a factor and replacement cost is higher than an item's original cost./nNIFO does not conform to generally accepted accounting principles.

Term: What (and Who) Is Next of Kin, and Why Does It Matter?
Definition: Next of kin is defined as a person's closest living relatives through blood or legal relationships./nThe specifics of determining next of kin, and inheritance, vary by jurisdiction./nA legal will covering inheritable property usually takes precedence over the inheritance rights of someone's next of kin./nIn some cases, the next of kin may be able to inherit someone's digital assets and obligations./nFunds from insurance policies and retirement accounts go to beneficiaries designated by these documents, regardless of relationships or willbequests.

Term: NEXUS: What it Means, How it Works, Ineligibility
Definition: NEXUS is a government-sponsored program that eases travel bureaucracy for pre-screened citizens of the United States and Canada across air, land, and sea./nNEXUS members can use the Global Entry and TSA PreCheck programs without applying separately to each./nMembership to NEXUS is valid for slightly more than five years and is available by paying a $50 fee and consenting to a background check and personal interview.

Term: Nigerian Letter Scam Definition and How to Avoid It
Definition: The Nigerian letter scam is a scheme in which a sender offers a commission to someone—generally via email—to help transfer a large sum of money./nNigerian letter scammers hope the commission offered will be enticing enough to compel recipients to send thousands of dollars to a stranger./nThe reasons given for the transfer can differ from a government freezing an account to an inheritance with no beneficiary./nNigerian letter scams are also known as advance fee fraud or 419 fraud./nThe name stems from the prevalence of these scams in Nigeria during the 1990s.

Term: Nifty Fifty: What it is and how it Works
Definition: The Nifty Fifty was a group of 50 large-cap stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in the 1960s and 1970s, characterized by their consistent earnings growth and high P/E ratios./nExamples of Nifty Fifty stocks included household names such as General Electric, Coca-Cola, and IBM. However, part of this list also included now-struggling or defunct companies like Xerox and Polaroid./nToday’s blue-chip stocks in several ways resemble the Nifty Fifty stocks of prior decades.

Term: Night Depository: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A night depository is a secured drop box on the exterior of a bank where accountholders can deposit their daily cash, checks, and credit card slips outside of normal banking hours./nNight depositories are used mainly by small business owners who still deal mainly in cash and checks, and want these receivables secured as soon as possible./nNight depositories are unlocked with a key, and deposits are inserted into them in special locked bags. Banks open them the next business day, tally the funds, and deposit them in the client's business account./nClients pay a fee to for night depository service.

Term: Nikkei: How it Works, Special Considerations
Definition: The Nikkei is Japan's leading stock index comprised of the country's top 225 blue-chip stocks./nThe Nikkei is a price-weighted index, which means the index is an average of the share prices of all the companies listed./nSome of the best-known companies listed in the Nikkei are Sony Corporation, Canon Inc, Nissan Motor Company, and Honda Motor Company./nAnother Japanese stock index is the Tokyo Price Index (or TOPIX), which is a capitalization-weighted index that includes all the stocks in the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

Term: NINJA Loan: Definition, History, Current Availability
Definition: A NINJA (no income, no job, and no assets) loan is a term describing a loan extended to a borrower who may have no ability to repay the loan./nA NINJA loan is extended with no verification of a borrower's assets./nNINJA loans largely disappeared after the U.S. government issued new regulations to improve standard lending practices after the 2008 financial crisis./nSome NINJA loans offer attractive low interest rates that increase over time./nThey were popular because they could be obtained quickly and without the borrower having to provide documentation.

Term: What Is the Nixon Shock? Definition, What Happened, and Aftereffects
Definition: The Nixon Shock relates to an economic policy shift undertaken by President Nixon to prioritize jobs growth, lower inflation, and exchange rate stability./nIt effectively led to the end of the convertibility of U.S. dollars into gold./nThe Nixon Shock was the catalyst for thestagflationof the 1970s as the U.S. dollar devalued./nThanks in large part to the Nixon Shock, central banks have more control over their nations' money and the management of variables such as interest rates, overall money supply, andvelocity./nLong after the Nixon Shock, economists are still debating the merits of this policy shift and its eventual ramifications.

Term: No Documentation (No Doc) Mortgages: How it Works, Types
Definition: No documentation mortgages do not require income verification from the borrower, only a declaration that the borrower can repay the loan./nNo doc mortgages are commonly granted to individuals who don't have a regular source of income including those who are self-employed./nSince the Great Recession, true no doc mortgages are essentially illegal./n"No doc" mortgages may now be loans that do not require traditional income-verifying documents, but that still require other documents./nNo doc mortgages generally require higher down payments and higher interest rates than traditional mortgages.

Term: No-Par Value Stock: Meaning and Use Cases
Definition: No-par value stock is issued without a par value./nThe value of no-par value stocks is determined by the price investors are willing to pay on the open market./nThe advantage of no-par value stock is that companies can then issue stock at higher prices in future offerings./nWhile no-par value stock is issued with no face value, low-par value stock is issued with a price as low as $0.01./nOn the downside of low-par value stock, if the issuing company defaults or shutters its doors, analysts may assume it was never fully capitalized to begin with.

Term: No-Load Fund: Definition, How It Works, Benefits, and Examples
Definition: A no-load fund is a mutual fund that doesn't charge commission or sales charge./nNo-load funds are possible because the shares are distributed directly by the investment company, instead of going through a secondary party./nLoad funds charge a commission at the time of the fund's purchase, at the time of its sale, or as a "level-load" for as long as the investor holds a stake./nOver 90% of mutual funds are no-load funds.

Term: No-Shop Clause: Meaning, Examples and Exceptions
Noise: What it Means, Cause, Alternatives
Definition: Noise refers to information or activity that confuses or misrepresents genuine underlying trends./nIn the financial markets, noise can include small price movements and corrections in that distort the overall trend./nMarket noise can make it difficult to determine what's driving a trend or if a trend is changing or merely experiencing short-term volatility.

Term: No-Load Fund: Definition, How It Works, Benefits, and Examples
Definition: A no-load fund is a mutual fund that doesn't charge commission or sales charge./nNo-load funds are possible because the shares are distributed directly by the investment company, instead of going through a secondary party./nLoad funds charge a commission at the time of the fund's purchase, at the time of its sale, or as a "level-load" for as long as the investor holds a stake./nOver 90% of mutual funds are no-load funds.

Term: Noise Trader: Meaning, Technical Traders, Agenda
Definition: Noise traders trade on signals they believe to generate better than random returns, however this belief is not well founded./nThe idea of a noise trader came from the notion that price action has "noise" which is unrelated to the signal of sound analysis about security value./nSuch notions have led to the contradictory and oversimplified view that fundamental analysis is true signal and technical analysis is mere noise./nA better consideration for identifying noise trading is to understand the concept of the noise trader agenda.

Term: Nominal: What It Means in Finance and Economics
Definition: Nominal is a financial term that has several different contexts./nIt can mean small or far below the real value or cost such as a nominal fee./nNominal also refers to an unadjusted rate in value such as interest rates or GDP./nIn finance, thereal interestrate is the nominal interest rate minus the inflation rate.

Term: Nominal Rate of Return Definition
Definition: The nominal rate of return is the amount of money generated by an investment before factoring in expenses such as taxes, investment fees, and inflation./nThe nominal rate of return helps investors gauge the performance of their portfolio by stripping out outside factors that can affect performance such as taxes and inflation./nTracking the nominal rate of return for a portfolio or its components helps investors to see how they're managing their investments over time.

Term: Nominal Gross Domestic Product: Definition and Formula
Definition: A country's nominal GDP assesses the economic production in its economy but includes the current prices of goods and services in its calculation./nGDP is typically measured as the monetary value of goods and services produced./nSince nominal GDP doesn't remove the pace of rising prices when comparing one period to another, it can inflate the growth figure./nGrowing nominal GDP from year to year may reflect a rise in prices as opposed to growth in the number of goods and services produced./nReal GDP starts with nominal GDP but factors in price change between periods.

Term: Nominal Interest Rate: Formula, What It Is vs. Real Interest Rate
Definition: The federal funds rate, the interest rate set by the Federal Reserve, is the short-term nominal interest rate that is the basis for other interest rates charged by banks and financial institutions./nInvestors consider the real interest rate rather than the nominal to avoid purchasing power erosion through inflation./nAPY (annual percentage yield) is the effective interest rate that tends to be more relevant to borrowers and lenders than the nominal, or stated, interest rate.

Term: Nominal Value: What It Means, Formulas for Calculating It
Definition: Nominal value of a security, often referred to as face or par value, is its redemption price and is normally stated on the front of that security./nFor bonds, the nominal value is the face value, and will vary from its market value based on market interest rates../nA preferred stock's nominal (par) value is important in that it is used to calculate its dividend while the nominal value of common stock is an arbitrary value assigned for balance sheet purposes./nIn economics, nominal value refers to the current monetary value and does not adjust for the effects of inflation.

Term: Nominal Yield: Definition and How it Works
Definition: A bond's nominal yield, depicted as a percentage, is calculated by dividing total interest paid annually by the face, or par, value of the bond./nTwo components combine to determine the nominal yield on a debt instrument: the prevailing rate of inflation and the credit risk of the issuer./nThe nominal yield does not always represent the current yield because it is a percentage based on the bond's par value and not the actual price that was paid for that bond.

Term: Nominated Advisor (NOMAD): What it is, Qualifications
Definition: A nominated advisor is a financial services firm that shepherds a company onto the LSE's Alternative Investment Market (AIM)./nNOMADs are corporate finance advisors, who are usually boutique investment banks./nCompanies that want to list on the AIM must retain NOMADs as per LSE requirements./nThe NOMAD continues to monitor its client even after successfully listing on the AIM./nNOMADs must meet certain criteria to qualify.

Term: Nomination Committee: Definition, Function, Importance
Definition: A nomination committee is a group that is part of the corporate governance of an organization or firm./nThe nominating committee's job includes considering a firm's potential board of directors and other key management roles./nNominating committees often consist of the chair of the board, the deputy chair, and the company's CEO.

Term: Understanding Nominee and Nominee Accounts
Definition: In finance, a nominee refers to a person or company who has been entrusted with the safekeeping of investors' securities or property; all of your investments are held in its name, while you retain control./nThe securities are held in trust and the nominee is the legal owner, but you hold on to real ownership as the beneficiary./nThe broker can buy and sell on your behalf, but your funds are protected if the brokerage goes out of business or your broker tries to swindle you./nThe nominee company should be a neutral third party that is separate from the brokerage itself.

Term: Non-Accredited Investor: Definition, SEC Rules, vs. Accredited
Definition: A non-accredited investor is any investor who does not meet the income or net worth requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)./nNon-accredited investors are anyone who makes less than $200,000 annually ($300,000 including a spouse) with a total net worth of less than $1 million when their primary residence is excluded./nThe SEC regulates what a non-accredited investor can invest in and what those investments need to provide in terms of documentation and transparency.

Term: Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment (NAIRU)
Definition: The non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment (NAIRU) is the lowest level of unemployment that can occur in the economy before inflation starts to inch higher./nWhen unemployment is at the NAIRU level, inflation is steady; when unemployment rises, inflation decreases; when unemployment drops, inflation increases./nWith no set formula to determine NAIRU, the Federal Reserve has historically used statistical models to put the NAIRU level somewhere between 5% and 6% unemployment./nAssessing the NAIRU level amid its inquiry into inflation and unemployment helps the Federal Reserve in its goal to both achieve maximum employment and price stability./nOn the downside: NAIRU does not account for the variety of factors that impact unemployment, besides inflation. Also, the historical connection between inflation and unemployment can break down, rendering NAIRU less effective.

Term: Non-Amortizing Loan: Meaning, Types, Uses
Definition: A non-amortizing loan is a type of loan for which payments on the principal are paid in a lump sum./nThe value of the loan principal does not decrease over the life of the loan./nInterest-only and balloon-payment loans are popular types of non-amortizing loans.

Term: Non-Assessable Stock: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: Non-assessable refers to a class of shares that do not allow the issuer to demand additional payment for the shares from stockholders./nThe majority of shares are currently non-assessable./nIn the 19thcentury, companies issued assessable stock at a discount with the understanding that the issuer could levy an assessment for more funds on shareholders in the future.

Term: Nonbank Financial Institutions: What They Are and How They Work
Definition: Nonbank financial companies (NBFCs), also known as nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) are entities that provide certain bank-like financial services but do not hold a banking license./nNBFCs are not subject to the banking regulations and oversight by federal and state authorities adhered to by traditional banks./nInvestment banks, mortgage lenders, money market funds, insurance companies, hedge funds, private equity funds, and P2P lenders are all examples of NBFCs./nSince the Great Recession, NBFCs have proliferated in number and type, playing a key role in meeting the credit demand unmet by traditional banks.

Term: Non-Cash Item Definition in Banking and Accounting
Definition: In banking, a non-cash item is a negotiable instrument—such as a check or bank draft—that is deposited but cannot be credited until it clears the issuer's account./nIn accounting, a non-cash item refers to an expense listed on an income statement, such as capital depreciation, investment gains, or losses, that does not involve a cash payment.

Term: Non-Cash Charge: Definition and Examples in Accounting
Definition: A non-cash charge is a write-down or accounting expense that does not involve a cash payment./nDepreciation, amortization, depletion, stock-based compensation, and asset impairments are common non-cash charges that reduce earnings but not cash flows./n﻿Non-cash charges are necessary for firms that use accrual basis accounting.

Term: What Is a Non-Compete Agreement? Its Purpose and Requirements
Non-Competitive Tender: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: A non-competitive tender is an offer to purchase Treasury securities made by smaller investors./nNon-competitive tenders don’t specify the price or terms of the security. Instead, the terms are set by a competitive bidding process among large institutional buyers./nInvestors can use non-competitive tenders to purchase between $10,000 and $500,000 worth of Treasury securities at a time.

Term: Non-Controlling Interest: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: A non-controlling interest, also known as a minority interest, is an ownership position in which the shareholder owns less than 50% of outstanding shares./nMinority interest shareholders have no individual control over corporate decisions or votes./nA direct non-controlling interest receives a proportionate allocation of all recorded equity of a subsidiary, both pre- and post-acquisition amounts./nAn indirect non-controlling interest receives a proportionate allocation of a subsidiary's post-acquisition amounts only./nThe opposite of a non-controlling interest is a controlling interest where a shareholder has voting rights to determine corporate decisions.

Term: Noncovered Security: Definition, Reporting Rules, vs. Covered
Definition: A noncovered security is an SEC designation under which the cost basis of securities that are small and of limited scope may not be reported to the IRS/nAn investment security bought in 2011 but transferred in the same year to a DRIP that uses the average cost method of calculating the cost basis is a noncovered security./nStocks are considered noncovered if sold by foreign intermediaries and foreigners (i.e., individuals absent from the country for at least 183 days of the calendar year)./nInvestment sales are also divided into covered and noncovered securities using Form 8949.

Term: Non-Deliverable Swap (NDS): Overview and Examples
Definition: A non-deliverable swap (NDS) is a type of currency swap that is paid and settled in U.S. dollar equivalents rather than the two currencies involved in the swap itself./nAs a result, the swap is considered non-convertible (restricted) since there is no physical delivery of the underlying currencies./nNDS are typically used when the underlying currencies are difficult to obtain, are illiquid, or are volatile - for instance, for developing country currencies or restricted currencies like Cuba or North Korea.

Term: Non-Deliverable Forward (NDF) Meaning, Structure, and Currencies
Definition: A non-deliverable forward (NDF) is a two-party currency derivatives contract to exchange cash flows between the NDF and prevailing spot rates./nThe largest NDF markets are in the Chinese yuan, Indian rupee, South Korean won, New Taiwan dollar, and Brazilian real./nThe largest segment of NDF trading is done via the U.S. dollar and takes place in London, with active markets also in Singapore and New York.

Term: Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) Explained, With Pros and Cons
Definition: An NDA acknowledges a confidential relationship between two or more parties and protects the information they share from disclosure to outsiders./nThe NDA is common before discussions between businesses about potential joint ventures./nEmployees are often required to sign NDAs to protect an employer's confidential business information./nAn NDA may also be referred to as a confidentiality agreement./nThere are two primary types of non-disclosure agreements: mutual and non-mutual non-disclosure agreements.

Term: Understanding Non-Exempt Employee Status, Pros & Cons, and Job Types
Definition: Non-exempt employee status is a federal designation that stipulates different rights an employee has./nNon-exempt employees are generally hourly-rate employees who must be paid an overtime rate of 1.5 times their hourly rate./nExempt employees make at least $684 a week or $35,568 annually and are usually paid a salary./nNon-exempt employees typically make less than this amount but not always as the thresholds can differ by state./nNon-exempt employees’ rights are outlined in the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), which was amended starting Jan. 1, 2020.

Term: Nonfarm Payroll: What It Means, and Why It's Important
Definition: Nonfarm payrolls include 80% of the number of workers in the U.S. and exclude farm workers and workers in several other job classifications./nActive duty military members are excluded from the nonfarm payroll data./nData on nonfarm payrolls is collected by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) and included in the monthly Employment Situation report./nThe Employment Situation report includes two surveys, the Household Survey, and the Establishment Survey.

Term: Non-Executive Director Role and Responsibilities Defined
Definition: A non-executive director is a member of a company's board of directors who is not part of the executive team./nThis director typically does not engage in the day-to-day management of the organization but is involved in policymaking and planning exercises./nTheir responsibilities include monitoring executive directors and acting in the interest of the company stakeholders./nMost non-executive directors are compensated for their time through fees, equity, and cash payments./nThey differ from executive directors who are hired to oversee the operational activities of non-profits.

Term: What Is a Non-Interest-Bearing Current Liability (NIBCL)?
Definition: A non-interest bearing current liability is an item in a corporate balance sheet that reflects short-term expenses and debts that are not accruing interest./nCorporate balance sheets distinguish between obligations to pay debts with interest and obligations to pay ordinary expenses such as account receivables./nIn either case, these are obligations due in one year or less.

Term: Non-GAAP Earnings: Definition and How They Work in Analysis
Definition: Non-GAAP earnings are an alternative accounting method used to measure the earnings of a company./nNon-GAAP earnings are pro forma figures, which exclude "one-time" transactions, such as an organizational restructuring./nNon-GAAP earnings can sometimes provide a more accurate measure of a company’s financial performance from direct business operations./nInvestors should be wary of possible misleading reporting by companies who exclude items that have a negative effect on GAAP earnings.

Term: Non-Marginable Securities: Definition, Examples, Vs. Marginable
Definition: Non-marginable securities are not allowed to be purchased on margin at a particular brokerage, or financial institution, and must be fully funded by the investor's cash./nNon-marginable securities are put in place to mitigate risks and control costs on stocks that are volatile./nNon-marginable securities include recent IPOs, penny stocks, and over-the-counter bulletin board stocks./nThe downside of marginable securities is that they can lead to margin calls, which in turn cause the liquidation of securities and financial loss./nSecurities that may be posted in a margin account as collateral are known as marginable securities.

Term: Non-Issuer Transaction: What It Is, Types
Definition: A non-issuer transaction involves the purchase or sale of securities that does not involve the issuer of those securities./nAn isolated non-issuer transaction involves an ad-hoc exchange of securities between two private parties, often on an over-the-counter (OTC) basis, exempting it from registration./nNon-issuer transactions involving outstanding securities refer largely to trades executed among counterparties on secondary markets that do not involve the issuer.

Term: Non-Marketable Security: Definition, Examples, Vs. Marketable
Definition: Non-marketable securities are assets that cannot easily be liquidated to cash in a timely or cost-effective manner./nOften debt securities, these assets cannot typically be bought or sold on a public exchanges and must trade OTC./nExamples include savings bonds, shares in limited partnerships or privately-held companies, and some complex derivatives products./nIn contrast, marketable securities include common stock, Treasury bills, and money market instruments, among others.

Term: Non-Member Banks: What It Is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: Non-member banks refer to banks that are not members of the U.S. Federal Reserve System, typically state-chartered banks./nState-chartered banks may ultimately decide to refrain from membership under the Fed because regulation can be less onerous based on state laws and under the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), which oversees non-member banks./nOther examples of non-member banks include the Bank of the West and GMC Bank.

Term: What Is Non-Negotiable? Meaning, Definition, and Examples
Definition: Non-negotiable describes the price of a good or security that cannot be adjusted, or a part of a contract that is considered a requirement by one or both involved parties./nAn item can be deemed non-negotiable if one party involved in a transaction is not willing to make any changes to a condition that has been set in place./nAdditionally, the term can relate to a good or security whose ownership is not easily transferable from one party to another, such as government savings bonds.

Term: Non-Objecting Beneficial Owner (NOBO): What it is, How it Works
Definition: Non-Objecting Beneficial Owners (NOBOs) elect to release their name and address to companies in which they have bought securities./nAn objecting beneficial owner (OBO) chooses not to release their information to companies./nThe information released allows for companies to send information, such as voting proxies, financial reports, and other materials pertaining to the business./nThe SEC has outlined a variety of rules in how companies can interact with objecting and non-objecting beneficial owners./nCertain parties, such as companies, are interested in abolishing the distinction between beneficial owners, where banks, brokers, and OBOs wish to keep the distinction.

Term: Non-Operating Asset: Definition, Balance Sheet Place, and Example
Definition: Non-operating assets are assets that are not considered to be part of a company's core operations./nA company's non-operating assets may be unused land, spare equipment, investment securities, and so on./nIncome from non-operating assets contributes to the non-operating income of a company. These assets and any income from them are usually omitted from the financial analysis of a company's core business./nNon-operating assets can function as a way to diversify risk and revenues.

Term: Non-Operating Expense: Definition and Examples
Definition: A non-operating expense is incurred when a cost doesn't directly relate to a firm's primary or core business./nNon-operating expenses are deducted from operating profits and accounted for at the bottom of a company's income statement./nExamples of non-operating expenses include interest payments, or costs, from currency exchanges.

Term: Non-Owner Occupied: Meaning, Overview, FAQs
