Definition: Non-owner occupied is a real estate classification that means the property owner does not occupy the property as their personal residence./nThe accurate classification of a property as non-owner occupied is important for lenders to determine the interest rate that they will charge borrowers and to ensure they are adequately compensated for the risks they take in lending money./nBecause borrowers of non-owner-occupied properties are more likely to default on their mortgages, lenders will charge them a higher interest rate than a mortgage on an owner-occupied property./nOccupancy fraud occurs when a borrower lies to a lender, claiming that a property will be owner occupied when, in reality, it will not./nA borrower can use a non-owner-occupied renovation loan to purchase an investment property and pay for the costs to repair the property for future tenants.

Term: Non-Operating Income: Definition, Examples, and Purpose
Definition: Non-operating income is the portion of an organization's income that is derived from activities not related to its core business operations./nIt can include dividend income, profits or losses from investments, as well as gains or losses incurred by foreign exchange and asset write-downs./nSeparating non-operating income from operating income gives investors a clearer picture of how efficient a company is at turning revenue into profit.

Term: Nonperforming Asset (NPA): What It Is and Different Types
Definition: Nonperforming assets (NPAs) are recorded on a bank's balance sheet after a prolonged period of non-payment by the borrower./nNPAs place financial burden on the lender; a significant number of NPAs over a period of time may indicate to regulators that the financial fitness of the bank is in jeopardy./nNPAs can be classified as a substandard asset, doubtful asset, or loss asset, depending on the length of time overdue and probability of repayment./nLenders have options to recover their losses, including taking possession of any collateral or selling off the loan at a significant discount to a collection agency.

Term: Non-Purpose Loan: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: A non-purpose loan is an alternative type of loan that uses investment securities as collateral and relies on complex structuring./nEven when put up as collateral, non-purpose loans allow investors to continue to receive the benefits of their portfolio holdings—such as dividends, interest and appreciation—without having to sell their investments./nFinancial institutions must disclose whether a loan is a non-purpose loan to the Federal Reserve under Regulation U.﻿﻿

Term: 409A Plans: Meaning, Overview, Limitations
Definition: A non-qualified deferred compensation (NQDC) has been earned by an employee but not yet received from their employer./n409A plans emerged in response to the cap on employee contributions to government-sponsored retirement savings plans./nAn NQDC plan sponsored by for-profit plan sponsors is governed by Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 409A./nAn NQDC sponsored by a nonprofit or governmental plan sponsor is governed under IRC Section 457(b) or 457(f).

Term: What Is a Non-Qualified Stock Option (NSO), and How Is It Used?
Definition: Non-qualified stock options require payment of income tax of the grant price minus the price of the exercised option./nNSOs might be provided as an alternative form of compensation, especially in early-stage companies./nNSOs allow employees to assume some of the risks of a new business, but they can also earn higher rewards if the company succeeds./nNSOs allow the holder to buy a company's stock at a preset price at some time in the future. If the holder does not exercise them before the expiration date, they lose the option.

Term: Non-Qualifying Investment: Definition, Examples, Taxation
Definition: A non-qualifying investment is an investment that doesn't have any tax benefits./nAnnuities are a common example of non-qualifying investments as are antiques, collectibles, jewelry, precious metals, and art./nNon-qualifying investments are purchased and held in tax-deferred accounts, plans, or trusts and returns from these investments are taxed on an annual basis.

Term: Non-Qualified Plan: Definition, How It Works, and 4 Major Types
Definition: Nonqualified plans are retirement savings plans./nThey are called nonqualified because unlikequalified plansthey do not adhere to Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) guidelines./nNonqualified plans are generally used to provide high-paid executives with an additional retirement savings option.

Term: Non-Recourse Finance: Definition, Uses, Vs. Recourse Loan
Definition: Non-recourse financing entitles the lender to repayment only from the profits of the project that the loan is funding./nNo other assets of the borrower can be seized to recoup the loan upon default./nNon-recourse financing typically requires substantial collateral and a higher interest rate and is typically used in land development projects.

Term: Non-Recourse Debt: Definition, Example, vs. Recourse Debt
Definition: Non-recourse debt is a type of loan that is secured by collateral, commonly property./nLenders charge higher interest rates on non-recourse debt./nNon-recourse debt is characterized by high capital expenditures, long loan periods, and uncertain revenue streams./nA non-recourse debt does not hold the borrower personally liable for the loan.

Term: Nonrefundable Tax Credit: Definition, How It Works, and Benefits
Definition: A tax credit is a tax break that reduces a filer’s tax liability dollar for dollar./nA nonrefundable tax credit can only reduce tax liability to zero./nA refundable tax credit results in a tax refund if the amount owed is below zero./nExamples of nonrefundable credits in the U.S. tax code include the foreign tax credit (FTC) and the saver’s credit.

Term: Non-Renounceable Rights: What They are, How They Work
Definition: A non-renounceable rights issue allows existing shareholders to purchase more shares of a company at a discount. Those shares can't be traded./nA renounceable right, on the other hand, permits the trading of the rights./nCompanies might offer non-renounceable rights issues if an urgent need for cash arises.

Term: Non-Sampling Error
Definition: A non-sampling error is a term used in statistics that refers to an error that occurs during data collection, causing the data to differ from the true values./nA non-sampling error refers to either random or systematic errors, and these errors can be challenging to spot in a survey, sample, or census./nSystematic non-sampling errors are worse than random non-sampling errors because systematic errors may result in the study, survey or census having to be scrapped./nThe higher the number of errors, the less reliable the information./nWhen non-sampling errors occur, the rate of bias in a study or survey goes up.

Term: Non-Security: What it is, How it Works, Valuation
Definition: Non-securities, also called real assets, are investments that are not available for purchase or sale on public exchanges./nThey may, however, be a component of an investment that trades publicly, such as an ETF./nDiamonds and fine art are examples of non-security investments.

Term: Non-Sufficient Funds (NSF): What It Means & How to Avoid Fees
Definition: A checking account is said to have “non-sufficient funds” (NSF), or "insufficient funds” when it lacks the money needed to cover transactions./nThe acronym NSF also references the fee a customer is charged for presenting a check or payment that cannot be covered by the balance in the account./nConsumers can avoid NSF fees by opting for overdraft protection through their banks.

Term: Non-Taxable Distribution Defintion and Examples
Definition: A non-taxable distribution may be a stock dividend, a stock split, or a distribution from a corporate liquidation./nA non-taxable distribution is only taxable when you sell the stock of the corporation that issued the distribution./nThe non-taxable distribution is reported to the IRS as a reduction in the cost basis of the stock.

Term: Non-Traded REIT: Explanation, How They Work, Characteristics
Definition: Non-traded REITs are not listed on public exchanges and can provide retail investors access to inaccessible real estate investments with tax benefits./nDespite not being listed, non-traded REITs must still be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission and are required to make regular, periodic regulatory filings./nSimilar to exchange-traded REITs, non-traded REITs are subject to the same IRS requirements that include returning at least 90% of taxable income to shareholders.

Term: Nonaccrual Experience (NAE) Method
Definition: The Nonaccrual Experience (NAE) Method is an accounting standard that accounts for bad or delinquent debts./nUnder this method, firms don’t have to accrue income that, based on past experience, is not expected to be collected./nInstead, bad debts that are likely to remain uncollected can be written off.

Term: Nonaccrual Loan: Definition, FDIC Criteria, Ways To Fix
Definition: A lending institution categorizes an unsecured debt as a nonaccrual loan if no payment has been made for 90 days or more./nIn accounting terms, the expected interest has not accrued to the lender because no interest has been paid by the customer./nA borrower can work out a repayment plan to restore the loan to its previous status.

Term: Noncancellable Insurance Policy: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A noncancellable disability insurance policy can’t be cancelled, have its premiums raised or benefits cut as long as the customer pays the premiums./nUnder a noncancellable policy, even if your income falls, the company will keep the same level of coverage./nMany noncancellable policies expire at age 65, when most people retire./nDisability insurance could also be guaranteed renewable, meaning prices can go up over time, or conditionally renewable, meaning the insurer can change and even cancel your coverage./nNoncancellable policies are more predictable but can cost more than other options.

Term: Non-Conforming Mortgage: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: A non-conforming mortgage is a home loan that does not adhere to government-sponsored enterprises (GSE) guidelines and, therefore, cannot be resold to agencies such as Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac./nThese loans often carry higher interest rates than conforming mortgages./nMortgages that exceed the conforming loan limit are classified as non-conforming and are called jumbo mortgages./nOther than the loan size, mortgages may become non-conforming based on a borrower’s loan-to-value ratio (down payment size), debt-to-income ratio, credit score and history, and documentation requirements.

Term: Noncumulative: Definition, How It Works, Types, and Examples
Definition: Noncumulative stock does not pay unpaid or omitted dividends./nCumulative stock entitles investors to missed dividends./nCumulative preferred stock is more attractive to investors than noncumulative.

Term: Nonce: What It Means and How It's Used in Blockchain
Definition: A nonce is a numerical value used in a trial-and-error process to have a block added to the blockchain./nThe nonce is increased by a value of one for every attempt made./nFinding the right combination of nonce and other values in the block consumes significant computational power./nThe nonce is one of a few values that can be altered to generate hashes for the competitive mining process.

Term: Noncallable: What it Means, How it Works
Noncurrent Assets: Types, Examples, and Proper Accounting
Definition: Noncurrent assets are a company's long-term investments that are not easily converted to cash or are not expected to become cash within an accounting year./nAlso known as long-term assets, their costs are allocated over the number of years the asset is used and appear on a company’s balance sheet./nNoncurrent assets fall under three major categories: tangible assets, intangible assets, and natural resources./nExamples of noncurrent assets include investments, intellectual property, real estate, and equipment.

Term: Noncurrent Liabilities: Definition, Examples, and Ratios
Definition: Noncurrent liabilities, also known as long-term liabilities, are obligations listed on the balance sheet not due for more than a year./nVarious ratios using noncurrent liabilities are used to assess a company’s leverage, such as debt-to-assets and debt-to-capital./nExamples of noncurrent liabilities include long-term loans and lease obligations, bonds payable and deferred revenue.

Term: Nonelective Contribution: Definition and Benefits to Employees
Definition: Nonelective contributions are employer contributions to an employee's retirement plan, regardless of the employee's contribution./nNonelective contributions benefit employees since they can save more for retirement than they could do by themselves./nNonelective contributions are issued at the discretion of the employer and can change at any time./nContributions of this type can gain an employer IRS "safe harbor" protections.

Term: Nonfinancial Asset: Definition, How It's Valued, and Examples
Definition: A nonfinancial asset is determined by the value of its physical traits and includes items such as real estate and factory equipment./nIntellectual property, such as patents, are also considered nonfinancial assets./nNonfinancial assets play an important role in determining a company's market value and ability to borrow./nFinancial assets, such as stocks, are the opposite of nonfinancial assets. They are easier to value and more liquid.

Term: Nonfeasance: Meaning, In Finance, Related Terms
Definition: Nonfeasance is the willful absence of action to help prevent harm or damage from occurring./nNonfeasance may or may not be illegal in and of itself; however, employers have the legal right to terminate an employee or contractor for nonfeasance./nFinancial nonfeasance involves a failure to act by a fiduciary or financial representative on behalf of a client, for instance by failing to input a trade a broker has been given by a customer.

Term: What Is a Nonforfeiture Clause? 4 Payout Options Explained
Definition: A nonforfeiture clause is an insurance policy clause stipulating that an insured party can receive full or partial benefits or a partial refund of premiums after a lapse due to nonpayment./nPermanent life insurance, long-term disability, and long-term care insurance policies may have nonforfeiture clauses./nFor traditional whole life policies, the policyholder decides how they would like to access the policy’s cash value.

Term: Noninterest Expense: Meaning, Overview, FAQ
Definition: Noninterest expenses are the fixed operating costs of a bank (e.g., salaries and rent)./nNoninterest expenses are offset by service fees such as fee income from loan originations, late charges on loans, annual fees, and credit facility fees./nNoninterest expenses are typically higher for investment banks than commercial banks (even though they might appear lower) because trading, asset management, and capital markets advisory services are costly.

Term: What Is Nonlinear Regression? Comparison to Linear Regression
Definition: Both linear and nonlinear regression predict Y responses from an X variable (or variables)./nNonlinear regression is a curved function of an X variable (or variables) that is used to predict a Y variable/nNonlinear regression can show a prediction of population growth over time.

Term: What Is Nonlinear? Definition, vs. Linear, and Analysis
Definition: Nonlinearity is a mathematical term describing a relationship between an independent variable and a dependent variable that is not predictable from a straight line./nCertain investment classes, such as options, show a high degree of nonlinearity, which can make these investments seem more chaotic./nInvestors of asset classes that exhibit a high level of nonlinearity will often use sophisticated modeling techniques to estimate their potential loss or gain over a specific period of time.

Term: Understanding Nonmonetary Assets vs. Monetary Assets
Definition: A nonmonetary asset refers to an asset that a company holds that does not have a precise dollar value and is not easily convertible to cash or cash equivalents./nCompanies categorize nonmonetary assets as either tangible assets or intangible assets./nExamples of nonmonetary assets that are considered tangible are a company's property, plant, equipment, and inventory./nExamples of nonmonetary assets that are considered intangible are a company's intellectual property, such as its patents, copyrights, and trademarks./nIn contrast, monetary assets can easily be converted to cash or cash equivalents for a fixed or precisely determined amount of money.

Term: What Is Nonparametric Method? Analysis Vs. Parametric Method
Definition: The nonparametric method is a branch of statistics in which the data are not assumed to come from prescribed models that are determined by a small number of parameters./nThe nonparametric analysis is often best suited when considering the order of something, where even if the numerical data changes, the results will likely stay the same./nThis is in contrast to parametric methods, which make assumptions about the shape or characteristics of the data. Examples of such methods include the normal distribution model and the linear regression model.

Term: Nonparametric Statistics: Overview, Types, and Examples
Definition: Nonparametric statistics are easy to use but do not offer the pinpoint accuracy of other statistical models./nThis type of analysis is often best suited when considering the order of something, where even if the numerical data changes, the results will likely stay the same.

Term: What Is Nonpassive Income and Losses? What Is Included
Definition: Nonpassive income and losses are any income or losses that cannot be classified as passive./nIncluded in nonpassive income is any active income, such as wages, business income, or investment income./nLosses or income may qualify as nonpassive if the taxpayer annually and actively participates for more than 500 hours in the business venture (100 hours if no other partner or co-worker puts in more work hours than the taxpayer during the year)./nOther types of income can qualify as nonpassive, such as investment income in the forms of dividends, selling investments, and interest. Compensation paid for the destruction or theft of property is considered nonpassive./nRetirement income, such as deferred compensation and social security, may also be included as nonpassive.

Term: Nonperforming Loan (NPL) Definitions, Types, Causes, Consequences
Definition: A nonperforming loan (NPL) is a loan in which the borrower is in default and hasn't made any scheduled payments of principal or interest for a certain period of time./nIn banking, commercial loans are considered nonperforming if the borrower is 90 days past due./nThe International Monetary Fund considers loans that are less than 90 days past due as nonperforming if there's high uncertainty surrounding future payments./nHowever, there is no standard or definition of NPLs./nSome banks opt to sell NPLs to other banks or investors to free up capital and/or focus on performing loans that bring in income.

Term: Nonprofit Organization (NPO): Definition and Example
Definition: The mission of a nonprofit is to contribute a benefit to society rather than to make a profit./nNonprofits may receive donations from individuals, corporations, and government entities./nTo qualify as a tax-exempt nonprofit, the entity must serve the public good, meet filing requirements, be established as a 501(c)(3) or similar type of organization, and avoid engaging in certain types of activities./nNonprofits file Form 990 with the IRS to report their revenues, expenses, and activities.

Term: Nonrenewable Resource: Definition, Features, and Examples
Definition: A nonrenewable resource is a substance that is used up more quickly than it can replace itself./nThe supply of a nonrenewable resource is finite, which means it cannot easily be replenished/nNonrenewable resources are extracted directly from the Earth./nMost fossil fuels, minerals, and metal ores are nonrenewable resources./nThe opposite of nonrenewable resources is renewable ones, whose supplies are abundant and are considered sustainable.

Term: Nonresident Alien: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Nonresident aliens are noncitizens of the U.S. who pass the substantial presence tests or are exempt from a Green Card./nForeign nationals are classified as either resident or nonresident aliens for tax purposes./nOnce someone has been in the U.S. for at least 31 days and resided in the country for over 183 days in a three-year period, they may qualify as a resident alien./nNonresident aliens only have to pay taxes if the income is effectively connected to a trade or business in the U.S.

Term: Nontariff Barrier: Definition, How It Works, Types, and Examples
Definition: A nontariff barrier is a trade restriction–such as a quota, embargo or sanction–that countries use to further their political and economic goals./nCountries usually opt for nontariff barriers (rather than traditional tariffs) in international trade./nNontariff barriers include quotas, embargoes, sanctions, and levies.

Term: Normal-Course Issuer Bid (NCIB): Definition and How It Works
Definition: An NCIB is a stock buyback program used by companies listed in Canada./nThe NCIB is used to raise cash, force the share price higher, ward off a takeover, or some combination of all of these./nThe NCIB must be approved in advance by the exchanges.

Term: Normal Distribution: What It Is, Uses, and Formula
Definition: The normal distribution is the proper term for a probability bell curve./nIn a normal distribution, the mean is zero and the standard deviation is 1. It has zero skew and a kurtosis of 3./nNormal distributions are symmetrical, but not all symmetrical distributions are normal.

Term: Nordic Model: Comparing The Economic System to the U.S.
Definition: The Nordic model combines elements of capitalism and socialism./nImportant features of the Nordic model include the public provision of social services, investment in services associated with human capital, and a strong social safety net./nSociety-wide risk sharing is a cardinal component of the Nordic model.

Term: Normal Goods: Definition, Demand, and Examples
Definition: A normal good is a good that experiences an increase in demand due to an increase in a consumer's income./nNormal goods have a positive correlation between income and demand./nExamples of normal goods include food, clothing, and household appliances.

Term: Normal Profit: Definition, Formula to Calculate, Example
Definition: Normal profit is often viewed in conjunction with economic profit./nNormal profit is a condition that exists when a company or industry's economic profit is equal to zero./nNormal and economic profits differ from accounting profit, which does not take into consideration implicit costs./nA company may report high accounting profit but still be in a state of normal profit if the opportunity costs of maintaining business operations are high./nIn macroeconomics, an industry is expected to experience normal profit during times of perfect competition.

Term: Normalized Earnings: Definition, Purpose, Benefits, and Examples
Definition: Normalized earnings remove one-off events and smooth seasonal effects on revenue./nNormalized earnings better represent the true health of a company's core business./nNormalized earnings per share can be used to compare two companies where one has suffered or benefited from a number of one-off events.

Term: Normal Yield Curve: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The normal yield curve is a yield curve in which short-term debt instruments have a lower yield than long-term debt instruments of the same credit quality./nAn upward sloping yield curve suggests an increase in interest rates in the future./nA downward sloping yield curve predicts a decrease in future interest rates.

Term: What Is the Full Retirement Age (FRA) for Social Security?
Definition: Full retirement age (FRA) is the age you must reach to receive full retirement benefits from Social Security./nYour FRA varies depending on the year you were born./nThe FRA in the United States is 66 years and two months for those born in 1955, increasing gradually to 67 for those born in 1960 or later./nFRA can also refer to the age at which a worker is eligible to receive pension benefits./nThe FRA for other countries’ retirement systems also varies and is typically from 65 to 67 years of age.

Term: Normative Economics: Definition, Characteristics, and Examples
Definition: Normative economics aims to determine what should happen or what ought to be./nWhile positive economics describe economic programs, situations, and conditions as they exist, normative economics aims to prescribe solutions./nNormative economics expresses ideological judgments about what may result in economic activity if public policy changes are made./nBehavioral economics tends to be a normative project./nNormative economics cannot be verified or tested.

Term: What Was the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)?
Definition: The North American Free Trade Agreement was implemented in 1994 to encourage trade between the U.S., Mexico, and Canada./nNAFTA reduced or eliminated tariffs on imports and exports between the three participating countries, creating a huge free-trade zone./nTwo side agreements to NAFTA aimed to establish high common standards in workplace safety, labor rights, and environmental protection, to prevent businesses from relocating to other countries to exploit lower wages or looser regulations./nIt was later replaced by the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which was signed on November 30, 2018 and went into full force on July 1, 2020./nNAFTA was a controversial agreement, harming the U.S. economy by some measures and improving it in others.

Term: North American Securities Administrators Association (NASAA)
Definition: Organized in 1919, the North American Securities Administrators Association (NASAA) is the oldest international regulatory organization devoted to investor protection./nNASAA is a voluntary association whose membership consists of 67 state, provincial, and territorial securities administrators in the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Canada, and Mexico./nIt works to protect customers of investment advice and securities as part of a complementary regulatory system that works at the federal, state/provincial, and industry levels./nNASAA seeks to help investors identify and avoid fraud by educating the public, investigating violations of state and provincial law, and filing enforcement actions.

Term: Norwegian Krone (NOK): History, Example, FAQs
Definition: The Norwegian krone (NOK), which began circulation in 1875, is the official currency of Norway./nThe krone's regulation and circulation are controlled by the country's central bank, the Norges Bank./nThe Norwegian krone currency code is "NOK" and its symbol is "kr."/nCoins come in denominations of 1, 5, 10, and 20 krone, and banknotes are divided into 50, 100, 200, 500, and 1,000 denominations./nThe Norwegian Krone has a value of $0.10 cents as of August 23, 2022.

Term: North Sea Brent Crude: Meaning, Investing, History
Definition: North Sea Brent Crude is a blended light sweet crude oil recovered from the North Sea in the early 1960s./nPricing for North Sea Brent crude, classified as a sweet light crude, serves as the most widely used benchmark for other worldwide oil markets./nLight sweet crude oils are simpler to process into products such as gasoline, which means they tend to fetch higher prices on commodity markets./nSince the oil crisis of the late 1970s, the vast majority of crude oil commodity sales have taken place on the futures market./nInvestors typically trade Brent-related commodity contracts either as a hedge or on a speculative basis. Those taking hedge positions include companies that produce and market crude oil, as well as refineries or other entities that process the oil.

Term: Nostro Account
Definition: Nostro accounts simplify the process of exchanging and trading in foreign currencies./nMajor examples of convertible currencies are the U.S. dollar, the Canadian dollar, the British pound, the euro, and the Japanese yen./nThe bank that is holding a nostro or vostro account may be called the "facilitator" bank./nNostro accounts aren't the same as standard demand deposit accounts because these types of accounts are denominated in foreign currencies.

Term: Not for Profit: Definitions and What It Means for Taxes
Definition: In a not-for-profit organization, all funds either earned or donated must be used for pursuing the group’s objectives and paying its running costs./nNonprofit funds never go to the group’s members, directors, or officers./nMany nonprofits have a lot in common with for-profit organizations and use similar business tactics and management techniques to run their enterprises./nEvery not-for-profit organization has to maintain compliance with the state agency that regulates charitable organizations where it is based.

Term: Definition of a Notary, Duties, Where to Notarize, and Examples
Definition: A notary is an impartial witness to the signing or authentication of a legal document./nExamples in which notaries are required include real estate deeds, affidavits, wills, trusts, and powers of attorney./nNotaries must be at least 18 years old and reside in the state where they are licensed.Thereafter the steps to becoming a notary differ from state to state./nThe National Notary Association (NNA) is a good resource for education and information about notaries.

Term: Not-Held Order: Types, Benefits and Limitations
Definition: An investor may place a not-held order in hopes of obtaining a better price than could be obtained with an immediate transaction./nThe not-held gives the broker time to aim for the best possible fill for the client./nNot-held orders may be placed as market orders or limit orders./nNot-held orders absolve the broker from any losses that the shareholder may suffer if the broker misses an opportunity while waiting for a better price.

Term: What Notching Debt Means to Credit Rating Agencies
Definition: Notching is when a credit rating agency bumps up or down the credit rating on an issuer's specific debts or obligations./nThis is different than a credit agency upgrading or downgrading the company or issuer as a whole./nBecause certain types of debt—for instance, subordinated debts—are inherently riskier than senior debts, the rating on junior debts can be notched lower./nSimilarly, those debts from the issuer that are senior and secured by collateral may be notched higher./nDebt notches are evaluated by comparing the individual credit ratings of two or more bonds.

Term: Notes as Investment Vehicles, Various Types
Definition: A note is a legal document representing a loan made from an issuer to a creditor or an investor./nNotes entail the payback of the principal amount loaned, as well as any predetermined interest payments./nThe U.S. government issues Treasury notes (T-notes) to raise money to pay for infrastructure.

Term: Notice of Assessment (NOA): Definition, Details, Objection Filing
Definition: For Canadian taxpayers, a notice of assessment (NOA) is a government-issued estimate of taxes owed for a given year./nCorrections made to these estimates will also appear on an NOA, and filers have 90 days to formally object or make amendments to any of the information on the document./nAn NOA may also signal that a business or individual has been identified for a tax audit.

Term: Notice of Employment Termination: Meaning and Considerations
Notice Of Deficiency: What it Means, Examples
Definition: A notice of deficiency is a legal determination by the IRS of a taxpayer’s tax deficiency; the official name for the form is IRS Notice CP2319A: Notice of Deficiency and Increase in Tax./nA notice of deficiency is issued when the IRS proposes a change to a tax return because they found that the information reported on a return does not match their records./nA notice of deficiency is usually triggered by tax information received from a third party filer–such as an employer or a financial institution–that does not match the information reported by the taxpayer.

Term: Notice to Creditors: Definition, Purpose, and How To Publish
Definition: A notice to creditors is a public statement noting the death of an individual to alert potential creditors to the situation./nStill published in local newspapers, the notice is filed by the estate's executor and meant to facilitate the probate proceedings./nKnown creditors must be given a specific notice, while the published notice serves to capture all other unknown creditors./nCreditors will have a limited amount of time to respond to the notice, which may also be filed by individuals declaring bankruptcy.

Term: Notice of Default: Meaning, Overview, Special Considerations
Definition: A notice of default is a public notice filed with a court that states that a mortgagor is in default./nIt is typically the final action lenders take before activating the lien and seizing the collateral for foreclosure./nThe notice must include details such as the borrower and lender's name and address, the property address, and the nature of the default.

Term: Notional Principal Amount: Definition, Calculations, and Example
Definition: A notional principal amount is the predetermined dollar value used in interest rate swaps./nInterest payments that each party pays the other in an interest rate swap are based on the notional principal amount./nNotional principal amounts are theoretical./nIn bonds, the notional principal amount is equal to the face value of a bond.

Term: Understanding Notional Value and How It Works
Definition: Notional value is a term often used by derivatives traders to refer to the total value of the underlyingassetin a contract./nNotional value is the same as face value, used to determine payments on a financial asset./nThe notional value of derivatives contracts is much higher than the market value because leverage is used./nNotional value is integral in assessing portfolio risk and can be very useful when determining hedge ratios to offset that risk./nNotional value can be applied to interest rate swaps, total return swaps, equity options, and foreign currency derivatives.

Term: Null Hypothesis: What Is It, and How Is It Used in Investing?
Definition: A null hypothesis is a type of conjecture in statistics that proposes that there is no difference between certain characteristics of a population or data-generating process./nThe alternative hypothesis proposes that there is a difference./nHypothesis testing provides a method to reject a null hypothesis within a certain confidence level./nIf you can reject the null hypothesis, it provides support for the alternative hypothesis./nNull hypothesis testing is the basis of the principle of falsification in science.

Term: Novation: Definition in Contract Law, Types, Uses, and Example
Definition: To novate is to replace an old obligation with a new one./nIn contract law, a novation replaces one of the parties in a two-party agreement with a third party, with the agreement of all three parties./nIn a novate, the original contract is void. The party that drops out has given up its benefits and obligations./nIn the financial markets, using a clearinghouse to vet a transaction between two parties is known as a novation./nNovation is different than an assignment, where the original party to the agreement retains ultimate responsibility. Therefore, the original contract remains in place.

Term: Numeraire: What it is, History, How it Works
Definition: Numeraire is an economic term of French origin, which acts as a benchmark in comparing the value of similar products or financial instruments./nA numeraire is usually applied to a single good, which becomes the base value for the entire index or market./nThe U.S. dollar remains the numeraire for most commodity prices.

Term: What Is Numismatics? Meaning, Qualifications, and Example
Definition: Numismatics is the study of coins and other currency units and is usually associated with the appraisal and collection of rare coins./nNumismatists study the physical properties, production technology, and historical context of specimens of currency./nRare and collectible coins may trade at well above their nominal face value or commodity melt value and are often withdrawn from circulation and viewed as investments rather than actual money./nNumerous clubs, societies, and other organizations have been established to support the study of numismatics./nThe qualification for becoming a numismatist in the U.S. include successfully completing specialized courses and passing a 200-question exam.

Term: NYSE Arca: Definition, History, Funds, Membership, and Options
Definition: NYSE Arca is an electronic stock and exchange-traded product (ETP) order-matching platform./nNYSE Arca was formed from the 2006 merger of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) and Archipelago (Arca)./nNYSE Arca boasts the largest volume of ETF trading among all other exchanges in the world./nNYSE Arca Options also allows for order matching and execution of listed options orders./nThe Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) acquired NYSE and NYSE Arca by 2013.

Term: N.V.: Alternative Investing Meaning, Examples and FAQs
Definition: N.V. is an acronym for Naamloze Vennootschap, a public limited liability company in the Netherlands and other Dutch-influenced nations./nAn N.V. issues shares to shareholders who have the power to make decisions about the company./nCompanies that wish to adopt this corporate structure must meet certain requirements, including a minimum startup capital threshold of €45,000/nEstablishing an N.V. allows shareholders to remain anonymous and alleviates directors of personal liability./nRules and regulations about setting up N.V. corporatios vary based on the country in which they operate.

Term: Obamanomics: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: Obamanomics refers to the economic policies of former U.S. President Barack Obama./nThe term is often associated with the stimulus programs used to combat the Great Recession./nExamples of these policies include the 2009 American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, which was an $831 billion economic stimulus package, and the 2009 bailout of the U.S. automobile industry./nCritics of Obamanomics view it as representing an undue expansion of the government’s economic role, including increased government spending, taxation, and regulation./nIt is often contrasted with Reaganomics, another popular term referring to the economic policies of former President Ronald Reagan.

Term: NYSE Composite Index: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The NYSE Composite Index is a trackable index that reflects the performance of all the stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange./nThe NYSE Composite Index has a perception of quality due to strict listing requirements and global diversity due to the breadth of its holdings./nThe NYSE lists more than 2,400 companies, of which international companies constitute about one-third of total market capitalization.

Term: Obelisk Consensus Algorithm Definition
Definition: Obelisk is the proprietary blockchain consensus algorithm of the Skycoin ecosystem./nObelisk attempts to address the issues with consensus mechanisms by distributing influence over a network, according to a concept called a “web of trust.”/nThe Obelisk consensus uses separate nodes for consensus and block creation.

Term: Objective Probability: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: Objective probability is the probability an event will occur based on an analysis in which each measure is based on a recorded observation or a long history of collected data./nIn contrast, subjective probability allows the observer to gain insight by referencing things they've learned and their own experience./nIn finance, people ought to use objective probabilities to make decisions instead of relying on subjective stories, personal experience, or anecdotal evidence.

Term: Obligatory Reinsurance: Meaning, Types, Pros and Cons
Obligation: Legal Definition and Examples in Finance
Definition: Obligations are responsibilities, often in the form of a contract, such as a mortgage or auto loan./nThe Financial Obligation Ratio published by the Fed is a good benchmark for household budgeting./nFailure to meet obligations is often met with punishment, such as imprisonment or fines./nDebt, liquidity, and solvency ratios are all used to measure a firm's ability to meet its debt obligations.

Term: Obligor: Definition, Responsibilities, Scenarios, and Types
Definition: An obligor is a person or entity who is legally or contractually obliged to provide a benefit or payment to another./nAn obligee is a persona or entity receiving the payments, or who is owed the obligation./nAn affirmative covenant is something that the obligor is required to do, such as hit specific performance benchmarks./nIn family law, there are certain cases when a court order requires one of the parents, the obligor, to pay child support to the other parent.

Term: Obsolescence Risk: What it is, How it Works
What Is Obsolete Inventory, and How Do You Account for It?
Definition: Obsolete inventory is inventory at the end of its product life cycle that needs to be either written-down or written-off the company's books./nObsolete inventory is written-down by debiting expenses and crediting a contra asset account, such as allowance for obsolete inventory./nThe contra asset account is netted against the full inventory asset account to arrive at the current market value or book value./nWhen obsolete inventory is disposed of, both the related amount in the inventory asset account and the contra asset account are removed in the disposal journal entry.

Term: What Is an Occupancy Rate? Definition and Use in Analysis
Definition: The occupancy rate measures the ratio of occupied to total usable rental space./nThis rate helps analyst understand changes in the residential and commercial real estate markets and is often used in evaluating hotel and resort properties./nOccupancy rates can also be applied to residential buildings, hospital beds, or even entire cities to gauge underlying economic activity and trends.

Term: Occurrence Policy: What it is, How it Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: An occurrence policy covers claims made for injuries sustained during the life of an insurance policy, even if they're filed after the policy is canceled./nThey cater specifically to events that may cause injury of damage years after they occur, such as exposure to hazardous chemicals./nAn occurrence policy is an alternative to claims-made ones, which provide benefits only if a claim is filed while the policy is active./nInsurers typically place a cap on the total coverage offered through occurrence policies.

Term: Ocean Bill of Lading: What it is, How it Works
Occupational Labor Mobility: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Occupational mobility refers to the ease with which a worker can leave one job for another in a different field./nWhen labor mobility is high, economists predict a high degree of productivity and growth./nLow-skilled labor and workers with skills that are more general or can be more readily transferred will tend to experience greater occupational labor mobility./nOccupational mobility can be restricted through regulations. Licensing, training, or education requirements prevent the free flow of labor from one industry to another.

Term: Occupational Safety and Health Act: Definition and Requirements
Definition: The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is a U.S. law establishing workplace standards to ensure that employees are protected from hazards that compromise their safety and health./nThe Occupational Safety and Health Act applies to most private sector employers and their workers, in addition to some in the public sector./nThe Occupational Safety and Health Act established the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the National Institute for Occupational Safety & Health (NIOSH)./nOSHA serves as the enforcement arm of the act, applying fines and penalties to employers that violate its rules, standards, and guidelines.

Term: October Effect: Definition, Examples, and Statistical Evidence
Definition: The October effect is the perception that stock markets decline during the month of October, and it is classified as a market anomaly./nIt is one of several calendar anomalies, along with the supposed September effect and Santa Claus rally./nThe October effect is considered to be more of a psychological expectation than an actual phenomenon, as most statistics counter the theory./nThe October effect, as well as other calendar anomalies, largely have seemed to disappear over the past decades./nIn fact, October has tended to be a net positive month, on average, over the past century or more.

Term: What Is an Odd Lot? Definition in Trading and How They Arise
Definition: An odd lot refers to an order amount for a security that is less than the normal unit of trading for an asset, which is typically 100 shares for stocks./nOdd lots contrast with round lots, which are order amounts for a security that can be divided evenly by 100./nOdd lots tend to emerge in a portfolio as a result of a company announcing a reverse stock split, or due to dividend reinvestment plans./nAn odd lot order generally costs more due to higher commission levels and takes longer to complete than other orders./nLarge companies view odd lots as pretty insignificant and may choose to eliminate such holdings by buying out the shareholder at a premium or offering the shareholder more stock to make a round lot.

Term: Odd Lot Theory: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Odd-lot trades refer to orders involving shares less than a round lot of 100 shares./nThese odd-lot trades are thought to be made predominantly by individual retail traders who are likely less informed participants in the market./nOdd lot theory advises trading against these uninformed traders' activity./nTesting of this hypothesis seems to indicate that this observation is not persistently valid.

Term: OEX S&P 100 Index: Meaning, Overview, How it Works
Definition: OEX, which trades on the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE), is the ticker symbol used to identify Standard & Poor's 100 index options./nOEX options were the original standard for index options trading on the domestic stock market, though, over time, options on the S&P 500 (SPX) passed them in popularity./nTraders use OEX options to hedge or speculate on the performance of the large-cap segment of the stock market.

Term: Off-Balance Sheet (OBS) Activities: Types and Examples
Definition: Off-balance sheet (OBS) items are an accounting practice whereby a company does not include a liability on its balance sheet./nWhile not recorded on the balance sheet itself, these items are nevertheless assets and liabilities of the company./nOff-balance sheet items can be used to keep debt-to-equity (D/E) and leverage ratios low, facilitating cheaper borrowing and preventing bond covenants from being breached./nThe practice of off-balance sheet financing has come under increasing scrutiny after a number of accounting scandals revealed the misuse of the practice.

Term: Odious Debt: What it Means, How it Works, Examples
Definition: Odious debt is a term applied to a predecessor government's debt that a successor government wishes to repudiate on ostensibly moral grounds./nOdious debt is not an established principle of international law, but is often given as a rationale by the victors of civil or international conflict to repudiate their defeated opponents’ debts./nThe successful application of the concept of odious debt presents a significant risk for investors in sovereign debt and may increase borrowing costs for countries under threat of regime change.

Term: Off-Balance Sheet Financing (OBSF): Definition and Purpose
Definition: Off-balance sheet financing is an accounting practice where companies keep certain assets and liabilities from being reported on balance sheets./nThis practice helps companies keep debt-to-equity and leverage ratios low, resulting in cheaper borrowing and the prevention of covenants from being breached./nOff-balance sheet financing isn't illegal as long as companies abide by accounting rules and regulations./nRegulators are keen on clamping down on questionable OBSF./nMore stringent reporting rules are in place to give more transparency to controversial operating leases.

Term: Off-Chain Transactions: Definition, Advantages, Vs. On-Chain
Definition: In blockchain-based cryptocurrencies, off-chain transactions refer to those which occur outside of the blockchain itself./nOff-chain transactions can work by swapping private keys to an existing wallet instead of transferring funds, or by using a third-party or coupon-based interlocutor./nOff-chain transactions can entail lower fees, immediate settlement, and greater anonymity than on-chain transactions./nDepending on the method used, off-chain transactions may eventually have to be recorded on-chain.

Term: Off-The-Run Treasuries: What They are, How They Work
Definition: Off-the-run treasuries refer to any Treasury security that has been issued, except for the newest issue, which are called on-the-run./nOff-the-run treasuries tend to be somewhat less liquid than on-the-run securities, although they are still actively traded on the secondary market./nThe price difference between on-the-run and off-the-run Treasuries is often referred to as the liquidity premium, as the more liquid Treasuries are obtained at a higher cost.

Term: Offer to Buy An Asset: Types and Examples
Definition: An offer is a conditional proposal made by a buyer or seller to buy or sell an asset, which becomes legally binding if accepted./nThere are many different types of offers, each of which has a distinct combination of features ranging from pricing requirements, rules and regulations, type of asset, and the buyer's and seller's motives./nWhen it comes to equity and debt offerings, the offering price is the price at which publicly issued securities are offered for purchase by the investment bank underwriting the issue.

Term: What Is an Offensive Competitive Strategy? Company Actions
Definition: Offensive competitive strategies seek to shape an industry through first-mover and other aggressive moves./nThis can be an expensive strategy as it may include mergers & acquisitions, R&D investment, and intellectual property protection./nOffensive strategies may be contrasted with defensive ones, which instead focus on establishing a wide moat through building brand loyalty, offering high quality goods, and customer service.

Term: Offering: Definition, Types, and Examples in Finance
Definition: An offering refers to when a company issues or sells a security./nIt is most commonly known as an initial public offering./nIPOs can be risky because it's difficult to protect how the stock will perform on its initial day of trading.

Term: Offering Memorandum: Definition, Example, Vs. Prospectus
Definition: An offering memorandum is a document issued to potential investors in a private placement deal./nThe offering memorandum spells out the private placement's objectives, risks, financials, and deal terms./nAn offering memorandum is essentially a thorough business plan intended for sophisticated investors to use in their due diligence.

Term: Offering Circular: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: An offering circular is a formal written offer to sell newly issued securities that provides essential information to prospective investors./nIt is a condensed prospectus that must nonetheless include accurate data related to the issuer's finances, risk factors, usage of the proceeds from the issue, and other pertinent information./nThe offering circular, while abbreviated, should not be confused with the more informal "red herring" document, which is intended as a marketing device rather than a regulatory document.

Term: Offering Price: What it is, How it Works, In Practice
Definition: An offering price refers to the price of a stock set by an investment bank during the IPO process./nAn offering price is based on the company's legitimate prospects and set at a level that will attract interest from the general investing public./nAfter the IPO, the prices of shares are driven by market forces and will deviate from the offering price./nWhile a nice pop after the offering makes for juicy headlines, there are many examples wherein shares failed to hold above the offering price after the IPO.

Term: Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC): Definition, Sanctions
Definition: OFAC enforces U.S. trade and economic sanctions imposed on foreign nations or groups./nThe sanctions may be approved by Congress or initiated by emergency powers held by the president./nSanctions are intended to disrupt activity detrimental to the U.S. and its allies and force an end to them.

Term: Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions (OSFI) Definition
Definition: OSFI is an independent arm of the Government of Canada that supervises and regulates financial institutions and pension plans./nOSFI's goals are to protect depositors, policyholders, the financial institution (FI), creditors, and pension plan members./nOSFI guarantees bank deposits through the Canadian Deposit Insurance Corporation (CDIC).

Term: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) Structure, Powers
Definition: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) charters regulates, and supervises both national and foreign banks operating in the U.S./nAppointed by the president, the OCC is funded by the banks themselves that must pay examination and processing fees./nThe OCC has quite a bit of power, including the ability to deny applications for new bank branches, remove bank directors, and even take supervisory actions against the banks.

Term: Official Strike: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: An official strike is one that complies with the required legal processes for declaring and carrying out a strike or other work stoppage./nOfficial strikes are considered protected concerted action under the National Labor Relations Act, but whether any particular strike counts as official or not can depend on rulings by the National Labor Relations Board./nWorkers engaged in an official strike enjoy better legal protections against dismissal or retaliation by their employer.

Term: Official Settlement Account: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: An official settlement account is used to track and account for international balance of payments between central banks./nIt is used to settle transfers of assets and global monetary reserves that circulate among nations' central banks./nCountries look to these accounts to monitor capital outflows and inflows to and from other countries.

Term: Offline Debit Card: What They Are and How They Work
Definition: An offline debit card is not connected to an online system when used. Funds are therefore withdrawn from an account 24 to 72 hours later./nAn offline debit card does not require a PIN for use, only a signature, and can be compared to writing a check./nOffline debit cards are primarily used for payments and cannot be used for withdrawing or depositing funds at an ATM./nCard network providers, such as Visa and Mastercard, sponsor offline debit cards./nThe same overdraft fees and returned payment fees of a debit card apply to offline debit cards.

Term: What Is an Offset? Definition, Example, and How It's Used
Definition: In accounting, an offset is the recording of a gain that nullifies the effect of the recording of a loss./nAn offset in futures trading is taking two opposite positions on a commodity to cancel the delivery of the commodity./nIn certain markets, an offset is used to reduce risk exposure.

Term: Offsetting Transaction: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: An offsetting transaction is an activity that cancels out the risks and benefits of another position or transaction./nOffsetting can mean closing a position, if possible, but can also mean taking the opposite position in the same (or as close as possible) instrument.

Term: Offset Mortgage: Overview, Benefits, Example
Definition: An offset mortgage involves combining aspects of a traditional mortgage with one or more deposit accounts at the same financial institution./nThe funds in the deposit accounts are then used to offset the mortgage balance, lowering monthly payments./nOffset mortgages are standard in many nations but U.S. tax laws do not currently allow them./nAn offset mortgage is an attractive option for paying back a mortgage loan primarily because the borrower can make small payments to pay down the principal instead of the interest.

Term: Offshore: Definition, How It Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: Offshore refers to any (business) activity that takes place outside an entity's home base./nThe term may be used to describe foreign banks, corporations, investments, and deposits./nA company may legitimately move offshore for the purpose of tax avoidance or to enjoy relaxed regulations./nOffshore financial institutions can also be used for illicit purposes such as money laundering and tax evasion./nIncreased pressure is leading to more reporting of foreign accounts to international tax authorities.

Term: Offshore Mutual Fund: Meaning, Risks, Advantages
Definition: Offshore mutual funds may provide investment exposure to international markets, as well as tax benefits from being domiciled in overseas jurisdictions./nHowever, offshore funds may follow different rules and regulations than standard investments, which could present some higher risks of capital loss./nInvestors should exercise caution. Sponsors located outside of established offshore financial centers can be prone to fraudulent activity due to relaxed regulations.

Term: Offshore Banking Unit (OBU): Definition and How They Work
Definition: Offshore banking units (OBUs) refer to bank branches located outside of its home country, and handling transactions made in foreign currency (known generically as "eurocurrency")./nOBUs make it easier for individuals and businesses to bank internationally and establish offshore accounts./nIndividuals may choose to keep their money offshore if there is instability in their own country, and they fear losing their investments./nOffshore bank accounts must be declared to the holder's home country for tax reasons; however, some countries allow foreigners to earn capital gains tax-free.

Term: Offshore Portfolio Investment Strategy (OPIS)
Definition: Offshore Portfolio Investment Strategy (OPIS) was a tax avoidance product offered by the accounting firm, KPMG./nOPIS was one of many tax avoidance schemes offered by accounting firms in the 1990s./nThese accounting schemes would create shell companies and record fake transactions and investments that would result in losses. These losses were used to offset the profits of a company, resulting in a lower amount of taxes owed./nThe Internal Revenue Service (IRS) eventually made these tax schemes illegal, as they served no purpose except to lower taxes and robbed the government of tax revenue./nThe companies involved in the tax scandals had to pay millions of dollars in damages.

Term: What Is an Offtake Agreement in Project Financing?
Definition: An offtake agreement is an agreement to buy or sell, in advance, some of a producer's goods that haven't yet been made, making it easier for producers to obtain financing./nThis type of agreement may be negotiated far in advance, often prior to construction of manufacturing facilities and before actual production has begun./nOfftake agreements can help buyers lock in a price and guarantee supply of a product in anticipation of future demand.

Term: Oil Field: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: An oil field is a piece of land beneath which fossil fuels can be extracted for economic value./nMost of the world's oil is concentrated in oil fields located in the Middle East, along with other large deposits discovered beneath the ocean's surface./nOil exploration to discover new drilling sites can expensive and risky, but also quite lucrative if a large reserve is identified.

Term: Oil ETF: What It is, How it Works, and Challenges
Definition: An oil ETF is an exchange-traded fund (ETF) which invests in companies engaged in the oil and gas industry./nSome oil ETFs may be commodity pools, with limited partnership interests instead of shares. These pools invest in derivative contracts such as futures and options./nWith an oil ETF, the investors are not dealing in futures, so physical inventory isn't a concern.

Term: Understanding an OHLC Chart and How to Interpret It
Definition: An OHLC chart shows the open, high, low, and close price for a given period./nIt can be applied to any timeframe./nThe vertical line represents the high and low for the period, while the line to the left marks the open price and the line to the right marks the closing price. This entire structure is called a bar./nWhen the close is above the open, the bar is often colored black. When the close is below the open the bar is often colored red.

Term: Oil Pollution Act of 1990: Meaning, History, Liability
Definition: The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 expanded the power of federal agencies to prevent and punish mass oil spills./nIt was passed by the U.S. Congress in response to the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989 as an amendment to the Clean Water Act of 1972./nThe goal of the OPA was to design and establish a comprehensive federal framework that would prevent future oil spills and develop cleanup procedures in the case of a spill-related emergency./nThe OPA is primarily enforced and administered by the U.S. Coast Guard and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)./nBefore the passing of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, the U.S. was poorly placed in dealing with oil spills in terms of federal funding to respond to them as well as having a narrow scope of damages in regards to compensation to those affected. The OPA remedied these shortcomings.

Term: Oil Price to Natural Gas Ratio
Definition: The oil price to natural gas ratio expresses the price of oil relative to natural gas./nIt is a widely-used metric in the energy commodities market./nThe ratio has varied widely in recent years, reaching a historically low level in April 2020 during the 2020 crisis.

Term: Oil Reserves: Definition, Calculation, Statistics, and Examples
Definition: Oil reserves are the amount of crude oil a country or region has that can be extracted./nVenezuela, Saudi Arabia, and Canada are the three leading countries with the most oil reserves./nIndustry leader BP plc estimates that there are 1.73 trillion barrels of oil reserves globally./nApproximately 80% of the world’s oil reserves are in the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC)./nThe Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) is an emergency supply of crude oil that can be used to offset a severe oil supply shortage in the United States.

Term: What Is an Oil Refinery? What They Do, Services and How They Work
Definition: An oil refinery is a facility that takes crude oil and distills it into various useful petroleum products such as gasoline, kerosene, or jet fuel./nRefining is classified as a downstream operation of the oil and gas industry, although many integrated oil companies will operate both extraction and refining services./nRefineries and oil traders look to the crack spread, the relative difference in production cost and market price of various petroleum products in the derivatives market to hedge their exposure to crude oil prices.

Term: Oil Sands
Definition: Oil sands or tar sands are sand and rock materials which contain crude bitumen, a thick and viscous liquid./nThe end product of oil sands is conventional oil. However, the process to extract it is much more expensive and environmentally harmful as compared to other methods, such as oil rigs./nCanada has the third-largest proven oil reserves after Venezuela and Saudi Arabia.﻿﻿

Term: Okun's Law: Definition, Formula, History, and Limitations
Definition: Okun's law is an observed relationship between a country's GDP (or GNP) and employment levels./nOkun's law was coined by Arthur Okun, a Yale economist who served on President Kennedy'scouncil of economic advisors./nOkun's law predicts that a 1% drop in employment tends to be accompanied by a drop in GDP of around 2%. Likewise, a 1% increase in employment is associated with a 2% GDP increase./nOkun's law is not without controversy, and some economists disagree about the exact relationship between employment and productivity./nAlthough Okun's law is not derived from any theoretical prediction, observational data indicates that Okun's law often holds true.

Term: Old Age, Survivors, Disability Insurance (OASDI) Program Basics
Definition: Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance is the official though little-used name of the Social Security program in the U.S./nThe program provides benefits to retired adults and people with disabilities, and to their dependents./nOASDI taxes, also known as FICA payroll tax, fund the program from workers' wages and employer contributions./nIndividuals and employers split the Social Security taxes while self-employed individuals are responsible for both portions./nThe amount of an individual’s monthly Social Security payment is based on their earnings during their working years.

Term: Old Economy: Meaning, Overview, Examples
Definition: Old economy refers to industries that have not changed significantly despite advances in technology./nExamples of old economy industries include steel, agriculture, and manufacturing./nClimate change and new technologies impact the old economy, but most of the processes have been the same for hundreds of years./nThere is a limit to how much new technology can help old economy industries, which have roots that trace back to economic systems of the industrial revolution.

Term: Old Lady: What It Means, How It Works, History
Definition: The Old Lady, or the Old Lady of Threadneedle Street, is a colloquial nickname for the Bank of England./nThis nickname originates from a 1797 satirical cartoon regarding the suspension of gold redemption under the Restriction Act of 1797./nThe nickname has since appeared in cartoons, newspapers, books, and common usage to refer to the Bank.

Term: Oligopsony: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: An oligopsony concentrates the market for a product in the hands of a few big players./nThe buyers dominate the market, keeping prices down and wielding considerable influence over the industry./nThe supermarket industry is emerging as an oligopsony with global reach.

Term: Oligopoly: Meaning and Characteristics in a Market
Definition: An oligopoly is a market structure wherein a small number of producers work to restrict output or fix prices so they can achieve above-normal market returns./nEconomic, legal, and technological factors can contribute to the formation and maintenance, or dissolution, of oligopolies./nThe major difficulty that oligopolies face is the prisoner's dilemma that each member faces, which encourages each member to cheat./nGovernment policy can discourage or encourage oligopolistic behavior, and firms in mixed economies often seek government blessing for ways to limit competition.

Term: What an Ombudsman Does, Types, Pros & Cons
Definition: An ombudsman investigates complaints leveled against businesses and other organizations, including the government./nDepending on the jurisdiction, an ombudsman's decision may or may not be legally binding./nHowever, even if not binding, the decision typically carries considerable weight./nIn the U.S., members of Congress serve as ombudsmen./nThe processing time for a complaint can be between 90 days and nine months, depending on the type and complexity of the complaint.

Term: Omega: Meaning and Calculations in Options Trading
Definition: The third derivative of the option price, Omega measures the effect of an option's leverage./nOmega is not always referenced among option Greeks./nThis variable is used most often by option market makers or other sophisticated, high-volume option traders.

Term: What Is an Omnibus Account? How It's Managed
Definition: An omnibus account allows for managed trades of more than one person, and allows for anonymity of the persons in the account./nOmnibus accounts allow more efficient transactions to take place, since the manager can act swiftly when market conditions call for it./nAlso, the manager's compensation is often tied to the performance of the omnibus account, adding incentive to have it perform well./nFor investors that want privacy, an omnibus account is beneficial.

Term: On Account: Definition, Journal Entry Explanation, and Examples
Definition: "On account" is used in accounting to note partial payments or purchases made on credit./nPurchases on account are purchases made on credit./nOn account also refers to payment on an account.

Term: On-Balance Volume (OBV): Definition, Formula, and Uses As Indicator
Definition: On-balance volume (OBV) is a technical indicator of momentum, using volume changes to make price predictions./nOBV shows crowd sentiment that can predict a bullish or bearish outcome./nComparing relative action between price bars and OBV generates more actionable signals than the green or red volume histograms commonly found at the bottom of price charts.

Term: On-Chain Governance: Definition, Types, vs. Off-Chain
Definition: On-chain governance is an integrated voting system for managing and implementing changes to cryptocurrency blockchains./nOn-chain governance is intended to let a community decide which changes are made./nAnyone can propose changes to the blockchain, and participants with voting rights decide whether to accept or reject the proposals.

Term: On-The-Run Treasuries: Definition and How They're Traded
Definition: On-the-run Treasuries are the most recent Treasury released for a certain maturity./nOff-the-run Treasuries are those that have been issued before and remain outstanding./nA Treasury transitions from on-the-run to off-the-run once a newer set of Treasuries is released for sale.

Term: On-The-Run Treasury Yield Curve: What It is, How It Works
Definition: The on-the-run Treasury yield curve graphically shows the current yields versus maturities of the most recently sold U.S. Treasury securities and is the primary benchmark used in pricing fixed-income securities./nOn-the-run Treasury yield curve is the opposite of the off-the-run Treasury yield curve, which refers to U.S. treasuries, of a given maturity, which are not part of the most recent issue./nOn-the-run treasury yield curve is less accurate than off-the-run treasury yield curve as the volatility of current demand for recent supply tends to lead to price distortions.

Term: On-Us Item: Transactions Paid And Deposited at The Same Bank
Definition: An on-us item refers to a check or payment that is deposited or processed by the bank issuing or initiating the payment./nBecause the transaction remains within a single bank, it is preferred for its lower expenses and added ability to profit from it./nFor not-on-us items, an inter-bank payments or clearing network must be used, which may carry fees and charges.

Term: How China's One Belt One Road (OBOR) Initiative Works & Its Goals
Definition: OBOR is a project that focuses on improving connectivity and cooperation among multiple countries in Asia, Africa, and Europe./nOBOR's scope has expanded over the years to include new territories and development initiatives./nKyrgyzstan and Tajikistan support OBOR thanks to the massive investments by China in local transmission projects in these nations.

Term: Bank Holding Company Definition, How It Operates
Definition: A bank holding company is a corporate entity that owns a controlling interest in one or more banks./nThe one-bank holding company is simply a holding company for one bank but it has a shorter history as a more flexible arrangement for an independent bank./nHolding companies of many kinds exist throughout the economy. Berkshire Hathaway is one.

Term: One-Cancels-the-Other (OCO) Order
Definition: One-cancels-the-other (OCO) is a type of conditional order for a pair of orders in which the execution of one automatically cancels the other./nTraders generally execute OCO orders for volatile stocks that trade over a wide price range./nOn many trading platforms, multiple conditional orders can be placed with other orders canceled when one has been executed.

Term: What Was China's One-Child Policy? Its Implications and Importance
Definition: The “one-child policy” is a name given to Chinese government laws for controlling population growth. According to estimates, it prevented about 400 million births in the country./nIntroduced in 1979 and discontinued in 2015, the policy was enforced through a mix of incentives and sanctions./nThe one-child policy has had three important consequences for China's demographics: it reduced the fertility rate considerably, it skewed China's gender ratio because people preferred to abort or abandon their female babies, and resulted in a labor shortage given the increasing proportion of the population who were older adults.

Term: One-Stop-Shop: Definition, Example, History, Pros and Cons
Definition: A one-stop shop is a business or office that offers multiple services or products to customers./nThe business strategy behind the one-stop shop is to provide convenience and efficiency to clients, gaining loyalty as well as revenue./nFor the consumer, using a one-stop shop can be efficient and provide insight into one's affairs, but it can also limit options and be more expensive.

Term: 1% Rule in Real Estate: What It Is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: The rent charged should be equal to or greater than the investor's mortgage payment to ensure that they at least break even on the property./nMultiply the purchase price of the property plus any necessary repairs by 1% to determine a base level of monthly rent./nIdeally, an investor should seek a mortgage loan with monthly payments of less than the 1% figure.

Term: One-Tailed Test Explained: Definition and Example
Definition: A one-tailed test is a statistical hypothesis test set up to show that the sample mean would be higherorlower than the population mean, but not both./nWhen using a one-tailed test, the analyst is testing for the possibility of the relationship in one direction of interest and completely disregarding the possibility of a relationship in another direction./nBefore running a one-tailed test, the analyst must set up a null and alternative hypothesis and establish a probability value (p-value).

Term: One-Third Rule: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The one-third rule is a rule of thumb that estimates the change in labor productivity based on changes in capital per hour of labor./nThe rule is used to determine the impact that changes in technology or capital have on production./nThe more goods and services a laborer can produce in an hour of work, the higher the standard of living in that economy./nIt can be hard to obtain more human capital, especially in countries that have a lower participation rate, or percentage of the population participating in the labor force.

Term: One-Time Charge: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A one-time charge is a non-recurring event that results in an isolated charge or write-off./nOne-time charges are not typically reflective of long-term financial performance, so many companies report pro-forma earnings that exclude the impact of such charges./nSome companies incorrectly record charges that they repeatedly incur in the course of their usual business activities as one-time charges./nStock prices have demonstrated a tendency to significantly suffer during periods of frequent one-time charges, as it could be signal a red flag.

Term: One-Time Item: Overview, Benefits, Examples
Definition: A one-time item is a gain, loss, or expense on the income statement that is nonrecurring in nature./nA one-time item is not considered part of a company's ongoing business operations./nOne-time items are usually excluded by analysts and investors to properly evaluate a company's core performance.

Term: One-Touch Option: Meaning, Overview, Outcomes
Definition: A one-touch option pays a premium to the holder of the option if the spot rate reaches the strike price at any time prior to option expiration./nOne-touch options are usually less expensive than other exotic or binary options like double one-touch or barrier options./nDerivatives, like one-touch options, are not frequently traded by small investors.

Term: What Happened to OneCoin, the $4 Billion Crypto Ponzi Scheme?
Definition: OneCoin was a Ponzi scheme that pulled in $4 billion from 2014 to 2016./nOneCoin was not actively traded, nor could the coins be used to purchase anything./nIts founder, Ruja Ignatova, has disappeared and co-founder Sebastian Greenwood is in jail in the U.S./nThe company’s main business was selling course materials, which were reportedly plagiarized in most cases./nIts course material business model was akin to a multi-level marketing (MLM) scheme, where course material buyers were paid to recruit new buyers.

Term: Onerous Contract: Definition, Accounting Rules, Examples
Definition: An onerous contract is an accounting term defined under the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), used in many countries around the world./nCompanies that follow those standards are required to report any onerous contracts they're committed to on their balance sheets./nIn the United States, companies typically follow a different set of accounting standards and generally don't have to account for their onerous contracts.

Term: What Is Online Banking? Definition and How It Works
Definition: Online banking allows you to conduct financial transactions through a computer or smart phone using the internet./nWith online banking, you don’t need to visit a branch to complete many transactions./nTo take advantage of online banking, you’ll need an electronic device, an internet connection, and perhaps your debit card or account numbers.

Term: Online-to-Offline (O2O) Commerce Definition and Trends
Definition: Online-to-offline (O2O) commerce is a business model that draws potential customers from online channels to make purchases in physical stores./nTechniques that O2O commerce companies may employ include in-store pick-up of items purchased online, allowing items purchased online to be returned at a physical store, and allowing customers to place orders online while at a physical store./nAmazon's purchase of Whole Foods Markets and Walmart's acquisition of Jet.com are two examples of O2O commerce./nTarget, Walmart, Kroger, Nordstrom, and many other retailers have increased home delivery and/or curbside pickup services as two effective O2O strategies to meet consumer needs for safe shopping options.

Term: Online Shoplifting: What It is, How It Works, Types
