Definition: Online shoplifting involves stealing products from an ecommerce site./nA chargeback or dispute claiming the goods were never received (although they were) is one form of online shoplifting./nThere are secondary effects to this type of fraud, including credit card issuers refusing to work with the merchant due to excessive chargebacks./nIllegally downloading copyrighted music, books, or movies is another form of online shoplifting.

Term: Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board (OTPPB) Overview
Definition: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan Board (OTPPB) oversees the retirement plan established for the benefit of public school teachers in Ontario, Canada./nThe OTPPB manages a variety of assets, including international equities, bonds, commodities, and real estate./nThe pension board oversees investment assets of nearly $200 billion, serving the needs of more than 300,000 retirees and employees.

Term: Opaque Pricing: Meaning, Benefits, Types
What Is an Opco? Definition, Example, Vs. Propco
Definition: Opco is the abbreviation for "operating company," typically used when describing the primary operating company involved in an opco/propco deal that structures a REIT./nIn an opco/propco deal strategy, companies are divided into at least an operating company and a property company in order to improve the finances of both prospects./nThere are functional and strategic differences between real estate operating companies and REITs, but REITs do not need to operate the properties.

Term: OPEC Basket: Meaning, Benefits, Criticism
Definition: The OPEC Basket is a weighted average of oil prices from the different OPEC members around the world./nThe main use of the OPEC Basket is setting and achieving OPEC price targets./nSince it is just an average, an OPEC Basket is not a type of crude oil that businesses can buy directly.

Term: Operating Company/Property Company Deal (Opco/Propco)
Definition: Opco/propco business arrangements result in a subsidiary or property company (the propco) holding or owning all of the assets and real estate that the main operating company (the opco) uses to generate revenues./nOpco/propco deals can help the parent company benefit as financing and credit terms are independent of the operating company./nIn addition to loan independence, these types of deals can have tax advantages for the parent company./nAlthough some may consider these types of deals tax loopholes, they are entirely legal and are generally considered the mark of an intelligent business.

Term: Open Architecture: What it is, How it Works
Definition: In finance, open architecture refers to when a bank or investment firm offers both in-house and third-party products and services to its clients./nThe goal is to create a one-stop shop of clients, who do not have to shop around several firms to get the offerings that they want or are best-suited for./nOpen architecture has resulted in greater fee competition and transparency, which benefits investors.

Term: Open Banking: Definition, How It Works, and Risks
Definition: Open banking is the system of allowing access and control of consumer banking and financial accounts through third-party applications./nOpen banking has the potential to reshape the competitive landscape and consumer experience of the banking industry./nOpen banking raises the potential for both promising gains and grave risks to consumers as more of their data is shared more widely.

Term: Open Cover: Meaning, Overview, Requirements
Definition: Open cover is insurance provided to companies engaged in the marine business./nAn insurer provides insurance to all of the cargo shipped under an open cover marine policy./nThe insurance policy for open cover can be either a renewable policy for each shipment or a permanent policy, covering many shipments./nRisks to cargo include sinking, piracy, damage from loading/unloading, and infestation./nA policyholder must disclose all pertinent information and fill out certificates with detailed information regarding each shipment./nCountries govern their waters, so marine insurance regulations are under the control of the governments where any losses may occur.

Term: Open-End Credit: Definition, How It Works, vs. Closed-End Credit
Definition: Open-end credit is a type of loan that the borrower can draw money from repeatedly up to a certain pre-approved limit./nUnlike closed-end credit, it has no fixed end date for repayment./nWhen the borrower repays some of the money they have borrowed, it restores that portion of their pre-approved limit./nCredit cards and lines of credit are examples of open-end credit and are also referred to as revolving credit./nOpen-end credit is different fromclosed-end credit,in which the borrower receives money in a lump sum and must pay it back by a fixed end date./nMortgages and car loans are examples of closed-end credit.

Term: Open-End Lease: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Open-end leases are used for both commercial and individual purposes—often for purchasing or leasing vehicles./nAn open-end lease for an apartment or home rental may be based on a month-by-month rental agreement between the landlord and the renter./nIn terms of flexibility, the open-end lease is typically less rigid than a closed-end lease./nA closed-end care lease may make more sense for general consumers who need a vehicle that will make regular trips of predictable length.

Term: Open-Ended Fund: Definition, Example, Pros and Cons
Definition: An open-end fund is an investment that uses pooled assets, allowing for ongoing new contributions and withdrawals./nAs a result, open-ended funds have a theoretically unlimited number of potential shares outstanding./nMost mutual funds and exchange-traded funds are open-end funds./nOpen-end mutual fund shares do not trade on exchanges and are priced at their portfolio's net asset value (NAV) at the end of each day. ETFs trade throughout the trading day.

Term: Open-End Management Company: Meaning, Types, FAQs
Definition: An open-end management company manages open-end funds, such as open-end mutual funds and exchange traded funds (ETFs)./nOpen-end mutual funds are not traded on exchanges; the open-end management company is responsible for distributing and redeeming all of the shares of open-end mutual funds offered in the market./nETFs offered by open-end management companies also do not have a specified number of shares offered, meaning the open-end management company can issue and redeem shares at their discretion./nOpen-end funds and ETFs do have many similarities; both are pooled funds allowing for management and operational economies of scale./nClosed-end funds are different from open-end funds in that they have a specific number of shares available and are priced throughout the day at their market price as opposed to once a day at their NAV like open-end funds.

Term: Open-End Mortgage: Overview, Benefits, Examples
Definition: An open-end mortgage is a type of mortgage that allows the borrower to increase the amount of the mortgage principal outstanding at a later time./nAn open-end mortgage allows a borrower to take a portion of the loan value for which they have been approved to cover the costs of their home; by taking only a portion, the borrower can pay a lower interest rate since they are only obligated to make interest payments on the outstanding balance./nAn open-end mortgage is advantageous for a borrower who qualifies for a higher loan principal amount than may be needed to buy the home.

Term: What Is an Open-Ended Investment Company (OEIC)? How They Work
Definition: An open-ended investment company (OEIC) is a type of investment fund in the United Kingdom, similar to an open-ended mutual fund in the U.S./nOEICs offer a professionally managed portfolio of pooled investor funds that invests in different equities, bonds, and other securities./nOEICs are priced once a day, based on the net asset value of their underlying portfolio assets./nMost OEICs carry sales charges and annual management fees, known as the ongoing charges figure.

Term: Open Interest: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Open interest is the total number of open derivative contracts, such as options or futures, that have not been settled./nOpen interest is commonly associated with the futures and options markets./nIncreasing open interest represents new or additional money coming into the market, while decreasing open interest indicates money flowing out of the market./nTo comprehend open interest, you should understand that traders can buy and sell to open and close positions.

Term: Open House: Definition, How It Works, Advantages & Disadvantages
Definition: An open house is a scheduled period of time in which a home is available for viewing by potential buyers./nOpen houses can attract interested buyers and lead to an offer or alert the realtor to issues with the space that might be pointed out./nOn the other hand, open houses can entail a considerable amount of effort in organizing./nSome realtors may serve light refreshments at an open house or even cocktails during an evening open house./nAn open house is a great, low-pressure way to show the house to potential buyers.

Term: Audit: What It Means in Finance and Accounting and 3 Main Types
Definition: The three main types of audits are external audits, internal audits, and Internal Revenue Service audits./nExternal audits are commonly performed by Certified Public Accounting (CPA) firms and result in an auditor's opinion which is included in the audit report./nAn unqualified or clean audit opinion means that the auditor hasn't identified any material misstatement as a result of his or her review of the financial statements./nExternal audits can include a review of both financial statements and a company's internal controls./nInternal audits serve as a managerial tool to make improvements to processes and internal controls.

Term: Open Loop Card: What it is, How it Works
Definition: An open loop card is a general-purpose charge card that can be used anywhere that brand of card is accepted./nThe opposite of an open loop card is a card that can only be used at a specific retailer, known as a closed loop card./nOpen loop cards can be credit cards,debit cards, gift cards, or prepaid cards.

Term: Open Listing: Meaning, Considerations, and FAQs
Definition: Home sellers may have the option of offering a real estate agent an exclusive listing or an open listing./nAn open listing allows other local real estate agents to compete to find a buyer for the property./nAn exclusive listing gives the sole agent an incentive to work hard for the sale./nAn open listing offers the possibility of more showings and wider interest in the home.

Term: What Is an Open Market Economic System, and How Does It Work?
Definition: An open market is an economic system with little to no barriers to free-market activity./nOpen markets may have competitive barriers to entry, but never any regulatory barriers to entry./nThe United States, Canada, Western Europe, and Australia are countries with relatively open markets.

Term: What Are Open Market Operations (OMOs), and How Do They Work?
Definition: Open market operations are one of three tools used by the Fed to affect the availability of money and credit./nThe term refers to a central bank buying or selling securities in the open market to influence the money supply./nThe Fed uses open market operations to manipulate interest rates, starting with the federal funds rate used in interbank loans./nBuying securities adds money to the system, lowers rates, makes loans easier to obtain, and increases economic activity./nSelling securities removes money from the system, raises rates, makes loans more expensive, and decreases economic activity.

Term: Open-Market Transactions: Meaning, Process, Why They Happen
Definition: An open-market transaction refers to the buying or selling of shares in a company by insiders of that company./nWhen enacting an open-market transaction, an insider has to fill out the appropriate paperwork with the SEC to avoid violating any insider trading laws./nWhen open-market transactions occur, outside investors pay attention as the purchase or sale of securities by insiders can indicate the outlook of the company./nMore interest is placed on the buying of shares by insiders than the selling of shares.

Term: Open Mouth Operations
Definition: Open mouth operations broadcast where the Fed, or central bank, believes interest rates and inflation should be in the short-and medium-term./nOpen mouth operations can cause the markets to react, which can lead to an adjustment in interest rates without the need for central bank action./nIf the marketplace response does not move interest rates and inflation, the Fed may take steps, including changing the fed funds rate and open market operations (OMO).

Term: Open Outcry: What it is, How it Works, Decline in Popularity
Definition: Open outcry was the primary method for how pit traders communicated trade orders./nThe fierce competition in trading pits made things highly efficient, but electronic trading has proved to be even more efficient./nSuccessful traders in open outcry relied on temporary information asymmetry in order to be successful, but more information parity helps retail and institutional traders alike to profit from greater trading efficiency and increased participation.

Term: Open Order: Definition in Trading, How They Work, and Causes
Definition: Open orders are those unfilled and working orders still in the market waiting to be executed./nOrders may remain open because certain conditions such as limit price have not yet been met./nMarket orders, on the other hand, do not have such restrictions and are typically filled fairly instantaneously./nOpen orders may be cancelled before they are filled in whole or in part.

Term: Open Position: Meaning and Risk in Trading
Definition: An open position is a trade that has been established, but which has not yet been closed out with an opposing trade./nIf an investor owns 300 shares of a stock, they have an open position in that stock until it is sold./nAn open position represents market exposure for the investor, and the risk remains until the position is closed./nDay traders open and close their positions in a matter of seconds and aim to have no open positions at the end of the day.

Term: Open Source: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: Open source refers to a project, often a software or IT development project, with freely available code and permission to make edits, bug fixes, alterations, and enhancements./nOpen source software efforts have been behind popular applications and operating systems including the Android OS for smartphones and the Firefox web browser./nOpen source relies on community engagement, trust, and permissive licensing strategies./nAn advantage of open source is the greater potential for innovative ideas and changes offered by a large community of coders compared to a single design firm./nA disadvantage of open source is that no one entity is responsible for maintaining the software so flaws won't be fixed unless they're discovered.

Term: Open Trade Equity (OTE): Definition, Uses, and Examples
Definition: Open Trade Equity (OTE) represents the amount of an unrealized gain or loss on an open position before it has been closed out./nOTE is useful in providing traders a better picture of their actual p&l, especially when trades are margined./nA positive OTE improves the odds of realizing a profit while a negative OTE raises the odds of realizing a loss.

Term: Opening Bell: What it is, How it Works, FAQ
Definition: The opening bell represents the start of a regular trading session on an exchange./nIt is largely symbolic since the majority of trading is electronic and trading is rarely conducted on a physical trading floor./nThe opening bell gives occasion for exchanges to make news and better market securities during an initial public offering (IPO)./nCelebrities and visiting dignitaries are often invited to ring the opening bell as a symbolic ritual for traders in the stock market./nThe NYSE's bell calendar lists all of the people scheduled to ring the opening bell.

Term: Opening Cross: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: The Opening Cross is the way the Nasdaq determines the opening price for individual shares trading on the exchange./nThe process reflects the change in sentiment and share price for a stock between the closing of the market the previous day and today./nAn auction determines prices for the Opening Cross, with buyers and sellers placing offers and counteroffers until prices match, resulting in a trade./nThe aim of using the Opening Cross is to avoid surprises and give all investors the same information about the demand for each stock when the market opens.

Term: Opening Price: Definition, Example, Trading Strategies
Definition: The opening price is the first price at which a security trades at the open./nThe opening price is different from the previous day's closing price./nThere are several day-trading strategies based on the opening price of a market or security.

Term: Opening Range: Overview and Examples in Technical Analysis
Definition: The opening range shows a security's high and low prices for a given period after the market opens./nOpening ranges are important to traders because they can provide an indication of sentiment and price trends for the day./nTraders often monitor opening ranges before or after periods of heightened volatility./nMany traders follow the opening range after a major event or announcement./nTraders can use different patterns, technical analysis, and timeframes to track the opening range.

Term: What Are Operating Activities, and What Are Some Examples?
Operating Cash Flow (OCF): Definition, Cash Flow Statements
Definition: Operating cash flow is an important benchmark to determine the financial success of a company's core business activities./nOperating cash flow is the first section depicted on a cash flow statement, which also includes cash from investing and financing activities./nThere are two methods for depicting operating cash flow on a cash flow statement—the indirect method and the direct method./nThe indirect method begins with net income from the income statement then adds back non-cash items to arrive at a cash basis figure./nThe direct method tracks all transactions in a period on a cash basis and uses actual cash inflows and outflows on the cash flow statement.

Term: Operating Cash Flow Demand (OCFD)
Definition: Operating cash flow demand is the amount of operating cash flow an investor needs to meet the objectives its strategic investments./nFor individual investors, the OCFD is the capital needed to achieve the desired return on investment./nCorporations use the OCFD to compute the cash value added of their strategic investments and operations./nKnowing the OCFD allows investors to make smart decisions about how they spend their money on certain investments.

Term: Operating Cash Flow Margin Defined With Formula, Example
Definition: The operating cash flow margin reveals how effectively a company converts sales to cash and is a good indicator of earnings quality./nOperating cash flow margin is calculated by dividing operating cash flow by revenue./nThis ratio uses operating cash flow, which adds back non-cash expenses./nThis is what distinguishes it from operating margin, which uses operating income that excludes such expenses as depreciation.

Term: Operating Cash Flow (OCF): Definition, Types, and Formula
Definition: The operating cash flow ratio indicates if a company's normal operations are sufficient to cover its near-term obligations./nA higher ratio means that a company has generated more cash in a period than what was immediately needed to pay off current liabilities./nCash flow from operations (CFO) is preferred over net income because there is less room to manipulate results through accounting tricks.

Term: Operating Costs Definition: Formula, Types, and Real-World Examples
Definition: Operating costs are the ongoing expenses incurred from the normal day-to-day of running a business./nOperating costs include both costs of goods sold (COGS) and other operating expenses—often called selling, general, and administrative (SG&A) expenses./nCommon operating costs in addition to COGS may include rent, equipment, inventory costs, marketing, payroll, insurance, and funds allocated for research and development./nOperating costs can be found and analyzed by looking at a company's income statement.

Term: Operating Earnings: Meaning, Formula, Example
Definition: Operating earnings is a measure of the amount of profit realized from a business's core operations./nOperating earnings is a useful figure since it doesn't include taxes and other one-off items that might skew net income in a specific accounting period./nA commonly used variant of operating earnings is the operating margin, a percentage figure that represents operating earnings divided by total revenue.

Term: Operating Expense (OpEx) Definition and Examples
Definition: An operating expense is an expense that a business incurs through its normal business operations./nOperating expenses include rent, equipment, inventory costs, marketing, payroll, insurance, step costs, and funds allocated for research and development./nThe Internal Revenue Service (IRS) allows businesses to deduct operating expenses if the business operates to earn profits./nBy contrast, a non-operating expense is an expense incurred by a business that is unrelated to the business's core operations./nA capital expense is a different type of expense that relates to acquiring, maintaining, or upgrading an asset.

Term: Operating Income
Definition: Operating income reports the amount of profit realized from a business's ongoing operations./nOperating income is calculated by subtracting operating expenses from a company's gross profit./nOperating expenses are naturally recurring costs incurred to run a business such as administrative, selling, or general expenses./nOperating income is the same as EBIT as both measurements reflect profit prior to non-operating expenses such as interest or taxes./nOn the other hand, operating income and net income differ because net income reflects these additional costs.

Term: Operating Expense Ratio (OER): Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: In real estate, the operating expense ratio (OER) is a measurement of the cost to operate a piece of property, compared to the income brought in by the property./nThe operating expense ratio (OER) is calculated by dividing all operating expenses less depreciation by operating income./nA lower operating expense ratio (OER) is more desirable for investors because it means that expenses are minimized relative to revenue.

Term: Operating Loss (OL): Definition, How It's Calculated, and Causes
Definition: If a company's operating expenses exceed their gross profits, it will show an operating loss on the financial statements./nAn operating loss excludes the effect of interest income, interest expense, extraordinary gains or losses, or income or losses from equity investments or taxes./nAn operating loss reflects unprofitable operations, and changes may be required to decrease costs or increase revenues./nA company might also experience an operating loss if it is re-investing in itself to expand business in the future.

Term: Operating Income Before Depreciation and Amortization (OIBDA)
Definition: Operating income before depreciation and amortization (OIBDA) shows a company's profitability in its core business activities./nOIBDA excludes the effects of capital spending on fixed assets, such as equipment./nOIBDA also excludes the interest expense or cost of debt and tax expenses./nAnalyzing a company's OIBDA shows how well a company is generating revenue while managing its production and operating expenses.

Term: Operating Leverage: What It Is, How It Works, How to Calculate
Definition: The operating leverage ratio is used to calculate a company’s break-even point and help set appropriate selling prices to cover all costs and generate a profit./nCompanies with high operating leverage must cover a larger amount of fixed costs each month regardless of whether they sell any units of product./nLow-operating-leverage companies may have high costs that vary directly with their sales but have lower fixed costs to cover each month.

Term: Operating Lease: How It Works and Differs From a Finance Lease
Definition: An operating lease is a contract that permits the use of an asset without transferring the ownership rights of said asset./nA finance lease is a contract that permits the use of an asset and transfers ownership after the lease period is complete, and the lessor meets all other contract obligations./nGAAP rules govern accounting for operating leases./nAll leases 12 months and longer must be recognized on the balance sheet./nLeases shorter than 12 months can be recognized as expenses using the straight-line method.

Term: Operating Margin: What It Is and the Formula for Calculating It, With Examples
Definition: The operating margin represents how efficiently a company is able to generate profit through its core operations./nIt is expressed on a per-sale basis after accounting for variable costs but before paying any interest or taxes (EBIT)./nHigher margins are considered better than lower margins, and can be compared between similar competitors but not across different industries./nTo calculate the operating margin, divide operating income (earnings) by sales (revenues).

Term: Operating Profit: How to Calculate, What It Tells You, and Example
Definition: Operating profit is the net income derived from a company's primary or core business operations./nOperating profit does not include non-operating income, but EBIT does./nIt eliminates several extraneous and indirect factors that can obscure a company's real performance./nA company's operating profit margin shows how well a company turns gross revenue into this figure.

Term: Operating Ratio: Definition and Formula for Calculation
Definition: The operating ratio shows the efficiency of a company's management by comparing the total operating expense of a company tonet sales./nAn operating ratio that is decreasing is viewed as a positive sign, as it indicates that operating expenses are becoming an increasingly smaller percentage of net sales./nA limitation of the operating ratio is that it doesn't include debt.

Term: Operation Twist: Definition, How It Works, and Economic Impact
Definition: Operation Twist is a monetary policy strategy used by central banks aimed at stimulating economic growth through lowering long-term interest rates./nThis is achieved by selling near-term Treasuries to buy longer-dated ones./nOperation Twist effectively "twists" the ends of the yield curve where short-term yields go up and long-term interest rates drop simultaneously./nOperation Twist was first attempted in 1961, and again in the years following the 2008-09 financial crisis.

Term: Operating Revenue: Definition, How It's Generated, and Examples
Definition: Operating revenue is generated by a company's primary business activities./nOperating revenue can be compared year-over-year to assess the health of a company and its operations./nOperating revenue should be separated out from non-operating revenue that occurs from infrequent, unusual, or one-time events.

Term: Operational Efficiency: Definition, Examples, Vs. Productivity
Definition: Operational efficiency measures the proportion of costs incurred during an economic or financial activity, where lower costs equate with greater efficiency./nFor investors and traders, markets exhibit operational efficiency when transaction costs are low./nOffering bulk discounts or free commissions to traders is one way to increase the operational efficiency of investment markets.

Term: Operational Risk: Overview, Importance, and Examples
Definition: Operational risk summarizes the chances and uncertainties a company faces in the course of conducting its daily business activities, procedures, and systems./nOperational risk is heavily dependent on the human factor: mistakes or failures due to actions or decisions made by a company's employees./nCompanies assess operational risk by identifying key risk indicators (KRIs) and collecting data against these metrics./nA type of business risk, operational risk is distinct from systematic risk and financial risk./nCompanies can manage operational risk by anticipating risks before they arise, perform cost/benefit analysis, avoid unnecessary risk, and delegate strategic planning to upper management.

Term: Operating Target: What It is, How It Works
Definition: The operating target is an intermediate goal that guides the day-to-day actions of the central bank./nAn operating target works like the speedometer on a car, giving the central bank feedback on the success of the monetary fuel that it has added to feed the economy./nThe U.S. Federal Reserve uses the federal funds' interest rate as its primary operating target for U.S. monetary policy.

Term: Oprah Effect: What It Is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: The Oprah Effect was a boost in sales for companies and individuals featured by Oprah Winfrey, queen of daytime talk shows, on her TV program./nSeveral well-known individuals with talk shows, such as Dr. Phil and health-expert Dr. Oz, received an initial boost to their careers from Oprah./nThe Oprah Effect was considered powerful because of its authenticity.

Term: Operations Management: Understanding and Using It
Definition: Operations management (OM) is the administration of business practices to create the highest level of efficiency possible within an organization./nOperations management is concerned with converting materials and labor into goods and services as efficiently as possible./nCorporate operations management professionals try to balance costs with revenue to maximize net operating profit.

Term: Opportunity Cost: Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: Opportunity cost is the forgone benefit that would have been derived from an option other than the one that was chosen./nTo properly evaluate opportunity costs, the costs and benefits of every option available must be considered and weighed against the others./nConsidering potential opportunity costs can guide individuals and organizations to more profitable decision making./nOpportunity cost is a strictly internal measure used for strategic planning; it is not included in accounting profit or reflected in external financial reporting./nExamples of opportunity cost considerations include investing in a new manufacturing plant in Los Angeles as opposed to Mexico City, deciding to upgrade company equipment or hire additional workers, or buying stock A vs. stock B.

Term: Optimal Capital Structure Definition: Meaning, Factors, and Limitations
Definition: An optimal capital structure is the best mix of debt and equity financing that maximizes a company’s market value while minimizing its cost of capital./nMinimizing the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) is one way to optimize for the lowest cost mix of financing./nAccording to some economists, in the absence of taxes, bankruptcy costs, agency costs, and asymmetric information, in an efficient market, the value of a firm is unaffected by its capital structure.

Term: Optimal Currency Area (OCA) Definition & Criteria
Definition: An optimal currency area (OCA) is the geopolitical area over which a single, unified currency will provide the best balance of economies of scale to a currency and effectiveness of macroeconomic policy to promote growth and stability./nEconomist Robert Mundell first outlined criteria for an OCA, which are based on the degree of integration and similarity between economies./nThe euro is an example of an application of an OCA, though events such as the Greek debt crisis have put this to the test.

Term: Optimization: Overview and Examples in Technical Analysis
Definition: Optimization is the process of improving a portfolio, algorithm or trading system to reduce costs or increase efficiency./nPortfolios can be optimized by reducing risks, increasing expected returns, or changing the frequency of rebalancing./nBecause markets and laws are constantly changing, optimization is a constant and ongoing process./nTrading algorithms need constant optimization, both to adjust for changing market conditions and to reduce the risk of programming errors./nBecause optimizing one factor may require tradeoffs in other factors, there is a danger of over-optimization.

Term: Option Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (Option ARM) Overview
Definition: An option ARM is a variation on an adjustable rate mortgage that allows the borrower to select from different payment options each month./nThese options are typically a 30-year, fully amortizing payment; a 15-year, fully amortizing payment; an interest-only payment, or a so-called minimum payment which did not cover the monthly interest./nIn order to avoid substantially increasing the amount of debt owed, the borrower must carefully choose the repayment structure they want to adopt with an option ARM.

Term: What Is Option-Adjusted Spread (OAS)? Definition and Example
Definition: The option-adjusted spread (OAS) measures the difference in yield between a bond with an embedded option, such as an MBS or callables, with the yield on Treasuries./nEmbedded options are provisions included with some fixed-income securities that allow the investor or the issuer to do specific actions, such as calling back the issue./nUsing historical data and volatility modeling, OAS considers how a bond's embedded option can change the future cash flows and thus the overall value of the bond.

Term: Optimum Currency Area (OCA) Theory: Examples in Economics
Definition: Optimum currency area (OCA) theory states that regions that are not bounded by national borders and share certain traits should share a common currency./nOCA theory was developed in 1961 by Canadian economist Robert Mundell based on earlier work by Abba Lerner./nOCA theory posits that implementing currencies by geographic and geopolitical region, instead of by country, leads to greater economic efficiency./nAn OCA must meet four criteria to qualify, and some economists suggest a fifth.

Term: Options Contract: What It Is, How It Works, Types of Contracts
Definition: An options contract is an agreement between two parties to facilitate a potential transaction involving an asset at a preset price and date./nCall options can be purchased as a leveraged bet on the appreciation of an asset, while put options are purchased to profit from price declines./nBuying an option offers the right, but not the obligation, to purchase or sell the underlying asset./nFor stock options, a single contract covers 100 shares of the underlying stock.

Term: Option Chain: What It Is and How To Read and Analyze It
Definition: An options chain is a table displaying options quotes for a particular underlying security./nThe options chain matrix is updated in real-time showing the last price, trading volume, and best bid and offer for the calls and puts of an options series, typically segmented by expiration date./nAn option's strike price is also listed, which is the stock price at which the investor buys the stock if the option is exercised.

Term: Option Cycle: Definition, How It Works, Examples
Definition: An option cycle is the set of months on which a company's quarterly options expire./nOne of three cycle assignments is assigned to most options series at the time the stock is listed./nOption volume and open interest are typically greater on those options that expire on the dates of the assigned option cycle.

Term: Option Class: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: An option class is comprised of all of the same type of option (i.e., either calls or puts) listed on the same underlying security./nAn option class can be broken down into subsets called options series, which are all the calls or puts for an underlying asset that expire in the same month./nAn option chain instead includes both all the calls and all the puts listed on some security./nHow large the option class is depends on the volume of the underlying asset and the market conditions of both the underlying and the underlying's options market.

Term: Options Disclosure Document (ODD): Meaning, Requirements
Definition: The Options Clearing Corporation is responsible for issuing the options disclosure document and its supplements./nIn 1994, the OCC distributed the first options disclosure document, which provides investors with important educational information regarding options trading./nThe booklet covers topics important to options investors such as options definitions, index options, debt options, foreign currency options, and risks of options trading./nInvestors can obtain copies of the booklet and supplements through their broker or online at theOCC's website.

Term: Option Margin: Definition, Requirements, How To Calculate
Definition: Options margins are the cash or security that traders must submit to the broker as collateral before writing or selling options./nOption margins are typically based on the Federal Reserve's Regulation T and vary based on option.

Term: Option Pool: Definition, Purpose, How It Works, and Structure
Definition: An option pool refers to a block of company equity that has been reserved for early investors or employees of a start-up company./nThe option pool is used to attract capital or talent when a company is growing and not yet producing enough revenue or cash flows to be viable without that investment or employment./nOption pools can range from 15–25% of initial equity, but the availability of an option pool will tend to dilute the shareholdings of founders and early investors or employees over time.

Term: Option Premium: Definition, Factors Affecting Pricing, and Example
Definition: The premium on an option is its price in the market./nOption premium will consist of extrinsic, or time value for out-of-the-money contracts and both intrinsic and extrinsic value for in-the-money options./nAn option's premium will generally be greater given more time to expiration or greater implied volatility.

Term: Option Pricing Theory: Definition, History, Models, and Goals
Definition: Option pricing theory is a probabilistic approach to assigning a value to an options contract./nThe primary goal of option pricing theory is to calculate the probability that an option will be exercised, or be in-the-money (ITM), at expiration./nIncreasing an option's maturity or implied volatility will increase the price of the option, holding all else constant./nSome commonly used models to price options include the Black-Scholes model, binomial tree, and Monte-Carlo simulation method.

Term: Option Series: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: An option series refers to a grouping of options on a given underlying security with the same specified strike price and the same expiration month./nSince option series contain calls or puts on the same security at the same price that expire at the same time, their prices should be extremely similar./nAn investor will find multiple option series listings within an option class, which refers to the option’s designation as either a call or a put./nOption series offer many ways for traders to make money.

Term: Optionable Stock: What It Is, How It Works, Requirements
Definition: An optionable stock is one that has listed options on it available to trade./nIn order for a stock to be optionable, it must meet the minimum criteria established by exchanges./nCurrently, there are almost 6,000 companies with optionable stocks, as well as several hundred more exchange-traded funds (ETFs) with listed options./nIf a stock is not optionable, it is more difficult to hedge positions in that stock, which makes it harder to mitigate the risks involved.

Term: Options Backdating
Definition: Options backdating is a practice whereby a firm issuing stock options to employees uses an earlier date than the actual issue date in order to fix a lower exercise price, making the options more valuable./nBackdating options has been considered to be an unethical or illegal practice, and is now subject to legal and regulatory enforcement since the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002./nOptions backdating has become much more difficult since the introduction of Sarbanes-Oxley as companies are now required to report option grants to the SEC within two business days.

Term: Options Clearing Corporation (OCC): Meaning, Overview, History
Definition: The Options Clearing Corporation (OCC) serves as a central clearinghouse and regulator for listed options traded in the United States under the auspices of the SEC and CFTC./nThe OCC clears exchange-traded transactions in options contracts and interest rate composites./nValue-added solutions provided by the OCC include research services, investor education, customer support, and marketing outreach./nChanges have been made so the OCC could adapt its operations to better address risk after the 2008 financial crisis.

Term: Options Contract: What It Is, How It Works, Types of Contracts
Definition: An options contract is an agreement between two parties to facilitate a potential transaction involving an asset at a preset price and date./nCall options can be purchased as a leveraged bet on the appreciation of an asset, while put options are purchased to profit from price declines./nBuying an option offers the right, but not the obligation, to purchase or sell the underlying asset./nFor stock options, a single contract covers 100 shares of the underlying stock.

Term: Options Industry Council (OIC): What It is, How it Works
Definition: The Options Industry Council (OIC), established in 1992, is a cooperative formed by U.S. options exchanges and the Options Clearing Corporation./nThe OIC educates investors and financial advisers about the benefits and risks of exchange-traded equity options./nOIC offers online classes, in-person seminars, online webcasts, and podcasts along with educational materials, such as DVDs and brochures./nThere are three specialist areas served by the OIC, namely institutional investors, financial advisors, and investors.

Term: Options Price Reporting Authority: What it is and how it Works
Definition: The Options Price Reporting Authority (OPRA) is responsible for aggregating and disseminating price quotations for listed options contracts in the U.S./nOPRA provides data feeds to financial firms, brokers, and traders, displaying the national best bid and offer for an options contract or series./nOptions quotes are presented as tables of data known as options chains.

Term: Options On Futures: Definition, How They Work, and Example
Definition: Options on futures work similarly to options on other securities (such as stocks), but they tend to be cash settled and of European style, meaning no early exercise./nFutures options can be thought of as a 'second derivative' and require the trader to pay attention to detail./nThe key details for options on futures are the contract specifications for both the option contract and the underlying futures contract.

Term: Oral Contract: Definition, Example, How to Prove and Enforce
Definition: An oral contract is a type of contract that is agreed to via spoken communication, but not written down and signed./nOral contracts are legally binding but can be difficult to prove in a court of law./nThe enforceability of oral contracts depends on the jurisdiction as well as the type of deal./nIt is recommended that oral contracts only be used for simple deals whereas written contracts should be used for more complex deals that include a lot of information.

Term: The Oracle of Omaha: How Warren Buffett Built His Fortune
Definition: Billionaire Warren Buffett (who lives and works in Omaha, Nebraska) is known as the Oracle of Omaha, a nickname he earned as one of the world's most successful and closely followed investors./nThe Oracle of Omaha built his fortune as a value investor, buying undervalued stocks with sound fundamentals for a discounted price, then holding them as long-term investments./nBuffett is chair and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, which owns over 60 companies, including GEICO Insurance, Duracell, and See's Candies.

Term: Orange Book: What it is and how it Works
Definition: The Orange Book is a freely accessible list maintained by the FDA describing all pharmaceutical drugs that have been proven both safe and effective./nOnly drugs that have successfully cleared phase 3 clinical trials are added to the list./nThe Orange Book is useful for finding generic drug equivalents, which may often be much lower cost for patients.

Term: Order Audit Trail System (OATS): What it is, Example
Definition: The order audit trail system (OATS) is a computerized regulatory mechanism that maintains detailed records of securities transactions./nOATS requires member firms of FINRA to automatically record and report orders to FINRA./nOATS was established so that orders could be more easily tracked and reviewed if necessary; for instance, in the case of a trading error or suspected market manipulation./nIndividual traders and investors are not required to provide OATS data to FINRA. This is the job of the broker or member firm handling client orders.

Term: What Is an Order Book? Definition, How It Works, and Key Parts
Definition: An order book is an electronic list of buy and sell orders for a security or other instrument organized by price level./nOrder books are used by almost every exchange for various assets like stocks, bonds, currencies, and even cryptocurrencies./nThese lists help improve market transparency as they provide information on price, availability, depth of trade, and who initiates transactions./nThere are three parts to an order book: buy orders, sell orders, and order history.

Term: Order Driven Market: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: In an order-driven market, trades are based on buyers' and sellers' requirements, with their desired bid and ask prices and the number ofsharesthey want to trade put on display./nThis is theopposite of a quote-driven market, in which trades are determined by market makers—dealers and specialists looking to fill orders from their inventory or match them with other orders./nOrder-driven markets provide two basic types of orders: market orders and limit orders./nOrder-driven markets are seen as less liquid, but more transparent than quote-driven markets.

Term: Order Imbalance: Definition, Causes, and Trading Strategies
Definition: Order imbalances exist when there is an excess of buy or sell orders for a specific security./nMost order imbalances are short-lived but can exist for hours and even the entire day./nUsing limit orders rather than market orders can help mitigate some of the problems with buying or selling during order imbalances.

Term: Order Paper: What it is and How it Works
Definition: An order paper is a negotiable instrument that is payable to a specified person or its assignee./nAn order paper specifies the name of the individual to which payment of the instrument can be made./nA bearer instrument is the opposite of an order instrument, as no individual is designated. Anyone holding the bearer instrument can be paid./nThe most common example of an order paper is a personal check./nEndorsing an order instrument turns it into a bearer instrument, which can increase the risk of theft./nTo avoid turning an order instrument into a bearer instrument, a payee can use a special endorsement or a restrictive endorsement.

Term: What an Order Management System (OMS) Does for Finance, Business
Definition: An order management system (OMS) is a software system that facilitates and manages the execution of trade orders./nIn the financial markets, an order must be placed in a trading system to execute a buy or sell order for a security./nBrokers and dealers use an OMS when filling orders for various types of securities and can track the progress of each order throughout the system./nAn effective OMS helps firms with the real-time monitoring of positions and the ability to prevent regulatory violations.

Term: Order Protection Rule
Definition: The Order Protection Rule aims to ensure that investors receive the best price when their order is executed by removing the ability to have orders traded through (executed at a worse price)./nIt mandates stocks must be traded on exchanges that show the best quotes, and requires trading centers to establish and enforce written policies and procedures that ensure this./nThe Order Protection Rule is a provision of the Regulation National Market System (NMS), a set of rules passed by the SEC in 2005, and also goes by the name, "trade-through rule".﻿﻿

Term: Orderly Market: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: An orderly market is any market, such as goods, services, or financial securities, in which supply and demand are reasonably equal./nAn orderly market is said to be in a state of equilibrium./nWhen goods, services, or securities are traded in a fair, reliable, secure, accurate, and efficient way, orderly markets contribute to economic growth.

Term: Ordinary and Necessary Expense: What it is, How it Works
Definition: O≠ are generally the expenses you incur as a cost of owning a business./nCommon ordinary and necessary expenses include business-related software for a computer or rental expenses./nPortions of the home used for business are sometimes tax-deductible.

Term: What Are Ordinary Annuities, and How Do They Work (With Example)?
Definition: An ordinary annuity is a series of regular payments made at the end of each period, such as monthly or quarterly./nIn an annuity due, by contrast, payments are made at the beginning of each period./nConsistent quarterly stock dividends are one example of an ordinary annuity; monthly rent is an example of an annuity due.

Term: Ordinary Income: What It Is and How It's Taxed
Definition: Ordinary income is any income taxable at marginal rates./nExamples of ordinary income include salaries, tips, bonuses, commissions, rents, royalties, short-term capital gains, unqualified dividends, and interest income./nFor individuals, ordinary income usually consists of the pretax salaries and wages they have earned./nIn a corporate setting, ordinary income comes from regular day-to-day business operations, excluding income gained from selling capital assets.

Term: Ordinary Dividends: Meaning, Overview, Examples
Definition: Ordinary, or non-qualified, dividends are paid by corporations to shareholders of record./nDividends are considered ordinary by default unless they meet special requirements put in place by the IRS./nOrdinary dividends are taxed as ordinary income, while qualified dividends are taxed at the lower capital gains rate.

Term: Ordinary Loss Tax Deduction: Meaning and FAQs
Definition: An ordinary loss is realized by a taxpayer when expenses exceed revenues in normal business operations./nOrdinary losses are separate from capital losses./nAn ordinary loss is fully deductible to offset income thereby reducing the tax owed by a taxpayer./nCapital losses occur when capital assets are sold for less than their cost./nTaxpayers are allowed to deduct up to a certain limit for capital losses, whereas there is no limit for ordinary losses.

Term: Organic Growth: What It Is, and Why It Matters to Investors
Definition: Organic growth refers to the growth of a business through internal processes, relying on its own resources./nStrategies for organic growth include optimization of processes, reallocation of resources, and new product offerings./nMeasuring organic growth is done by comparing revenues year over year and comparable store sales./nOrganic growth stands in contrast to inorganic growth, which is external growth, such as through mergers and acquisitions.

Term: Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development (OECD)
Definition: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) is a group of 37 member countries that discuss and develop economic and social policy./nMembers of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) are typically democratic countries that support free-market economies./nThe stated goal of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) is to shape policies that foster prosperity, equality, opportunity and well-being for all.﻿﻿/nThe Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) was established on Dec. 14, 1960, by 18 European nations, plus the United States and Canada.﻿﻿/nThe organization is headquartered in the Chateau de la Muette in Paris, France.﻿﻿

Term: Organic Sales: Overview, Benefits, Examples
Definition: Organic sales are revenues generated from within a company that are a direct result of the firm's existing operations./nOrganic sales do not include sales revenue growth as a result of an acquisition of another company within the last year./nOrganic sales figures are important since they show sales revenue growth from a company's core operations.

Term: Ordinary Shares: Definition, How They Work, Advantages
Definition: Ordinary shares of stock represent proportional ownership of a company./nThese shares come with voting rights equaling one vote per share./nOwners of ordinary shares may or may not receive dividends based on a company’s performance./nPreferred shares come with guaranteed dividends at a set percentage.

Term: Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS): Overview
Definition: The Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States is an economic union comprising 11 member states in the Eastern Caribbean./nSeven states are protocol members, meaning they enjoy the benefits of free movement of people, capital, and goods, while four are associate members./nEight members share a currency, the Eastern Caribbean Dollar.

Term: Organic Reserve Replacement
Definition: Organic reserve replacement is the supply of oil reserves that an oil company acquires from exploration and production, and not by purchasing aproven reserve./nThe organic reserve replacement is a relevant metric to those needing to evaluate an oil company./nInvestors looking at the financial strength of oil and gas companies should consider a company's organic replacement when evaluating its reserve-replacement ratio.

Term: Organizational Structure for Companies With Examples and Benefits
Definition: An organizational structure outlines how certain activities are directed to achieve the goals of an organization./nSuccessful organizational structures define each employee's job and how it fits within the overall system./nA centralized structure has a defined chain of command, while decentralized structures give almost every employee receiving a high level of personal agency./nTypes of organizational structures include functional, divisional, flatarchy, and matrix structures./nSenior leaders should consider a variety of factors before deciding which type of organization is best for their business, including the business goals, industry, and culture of the company.

Term: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC)
Definition: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is a cartel consisting of 13 of the world’s major oil-exporting nations./nOPEC aims to regulate the supply of oil in order to set the price on the world market./nThe arrival of fracking technology for natural gas in the U.S. has reduced OPEC’s ability to control the world market./nThe organization was established in 1960 by its founding members Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, and Venezuela./nWhile OPEC does ensure that there is a steady supply of oil in the global market, it has come under fire for holding considerable power in the industry, which allows it to keep prices as high as possible.

Term: What Is Organizational Behavior (OB), and Why Is It Important?
Definition: Organizational behavior is the study of how people interact in group settings./nThis field of study includes areas of research dedicated to improving job performance, increasing job satisfaction, promoting innovation, and encouraging leadership./nThe Hawthorne Effect, which describes the way test subjects' behavior may change when they know they are being observed, is the best-known study of organizational behavior./nOrganizational behavior is a foundation of corporate human resources, encompassing elements such as employee retention, engagement, training, and culture./nOrganizational behavior is a subset of organizational theory which studies a more holistic way of structuring a company and managing its resources.

Term: Organizational Chart Types, Meaning, and How It Works
Definition: An organizational chart graphically represents an organization's structure, highlighting the different jobs, departments, and responsibilities that connect the company's employees to each other and to the management team./nOrganizational charts can be broad-based, depicting the overall company, or can be department- or unit-specific, focusing on one spoke on the wheel./nMost org charts are structured by using the "hierarchical" model, which shows management or other high-ranking officials on top, and lower-level employees beneath them./nOther types of charts include the flat org chart, the matrix chart, and the divisional org chart.

Term: Organization Economics: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Organizational economics is used to study transactions within individual firms and determine management approaches to managing resources./nIt can involve a wide variety of ideas and theories including agency theory, transaction cost economics, and property rights theory./nInsights from organizational economics provide a method for causal analysis of critical motivations and decisions in an organization.

Term: Organized Labor - Defining Unions and Collective Bargaining
Definition: Organized labor is a strategy where workers join unions to engage in collective bargaining with their employers./nOrganized labor has been credited with higher wages, fewer hours, and improved benefits for workers in many industries./nIn most countries, union formation is regulated by a government agency, such as the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) in the United States./nIn most countries, workers seeking to unionize must collect a set number of signatures before holding a union election in their workplace./nMany companies try to discourage workers from joining unions because they will increase the cost of labor.

Term: Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM): Definition and Examples
Definition: An OEM provides components for the finished products of another company, known as a value-added reseller (VAR)./nOEMs usually focus on business-to-business sales, while VARs sell to the public or other end users./nOEM parts often compete with generic, aftermarket, replacement parts./nAn OEM differs from an original design manufacturer (ODM), a company that customizes its products for resale.

Term: Original Face: What It is, How It Works, Benefits
Definition: Original face is the total outstanding balance of a mortgage-backed security (MBS) at the time it is issued./nOver time, the outstanding balance declines as the underlying loans are repaid, resulting in a lower current value versus the original face value./nMortgage-backed securities with the same issue date and original face can have different current values due to the varying pace of loan repayments.

Term: Original Issue Discount (OID): Formula, Uses, and Examples
Definition: The original issue discount (OID) is the difference between the original face value amount and the discounted price paid for a bond./nOID bonds have the potential for gains since investors can buy the bonds for a lower price than their face value./nOID bonds sold at a discount could indicate an issuer is facing financial difficulty and default is possible.

Term: Origination: Definition in Finance, Loan Process, and Requirements
Definition: The origination process often involves a number of steps and is overseen by the FDIC./nPre-qualification is the first step of the origination process and is when a loan officer obtains all basic data and information relating to income and the property in question./nAll paperwork and documentation are then run through an automatic underwriting program for loan approval.

Term: Origination Fee: Definition, Average Cost, and Ways to Save
Definition: An origination fee is typically 0.5% to 1% of the loan amount and is charged by a lender as compensation for processing a loan application./nOrigination fees are sometimes negotiable, but reducing them or avoiding them usually means paying a higher interest rate over the life of the loan./nThese fees are typically set in advance of the loan execution, and they should not come as a surprise at the time of closing.

Term: Origination Points: Meaning, Examples in Mortgages
Definition: There are two types of points in a mortgage: discount and origination./nOrigination points are fees paid for the evaluation, processing, and approval of mortgage loans./nThe more discount points paid, the lower the interest rate on the mortgage./nOne point is typically equal to 1% of the mortgage amount./nUnlike some other mortgage fees, origination points are not tax-deductible./nIt can pay to research and ask questions because the number of origination points can vary among different lenders.

Term: Orphan Drug Credit: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: The Orphan Drug Act gives drug companies incentives to develop treatments for rare diseases, including a 25% tax credit on qualified clinical trials./nOther incentives include a rebate on application fees and a seven-year window of drug exclusivity./nThe act was adopted in 1983 and has led to approvals for more than 780 products to treat more than 250 rare diseases./nAbout half of the approved treatments are in the field of oncology (the treatment of cancer).﻿﻿

Term: Orphan Block: What it is, How it Works, FAQ
Definition: An orphan block is a block that has been solved within the blockchain network but was not accepted by the network./nThere can be two miners who solve valid blocks simultaneously. The network uses both blocks until one chain has more verified blocks. Then, the blocks in the shorter chain are orphaned./nOrphan blocks are a regular occurrence in a distributed blockchain such as Bitcoin.

Term: Oscillator: What They Are and How They Work
Definition: Oscillators are momentum indicators used in technical analysis, whose fluctuations are bounded by some upper and lower band./nWhen oscillator values approach these bands, they provide overbought or oversold signals to traders./nOscillators are often combined with moving average indicators to signal trend breakouts or reversals.

Term: Oscillator of a Moving Average (OSMA): What it is, How it Works
Definition: The OsMA is a combination of an oscillator and a moving average of that oscillator. It measures the distance between these two values./nAny oscillator and any moving average (MA) of it can be used to create an OsMA./nMAs (of an oscillator) move slower than the oscillator. Therefore, an increasing OsMA is bullish as prices are rising and vice-versa./nWhen the OsMA goes from negative to positive that may indicate an uptrend is starting.; When the OsMA goes from positive to negative that may indicate a downtrend is starting./nGenerally, when the OsMA is positive it helps confirm a price uptrend, and when negative helps confirm a downtrend in price.

Term: Oslo Stock Exchange (OSL): Meaning, History, Associated Markets
Definition: The Oslo Stock Exchange is the major stock market in Norway and the country's only regulated securities exchange./nThe exchange was established in 1819./nThe OSL was privatized in 2001 but was acquired by Euronext in 2019./nAlthough the majority of companies are Norwegian, listing by foreign companies is encouraged by the exchange./nTrading is fully electronic on the Oslo Stock Exchange.

Term: OTC Markets Group: What it is, Structure, FAQs
Definition: OTC Markets Group Inc. is the largest U.S. marketplace for OTC securities with over 11,500 securities listed as of 2022./nOTC Markets Group Inc. provides services in three core areas, namely trading services, market data, and corporate services./nOTC securities are listed in three tiers: OTCQX, which has the most stringent listing requirements, the OTCQB, which is the venture market, and the Pink Open Market, which includes companies in financial distress or bankruptcy./nOf the three tiers, the Pink Open Market is the largest in terms of the number of companies and trade volume./nThe handling of most OTC securities trading in the U.S. is on the company’s OTC Link platform, an alternative trading system registered with the SEC.

Term: OTC Options: Difference From Standard Options, Risks
Definition: OTC options are exotic options that trade in the over-the-counter market rather than on a formal exchange like exchange traded option contracts./nOTC options are the result of a private transaction between the buyer and the seller./nOTC option strike prices and expiration dates are not standardized, which allows participants to define their own terms, and there is no secondary market.

Term: OTC Pink: Definition, Company Types, Investment Risks
Definition: OTC Pink, also known as the "pink sheets," is the most speculative of OTC Markets Group's platforms./nCompanies on OTC Pink are not held to particular disclosure requirements or high financial standards seen with the stocks listed on major exchanges./nDue to the wide variety of companies listed on OTC Pink, including dark companies, delinquent companies, and worse, only sophisticated investors with a high risk tolerance should consider it./nThe terms "Pink Sheets" or "OTC Pink" are considered outdated in the context of today's financial markets.

Term: What Is OTCQX? Definition, Criteria for Stocks, and Other Tiers
Definition: The OTCQX is the highest quality tier of OTC markets and offers trading in companies that are not listed on traditional exchanges./nCompanies listed on the OTCQX markets have to follow certain rules and criteria and are subject to SEC regulation. For example, they have to adhere to governance transparency and must not be penny stocks./nThe two lower-tier venues for OTC trading in the U.S. are the OTCQB (formerly the OTCBB) and the Pink Sheets.

Term: Other Comprehensive Basis of Accounting (OCBOA) Overview
Definition: Generally acceptedaccounting principles(GAAP) is a method of creating financial statements based on principles issued by theFinancial Accounting Standards Board(FASB); public U.S. companies must follow GAAP./nOther Comprehensive Basis of Accounting (OCBOA) is a non-GAAP accounting protocol used to generate financial statements./nOCBAOA examples include the income tax basis of accounting, the cash basis of accounting, and the modified cash basis of accounting./nStatements prepared under OCBOA are easier to analyze than those created under GAAP; they also often cost less to prepare./nOCBOA doesn't require a statement of cash flows, versus GAAP, and is perceived as having disclosures that are insufficient.

Term: OTCQB (The Venture Market): Definition in Stocks and Benefits
Definition: The OTCQB is the mid-tier OTC equity market, which lists primarily early-stage and developing companies in the U.S. and international markets./nOTCQB companies must meet certain minimum reporting standards, pass a bid test, and undergo annual verification./nThe other OTC tiers are the highest quality OTCQX, and the most speculative Pink Sheets.

Term: Other Current Assets (OCA) Definition and Examples of Use
Definition: Other current assets are liquid assets that are characterized as uncommon or insignificant./nThey are listed on the balance sheet alongside other assets and are convertible into cash within one year./nBecause these assets are recorded rarely, or are insignificant, the net balance in the OCA account is typically quite small.

Term: Other Current Liabilities: Definition, Examples, Accounting For
Definition: The term, other current liabilities is a line item on the balance sheet./nThe word "other" means that these current liabilities are not significant enough to occupy their own line./nThey are grouped together for the sake of simplicity and readability.

Term: Other Long-Term Liabilities: Meaning, Types, Example
Definition: Other long-term liabilities are debts due beyond one year that are not deemed significant enough to warrant individual identification on a company's balance sheet./nOther long-term liabilities are lumped together on the balance sheet rather than broken down one by one and given an individual figure./nSome companies may disclose the composition of these liabilities in the footnotes to their financial statements if they believe they are material.

Term: Other Post-Employment Benefits (OPEB): Meaning, Types, and FAQs
Definition: Other post-employment benefits (OPEBs) are benefits, other than pension distributions, that some employers provide to retirees./nOPEBs can include paid health insurance, life insurance, and deferred compensation./nOPEBS are not guaranteed unless plan documents specifically state that the employer cannot change or discontinue them.

Term: Other Post-Retirement Benefits: Meaning, Benefits, Cost
Definition: Other post-retirement benefits include benefits that employees are paid when they retire that are not pension distributions./nEmployees often share the cost of these benefits through co-payments./nOther post-retirement benefits might include dental, legal services, and tuition credit.

Term: Out-of-Pocket Expenses: Definition, How They Work, and Examples
Definition: An out-of-pocket expense is a payment you make with your own money that may be reimbursed later by an employer./nWork-related out-of-pocket expenses are usually reimbursed by the employer./nIn health insurance, out-of-pocket expenses are your share of the medical costs you incur and may include deductibles, copays, and coinsurance./nHealth insurance plans have legally-mandated out-of-pocket maximums that cap the total amount you must pay each year for covered healthcare expenses./nSome out-of-pocket expenses can be deducted from your income taxes. However, those expenses must add up to a substantial percentage of income if they are to exceed the currentstandard deduction.

Term: What Is an Out-of-Pocket Maximum? Definition and How It Works
Definition: An out-of-pocket maximum, also referred to as an out-of-pocket limit, is the most a health insurance policyholder will pay each year for covered healthcare expenses./nWhen this limit is reached, your health plan will cover 100% of your qualified expenses./nYou can generally choose from a range of plans with different out-of-pocket limits. However, plans with lower out-of-pocket maximums normally have higher premiums, and those with higher out-of-pocket maximums have lower premiums./nSome individuals (or families) may qualify for lower out-of-pocket maximums if they earn under certain income thresholds or meet other requirements.

Term: Out of the Money: Option Basics and Examples
Definition: Out of the money is also known as OTM, meaning an option has no intrinsic value, only extrinsic value./nA call option is OTM if the underlying price is trading below the strike price of the call. A put option is OTM if the underlying's price is above the put's strike price./nAn option can also be in the money or at the money./nOTM options are less expensive than ITM or ATM options. This is because ITM options have intrinsic value, and ATM options are very close to having intrinsic value.

Term: Outlay Cost: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Outlay costs are any costs incurred to acquire an asset or execute a strategy, but can also be costs paid to vendors for goods or services./nFor corporations, outlay costs for new projects include start-up, production, and asset acquisition costs./nOutlay costs do not include foregone profits or benefits—also known as opportunity costs. Total costs include both the outlay cost and opportunity cost./nOutlay costs reduce earnings immediately with cash accounting, while with accrual accounting they are split across all periods the expense applies and matched to related revenues.

Term: Outperform: Definition and Examples in Finance and Investing
Definition: Outperform is often used as an analyst rating./nOn a scale of 1 (best) and 5 (worst), outperform is likely to be a 2./nAnother use of the term is simply as a comparison of performance between two securities: the better of the two outperforms the other./nCompanies typically outperform their peers when they manage their production and marketing efforts more efficiently.

Term: Outplacement: What it is, How it Works, Benefits
Definition: Outplacement is a service that helps a terminated employee with the transition to a new job, which can include resume writing, job search, and job coaching./nOutplacement can have benefits and costs for both employers and employees, as a part of the total compensation cost of a company's labor force./nOutplacement can reduce stress and turmoil for transitioning employees and mitigate risk for the employer.

Term: Output Gap: What It Means, Pros & Cons of Using It, Example
Definition: An output gap is a difference between an economy's actual output and its maximum potential output expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product./nThe output gap is a comparison between actual GDP (output) and potential GDP (maximum-efficiency output)./nA positive or negative output gap is an unfavorable indicator of an economy's efficiency./nPolicymakers often use the output gap to determine inflationary pressure so they can make policy decisions./nAlthough it's an important economic indicator, the output gap isn't always reliable because the potential output must be estimated.

Term: Outright Forward: What it is, How it Works
Definition: An outright forward, or currency forward, is a currency contract that locks in the exchange rate and a delivery date beyond the spot value date./nIt is the simplest type of foreign exchange forward contract and protects an investor, importer or exporter from exchange rate fluctuations./nThe price of an outright forward is derived from the spot rate plus or minus the forward points calculated from the interest rate differential.

Term: Outright Futures Position: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: An outright futures position is a single directional bet position on a futures contract and is not part of a larger or more complex strategy./nAn outright position exposes the trader to greater risk than a hedged position, although the outright position has theoretically greater profit potential./nIf a hedge or offsetting position is added to an outright position, then it is no longer an outright position, but rather a hedged or partially-hedged position.

Term: Outright Option: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: An outright option is one that is purchased individually and is not part of a multiple-leg options trade./nAn outright option, which can include calls and puts, can refer to any basic option purchased on a single underlying security./nOutright options trade on an exchange similar to security assets, like stocks.

Term: Outside Days: Meaning, Overview, Example
Definition: An outside day is a daily price action that has a higher high and a lower low than the prior price bar./nAn outside day also has an open and close that both fall outside the prior open and close./nWhen the price bars move in opposite directions, it's called an outside reversal./nContext is important when trading outside days: This includes volume, overall trend direction, the direction of the price bars within the outside day pattern, and the direction of the price bar following the pattern.

Term: Outside Sales: What They are, How They Work
Definition: Outside sales consists of sales professionals that are physically active in the field, outside of the office, to bring in business for a company./nThe professional characteristics of an outside sales force does not include those of a typical office job with specific working hours or an office setting./nOutside sales professionals are often on the road, meeting with clients, entertaining potential customers, and constantly available for when a client needs assistance./nThe costs of an outside sales professional include travel, such as car rentals or plane tickets, accommodation in hotels, and a budget for entertainment expenses./nBecause of the nature of the job, an outside sales workforce is more costly than an inside sales workforce; however, an outside sales workforce also brings in more business./nGiven advancements in technology, such as video conferencing, inside sales and outside sales jobs are becoming more of a hybrid nature.

Term: Outside Reversal: Meaning in Technical Analysis
Definition: Outside reversal is a two-day price pattern that implies a reversal if it runs counter to the existing trend./nThe first day is typically a small range day and the second is a larger range day./nThis pattern is known as an engulfing pattern in candlestick studies.

Term: Outsourcing: How It Works in Business, With Examples
Definition: Companies use outsourcing to cut labor costs, including salaries for their personnel, overhead, equipment, and technology./nOutsourcing is also used by companies to dial down and focus on the core aspects of the business, spinning off the less critical operations to outside organizations./nOn the downside, communication between the company and outside providers can be hard, and security threats can amp up when multiple parties can access sensitive data./nSome companies will outsource as a way to move things around on the balance sheet./nOutsourcing employees, such as with 1099 contract workers, can benefit the company when it comes to paying taxes.

Term: Outstanding Check: Definition, Risks, and Ways to Avoid
Definition: An outstanding check is a financial instrument that has not yet been deposited or cashed by the recipient./nAn outstanding check is still a liability for the payor who issued the check./nChecks that remain outstanding for long periods of time run the risk of becoming void./nBe mindful of outstanding checks you've written before spending down your bank account./nOutstanding checks have the added benefit ofcash float, meaning the payor holds onto cash for longer or has extra time to save up enough cash to make payment.

Term: Outward Arbitrage
Definition: Outward arbitrage is a type of arbitrage in which multinational, American-based banks engage to take advantage of interest rate differences between the U.S. and other countries./nOutward arbitrage occurs when interest rates are lower in the United States than abroad, so banks borrow in the United States at a low rate, then lend abroad at a higher rate, profiting from the difference./nInward arbitrage is the opposite, and occurs when domestic rates are higher than those abroad./nOutward arbitrage was a phrase coined in the middle of the twentieth century, because of strong demand for savings accounts abroad that were denominated in U.S. dollars./nArbitrage occurs when there are minor fluctuations or discrepancies regarding interest rates.

Term: Outward Direct Investment: Meaning, Overview, History
