Definition: A progressive tax imposes a higher tax rate on higher taxable incomes than lower ones./nA regressive tax takes a larger percentage of income from low-income individuals than from those with high income./nA sales tax is an example of a regressive tax./nA flat tax is a single income tax rate that applies to all taxable income, no matter how much or how little./nThe U.S. Social Security payroll tax is considered a flat tax (with an income cap).

Term: Project Finance: Definition, How It Works, and Types of Loans
Definition: Project finance involves the public funding of infrastructure and other long-term, capital-intensive projects./nProject financing often utilizes a non-recourse or limited recourse financial structure./nA debtor with a non-recourse loan cannot be pursued for any additional payment beyond the seizure of the asset./nProject debt is typically held in a sufficient minority subsidiary that is not consolidated on the balance sheet of the respective shareholders, which makes it an off-balance sheet item.

Term: What Is Project Management and What Are the Types?
Definition: On a very basic level, project management includes the planning, initiation, execution, monitoring, and closing of a project./nMany different types of project management methodologies and techniques exist, including traditional, waterfall, agile, and lean./nProject management is used across industries and is an important part of the success of construction, engineering, and IT companies.

Term: Promissory Estoppel Explained, With Requirements & Example
Definition: Estoppel is a legal principle that keeps people and businesses from, essentially, going back on their word or promise./nPromissory estoppel helps injured parties to recover on promises made that have led to economic loss when not met./nPromissory estoppel helps injured parties recover damages they suffer due to broken promises by another party./nPromissory estoppel has different applications in different jurisdictions, so it is important to consult a lawyer before considering a case.

Term: Projected Benefit Obligation (PBO) Definition & How It Works
Definition: A projected benefit obligation (PBO) is an actuarial measurement of what a company will need at the present time to cover future pension liabilities./nProjected benefit obligation (PBO) assumes that the plan will not terminate in the foreseeable future and is adjusted to reflect expected compensation in the years ahead./nActuaries are responsible for using the projected benefit obligation (PBO) in order to calculate whether or not pension plans are underfunded.

Term: What Is a Promoter? How It Works and Criticism of Promoters
Definition: A promoter is an individual or organization that helps raise money for some investment activity./nPromoters often tout penny stocks, an area where false promises and misrepresentation of the company or its prospects have become commonplace./nPromoters can also be writers who review or write about a company for compensation, which can lead to skewed analyses./nPromoters do not need to be licensed or have any particular qualifications./nStock promoting is not illegal as long as the compensation information is disclosed.

Term: Promissory Note: What It Is, Different Types, and Pros and Cons
Definition: A promissory note is a financial instrument that contains a written and signed promise between two parties to repay a sum of money in exchange for a loan or other financing./nA promissory note typically contains all the terms pertaining to the indebtedness, such as the principal amount, interest rate, maturity date, date and place of issuance, and issuer's signature./nIn terms of their legal enforceability, promissory notes lie somewhere between the informality of an IOU and the rigidity of a loan contract.

Term: Promotion: Definition In Jobs and How To Ask for One
Definition: A promotion can refer tothe advancement of an employee's position, creating awareness around certain product deals, or creating buzz around little-known stocks./nPromotions are applied frequently in the marketing sector./nThe term is used differently in different contexts, the most popular being a job promotion./nIn investments, a promotion creates awareness of little-known stocks in the hope of increasing demand and the price of the stock./nPromotion marketing materials can include t-shirts, postcards, and keychains. These items are often called "swag" in the marketing world.

Term: Proof of Funds (POF): Definition, What Qualifies, and How to Get
Definition: Proof of funds refers to a document that demonstrates the ability of an individual or entity to pay for a specific transaction./nA bank statement, security statement, or custody statement usually qualify as proof of funds./nProof of funds is typically required for a large transaction, such as the purchase of a house./nBasic information such as the bank name and address, bank statement, total balance amounts, and a bank personnel's signature is required on the proof of funds document./nProof of funds and proof of deposit are often both needed when applying for a mortgage.

Term: What Is Proof of Work (PoW) in Blockchain?
Definition: Proof of work (PoW) is a decentralized consensus mechanism that requires network members to expend effort in solving an encryption puzzle./nProof of work is also called mining, in reference to receiving a reward for work done./nProof of work allows for secure peer-to-peer transaction processing without needing a trusted third party./nProof of work at scale requires vast amounts of energy, which only increases as more miners join the network.

Term: What Does Proof-of-Stake (PoS) Mean in Crypto?
Definition: Under proof-of-stake (POS), validators are chosen based on the number of staked coins they have./nProof-of-stake (POS) was created as an alternative to proof-of-work (POW), the original consensus mechanism used to validate transactions and open new blocks./nWhile PoW mechanisms require miners to solve cryptographic puzzles, PoS mechanisms require validators to hold and stake tokens for the privilege of earning transaction fees./nProof-of-stake (POS) is seen as less risky regarding the potential for an attack on the network, as it structures compensation in a way that makes an attack less advantageous./nThe next block writer on the blockchain is selected at random, with higher odds being assigned to nodes with larger stake positions.

Term: What Is Property? Definition, Types, Valuation, and Taxation
Definition: Property is any item that a person or a business has legal title over./nProperty can be tangible items, such as houses, cars, or appliances, or it can refer to intangible items that carry the promise of future worth, such as stock and bond certificates./nIntellectual property refers to ideas such as logo designs and patents./nProperty owners may also have liabilities, which is the case if a business owner is on the hook for medical expenses resulting from a customer incurring an injury on his company's grounds./nThe most common types of property are real, private, government-owned, and personal property.

Term: Property Management: Definition, Roles, Types, and Duties
Definition: Property management is the oversight of real estate by a third party./nProperty managers can manage various types of property: residential, commercial, industrial, and property for special purposes./nProperty managers are generally responsible for the day-to-day operations of the real estate, from screening tenants to arranging for repairs and maintenance./nOwners pay property managers a fee or a percentage of the rent generated by the property./nEvery state has its own laws regulating the activities of property managers.

Term: Property, Plant, and Equipment (PP&E) Definition in Accounting
Definition: Property, plant, and equipment (PP&E) are long-term assets vital to business operations and the long-term financial health of a company./nEquipment, machinery, buildings, and vehicles are all types of PP&E assets./n(PP&E) are also called fixed or tangible assets, meaning they are physical items that a company cannot easily liquidate./nPurchases of PP&E are a signal that management has faith in the long-term outlook and profitability of its company./nInvestment analysts and accountants use the PP&E of a company to determine if it is on a sound financial footing and utilizing funds in the most efficient and effective manner.

Term: What Are Property Rights and Why Do They Matter?
Definition: Property rights give the owner or right holder the ability to do with the property as they choose./nThese rights define the theoretical and legal ownership of resources./nProperty can be owned by individuals, businesses, and governments./nThese rights define the benefits associated with ownership of the property.

Term: Property Tax: Definition, What It's Used for, and How It's Calculated
Definition: Property tax is based on the assessed value of the property, which can be real estate or tangible personal possessions./nProperty tax revenue is the primary source of funding for local services in the U.S./nProperty tax rates vary widely in cities and towns throughout the U.S.

Term: Property Tax Deduction: Definition, How It Works and How to Claim
Definition: State and local governments assess property taxes annually, based on the value of a property./nA property owner can claim a tax deduction on some or all of the taxes paid on that property, provided it is for personal use and the owner itemizes deductions on the federal tax return./nTaxes paid on rental or commercial property—and on property not owned by the taxpayer—can not be deducted./nStarting in 2018, the deduction for state and local taxes, including property taxes, was capped at a total of $10,000 ($5,000 if married filing separately).

Term: Proprietary Trading: What It Is, How It Works, Benefits
Definition: Proprietary trading refers to a financial institution using its own capital, rather than client funds, to conduct financial transactions./nProprietary traders may execute an assortment of market strategies that include index arbitrage, statistical arbitrage, merger arbitrage, fundamental analysis, volatility arbitrage, technical analysis, and/or global macro trading./nMarket analysts understand that large financial institutions purposely obfuscate details on proprietary vs. non-proprietary trading operations in order to obscure activities promoting corporate self-interest.

Term: Proportional Tax: What It Is and How It Works
Definition: A proportional tax, or flat tax, assesses the same tax rate on everyone regardless of income or wealth./nProportional taxation is intended to create greater equality between marginal tax rates and average tax rates./nProponents of proportional taxes argue they encourage people to spend more and work more because there is no tax penalty for higher earnings.

Term: Proration: What it Means, How it Works, Examples
Definition: Proration refers to actions when a company splits its original cash and equity offer to accommodate investor choices./nIt occurs when available cash or shares are not sufficient to satisfy the offers that shareholders tender during a certain corporate action./nExamples of instances in which proration can occur are mergers and acquisitions, stock splits, and special dividends./nShareholders may prefer cash over equity due to differences in taxes, interest rates, and growth opportunities./nProration is not the same as pro-rata, which is a proportional allocation of something like a payment or expense.

Term: Prospect Theory: What It Is and How It Works, With Examples
Definition: The prospect theory says that investors value gains and losses differently, placing more weight on perceived gains versus perceived losses./nAn investor presented with a choice, both equal, will choose the one presented in terms of potential gains./nProspect theory is also known as the loss-aversion theory./nThe prospect theory is part of behavioral economics, suggesting investors choose perceived gains because losses cause a greater emotional impact./nThe certainty effect says individuals prefer certain outcomes over probable ones, while the isolation effect says individuals cancel out similar information when making a decision.

Term: Protective Put: What It Is, How It Works, and Examples
Definition: A protective put is a risk-management strategy using options contracts that investors employ to guard against a loss in a stock or other asset./nFor the cost of the premium, protective puts act as an insurance policy by providing downside protection from an asset's price declines./nProtective puts offer unlimited potential for gains since the put buyer also owns shares of the underlying asset./nWhen a protective put covers the entire long position of the underlying, it is called a married put.

Term: What Is a Prospectus? Example, Uses, and How to Read It
Definition: The Securities and Exchange Commission requires that security issuers file a prospectus when offering investment securities to the public./nThe prospectus provides details about the investment/security and the offering./nA mutual fund prospectus contains details on investment objectives, strategies, performance, distribution policy, fees, and fund management./nThe risks of the investment are typically disclosed early in the prospectus and then explained in more detail later in the document.

Term: Protectionism: Examples and Types of Trade Protections
Definition: Protectionist policies place specific restrictions on international trade for the benefit of a domestic economy./nProtectionist policies typically seek to improve economic activity but may also be the result of safety or quality concerns./nThe value of protectionism is a subject of debate among economists and policymakers./nTariffs, import quotas, product standards, and subsidies are some of the primary policy tools a government can use in enacting protectionist policies.

Term: Contract Provision: Meaning, Considerations and FAQs
Definition: A contract provision is a stipulation in a contract, legal document, or a law./nA contract provision often requires action by a certain date or within a certain period of time./nOne of the most familiar uses of a contract provision is a bond’s call provision, which refers to a specific date; after this date, the company may recall and retire the bond./nA sunset provision is a provision in a regulation stating that sections of the law, or the whole law, expire on a set date.

Term: Provident Fund: Definition, How It Works for Retirement
Definition: A provident fund is a government-backed retirement plan used in Singapore, India, and other countries./nBoth the employee and employer contribute to a fund that aims to provide financial support to the employee when they reach retirement./nA provident fund is managed by the government, with sets minimum and maximum contribution levels.

Term: Proxy Fight: Definition, Causes, What Happens, and Example
Definition: A proxy fight refers to the act of a group of shareholders joining forces and attempting to gather enough shareholder proxy votes to win a corporate vote./nThe voting bids in a proxy vote could include replacing corporate management or the board of directors./nProxy fights also emerge over corporate takeovers and mergers, most notably with hostile takeovers.

Term: Proxy Definition, How It Works, Statements, Benefits, and Example
Definition: A proxy is an agent legally authorized to act on behalf of another party./nThe proxy may also allow an investor to vote without being physically present at the annual shareholder's meeting./nManagement ensures ownership interests are fully represented by encouraging shareholders who are unable to attend annual meetings to vote by proxy./nA proxy statement is a packet of documents containing information necessary to make informed votes on issues facing the company.

Term: What Is a Proxy Statement? Definition, What's In It, and Voting
Definition: Public companies are required to file proxy statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission./nThe proxy statement is filed when a company is seeking shareholder votes and is filed ahead of an annual meeting./nThe proxy statement, called a Form DEF 14A, highlights new board of director nominees, proposed executive salary and compensation, and any other information a shareholder may need to vote on an issue./nProxy statements provide shareholders with crucial information needed to assess the qualifications and compensation of key members of the company's management team and board of directors./nA proxy statement is different from a proxy vote, in which a shareholder agrees that another person can vote on behalf of the shareholder.

Term: What Is a Proxy Vote, and How Does It Work? With Examples
Definition: A proxy vote is a ballot cast by one person or firm for a company's shareholder who can't attend a meeting, or who doesn't want to vote on an issue./nPrior to a company's annual meeting, eligible shareholders may receive voting and proxy information before a shareholder vote./nRather than physically attending the shareholder meeting, investors may elect someone else to vote in their place./nA person designated as a proxy will cast a proxy vote in line with the shareholder's directions as written on their proxy card.

Term: Publicly Traded Company: Definition, How It Works, and Examples
Definition: A public company, also called a publicly traded company, is a corporation whose shareholders have a claim to part of the company's assets and profits./nOwnership of a public company is distributed among general public shareholders through the free trade of shares of stock on stock exchanges or over-the-counter (OTC) markets./nA public company is required to disclose its financial and business information regularly to the public./nIt must also report its securities trading on public exchanges.

Term: Public Company Accounting Oversight Board: Overview, History
Definition: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) is a non-profit organization that regulates audits of publicly traded companies to minimize audit risk./nThe PCAOB was established at the same time as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 to address the accounting scandals of the late 1990s./nThe board protects investors and other stakeholders of public companies by ensuring that auditors follow strict guidelines.

Term: What Are Public Goods? Definition, How They Work, and Example
Definition: A public good is the opposite of a private good, which is consumed only by the person or people who can afford to pay for it./nA public good can be consumed by many people without restricting its availability to others./nThere is always disagreement over what is or should be a public good or a private good./nThese disagreements are decided by government spending priorities.

Term: What Public Limited Company (PLC) Means in the U.K.
Definition: PLC, or public limited company, is an abbreviation for public companies in the U.K./nAll of the companies listed on the London Stock Exchange are PLCs./nAny retail investor may buy stock in a PLC./nUnlike privately held companies, public companies must publish certain financial data and disclosures for the public at regular intervals./nThe formal names of some familiar U.K. brands like Burberry and Shell include the suffix PLC.

Term: Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs): Definition, How They Work, and Examples
Definition: Public-private partnerships allow large-scale government projects, such as roads, bridges, or hospitals, to be completed with private funding./nThese partnerships work well when private sector technology and innovation combine with public sector incentives to complete work on time and within budget./nRisks for private enterprise include cost overruns, technical defects, and an inability to meet quality standards, while for public partners, agreed-upon usage fees may not be supported by demand—for example, for a toll road or a bridge./nDespite their advantages, public-private partnerships are often criticized for blurring the lines between legitimate public purposes and private for-profit activity, and for perceived exploitation of the public due to self-dealing and rent-seeking that may occur.

Term: Pullback: What It Means in Trading, With Examples
Definition: A pullback is a temporary reversal in the upside price action of an asset or security./nThe duration of a pullback is usually only a few consecutive sessions. A longer pause before the uptrend resumes is generally referred to as consolidation./nPullbacks can provide an entry point for traders looking to enter a position when other technical indicators remain bullish./nTraders can uselimit ordersorstop entry ordersto take advantage of a pullback to get in on the primary uptrend.

Term: Pump-and-Dump: Definition, How the Scheme is Illegal, and Types
Definition: Pump-and-dump is an illegal scheme to boost a stock's or security's price based on false, misleading, or greatly exaggerated statements./nPump-and-dump schemes usually target micro- and small-cap stocks./nPeople found guilty of running pump-and-dump schemes are subject to heavy fines./nPump-and-dump schemes are increasingly found in the cryptocurrency industry.

Term: What Is a Purchase APR? Definition, Rates, and Ways to Avoid
Definition: A credit card's APR is an annualized percentage rate that is applied each month to unpaid balances. The monthly interest amount that appears on the bill is one-twelfth of the annual APR./nThe purchase APR is the interest charged on purchases you have made with the card./nMost credit cards have several APRs attached. Different rates for purchases and cash advances are common./nThe APRs on a credit card can be changed by the credit card company even if it is a "fixed-rate" card.

Term: Pump Priming Definition, Examples of Use in the U.S., Japan
Definition: Pump priming refers to the steps taken to stimulate spending in an economy during or after a recession./nGenerally, it involves pumping government funds into a depressed economy to encourage growth./nThese financial injections can increase purchasing power and spur demand for goods and services.

Term: Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) Definition and How It Works
Definition: The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) is a measure of the prevailing direction of economic trends in manufacturing./nThe PMI is based on a monthly survey of supply chain managers across 19 industries, covering both upstream and downstream activity./nThe value of the PMI and its movements can provide useful insight to business decision makers, market analysts, and investors./nThe PMI is a leading indicator of overall economic activity in the U.S.

Term: Purchase Money Security Interest (PMSI) Definition, How It Works
Definition: A PMSI gives a retailer or supplier priority for collecting on debt when a borrower or buyer defaults./nThe goods sold in PMSI cases serve as collateral that can be seized for nonpayment./nFor inventory goods, the lending party must notify other parties with potential secured interest claims as well as file a UCC-1 legal notice./nFor non-inventory goods, the lending party must file a UCC-1 before the borrower takes possession of the goods or within the first 20 days after./nThough creditors are often prioritized based on the timing of their secured interest, PMSI creates an exception that allows creditors to "jump the line" even if they weren't first.

Term: Understanding Purchasing Power and the Consumer Price Index
Definition: Purchasing power is the amount of goods or services that a unit of currency can buy at a given point in time./nInflation erodes the purchasing power of a currency over time./nCentral banks adjust interest rates to try to keep prices stable and maintain purchasing power./nOne U.S. measure of purchasing power is the Consumer Price Index (CPI)./nGlobalization has linked currencies more closely than ever so protecting purchasing power worldwide is crucial.

Term: Pure Play: Examples of Niching Down in Investing
Definition: A pure play refers to an investment in a company that is focused on one specific industry or niche./nSome investors like pure plays for their ease of analysis and the exposure they offer to particular sectors./nPure plays can be difficult to identify as many corporations today are involved in several product lines or market segments.

Term: What Is Pure Risk? Definition, 2 Potential Outcomes, and Types
Definition: Pure risk cannot be controlled and has two outcomes: complete loss or no loss at all./nThere are no opportunities for gain or profit when pure risk is involved./nPure risks can be divided into three different categories: personal, property, and liability./nMany cases of pure risk are insurable.

Term: Pushdown Accounting: Definition, How It Works, Example
Definition: Pushdown accounting is a method of accounting for the purchase of another company at the purchase price rather than its historical cost./nThe target company’s assets and liabilities are written up (or down) to reflect the purchase price./nAny gains and losses associated with the new book value are “pushed down” from the acquirer’s to the acquired company’s income statement and balance sheet.

Term: Put: What It Is and How It Works in Investing, With Examples
Definition: A put gives the owner the right, but not the obligation, to sell the underlying stock at a set price within a specified time./nA put option's value goes up as the underlying stock price depreciates; the put option's value goes down as the underlying stock appreciates./nWhen an investor purchases a put, they expect the underlying stock to decline in price.

Term: Put-Call Parity: Definition, Formula, How it Works, and Examples
Definition: Put-call parity shows the relationship that has to exist between European put and call options that have the same underlying asset, expiration, and strike prices./nThis concept says the price of a call option implies a certain fair price for the corresponding put option with the same strike price and expiration and vice versa./nPut-call parity doesn't apply to American options because you can exercise them before the expiry date./nIf the put-call parity is violated, then arbitrage opportunities arise./nYou can determine the put-call party by using the formula C + PV(x) = P + S.

Term: Put-Call Ratio Meaning and What It Says About How to Gauge the Market
Definition: A put option gets the trader the right to sell an asset at a preset price./nA call option is a right to buy an asset at a preset price./nTraders buying more puts than calls indicates a bearish market./nIf they are buying more calls than puts, watch out for a bull market ahead.

Term: Put Option: What It Is, How It Works, and How to Trade Them
Definition: Put options give holders of the option the right, but not the obligation, to sell a specified amount of an underlying security at a specified price within a specified time frame./nPut options are available on a wide range of assets, including stocks, indexes, commodities, and currencies./nPut option prices are impacted by changes in the price of the underlying asset, the option strike price, time decay, interest rates, and volatility./nPut options increase in value as the underlying asset falls in price, as volatility of the underlying asset price increases, and as interest rates decline./nPut options lose value as the underlying asset increases in price, as volatility of the underlying asset price decreases, as interest rates rise, and as the time to expiration nears.

Term: Q As A Ticker Symbol: Meaning, How It Works
Definition: Q is a former Nasdaq designation that noted a company had filed for bankruptcy./nThe Q would show up as the final letter in a stock symbol./nThe Nasdaq phased out the usage of Q as of 2016.

Term: What Is a Pyramid Scheme? How Does It Work?
Definition: A pyramid scheme funnels earnings from all recruited participants on lower levels of an organization to participants on higher levels./nIt is a felony in the U.S. to recruit participants into pyramid schemes./nPyramid schemes rely on income from recruitment fees and not, as participants may believe, from the sale of actual goods or services with real value./nMulti-Level Marketing operations (MLMs) are legitimate business programs in which distributors earn money from the sale of tangible goods and from commissions on their recruited distributors' purchases and sales./nPyramid schemes often masquerade as MLMs but their focus is on fees from recruits, not revenue from product sales.

Term: Q Ratio or Tobin's Q: Definition, Formula, Uses, and Examples
Definition: The Q ratio was popularized by Nobel Laureate James Tobin and invented in 1966 by Nicholas Kaldor./nThe Q ratio, also known as Tobin's Q, measures whether a firm or an aggregate market is relatively over- or undervalued./nIt relies on the concepts of market value and replacement value./nThe simplified Q ratio is the equity market value divided by equity book value.

Term: Qatar Investment Authority (QIA): Meaning, History, FAQs
Definition: The Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) is that nation's sovereign wealth fund, located in Doha./nEstablished in 2005, the QIA has grown to become of of the world's largest SWFs./nMuch of Qatar's wealth comes from oil and gas revenues./nAs of mid-2022, the QIA's portfolio was worth roughly $360 billion./nThe fund has a long-term investment outlook and can invest in a wide variety of asset classes.

Term: Qatari Riyal: What it is, How it Works, FAQ
Definition: The Qatari riyal is the official currency of the State of Qatar. The currency code is QAR, and the abbreviation is QR./nQAR is pegged to the USD at a rate of 1 USD/QAR 3.64 and is allowed to fluctuate in a band between 3.6385 and 3.6415./nThe Qatar Central Bank oversees the issuance of currency and has regulatory control to maintain the currency peg./nThe peg has largely been maintained both domestically and in foreign markets, although the QAR did drop to 3.81 in 2017 (in foreign markets) when several countries cut diplomatic ties with Qatar based on terrorism allegations./nThe Qatari riyal has bill denominations of one, five, 10, 50, 100, and 500 riyals. Coins denominations are one, five, 10, 25, and 50 dirhams.

Term: Qstick Indicator: Meaning, Calculation, Example
Definition: The QStick calculates a moving average of the difference between closing and opening prices./nA rising indicator signals the price is closing higher than it opened, on average./nA falling QStick signals the price is closing lower than it opened, on average./nThe QStick can generate trade signals based on signal-line or zero-line crossovers.

Term: QQQQ: Definition, Composition, and Current Ticker
Definition: QQQQ is the original ticker symbol for the Invesco QQQ Trust, an ETF that trades on the Nasdaq exchange./nThe ETF, whose current ticker symbol is QQQ, is also known as "cubes" or "triple-Qs."/nQQQ offers broad exposure to the tech sector by tracking the Nasdaq 100 Index./nThe Nasdaq 100 Index tracks the 100 largest and most actively traded non-financial stocks on the Nasdaq./nThe ETF itself includes a very small percentage of financial services stocks, as of April 2023.

Term: Qualified Small Employer Health Reimbursement Arrangement (QSEHRA)
Definition: A QSEHRA is a health cost reimbursement plan that small business employers with no group insurance plan can offer to their employees./nThe costs that are reimbursed are tax-free for employees and tax-deductible for the business, up to certain limits./nThe plan can be used to offset health insurance coverage or repay uncovered medical expenses.

Term: Qtum: What it is, How it Works, Comparisons
Definition: Qtum is a cryptocurrency that combines the security of Bitcoin's blockchain model and the flexibility of Ethereum's smart contracts./nIt uses a proof-of-stake consensus model for creating new blocks, which is far easier and less energy-intensive than Bitcoin's proof-of-work model./nQtum is designed for use by large organizations, with the goal of becoming integral to a range of industries, including finance and social media.

Term: Quadrix
Definition: Quadrix is a proprietary stock screening system./nThe screener looks at publicly traded stocks in the U.S. including some ADRs of foreign companies listed on U.S. exchanges./nQuadrix is not a risk-based portfolio builder based on modern portfolio theory of the kind used by many roboadvisors.

Term: Quadruple (Quad) Witching: Definition and How It Impacts Stocks
Definition: Quadruple witching refers to the simultaneous expiration of stock index futures, stock index options, stock options, and single stock futures derivatives contracts four times a year./nQuadruple witching has given way to triple witching since single stock futures stopped trading in the U.S. in 2020./nThis event occurs once every quarter, on the third Friday of March, June, September, and December./nTrading volume typically surges on triple witching days as traders adjust portfolios and roll some contracts./nTriple witching does not usually cause increased market volatility.

Term: Qualification Ratio: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A qualification ratio calculates a borrower's ability to repay a loan, typically as a proportion of either debt to income or housing expenses to income./nLenders use qualification ratios to help underwrite a loan application for approval and/or the terms of credit that should be extended./nLenders use the front-end ratio in conjunction with the back-end ratio to determine how much to lend./nCertain qualitative factors may also come into play, giving lenders some wiggle room to extend or deny a loan.

Term: Qualified Annuity: Meaning, Overview, FAQ
Definition: Contributions to a qualified annuity are made with pre-tax dollars./nThis means that taxes are postponed until withdrawals are made after retirement./nContributions to a non-qualified annuity are in post-tax dollars because taxes on the contributions have already been paid./n"Qualified" and "non-qualified" are IRS terms. A qualified plan has an immediate tax benefit.

Term: Qualified Adoption Expenses (QAE): What It is, How It Works
Definition: Qualified adoption expenses (QAE) are the necessary costs paid to adopt a child younger than 18 years old or a disabled person who requires care./nThese costs may have been incurred prior to or after the legal adoption of an individual./nQualified adoption expenses are IRS-defined reasonable and necessary adoption-related costs, including court costs, adoption, and attorney fees./nThe maximum credit amount allowed for adoptions is $14,890 per child for 2022 and $15,950 for 2023.

Term: Understanding Qualified Automatic Contribution Arrangement (QACA)
Definition: Qualified automatic contribution arrangements (QACAs) are a form of automatic-enrollment retirement plan offered by employers./nAs an opt-out plan, employees will automatically be enrolled with a matching contribution unless they choose to leave the plan./nQACAs have "safe harbor" provisions that exempt them from actual deferral percentage (ADP) testing requirements./nA QACA must specify a schedule of uniform minimum default percentages starting at 3% that gradually increase with each year that an employee participates.

Term: Qualified Charitable Organization: Meaning, Rules, FAQs
Definition: A qualified charitable organization is recognized as tax exempt in the pursuit of philanthropic, nonprofit, or civic activities./nSection 501(c)(3) is the specific portion of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code (IRC) and a specific tax category for nonprofit organizations./n501(c)(3) organizations are not only tax exempt; donations to them may also be tax deductible for donors.

Term: Qualified Disclaimer: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A qualified disclaimer is a part of the U.S. tax code that allows estate assets to pass to a beneficiary without being subject to income tax./nLegally, the disclaimer portrays the transfer of assets as if the intended beneficiary never actually received them./nFor a disclaimer to qualify, it must meet four requirements spelled out in writing and consistent with federal law.

Term: Qualified Distribution: Definition, How Plans Work, and Taxation
Definition: A qualified distribution is a withdrawal from a qualified retirement plan such as a 401(k) plan, 403(b) plan, or IRA./nQualified distributions come with tax and penalty conditions set by the IRS to keep investors from using funds for purposes other than retirement./nTax-deferred plans require account holders to be at least 59½ years of age to make a qualified distribution./nQualified distributions from Roth IRAs include the 59½ age requirement and require the account to be open for at least five tax years before making a withdrawal./nTaxable portions of non-qualified distributions are subject to a 10% early withdrawal penalty by the IRS.

Term: What Are Qualified Dividends, and How Are They Taxed?
Definition: A qualified dividend is an ordinary dividend that meets the criteria to be taxed at capital gains tax rates, which are lower than income tax rates for some taxpayers./nQualified dividends must meet special requirements issued by the IRS./nThe maximum tax rate for qualified dividends is 20%, with a few exceptions for real estate, art, or small business stock. Ordinary dividends are taxed at income tax rates, which as of the 2023 tax year, maxes out at 37%.

Term: Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor (QDII) Overview
Definition: A qualified domestic institutional investor (QDII) is an institutional investor that meets qualifications to invest in securities in foreign markets./nQDII programs started in China in 2006 and allow five types of Chinese entities to invest abroad: insurance companies, banks, trust companies, funds, and securities firms./nEntities that want to participate in the QDII program must first receive approval from China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE), which is also responsible for establishing the investment quota amount allowed each participant./nOnce approved, entities are allowed to make investments in the overseas markets for both themselves or on behalf of retail clients./nFirms can make investments in equities, fixed income, and derivatives in specified overseas markets.

Term: Qualified Domestic Trust (QDOT): Definition and How It Works
Definition: A qualified domestic trust (QDOT) allows surviving spouses who are not U.S. citizens to take the full marital deduction on estate taxes./nIf you are married to someone who is a citizen of another country, it may make sense to establish and fund a QDOT./nPlacing assets in a legal vehicle like a QDOT provides a safety net for a surviving spouse who is not a U.S. citizen./nAs with any trust, it is crucial to meet all requirements and provisions so that the QDOT remains valid.

Term: What Is a Qualified Domestic Relations Order (QDRO)?
Definition: A qualified domestic relations order (QDRO) means—or is defined as—a legal document that may be issued by a court./nThis type of document is often used in divorce agreements./nA QDRO recognizes that a spouse, former spouse, child, or other dependent is entitled to receive some of the account owner’s retirement plan assets./nA court order cannot force a retirement plan to disburse any benefit not provided through the plan or require increased benefits from the retirement plan./nIn most cases, taxes must be paid on money from a QDRO.

Term: Qualified Electric Vehicle: What It is, How it Works
Definition: A qualified electric vehicle is a plug-in electric passenger vehicle or light truck that allows the owner to claim a nonrefundable tax credit after purchase./nThe vehicle must have at least four wheels, be designed for use in public, and were not used for commercial purposes./nIt must be powered primarily by an electric motor that draws its charge from rechargeable batteries or fuel cells./nVehicle owners may qualify for the full $7,500 credit, as long as they fill out Form 8936./nThe credit phases out after a certain period of time, which is based on the manufacturer.

Term: Qualified Eligible Participant (QEP): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A qualified eligible participant is an individual who meets the requirements to trade in different investment funds, such as futures and hedge funds./nA QEP must own at least $2,000,000 of securities and other investments, have an open account with a FCM for at least six months, and have a portfolio that has at least $200,000 of initial margin and option premiums for commodity interest transactions./nQEPs are similar to, but not the same as, accredited investors in that they are assumed to have a sophisticated understanding of the complexities of trading risky assets such as futures and hedge funds.

Term: Qualified Exchange Accommodation Arrangements Overview
Definition: A 1031 exchange is when investors can defer taking a capital gain or loss on the sale of real estate as long as the relinquished property is replaced by a like-kind property./nA qualified exchange accommodation arrangement is when a third party temporarily holds a real estate investor's relinquished or replacement property./nThe arrangement helps investors defer a realized capital gain or loss from the sale of real estate by allowing them to complete a like-kind exchange.

Term: Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) Definition, Rules
Definition: Launched in 2002 by the Chinese government, the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) program allows certain licensed international investors the opportunity to invest in China's stock exchanges./nThe QFII program allows foreign institutional investors to buy and sell yuan-denominated "A" shares of Chinese companies./nA similar program to QFII, the Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (RQFII) program imposes fewer restrictions on overseas investors and makes it easier for direct investment in China's domestic capital markets.

Term: Qualified Higher Education Expenses: What They are, How They Work
Definition: A qualified higher education expense is any money paid by an individual for expenses required to attend a college, university, or other post-secondary institution./nQHEEs include tuition, books, fees, and supplies such as laptops and computers, but expenses like insurance and health fees are not eligible./nTaxpayers may claim QHEEs under the tuition and fees deduction by using Form 8917 with their completed tax return./nFilers may apply for the American Opportunity Tax Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit as an alternative.

Term: What Is a Qualified Institutional Buyer (QIB), and Who Qualifies?
Definition: A qualified institutional buyer (QIB) is a class of investor that by virtue of being a sophisticated investor, does not require the regulatory protection that the Securities Act's registration provisions gives to investors./nTypically, a QIB is a company that manages a minimum investment of $100 million in securities on a discretionary basis or is a registered broker-dealer with at least a $10 million investment in non-affiliated securities./nOn Aug. 26, 2020, the SEC adopted amendments to the QIB and accredited investor definitions that broadened the list of entities eligible to qualify in these categories./nUnder Rule 144A, QIB's are allowed to trade restricted and control securities on the market, which increases the liquidity for these securities.

Term: Qualified Institutional Placement (QIP): Definition and Rules
Definition: Qualified institutional placements (QIPS) are a way to issue shares to the public without going through standard regulatory compliance./nQIPs instead follow a looser set of regulations but where allottees are more highly regulated./nThe practice is mostly used in India and other Southeast Asian countries./nQIPs were created to avoid dependency on foreign resources for raising capital./nQualified institutional buyers (QIBs) are the only entities allowed to purchase QIPs.

Term: Qualified Longevity Annuity Contract (QLAC): Definition, Taxes, and Example
Definition: A QLAC is a retirement strategy in which a portion of required minimum distributions (RMDs) are deferred./nThe SECURE 2.0 Act of 2022 allows individuals to move $200,000 from a qualified retirement plan or IRA to a QLAC./nA QLAC allows taxes to be deferred that are normally required by RMDs./nQLACs are available for purchase through many insurance companies.

Term: Qualified Joint and Survivor Annuity (QJSA): Meaning, Example
Definition: A qualified joint and survivor annuity provides lifetime payments to spouses, children, or dependents./nA QJSA generally requires at least a 50% survivor annuity./nIf the participant is in poor health, a QJSA may not be a good investment.

Term: Qualified Mortgage: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A qualified mortgage is a mortgage that meets certain requirements for lender protection and secondary market trading under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act./nProvisions of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act—which was passed in 2010 and created the rules that regulate qualified mortgages—are intended to protect both borrowers and the financial system from the risky mortgage lending practices that contributed to the subprime mortgage crisis of 2007./nTo be eligible for a qualified mortgage, borrowers must meet certain requirements; these requirements are meant to determine a borrower's ability to repay their mortgage.

Term: Qualified Opinion: Definition and Place in Auditor's Report
Definition: A qualified opinion is one of four possible auditor's opinions on a company's financial statement./nThe other auditor's opinions are unqualified, adverse, or a disclaimer of opinion./nA qualified opinion indicates that there was either a scope limitation, an issue discovered in the audit of the financials that were not pervasive, or an inadequate footnote disclosure./nA qualified opinion is an auditor's opinion that the financials are fairly presented, with the exception of a specified area./nUnlike an adverse or disclaimer of opinion, a qualified opinion is generally still acceptable to lenders, creditors, and investors./nThe auditor's opinion is usually found in the third and final section of an auditor’s report.

Term: Qualified Personal Residence Trust (QPRT): Overview, Examples
Definition: A QPRT allows you to remove your home from your estate to reduce gift taxes./nProperty value during the retained interest period is calculated based on IRS applicable federal rates./nOther types of trusts include a bare trust and a charitable remainder trust.

Term: Qualified Pre-Retirement Survivor Annuity (QPSA) Overview
Definition: A qualified pre-retirement survivor annuity (QPSA) provides monetary distribution to a surviving spouse of a deceased employee./nThe employee must be under a qualified plan in order for compensation to occur./nThe Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) dictates how payments are to be calculated./nThere are rules to follow for survivor benefit payments to non-spouse beneficiaries./nA QPSA notice is required if a retirement plan offers a QPSA.

Term: Qualified Professional Asset Manager (QPAM)
Definition: A qualified professional asset manager (QPAM) is a registered investment adviser that assists institutions in making investments./nThe focus for a QPAM is on retirement accounts, such as pension plans./nWhen employing a QPAM, investment funds can do business in areas otherwise prevented by ERISA. This is known as a QPAM exemption./nBanks and insurance companies may qualify as QPAMs as long as they are registered investment advisers with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)./nA QPAM is also defined as a registered investment adviser with AUM of at least $85 million and shareholder's equity of $1 million or more.

Term: Qualified Reservist: Meaning, Pros and Cons
Definition: Qualified reservists, when called to duty, can thereafter make tax-free withdrawals from certain retirement accounts./nQualified reservist rules are fairly recent, enacted as part of the Pension Protection Act of 2006. Initially, the rules only applied to active reservists on Dec. 30, 2007, or before./nMany service people take their distributions early because of this, but it can have long-term negative effects on a retirement nest egg./nRetirement benefits that are taken are still subject to certain state and federal taxes./nPerhaps the biggest disadvantage of the qualified reservist rules is that missing even a single year of savings in a 401k or IRA can make a difference in retirement.

Term: Qualified Retirement Plan: Definition and 2 Main Types
Definition: A qualified retirement plan is an employer-sponsored plan that meets Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and U.S. Labor Department requirements and offers certain tax benefits to employees and employers./nThose benefits can include tax deductions for contributions and tax deferral of investment gains until the money is withdrawn from the account./nQualified retirement plans can be either defined-benefit or defined-contribution plans./nExamples of qualified retirement plans include traditional pensions, 401(k) plans, and profit-sharing plans.

Term: Qualified Special Representative Agreement (QSR): Overview
Definition: The Qualified Special Representative Agreement (QSR) is the agreement between broker-dealers to clear trades without interacting with the NASDAQ ACT system./nOne broker-dealer can send trades directly to the National Securities Clearing Corporation on behalf of another broker-dealer through the Qualified Special Representative Agreement (QSR)./nBenefits of the QSR agreement include simpler processing, lower transaction costs, and extended trading hours./nRisks include counterparty risk and operational risk.

Term: QTIP Trusts: Definition, How They Work, Advantages
Definition: A qualified terminable interest property (QTIP) trust allows an individual, called the grantor, to leave assets for a surviving spouse and determine how the trust's assets are split up after the surviving spouse dies./nUnder a QTIP trust, income is paid to a surviving spouse while the balance of the funds is held in trust until that spouse's death. At that point, the remainder is paid to the beneficiaries specified by the grantor./nQTIP trusts are used in estate planning and are especially helpful when beneficiaries exist from a previous marriage, but the grantor dies before a subsequent spouse does./nIn QTIP trust, estate tax is not assessed at the point of the first spouse's death but is determined after the second spouse has passed./nA QTIP trust is established by making a QTIP trust election on the executor's tax return.

Term: Who Is a Qualifying Widower or Widow? Tax Filing Status Explained
Definition: Qualified widow or widower is a tax filing status that allows a surviving spouse to use the married filing jointly tax rates on their tax return./nThe survivor must remain unmarried for at least two years following the year of the spouse’s death to qualify for the tax status./nThe taxpayer must have at least one dependent child and have handled at least half of the household costs./nThe qualifying widow(er) status offers the same standard deduction amount and tax bracket ranges as those for married couples who file jointly./nThe surviving spouse must file as single or head of household following the third year of their spouse's death.

Term: Qualified Trust: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A qualified trust is a stock bonus, pension, or profit-sharing plan established by an employer for their employees./nA qualified trust is tax-advantaged as long as it meets IRS requirements./nIn order to determine benefits, an employer may consider the life expectancy of their employees, but they cannot factor in the race, gender, religion, or current compensation of their employees.

Term: What Is a Qualifying Disposition and How Does It Work?
Definition: A qualifying disposition is the sale or transfer of stock that qualifies for favorable tax treatment./nShares involved in qualifying dispositions are traditionally acquired through an employee stock purchase plan (ESPP), or through an incentive stock option (ISO)./nNon-statutory stock options (NSOs) do not qualify for capital gains tax treatment and get taxed at ordinary income rates.﻿﻿/nESPPs and ISOs are used by companies to attract and retain talented personnel.

Term: What Is a Qualifying Event for Insurance? How It Works and Types
Definition: A qualifying event allows you to change your existing health insurance policy, or sign up for a new one, outside of open enrollment periods./nOpen enrollment periods are typically held at the end of the year with coverage starting at the beginning of the following year./nExamples of qualifying events include the birth or adoption of a child, death of a spouse, or a change in marital status.

Term: Qualifying Annuity: What It is, How it Works
Definition: A qualifying annuity is an annuity approved by the IRS for use within an IRA or a qualified retirement plan, similar to other types of annuities./nA qualifying annuity can be variable, fixed, or indexed./nWithdrawals from an annuity before age 59½ are subject to a 10% penalty./nHowever, since a non-qualified annuity is purchased with after-tax dollars, only the earnings would be subject to the penalty.﻿﻿

Term: Qualifying Investment: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: Qualifying investments are purchased with pretax income and are not taxed until the investor withdraws them./nThey provide an incentive to contribute to accounts, such as IRAs, to defer taxes until the funds are withdrawn in retirement./nFinancial instruments that qualify for deferred taxes include annuities, stocks, bonds, mutual funds, ETFs, IRAs, RRSPs, and some trusts./nRoth IRAs require the investor pay taxes upfront and therefore don't meet the guidelines.

Term: Qualifying Ratios: What They are, How They Work
Definition: The debt-to-income ratio (total expenses divided by gross income) is used in underwriting personal loans, credit card applications, and mortgages./nThe housing expense ratio (housing-relating expenses divided by gross income) is used in underwriting mortgages./nWhile each lender sets its own qualifying standards, what's generally desirable is a debt-to-income ratio of 36% or less, and a housing expense ratio of 28%.

Term: Qualifying Transaction: What It is, How it Works
Definition: A qualifying transaction is a process in which a private company in Canada goes public with the intent to raise capital for business purposes./nA qualifying transaction involves the creation of a capital pool company (CPC) that acquires all of the outstanding shares of the private company, making it a subsidiary and a public company./nThe CPC is responsible for selling the shares and raising the capital all while obeying the rules and regulations around a qualifying transaction./nA CPC must complete a qualifying transaction's requirements within 24 months of its creation, which involves filing a prospectus and applying to the TSX Venture Exchange./nA qualifying transaction is the most common form of going public on the TSX Venture Exchange, particularly when compared to an initial public offering (IPO).

Term: Qualifying Relative Definition and IRS Guidelines
Definition: A qualifying relative is a dependent you can claim when filing your taxes./nBefore claiming a qualifying relative, examine how much income your relative makes, how much support you provide for them, and your relationship with them./nAs a dependent, a qualifying relative can provide the taxpayer tax credits that accompany the addition of the relative to the household./nThe Tax Cuts and Jobs Act suspended the deduction for qualifying relative exemptions for tax years 2018 through 2025, however, taxpayers may claim other tax benefits.

Term: Quality Control: What It Is, How It Works, and QC Careers
Definition: Quality control (QC) is a process through which a business seeks to ensure that product quality is maintained or improved./nQuality control involves testing units and determining if they are within the specifications for the final product./nThe quality control used in a business is highly dependent on the product or industry, and several techniques exist for measuring quality./nThe food industry uses quality control methods to ensure customers do not get sick from their products./nQuality control creates safe measures that can be implemented to make sure deficient or damaged products do not end up with customers.

Term: Qualifying Widow/Widower Meaning and Tax Advantages
Definition: Qualifying widow/widower filing status applies to surviving spouses with dependents./nThis allows the surviving spouse to file taxes jointly with the deceased spouse./nThe qualifying widow/widower status applies the standard deduction for a married couple filing jointly.

Term: Qualitative Analysis
Definition: Qualitative analysis uses subjective judgment based on "soft" or non-quantifiable data./nQualitative analysis deals with intangible and inexact information that can be difficult to collect and measure./nMachines struggle to conduct qualitative analysis as intangibles can’t be defined by numeric values./nUnderstanding people and company cultures are central to qualitative analysis./nLooking at a company through the eyes of a customer and understanding its competitive advantage assists with qualitative analysis.

Term: What Is a Quality Control Chart and Why Does It Matter?
Definition: A quality control chart is a graphical representation of whether a firm's products or processes are meeting their intended specifications./nIf problems appear to arise, the quality control chart can be used to identify the degree by which they vary from those specifications and help in error correction./nA common depiction of the quality control chart is the x-bar chart, where the y-axis tracks variance of the tested attribute is acceptable in a univariate or multivariate manner.

Term: Quality Management: Definition Plus Example
Definition: Quality management is the act of overseeing all activities and tasks needed to maintain a desired level of excellence./nQuality management includes the determination of a quality policy, creating and implementing quality planning and assurance, and quality control and quality improvement./nTQM requires that all stakeholders in a business work together to improve processes, products, services and the culture of the company itself.

Term: What Is Quality of Life? Why It's Important and How to Improve It
Definition: Quality of life is often directly related to job satisfaction./nQuality of life factors include the availability of free time, a reasonable commute, harmonious relationships with colleagues, and the satisfaction of a job well done./nThe relative importance of the many factors that make up quality of life varies among individuals.

Term: Quality of Earnings: Definition, Analysis, and Why It's Important
Definition: A company's real quality of earnings can only be revealed by spotting and removing any anomalies, accounting tricks, or one-time events that skew the numbers./nQuality of earnings is the percentage of income that is due to higher sales or lower costs./nAn increase in net income without a corresponding increase in cash flow from operations is a red flag./nTracking activity from the income statement through to the balance sheet and cash flow statement is a good way to gauge quality of earnings.

Term: Quant Fund: Definition, How They Work, Performance, and Risks
Definition: A quant fund makes investment decisions based on the use of advanced mathematical models and quantitative analysis./nManagers utilize algorithms and custom-built computer models to pick their investments./nInvestors are turning to and sticking with quantitative analysis within funds because of the rising availability of market data./nAlthough quant funds utilize state-of-the-art technology, the use of quantitative analysis isn't new.

Term: Quality Spread Differential (QSD): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A quality spread differential (QSD) is the difference between market interest rates achieved by two parties who enter an interest rate swap./nIt is a measurement that companies can use to gauge counterparty risk in an interest rate swap./nThe QSD is calculated by subtracting the contracted market rate by the rate available to the counter-party on similar rate instruments./nWhen the QSD is positive, the swap is considered to benefit both parties involved.

Term: Quantity-Adjusting Option: Overview, Benefits, FAQ
Definition: The Quanto option is designed to remove currency rate risk as a factor in foreign options trading./nThe options contract specifies that the underlying asset is denominated in one currency while settlement is to be made in another currency./nQuanto options have been a key factor in opening up international transactions in foreign markets whose currencies tend to be volatile./nQuanto options are a type of exotic derivative and usually trade over the counter.

Term: Quantitative Analysis (QA): What It Is and How It's Used in Finance
Definition: Quantitative analysis (QA) is a set of techniques that use mathematical and statistical modeling, measurement, and research to understand behavior./nQuantitative analysis presents financial information in terms of a numerical value./nIt's used for the evaluation of financial instruments and for predicting real-world events such as changes in GDP./nWhile powerful, quantitative analysis has some drawbacks that can be supplemented with qualitative analysis.

Term: Quantitative Easing 2 (QE2): Meaning, How it Works, Impact
Definition: QE2 was a round of quantitative easing initiated by the Federal Reserve in late 2010 that expanded its balance sheet by $600 billion.﻿﻿/nQuantitative easing refers to strategies a central bank can use to increase the domestic money supply via asset purchases./nCentral banks turn quantitative easing when interest rates are at or near 0% levels./nQE2 was followed by QE3 in September 2012.﻿﻿

Term: What Is Quantitative Trading? Definition, Examples, and Profit
Definition: Quantitative trading utilizes mathematical functions and automated trading models to make trading decisions./nIn this type of trading, backtested data are applied to various scenarios to help identify opportunities for profit./nThe advantage of quantitative trading is that it allows for optimal use of available data and eliminates the emotional decision-making that can occur during trading./nA disadvantage of quantitative trading is that it has limited use: a quantitative trading strategy loses its effectiveness once other market actors learn of it, or as market conditions change./nHigh-frequency trading (HFT) is an example of quantitative trading at scale.

Term: What Is Quantitative Easing (QE) and How Does It Work?
Definition: Quantitative easing is a form ofmonetary policyused by central banks to increase the domestic money supply and spur economic activity./nWith QE, the central bank purchases government bonds and other financial instruments, such as mortgage-backedsecurities(MBS)./nQuantitive easing is typically implemented when interest rates are near zero and economic growth is stalled./nIn the U.S., the Federal Reserve implements quantitative easing policies.

Term: Quantity Discount: Definition, Purpose, Pros & Cons
Definition: A quantity discount is an incentive offered to buyers that results in a decreased cost per unit of goods or materials when purchased in greater numbers./nEnticing buyers to purchase in bulk enables sellers to increase their units per transaction (UPT), lower their inventories, and potentially reduce per-unit costs./nDiscounts can have an adverse impact on profit per unit, also known as the marginal profit./nAn alternative to quantity discount is linear pricing: charging the same price regardless of how many items the customer buys.

Term: Quantity Demanded: Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Quantity demanded refers to the total amount of a good or service that consumers demand over a given period./nQuantity demanded depends on the price of a good or service in a marketplace./nThe price of a product and the quantity demanded for that product have an inverse relationship according to the law of demand./nAn increase in quantity demanded is caused by a decrease in the price of the product and vice versa.

Term: What Is Quantity Supplied? Example, Supply Curve Factors, and Use
Definition: The quantity supplied is the amount of a good or service that is made available for sale at a given price point./nIn a free market, higher prices tend to lead to a higher quantity supplied and vice versa./nThe quantity supplied differs from the total supply and is usually sensitive to price./nAt higher prices, the quantity supplied will be close to the total supply, while at lower prices, the quantity supplied will be much less than the total supply./nThe quantity supplied can be influenced by many factors, including the elasticity of supply and demand, government regulation, and changes in input costs.

Term: Quanto Swap: Meaning, Requirements, Example
Definition: A quanto swap is a derivative transaction where two parties exchange interest rates in different currencies./nQuanto swaps may also be known as guaranteed exchange rate swaps, differential, rate differential, or simply "diff' swaps./nAlthough the payments reference exchange rates in two different currencies, the principal for both payments is in the same currency./nQuanto swaps are useful to investors who believe that a particular asset will do well in a certain country, but that country's currency will not do well./nQuanto swaps can used fixed or floating interest rates. A fixed-for-floating swap has slightly higher risk, but reduces foreign exchange risks.

Term: Quantity Theory of Money: Definition, Formula, and Example
Definition: The quantity theory of money is a framework to understand price changes in relation to the supply of money in an economy./nIt argues that an increase in money supply creates inflation and vice versa./nThe Irving Fisher model is most commonly used to apply the theory. Other competing models were formulated by British economist John Maynard Keynes, Swedish economist Knut Wicksell, and Austrian economist Ludwig von Mises./nThe other models are dynamic and posit an indirect relationship between money supply and price changes in an economy.

Term: Quarter on Quarter (QOQ): Definition, How To Calculate, Example
Definition: QOQ compares a change in performance between one fiscal quarter and the previous fiscal quarter./nQOQ reflects short-term changes in various metrics and can indicate company performance over two quarters./nBusinesses that have income fluctuations or peak earnings at certain times may need to make seasonal adjustments or use a YOY metric to measure performance.

Term: Quantum Computing: Definition, How It's Used, and Example
Definition: Quantum computing uses phenomena in quantum physics to create new ways of computing./nQuantum computing involves qubits./nUnlike a normal computer bit, which can be either 0 or 1, a qubit can exist in a multidimensional state./nThe power of quantum computers grows exponentially with more qubits./nClassical computers that add more bits can increase power only linearly.

Term: Understanding Quarter Over Quarter (Q/Q) Growth, Example
Definition: Quarter over quarter (Q/Q) measures the growth of an investment or a company from one quarter to the next./nQ/Q is also used to measure changes in other important statistics, such as gross domestic product (GDP)./nAnalysts consider Q/Q when reviewing a company’s performance over multiple quarterly periods./nQuarterly results can be found via the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) or on a company's website./nComparing Q/Q information among companies with different quarter start dates can distort an analysis due to seasonal factors or temporary environmental conditions./nThere are other variations on Q/Q such as month over month and year-over-year.

Term: Fiscal Quarters (Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4) Explained
Quarter-To-Date (QTD): Definition, Uses, Analysis, Example
Definition: Quarter-to-date (QTD) is a time interval that captures a company's financial information from the start of a quarter to a point later in the quarter./nThe information for a quarter-to-date analysis is requested before a quarter has ended in order to gauge if a company is on track to meet quarterly results./nQuarter-to-date information allows management to correct course if they are not on track to meet financial targets./nA quarter-to-date analysis is most useful later in the quarter when there has been enough time to collect meaningful data./nNeeded changes based on quarter-to-date data, however, are more impactful earlier on in the quarter./nQuarter-to-date information is primarily for internal use rather than external use.

Term: Quarterly Income Preferred Securities (QUIPS)
Definition: Quarterly Income Preferred Securities (QUIPS) represent a relatively complicated structure that allows companies to raise money while receiving a tax benefit, and investors to receive dividends./nQUIPS are shares in a limited partnership or company that's a subsidiary of another company—and exists solely to issue the shares./nQUIPS proceeds are lent to the parent firm, which pays interest on them; this interest is repaid to the investors who bought the QUIPS./nQUIPS benefit companies who are able to raise cash and take a tax deduction on the interest they pay, without increasing their debt ratio./nThe issuing entity isn't obligated to pay dividends, and Investors have little recourse if they don't.

Term: Quarterly Income Debt Securities (QUIDS)
Definition: Quarterly Income Debt Securities (QUIDS) are tradable debt instruments that pay a quarterly coupon./nQUIDS were established by Goldman Sachs, which established a service mark for that name in 1993./nQUIDS are sold in small denominations, but have a long lifespan before maturing./nCompanies typically issue QUIDS through a subsidiary, which allows QUIDS holders to move ahead of other creditors and shareholders in the event of bankruptcy.

Term: Quarterly Revenue Growth: Meaning, Example, Limitations
Definition: Quarterly revenue growth measures the increase in a firm's sales from one quarter to another./nAnalysts can review the sales of successive quarterly periods or the quarter of one year compared to the same quarter of another year./nFor an accurate picture of growth, investors should look at the growth of several quarters and how consistent it is./nPoor growth for one or a few quarters is not always indicative of a bad investment or poor performing company.

Term: What Is a Quartile? How It Works and Example
Definition: Quartiles organize data into three points—a lower quartile, median, and upper quartile—to form four dataset groups./nAlong with the minimum and maximum values of the data set, the quartiles divide a set of observations into four sections, each representing 25% of the observations./nQuartiles are used to calculate the interquartile range, which is a measure of variability around the median.

Term: Quasi Contract
Definition: A quasi contract is a retroactive remedy between two parties who have no contract with one another./nIt is created by a judge to correct a circumstance in which one party acquires something at the expense of the other./nThe plaintiff must have furnished an asset, item, benefit, or service to another party such that the defendant should have known to pay for it./nThe defendant must have accepted, or acknowledged receipt of, the item but made no effort or offer to pay for it even when they know they should.

Term: Quasi-Public Corporations: What They Are and How They Work
Definition: A quasi-public corporation is a private company that is backed by a branch of government with a public mandate to provide a given service./nIn exchange for their services, they often receive some form of partial funding from the state./nA quasi-public corporation must generally prioritize its government mandate over creating value and profit for shareholders./nThese types of corporations should not be viewed as risk-free investments because of their ties to the government.

Term: Quasi-Reorganization: Meaning, Benefits, Goals
Definition: A quasi-reorganization allows a company to eliminate a deficit in its retained earnings by restating assets, liabilities, and equity in a manner representative of a bankruptcy./nQuasi-reorganizations are allowed under the U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP)./nShareholders of the firm must agree to a quasi-reorganization before it takes place./nThe main goal of a quasi-reorganization is to bring the retained earnings balance to zero by writing down overvalued assets to their fair value with a direct reduction in retained earnings./nLiabilities are also valued at fair value with any resulting offsets going to the retained earnings deficit./nQuasi-reorganizations are controversial since they are not a change of the economic reality, but rather a method to make books appear more favorable.

Term: Queuing Theory Definition, Elements, and Example
Definition: Queuing theory is the study of the movement of people, objects, or information through a line./nStudying congestion and its causes in a process is used to help create more efficient and cost-effective services and systems./nOften used as an operations management tool, queuing theory can address staffing, scheduling, and customer service shortfalls./nSome queuing is acceptable in business. If there's never a queue, it's a sign of overcapacity./nQueuing theory aims to achieve a balance that is efficient and affordable.

Term: Quick Liquidity Ratio
Definition: The quick liquidity ratio is the total amount of a company’s quick assets divided by the sum of its netliabilities and reinsurance liabilities./nThis calculation is one of the most rigorous ways to determine a debtor's capacity to pay off current debt obligations without needing to raise external capital./nThe quick liquidity ratio is an important measure of an insurance company’s ability to cover its liabilities with relatively liquid assets./nIf an insurer has a high quick liquidity ratio, it’s in a better position to make payments than an insurer with a lower ratio.

Term: Quick Assets
Definition: Current and quick assets are two categories from the balance sheet that analysts use to examine a company’s liquidity./nQuick assets are equal to the summation of a company’s cash and equivalents, marketable securities, and accounts receivable which are all assets that represent or can be easily converted to cash./nQuick assets are considered to be a more conservative measure of a company's liquidity than current assets since it excludes inventories./nThe quick ratio is used to analyze a company's immediate ability to pay its current liabilities without the need to sell its inventory or use financing.

Term: Quick Response (QR) Code: Definition and How QR Codes Work
Definition: Quick response (QR) codes are square-shaped matrices of dark or light pixels that encode and quickly retrieve data using computer devices./nAn enhancement on traditional barcodes, QR codes can store vastly more information and are used in various applications, from supply chain management to cryptocurrency wallet addresses./nSeveral versions and variations of QR codes that are customized for different purposes or can store greater amounts of data now exist.

Term: Quick-Rinse Bankruptcy
Definition: The aim of a quick-rinse bankruptcy is to move through legal proceedings faster than the average bankruptcy./nAll parties involved negotiate terms prior to the bankruptcy proceedings./nThe name quick-rinse bankruptcy was coined in 2008 during the credit crisis and described the bankruptcies of Chrysler and General Motors./nQuick-rank bankruptcies are important because companies in trouble have a limited amount of time before losing customers, working capital, financing sources, suppliers, and vendors./nA quick-rinse bankruptcy differs from a prepackaged bankruptcy in that it comes with the promise of taxpayer financing.

Term: Quick Ratio Formula With Examples, Pros and Cons
Definition: The quick ratio measures a company’s capacity to pay its current liabilities without needing to sell its inventory or obtain additional financing./nThe quick ratio is considered a more conservative measure than the current ratio, which includes all current assets as coverage for current liabilities./nThe quick ratio is calculated by dividing a company’s most liquid assets like cash, cash equivalents, marketable securities, and accounts receivables by total current liabilities./nSpecific current assets such as prepaids and inventory are excluded, as those may not be as easily convertible to cash or may require substantial discounts to liquidate./nThe higher the ratio result, the better a company’s liquidity and financial health; the lower the ratio, the more likely the company will struggle with paying debts.

Term: What Is a Quid? History of the British Pound Sterling (GBP)
Definition: "Quid" is a slang expression for the British pound sterling, or the British pound (GBP), the currency of the United Kingdom (U.K.)./nA quid equals 100 pence./nThe use of the quid began in the late 17thcentury./nThe modern-day pound sterling is no longer comprised of silver.

Term: Quid Pro Quo: Definition, Examples, and Legality
Definition: Quid pro quo describes an agreement between two or more parties in which there is a reciprocal exchange of goods or services./nThe phrase is Latin for "something for something."/nCourts may render a business contract void if it appears unfair or one-sided, and so a quid pro quo consideration is often warranted./nIn politics, quid pro quo agreements may be acceptable as long as they do not imply bribery or any other misappropriation./nEven if a quid pro quo arrangement is legal, it may be perceived as unethical or shady.

Term: Quid Pro Quo Contribution: What It is, How it Works
Definition: A quid quo pro contribution to charity is a contribution for which the donor receives something of value in return./nQuid pro quo contributions are designed to incentivize giving./nAt tax time, the donor must deduct the dollar value of what they received from the full amount of the donation they made; thus, they arrive at the correct sum to claim as a tax deduction.

Term: Quiet Period: Definition, Purpose, Violation Examples
Definition: A quiet period is a set amount of time when a company's management and marketing teams cannot share opinions or additional information about the firm./nThe purpose of the quiet period is to preserve objectivity and avoid the appearance of a company providing insider information to select investors./nWith an IPO, the quiet period stretches from when a company files registration paperwork with U.S. regulators through the 40 days after the stock starts trading./nWith publicly-traded companies, the quiet period refers to the four weeks before the end of the business quarter./nThe JOBS Act created a class of companies—emerging growth companies—doing away with specific quiet periods, notably the 25-day research quiet period.

Term: Quiet Title Action: Definition, How It Works, Uses, and Cost
