Definition: Survivorship bias occurs when only the winners are considered while the losers that have disappeared are not considered./nThis can occur when evaluating mutual fund performance (where merged or defunct funds are not included) or market index performance (where stocks that have been dropped from the index for whatever reason are discarded)./nSurvivorship bias skews the average results upward for the index or surviving funds, causing them to appear to perform better since underperformers have been overlooked.

Term: Sustained Growth Rate (SGR): Definition, Meaning, and Limitations
Definition: The sustainable growth rate (SGR) is the maximum rate of growth that a company can sustain without having to finance growth with additional equity or debt./nCompanies with high SGRs are usually effective in maximizing their sales efforts, focusing on high-margin products, and managing inventory, accounts payable, and accounts receivable./nA high SGR in the long-term can prove difficult for companies due to competition entering the market, changes in economic conditions, and increased research and development./nThe SGR is used by businesses to plan long-term growth, capital acquisitions, cash flow projections, and borrowing strategies./nCompanies looking to grow at a more substantial rate could cut their dividends, but this is a contentious maneuver.

Term: What is Sustainability? How Sustainabilities Work, Benefits, and Example
Definition: Sustainability is ability to maintain or support a process over time./nSustainability is often broken into three core concepts: economic, environmental, and social./nMany businesses and governments have committed to sustainable goals, such as reducing their environmental footprints and conserving resources./nSome investors are actively embracing sustainability investments, known as "green investments."/nSkeptics have accused some companies of "greenwashing," the practice of misleading the public to make a business seem more environmentally friendly than it is.

Term: Swap Execution Facility (SEF): Definition, Goal and How It Works
Definition: Swap execution facilities (SEFs) are trading platforms intended for swaps products./nThey are mandated under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act of 2010./nBecause of the complex nature of swaps, these platforms are not exchanges per se but they do function as a counterparty matching service./nSwaps traded on SEFs fall under the oversight of both the SEC and CFTC./nSwaps volume has increased over the years and now dozens of entities provide SEF platforms.

Term: Swaptions: Guide to Swap Options, With Types and Styles
Definition: Bermudan swaption:the purchaser is allowed to exercise the option and enter into the specified swap on a predetermined set of specific dates./nEuropean swaption:the purchaser is only allowed to exercise the option and enter into the swap on theexpiration dateof the swaption./nAmerican swaption:the purchaser can exercise the option and enter into the swap on any day between the origination of the swap and the expiration date. (There may be a short lockout period after origination.)

Term: Swap Rate: What It Is, How It Works, and Types
Definition: Swap rate denotes the fixed rate that a party to a swap contract requests in exchange for the obligation to pay a short-term rate, such as the Federal Funds rate./nWhen the swap is entered, the fixed rate will be equal to the value of floating-rate payments, calculated from the agreed counter-value./nSwaps are typically quoted in a swap spread, which calculates the difference between the swap rate and counter-party rate.

Term: Swap Definition & How to Calculate Gains
Sweat Equity: What It Is, How It Works, and Example
Definition: Sweat equity is the unpaid labor employees and cash-strapped entrepreneurs put into a project./nHomeowners and real estate investors can use sweat equity to do repairs and maintenance on their own rather than pay for traditional labor./nIn startups, owners and employees typically accept salaries that are below their market values in return for a stake in the company./nWorking for sweat equity comes with more risk than a conventional salary, but higher upsides if the company succeeds./nInrent-to-ownsituations, some landlords may allow renters to gain equity by performing repairs or maintenance that would otherwise be the responsibility of the landlord.

Term: Sweep Accounts Definition: Types and How They Work
Definition: A sweep account automatically transfers cash funds into a safe but higherinterest-earning investment option at the close of each business day, e.g., into a money market fund./nSweep accounts try to minimize cash drag by capitalizing on the immediate availability of higher-interest accounts./nA sweep account service may not always be free and you might have to pay fees to your broker that might make the sweep less attractive on a net basis.

Term: Symmetrical Distribution Defined: What It Tells You and Examples
Definition: A symmetrical distribution is one where splitting the data down the middle produces mirror images./nBell curves are a commonly-cited example of symmetrical distributions./nHaving a symmetrical distribution is useful for analyzing data and making inferences based on statistical techniques./nIn finance, data-generating processes with symmetrical distributions can help inform trading decisions./nReal-world price data, however, tend to exhibit asymmetrical qualities such as right-skewness.

Term: Switching Costs: Definition, Types, and Common Examples
Definition: Switching costs are the costs a consumer pays as a result of switching brands or products./nSwitching costs can be monetary, psychological, effort-based, and time-based./nSwitching costs can be classified as high switching costs or low switching costs./nCompanies seek to employ high switching costs to prevent customers from moving to another brand./nCompanies with difficult-to-perfect products and low competition will use high switching costs to maximize profits./nSome companies who are unable to charge higher dollar amounts for switching will ensure long wait times and product delays, keeping their consumer base via a strictly time-based switching cost.

Term: Swingline Loan: Definition and Use in Business
Definition: A swingline loan is a type of loan that gives borrowers access to a large amount of cash for a short period of time./nA swingline loan can also be used as revolving credit, which is a line of credit that a borrower can repeatedly draw on and pay back./nWhile swingline loans can be accessed on very short notice, they also need to be repaid quickly and tend to have higher interest rates than standard lines of credit.

Term: Syndicate: Definition, How It Works, and Types of Syndicates
Syndicated Loan: What It Is, How It Works, and Examples
Definition: A syndicated loan is financing offered by a syndicate made up of a group of lenders that work together to provide funds for a borrower./nThe borrower can be a corporation, a large project, or a sovereign government./nSyndicated loans involve large sums, which allows the risk to be spread out among several financial institutions to mitigate the risk in case the borrower defaults.

Term: Synergies: Concepts in Finance and Examples
Definition: Synergy is the concept that the value and performance of two companies combined will be greater than the sum of the separate individual parts./nIf two companies can merge to create greater efficiency or scale, the result is what is sometimes referred to as a synergy merge./nThe expected synergy achieved through a merger can be attributed to various factors, such as increased revenues, combined talent and technology, and cost reduction./nIn addition to merging with another company, a company can also create synergy by combining products or markets, such as when one company cross-sells another company's products to increase revenues./nCompanies can also achieve synergy between different departments by setting up cross-disciplinary workgroups in which teams work cooperatively to increase productivity and innovation.

Term: Synthetic: Definition in Finance, Types of Assets
Definition: Synthetic is the term given to financial instruments that are engineered to simulate other instruments while altering key characteristics, like duration and cash flow./nSynthetic positions can allow traders to take a position without laying out the capital to actually buy or sell the asset./nSynthetic products are custom designed investments that are, typically, created for large investors.

Term: Systematic Investment Plan (SIP): Definition and Example
Definition: A systematic investment plan involves investing a consistent sum of money regularly, and usually into the same security./nA SIP generally pulls automatic withdrawals from the funding account and may require extended commitments from the investor./nSIPs operate on the principle of dollar-cost averaging./nMost brokerages and mutual fund companies offer SIPs.

Term: What Is Systemic Risk? Definition in Banking, Causes and Examples
Systematic Sampling: What Is It, and How Is It Used in Research?
Definition: Systematic sampling is a probability sampling method in which a random sample, with a fixed periodic interval, is selected from a larger population./nThe fixed periodic interval, called the sampling interval, is calculated by dividing the population size by the desired sample size./nAdvantages of this methodology include eliminating the phenomenon of clustered selection and a low probability of contaminating data./nDisadvantages include overrepresentation or underrepresentation of particular patterns and a greater risk of data manipulation./nThere are three main types of systematic samples: Random systematic samples, linear systematic samples, and circular systematic samples.

Term: T+1 (T+2, T+3) Explained: Definitions and Settlement Example
Definition: T+1 (or T+2, T+3) are abbreviations that refer to the settlement date of transactions./nThe letter "T" indicates the transaction date; the numbers 1, 2, or 3 denote how many days after the transaction date the settlement takes place./nStocks are T+1, while bonds, mutual funds, and money market funds vary among T+1, T+2, and T+3.

Term: What Is T-Distribution in Probability? How Do You Use It?
Definition: The t-distribution is a continuous probability distribution of the z-score when the estimated standard deviation is used in the denominator rather than the true standard deviation./nThe t-distribution, like the normal distribution, is bell-shaped and symmetric, but it has heavier tails, which means that it tends to produce values that fall far from its mean./nT-tests are used in statistics to estimate significance.

Term: Tactical Asset Allocation (TAA): Definition and Example Portfolio
Definition: Tactical asset allocation involves taking an active stance on the strategic asset allocation itself and adjusting long-term target weights for a short period to capitalize on the market or economic opportunities./nTactical shifts may also come within an asset class./nIn a discretionary TAA, an investor adjusts asset allocation, according to market valuations of the changes in the same market as the investment.

Term: T-Account: Definition, Example, Recording, and Benefits
Definition: A T-account is an informal term for a set of financial records that usedouble-entry bookkeeping./nIt is called a T-account because the bookkeeping entries are laid out in a way that resembles a T-shape./nThe account title appears just above the T. Underneath, debits are listed on the left and credits are recorded on the right, separated by a line./nThe T-account guides accountants on what to enter in a ledger to get an adjusting balance so that revenues equal expenses.

Term: What Is the Taft-Hartley Act?
Definition: The Taft-Hartley Act was introduced after several major strikes in 1945 and 1946./nThe Act of 1947 prohibits certain union practices and requires that they disclose their financial and political activities./nThough the legislation was vetoed by Harry S. Truman, the vote was overridden by both the House and Senate and became law./nThis act is also known as the Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA) and is an amendment to the 1935 Wagner Act./nThe Taft-Hartley Act has had six amendments including more recent updates to right-to-work laws.

Term: T-Test: What It Is With Multiple Formulas and When To Use Them
Definition: A t-test is an inferential statistic used to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two variables./nThe t-test is a test used for hypothesis testing in statistics./nCalculating a t-test requires three fundamental data values including the difference between the mean values from each data set, the standard deviation of each group, and the number of data values./nT-tests can be dependent or independent.

Term: How Tag-Along (vs. Drag-Along) Rights Work, With an Example
Definition: Tag-along rights are contractual obligations to protect a minority investor in a startup or company./nTag-along rights are mainly used to ensure that the stake of minority stakeholders is considered during a company sale./nTag-along rights also provide greater liquidity to minority shareholders./nThe minority investors are entitled to the same price and conditions as the majority investor when the shares are sold./nTag-along rights can sometimes make it more difficult for a sale to be completed.

Term: Taguchi Method of Quality Control: Definition, Example, and Uses
Definition: In engineering, the Taguchi method of quality control focuses on design and development to create efficient, reliable products./nIts founder, Genichi Taguchi, considers design to be more important than the manufacturing process in quality control and seeks to eliminate variances in production before they can occur./nCompanies such as Toyota, Ford, Boeing, and Xerox have adopted this method.

Term: Understanding Tail Risk and the Odds of Portfolio Losses
Definition: Tail risk is the chance of a loss occurring due to a rare event, as predicted by a probability distribution./nColloquially, a short-term move of more than three standard deviations is considered to instantiate tail risk./nWhile tail risk technically refers to both the left and right tails, people are most concerned with losses (the left tail)./nTail events have had experts questions the true probability distribution of returns for investable assets.

Term: What Is Takaful Insurance and How Does It Work?
Definition: Takaful is a type of Islamic insurance wherein members contribute money into a pool system to guarantee each other./nTakaful-branded insurance is based on sharia or Islamic religious law and covers health, life, and general insurance needs./nAny claims made by participants are paid out of the takaful fund.

Term: Take or Pay: What It Means and How It Works in Contracts
Definition: Take or pay is a type of provision in a purchase contract that guarantees the seller a minimum portion of the agreed-on payment if the buyer does not follow through with actually buying the full amount of goods./nTake-or-pay provisions can commonly be found in the energy sector, where overhead costs are high./nTake-or-pay provisions benefit buyers, sellers, and the economy as a whole by sharing the risk of overhead investment and facilitating commerce that might otherwise not occur.

Term: Take-Profit Order (TP): Definition, Use in Trading, and Example
Definition: Take-profit (T/P) orders are limit orders that are closed when a specified profit level is reached./nLimit prices for T/P orders are placed using either fundamental or technical analysis./nTake-profit orders are beneficial for short-term traders interested in profiting from a quick bump in the security costs.

Term: Take-Out Loan: Definition, Uses in Real Estate, Example
Definition: A take-out loan provides a long-term mortgage or loan on a property that "takes out" an existing loan./nThe take-out loan will replace interim financing, such as replacing a construction loan with a fixed-term mortgage./nIf the take-out loan is used to finance a rental or income-generating property, the take-out lender may be entitled to a portion of the rents earned.

Term: What Is a Tangible Asset? Comparison to Non-Tangible Assets
Definition: Tangible assets are items with a real physical form that may depreciate in value over time./nTangible assets are recorded on the balance sheet, usually as a long-term asset./nTangible assets are usually less liquid than intangible assets, items that you can't touch./nThough tangible assets usually have real world value, they are also associated with potentially higher expenses or risks such as storage, insurance, and obsolescence./nExamples of tangible assets include land, buildings, machinery, or inventory.

Term: What Is a Takeover? Definition, How They're Funded, and Example
Definition: A takeover occurs when an acquiring company successfully closes on a bid to assume control of or acquire a target company./nTakeovers are typically initiated by a larger company seeking to take over a smaller one./nTakeovers can be welcome and friendly, or they may be unwelcome and hostile./nCompanies may initiate takeovers because they find value in a target company, they want to initiate change, or they may want to eliminate the competition.

Term: Tangible Book Value Per Share (TBVPS): Definition and Formula
Definition: Tangible book value per share (TBVPS) is the value of a company’s tangible assets divided by its current outstanding shares./nTBVPS determines the potential value per share of a company in the event that it must liquidate its assets./nAssets such as property and equipment are considered tangible assets. Intangible assets, such as goodwill, are not included in the calculation of TBVPS./nOne of the criticisms of TBVPS’s validity is the lack of accuracy in the accounting of a company’s tangible assets.

Term: Tangible Net Worth: Definition, Meaning, Formula & Calculation
Definition: Tangible net worth is typically the net worth of a company excluding intangible assets such as copyrights, patents, and intellectual property./nThe tangible net worth calculation for a company is total assets minus total liabilities minus intangible assets./nTangible net worth can also be calculated for individuals, using the same formula of total tangible assets minus total debt liabilities.

Term: Tangible Common Equity (TCE): Definition, Calculation and Example
Definition: Tangible common equity (TCE) is a measure of a company's physical capital, which is used to evaluate a financial institution's ability to deal with potential losses./nMeasuring a company's TCE is particularly useful for evaluating companies that have large amounts of preferred stock, such as U.S. banks that received federal bailout money in the 2008 financial crisis./nThe TCE ratio (TCE divided by tangible assets) is a measure of capital adequacy at a bank. This ratio measures a firm's tangible common equity in terms of the firm's tangible assets.

Term: Tape Reading? What It Was and How Traders Used It and Modern Day
Definition: Tape reading was the way that day traders used to analyze the price and volume of a given stock before the technology was replaced./nA stock's ticker symbol, price, and volume were sent over telegraph lines via ticker tape./nWhile tape reading was phased out in the 1960s, similar strategies are used by electronic traders, and many of the terms originating from the time are still widely used.

Term: What Is Tangible Personal Property and How Is It Taxed?
Definition: Tangible personal property is personal property that can be felt or touched and physically relocated./nExamples include office equipment, livestock, jewelry, toys, light trucks, and buses./nIn several countries, including many states in the U.S., tangible personal property is subject to ad valorem taxes./nThese taxes vary considerably, may not apply to all types of tangible personal property, and are exempt in some states.

Term: Taper Tantrum of 2013: What It Is and What Caused It
Definition: Taper tantrum refers to the 2013 collective reactionary panic that triggered a spike in U.S. Treasury yields, after investors learned that the Federal Reserve was slowly putting the brakes on its quantitative easing (QE) program./nThe main worry behind the taper tantrum stemmed from fears that the market would crumble, as the result of the cessation of QE./nIn the end, the taper tantrum panic was unjustified, as the market continued to recover after the tapering program began.

Term: Tapering: How, Why, and When the Fed Does It and Impact on Financial Markets
Definition: Tapering is the reversal of quantitative easing policies, implemented by a central bank and intended to stimulate economic growth./nTapering refers specifically to the reduction of central bank assets./nFinancial markets may experience a downturn in response to tapering, known as a "taper tantrum."

Term: What Is a Target-Date Fund? Risk Tolerance and Example
Definition: A target-date fund is a class of mutual funds or ETFs that periodically rebalances asset class weights to optimize risk and returns for a predetermined time frame./nThe asset allocation of a target-date fund is typically designed to gradually shift to a more conservative profile so as to minimize risk when the target date approaches./nThe appeal of target-date funds is that they offer investors the convenience of putting their investing activities on autopilot in one vehicle./nTarget-date funds usually mature in 5-year intervals, such as 2035, 2040, and 2045./nWhile relatively more expensive than other types of mutual fund, expense ratios on target-date funds have come down significantly in recent years.

Term: What Is a Tariff and Why Are They Important?
Definition: Governments impose tariffs to raise revenue, protect domestic industries, or exert political leverage over another country./nTariffs often result in unwanted side effects, such as higher consumer prices./nTariffs have a long and contentious history, and the debate over whether they represent good or bad policy still rages.

Term: Target Market: Definition, Purpose, Examples, Market Segments
Definition: A target market is a group of customers with shared demographics who have been identified as the most likely buyers of a company's product or service./nIdentifying the target market is important in the development and implementation of a successful marketing plan for any new product./nThe target market also can inform a product's specifications, packaging, and distribution.

Term: Targeted Accrual Redemption Note (TARN): What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A targeted accrual redemption note (TARN) is an index-linked derivative containing a target cap./nThe cap refers to the maximum amount of accumulated coupon payments received./nOnce the cap has been reached, the note automatically terminates./nFX-TARNS are linked to an index of currencies rather than equities.

Term: Tax Accounting: Definition, Types, vs. Financial Accounting
Definition: Tax accounting is the subsector of accounting that deals with the preparations of tax returns and tax payments./nTax accounting is used by individuals, businesses, corporations and other entities./nTax accounting for an individual focuses on income, qualifying deductions, donations, and any investment gains or losses./nFor a business, tax accounting is more complex, with greater scrutiny regarding how funds are spent and what is or isn't taxable.

Term: What Is Tax Avoidance and How Is It Different From Tax Evasion?
Definition: Tax avoidance is any legal method used by a taxpayer to minimize the amount of income tax owed./nIndividual taxpayers and corporations can use forms of tax avoidance to lower their tax bills./nTax credits, deductions, income exclusion, and loopholes are forms of tax avoidance./nThese are legal tax breaks offered to encourage certain behaviors, such as saving for retirement or buying a home./nTax avoidance is unlike tax evasion, which relies on illegal methods such as underreporting income.

Term: Tax-Advantaged: Definition, Account Types, and Benefits
Definition: Tax-advantaged refers to favorable tax status held by certain qualified investments, accounts, or other financial vehicles./nInvestors of different financial situations can benefit from tax-advantaged investments and accounts./nCommon examples include municipal bonds, 401(k) or 403(b) accounts, 529 plans, and certain types of partnerships./nTax-deferred status means that pre-tax income is used to fund an investment where taxes will be paid at a later date and at tax rates at that time./nTax-exempt status uses after-tax money to fund investments where gains or income produced by them are not subject to ordinary income tax.

Term: What Is a Tax Base? Definition, Formula, and Examples
Definition: A tax base is the overall value of assets, income, and economic activity that is subject to taxation./nIndividual income taxes are the main source of revenue for the U.S. government./nAdditional revenue comes from business and corporate taxes, excise taxes, customs duties, and even fees paid for entrance to national parks./nAll of those sources combined add up to the tax base of the United States./nIn fiscal year 2023, the federal government collected $4.44 trillion from its tax base.

Term: Tax Benefit: Definition, Types, and IRS Rules
Definition: Tax benefits create savings for individual and business taxpayers./nCommon tax benefits include deductions, credits, exclusions, and shelters./nYou can take standard or itemized deductions plus any available above-the-line deductions./nTo qualify for tax benefits, you must meet specific requirements, such as income limits, filing status, and dependent status./nBe sure to stay abreast of any tax benefits you may be eligible for so you don't miss out on tax savings.

Term: 2023-2024 Tax Brackets and Federal Income Tax Rates
Definition: There are currently seven federal tax brackets in the United States, with rates ranging from 10% to 37%./nThe U.S. tax system is progressive, with people in lower brackets taxed at lower rates and those in higher brackets taxed at higher ones./nUnless your total income fits in just the lowest tax bracket, you are charged at multiple rates, according to the additional brackets into which your income flows./nTypically, the IRS adjusts tax brackets for inflation every year./nThere are numerous legal ways to lower your taxes, including lowering your taxable income via contributions to retirement accounts and taking advantage of tax credits you may be eligible for.

Term: Tax-Deductible Interest: Definition and Types That Qualify
Definition: Interest is the amount of money you pay a lender to borrow money./nTheInternal Revenue Service (IRS)allows taxpayers to deduct several interest expenses, including home mortgage interest and student loan interest./nYou can itemize investment interest and qualified mortgage interest (including points if you’re the buyer) on Schedule A of Form 1040 or 1040-SR./nThe student loan interest deduction is an adjustment to income on yourtax return, so you don’t need to itemize to take it./nSome interest is not tax deductible, such as that you pay on personal car loans and credit card balances.

Term: Tax Credit: What It Is, How It Works, What Qualifies, 3 Types
Definition: A tax credit is an amount of money that taxpayers can subtract, dollar for dollar, from the income taxes they owe./nTax credits are more favorable than tax deductions because they reduce the tax due, not just the amount of taxable income./nThere are three basic types of tax credits: nonrefundable, refundable, and partially refundable./nNonrefundable tax credits can reduce the tax you owe to zero, but they don’t provide refunds./nRefundable credits are paid out in full, providing a refund for any remaining tax credit amount beyond zero tax due.

Term: Tax Break Definition, Different Types, How to Get One
Definition: Tax breaks such as credits and deductions lower your total tax liability./nTax breaks are the product of tax laws designed to strengthen the economy or promote specific policy goals./nTax breaks are also specifically designed to promote specific economic activity (i.e. there are tax incentives for getting a secondary education)./nA tax credit offsets your tax liability on a dollar-for-dollar basis, and some refundable tax credits may reduce your liability below $0 and into a refund./nA tax deduction reduces the amount of gross income that is subject to taxes.

Term: Tax Deferred: Earnings With Taxes Delayed Until Liquidation
Definition: Tax-deferred status refers to investment earnings, such as interest, dividends, or capital gains, that accumulate tax-free until the investor takes constructive receipt of the profits./nAn investor benefits from the tax-free growth of earnings with tax-deferred investments/nThe tax savings can be substantial when investments are held until retirement./nA 401(k) plan is an example of a tax-deferred vehicle. It's a tax-qualified defined contribution account offered by employers to help grow their employees’ retirement savings.

Term: Tax Deed: Definition, How to Clear It, and Tax Deed Sales
Definition: A tax deed grants ownership of a property to a government body when the owner fails to pay the associated property taxes./nTax deeds are sold to the highest bidder at auction for a minimum bid of the outstanding taxes plus interest and the costs associated with the sale./nSuccessful bidders have a minimum amount of time to pay for the purchase—usually 48 to 72 hours./nAt the close of the auction, the county receives the total delinquent tax assessment, and the former owner receives the net proceeds after taxes and penalties./nProperty owners may file a claim to receive any amount paid to the municipality in excess of the property taxes plus interest.

Term: Understanding Tax Deductions: Itemized vs. Standard Deduction
Definition: Tax deductions are subtracted from your taxable income, thereby lowering the amount of tax you owe./nYou can choose the standard deduction or itemize your deductions on Schedule A of Form 1040 or 1040-SR./nThe Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) nearly doubled the standard deduction and improved several tax deductions./nThe TCJA also eliminated or limited many itemized deductions, including the mortgage interest deduction./nIf you itemize your deductions, be sure to keep receipts to substantiate your expenses.

Term: What Is Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 (TEFRA)?
Definition: The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 was the biggest tax increase in U.S. history, when adjusted for inflation./nThe legislation quickly followed the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, which was the biggest tax cut in U.S. history./nFollowing the passage of ERTA, the U.S. fell into the second half of a "double-dip" recession, and the U.S. budget deficit was soaring./nTEFRA supporters said its aim was to close tax loopholes introducing stricter compliance and tax-collection measures, rather than raise taxes./nTEFRA also rescinded some ERTA reductions in personal income-tax rates that had not yet gone into effect.

Term: Tax Evasion: Meaning, Definition, and Penalties
Definition: Tax evasion can be either the illegal non-payment or the illegal underpayment of actual tax liabilities due./nTax evasion can be determined by the IRS regardless of whether or not tax forms were filed with the agency./nTo determine tax evasion, the agency must be able to show that the avoidance of taxes was willful on the part of the taxpayer./nWhile tax evasion is illegal, tax avoidance includes finding legal ways (within the law) to reduce taxpayer obligations.

Term: Tax-Equivalent Yield Explained: Definition, Calculation, Examples
Definition: The tax-equivalent yield is the return that a taxable bond needs to possess for its yield to equal the yield on a comparable tax-exempt bond, such as a municipal bond./nThis calculation is a tool investors can use to compare the returns between a tax-free investment and a taxable alternative./nTax implications are a complicated and important part of any financial strategy, as well as an often overlooked part.

Term: Tax-Exempt Interest Definition and Examples
Definition: Tax-exempt interest refers to interest income that is not subject to taxation, most notably at the federal level./nSome municipal bonds may also be "triple-exempt", where tax is not paid at the federal, state, nor local level./nTax-exempt interest may also be earned in Roth retirement accounts as well as some other tax-advantaged products and accounts.

Term: What Is Tax Fraud? Definition, Criteria, Vs. Tax Avoidance
Definition: Tax fraud costs the government millions of dollars a year./nTax fraud is a different issue than tax avoidance or negligence./nFailing to report and pay payroll taxes is an example of business tax fraud.

Term: Tax Expense: Definition, Calculation, and Effect on Earnings
Definition: Tax expenses are the total amount of taxes owed by an individual, corporation, or other entity to a taxing authority./nIncome tax expense is calculated by multiplying taxable income by the effective tax rate./nOther taxes may be levied against an asset's value, such as property or estate taxes.

Term: What Does It Mean to Be Tax-Exempt or Have Tax-Exempt Income?
Definition: Tax-exempt status allows a taxpayer to file a return with the IRS that exempts them from paying taxes on any net income or profit./nA taxpayer can offset capital gains and avoid taxes on disposed assets, though this often allows a taxpayer to be exempt up to their current or prior losses./nTaxpayers who avoid taxes may still be required to pay alternative minimum taxes./nMost commonly, organizations gain tax-exempt status by requesting the status from the IRS./nTo maintain the status, organizations must meet ongoing filing and reporting requirements.

Term: Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA): Definition and Calculation
Definition: Tax-free savings accounts are a type of tax-advantaged account available to Canadian residents age 18 or older./nTFSAs let you save money on taxes because the gains on investments in the account are not taxed and withdrawals are tax free./nTFSAs have annual contribution limits called contribution room./nContributions less than the annual limit leave a carryover amount that can be added to the next year's allowed contribution./nCarryovers are retroactive back to the year that TFSAs were created, 2009.

Term: What Is a Tax Identification Number (TIN)?
Definition: Tax identification numbers are nine-digit tracking numbers used by the IRS./nThe IRS issues all U.S. tax I.D. numbers except for Social Security numbers, issued by the Social Security Administration./nTax filers must include their TIN on tax-related documents and when claiming benefits.

Term: Tax Incidence: Definition, Example, and How It Works
Definition: A tax incidence describes a case when buyers and sellers divide a tax burden./nA tax incidence will also lay out who bears the burden of a new tax, for instance among producers and consumers, or among various class segments of a population./nThe elasticity of demand of a good can help determine the tax incidence among parties.

Term: Tax Haven: Definition, Examples, Advantages, and Legality
Definition: Tax havens encourage foreign depositors by offering tax advantages to corporations and the wealthy./nMany have secrecy laws that block information on their deposits from foreign tax authorities./nDepositing money in a tax haven is legal as long as the depositor pays the taxes required by the home jurisdiction.

Term: What Is a Tax Holiday? How They Work, Examples, and Effectiveness
Definition: A tax holiday is a governmental incentive that temporarily reduces or eliminates taxes for consumers or businesses./nThe objective of a tax holiday is to encourage economic activity and foster growth./nTax holidays may also be offered to businesses as an investment incentive./nThere is ongoing debate about whether the benefits of tax holidays justify their costs./nSome states that have offered sales tax holidays in the recent past have canceled them amid political opposition.

Term: Tax Liability: Definition, Calculation, and Example
Definition: Tax liability is the total amount of tax debt owed to a government by an individual, corporation, or other entity./nIncome taxes, sales tax, and capital gains tax are all forms of tax liabilities./nTaxes are imposed by various taxing authorities, including federal, state, and local governments. Taxes generate the funds to pay for services such as repairing roads and maintaining a military./nYou can lower your tax liabilities by claiming deductions, exemptions, and tax credits.

Term: Tax Lien: Meaning, How to Resolve With IRS
Definition: If a taxpayer does not respond to a demand for payment, the government may place a lien on the person's assets./nThe lien may be removed if the taxpayer agrees to a payment plan or takes other action with the agreement of the government./nIf no attempt to repay is made, the government may seize the assets for sale.

Term: Tax Loss Carryforwards: How They Work, Types, and Examples
Definition: A tax loss carryforward allows taxpayers to use a loss from one year to offset income in future years./nThere are two types of tax loss carryforwards: net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards and capital loss carryforwards./nNet operating loss carryforwards apply to businesses./nCapital loss carryforwards can apply to either businesses or individuals, although the rules work differently.

Term: What Is a Tax Lien Certificate? How They're Sold in Investing
Definition: Tax lien certificates are documents that represent a legal claim against a property with unpaid property taxes./nThe local government may place a lien on a property when taxes are in default./nThe local government may choose to sell the tax lien certificate to an investor; in this manner, the government is able to receive funds as originally intended./nAn investor that receives a tax lien certificates collects a legal claim against the property for the amount paid./nThe investor may receive funds back if property taxes are eventually paid; they often receive revenue via a penalty charged as an interest rate to the defaulter.

Term: Tax-Loss Harvesting: Definition and Example
Definition: Tax-loss harvesting is a strategy investors can use to reduce capital gains taxes owed from selling profitable investments./nA tax-loss harvesting strategy involves selling an asset or security at a net loss./nYou can use proceeds from a sale to purchase a similar asset and maintain the portfolio balance.

Term: Tax Planning: What It Is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: Tax planning is the analysis of a financial situation or plan to ensure that all elements work together to allow you to pay the lowest taxes possible./nConsiderations of tax planning include the timing of income, size, the timing of purchases, and planning for expenditures./nTax planning strategies can include saving for retirement in an IRA or engaging in tax gain-loss harvesting.

Term: Tax Rate Definition, Effective Tax Rates, and Tax Brackets
Definition: A tax rate is a percentage at which the income of an individual or corporation is taxed./nThe U.S. imposes a progressive taxation on income, where the higher the income, the greater the percentage of tax that is levied./nThe U.S. applies its tax rates in marginal increments, so taxpayers may pay an effective tax rate lower than their top bracket rate./nTax rates are also applied as sales tax on goods and services or as capital gains tax on investments./nOther nations charge a flat tax rate or a regressive tax rate.

Term: Tax Reform Act of 1986: Overview and History
Definition: The Tax Reform Act of 1986 was a comprehensive tax reform legislation that was passed into law by President Ronald Reagan./nThe law effectively lowered the top marginal tax bracket income tax rates while eliminating several loopholes./nThe 1986 reform was followed up by subsequent bills in 1993 and later.

Term: What Is a Tax Refund? Definition and When to Expect It
Definition: If you get a tax refund, then you likely overpaid your taxes during the previous tax year./nYou may also receive a refund if you qualify for a refundable tax credit, such as the Earned Income Tax Credit, premium tax credit, or Child Tax Credit./nEmployees can avoid overpaying by accurately filling out their W-4s and ensuring that the information is current./nSelf-employed taxpayers can avoid overpaying by estimating their quarterly taxes with greater accuracy./nA tax bill is the opposite of a tax refund, which you owe if your employer didn't withhold enough taxes from your pay.

Term: What Is Tax Relief? How It Works, Types, and Example
Definition: Various types of tax relief can help you lower your tax bill or settle tax-related debts./nTax deductions let you deduct certain expenses (such as home mortgage interest) from your taxable income, thereby lowering the amount of tax you owe./nTax credits directly reduce your tax bill and may provide a refund even if you don't owe any tax./nThe IRS Fresh Start program helps individuals and businesses settle back taxes and avoid tax liens.

Term: What Is a Tax Return, and How Long Must You Keep Them?
Definition: A tax return is a documentation filed with a tax authority that reports income, expenses, and other relevant financial information./nOn tax returns, taxpayers calculate their tax liability, schedule tax payments, or request refunds for the overpayment of taxes./nIn most places, tax returns must be filed annually.

Term: When Is Tax Season? Definition, Dates, and Deadlines
Definition: For the current tax season, you should receive all the forms detailing your 2023 taxable income by the end of January 2024./nTax Day is Monday, April 15, 2024./nBy the end of January, employees should have received a W-2, Wage and Tax Statement recording their income and taxes paid during the previous year. Independent contractors should receive a Form 1099./nIf you have an account with a broker, you should receive a Form 1099-B./nIf you're on Social Security, the government will send you a Form 1099.

Term: Tax Selling: What it is, How it Works, Tax Benefits
Definition: Tax selling is when an investor sells an asset at a capital loss in order to lower or eliminate the capital gain realized by other investments, for income tax purposes./nA wash sale is when an investor sells an asset through a broker in order to realize a loss, but simultaneously repurchases the same asset from another broker within 30 days of the sale./nThe IRS prohibits wash sales.

Term: Tax Shelter: Definition, Examples, and Legal Issues
Definition: A tax shelter is a place to legally store assets so that current or future tax liabilities are minimized./nA tax shelter is a tax minimization strategy, and should not be confused with the illegal practice of tax evasion./nTax shelters may permanently reduce the amount of tax a taxpayer owes or may simply defer the taxes owed to a future period./nA tax shelter is also different than a tax haven, as tax havens are often more secretive and less transparent./nQualified retirement accounts, certain insurance products, partnerships, municipal bonds, and real estate investments are all examples of potential tax shelters.

Term: Tax-Sheltered Annuity: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: A tax-sheltered annuity allows employees to invest income before taxes into a retirement plan./nTSA plans are offered to employees of public schools and tax-exempt organizations./nThe IRS taxes the withdrawals, but not the contributions into the tax-sheltered annuity./nBecause employers can contribute to TSA plans, employees have the benefit of additional tax-free funds accruing./nCharities, religious organizations, and other nonprofits can qualify to offer employees tax-sheltered annuities.

Term: Tax Shield: Definition, Formula for Calculation, and Example
Definition: A tax shield allows an individual or corporation to reduce taxable income./nTax shields are achieved through claiming allowable deductions, such as mortgage interest, medical expenses, charitable donations, amortization, and depreciation./nTax shields lower the amount of taxes an individual or business taxpayer owes.

Term: Tax Table Definition
Definition: A tax table is a chart that displays the amount of tax due based on income received./nThe IRS provides tax tables to help taxpayers determine how much tax they owe and how to calculate it when they file their annual tax returns./nTax tables are divided by income ranges and filing status./nTax tables are commonly used by individual and corporate taxpayers with modest income levels while high-income earners use more detailed tax rate schedules./nTax tables are updated by the IRS every year.

Term: What Is the Tax-to-GDP Ratio? What Is a Good One?
Definition: The tax-to-GDP ratio measures a nation's tax revenue relative to the size of its economy./nThis ratio is used with other metrics to determine how well a nation's government directs its economic resources through taxation./nDeveloped nations typically have higher tax-to-GDP ratios than developing nations./nHigher tax revenues mean a country can spend more on improving infrastructure, health, and education, all of which are keys to the long-term prospects for a country's economy and people./nTax revenues above 15% of a country's gross domestic product (GDP) are a key ingredient for economic growth and poverty reduction, according to the World Bank.

Term: What Is a Tax Treaty Between Countries & How Does It Work?
Definition: A tax treaty is a bilateral (two-party) agreement made by two countries to resolve issues involving double taxation of passive and active income of each of their respective citizens./nWhen an individual or business invests in a foreign country, the issue of which country should tax the investor’s earnings may arise./nBoth countries may enter into a tax treaty to agree on which country should tax the investment income to prevent the same income from getting taxed twice./nSome countries are seen as being tax havens; these countries typically do not enter into tax treaties.

Term: Tax Wedge: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: The tax wedge is the net difference in gross income and net income after taxes have been deducted./nIn progressive tax systems, the tax wedge increases on a marginal basis as income increases./nEconomists propose that a tax wedge creates market inefficiencies by artificially shifting the true price of labor as well as goods and services.

Term: Taxable Wage Base: Overview and Example
Definition: The taxable wage base is the maximum amount of earned income on which employees must pay Social Security taxes./nThe taxable wage base is also known as the Social Security wage base./nThe maximum amount of income that taxpayers must pay Social Security tax on is $160,200 in 2023 and $168,600 in 2024./nHalf of the Social Security tax is paid by the employer, while half is paid by the employee./nSome state unemployment agencies use a taxable wage base to calculate unemployment taxes.

Term: Taxable Income: What It Is, What Counts, and How to Calculate
Definition: Taxable income is the portion of your gross income that the IRS deems subject to taxes./nIt consists of both earned and unearned income./nTaxable income comes from compensation, businesses, partnerships, and royalties, among other sources./nTaxable income is generally less than adjusted gross income because of deductions that reduce it./nYou can begin calculating your taxable income by determining your filing status and gathering the documents related to all your income sources.

Term: Taxation Without Representation: What It Means and History
Definition: Taxation without representation was possibly the first slogan adopted by American colonists chafing under British rule./nThey objected to the imposition of taxes on colonists by a government that gave them no role in its policies./nIn the 21st century, the people of the District of Columbia are citizens who endure taxation without representation.

Term: Taxpayer: Definition, Overview and Types
Definition: A taxpayer may be an individual or business entity that is obligated to pay taxes to a federal, state, or local government./nTaxes from both individuals and businesses are a primary source of revenue for governments./nIndividuals and businesses have different annual income tax obligations.

Term: Taxation Defined, With Justifications and Types of Taxes
Definition: Taxation occurs when a government or other authority requires that a fee be paid by citizens and corporations, to that authority./nThe fee is involuntary, and as opposed to other payments, not linked to any specific services that have been or will be provided./nTax occurs on physical assets, including property and transactions, such as a sale of stock, or a home./nTypes of taxes include income, corporate, capital gains, property, inheritance, and sales.

Term: What Is a Tax Identification Number (TIN)?
Definition: Tax identification numbers are nine-digit tracking numbers used by the IRS./nThe IRS issues all U.S. tax I.D. numbers except for Social Security numbers, issued by the Social Security Administration./nTax filers must include their TIN on tax-related documents and when claiming benefits.

Term: Taylor Rule Definition
Definition: The Taylor Rule is a formula tying a central bank's policy rate to inflation and economic growth./nDeveloped by economist John Taylor in 1993, it assumes an equilibrium federal funds rate 2% above the annual inflation rate./nThe Taylor Rule adjusts the equilibrium rate based on divergence in inflation and real GDP growth from the central bank's targets./nOvershoots of inflation and growth targets raise the policy rate under the Taylor Rule, while shortfalls lower it./nThe basic Taylor Rule formula doesn't account for the ineffectiveness of negative interest rates or for alternative monetary policy tools like asset purchases./nThe Taylor Rule formula makes inflation the single most important factor in setting rates, while the Federal Reserve has a dual mandate to promote stable prices and maximum employment.

Term: Teacher Retirement System (TRS): What It Is And How It Works
Definition: The Teacher Retirement System (TRS) is a network of organizations at the state level that primarily administers pensions and other retirement plans for educators./nThe benefits offered by TRSs include traditional defined-benefit pensions along with defined-contribution plans including 403(b) plans, which resemble 401(k)s./nThe specific benefits of TRS plans vary widely by state and even by the school district./nStudies show that most teachers don't receive their full pensions.

Term: TIAA: Definition, History, and Retirement Products
Definition: TIAA is an acronym for the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association./nTIAA is led by Thasunda Brown Duckett, its president and CEO./nIt is a for-profit financial institution that provides pension, insurance, and investment services, mainly for teachers and their families./nTIAA was formerly also part of the College Retirement Equities Fund (CREF), which spun off as a separate entity in 2016.

Term: Technical Analysis: What It Is and How to Use It in Investing
Definition: Technical analysis is atrading disciplineemployed to evaluate investments and identify trading opportunities in price trends and patterns seen on charts./nTechnical analysts believe past trading activity and price changes of a security can be valuable indicators of the security's future price movements./nTechnical analysis may be contrasted with fundamental analysis, which focuses on a company's financials rather than historical price patterns or stock trends.

Term: Technical Analyst or Chartist: One Who Uses Technical Analysis
Definition: Technical analysts, also known as chartists or technicians, employ technical analysis in their trading and research./nTechnical analysis looks for price patterns and trends based on historical performance to identify signals based on market sentiment and psychology./nTechnical analysts may augment their training and education by earning the chartered market technician (CMT) professional designation.

Term: Technical Indicator: Definition, Analyst Uses, Types and Examples
Definition: Technical indicators are heuristic or mathematical calculations based on the price, volume, or open interest of a security or contract used by traders who follow technical analysis./nTechnical analysts or chartists look for technical indicators in historical asset price data to judge entry and exit points for trades./nThere are several technical indicators that fall broadly into two main categories: overlays and oscillators.

Term: Technical Job Skills: Overview and Examples
Definition: Technical skills are practical abilities that an employee possesses that help a firm achieve its functions./nThese skills are obtained and honed through education, practice, and repetition, and may be either manual (e.g. sewing) or cognitive (e.g. accounting)./nUnlike "soft skills," people can prove their technical competencies by taking an aptitude test or providing certification, a degree, an apprenticeship, or work experience.

Term: Technical Skills You Should List on Your Resume
Definition: Technical skills are sets of abilities or knowledge used to perform practical tasks in the areas of science, the arts, technology, engineering, and math./nTechnical skills typically require the use of certain tools and the technologies required to use those tools./nIn finance, technical skills may refer to traders and analysts who follow the procedures of technical analysis, using charts, indicators, and patterns to generate buy and sell signals./nIn most cases, the acquisition of advanced technical skills requires specialized training or education, which takes both time and resources./nTechnical skill requirements are listed for most career fields.

Term: What Is Technocracy? Definition, How It Works, and Critiques
Definition: A technocracy is a form of governance whereby government officials or policymakers, known as technocrats, are chosen by some higher authority due to their technical skills or expertise in a specific domain./nDecisions made by technocrats are supposed to be based on information derived from data and objective methodology, rather than opinion or self-interest./nCritics complain that technocracy is undemocratic and disregards the will of the people.

Term: What Is the Technology, Media and, Telecom (TMT) Sector?
Definition: The technology, media, and telecom (TMT) sector is an industry grouping that includes companies focused on new technologies./nThe TMT sector includes a wide range of companies that depend on research & development (R&D)./nBy getting in early on stocks in the TMT industry, growth investors hope to achieve higher returns./nSince the TMT segment is so broad, it's often divided into subsectors, including hardware, semiconductors, software, media, and telecom.

Term: Technology Sector: Definition, 4 Major Sectors, Investing in Tech
Definition: The technology sector is comprised of businesses that sell goods and services in electronics, software, computers, artificial intelligence, and other industries related to information technology (IT)./nTech companies invest heavily in research and development and may undertake riskier projects with greater future potential./nTech companies run social media platforms like Facebook, X platform (formerly Twitter), and Instagram./nCompanies rely on the technology sector to help them grow and thrive./nThe technology sector is often one of the most attractive growth investments in an economy.

Term: Temporal Method: What it Means, Examples
Definition: The temporal method is used to convert the currency of a foreign subsidiary into the same currency as the parent company./nThe parent company's currency is called the functional currency./nThe currency translation technique allows the parent company to report profits or losses and file financial statements when it has subsidiaries outside of the country where it is domiciled./nGains or losses due to exchange rate conversions are reported in the parent company's net earnings.

Term: What Is the TED Spread? Definition, How It's Used and Calculation
Definition: The TED spread is the difference between the three-month LIBOR and the three-month Treasury bill rate./nThe TED spread is commonly used as a measure of credit risk, as U.S. Treasury bills are seen as risk-free./nThe TED spread often widens in periods of economic crisis, as the default risk widens; the spread narrows when the economy is more stable and defaults are less of a risk.

Term: Telegraphic Transfer (TT): What It Is and How It's Processed
Definition: A telegraphic transfer is an electronic method of transferring funds, used primarily for overseas wire transactions./nTelegraphic transfers are used most often with Clearing House Automated Payment System (CHAPS) transfers in the U.K. banking system./nTypically, a telegraphic transfer is complete within two to four business days, depending on the origin and destination of the transfer, as well as any currency-exchange requirements./nTelegraphic transfers are also known as telex transfers (TT), or more generically as wire transfers or electronic funds transfers.

Term: Tenancy at Sufferance: Legal Definition, Vs. Tenancy at Will
Definition: Tenancy at sufferance refers to holdover tenants of an expired lease who no longer have the landlord's permission to remain in the property, but who have not yet been evicted./nThe term sufferance means the absence of objection without genuine approval./nA holdover tenant at sufferance may be subject to eviction, and depending on state law may be accused of trespassing.

Term: Tenancy-at-Will: Definition, How It Works, Protections, and Rules
Definition: A tenancy-at-will is an agreement between a landlord and a tenant without a written agreement./nThis type of tenancy doesn't specify its duration or the exchange of payment./nA tenancy-at-will can be terminated at any time by either party./nTenants and landlords may find these types of arrangements attractive because they're flexible and allow for changes to rentals without breaking a contract.

Term: What Is Tenancy by the Entirety? Requirements and Rights
Definition: Tenancy by the entirety is a form of property ownership reserved only for married couples./nEach spouse has a legal right to an equal portion of the property provided they were married at the time title was received in both their names./nThis arrangement creates a right of survivorship, so when one spouse dies, their interest in the property is automatically transferred to the surviving spouse./nCreditors cannot enforce a lien on any property that falls under a tenancy by the entirety if only one spouse owns the debt.

Term: Tenancy In Common (TIC) Explained: How It Works and Compared to Joint Tenancy
Definition: Tenancy in Common (TIC) is a legal arrangement in which two or more parties have ownership interests in a real estate property or parcel of land./nTenants in common can own different percentages of the property./nTenants in common can bequeath their share of the property to a named beneficiary upon their death./nJoint Tenancy and Tenancy by Entirety are two other types of ownership agreements.

Term: Tender in Finance Definition: How It Works, With Example
Definition: Tender usually refers to the process whereby governments and financial institutions invite bids for large projects that must be submitted within a finite deadline./nA tender offer is a public solicitation to all shareholders requesting that they tender their stock for sale at a specific price during a certain time./nA request for tender is a formal and structured invitation to suppliers to submit competitive bids to supply raw materials, products, or services./nThe term tender also refers to the process whereby shareholders submit their shares or securities in response to a takeover offer./nLarge institutional investors buy government securities through a competitive tender process, while smaller investors buy government securities through a non-competitive tender process.

Term: Tender Offer Definition: How It Works, With Example
Definition: A tender offer is a public solicitation to all shareholders requesting that they tender their stock for sale at a specific price during a certain time./nThe tender offer typically is set at a higher price per share than the company’s current stock price, providing shareholders a greater incentive to sell their shares./nIn the case of a takeover attempt, the tender may be conditional on the prospective buyer being able to obtain a certain amount of shares, such as a sufficient number of shares to constitute a controlling interest in the company.

Term: Tenkan-Sen (Conversion Line): Formula, Calculation and Meaning
Definition: The Tenkan-Sen is the fastest moving line that appears in the Ichimoku Cloud indicator./nThe line follows price closely, therefore it helps highlight short-term price direction via its slope./nTenkan-Sen is its own line/indicator, but its value is also used in the Senkou Span A (Leading Span A) formula./nSenkou Span A is one of the two lines that form the "cloud" or "kumo" for the Ichimoku Cloud indicator.

Term: What Is Tenor? Definition, How It Works, and Example
Definition: The term tenor describes the length of time remaining in the life of a financial contract./nBy contrast, maturity refers to the date when a transaction or investment ends./nHigher-tenor contracts are sometimes considered riskier, and vice versa./nTenor is particularly important in a credit default swap because it coordinates the term remaining on the contract with the maturity of the underlying asset./nUnderstanding the tenor of a financial contract is crucial to analyze the contract's riskiness and maintain a steady cash flow.

Term: Term Loan Definition, Types, and Common Attributes
Definition: A term loan provides borrowers with a lump sum of cash upfront in exchange for specific borrowing terms./nBorrowers agree to pay their lenders a fixed amount over a certain repayment schedule with either a fixed or floating interest rate./nTerm loans are commonly used by small businesses to purchase fixed assets, such as equipment or a new building./nBorrowers prefer term loans because they offer more flexibility and lower interest rates./nShort and intermediate-term loans may require balloon payments while long-term facilities come with fixed payments.

Term: Term Deposit: Definition, How It's Used, Rates, and How to Invest
Definition: A term deposit is a type of deposit account held at a financial institution where money is locked up for some set period of time./nTerm deposits are usually short-term deposits with maturities ranging from one month to a few years./nTypically, term deposits offer higher interest rates than traditional liquid savings accounts, whereby customers can withdraw their money at any time.

Term: Term Life Insurance: What It Is, Different Types, Pros and Cons
Definition: Term life insurance guarantees payment of a stated death benefit to the insured's beneficiaries if the insured person dies during the specified term./nThese policies have no value other than the guaranteed death benefit and don’t feature a savings component (as is found in permanent life insurance products)./nTerm life premiums are based on a person’s age, health, and life expectancy./nDepending on the insurance company, it may be possible to turn term life into whole life insurance./nYou can purchase term life policies that last 10, 15, 20 years, or more, and can usually renew them for an additional term.

Term: Term Sheets: Definition, What's Included, Examples, and Key Terms
Definition: A term sheet is a nonbinding agreement outlining the basic terms and conditions under which an investment will be made./nTerm sheets are most often associated with start-ups. Entrepreneurs find that this document is crucial to attracting investors, such as venture capitalists (VC) with capital to fund enterprises./nThe company valuation, investment amount, percentage stake, voting rights, liquidation preference, anti-dilutive provisions, and investor commitment are some items that should be spelled out in the term sheet./nTerm sheets are also used for mergers, acquisitions, and long-term debt (i.e. commercial real estate development)./nTerm sheets are non-binding, though may often require an upfront good faith deposit or other indicator of evidence that both parties intend to carry out an executed full agreement.

Term: Term Structure of Interest Rates Explained
Definition: The term structure of interest rates, commonly known as the yield curve, depicts the interest rates of similar quality bonds at different maturities./nThe term structure of interest rates reflects expectations of market participants about future changes in interest rates and their assessment of monetary policy conditions./nOne commonly used yield curve compares the three-month, two-year, five-year, 10-year, and 30-year U.S. Treasury debt.

Term: Terminal Capitalization Rate: Definition and Calculation Example
Definition: The terminal capitalization rate, or exit rate, is used to estimate the resale value of a property at the end of the holding period./nThe going-in cap rate is the property's projected first-year net operating income divided by the purchase price of the property./nIf the terminal capitalization rate is lower than the going-in rate, it usually means that the property investment was profitable.

Term: Term to Maturity in Bonds: Overview and Examples
Definition: A bond's term to maturity is the period during which its owner will receive interest payments on the investment./nWhen the bond reaches maturity, the owner is repaid its par, or face, value./nThe term to maturity can change if the bond has a put or call option.

Term: Terminal Value (TV) Definition and How to Find The Value (With Formula)
Definition: Terminal value (TV) determines a company's value into perpetuity beyond a forecast period./nAnalysts use the discounted cash flow model (DCF) to calculate the total value of a business. The forecast period and terminal value are both integral components of DCF./nThe two most common methods for calculating terminal value are perpetual growth (Gordon Growth Model) and exit multiple./nThe perpetual growth method assumes that a business will generate cash flows at a constant rate forever, while the exit multiple method assumes that a business will be sold.

Term: What Does Termination of Employment Mean?
Definition: Termination of employment refers to the end of an employee’s work with a company./nTermination may be voluntary, as when a worker leaves of their own accord./nInvoluntary termination occurs when a company downsizes, makes layoffs, or fires an employee./nSeverance packages are discretionary, which means a company does not need to offer them to employees when their employment is terminated./nA worker who is unemployed through no fault of their own may be eligible to receive unemployment benefits.

Term: Terms of Trade (TOT): Definition, Use as Indicator, and Factors
Definition: Terms of trade (TOT) is a key economic metric of a country's health measured through what it imports and exports./nTOT is expressed as a ratio that reflects the number of units of exports that are needed to buy a single unit of imports./nTOT is determined by dividing the price of the exports by the price of the imports and multiplying the number by 100./nA TOT over 100% or that shows improvement over time can be a positive economic indicator as it can mean that export prices have risen as import prices have held steady or declined.

Term: Terms of Employment: Definition and Examples
Definition: Terms of employment are the benefits and responsibilities that an employee agrees to when they accept a job./nTerms may include things like salary, benefits, retirement, company policies, and termination agreements./nExecutives and workers with skills that are in demand generally have some bargaining power in their terms of employment./nThe minimum terms of employment are set by the U.S. Department of Labor.

Term: What Are Tertiary Sectors? Industry Defined, With Examples
Definition: The tertiary industry is the services sector of an economy, encompassing medical providers, educators, financial services, haircuts, and personal trainers, among many others./nThe tertiary sector can be subdivided broadly into for-profit and nonprofit segments./nEconomists have found that as a nation's economy grows and develops, the tertiary sector becomes larger while the primary sector that produces raw materials shrinks./nThe service sector is now the largest sector of the global economy in terms of value-added and is especially important in more advanced economies.

Term: Texas Ratio: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The Texas ratio assesses a bank’s financial position./nThe ratio is non-performing assets divided by the sum of a bank’s tangible common equity and loan loss reserves./nThe higher the Texas ratio the more financial trouble a bank might be in./nA high Texas ratio, however, doesn’t mean the bank will go bankrupt.

Term: Testamentary Trust: Definition, Examples, Pros and Cons
Definition: A testamentary trust is a trust that is to contain a portion or all of a decedent's assets outlined within a person's last will and testament./nA testamentary trust is not established until after the person passes away in which the executor settles the estate as outlined in the will./nA testamentary trust can name minors as beneficiaries, in which the deceased's assets are paid out only when they reach a certain age./nThe trust can also be used to reduce estate tax liabilities and ensure professional management of the assets./nA disadvantage of a testamentary trust is that it does not avoid probate—the legal process of distributing assets through the court.

Term: Tether (USDT): Meaning and Uses for Tethering Crypto
Definition: USDT is a stablecoin, a type of cryptocurrency that is pegged to a fiat currency, namely the U.S. dollar./nInvestors in USDT seek to invest in cryptocurrency while avoiding the extreme volatility of untethered cryptocurrencies./nTether can be purchased througha crypto exchange or appusing Kraken or Coinbase, among other cryptocurrency exchanges.

Term: Tezos (XTZ): Definition and How It Works in Crypto
Definition: Tezos is a blockchain network linked to a digital token known as Tez, or tezzie./nThe network's governance is based on economic stakes and precludes forks./nTezos uses a proof-of-stake mechanism to validate blockchain transactions, which uses less energy than Bitcoin mining./nFollowing a highly successful ICO, Tezos was dogged by a power struggle and lawsuits./nAfter topping $8 in October 2021, the price of a Tez declined to just under a dollar by May 2023.

Term: Theoretical Ex-Rights Price – TERP
Definition: TERP is the theoretical market price of a stock after the completion of a rights offering./nNew rights issues result in an increase in the number of shares available and therefore have an impact on the price of the underlying stock./nTypically, rights offerings give shareholders the chance to buy more shares at a discounted price, causing a dilution effect./nGenerally, the TERP will be lower than the pre-offering market price immediately following the rights issuing period.

Term: The Greatest Generation: Definition and Characteristics
Definition: The Greatest Generation commonly refers to those Americans who were born in the 1900s through the 1920s./nThe Greatest Generation members lived through the Great Depression and many of them fought in World War II./nThese individuals have often been described as driven, patriotic, and team players./nThe Greatest Generation members also tend to be the parents of the Baby Boomer generation./nThere are fewer than 100,000 of the Greatest Generation left today in the U.S.

Term: Theoretical Value (of a Right) Explained With Formula
Definition: The theoretical value of a right can be calculated during the cum rights period./nInvestors with subscription rights are told the price for which they can purchase the shares—usually at a discount to current market price./nThese same investors are told how many rights are necessary to purchase one share of stock./nFrom this information the theoretical price can be calculated.

Term: What Is Theory of Price? Definition In Economics and Example
Definition: The theory of price is an economic theory that states that the price for any good or service is based on the relationship between its supply and demand./nThe optimal market price is the point at which the total number of items available can be reasonably consumed by potential customers./nWhen supply and demand are in sync, the market is said to have achieved equilibrium./nSupply may also be affected by factors such as the availability of raw materials; demand may fluctuate depending on competitor products, an item's perceived value, or its affordability to the consumer market.

Term: Theory of the Firm: What It Is and How It Works in Economics
Definition: In neoclassical economics, the theory of the firm is a microeconomic concept that states that a firm exists and make decisions to maximize profits./nThe theory of the firm influences decision-making in a variety of areas, including resource allocation, production techniques, pricing adjustments, and the volume of production./nModern takes on the theory of the firm sometimes distinguish between long-run motivations, such as sustainability, and short-run motivations, such as profit maximization.

Term: There Ain't No Such Thing as a Free Lunch: Meaning and Examples
Definition: "There ain't no such thing as a free lunch" (TANSTAAFL) is a phrase that describes the cost of decision-making and consumption./nTANSTAAFL suggests that things that appear to be free will always have some hidden or implicit cost to someone, even if it is not the individual receiving the benefit./nIn investing, buying Treasury bills is an example of someone thinking they are getting a good deal for very little. But the tradeoff in buying Treasuries is the opportunity cost of not being invested in higher-risk, higher-reward securities over time.

Term: Theta: What It Means in Options Trading, With Examples
Definition: Theta refers to the rate of decline in the value of an option over time./nIf all other variables are constant, an option will lose value as it passes time toward its expiration date./nTheta, usually expressed as a negative number for long positions, indicates how much of the option's value is being lost.

Term: What Is a Third Party? How Their Role Works and Examples
Definition: Third parties work on behalf of one or more individuals involved in a transaction./nIn the case of a real estate transaction, an escrow company works to protect all parties in the transaction./nIn the case of third party debt collection, the third party sides with the lender to recover as much of the outstanding debt as possible and is incentivized accordingly./nThird party is also used to refer to outsourcing certain functions to an outside company to ensure efficient service for clients.

Term: Third Party Liability Insurance Types
Definition: Third-party insurance covers an individual or firm against a loss caused by some third party, such as car insurance./nThe first party is the insured, the second party is the insurer, and the third party is the person causing the loss or claim./nThe two main categories of third-party insurance are liability coverage and property damage coverage./nMost people are required by law to carry different forms of insurance on their homes and vehicles.

Term: Third-Party Transaction Definition, How It Works, Examples
Definition: A third-party transaction often involves a seller, a buyer, and an additional party not connected to the others./nExamples of third-party transactions are everywhere in daily life, including Insurance brokers, mortgage brokers, and online payment portals./nThe number of people and businesses participating in third-party transactions has exploded in the digital era through online payment platforms.

Term: Third World Countries: Definition, Criteria, and List of Countries
Definition: "Third World" is an outdated and offensive Cold War-era term./nCurrently accepted terms include "developing" and "lower-middle or low-income." The poorest and least industrialized nations are sometimes termed "frontier" or "least developed" countries./nWhatever the terminology, the terms are intended to characterize a nation's place in the global economy.

Term: Who Is Thomas Malthus?
Definition: Thomas Malthus was an 18th-century British philosopher and economist noted for the Malthusian growth model, an exponential formula used to project population growth./nThe theory states that the supply of food cannot keep up with the growth of the human population, inevitably resulting in disease, famine, war, and calamity./nA noted statistician and proponent of political economy, Malthus founded the Statistical Society of London./nMalthus' theories were later used to justify British colonial policies that worsened the human toll of the Irish Potato Famine./nHis theory is now largely dismissed, as modern farming techniques have allowed food production to scale much faster than Malthus could have anticipated.

Term: Three White Soldiers Candlestick Pattern in Trading Explained
Definition: Three white soldiers are considered a reliable reversal pattern when confirmed by other technical indicators like therelative strength index (RSI)./nThe size of the candles and the length of the shadow is used to judge whether there is a risk ofretracement./nThe opposite pattern of three white soldiers is three black crows, which indicates the reversal of an uptrend.

Term: Three Black Crows Definition and How to Use the Pattern
Definition: Three black crows is a bearish candlestick pattern used to predict the reversal of a current uptrend./nTraders use it alongside other technical indicators such as the relative strength index (RSI)./nThe size of the three black crows candles and the shadow can be used to judge whether the reversal is at risk of a retracement./nThe opposite pattern of three black crows is three white soldiers, which indicates a reversal of a downtrend.

Term: Three Sigma Limits Statistical Calculation, With an Example
Definition: Three-sigma limits (3-sigma limits) is a statistical calculation that refers to data within three standard deviations from a mean./nThree-sigma limits are used to set the upper and lower control limits in statistical quality control charts./nOn a bell curve, data that lie above the average and beyond the three-sigma line represent less than 1% of all data points.

Term: Thrift Bank: Definition, History, How It Works, and Impact
Definition: A thrift bank—also called a Savings and Loan Association (S&L)—is a type of financial institution that specializes in offering savings accounts and originating home mortgages for consumers./nWhile a thrifts' core offerings are traditional savings accounts and home loan origination, these institutions also offer checking accounts, personal and car loans, and credit cards for consumers./nIn the years since the Savings and Loan Crisis—which occurred between 1986 and 1995)—many structural changes have been made to thrift banks that have blurred some of the distinctions between them and conventional banks.
