Definition: Whole life insurance lasts for an insured's lifetime, as opposed to term life insurance, which is for a specific amount of years./nMost whole life policies feature level premiums, meaning the amount you pay every month won’t change./nWhole life insurance has a cash savings component, known as the cash value, which the policy owner can draw on or borrow from./nThe cash value of a whole life policy typically earns a fixed rate of interest./nWithdrawals and outstanding loan balances reduce death benefits.

Term: Wholesale Insurance
Definition: Wholesale insurance refers to coverage for employer groups that are too small to qualify for true group coverage./nWholesale insurance is sold to groups that aren't large enough to get typical group coverage, usually with fewer than 10 employees./nPolicies come at individual rates but normally contain the same provisions./nWholesale insurance is normally offered by nonadmitted carriers—also known as surplus line or excess line carriers.

Term: What Is Wholesale Banking? Types of Services and Example
Definition: Wholesale banking refers to banking services sold to large clients, such as corporations, other banks, and government agencies./nTypical services sold are mergers and acquisitions, consulting, currency conversion, andunderwriting./nWholesale banking is the opposite of retail banking, which services individuals and small businesses./nMost standard banks offer wholesale banking services in addition to traditional retail banking services./nWholesale banking also refers to the borrowing and lending between institutional banks.

Term: Wholesale Money: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Wholesale money refers to large sums of money lent by financial institutions in money markets./nAs the subprime crisis showed, it is quick to arrange but dangerous to rely on./nWholesale money markets are a good leading indicator of stress in the financial system.

Term: Wholesale Price Index (WPI): What It Is and How It's Calculated
Definition: A wholesale price index (WPI) measures overall change in producer prices over time./nIt is a measure of inflation based on the prices of goods before they reach consumers./nIn the U.S. the WPI was renamed the Producer Price Index (PPI) in 1978./nThe U.S. WPI never measured the prices charged by wholesaling intermediaries./nThe U.S. PPI includes product category indexes distinguishing between intermediate and finished goods.

Term: Wholesale Trade: What it is, how Data is Used
Definition: Wholesale-trade data gives investors a closer look at the consumer economy, as wholesalers' sales and inventory numbers can be a leading indicator of consumer trends./nBy looking at the ratio of sales to inventories, investors can see whether or not production may grow or slow in the future./nOnly those firms that sell to governments, institutions, and other businesses are considered part of wholesale trade.

Term: Wholesaling: Definition, How It Works, and Role in Supply Chain
Definition: Wholesalers are not manufacturers. Their business is distributing the end products. They purchase goods from manufacturers in bulk at a discount and sell to retailers./nWholesalers also provide cost savings to retailers when retailers buy in bulk from the wholesaler. The retailer then repackages the bulk items into smaller quantities for sale directly to consumers./nWholesaling is one step in the supply chain that starts with a supplier of raw materials and ends with a sale to an end-user./nIn banking, the term wholesaling refers to financial services provided to large institutional clients rather than individual retail customers.

Term: What Is a Wholly-Owned Subsidiary? How It Works and Examples
Definition: A wholly-owned subsidiary is a company whose common stock is 100% owned by a parent company./nWholly-owned subsidiaries allow the parent company to diversify its product lines, streamline management, and possibly reduce risk./nBy its nature, a wholly-owned subsidiary has no obligations to minority shareholders./nThe financial results of a wholly-owned subsidiary are reported on the parent company's consolidated financial statement.

Term: Whoops: What It Means, How It Works, History
Definition: Whoops is a derogatory slang term for the Washington Public Power Supply System./nToday, the Washington Public Power Supply Company is called Energy Northwest company and is no longer referred to as "Whoops."/nIn the 1980s, the company faced a series of expensive setbacks./nIn 1983 the Washington Public Power Supply Company was responsible for the largest municipal debt default in history.

Term: Wide Basis: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A wide basis is a market condition in which the gap between spot prices and futures prices is relatively large./nSuch a divergence between spot price and futures price may be associated with illiquidity or high carrying costs./nBasis inevitably reduces as the futures contract approaches its expiration date; any gap that remains would produce opportunities for arbitrage profits.

Term: Wide Economic Moat: Meaning, How it Works, Sources
Definition: An economic moat is a distinct advantage a company has over its competitors that allows it to protect its market share and profitability./nA wide economic moat is one that is difficult to mimic or duplicate (e.g., brand identity, patents) and thus creates an effective barrier against competition from other firms./nCompanies with a wide economic moat have are able to generate large amounts of free cash flow and have a track record of strong returns.

Term: Wide-Ranging Days: What They Mean, How They Work
Definition: Wide-ranging days occur when the high and low prices of a stock are much further apart than they are on a typical day./nExtreme wide-ranging days can help predict major trend reversals./nThe average true range (ATR) provides a way to compare the trading range between multiple days./nMeanwhile, the volatility ratio can be used to identify wide-ranging days using a technical indicator that automates the process of finding wide-ranging days./nWide-ranging days typically occur when the volatility ratio exceeds a reading of 2.0 over a 14-day period.

Term: Wide Variety: What it is, How it Works, Disadvantages
Definition: A wide variety merchandising strategy draws customers in with an impressive array of products in a relatively compact space./nThe deepassortment strategy, by contrast, offers a greater range of sizes, colors, styles, and brands./nWide variety can be most effective in a boutique or small store./nA wide variety store can compete with big box stores by offering superior service and a more enjoyable shopping experience.

Term: Widely Held Fixed Investment Trust (WHFIT): Meaning, How it Works
Definition: A widely held fixed investment trust (WHFIT) is an investment vehicle where at least one interested third-party is involved./nThe third party, or middleman, is responsible for holding the unit shares as custodian./nWithout this middleman role, the WHFIT would be simply a unit investment trust (UIT), and in many ways they function identically from an investor's perspective./nWHFITS may invest in a fixed portfolio of stocks and bonds, or else real estate mortgage investments.

Term: Widow Maker: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: In financial markets, the term widow maker refers to a trade that results in a large, even catastrophic loss./nWidow maker can also refer to a trade in which the market repeatedly confounds market consensus and even defies historical patterns, resulting in losses for everyone who tries the trade./nThe term widow maker has also been used in forestry and medicine and denotes the possibility of sudden death./nA common widow maker trade in the financial markets involves natural gas futures./nThe most famous widow maker trade is shorting Japanese government bonds (JGBs) given that the Japanese government continues to push interest rates lower.

Term: Widow-And-Orphan Stock: Meaning, Pros And Cons
Definition: Widow-and-orphan stocks are low-volatility yet high-dividend paying stocks./nThese stocks are traditionally held as blue chip companies in non-cyclical industries like consumer staples./nWhile this term is no longer used commonly today, large-cap value stock investors tend to pick stocks that could be classified as widow-and-orphan.

Term: What Is a Widow's Allowance, and How Does It Work?
Definition: A "widow’s allowance" is a traditional term that refers to the funds or personal property that a widow receives after her husband's death to meet her immediate needs. It is also known as a "widower's allowance" or "spousal allowance," depending on the parties involved. Certain children may also receive this allowance./nA probate court or state statute determines the allowance amount./nThe disbursement of the allowance may be time-limited./nA widow's allowance differs from a widow’s pension, which is a recurring benefit payment that a surviving spouse receives from Social Security or a VA survivors pension.

Term: Widow's Exemption: Definition, State and Federal Tax Rules
Definition: A widow's exception is a tax statute that reduces the tax burden for a widow or widower after their spouse passes away./nIn many states, the widow's exception comes in the form of reduced property taxes for a period of time./nThe widow's exception typically appears on federal taxes as an exemption on certain limits for gifts and inheritances from the deceased's estate./nAnyone who is legally married qualifies to receive tax relief after a spouse's death, but not state-recognized domestic partnerships./nState tax relief for widows and widowers varies state by state.

Term: Wild Card Option: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: The term “wild card option” refers to a right held by the seller of a Treasury bond futures contract./nIt permits the seller to wait until after-hours trading before delivering its bonds to the futures contract buyer./nThis can occasionally lead to a more favorable price for the seller, lowering the cost of their short position and thereby increasing their profits.

Term: Wilcoxon Test: Definition in Statistics, Types, and Calculation
Definition: The Wilcoxon test compares two paired groups and comes in two versions, the rank sum test, and signed rank test./nThe goal of the test is to determine if two or more sets of pairs are different from one another in a statistically significant manner./nBoth versions of the model assume that the pairs in the data come from dependent populations, i.e., following the same person or share price through time or place.

Term: Wild Card Option: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: The term “wild card option” refers to a right held by the seller of a Treasury bond futures contract./nIt permits the seller to wait until after-hours trading before delivering its bonds to the futures contract buyer./nThis can occasionally lead to a more favorable price for the seller, lowering the cost of their short position and thereby increasing their profits.

Term: Wildcat Banking: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: Wildcat banking refers to the banking industry in parts of the United States from 1837 to 1865, when banks were established in remote and inaccessible locations./nWildcat banks were not fully free of regulation; they were only free of federal regulation. Wildcat banks were chartered under applicable state laws and regulated on the state level. Banking regulations, therefore, varied from one state to the next during the Free Banking Era./nThe term "wildcat banking" supposedly had its genesis in the 1830s in Michigan, where bankers were believed to have set up banks in areas so remote that wildcats roamed there. Others say the term originated with an early bank that issued currency bearing an image of a wildcat.

Term: Wilder's DMI (ADX) Indicator: Definition and Calculation Formula
Definition: The DMI is a collection of indicators including +DI, -DI, and ADX./nBoth +DI and -DI measure up and down price movement, and crossovers of these lines can be used as trade signals./nADX measures the strength of the trend, either up or down; a reading above 25 indicates a strong trend.

Term: Wildcatting: What It Means, How it Works
Definition: Wildcatting informally refers to a practice instituted by the SEC that calls for the review of an entire industry whenever critical problems are found within one or two companies in that industry./nWildcatting is a term used in the oil industry, where companies drill test wells for oil in unexplored or wild areas./nWildcatting emerged after the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, which provided greater transparency for investors.﻿﻿

Term: Wildcat Drilling
Definition: Wildcat drilling is a form of exploratory drilling in the oil & gas exploration and production process that seeks to exploit unproven or high-risk areas./nA wildcat driller may alternatively seek to return to existing or older wells that are no longer profitable or useful for larger oil companies./nWildcatting often involves smaller firms and can involve both high risk and high reward for stakeholders.

Term: William T. Dillard Ii: Education, Ceo Career, Accomplishments
Definition: William T. Dillard II became CEO of Dillard's Inc. in 1998./nHe implemented one of the first computerized inventory management systems in the retail industry./nDillard II was inducted into the Arkansas Business Hall of Fame in 2016.

Term: Who Is William Cavanaugh III?
Definition: William Cavanaugh III was the CEO of Carolina Power & Light, which later became Progress Energy./nHe graduated from Tulane University in 1961 and received several certifications that helped boost him as a leader./nCavanaugh opposed the deregulation of the energy industry because he didn't see how the move would make energy companies both more profitable and better for customers./nCavanaugh retired from Progress Energy in 2004./nOnce retired, he held positions at energy industry groups such as the World Association of Nuclear Operators.

Term: Will: What It Means, How It Works, and Requirements
Definition: Writing your will ensures that your family and friends inherit your assets without delay or unnecessary complications./nIt is a declaration of your intentions and a straightforward list of all of your assets./nYou also can use your will to protect your minor children or other family members who rely on you.

Term: William F. Sharpe: Early Life, Accomplishments, Sharpe Ratio
Definition: William F. Sharpe is an economist credited with developing the CAPM and Sharpe ratio./nThe CAPM is a cornerstone in portfolio management and seeks to find the expected return by looking at the risk-free rate, beta, and market risk premium./nThe Sharpe ratio helps investors decipher which investments provide the best returns for the risk level.

Term: Who Was William J. O'Neil?
Definition: William J. O'Neil worked as a stockbroker at Hayden, Stone, & Co. in Los Angeles./nO'Neil bought a seat on the NYSE at age 30./nHe founded William O'Neil Co. Inc. in 1963, which developed the first computerized securities database./nWilliam J. O'Neil created the CAN SLIM growth investment strategy./nHe founded theInvestor's Business Dailyin 1984.

Term: Who Is Bill Gross?
Definition: Bill Gross co-founded Pacific Investment Management Company, PIMCO, and is known as the "Bond King."/nHe created the first investable market for fixed-income securities./nGross is a successful stamp collector and benefactor of the William H. Gross Stamp Gallery at the Smithsonian National Postal Museum.

Term: Williams %R: Definition, Formula, Uses, and Limitations
Definition: Williams %R moves between zero and -100./nA reading above -20 is overbought./nA reading below -80 is oversold./nAn overbought or oversold reading doesn't mean the price will reverse. Overbought simply means the price is near the highs of its recent range, and oversold means the price is in the lower end of its recent range./nCan be used to generate trade signals when the price and the indicator move out of overbought or oversold territory.

Term: Willie Sutton Rule: What It is, How It Works
Definition: The Willie Sutton Rule states that one's first choice should be to choose the most obvious route./nNamed after bank robber William Sutton, the rule applies to investors in that they should most often seek out low hanging fruit first before trying more obscure strategies./nIn medicine, the rule suggests that the most likely diagnosis for an ailment should be ruled out first before exploring uncommon conditions.

Term: FT Wilshire 5000 Index (FTW5000): Definition and What's Included
Definition: The FT Wilshire 5000 Index (FTW5000) seeks to capture 100% of the investible U.S. market./nIt previously (before June 30, 2021) traded as the Wilshire 5000 Total Market Index (TMWX)./nAt its high point, the FT Wilshire 5000 Index had over 7,500 stocks but currently has just 3,687.

Term: Win/Loss Ratio: Definition, Formula, and Examples in Trading
Definition: The win/loss, or success ratio, is a trader's number of winning trades divided by the number of losing trades./nThe win/loss ratio can indicate how many times a trader will have successful, money-making trades relative to how many times they'll have money-losing trades./nThe win/loss ratio doesn't take into account the amounts of money that trades made or lost./nTraders can use the win/loss ratio to rate the success of a trading strategy./nThe win/loss ratio and the win rate (wins/total trades) can be used to determine the probability of being profitable.

Term: Windfall Profits: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Windfall Tax: Definition, Purposes, Examples
Definition: A windfall tax is a surtax imposed by governments on businesses or economic sectors that have benefited from economic expansion./nThe purpose is to redistribute excess profits in one area to raise funds for the greater social good; however, this can be a contentious ideal./nSome individual taxes—such as inheritance tax or taxes on lottery or game-show winnings—can also be construed as a windfall tax.

Term: What Is Winding Up? How Does It Differ From Bankruptcy?
Definition: Winding up refers to the process of liquidating the assets of a business that has ceased operations./nThe sole purpose of a business that is winding up is to sell off assets, pay off creditors, and distribute any remaining assets to the owners./nThe two main types of winding up are compulsory winding up and voluntary winding up./nWinding up a business is not the same as bankruptcy, although it is usually a result of bankruptcy.

Term: Window Guaranteed Investment Contract
Definition: A window guaranteed investment contract (WGIC) promises guaranteed returns from a series of installment payments paid in during the contribution window./nAfter the window has closed, no further contributions can be made./nThe contract then matures for a period of several years before returning principal and interest to investors./nLike all GICs, these products are considered low-risk and likewise carry lower average returns.

Term: What Is Window Dressing in Finance?
Definition: Window dressing occurs when portfolio and fund managers try to boost reported performance before publishing required reports./nIt can be identified by carefully evaluating a fund's holdings and looking for suspicious trades coinciding with the end of a quarter or fiscal year./nYou can identify financial report window dressing by learning how businesses adjust their accounting procedures to appear to be performing better./nWindow dressing can give the appearance of better returns and performance, but these strategies often defer losses that will materialize later on.

Term: What Is a Window of Opportunity?
Definition: Windows of opportunity are short periods within which a decision can be made that will produce a desired outcome./nWindows of opportunity are often fleeting with an ending date./nIn investing, trading opportunities for hot IPOs, a real estate purchase, or a chance at an M&A deal all present themselves as windows of opportunity.

Term: Windstorm Insurance: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Windstorm insurance protects policyholders from property damage caused by gusty events, such as tornadoes, hurricanes and gales./nWindstorm insurance will typically cover physical damages to the property and personal belongings./nWindstorm coverage is typically affixed as a rider to a homeowners insurance policy./nMany policies limit the time frame to file a claim for windstorm damage.

Term: Windstorm Insurance: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Windstorm insurance protects policyholders from property damage caused by gusty events, such as tornadoes, hurricanes and gales./nWindstorm insurance will typically cover physical damages to the property and personal belongings./nWindstorm coverage is typically affixed as a rider to a homeowners insurance policy./nMany policies limit the time frame to file a claim for windstorm damage.

Term: Winner-Takes-All Market: Definition, Examples, Economic Impact
Definition: A winner-takes-all market refers to an economic system where competition allows the best performers to rise to the top at the expense of the losers./nThe ultimate end-result of a winner-takes-all market is an oligopoly, where only a small handful of large, powerful companies control a majority of market share./nStock markets and other potential zero-sum systems also lead to a winner-takes-all situation where the rich get richer and extends wealth inequality.

Term: Winner's Curse: Definition, How It Works, Causes, and Example
Definition: The winner's curse is a tendency for the winning bid in an auction to exceed the intrinsic value or true worth of an item./nThe gap in auctioned vs. intrinsic value can typically be attributed to incomplete information, types of bidders, emotions, or a variety of other subjective factors./nOriginally, the term winner's curse was coined as a result of companies bidding for offshore oil drilling rights in the Gulf of Mexico.﻿﻿/nIn the investing world, the term often applies to initial public offerings (IPOs) but comprehensively a winner’s curse can happen in any market where auctions take place./nThe gap between intrinsic and auction value will generally be influenced by the bidders involved.

Term: Winsorized Mean: Formula, Examples and Meaning
Definition: The winsorized mean is an averaging method that involves replacing the smallest and largest values of a data set with the observations closest to them./nIt mitigates the effects of outliers by replacing them with less extreme values./nThe winsorized mean is not the same as the trimmed mean, which involves removing data points as opposed to replacing them—although the results of the two tend to be close./nThe winsorized mean is also not the same as the arithmetic mean which does not adjust for outliers.

Term: Wire Room: What It Is, How It Works, FAQs
Definition: A wire room is a department dedicated to fulfilling client fund transfers and order requests./nCommon examples include processing new deposits and withdrawals or implementing purchase or sales orders conveyed through client brokers./nWire rooms have security measures in place to prevent fraud and ensure transactions are completed correctly as well as being required to maintain files and records of all business conducted./nHistorically, wire rooms involved a large amount of staff. However, advances in automation have meant that a growing percentage of these functions are now performed by computerized systems.

Term: Wire Fraud Laws: Overview, Definition and Examples
Definition: Wire fraud is a type of fraud that involves the use of some form of telecommunications or the internet./nThis type of crime can make use of any and all forms of electronic media including telephone or fax machine, email or social media, or SMS and text messaging./nWire fraud often involves communications made between state or national borders, and is punishable by both hefty fines and jail sentences.

Term: What Is a Wire Transfer? How It Works, Safety, and Fees
Definition: Wire transfers are sent electronically across a network of banks or transfer agencies around the world./nYou must pay for a wire transfer when it's sent by the remitting bank and provide the recipient's name and bank account number, and the amount transferred./nMost wire transfers can take as long as two business days to process./nInternational wire payments are monitored by the Office of Foreign Assets Control to ensure the money isn't being wired to terrorist groups or for money laundering purposes./nAll transfers go through a domestic automated clearing house before they are settled.

Term: Wirehouse: What They are, Role in Economy
Definition: A wirehouse is a full-service broker-dealer of any size./nThe term "wirehouse" recalls a period in which broker-dealer offices were connected by private telephone or telegraph lines so that all branches would have immediate access to the same market information as one another./nAlthough virtually every financial institution has moved beyond these "wires" in daily practice, the term remains one used to describe these institutions today.

Term: Wisdom of Crowds: Definition, Theory, Examples
Definition: Wisdom of crowds refers to the idea that large groups of people are collectively smarter than individual experts./nWisdom of crowds was first popularized byNew Yorkerwriter James Surowiecki in his 2004 book,The Wisdom of Crowds./nThe wisdom of crowds theory helps explain market movement and herd-like behavior among investors./nFor crowds to be wise, they must be characterized by a diversity of opinions and each person's opinion should be independent and free from the influence of others./nThe quality of the crowd matters, as an ill-informed crowd or one with little knowledge, can lead to adverse outcomes.

Term: Wisconsin School of Business
Definition: Wisconsin School of Business is located at the University of Wisconsin at Madison./nTuition, fees and expenses for the MBA program cost $21,166 per year for in-state residents and $42,704 annually for non-residents.﻿﻿/nThere were 96 students enrolled in the full-time MBA 2022 graduating class. Eighty percent of MBA candidates scored between 610 and 700 on the GMAT.﻿﻿/nRecent graduates reported a starting salary of nearly $108,000 per year, while the average signing bonus was $24,700.﻿﻿

Term: Wirehouse Broker: What They do, During the Financial Crisis
Definition: Wirehouse is an archaic name for a full-service brokerage house, particularly one of the biggest players./nThe name referred to the telegraph and telephone lines that allowed big brokerages to share the latest stock information with their remote offices and execute trades quickly./nToday's brokers, whether they work for a wirehouse or independently, have access to much the same information and market access via the internet.

Term: With Approved CredIt (WAC): What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: WAC statements are a type of disclaimer used by advertisers./nThey are intended to clarify that the promotional offer described in the ad is only available subject to a credit approval process./nWAC statements are designed to protect the advertiser against accusations of false or misleading advertising.

Term: Witching Hour: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The witching hour is the last trading hour before options or other derivatives contracts expire./nThere is ordinarily a higher trading volume as investors rush to close or roll positions./nDouble and triple witching refer to the expiration of two or three types of derivative contracts on the same day.

Term: With Benefit of Survivorship: What It is, How It Works, and Example
Definition: With benefit of survivorship is a legal agreement between co-owners of a property, where the surviving owner(s) share full ownership of the property if the other dies./nIt bypasses the probate process that is generally undertaken to convey an estate's assets to survivors./nA key requirement of the agreement is that all co-owners must acquire the same title on the asset at the same time and control an equal share.

Term: Discretionary Order: Meaning, Examples, Investment Management
Definition: Discretionary orders are those where a broker has some latitude in working the order on behalf of a client, without their express permission for each individual order decision or detail./nDiscretion most commonly accompanies conditional orders such as setting the limit price in response to changing market conditions./nDiscretionary orders are also a key component of discretionary investment management, whereby a broker or advisor trades on behalf of a client without getting their input on every action./nDiscretionary orders relieve the broker from responsibility for potential losses that their client may suffer, so long as they are using their discretion with the aim of best execution.

Term: Withdrawal: Definition in Banking, How It Works, and Rules
Definition: A withdrawal involves removing funds from a bank account, savings plan, pension, or trust./nSome accounts don't function like simple bank accounts and carry fees for the early withdrawal of funds./nBoth certificates of deposit and individual retirement accounts deal with withdrawal penalties if the accounts are withdrawn before the stipulated time.

Term: Withdrawal Benefits: What They are, How They Work
Definition: Withdrawal benefits allow individuals with an employer-sponsored retirement account to claim those funds upon leaving that employer./nIf younger than the minimum retirement age, these funds must be rolled over to another qualified retirement plan, or else face penalties and taxes./nIf a company matches retirement contributions, vested amounts will be included in the withdrawal benefits.

Term: Withdrawal Plan: Meaning, Advantages, Disadvantages
Definition: A withdrawal plan is a plan for withdrawing from mutual funds or other types of investment accounts./nThis is a payment structure allowing withdrawals on a periodic basis./nA withdrawal plan provides an income stream during retirement years.

Term: Withdrawal Penalty: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A withdrawal penalty refers to the charge given to an individual if they perform an early withdrawal from a locked or time-specific account./nAn example of one of these accounts would be a retirement account like an IRA./nThe amount of a withdrawal penalty depends on many factors, including the type of financial instrument involved./nIn the case of an IRA, there are specific allowances made for early withdrawal without incurring a penalty tax./nThe withdrawal penalty for taking funds from an IRA or other retirement accounts can be expensive.

Term: Withholding: Definition, Tax Rules, Federal vs. State
Definition: Withholding could be considered an installment payment on the tax that an employee will owe for the full year./nForm W-4 requires information such as marital status and number of dependents so that employers can determine the amount to withhold./nIf employers do not withhold enough tax, the employee ends up owing money at the end of the year./nSocial Security and Medicare taxes in addition to income taxes are automatically withheld from employees' wages./nState withholding rates vary, and nine states have no income tax./nSeventeen states allow local governments to levy income tax on their residents.

Term: Withdrawal Credits: Pension Plan Overview
Definition: A withdrawal credit in a pension plan refers to the portion of an employee's retirement assets in a qualified pension plan that the employee is entitled to withdraw when they leave a job./nUnder most pension plans, both the employer and employee make periodic contributions to a fund shared by all eligible employees./nWhether you have a government-sponsored plan or one in the private sector, it's important to know your options and obligations before you withdraw funds from your retirement account.

Term: Withholding Allowance: What Is It, and How Does It Work?
Definition: A withholding allowance is anexemptionfrom withholding that reduces the amount of income tax an employer deducts from an employee’s paycheck. It is linked to personal exemptions, which are federal tax breaks for all taxpayers./nThe passage of theTax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA)of 2017 and the elimination of personal exemptions put an end to the withholding allowance./nBefore 2018, withholding was based on the number of allowances a taxpayer claimed for themselves, their spouse, and their dependents, as well as their tax filing status./nWith the TCJA, changes to the standard deduction amount and Child Tax Credit may offset at least part of the change brought about by eliminating personal exemptions for most families./nIRSForm W-4 is used to calculate withholding. Individuals should file a newForm W-4whenever their personal or financial situation changes.

Term: Withholding Tax Explained: Types and How It's Calculated
Definition: Withholdingtax is a set amount of income tax that an employer withholds from an employee’s paycheck./nEmployers remit withholding taxes directly to the IRS in the employee's name./nThe tax withholding is a credit against the employee’s annual income tax bill./nIf too much money is withheld, an employee receives a tax refund; if too little is withheld, they may have to pay the IRS more with their tax return./nWithholding tax is deducted from payments to U.S. residents and nonresidents who earn money from American sources.

Term: WM/Reuters Benchmark Rates: Definition and Use For Portfolios
Definition: The WM/Reuters Benchmark rates are spot and forward exchange rates used as standard rates for portfolio valuation and performance measurement.

Term: Without Recourse: Meaning, Example, Vs. With Recourse
Definition: Without recourse means that the buyer of a promissory note, or lender, assumes the risk of default./nWhen a financial instrument contains the words "without recourse," the endorser is released from future claims./nSales agreements that are made without recourse create acaveat emptorsituation.

Term: Wolfe Wave: Definition, Pattern Examples, Trading Strategies
Definition: In technical analysis, Wolfe Waves are price patterns consisting of five waves that indicate either bullish or bearish trends./nTo be properly identified as a Wolfe Wave a series of criteria must be met, such as wave cycles each being similar and distinct price action in the third and fourth waves./nFor a true Wolfe Wave, the fifth wave instance in the pattern will be followed by a breakout in price.

Term: Word-of-Mouth Marketing: Meaning and Uses in Business
Definition: Word-of-mouth marketing (WOM marketing) happens when consumers talk about a company's product or service to their friends, family, and to others with whom they have close relationships./nWOM marketing is one of the most powerful forms of advertising as 88% of consumers trust their friends' recommendations over traditional media./nCompanies can encourage WOM marketing by exceeding expectations on a product, providing good customer service, and giving exclusive information to consumers./nThe Word of Mouth Marketing Association (WOMMA) cites the best word-of-mouth marketing strategies as being honest, credible, social, repeatable, measurable, and respectful./nWOM marketing includes various marketing techniques, such as buzz, blogs, and social media marketing.

Term: Worden Stochastics: Meaning, Limitations, Example
Definition: The Worden Stochastic is different from other stochastics in that it ranks closing prices, assigning a value based on where the recent close ranks compared to prior closes./nLike other stochastics, the Worden version provides overbought and oversold levels, as well as potential trade signals using signal line crossovers./nA reading above 80 is considered overbought, while a reading below 20 is considered oversold. This isn't necessarily a reason to buy or sell. It just indicates the price is in the upper or lower portion of its recent closing price range.

Term: WordPress: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: WordPress is a leading open-source CMS platform./nIt is known for its highly customizable nature, boasting a large community of plugin developers./nDue to its large user-base, WordPress is frequently the target ofhackers. To reduce this risk, users should ensure that their WordPress software is kept up-to-date at all times.

Term: Work Cell: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A work cell is a term used to describe the logical and strategic arrangement of resources in a business environment including people, machinery, and other equipment./nWork cells are based on the platform of lean manufacturing, which focuses on value creation for the end customer and reduction of wastage./nIn the office or administrative context, work cells may facilitate a better flow of communication and more efficient use of shared resources.

Term: Workable Indication
Definition: A workable indication is a pricing technique used in buying or selling municipal bonds./nA workable indication is a nominal quote, stated as a range, that's similar to an estimate or initial bid—it isn't binding on the dealer offering it./nA workable indication differs from a firm quote, which does commit the dealer if it is accepted./nA dealer may offer a workable indication as a starting point for negotiations—to gauge investor interest—or because they can't locate a particular bond just yet./nWorkable indications occur in the muni bond secondary market, which tends to be slower and more relaxed than stock markets.

Term: Workers' Compensation Coverage B: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Workers' Compensation Coverage B is an insurance policy that covers costs related to medical care and lost income for injured workers./nPart B workers’ compensation is for additional damages that go beyond what Part A (which satisfies state insurance requirements) covers./nThis coverage is generally required by states if an employer has three or more employees (including the owners of uninsured subcontractors and their employees)./nInjured workers can be provided 100% coverage of all medical expenses, a percentage of lost wages (which varies by state and policy), a lump sum for disability and disfigurement, and a death benefit under Part B.

Term: Workers' Compensation Coverage A: Overview, Example, FAQ
Definition: Workers' compensation coverage A protects employees under state laws./nIt provides medical care, death, disability, and rehabilitation benefits for workers who are injured or killed while on the job./nThe benefits of workers' compensation are generally awarded on a no-fault basis./nPremiums are based on the employer's payroll and the type of duties its employees perform./nWorkers' compensation B includes workers' compensation A coverage but covers employees when the employer is liable through negligence or otherwise, paying out additional damages.

Term: Workers’ Compensation: What It Is, How It Works, and Who Pays
Definition: Workers’ compensation is a form of employer insurance coverage that pays benefits to workers who are injured or become disabled as a result of their job./nBy accepting workers’ compensation benefits, the employee waives the right to sue their employer for damages./nThe compensation may include partial salary repayment and coverage of medical costs./nWorkers’ comp is not the same as unemployment benefits or disability insurance.

Term: Workflow: What It Is, How It Works, Digital Era
Definition: Workflow describes the steps in a business work process, through which a piece of work passes from initiation to completion./nSix SigmaandTotal quality management(TQM) are two popular process improvement philosophies that companies embrace./nBig data has helped to automate workflows through the development ofartificial intelligenceandmachine learningsystems./nWorkflow software and apps help businesses manage projects across different teams, locations, and time zones.

Term: Working-Age Population: Definition, Importance, and Example
Definition: Working-age population refers to the total number of people in a region who are considered able and likely to work./nThe working-age population statistic is based on a predetermined age range, usually from late teens to retirement age./nLocal employment laws and other considerations may impact the parameters of a given region's working-age population./nThe working-age population is different from the working population, which is the number of people who are employed regardless of age./nSome workers older or younger than working age may be employed, while others may be working age but not employed.

Term: Working Capital Loan: Definition, Uses in Business, Types
Definition: A working capital loan is a loan taken to finance a company's everyday operations./nWorking capital loans are not used to buy long-term assets or investments; they are used to provide working capital to covers a company's short-term operational needs./nCompanies with high seasonality or cyclical sales may rely on working capital loans to help with periods of reduced business activity./nWorking capital loans are often tied to a business owner's personal credit, so missed payments or defaults may hurt their credit score.

Term: Working Capital: Formula, Components, and Limitations
Definition: Working capital, also called net working capital, represents the difference between a company’s current assets and current liabilities./nWorking capital is a measure of a company’s liquidity and short-term financial health./nA company has negative working capital if its ratio of current assets to liabilities is less than one (or if it has more current liabilities than current assets)./nPositive working capital indicates that a company can fund its current operations and invest in future activities and growth./nHigh working capital isn’t always a good thing. It might indicate that the business has too much inventory, not investing its excess cash, or not capitalizing on low-expense debt opportunities.

Term: Working Capital Management Explained: How It Works
Definition: Working capital management requires monitoring a company's assets and liabilities to maintain sufficient cash flow to meet its short-term operating costs and short-term debt obligations./nManaging working capital primarily revolves around managing accounts receivable, accounts payable, inventory, and cash./nWorking capital management involves tracking various ratios, including the working capital ratio, the collection ratio, and the inventory ratio./nWorking capital management can improve a company's cash flow management and earnings quality by using its resources efficiently./nWorking capital management strategies may not materialize due to market fluctuations or may sacrifice long-term successes for short-term benefits.

Term: Working Capital Turnover Ratio: Meaning, Formula, and Example
Definition: Working capital turnover measures how effective a business is at generating sales for every dollar of working capital put to use./nA higher working capital turnover ratio is better, and indicates that a company is able to generate a larger amount of sales./nHowever, if working capital turnover rises too high, it could suggest that a company needs to raise additional capital to support future growth.

Term: Working Class Explained: Definition, Compensation, Job Examples
Definition: Working class is a socioeconomic term describing persons in a social class marked by jobs that provide low pay and require limited skill./nTypically, working-class jobs have reduced education requirements./nToday, most working-class jobs are found in the services sector and include clerical, retail sales, and low-skill manual labor vocations.

Term: Working Interest: Meaning, Overview, Advantages and Disadvantages
Definition: A working interest is a type of investment in oil and gas operations./nIn a working interest, investors are liable for ongoing costs associated with the project but also share in any profits of production./nBoth the costs and risks of a working interest are extremely high./nThere are certain tax benefits related to costs and losses in a working interest.

Term: Working Control
Definition: Working control occurs when a minority shareholder, or group of them, has enough voting power to influence or determine corporate policy./nIt exists in corporations with widely dispersed share ownership where no single individual has a majority interest—51% or more of the voting shares./nWhile there are no official benchmarks for defining working control, holding 20% of all outstanding shares is often considered enough./nMultiple minority shareholders could also unite to obtain working control in a corporation.

Term: Workout Agreement: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A workout agreement allows a borrower in default and their lender to renegotiate the terms of a loan./nThe purpose is to accommodate the default borrower so that the lender has a more likely chance of recovering the loan principal and interest without foreclosure, making it mutually beneficial./nNot all lenders are willing to make a workout agreement, and terms will vary on a case-by-case basis.

Term: Working Ratio: Meaning, Example, Limitations
Definition: The working ratio measures a company's ability to recover operating costs from annual revenue./nIt is calculated by taking total annual expenses, excluding depreciation and debt-related expenses, and dividing it by the annual gross income./nThe lower the ratio, the more profitable a company is./nA working ratio below one implies the company is able to recover operating expenses, whereas a ratio above one reflects its inability to do so.

Term: Workout Market
Definition: The workout market is an estimation of what trading prices will adjust to within the foreseeable future, known as a market maker prediction./nThe estimation does not guarantee the prices will come to fruition, as external factors still influence the fiscal health of the market, but these predictions are considered a fair estimation./nA market maker can be either an individual or firm that frequently trades in securities from their own accounts./nWorkout market characteristics are most commonly found within thin markets, times when there are low numbers of buyers and sellers in the market.

Term: Working Tax Credit (WTC) Definition
Definition: The Working Tax Credit (WTC) is a state benefit offered to individuals living in the United Kingdom who work and have a low income./nYou must already be receiving the Child Tax Credit to qualify for the WTC./nThe Working Tax Credit (WTC) is available for individuals aged 25 and above or with a qualifying disability./nApplicants must be gainfully employed and working a minimum number of hours required each week, as determined by the applicant’s age.

Term: Workout Period: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A workout period occurs when the price or yield on a bond adjusts so that it is more in line with similar bonds in the market./nDuring the workout period, which can last from days to months or even years in some cases, new information provided by the issuer and underwriter is disseminated to the public to facilitate price discovery./nTraders may view the workout period as an opportunity for arbitrage, although there is no guarantee that their timing will be spot on.

Term: Work-in-Progress (WIP) Definition With Examples
Definition: A work-in-progress (WIP) is the cost of unfinished goods in the manufacturing process including labor, raw materials, and overhead./nWIPs are considered to be a current asset on the balance sheet./nMinimizing WIP inventory before reporting it is both standard and necessary since it is difficult to estimate the percentage of completion for an inventory asset./nA WIP is different from a finished good which refers to a product that is ready to be sold to the consumer.

Term: World Bank Group
Definition: The World Bank Group is the world's most prominent development bank, with a stated mandate and mission to reduce world poverty./nAs part of the Bretton Woods agreement, The World Bank Group was created on December 27, 1945./nFive organizations comprise The World Bank Group: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), The International Development Association (IDA), The International Finance Corporation (IFC), The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), and The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID)./nThe World Bank Group provides advice and financial assistance in the form of discounted loans and grants to countries struggling with poverty, with a focus on areas such as wellness, education, and agriculture./nThe World Bank Group has 189 member states, with the U.S. as the bank's largest shareholder.

Term: World Economic Forum (WEF): Definition and History of Meeting
Definition: The World Economic Forum (WEF) is a Geneva-based international organization that works toward global cooperation on the day's major economic and social issues./nIt is best known for its annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, which brings together business and political leaders and thinkers to discuss global issues and solutions./nThe environment and related issues such as biodiversity destruction and human-made disasters dominate the WEF's current list of most pressing global concerns./nThe WEF has no independent decision-making power but seeks to influence people to make decisions that benefit the global community./nThe organization is funded through its membership, which includes many prominent business and political figures.

Term: What Is the World Bank, and What Does It Do?
Definition: The World Bank is an international organization that provides financing, advice, and research to developing nations to help advance their economies./nThe World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF)—founded simultaneously under the Bretton Woods Agreement—both seek to serve international governments./nThe World Bank has expanded to become known as the World Bank Group with five cooperative organizations, sometimes known as the World Banks./nThe World Bank Group offers a multitude of proprietary financial assistance, products, and solutions for international governments, as well as a range of research-based thought leadership for the global economy at large./nThe World Bank's Human Capital Project seeks to help nations invest in and develop their human capital to produce a better society and economy.

Term: World Equity Benchmark Series (WEBS): What It is, How it Works
Definition: In 2000, the World Equity Benchmark Series (WEBS) was renamed to iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Exchange Traded Fund (ETF)./nThe iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF seeks to track the investment results of the MSCI Emerging Markets Index, an index composed of large- and mid-capitalization emerging market equities./nThe iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF is similar to the SPDR S&P 500 Trust, an exchange-traded fund (ETF) managed by State Street Global Advisors that tracks the Standard & Poor's 500 Index (S&P 500).

Term: World Economic Outlook: What it is, Examples
Definition: The World Economic Outlook (WEO) is an International Monetary Fund report providing output, inflation, employment, fiscal balances, and debt statistics for member countries./nThe report, best known for its global growth forecasts, summarizes the state of the global economy and highlights the most important recent developments./nThe IMF publishes the WEO report twice a year based on data obtained from its consultations with member countries' governments./nThe IMF also publishes two additional and less comprehensive WEO Updates a year, each three months after the main WEO report.

Term: World Federation of Stock Exchanges (WFE): Overview
Definition: The World Federation of Exchanges, located in London, represents more than 250 different exchanges and clearinghouses./nThe WEF also plays a role in facilitating the spread of ideas and best practices throughout the financial services industry./nWFE exchanges are home to 59,400 listed companies, and as of 2021, WFE members had a total annual trading volume of $162.04 trillion.

Term: World Fund
Definition: A world fund is a type of mutual fund or other investment company that invests in securities that are traded in several different countries, including the United States./nThe structure of world funds offers several valuable advantages, chief among those advantages is that it limits exposure to any specific country./nBy diversifying their portfolio, these funds and their investors can help minimize their risk of a major loss, since even large fluctuations in one region can often be offset and balanced out by gains in other regions.

Term: World Insurance: What It is, How It Works, Types
Definition: World insurance provides commercial liability coverage in the event the policyholder is sued anywhere in the world, subject to some restrictions./nIt is common for companies with global operations or who have contracts with international partners or associates to purchase world coverage./nSome common types of world insurance include foreign commercial general liability, foreign business auto, foreign voluntary workers’ compensation, and foreign travel accident and sickness insurance.

Term: World Trade Organization (WTO): What It Is and What It Does
Definition: The World Trade Organization (WTO) oversees global trade rules among nations and mediates disputes./nThe WTO has been a force for globalization, with both positive and negative effects./nBig businesses tend to support the WTO for its positive impact on international economic growth./nSkeptics see it as increasing the wealth gap and hurting local workers and communities.

Term: The Rise and Fall of WorldCom: Story of a Scandal
Definition: WorldCom was a telecommunications company that was established in 1983 by Murray Waldron, William Rector, and early investor Bernard Ebbers among others./nThe company provided discount long-distance services to its customers and pursued an aggressive acquisition strategy that propelled it to the largest company of its kind in the United States./nWorldCom was in financial trouble and used questionable accounting techniques to hide its losses from investors and others./nThe company filed for bankruptcy because of the scandal, and several key figures were punished, including its CEO and CFO./nWorldCom emerged from bankruptcy, restructured, and was purchased by Verizon.

Term: Worldwide Coverage: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: Worldwide coverage is a global policy provided by insurance companies that covers the insured business or individual against loss or damage, globally./nWorldwide coverage may only be valid for a certain period of time and may need to be renewed periodically./nThe documentation and premiums required for worldwide coverage depend on the type and value of coverage./nWorldwide coverage usually applies only to personal property, obtrusion of business, and crime./nIn the U.S., most workers' compensation insurance, commercial auto insurance, and general liability insurance only cover the U.S., Canada, and Puerto Rico.﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿/nWhen a policy doesn't specify the coverage territory it usually implies that it is worldwide coverage.

Term: Worthless Securities: Meaning, Overview, FAQ
Definition: Worthless securities are stocks, bonds, or other holdings that have no market value; they can be publicly traded or held privately./nThe IRS recommends investors account for worthless securities as if they were capital assets that had been dumped or exchanged on the last day of the tax year./nAs such, these securities can be claimed as a capital loss when the investor files their taxes; the holding period determines whether the loss is short-term or long-term./nPenny stocks have comparatively little market value but are not considered worthless, though they have the potential to become just that.

Term: Wrap Accounts: An Alternative to Broker's Commissions
Definition: A wrap account costs a flat fee for brokerage services based on the size of your portfolio./nA wrap account may be less expensive for active investors than one that charges commissions for each trade./nIn a wrap account, the broker's incentive is to maximize gains rather than generate trading fees./nGiven Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) settlements with wrap account managers over the last decade, it's prudent to ensure your brokerage is transparent about its fees and that you only pay those you understand to be included in your fee.

Term: Wrap-Around Insurance Program: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A wrap-around insurance program is a policy that provides punitive damages coverage for employment practices liability claims./nIt is also referred to as a wrap-around policy because it "wraps around" an admitted Employment Practices Liability Insurance (EPLI) policy./nEPLI protects employers from financial loss not protected by workers' compensation./nThe term wrap-around insurance can also appear in secondary or ancillary policies for health and life insurance and political risk insurance.

Term: W.P. Carey School of Business: Overview
Definition: The W.P. Carey School of Business is the business school of Arizona State University./nW.P. Carey School of Business is named after one of its significant benefactors, William Polk Carey./nThe school’s alumni network consists of over 120,000 individuals in 2022 and includes several prominent people.

Term: Wrap-Around Loan: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A wrap-around loan is a form of owner-financing where the seller of a property maintains an outstanding first mortgage that is then repaid in part by the new buyer./nInstead of applying for a conventional bank mortgage, the buyer signs a mortgage with the seller, and the new loan is now used to pay off the seller's existing loan./nWrap-around loans can be risky due to the fact that the seller-financier takes on the full default risk associated with both loans.

Term: Wraparound Mortgage: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Wraparound mortgages are used to refinance a property and are junior loans that include the current note on the property, plus a new loan to cover the purchase price of the property./nWraparounds are a form of secondary and seller financing where the seller holds a securedpromissory note./nA wraparound tends to arise when an existing mortgage cannot be paid off./nWith a wraparound mortgage, a lender collects a mortgage payment from the borrower to pay the original note and provide themselves with a profit margin.

Term: What Is a Wrap Fee? Definition, How It Works, Pros, and Cons
Definition: A wrap fee is a comprehensive charge for services provided by an investment manager or advisor./nThe fee generally covers investment advice, account management, commissions, trading fees, and related expenses. It may not cover all possible fees./nWrap fees usually are 1% to 3% per year of the assets managed.

Term: Writ: Definition in Law, Types, and Examples
Definition: A writ is a formal, legal document that orders a person or entity to perform or to cease performing a specific action or deed./nWrits are drafted by courts or other entities with jurisdictional or legal power./nWarrants and subpoenas are two common types of writs.

Term: Wrap-Up Insurance: Definition, 2 Main Types, and Coverage Example
Definition: Wrap-up insurance is a liability policy that acts as all-encompassing insurance protecting contractors and subcontractors./nOwner-controlled insurance is set up by the owner of a project for the benefit of the builder or contractor to cover all listed contractors./nA contractor-controlled insurance program extends coverage to all the contractors and subcontractors signed up on the project./nBe aware that wrap-up insurance policies may have explicit exclusions./nUpon completion of the development project, the site owner will want to transition to more individual coverage as needed.

Term: Writ of Attachment: What They Are, How They Work
Definition: A writ of attachment is a court order demanding a debtor's property be seized prior to a judgment in the creditor's favor./nA writ of attachment may be used in bankruptcy cases and in eviction cases (when a tenant will not leave on their own and will not pay rent)./nIn the event that the judge rules in favor of the debtor, the property will be returned unto them./nIf the creditor instead prevails, the seized property may be sold at auction to satisfy the unpaid debts.

Term: Writ of Seizure and Sale: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A writ of seizure and sale is a court order that allows a creditor or bank to take ownership of a property from a borrower./nWrits of seizure and sale are issued when a borrower has failed to make payments on the loan for an extended period of time./nOnce the creditor has seized the property, it's usually sold at auction to help the creditor recoup some of the losses from the defaulted loan.

Term: Writ of Execution: Definition, How It's Used, and What's Excluded
Definition: A writ of execution is a court order that puts in force a judgment of possession and directs law enforcement personnel to begin the transfer of assets, money, or property as the result of a legal judgment./nThe judgment for possession states the plaintiff has a right to the property; the writ of execution actually begins the transfer process from a judgment debtor to a plaintiff./nA writ of execution may be used in bankruptcy cases and in eviction cases (when a tenant will not leave on their own and will not pay rent).

Term: Write-Down: Definition in Accounting, When It's Needed and Impact
Definition: A write down is necessary if the fair market value (FMV) of an asset is less than the carrying value currently on the books./nThe income statement will include an impairment loss, reducing net income./nOn the balance sheet, the value of the asset is reduced by the difference between the book value and the amount of cash the business could obtain by disposing of it in the most optimal manner./nAn impairment can not be deducted on taxes until the asset is sold or disposed./nIf an asset is being "held for sale," the write down will also need to include the expected costs of the sale.

Term: Option Writer: Overview of Long and Short Strategies
Definition: Option writers collect a premium in exchange for giving the buyer the right to buy or sell the underlying at an agreed price within an agreed period of time./nA put or call can be covered or uncovered, with uncovered positions carrying much greater risk./nOption writers prefer if options expire worthless and out-of-the-money, so they get to keep the entire premium. Option buyers want the options to expire in-the-money.

Term: Write-Offs: Understanding Different Types To Save on Taxes
Definition: A write-off primarily refers to a business accounting expense reported to account for unreceived payments or losses on assets./nThree common scenarios requiring a business write-off include unpaid bank loans, unpaid receivables, and losses on stored inventory./nA write-off is a business expense that reduces taxable income on the income statement./nA write-off is different from a write-down, which partially reduces (but doesn't totally eliminate) an asset's book value.

Term: What Is a Written Premium in the Insurance Industry?
Definition: Written premium is an accounting term in the insurance industry used to describe the total amount that customers are required to pay for insurance coverage on policies issued by a company during a specific period of time./nThey may be measured as a gross or net figure, which shows how much of the premiums the company gets to keep for assuming risk./nWritten premiums stand in contrast to earned premiums, which is what an insurance company actually books as earnings./nWritten premiums are the principal source of an insurance company's revenues and appear on the top line of the income statement.

Term: Writing an Option: Definition, Put and Call Examples
Definition: Traders who write an option receive a fee, or premium, in exchange for giving the option buyer the right to buy or sell shares at a specific price and date./nPut and call options for stocks are typically written in lots, with each lot representing 100 shares./nThe fee, or premium, received when writing an option depends upon several factors, such as the current price of the stock and when the option expires./nBenefits of writing an option include receiving an immediate premium, keeping the premium if the option expires worthless, time decay, and flexibility./nWriting an option can involve losing more than the premium received.

Term: Written-Down Value (WDV) What It Is and How To Calculate It
Definition: Written-down value is the value of an asset after accounting for depreciation or amortization./nDepreciation is used for physical assets while amortization is used for intangible assets./nThe present worth of a previously purchased asset is represented through its written-down value./nWritten down value appears on the balance sheet and is calculated by subtracting accumulated depreciation or amortization from the asset's original value./nWritten-down value is used to monitor the value of an asset and arrive at its price when selling.

Term: Wrongful Dishonor: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Wrongful Termination Claim: Meaning, Types, Filing
Definition: A wrongful termination claim is a lawsuit-like action that an employee files against an employer whom they feel has fired them illegally./nMost wrongful termination claims are based on a violation of state or federal laws, but they can also represent a breach of an employment contract./nTypes of wrongful termination claims can include dismissal due to discrimination, medical history, retaliation for whistleblowing/complaint filing, organizing a union, or without contractual cause./nCompensation for wrongful termination can include monetary damages and/or restoration of employment.

Term: X-Mark Signature: Requirements and Legal Challenges
Definition: An X-mark signature is made by a person who is unable to append a full signature to a document due to illiteracy or disability./nBecause of the obvious potential for fraud, doubts may arise about the validity and enforceability of documents signed with X-mark signatures./nIn the event of a legal claim against the document, the relationship of each witness to the person signing the document may be called into question.

Term: X-Efficiency: Meaning and History in Economics
Definition: X-efficiency is the degree of efficiency maintained by firms under conditions of imperfect competition such as the case of a monopoly./nEconomist Harvey Leibenstein challenged the belief that firms were always rational and called this anomaly "X" for unknown–or x-efficiency./nLeibenstein introduced the human element, arguing that there could be degrees of efficiency, meaning that–at times–firms didn't always maximize profits﻿﻿

Term: eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL): Investor's Guide
Definition: eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL) is a freely available global framework of accounting standards used for exchanging business information./nXBRL is based on XML coding and is a standardized way of transmitting financial records around the world./nThe most current version of XBRL, v2.1, was published in 2003 and has remained stable. Several optional modules exist as add-ons.

Term: XCD (Eastern Caribbean Dollar): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The Eastern Caribbean dollar (XCD) is the official currency of the Organisation of the Eastern Caribbean States (OECS), replacing the British West Indies dollar in 1965./nIt is used on the island states of Anguilla, Antigua and Barbuda, Dominica, Grenada, Montserrat, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines./nThe currency is managed by the Eastern Caribbean Bank and has been pegged to the US Dollar since 1976.

Term: XD: What it is, How it Works, Special Rules
Definition: "XD" appears as a footnote, subscript, superscript, or suffix to a ticker symbol to signify the stock is ex-dividend./nStocks trading immediately past the dividend distribution may be lower in price, by the amount of the cash dividend payout./nXD is one of many qualifiers or suffixes that can be attached to a ticker symbol to denote some status or event related to a stock.

Term: Xetra: What it is, Comparison to Other Trading Systems
Definition: Xetra is a trading technology platform operated by the Deutsche Börse Group./nLaunched in 1997, the platform accounts for more than 90% of all trading in shares at all German exchanges./nXetra was one of the first global electronic trade systems and still lists the DAX./nIt offers increased flexibility for seeing order depth within the markets, and it offers trading in stocks, funds, bonds, warrants, and commodities contracts./nTrading activity takes place between 9 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. local time Monday to Friday, except for major holidays.

Term: Xenocurrency
Definition: A xenocurrency is a currency deposited or exchanged in a market outside its country of origin./nToday, the term “eurocurrency” or “foreign currency” is more frequently used./nThese types of currency transactions have become increasingly common, driven by the globalization of supply chains and financial markets.

Term: Y: What It Means, How It Works, Examples
Definition: The letter "Y" appears at the end of a stock symbol indicating that the stock is an American depositary receipt (ADR)./nADRs, which are negotiable certificates representing shares of foreign stock, are a popular way for U.S. investors to buy stocks of companies based outside of the U.S./nA depositary bank issues the depositary receipts on behalf of the foreign corporation; these receipts can then trade on a U.S. exchange or over-the-counter just like any other share of stock./nADR prices are quoted in U.S. dollars and dividends are also paid in U.S. dollars./nY stock listings are most common on ADRs trading in over-the-counter markets, while ADRs trading on large U.S. exchanges may or may not include the letter.

Term: XRT: What It Means, How It Works, Function Of Rights
Definition: XRT is an extension printed after the ticker symbol for a stock that indicates that the stock is trading on an ex-rights basis./nEx-rights means that the buyer of the stock does not have the rights to purchase more shares at a lower price anymore because those rights have expired./nXRT is printed on the ticker tape—or displayed on the electronic ticker—for clarity and to avoid disputes or confusion about where the rights currently remain.

Term: Y-Share: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A Y-share is an institutional share class offered in open-end mutual funds—having a high minimum investment—generally $25,000 or more./nThese shares offer a limited or waived load charge or lower comparative total annual fee./nY-shares are not associated with intermediary sales charges and usually do not pay any distribution fees or 12b-1 fees from the fund’s expenses, allowing their expense ratios to be lower overall than other share classes./nWhile Y-shares are typically reserved for institutional investors, they may allow investment from retirement plan investors in some cases./nFunds without retirement share classes may allow pooled fund investments in Y-shares from retirement plans that collectively seek investment in the fund.

Term: Yacht Insurance: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: Yacht insurance provides indemnity liability coverage for a sailing vessel./nIt has two principal parts: hull insurance and protection and indemnity (P&I) insurance./nWhile there is no legal agreed upon length that separates a yacht from a pleasure boat, generally it is considered to be somewhere between 27 and 30 feet.

Term: The Truth About Y2K: What Did and Didn't Happen in the Year 2000
Definition: Y2K was commonly used to refer to a widespread computer programming shortcut that was expected to cause extensive havoc as the year changed from 1999 to 2000./nThe change was expected to bring down computer systems infrastructures, such as those for banking and power plants./nWhile there was a widespread outcry about the potential implications of this change, not much happened.

Term: Yankee Bond: What it is, How it Works, Pros and Cons
Definition: A Yankee bond is a debt obligation denominated in U.S. dollars that is publicly issued in the U.S. by foreign banks and corporation, and sometimes even governments./nYankee bonds are subject to U.S. securities laws, as they trade on U.S. exchanges./nYankee bonds offer the issuer to chance to get cheaper financing and reach a broader investment audience; they offer investors the chance for better yields./nOn the downside, Yankee bonds can take a long time to come to market, subjecting them to interest rate risk; they are also vulnerable to currency risk and other problems in their home country's economy.

Term: Yale School of Management
Definition: The Yale School of Management (Yale SOM) is Yale University's business school, located in New Haven, CT./nThe stated mission of the Yale School of Management is to educate leaders for business and society./nYale SOM offers full-time and executive MBA degrees, one year master’s degree in systemic risk, global business and society, asset management, and advanced management. It also offers Ph.D.-level study in management fields./nFor the academic year 2021-2022, the total tuition and fees are $76,770. (Tuition at Yale School of Management is $74,500. There is an additional program fee of $2,270.)/nYale School of Management is one of the smaller business schools in America, with nearly 100 faculty and roughly 350 slots in its MBA program.

Term: Yankee Certificate of Deposit (CD): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Yankee CDs are a savings vehicle marketed to larger investors./nThey are issued by foreign banks seeking to raise capital from U.S. depositors./nYankee CDs contain shorter maturity periods than regular CDs, often for less than one year. During that timeframe, customers may be unable to withdraw their funds without facing steep early withdrawal penalties.

Term: Yankee Certificate of Deposit (CD): What it Means, How it Works
Definition: Yankee CDs are a savings vehicle marketed to larger investors./nThey are issued by foreign banks seeking to raise capital from U.S. depositors./nYankee CDs contain shorter maturity periods than regular CDs, often for less than one year. During that timeframe, customers may be unable to withdraw their funds without facing steep early withdrawal penalties.

Term: Yankee Market: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: "Yankee market" is a slang term for the stock market in the United States./nRelatedly, a Yankee bond is one issued by a foreign bank or company but traded in the United States and priced in U.S. dollars./nA reverse Yankee market and reverse Yankee bond refer to U.S. companies participating in the Euro bond market.

Term: Yard: Financial Slang Term for One Billion
Definition: A "yard" is a financial slang term meaning one billion./nIt is used to avoid confusion with the words million or trillion when making a trade./nThe term is often used in currency trading./nA yard is equal to 10y-10 to the ninth power./nThe financial world uses slang in the workplace./nSomeone who buys a yard of U.S. dollars is purchasing one billion dollars.

Term: Year-End Bonus Definition, Who Gets It, When, and Why?
Definition: A year-end bonus is a form of compensation that employers pay to their employees in addition to their regular earnings./nThis type of bonus is often tied to performance metrics./nBonuses can be made in cash as lump-sum payments or in other forms, such as stocks or paid time off./nEmployers and employees may arrange to have year-end bonuses paid in the following year for tax planning purposes./nUse your bonus spend, pay off debt, or save.

Term: What Are the Chances of Dying Each Year? How to Determine
Definition: Yearly probability of dying is a statistical estimate of the likelihood of a person dying within a year, based on their age, sex, and other factors./nAn individual’s probability of dying is reflected in mortality tables and often used in setting life insurance premiums and pricing annuities./nYearly probability of living is another way of looking at the same data.

Term: Yearly Probability of Living: Meaning, Example
Definition: The yearly probability of living is a statistical measure of the likelihood of surviving through a given year./nIt is calculated using data from mortality tables./nThis measure, and others like them, are an essential part of how insurance companies set their premiums. It is also used by insurance customers to determine whether they are receiving appropriate rates.

Term: Calculating Yearly Rate Of Return: Formula and Examples
Definition: Yearly rate of return is computed by looking at the value of an investment at the end of one year and comparing it to the value to the beginning of the year./nThe rate of return for a stock includes capital appreciation and any dividends paid./nA disadvantage of the yearly rate of return is that it only includes one year and does not consider the potential for compounding over many years.

Term: Year-Over-Year (YOY): What It Means, How It's Used in Finance
Definition: Year-over-year (YOY) is a method of evaluating two or more measured events to compare the results at one period with those of a comparable period on an annualized basis./nYOY comparisons are a popular and effective way to evaluate the financial performance of a company./nInvestors seeking to gauge a company’s financial performance use YOY reporting.

Term: Year to Date (YTD): What It Means and How to Use It
Definition: YTD refers to a period of time beginning the first day of the current calendar year or fiscal year up to the current date./nSome governmental agencies and organizations have fiscal years that begin on a date other than the first of January./nYTD analysis is useful for managers when reviewing interim financial statements in comparison to historical YTD financial statements.

Term: Yearly Renewable Term Plan of Reinsurance: Meaning, How it Works
Definition: Yearly renewable term (YRT) reinsurance is when a primary insurer transfers a portion of its risk to a reinsurer./nYRT reinsurance is typically used to reinsure traditional whole life insurance and universal life insurance./nThe reinsurance premiums paid by the ceding company vary based on the policyholder's age, plan, and policy year./nThe reinsurance premiums for the amount ceded to the reinsurer renew annually.

Term: Yearly Renewable Term (YRT): What it is, How it Works
Definition: A yearly renewable term is a one-year term life insurance policy./nThe policy can be extended into future years without additional underwriting but the premium will go up each year./nWhen you buy a YRT policy, the premium quoted is for each one-year term, starting in the current year./nIf you renew for many years, you might end up paying more in premiums than if you'd bought a level term life or permanent life insurance policy./nYRTs can often be converted to other types of insurance if your needs change over time.

Term: Year's Maximum Pensionable Earnings (YMPE) Overview
