Definition: The YMPE determines the maximum earnings amount for contributions to the CPP./nThe maximum pensionable earnings under the Canada Pension Plan (CPP) for 2022 are $64,900./nThe size of those payments depends on an individual's earnings during their working years, the age an individual starts receiving their pension, and how much and for how long an individual contributes to the CPP.

Term: Yellow Knight
Definition: A yellow knight is a company that was making a hostile takeover attempt, but then backs out and proposes a merger with the target company instead./nOften, this change of heart occurs after they realize that the target is going to cost more and/or has better takeover defenses than expected./nSuddenly the yellow knight might find itself in a weak bargaining position, forcing it to walk away or propose a friendly merger as an alternative.

Term: Years Certain Annuity: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A years certain annuity is usually monthly retirement income paid for a specific number of years./nA years certain annuity is unique because it is income that is paid for a particular length of time./nIf the annuitant dies before the period ends, it is paid to the beneficiary for the remaining period.

Term: Yellow Sheets: What They are, How They Work
Definition: Yellow sheets are bulletins that inform traders about corporate bonds that are available from brokerages as over-the-counter trades./nPink sheets are the equivalent for stocks that trade over the counter./nYellow sheets and pink sheets are now electronic services published by OTC Markets Group./nBoth list securities issued by companies that are not listed on the major public exchanges.

Term: Yen ETF: Meaning, Pros and Cons, Examples
Definition: A yen ETF tracks the relative value of Japan’s currency against a basket of other currencies or a single currency./nThe ETF invests in futures contracts, debt securities, money market funds, and cash deposits, all primarily held in yen./nSome yen ETFs match the current income earned on the yen assets with a dividend yield while others use that income to pay the expenses of managing the ETF./nThere are also leveraged yen ETFs that give 2x long or short exposure to the USD/JPY movements./nThe yen has historically been considered a safe haven, meaning it is sought after by investors in times of heightened geopolitical risk.

Term: Yields in Finance Defined: Formula, Types, and What It Tells You
Definition: Yield is return on investment, expressed as a percentage./nIn stocks, dividend yield is the total annual share of a company's profit that is returned to its shareholders./nIn bonds, yield is the interest that is paid to bondholders in return for their investment./nIn mutual funds, yield is the net income of the fund.

Term: Yield-Based Option: Meaning, Types, Pros and Cons
Definition: A yield-based option allows investors to buy or sell calls and puts on the yield of a security rather than its price./nA yield-based option is a contract that gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to purchase or sell at the underlying value, which is equal to 10 times the yield./nYield-based options are extremely useful for hedging portfolios and profiting in a rising interest rate environment./nIt might be easier to get some of the benefits of yield-based options by buying options on ETFs instead.

Term: Yield Curve Risk: Overview, Types of Risk
Definition: The yield curve is a graphical illustration of the relationship between interest rates and bond yields of various maturities./nYield curve risk is the risk that a change in interest rates will impact fixed income securities./nChanges in the yield curve are based on bond risk premiums and expectations of future interest rates./nInterest rates and bond prices have an inverse relationship in which prices decrease when interest rates increase, and vice versa.

Term: Yield Curve: What It Is and How to Use It
Definition: Yield curves plot interest rates of bonds of equal credit and different maturities./nThree types of yield curves include normal, inverted, and flat./nNormal curves point to economic expansion, and downward-sloping curves point to economic recession./nYield curve rates are published on the U.S. Department of the Treasury’s website each trading day.

Term: Yield Basis: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The yield basis method quotes the price of a fixed-income security (such as a bond) as a yield percentage instead of a dollar value./nThe yield basis method helps bond buyers easily compare the characteristics of various bonds before making a purchase./nThe yield quote tells the bond trader whether the bond is currently trading at a discount or premium compared to other bonds./nPurchasing a bond on a net yield basis means the yield also includes the broker's profit or markup for executing the trade.

Term: Yield Equivalence
Definition: Yield equivalence is the interest rate on a taxable security that would generate a return equivalent to the return of a tax-exempt security, and vice versa./nYield equivalence is important to municipal bond investors, who want to know if the tax savings of their bonds will make up for the lower yields relative to similar duration taxable securities./nWhen calculating the yield equivalence between tax-free and taxable investments, investors should be aware of the current tax rates.

Term: Yield Maintenance: Definition, Formula, and How It Works
Definition: Yield maintenance is a kind of prepayment fee that borrowers pay to lenders, or bond issuers to investors, to compensate for the loss of interest resulting from the prepayment of a loan or the calling in of a bond./nYield maintenance is intended to mitigate lenders' prepayment risk, or to discourage borrowers from settling their debts ahead of schedule./nThe formula for calculating a yield maintenance premium is: Yield Maintenance = Present Value of Remaining Payments on the Mortgage x (Interest Rate - Treasury Yield).

Term: Yield on Earning Assets: What it is, How it Works
Definition: Yield on earning assets is a financial solvency ratio that compares an entity's interest income to its earning assets./nIt is a measure of how much income assets are bringing in to the firm./nA higher yield on earning assets is preferred and indicates that a company is using its assets efficiently./nA high yield on earning assets also indicates that an entity is able to meet its short-term debt obligations and is not at risk of default or insolvency./nBanks have to strike a balance between the number of loans offered, the rates charged, and the duration of the loans when compared to assets to achieve the right ratio levels./nIncreasing a low yield on earning assets would require a restructuring of an entity's pricing policy, approach to risk management, and investment strategy.

Term: Yield on Cost (YOC): Overview and Examples
Definition: YOC is a measure of dividend yield based on the original price paid for the investment./nYOC can grow significantly over time if the company regularly increases its dividend, so investing for dividend growth is the way for long-term investors to maximize YOC./nInvestors using YOC should ensure they do not compare it to other stocks' current dividend yields, as this is an apples-to-oranges comparison.

Term: Yield Spread: Definition, How It Works, and Types of Spreads
Definition: A yield spread is a difference between the quoted rate of return on different debt instruments which often have varying maturities, credit ratings, and risk./nThe spread is straightforward to calculate since you subtract the yield of one from that of the other in terms of percentage or basis points./nYield spreads are often quoted in terms of a yield versus U.S. Treasuries, or a yield versus AAA-rated corporate bonds./nWhen yield spreads expand or contract, it can signal changes in the underlying economy or financial markets./nYield spreads can come in varying types, including zero-volatility spreads, high-yield bonds spreads, and option-adjusted spreads.

Term: Yield Spread Premium: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A yield spread premium (YSP) is additional compensation paid to a mortgage broker as compensation for placing a higher-interest loan with a borrower./nAny YSP will be listed on the HUD-1 form presented at closing./nThe yield spread premium is one of many fees associated with purchasing a piece of property or home./nIn 1999, legislation was passed, designed to protect homebuyers against exorbitant yield spread premium fees./nIn 2010, the Dodd-Frank Act banned the practice of the YSP.

Term: Yield Tilt Index Fund
Definition: A yield tilt index fund invests in stocks that mirror the holdings of an index but contain a higher weighting towards high yield investments./nA yield tilt index fund enhances the yield of a standard index fund by weighting its holdings towards stocks that offer higher dividend yields./nSince a yield tilt index fund uses a baseline benchmark index, the fund is diversified, reducing the risk of loss while boosting income./nThe fund will closely track its underlying index but will not match the index identically./nInvestors considering investing in yield tilt funds should make sure they understand the tax implications and purchase the funds in the most advantageous account.

Term: Yield-to-Average Life
Definition: Yield-to-average life is the calculation of a bond's yield that is based on the average maturity rather than the stated maturity date of the issue./nYield-to-average life determines the amount of time it will take to recover one-half of a bond’s face value./nTrustees of a sinking fund bond will use the yield-to-average-life calculation to help them determine if they should re-buy some of the bonds on the open market.

Term: What Is Yield To Call? Definition and How It's Calculated
Definition: Yield to call applies to callable bonds, which are securities that allow the investors to redeem the bonds or the bond issuer to repurchase them before the bonds reach maturity./nYield to call can be mathematically calculated, using computer programs./nA bond issuer might call a bond if interest rates change, making it more cost-effective to replace the bond with a new issue that has more favorable terms./nAn investor would call a bond to cash it in and reinvest or use the principal.

Term: Yield to Maturity (YTM): What It Is and How It Works
Definition: Yield to maturity is the total rate of return earned when a bond makes all interest payments and repays the original principal./nYTM is essentially a bond's internal rate of return if held to maturity./nCalculating the yield to maturity assumes all coupon or interest payments can be reinvested at the same rate of return as the bond.

Term: Yield to Worst (YTW): What It Is and the Formula to Calculate It
Definition: Yield to worst is a measure of the lowest possible yield that can be received on a bond with an early retirement provision./nYield to worst is often the same as yield to call./nYield to worst must always be less than yield to maturity because it represents a return for a shortened investment period.

Term: Yield Variance: Meaning, Calculations, and Examples
Definition: Yield variance measures the difference between actual output and standard output of a production or manufacturing process./nIt contrasts with mix variance, which is the difference in overall material usage./nYield variance will be above or below zero if a firm overestimates or underestimates how much material it takes to generate a certain amount.

Term: Yo-Yo: What It Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: "Yo-yo" is a slang term for a very volatile market; in this type of market, security prices continually go up and down./nSecurity prices in a yo-yo market may swing from very high to reach a low point over a given period of time, making it difficult for buy and hold investors to profit./nYo-yo markets can be profitable environments for astute traders who are able to recognize buy and sell points and make trades before the market reverses./nYo-yo markets are characterized by steep up and down movements in share prices which can occur within a short timeframe—such as weeks, days, or even hours.

Term: Antwerp Rules: Meaning, Origin, When it's Used
Definition: The York Antwerp Rules are a set of maritime regulations surrounding jettisoned cargo./nThe York Antwerp Rules are a set of maritime rules dating back to 1890./nThe rules are a codification of the law of general average.

Term: Yugen Kaisha (YK): What It is, How it Works
Definition: Ayugen kaisha(YK) was a form of limited liability company once common in Japan./nAs a result of the 2005 Companies Act of Japan, theyugen kaishaform was abolished effective 2006./nYK firms were restructured as joint-stock companies known askabushiki kaisha(which themselves were later replaced bygodo gaisha).

Term: Yuppie: Definition, History, and Yuppies Today
Definition: The term yuppie originated in the 1980s and is used to refer to young urban professionals who are successful in business and considerably affluent./nSome credit writer Joseph Epstein with using the term while others point to journalist Dan Rottenberg'sChicagomagazine article./nIt is difficult to identify modern yuppies because modern society has doled out wealth to various groups of people rather than a specific set of people with similar characteristics.

Term: Z
Definition: Z is a fifth-letter identifier for Nasdaq stock symbols./nIt indicates that a stock is different from a single issue of common or capital stock./nZ might indicate that the issue is a depositary receipt, stub, additional warrant, or unit.

Term: Z-Score: Meaning and Formula
Definition: A Z-Score is a statistical measurement of a score's relationship to the mean in a group of scores./nA Z-score can reveal to a trader if a value is typical for a specified data set or if it is atypical./nIn general, a Z-score of -3.0 to 3.0 suggests that a stock is trading within three standard deviations of its mean./nTraders have developed many methods that use z-score to identify correlations between trades, trading positions, and evaluate trading strategies.

Term: Z-Bond
Definition: A Z-bond, also known as an accrual bond, is often the last bond to mature. It receives payment, which is the accrual of interest added to the principal, after all other bond classes./nA Z-bond is a type of mortgage-backed security (MBS) and the last tranche of a collateralized mortgage obligation (CMO)./nZ-Bonds are categorized as speculative investments and can be risky for investors.

Term: Z-Test Definition: Its Uses in Statistics Simply Explained With Example
Definition: A z-test is a statistical test to determine whether two population means are different or to compare one mean to a hypothesized value when the variances are known and the sample size is large./nA z-test is a hypothesis test for data that follows a normal distribution./nA z-statistic, or z-score, is a number representing the result from the z-test./nZ-tests are closely related to t-tests, but t-tests are best performed when an experiment has a small sample size./nZ-tests assume the standard deviation is known, while t-tests assume it is unknown.

Term: Z-Share: What it Means, How it Works, Example
Definition: Z-shares are the class of mutual funds that employees of the fund's management company are allowed to own./nTypically, Z-shares are offered as part of employees' benefits packages, and some employers even match the number of Z-shares purchased. They can be a valuable offering for employees considering long-term employment prospects./nWhile Z-share investors will pay the same management and miscellaneous fund expenses as other investors, Z-shares typically do not charge any front-end or back-end fees.

Term: Zacks Investment Research
Definition: Zacks Investment Research is an American company that produces independent research and investment content./nZacks was founded in 1978 by Len Zacks, a Ph.D. scholar from MIT./nZacks Research is known for its focus on earnings estimate revisions, which Len Zacks described as "the most powerful force impacting stock prices."/nThe company is known for "Zacks Ranks," stock ratings on a scale of one to five. A rank of #1 means "Strong Buy."/nIn addition to "Zacks Ranks" for stock prices, the company has also introduced ratings for mutual funds and ETFs.

Term: Z Tranche: Meaning, Pros and Cons, Example
Definition: A Z tranche is a portion of a structured financial product that only receives payments once all the other tranches have been retired./nInstead of paying interestto the Z tranche, the money is used to pay off the principal of the upper tranches faster./nWaiting for everyone else to collect first means holders of Z tranches are the most likely to come up empty./nA Z tranche is commonly used to make the tranches that come first, or the more junior tranches, seem more appealing./nA common maturity length of a Z tranche can be 20 years or more.

Term: Zacks Lifecycle Indices
Definition: Zacks Lifecycle Indices are benchmarks used to measure the relative performance of target-date funds./nTarget-date funds are pooled investments that begin with more risky investments and gradually become more conservative over time as retirement approaches./nAs such, there are several Zacks Lifecycle indexes, each with a date corresponding with the terminal date of target-date funds, typically in 10-year increments

Term: ZCash: What it is, Why it was Created, How to Mine it
Definition: ZCash is a Bitcoin fork with a different hashing algorithm and security protocols./nZCash started as Zerocash; it was later improved upon by the Electric Coin Company and rebranded ZCash./nZCash verifies ownership of coins and transactions more anonymously than Bitcoin, thus providing more security for users./nZcoin can be mined on devices and computers, but the currency is best mined on dedicated systems called application-specific integrated circuits.

Term: Zakat: The Basic Rules for One of the Five Pillars of Islam
Definition: Zakat is a religious obligation for all Muslims who meet the necessary criteria to donate a certain portion of their wealth each year to charitable causes./nIt is said to purify yearly earnings that are over and above what is required to provide individuals and their families with their essential needs./nZakat is based on income and the value of possessions./nThe common minimum amount for those who qualify is 2.5% or 1/40 of a Muslim's total savings and wealth./nNo zakat is required when someone's personal wealth falls below the threshold during a lunar year,

Term: Zero Balance Account (ZBA): Definition in Banking, and Pros and Cons
Definition: A zero balance account (ZBA) is an account in which a balance of zero is maintained by transferring funds to and from a master account./nZBAs are not consumer products but are used by larger businesses./nAn organization may have multiple zero balance subaccounts to monitor and track spending by department or project./nZBAs promote risk mitigation, as a company has greater control over where it cash balances are and what unauthorized spending may occur./nZBAs are also typically heavily automated. Though this limits clerical errors and incites operational efficiency in some ways, a business must still monitor and reconcile its bank statements.

Term: Zero Balance Card: What it is, How it Works, Example
Definition: A zero balance card is a credit card with no outstanding balance./nCustomers can maintain such cards by paying off their full balance each month, or by simply refraining to make any purchases on their cards./nMaintaining zero balance cards can help improve customers’ credit scores by helping to reduce their overall credit utilization ratio.

Term: Zero-Based Budgeting: What It Is and How to Use It
Definition: Zero-based budgeting is a technique used by companies, but this type of budgeting can be used by individuals and families./nBudgets are created around the monetary needs for each upcoming period, like a month or a year./nTraditional budgeting and zero-based budgeting are two methods used to track expenditures./nZero-based budgeting helps managers lower costs for a company.

Term: Zero Basis Risk Swap (ZEBRA)
Definition: A zero basis risk swap (ZEBRA) is an interest rate swap entered into between a municipality and a financial intermediary./nA swap is an over-the-counter (OTC) derivative where one party pays the other party a fixed interest rate and receives a floating rate./nA ZEBRA entails the municipality paying a fixed rate of interest on a specified principal amount to the financial intermediary.

Term: Zero-Beta Portfolio: Definition, Formula, Example
Definition: A zero-beta portfolio is constructed to have zero systematic risk—a beta of zero./nBeta measures an investment's sensitivity to a price movement of a specifically referenced market index./nZero-beta portfolios have no market exposure so are unlikely to attract investor interest in bull markets, since such portfolios would underperform diversified market portfolios.

Term: Zero Capital Gains Rate: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A zero capital gains rate incurs no taxation on the sales of assets or property that would otherwise have a capital gain./nA 0% rate on the sale of property is most often associated with enterprise zones, which are special areas granted special status by a government in order to encourage development and economic growth./nIn order to keep a zero capital gains rate, property owners must meet certain qualifications and requirements, which may vary among different enterprise zones.

Term: Zero-Bound: Definition, Purpose, How It Works, Example
Definition: Zero-bound is an expansionary monetary policy tool where a central bank lowers short-term interest rates to zero, if needed, to stimulate the economy./nCentral banks will manipulate interest rates to either stimulate a stagnating economy or dampen an overheating one./nThe Great Recession forced some international central banks to push the limits of zero-bound below the numerical level and implement negative rates to spur growth and spending.

Term: Zero-Bound Interest Rate: Meaning, History, Crisis Tactics
Definition: Conventional wisdom says that interest rates are "zero-bound." That is, forcing rates below zero will not stimulate economic activity./nThat's logical: Why would anyone pay to loan money?/nIn fact, rates were allowed to drift below zero in three recent crises./nThe policy may have worked, perhaps because investors sought safety.

Term: Zero-Coupon Bond: Definition, How It Works, and How To Calculate
Definition: A zero-coupon bond is a debt security instrument that does not pay interest./nZero-coupon bonds trade at deep discounts, offering full face value (par) profits at maturity./nThe difference between the purchase price of a zero-coupon bond and the par value indicates the investor's return.

Term: Zero-Cost Strategy: What it is, How it Works, Examples
Definition: A zero-cost strategy is a trading or business decision that does not entail any additional expense to execute./nZero-cost trading strategies can be used with a variety of assets and investment types including equities, commodities, and options./nA zero-cost portfolio may see an investor build a strategy based on going long in stocks expected to go up in value and short stocks expected to fall in value—a long/short strategy./nZero-cost strategies are often more flexible that allow for easily obtainable educational opportunities for a trader or business./nZero-cost strategies may also have hidden long-term costs, limited upside, or restricting diversification.

Term: Zero Cost Collar: Definition and Example
Definition: A zero cost collar strategy is used to hedge against volatility in an underlying asset's prices./nA zero cost collar strategy involves selling a short call and buying a long put that place a cap and floor on profits and losses for the underlying./nIt may not always be successful because premiums or prices of different option types do not always match.

Term: Zero-Coupon Convertible: What it is, How it Works, Pricing
Definition: A zero-coupon convertible is a convertible bond issued by a corporation that pays no regular interest to bondholders./nBecause of the zero-coupon feature, these convertibles are sold at a discount and will instead mature to face value if they are not converted prior to the maturity date./nZero-coupon convertibles before they are converted, however, still favor investors in the event of a bankruptcy as bondholders are given repayment priority ahead of shareholders./nAs a result, these two features tend to balance each other out in terms of riskiness and benefits to investors, although these securities can be quite complex to accurately price.

Term: Zero-Coupon Inflation Swap (ZCIS): Formula, Examples and Benefits
Definition: A zero-coupon inflation swap (ZCIS) is a type of inflation derivative where an income stream tied to the inflation rate is exchanged for an income stream with a fixed interest rate./nA ZCIS pays both income streams as a single lump sum when the swap reaches maturity, and the inflation level is known instead of exchanging periodic payments./nAs inflation rises, the inflation buyer receives more from the inflation seller than what they paid./nConversely, if inflation falls, the inflation buyer receives less from the inflation seller than what they paid.

Term: Zero-Coupon Certificate of Deposit (CD): What It is, How It Works
Definition: A zero-coupon CD is a type of CD that does not pay interest throughout its term./nInstead, the investor is compensated by receiving a face value upon maturity that is higher than the instrument’s purchase price./nZero-coupon CDs generally offer higher returns than traditional CDs, in order to compensate the investor for the lack of interest income.

Term: Zero-Day Attack: What it is, Markets, FAQs
Definition: A zero-day attack is a software-related attack that exploits a weakness that a vendor or developer was unaware of./nThe name comes from the number of days a software developer has known about the problem./nThe solution to fixing a zero-day attack is known as a software patch./nZero-day attacks can be prevented, though not always, through antivirus software and regular system updates./nThere are different markets for zero-day attacks that range from legal to illegal. They include the white market, grey market, and dark market.

Term: Zero-Coupon Mortgage: What It is, How it Works
Definition: Zero-coupon mortgages are long-term commercial mortgages that defer all payments of principal and interest until maturity./nInterest due rolls into the outstanding amount borrowed, which must be paid off at the expiry date or refinanced at prevailing interest rates./nCommercial projects may use zero-coupon mortgages when the cash flows needed to repay the debt aren't available until the project nears completion./nLenders usually only offer zero-coupon mortgages to established commercial borrowers that have clean credit records.

Term: Zero-Coupon Swap: What it is, How it Works
Definition: A zero-coupon swap involves the fixed side of the swap being paid in one lump sum when the contract reaches maturity./nThe variable side of the swap still makes regular payments, as they would in a plain vanilla swap./nBecause the fixed leg is paid as a lump sum, valuing a zero-coupon swap involves determining the present value of those cash flows using a zero-coupon bond's implied interest rate.

Term: Zero-Dividend Preferred Stock: What it is, Pros and Cons
Definition: Zero-dividend preferred stock is preferred stock that does not pay out a dividend./nCommon stock is still subordinate to zero-dividend preferred stock./nZero-dividend preferred stock earns income from capital appreciation and may offer a one-time lump sum payment at the end of the investment term./nIssuers benefit from zero-dividend preferred stock as it allows them to raise capital, holds no voting rights, and pays no dividend./nThere are a few advantages and disadvantages of zero-dividend preferred stock for investors.

Term: Zero-Gap Condition: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: A zero-gap condition exists when a financial institution's interest-rate-sensitive assets and liabilities are in perfect balance for a given maturity./nLarge banks must protect their current net worth, and pension funds have the obligation of payments after a number of years, so they must protect the future value of their portfolios while also addressing the uncertainty of future interest rates./nIn a zero-gap condition scenario, the duration gap—or the difference in the sensitivity of an institution's assets and liabilities to changes in interest rates—is exactly zero./nUnder this condition, a change in interest rates will not create any surplus or shortfall for the company, since the firm is immunized to its interest rate risk for a given maturity.

Term: Zero-Floor Limit: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A zero-floor limit is a policy whereby all transactions must be authorized, regardless of size./nThe zero-floor limit has become increasingly common, due to the speed of computerized payment processing systems./nZero-floor limits can help protect against fraudulent transactions, particularly in relation to relatively small purchases which might otherwise go undetected.

Term: Zero Layoff Policy: What It Is, How It Works, Examples
Definition: A zero layoff policy is a form of protection offered to employees, should the company's business decline as a result of a weakening economy./nThe policy means that employees won't be terminated due to circumstances beyond their control, such as a recession./nHowever, an employee can still be let go for poor performance, ethical violations, or behavior that would result in termination regardless of the state of the economy.

Term: Zero-Investment Portfolio: What it is, How it Works
Definition: The zero-investment portfolio is a financial portfolio that is composed of securities that cumulatively result in a net value of zero./nA zero-investment portfolio that requires no equity whatsoever is purely theoretical; a truly zero-cost investment strategy is not achievable for several reasons./nThe most important contribution of portfolio theory to our understanding of investments is that a group of stocks can earn investors a better risk-adjusted return than individual investments can; however, diversification of assets cannot eliminate risk completely.

Term: Zero-One Integer Programming Meaning and Examples
Definition: Zero-one integer programming relies on mutually exclusive yes (1) and no (0) decisions to find solutions to logic problems./nIn zero-one integer problems, each variable is represented only by 0 ('no') or 1 ('yes'), and could represent selecting or rejecting an option, turning on or off electronic switches, or a straight-forward yes or no answer used in various other applications./nThis type of programming can be useful for companies making decisions on issues like what to invest in or which of two proposed products are easiest to manufacture.

Term: Zero-Lot-Line House: Definition, Advantages, Drawbacks and Types
Definition: A zero-lot-line house is a piece of residential real estate in which the structure comes up to, or very near to, the edge of the property line./nZero-lot-line houses can be attached or detached, and are especially popular in urban areas./nNoise and proximity to neighbors can be disadvantages to zero-lot-line homes./nLow maintenance and lower prices are advantages of zero-lot-line homes.

Term: Zero Percent: What It Is, How It Works, Example
Definition: Zero percent financing is an incentive offered by retailers who wish to sell products that might otherwise be unaffordable to most consumers./nThese offers are typically limited to short periods, such as six to twelve months./nCustomers often underestimate the long-term cost of such purchases, failing to recognize that their interest rate can increase substantially after the promotional period.

Term: Zero Plus Tick: What It is, How It Works, Example
Definition: A zero tick plus is when a security has a transaction above the national best bid (uptick), and then another transaction occurs at that same price./nUp until 2007, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) had a rule stating that a stock could only be shorted on an uptick or a zero plus tick in order to prevent the destabilization of a stock./nAs of 2010, an alternate uptick rule states that if a stock has declined more than 10% that day traders may only short on an uptick. They may short freely if the stock hasn't declined by more than 10%.

Term: Zero-Rated Goods: Definition and Examples
Definition: Zero-rated goods are products that are exempt from value-added taxation (VAT)./nCountries designate products as zero-rated because they are leading contributors to other manufactured goods and a significant component of a broader supply chain./nOften, goods and services that are zero-rated are those that are considered necessary, such as food items, sanitary products, and animal feeds./nExamples of zero-rated goods include certain foods and beverages, exported goods, equipment for the disabled, prescription medications, water, and sewage services.

Term: Zero-Sum Game Definition in Finance, With Example
Definition: A zero-sum game is a situation where, if one party loses, the other party wins, and the net change in wealth is zero./nZero-sum games can include just two players or millions of participants./nIn financial markets, futures and options are considered zero-sum games because the contracts represent agreements between two parties and, if one investor loses, then the wealth is transferred to another investor./nMost transactions are non-zero-sum games because the end result can be beneficial to both parties.

Term: Zero Uptick
Definition: A zero uptick is a security purchase executed at the same price as the trade immediately preceding it, but at a price higher than the transaction before that./nA zero uptick occurs instantly when a trade is made with qualifying characteristics based on the two transactions before it./nThe qualifications of a zero tick trade include trades between buyers and sellers on security that make no change to the price of that security./nZero upticks were often used by short-sellers to meet the uptick rule./nThe uptick rule (also known as the plus tick rule) was a law established by the SEC that required every short sale transaction to be entered at a higher price than the previous trade—it was eliminated in 2007.

Term: Zero-Volatility Spread (Z-Spread) Formula and Calculation
Definition: The zero-volatility spread of a bond tells the investor the bond's current value plus its cash flows at certain points on the Treasury curve where cash-flow is received./nThe Z-spread is also called the static spread./nThe spread is used by analysts and investors to discover discrepancies in a bond's price.

Term: ZEW Indicator of Economic Sentiment: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: The ZEW Indicator of Economic Sentiment measures overall expert opinions on the direction of the German economy over the next six months./nIt is constructed based on a monthly survey of up to 350 analysts, financial professionals, and other experts./nIndicators of popular and expert opinion are widely used to gauge trends in the economy based on various economic theories and the wisdom of crowds.

Term: Zeta Model: Meaning, Formula, Significance
Definition: The Zeta Model is a mathematical model that estimates the chances of a public company going bankrupt within a certain time period./nThe Zeta Model was developed by New York University professor Edward Altman in 1968./nThe resulting Z-score uses multiple corporate income and balance sheet values to measure the financial health of a company.

Term: Zig Zag Indicator: Definition, How Pattern Is Used, and Formula
Definition: The Zig Zag indicator lowers the impact of random price fluctuations and is used to identify price trends and changes in price trends./nThe indicator lowers noise levels, highlighting underlying trends higher and lower./nThe Zig Zag indicator works best in strongly trending markets.

Term: ZK-SNARK: Definition, How It's Used in Cryptocurrency, and History
Definition: Zk-SNARK is a zero-knowledge proof protocol used in encryption and is an acronym for "Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge."/nThis proof was first developed and introduced in the late 1980s and is now employed by the cryptocurrency Zcash to solve a perceived anonymity problem with Bitcoin-type blockchains./nZk-SNARK proofs once relied on an initial "trust system" setup that was replaced in 2022 with a setup that doesn't require trust.

Term: Zombie Bank: What it Means, How it Works, Examples
Definition: A zombie bank is an insolvent financial institution that is able to continue operating thanks to explicit or implicit support from the government./nZombie banks are kept afloat to prevent panic from spreading to healthier banks./nThe termzombie bank was first coined by Edward Kane of Boston College in 1987, in reference to the savings and loan crisis (S&L)./nRestoring zombie banks back to health can cost hundreds of billions of dollars, weigh on economic growth, and prevent investors from pursuing better opportunities elsewhere.

Term: Zombie Debt: What It Means, How It Works
Definition: Zombie debt is debt that is beyond the statute of limitations for collection./nDespite this, debt collection agencies may still attempt to collect on it, in a sense bringing it back from the dead./nThere is no legal obligation to pay back zombie debt, but debt collectors can be aggressive and unscrupulous in their attempts to get people to pay.

Term: Zombie Title Definition
Definition: A zombie title is one that remains with a homeowner when a foreclosure is dismissed but the owner is unaware of the dismissal. Thus, the title remains with the homeowner unaware./nThe lender may choose not to take the title of the foreclosed property if the costs associated with selling the property (arising from unpaid taxes, liens, and penalties) or potential liability are too high, and may walk away./nZombie titles arise because a financial institution is under no obligation to take the legal title to a property in foreclosure, and may not (or may be unable to) contact the homeowner if it dismisses the foreclosure.

Term: Zombie Foreclosure: What It Is, How It Works
Definition: Zombie foreclosure is the abandonment of property by homeowners who have defaulted on their mortgage, received a foreclosure notice, and mistakenly believe that they need to vacate the premises./nThe homeowner continues to hold title to the property and is responsible for its upkeep until the foreclosure process has been completed./nA zombie foreclosure can create problems for an entire neighborhood because a vacant, unattended house can lower property values./nDuring the 2008 financial crisis that severely impacted the housing market, zombie properties were widespread across the United States.

Term: Zone Of Possible Agreement (ZOPA): Definition in Negotiating
Definition: A zone of possible agreement (ZOPA) is a bargaining range in an area where two or more negotiating parties may find common ground./nA ZOPA can only exist when there is some overlap between each party's expectations regarding an agreement./nIf negotiating parties cannot reach a ZOPA, they are in a negative bargaining zone.

Term: Zombie ETF Definition
Definition: The popularity of ETFs has led to a flood of niche offerings, some of which fail to catch on with investors./nA zombie ETF has stopped growing and taking in new money for the company that issued it./nWhen a zombie is killed off, investors in the fund get cashed out. They will owe taxes on any profits for the year in which the payout was received.

Term: Zombies: Financial Term for Distressed Companies
Definition: Zombies are companies that earn just enough money to continue operating and service their debt./nZombie companies have no excess capital to spur growth and are considered close to insolvency./nIn rare cases, a zombie company might stretch itself financially, produce a lucrative product, and reduce its liabilities./nZombies are high-risk investments, and not for the faint-hearted.

Term: Zomma: What It is, How it Works, Example
Definition: Zomma is an option's sensitivity of gamma to changes in implied volatility, where a higher zomma indicates small changes in IV translate into large changes in gamma./nIt is one of the so-called minor Greeks used to manage higher-order risk in derivative trading, most commonly in the context of options trading./nZomma is a highly abstract concept that can only be understood in relation to other measurements used to evaluate an option's risk position.

Term: Zone of Resistance: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A zone of resistance is the price range achieved when a security's price rises to a predicted near-term high, known as a support level./nA zone of resistance is an upper boundary that the stock has not previously broken through, and is the opposite range to the zone of support./nA zone of resistance provides high probability areas where a reversal or continuation of an upward trend may occur.

Term: Zone of Support: What it Means, How it Works
Definition: A zone of support is when a security's price falls to a predicted low, known as a support level./nA zone of support is a lower boundary that the stock has not previously broken through./nA zone of support provides high probability areas where a reversal or continuation of the trend may occur.

Term: Zoning Ordinance: Definition, Types of Regulations, Pros and Cons
Definition: A zoning ordinance is a rule that defines how property in specific geographic zones can be used./nZoning ordinances may also regulate lot size, placement, density, and the height of structures./nZoning rules vary greatly by region, but their most general, shared purpose is to separate residential property use from commercial property use.

Term: Zoning: What It Is, How It Works, Classification Examples
Definition: Zoning allows local governments to regulate which areas under their jurisdiction may have real estate or land used for particular purposes./nExamples of zoning classifications include residential, commercial, agricultural, industrial, or hotel/hospitality, among other more specific designations./nZoning laws can be changed by a local government as long as they fall within state and federal statutes, and a particular plot of land may be rezoned based on consideration.

Term: What Was ZZZZ Best? How the Ponzi Scheme Creator Was Caught
Definition: ZZZZ Best was a company set up as a front for a Ponzi scheme./nIts founder Barry Minkow engaged in a range of criminal acts including insurance scams and check kiting./nMinkow and his business associate Tom Padgett set up a fake company called Interstate Appraisal to defraud financial institutions out of millions./nMinkow was eventually sentenced to 25 years in prison for fraud. When released, he ended up convicted for fraud again and sentenced to five more years./nThe fraud was discovered by a woman who chased the paper trail, all due to an overcharge of only a few hundred dollars.
